webTitle: Britons fly in to help embattled UN in Sierra Leone crisis

fields.headline: Britons fly in to help embattled UN in Sierra Leone crisis
fields.standfirst: Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone's fragile peace process was nearing collapse yesterday as a team of British military specialists arrived to assess help needed by the UN peacekeepers.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone's fragile peace process was nearing collapse yesterday as a team of British military specialists arrived to assess help needed by the UN peacekeepers.

The British officers arrived in the capital, Freetown, as international efforts intensified to free more than 300 UN troops held by Revolutionary United Front rebels in the east of the country. Security officers in the capital feared the RUF was also planning a major attack after reports that the rebels had captured the town of Lunsor to the north-east of Freetown.

RUF leader Corporal Foday Sankoh 'has always believed in shooting his way to power', said Sheka Mansaray, national security adviser. 'He's consistently tested the patience of the government and international community. He's seen nothing come out of these actions. I think he's encouraged to continue to do that.'

Sankoh's forces captured the UN troops last week after battles in Kailahun, Magburaka and Makeni in the central and eastern regions. In turn, Sankoh has accused the peacekeepers of attempting to disarm his fighters by force in contravention of their mandate. But commentators in Freetown say the RUF is testing the resolve of the UN troops following the 2 May departure of Nigerian peacekeeping forces who used more robust tactics against Sankoh's fighters.

The British team arrived in Freetown yesterday to assess what extra help was needed for the beleaguered UN peacekeepers and the Sierra Leone government, which has only a few thousand teenage recruits. On 3 May the 15-member UN Security Council turned down Secretary-General Kofi Annan's request for a UN force to free the hostages and save the peace accord.

But the following day Foreign Secretary Robin Cook told Annan that Britain would do 'all it reasonably could to support the UN forces in their mission'. Much is at stake for Britain and the UN in the survival of Sierra Leone's peace accord. After the Arms to Africa saga in 1998 - uncovered by Africa Confidential and The Observer - the Sierra Leone war has become a test of Labour's foreign policy.

Britain is now the biggest contributor of development aid and funding for the peace process in Sierra Leone. Other countries have been much more sceptical about the peace accord. And for the UN, a failure in Sierra Leone has worrying echoes of the failed UN-US peacekeeping operation in Somalia in 1993. It would also jeopardise the UN's peacekeeping operation in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and make it harder to win support for interventions in Ethiopia or Sudan.

webTitle: The men who will check the weapons

fields.headline: The men who will check the weapons
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Cyril Ramaphosa,  who is to help inspect IRA weapon dumps, is a former Secretary-General of the African National Congress.
fields.body:
Cyril Ramaphosa, who is to help inspect IRA weapon dumps, is a former Secretary-General of the African National Congress.

Ramaphosa played a significant role in ending apartheid after being elected ANC Secretary-General in 1991.

He was the main negotiator in constitutional talks with the National Party and was chairman of the Constitutional Assembly responsible for drafting a permanent constitution for South Africa.

He left his post in the ANC to follow a career in business.

In 1982 he became the first General Secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers and led the members to one of the biggest strikes ever in South African history.

Martti Ahtisaari, Former Finnish President is to co-lead the inspections of the IRA weapons dumps.

Ahtisaari is used to dealing with delicate situations - he acted as the European Union envoy during the Kosovo crisis last year.

He was also a veteran United Nations diplomat and former UN Under-Secretary General before winning Finland's first direct presidential election in 1994.

As president of a non-Nato country, he was asked to be peacemaker in Kosovo by UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan.

fields.headline: The IRA statement in full
fields.trailText: 'The leadership of the IRA is committed to a just and lasting peace. We have sustained that commitment despite the abuse of the peace process by those who persist with the aim of defeating the IRA and Irish republicans.
fields.body:
'The leadership of the IRA is committed to a just and lasting peace. We have sustained that commitment despite the abuse of the peace process by those who persist with the aim of defeating the IRA and Irish republicans.

'Republicans believe that the British Government claim to a part of Ireland, its denial of national self-determination to the people of the island of Ireland, the partition of our country and the maintenance of social and economic inequality in the Six Counties are the root causes of conflict.

'The maintenance of our cessation is our contribution to the peace process and to the creation of a future in which the causes of conflict are resolved by peaceful means. For our part, the IRA leadership is committed to resolving the issue of arms.

'The political responsibility for advancing the current situation rests with the two governments, especially the British Government, and the leadership of the political parties.

'The full implementation, on a progressive and irreversible basis by the two governments, especially the British Government, of what they have agreed will provide a political context, in an enduring political process, with the potential to remove the causes of conflict, and in which Irish republicans, and unionists can, as equals pursue our respective political objectives peacefully. 'In that context the IRA leadership will initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put IRA arms beyond use. We will do it in such a way as to avoid risk to the public and misappropriation by others and ensure maximum public confidence.

'We will resume contact with the Independent International Commission on Decommissioning and enter into further discussions with the Commission on the basis of the IRA leadership's commitment to resolving the issue of arms.

'We look to the two governments and especially the British government to fulfil their commitments under the Good Friday Agreement and the Joint Statement. To facilitate the speedy and full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement and the government's measures, our arms are silent and secure. There is no threat to the peace process from the IRA.

'In this context, the IRA leadership has agreed to put in place within weeks a confidence-building measure to confirm that our weapons remain secure. The contents of a number of our arms dumps will be inspected by agreed third parties who will report that they have done so to the Independent International Commission on Decommissioning. The dumps will be re-inspected regularly to ensure that the weapons have remained silent.'

(signed) P O'Neill

webTitle: She was all things to all men - and women

fields.headline: She was all things to all men - and women
fields.standfirst: Margaret Reynolds reveals gems among the fragments in The Sappho Companion
fields.trailText: Margaret Reynolds reveals gems among the fragments in The Sappho Companion
fields.body:
The Sappho Companion
Margaret Reynolds
Chatto & Windus £25, pp352
Buy it at BOL

Poor old Sappho. Hailed by her contemporaries as a poet to rival Homer, honoured by Plato as the 'tenth muse', her verses, many of them songs of love directed at other women, filled nine books and formed part of the great libraries of the ancient world.

Then, around the turn of the second millennium, Greek playwrights and Roman poets took to lampooning her as a sensualist. She acquired a mythical lover, Phaon, for unrequited love of whom she was supposed to have made a fatal leap from the cliff of Leucadia. The papyrus rolls bearing her verses crumbled and were lost or found their way, literally, into the rubbish-heaps of history. And now, we don't even say her name properly, for though she has been called,variously, Sappho, Sapho, Saffo, Psappha, her name is, correctly, Psappho, and sounds rather startling to English ears when pronounced in the Greek - something like Ppppsappoppo.

So Margaret Reynolds tells us in the introduction to her fascinating anthology of 2,500-years' worth of Sappho-inspired fiction, art and verse. And as the book also demonstrates, the confusion over Sappho's name is entirely appropriate. For the fragmentary nature of her oeuvre, her very absence from the historical record, has rendered Sappho susceptible to reconstruction and reappropriation by an astonishing range of cultural and literary fashions.

The strength of Reynolds's anthology is its historical and cultural range. It begins with 30 of Sappho's own Fragments in Greek and translated forms, follows these up with early reworkings by Ovid and Catullus, and ends 400 pages later with a newly-minted poem, based on Fragment 96, by Ruth Padel.

The history of changing representations of Sappho is really a number of histories, not least the history of sex and gender. Any Sapphic fiction-making involves acts of impersonation and ventriloquising, but male writers in particular have been keen to speak on Sappho's behalf, generating influential models which have also been silencing and punitive, anxiously heterosexualising or lubriciously indulgent. Ovid and Pope did much to fix Sappho in her suicidal pose. Baudelaire, Swinburne and Rops, on the other hand, co-opted her for decadence and pornography.

Her reputation has had a tendency to decline as women have gained cultural and economic power; but while men have belittled her, female writers as diverse as Christine de Pisan, Madame de Staël and Olive Schreiner have made of her an icon of the persecuted female artist. She has been reborn for every era of feminism - as a bluestocking, a New Woman, a flapper.

And, of course, as a lesbian. She has always figured as a kind of lesbian archetype - 'the first Tommy the world has upon record', as they quaintly put it in the 1780s. Just as her career works as a register of changing gender politics, so it illuminates the different phases of Western lesbian identity: Sappho the eighteenth-century Tommy becomes chic and élite for Renée Vivien and Natalie Barney, and has been reconstructed more recently as a hippie swinger, a goddess-worshipper.

Inevitably, the book is a crowded one, a busy and fragmented read. But fragments are what Sappho is all about, and the clutter of the book makes its own point about the reach and rapidity, the jostling for cultural space, of changing Sapphic fashions.

Another, perhaps more serious, potential problem is that of bathos. It is a pleasure to be reminded of the spareness and sublimity of Sappho's own verse; few of the fictions inspired by it, however, are very memorable in their own right. Tellingly, it is the imagists - Pound and H.D. - with their appreciation of gaps and silences, who come off best; other big names - Southey, Coleridge, Tennyson, Townsend Warner, Woolf - are not well served. Like Elvis, Sappho's songs seem to have exerted a fatal, karaoke-like spell over subsequent artists, major and lesser: the cumulative effect of this anthology is that of a Celebrity Stars in Their Eyes in which everyone's doing the same act.

But again, that's precisely the point, and the most appropriate Sapphic impersonators of all are the ones who finish this collection - the postmodernist Sapphos of Jeanette Winterson. They are sensitive to the violence of history, to the fragmentation of their own iconography: they can 'no longer read [their] own writing'.

But they are also less like Elvis, after all, and more like Madonna, aware of the power of simulation, of reinvention, of the performativity of gender: 'We are quick-change artists we girls.' Here, then, is Sappho re- and deconstructed. You've got to wonder where and how she's going to turn up next.

webTitle: Poet paid Lottery money for free verse

fields.headline: Poet paid Lottery money for free verse
fields.trailText: Tom Paulin, the poet and television pundit, is to be awarded £75,000 of Lottery money in the biggest act of state patronage for poetry since the reign of Queen Elizabeth I.
fields.body:
Tom Paulin, the poet and television pundit, is to be awarded £75,000 of Lottery money in the biggest act of state patronage for poetry since the reign of Queen Elizabeth I.

The 51-year-old Oxford don will be one of the first recipients of a three-year fellowship from Nesta, the newly created National Endowment for Science Technology and the Arts, and he is expected to use the time the money will buy him to experiment further with free verse.

Nesta, chaired by Lord Puttnam, the film producer and Labour peer, was created in 1998 to promote talent and ideas across business and academic disciplines. Paulin, who grew up in Belfast and appeared on BBC2's popular arts programme Late Review , is the only creative writer to have been nominated as a fellow in the first round of awards.

News of his fellowship has been welcomed by the Poet Laureate, Andrew Motion, who said: 'This is a very brave move, and a new body such as Nesta has a responsibility to be brave. Tom is a fantastically deserving case, and I am a great admirer of his work.'

Motion receives only £5,000 a year for his role as laureate - along, of course, with a traditional butt of sack which, so far, has not arrived.

'Before me, the traditional payment, since Dryden's time, used to be £100 a year,' he pointed out, 'although in Dryden's time that was quite a lot of money.'

Paulin's latest and sixth book of verse, The Wind Dog, was well-received and did much to re-establish his literary talent in the face of a growing reputation as a pugnacious commentator on the arts. But not everybody was impressed with his work. Guardian reviewer Richard Potts spotted signs of self-indulgence in Paulin's playful attitudes to syntax, punctuation and language. 'At this point in his career, there's every chance he will get away with it,' Potts conceded.

The decision is unlikely to be popular with Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, whom Paulin reviled on the Late Review as a former 'alcoholic pornographer'.

Motion is robust in his defence of Paulin's talent, though. 'He is unusual among modern poets in that he is both lyrically interesting and highly intelligent,' he said.

Paulin's influence has grown since he came to notice with early collections such as Fivemiletown . He is thought to have been crucial to the success of his friend and fellow Northern Irishman Paul Muldoon's bid to become professor of poetry at Oxford University.

Paulin recently failed to obtain funding from the Leverhulme Trust for a writing project on Daniel Defoe, and was beaten in the race for the T.S. Eliot Prize for poetry. The prize went to Hugo Williams for Billy's Rain, about an unhappy extra-marital affair.

The endowment fund will be launched next week when the first grants and fellowships will be announced. At its inception two years ago the fund was handed £200 million from National Lottery proceeds on the understanding it would make annual awards from the interest. Grants of at least £10m will be made to scientists, creative people and business innovators.

fields.headline: Roth in a hard place
fields.standfirst: Sex, race and Monicagate - Philip Roth makes light work of the difficult subjects in The Human Stain
fields.trailText: Sex, race and Monicagate - Philip Roth makes light work of the difficult subjects in The Human Stain
fields.body:
The Human Stain
Philip Roth
Jonathan Cape £16.99, pp368

Indian summers don't come much more blazing than the surge in Philip Roth's literary production that stretches from Sabbath's Theater in 1995 at least as far as the last pages of this new novel. Yet while the intensity of this run of four books (the middle pair being American Pastoral and I Married a Communist) has been constant, their polarity is unpredictable. American Pastoral was very nearly as ferocious a defence of the American way of life as Sabbath's Theater had been an attack on it.

The hero of The Human Stain is Coleman Silk, classics professor at Athena College, who resigns in disgust when charged with racism - he used the word 'spooks' to refer to two students who had never turned up for class, not knowing they were black and forgetting that the word had an insulting secondary meaning. Subsequently, he starts an affair with Faunia Farley, a functionally illiterate faculty janitor and part-time farmhand with a history of deprivation and suffering. She is 34 and he is 71.

There is a scattering of Hawthorne references (Faunia's name presumably one), but this is more than a recasting of The Scarlet Letter, in emulation of Updike's Roger's Version. From the outside, the liaison seems exploitative to the very edge of abuse - what could he find in a woman like that to treat with respect? - when in fact 'their coupling is the drama into which they decant all the angry disappointment of their lives'. The relationship becomes public while another scandal is breaking in its own slow-motion fashion - the President and what he did or did not do with Monica Lewinsky.

The national mood, as well as the local, is an 'ecstasy of sanctimony', though an obsession with purity is a perversion in its own right. At the high-water mark of Monicagate, the narrator dreams of a giant banner wrapped round the White House, in the manner of the artist Christo, bearing the message 'A Human Being Lives Here'. Was there any more to the scandal than that?

The listing of the author's previous works breaks them down intriguingly into categories. Sabbath's Theater falls under the lowly heading 'other books', while The Human Stain and its two immediate predecessors qualify as 'Zuckerman books' by virtue of sharing a narrator (there are also 'Roth books' and 'Kepesh books'). Roth's output for a decade and more was preoccupied with alter egos and decoys, self-referential games that had rapidly diminishing returns for everyone, it seemed, but the author, frowning contentedly in his hall of mirrors.

The reflexiveness of The Human Stain is more functional. Nathan Zuckerman, a novelist living reclusively, nevertheless befriends Coleman Silk and hears some of his confidences. Zuckerman is a usefully contrasting figure, having retired from the erotic arena even before a prostate operation interrupted his functioning, but for most of the book he recedes to a vanishing point.

We forget, when Coleman regrets having fed 'that great opportunistic maw, a novelist's mind', that the self-reproaching thought is phrased by Zuckerman himself. The internal topology of the book is paradoxical and satisfying, like that mysterious, self-violating shape, the Klein bottle, an impossible object which challenges our ideas of inside and outside, surface and edge.

Towards the end of the book, Zuckerman becomes more intrusive - we learn that he is writing a book about Coleman Silk called The Human Stain - and that he'll have to move away from the area, for his own safety, before it's published. One extended passage, from Faunia's point of view, and containing the title phrase ('Impurity, cruelty, abuse, error, excrement, semen - there's no other way to be here'), seems awkwardly interjected, for once, out of the preoccupations of narrator or author.

Yet the great thrill of the book is Roth's ability to fill his creatures, up to their ears and beyond, with their own vitality. Faunia comes alive in a long passage about her love for crows, her brutal ex-husband in a 10-page scene in a Chinese restaurant, where he is being helped by a support group of fellow Vietnam War vets to get through a meal without killing the waiters. It's a sort of home-grown therapy.

The initial situation of the book seems a little pat - the irresponsible accusation of racism inviting the conclusion that political correctness is the deeper problem. The patness turns out to be entirely deceptive and the book takes on the issue of race in America as seriously as a novel ever has. Still more impressive, because structurally unnecessary and thrown in for the sheer exhilaration of it, is a portrait of a French woman academic, career flirt and dispenser of all the right jargon, trying to draft a personal ad to appear in the New York Review of Books. Roth has learnt how to build up lovingly from inside what he despises in the abstract.

In the years since Portnoy's Complaint, Roth's writing has explored a harsh, borderline, nihilistic notion of sex. His carnal philosophy is comfortless but cogent, seeing desire not as a search for wholeness but as the force that disrupts the artificial unity we make of our experience - 'the redeeming corruption that de-idealises the species and keeps us everlastingly mindful of the matter we are'.

It's puzzling, then, that Roth or Zuckerman should be so surprised by the 'tyranny of propriety' and the prurient reaction to Monicagate. In the opening pages of the book, he comes close to moralising about moralising, preaching a sermon against sermons. If sex was simply recreation, then it would be grotesque for people to rail against it so much. But puritans actually agree with novelist or narrator in seeing it as an inherently transgressive drive.

The Clinton references wouldn't be missed, if Roth had decided against them. But it's hardly a crushing criticism of this mighty novel to suggest that it connects more vitally with its other recurring reference point - Greek tragedy - than with the headlines of 1998. The dark sun of his gifts shines on.
fields.bodyText: The Human Stain Philip Roth Jonathan Cape £16.99, pp368 Indian summers don't come much more blazing than the surge in Philip Roth's literary production that stretches from Sabbath's Theater in 1995 at least as far as the last pages of this new novel. Yet while the intensity of this run of four books (the middle pair being American Pastoral and I Married a Communist) has been constant, their polarity is unpredictable. American Pastoral was very nearly as ferocious a defence of the American way of life as Sabbath's Theater had been an attack on it. The hero of The Human Stain is Coleman Silk, classics professor at Athena College, who resigns in disgust when charged with racism - he used the word 'spooks' to refer to two students who had never turned up for class, not knowing they were black and forgetting that the word had an insulting secondary meaning. Subsequently, he starts an affair with Faunia Farley, a functionally illiterate faculty janitor and part-time farmhand with a history of deprivation and suffering. She is 34 and he is 71. There is a scattering of Hawthorne references (Faunia's name presumably one), but this is more than a recasting of The Scarlet Letter, in emulation of Updike's Roger's Version. From the outside, the liaison seems exploitative to the very edge of abuse - what could he find in a woman like that to treat with respect? - when in fact 'their coupling is the drama into which they decant all the angry disappointment of their lives'. The relationship becomes public while another scandal is breaking in its own slow-motion fashion - the President and what he did or did not do with Monica Lewinsky. The national mood, as well as the local, is an 'ecstasy of sanctimony', though an obsession with purity is a perversion in its own right. At the high-water mark of Monicagate, the narrator dreams of a giant banner wrapped round the White House, in the manner of the artist Christo, bearing the message 'A Human Being Lives Here'. Was there any more to the scandal than that? The listing of the author's previous works breaks them down intriguingly into categories. Sabbath's Theater falls under the lowly heading 'other books', while The Human Stain and its two immediate predecessors qualify as 'Zuckerman books' by virtue of sharing a narrator (there are also 'Roth books' and 'Kepesh books'). Roth's output for a decade and more was preoccupied with alter egos and decoys, self-referential games that had rapidly diminishing returns for everyone, it seemed, but the author, frowning contentedly in his hall of mirrors. The reflexiveness of The Human Stain is more functional. Nathan Zuckerman, a novelist living reclusively, nevertheless befriends Coleman Silk and hears some of his confidences. Zuckerman is a usefully contrasting figure, having retired from the erotic arena even before a prostate operation interrupted his functioning, but for most of the book he recedes to a vanishing point. We forget, when Coleman regrets having fed 'that great opportunistic maw, a novelist's mind', that the self-reproaching thought is phrased by Zuckerman himself. The internal topology of the book is paradoxical and satisfying, like that mysterious, self-violating shape, the Klein bottle, an impossible object which challenges our ideas of inside and outside, surface and edge. Towards the end of the book, Zuckerman becomes more intrusive - we learn that he is writing a book about Coleman Silk called The Human Stain - and that he'll have to move away from the area, for his own safety, before it's published. One extended passage, from Faunia's point of view, and containing the title phrase ('Impurity, cruelty, abuse, error, excrement, semen - there's no other way to be here'), seems awkwardly interjected, for once, out of the preoccupations of narrator or author. Yet the great thrill of the book is Roth's ability to fill his creatures, up to their ears and beyond, with their own vitality. Faunia comes alive in a long passage about her love for crows, her brutal ex-husband in a 10-page scene in a Chinese restaurant, where he is being helped by a support group of fellow Vietnam War vets to get through a meal without killing the waiters. It's a sort of home-grown therapy. The initial situation of the book seems a little pat - the irresponsible accusation of racism inviting the conclusion that political correctness is the deeper problem. The patness turns out to be entirely deceptive and the book takes on the issue of race in America as seriously as a novel ever has. Still more impressive, because structurally unnecessary and thrown in for the sheer exhilaration of it, is a portrait of a French woman academic, career flirt and dispenser of all the right jargon, trying to draft a personal ad to appear in the New York Review of Books. Roth has learnt how to build up lovingly from inside what he despises in the abstract. webTitle: The old devil has all the best letters

fields.headline: The old devil has all the best letters
fields.standfirst: The Letters of Kingsley Amis are a huge and enjoyable read
fields.trailText: The Letters of Kingsley Amis are a huge and enjoyable read
fields.body:
The Letters of Kingsley Amis
edited by Zachary Leader
HarperCollins £24.99, pp608
Buy it at BOL

The Letters of Kingsley Amis is a hugely entertaining book - and I mean hugely. Anyone confronting it can either resolve to do nothing else for several months and read it through or keep it indefinitely for dipping into, several pages at a time. Either would be worthwhile.

The events of Kingsley Amis's life are no secret. He was a scholarship boy at City of London School and an exhibitioner at Oxford, where he joined the Communist Party and met Philip Larkin, his lifelong friend. He was an officer in Signals till the end of the war, then went back to Oxford ('the nice thing about Oxford is that its vessels of corruption are always being replenished').

He married Hilly Bardwell when they decided an abortion was too risky, this being 1948, and later had two more children, including the novelist Martin. He got a job teaching English in what he calls Swonzy ('so handy for the National Scheissbedsodd').

After Lucky Jim appeared in 1954, his career took off; he won prizes, and eventually a fellowship at Peterhouse, Cambridge, which he gave up when he was able to live entirely from his writing. His stormy marriage to Hilly ended when, after heaven knows how many affairs on both sides, he fell in love with Elizabeth Jane Howard and married her in 1965. After Jane left him in 1980, Hilly moved back with her third husband to run the household, an unlikely arrangement that seemed to work well. Kingsley was knighted in 1990 and died in 1995, still brilliant, still insufferable, still drinking, by then an excessively right-wing, misogynistic, old curmudgeon.

The best of the letters are the early ones to Larkin, when he is pouring out his rages and frustrations and views - endless views - about jazz and women and poetry and those who don't use English properly; about his detested father-in-law ('wearing a beret, looking like a French instituteur cashiered for offences against minors') and Wales ('Llgo andw ghet stwft, iu stwpydd olld swd'). These letters rollick along, adorned with rude drawings and often very funny spoofs of serious poems, spewing venom, lunacy and bawdiness in equal amounts.

His denunciations, however unreasonable, are hypnotising. Since his hatreds included, apart from 'Pikarso', Chaucer, Milton, Dryden, Keats, Shelley, Beowulf ('I refer of course to the anonymous, crass, purblind, infantile featureless HEAP OF GANGRENED ELEPHANT SPUTUM, Barewolf'), Virginia Woolf, Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath, Waugh, Hugo, James and Dickens, it's a wonder that he managed to teach Eng Lit at all.

Kingsley deplored Gerard Manley Hopkins for trying to write poetry as if it was a musical score, but he himself played the typewriter like a jazz piano, pounding, improvising, breaking into capitals, repeating phrases or abbreviations over and over for whole lines (bw for boogie woogie bw bw bw bw bw bw) using spellings to imitate speech ('Thank you for your mewst amewsing card'), fulminating after a typing error in a splutter of consonants; signing off with phrases like 'Kingsley hamfat', 'Kingsley ikonoklastes'.

With Larkin, he seemed completely uninhibited; but they were less in touch during the Sixties, and though letters to Robert Conquest filled the gap to some extent, on the whole his letters become more decorous and duller, except when he was firing broadsides at newspapers - 'Not all standards have been fully lowered everywhere,' he wrote to The Observer, 'but your fashionable brand of sentimental mercy will hasten the process' - or writing lyrical love letters to Howard: 'I like women more than I did through being your lover.'

Once success struck, he had dozens of other outlets for writing: novels, of course, articles, reviews, spoofs, poems, a thriller. He selected science fiction, wrote about wine and was briefly poetry editor of the Daily Mirror; he finished a James Bond after Ian Fleming's death. But the letters do have the strong flavour of their times and are always readable; they excellently chart his progress from angry young man and left-wing iconoclast to fulminating Garrick Club grandee.

I didn't know Amis well, and nothing in the letters makes me wish I'd known him better, but I doubt if the publication of these letters will diminish his reputation as the publication of Philip Larkin's letters did his. Maybe, expecting something loftier from poets, we resent their grubbier aspects more; Kingsley's letters, though, reflect exactly the same personality as his books: irascible, brilliant, rude, moving and exceedingly funny.

Zachary Leader not only gives us essential footnotes but follows up everything: he can't mention that a phrase is borrowed from a jazz record without explaining which band played it and when. The treatment does nudge one toward asking whether Amis, as a novelist, really rates this kind of exalted attention?

In my view, he does. Kingsley Amis was that rarity, a man feted for being exactly on the pulse of his time - the Angry Young Man of the Fifties, casting a clear, disgusted eye on all that seemed most loved in British life - who, nevertheless, stayed the course as a novelist.

But history will decide whether he deserves the Valhalla treatment. Doubtless, there will be an iconoclastic student in the year 3000 distorting cyberspace to denounce him. In the meantime, if you can lift it, enjoy this book.

fields.headline: Letters from an old devil
fields.standfirst: Kingsley Amis was one of the century's most prolific letter writers, so editing his correspondence was never going to be easy. Zachary Leader describes the perils and pleasures of the job - and how he got it by playing tennis with Martin Amis
fields.trailText: Kingsley Amis was one of the century's most prolific letter writers, so editing his correspondence was never going to be easy. Zachary Leader describes the perils and pleasures of the job - and how he got it by playing tennis with Martin Amis
fields.body:
Editing the letters of Kingsley Amis has been the single most enjoyable job of my life - but it has not been without difficulties. Within three days of Amis's death, his friend and biographer Eric Jacobs offered his unexpurgated diary of the novelist's last year or so to two Sunday newspapers. This diary included intimate details of Amis's final illness and debilitation as well as hurtful private remarks about close relations.

The family was outraged, and though Jacobs agreed to withdraw the diaries from serialisation (only temporarily, as it turned out), he had lost its trust. As a consequence, he also lost the job of editing the letters, an appointment Amis himself had approved. Wounded, Jacobs rounded on Martin Amis, the family's spokesman, and later, after Martin announced that I was to take his place, on me. 'The curiously named Zachary Leader,' he wrote to one of Amis's correspondents, would be getting no help from him.

Martin chose me because we were friends, he'd read my work (which partly discusses editorial procedures and principles), and we saw each other weekly, to play tennis; so the inevitable hassles I'd subject him to as a researcher - about dates, biographical details, identifications - could be woven into a weekly routine, after play. Martin himself was working on his memoirs (to be published, wholly fortuitously, within days of the letters), and, after a while, the post-tennis queries ran both ways.

That we had each recently re-read his father's novels and poems meant we could also consult about elusive quotations and obscure literary allusions. It was a great way to work, especially since I was given free rein to print whatever letters I wanted (excepting a handful of letters containing wounding passages about relatives). Nothing Amis wrote about Martin himself was censored, nor, I should add, did anything in the letters ever shake Martin's confidence in his father's affection.

I began immediately with the job of collection - less arduous in a selected correspondence than a complete one. Soon after I started, I was given Amis's last address book and wrote in search of letters to everyone listed in it. I also tried to contact all possible recipients mentioned in the Memoirs (1991), in Jacobs's biography (1995), and present at the memorial meeting for Amis held at St Martin-in-the-Fields on 22 October 1996.

A number of interesting letters, mostly to fans (Amis was scrupulous about answering fan mail), resulted from requests for correspondence, or information about correspondence, placed in British and American newspapers and literary periodicals. I also found important letters to fellow writers in over 20 university libraries and research institutes.

Though laborious, the search was unanxious. From the start it was clear how rich the core of the book would be and where I would find it: in the Bodleian Library in Oxford, where Philip Larkin had deposited 531 previously unpublished Amis letters, and in Robert Conquest's garage in Palo Alto, California, where more than 100 letters were carefully stored in a cardboard box. Everything else I found - in public and private collections, the archives of publishers, editors, agents, critics, radio and television companies and newspapers - would be gravy.

Choosing which letters to print, from a trawl of several thousand, was more difficult, though my criteria of selection were straightforward. When two letters made the same general points, observations, jokes, or transmitted the same news, I chose what I thought the stronger or livelier letter. My aim was to print letters from all periods of Amis's life and to a range of his correspondents. As well as letters to friends and fellow writers (including John Betjeman, Anthony Powell, Edith Sitwell, C.P. Snow, John Wain and others), I also included a number of business letters. From the time he resigned his Fellowship in English at Peterhouse, Cambridge, in 1963, Amis supported himself and his family as a novelist and freelance writer. The letters show how he did it.

Amis's correspondence with women posed several problems. When Jacobs asked Amis who he thought might have letters, Amis replied 'women', adding immediately, in Jacobs's reconstruction (recorded in a note in the Huntington Library in California), 'that the trouble with that was that I might find some, then he would not want them published - for whatever reason - and then the women in question might be upset'.

The only such letters I print were written to Amis's second wife, the novelist Elizabeth Jane Howard. Hilly Amis (Lady Kilmarnock), his first wife, burned all his letters in 1963, the year their marriage collapsed. Though she does not remember how many there were, the figure must have been high. When they were separated for a month in October 1949 (Amis had just taken up a lectureship in English at Swansea), he wrote daily.

The letters to Hilly that survive, those written after 1963, are mostly notes about money and arrangements for the children. They are chastened, considerate, affectionate, but in no way communicate the depth of his feelings for her over the years. After the break-up of his second marriage, Amis became clearer (or at least more public) about Hilly's importance to him: leaving her, he claimed, was the single biggest mistake of his life. In the fiction, the biographical writings, and the poetry, his feelings for her are carefully pondered; in the extant letters they figure only rarely, or in passing, though when they do appear the writing takes on a special intensity.

Amis's feelings for Jane Howard, in contrast, are amply documented. As the letters she released to me show, he deeply loved her in the early years of their relationship. Gradually, however, as other letters reveal, he drew apart from her during their marriage, and he detested her after their break-up, with a ferocity as obvious in the correspondence as in the (related) misogyny of the later fiction. None of the letters I have seen to her are anything but warm and loving; but I have seen no letters from the period after she left him.

As for Amis's supposed hatred of women, though much of what he writes about them in the correspondence will be deplored, his love letters are warm, tender, even abject in their expression of feeling. Nor was he always rude to, or bored with, women he didn't want to sleep with, even feminists. In 1987, the English academic Jan Montefiore wrote to Amis for permission to quote eight lines from his poem 'A Bookshop Idyll', which she criticises in her book Feminism and Poetry. Amis responded as follows:

'Dear Miss Montefiore,

I have written to Candida Lacey giving permission for the inclusion of 8 lines from my poem 'A Bookshop Idyll' in your forthcoming monograph.

But please let me say that your interpretation of the poem is, I think, misguided. I really don't suggest (nor is it my opinion) that the love-poem is a quintessentially female mode; I was trying to make a more general point that women are less inhibited about expressing their feelings than men are, at any rate in our society. And though I'm pleased you think the poem good-natured, surely the people it patronises are not women but men, who cut a pretty sorry figure in the last verse [The last verse reads: 'Women are really much nicer than men, / No wonder we like them. / Deciding this, we can forget those times / We sat up half the night / Chockful of love, crammed with bright thoughts, names, rhymes, / And couldn't write'].

All the same, I wish you the best of luck with your undertaking, and hope you are suitably enthusiastic about that great heroine of mine, Christina Rossetti.

Yours sincerely,

Kingsley Amis'

Montefiore was amazed at the amiable tone of Amis's reply: 'As you can see he really couldn't have been nicer... and it's not as if I'd ever been introduced to him or to his son, or anything like that, so he wasn't doing me a personal favour, he was just being a decent liberal - unlike his agent who wanted to withhold permission because I'd been uncomplimentary.'

Though I have found and print similarly generous and fair-minded letters, no one will be surprised to discover that the correspondence is littered with malicious, intemperate remarks about just about everybody Amis knew, Larkin and Hilly excepted.

All I can say to those of Amis's friends and acquaintances who find themselves insulted or belittled in the letters is 'You're not alone'. Which is also what I'd say to maligned authors. That Amis admits to finding it hard to finish Martin's novels puts the son in good company; he also had trouble, the letters reveal, with Proust, Joyce, Lawrence, Updike, Bellow, and Nabokov. Towards the end of his life, he told Martin, the only books he could finish were thrillers, the sort that began 'A shot rang out' or 'A scream rent the air'.

The most difficult of the problems I faced in choosing letters concerned the feelings of their recipients, as of others Amis disparages. Early in my work I was offered a sheaf of letters by an American academic who had written several books on Amis. These letters stretch over 17 years and are mostly warm and affectionate, though in later letters there are glimmers of irritation.

Amis had taken this man to lunch, met his wife and son, had him to his house, introduced him to his friends, and written letters of reference for him. But he had also, I discovered, written a letter the man did not show me. A photocopy of this letter was found among Amis's papers after his death and offers a damning verdict on the first three chapters of the man's most recent work, a study of Amis's fiction. Here are its concluding paragraphs:

'It is not that I find what you have written offensive in any way, or improper to its subject. It is that the level of your performance seems to me to be so low as not to earn a place on any publisher's list.

Please realise that no imaginable rewriting would rectify the situation. The fact that I have left many passages of your typescript unmarked testifies to my weariness and boredom with them, not to their correctness or adequacy.

I think it would be best if the book were to be withdrawn.

Yours, Kingsley'

I thought long and hard before publishing this letter - it was the single most difficult decision I faced in the selection process. In the end, though, I decided to include it, for several reasons: Amis's literary executors had already deposited the photocopy at the Huntington, so it was available to other scholars; it shows an important side of Amis - how ferocious he could be in his later years; it says something about his willingness to sacrifice personal feelings for what he seems to have seen as the welfare of his reputation as a writer; and not printing the letter would have left readers with a false or partial understanding of the relations between the two men.

When informed of my decision the academic wrote that he understood, without being much pleased, adding that he remained baffled by Amis's sudden turn: 'It contradicts everything he communicated to me in person and in letters over the previous 17 years.'

The business of annotating the letters, the third phase of my job as editor, could be fiendishly difficult, especially when dealing with letters to Larkin. These letters, the most brilliant in the book, are filled with private jokes, allusions, obscure abbreviations, associational leaps and word games.

Most books, records, poems and songs, for example, are referred to by the first and last words in their titles, as in 'A Time' for A Dance to the Music of Time. Some are identified by the first letters, or first few letters, of their first and last words, as in 'GB' for 'Goodbye to Berlin,' or 'Appara' (an editor's nightmare this) for 'Appointment in Samarra.' Often the letters proceed associationally: 'I love the persistent mis-spelling of authors' names,' declares Amis in a letter of 25 May 1947, 'it's amazing how it lowers the tome wainsh the tone. Talking of Wainsh [ie John Wain]...'

Misspellings are of several sorts. Some derive from typos (all of which have been retained, even when most obvious), as in 'tome' for 'tone,' 'teh' for 'the,' or 'thiknign' for 'thinking' (which to Amis 'sounds really extraordinary - a character in Ibsen? Pastor Thiknign?'); others are laboriously crafted, as in 'methsleeves' for 'themselves,' or 'darts B.A.' for 'bastards.' Then there are phonetic spellings, often parodies of the sort of prim, suburban pronunciation mocked in the fiction: 'ab8' for 'about', 'hay' for 'how', 'refained' for 'refined', as in Chapter 4 of Lucky Jim, where Margaret comments of Christine after their first meeting: 'Pity she's so refained, though.'

Often I could only make sense of puzzling passages by reading the letters to which they responded. In this way I learned, for example, the identity of 'Bluebell' (Robert Conquest's dog) or 'engine driver Hunt', from a passage in a letter reading 'Praed, Hood, Gilbert - and engine driver Hunt' (Hunt turns out to be a subject, not an author, of light verse, from the pseudonymous Conquest limerick beginning 'A young engine driver called Hunt'), or the meanings of the abbreviations PWR, IWICSLMSK and BHQ (respectively, Pee-Wee Russell, 'I Wish I Could Shimmy Like My Sister Kate' and 'Bastard Headquarters', meaning God's Heaven, or, more generally, the place where things go wrong or get fucked up, said in one letter to be located in France).

The most fiendish of the puzzles I encountered in the correspondence occurs in a letter to Larkin of 22 March 1982. Amis had broken his leg ('standing up, trying to avoid an alcoholic fall') and was recuperating in the Kinnell Ward of the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead:

'There's an old woman here who sings all day. Wordless maunderings based on Camptown Races... Yes, all day. She's French, actually. Do you remember about Kinnell or Kinell? Used to be (milite) the more proper of a pair, the other being Kinarsoles.'

It was Denis Norden, an exact contemporary of Amis's at the City of London School, who explained to me the meaning of this passage. 'Milite' (Latin) I could get myself; in this context it means 'in military parlance'. 'Kinnell' or 'Kinell', Norden explained, are short for 'Fuckin'ell,' to go with 'Fuckin'arsoles.' Of the pair, then, 'Kinnell' is 'the more proper'. Presto! The critic P.N. Furbank then supplied a related marching song, one line of which runs 'Arsehole, arsole, a soldier of the King'. Such are the intricacies of scholarship.

One passage defeated me. In a letter of 27 August 1950 Amis calls Larkin 'my inner audience', my watcher in Spanish, the reader over my shoulder.' 'Inner audience' is clear enough and 'reader over my shoulder' comes from Robert Graves, but what is a 'watcher in Spanish'? Spanish has no equivalent of 'inner audience' or 'reader over my shoulder' involving the word 'watcher' (or spectator, observer, onlooker). No such term appears in the dictionaries of quotation or in Amis's B.Litt thesis (with its discussion of the role of the 'inner audience' in poetic composition).

fields.bodyText: Editing the letters of Kingsley Amis has been the single most enjoyable job of my life - but it has not been without difficulties. Within three days of Amis's death, his friend and biographer Eric Jacobs offered his unexpurgated diary of the novelist's last year or so to two Sunday newspapers. This diary included intimate details of Amis's final illness and debilitation as well as hurtful private remarks about close relations. The family was outraged, and though Jacobs agreed to withdraw the diaries from serialisation (only temporarily, as it turned out), he had lost its trust. As a consequence, he also lost the job of editing the letters, an appointment Amis himself had approved. Wounded, Jacobs rounded on Martin Amis, the family's spokesman, and later, after Martin announced that I was to take his place, on me. 'The curiously named Zachary Leader,' he wrote to one of Amis's correspondents, would be getting no help from him. Martin chose me because we were friends, he'd read my work (which partly discusses editorial procedures and principles), and we saw each other weekly, to play tennis; so the inevitable hassles I'd subject him to as a researcher - about dates, biographical details, identifications - could be woven into a weekly routine, after play. Martin himself was working on his memoirs (to be published, wholly fortuitously, within days of the letters), and, after a while, the post-tennis queries ran both ways. That we had each recently re-read his father's novels and poems meant we could also consult about elusive quotations and obscure literary allusions. It was a great way to work, especially since I was given free rein to print whatever letters I wanted (excepting a handful of letters containing wounding passages about relatives). Nothing Amis wrote about Martin himself was censored, nor, I should add, did anything in the letters ever shake Martin's confidence in his father's affection. I began immediately with the job of collection - less arduous in a selected correspondence than a complete one. Soon after I started, I was given Amis's last address book and wrote in search of letters to everyone listed in it. I also tried to contact all possible recipients mentioned in the Memoirs (1991), in Jacobs's biography (1995), and present at the memorial meeting for Amis held at St Martin-in-the-Fields on 22 October 1996. A number of interesting letters, mostly to fans (Amis was scrupulous about answering fan mail), resulted from requests for correspondence, or information about correspondence, placed in British and American newspapers and literary periodicals. I also found important letters to fellow writers in over 20 university libraries and research institutes. Though laborious, the search was unanxious. From the start it was clear how rich the core of the book would be and where I would find it: in the Bodleian Library in Oxford, where Philip Larkin had deposited 531 previously unpublished Amis letters, and in Robert Conquest's garage in Palo Alto, California, where more than 100 letters were carefully stored in a cardboard box. Everything else I found - in public and private collections, the archives of publishers, editors, agents, critics, radio and television companies and newspapers - would be gravy. Choosing which letters to print, from a trawl of several thousand, was more difficult, though my criteria of selection were straightforward. When two letters made the same general points, observations, jokes, or transmitted the same news, I chose what I thought the stronger or livelier letter. My aim was to print letters from all periods of Amis's life and to a range of his correspondents. As well as letters to friends and fellow writers (including John Betjeman, Anthony Powell, Edith Sitwell, C.P. Snow, John Wain and others), I also included a number of business letters. From the time he resigned his Fellowship in English at Peterhouse, Cambridge, in 1963, Amis supported himself and his family as a novelist and freelance writer. The letters show how he did it. Amis's correspondence with women posed several problems. When Jacobs asked Amis who he thought might have letters, Amis replied 'women', adding immediately, in Jacobs's reconstruction (recorded in a note in the Huntington Library in California), 'that the trouble with that was that I might find some, then he would not want them published - for whatever reason - and then the women in question might be upset'. The only such letters I print were written to Amis's second wife, the novelist Elizabeth Jane Howard. Hilly Amis (Lady Kilmarnock), his first wife, burned all his letters in 1963, the year their marriage collapsed. Though she does not remember how many there were, the figure must have been high. When they were separated for a month in October 1949 (Amis had just taken up a lectureship in English at Swansea), he wrote daily. The letters to Hilly that survive, those written after 1963, are mostly notes about money and arrangements for the children. They are chastened, considerate, affectionate, but in no way communicate the depth of his feelings for her over the years. After the break-up of his second marriage, Amis became clearer (or at least more public) about Hilly's importance to him: leaving her, he claimed, was the single biggest mistake of his life. In the fiction, the biographical writings, and the poetry, his feelings for her are carefully pondered; in the extant letters they figure only rarely, or in passing, though when they do appear the writing takes on a special intensity. Amis's feelings for Jane Howard, in contrast, are amply documented. As the letters she released to me show, he deeply loved her in the early years of their relationship. Gradually, however, as other letters reveal, he drew apart from her during their marriage, and he detested her after their break-up, with a ferocity as obvious in the correspondence as in the (related) misogyny of the later fiction. None of the letters I have seen to her are anything but warm and loving; but I have seen no letters from the period after she left him. As for Amis's supposed hatred of women, though much of what he writes about them in the correspondence will be deplored, his love letters are warm, tender, even abject in their expression of feeling. Nor was he always rude to, or bored with, women he didn't want to sleep with, even feminists. In 1987, the English academic Jan Montefiore wrote to Amis for permission to quote eight lines from his poem 'A Bookshop Idyll', which she criticises in her book Feminism and Poetry. Amis responded as follows: 'Dear Miss Montefiore, I have written to Candida Lacey giving permission for the inclusion of 8 lines from my poem 'A Bookshop Idyll' in your forthcoming monograph. But please let me say that your interpretation of the poem is, I think, misguided. I really don't suggest (nor is it my opinion) that the love-poem is a quintessentially female mode; I was trying to make a more general point that women are less inhibited about expressing their feelings than men are, at any rate in our society. And though I'm pleased you think the poem good-natured, surely the people it patronises are not women but men, who cut a pretty sorry figure in the last verse [The last verse reads: 'Women are really much nicer than men, / No wonder we like them. / Deciding this, we can forget those times / We sat up half the night / Chockful of love, crammed with bright thoughts, names, rhymes, / And couldn't write']. All the same, I wish you the best of luck with your undertaking, and hope you are suitably enthusiastic about that great heroine of mine, Christina Rossetti. Yours sincerely, Kingsley Amis' Montefiore was amazed at the amiable tone of Amis's reply: 'As you can see he really couldn't have been nicer... and it's not as if I'd ever been introduced to him or to his son, or anything like that, so he wasn't doing me a personal favour, he was just being a decent liberal - unlike his agent who wanted to withhold permission because I'd been uncomplimentary.' Though I have found and print similarly generous and fair-minded letters, no one will be surprised to discover that the correspondence is littered with malicious, intemperate remarks about just about everybody Amis knew, Larkin and Hilly excepted. All I can say to those of Amis's friends and acquaintances who find themselves insulted or belittled in the letters is 'You're not alone'. Which is also what I'd say to maligned authors. That Amis admits to finding it hard to finish Martin's novels puts the son in good company; he also had trouble, the letters reveal, with Proust, Joyce, Lawrence, Updike, Bellow, and Nabokov. Towards the end of his life, he told Martin, the only books he could finish were thrillers, the sort that began 'A shot rang out' or 'A scream rent the air'. The most difficult of the problems I faced in choosing letters concerned the feelings of their recipients, as of others Amis disparages. Early in my work I was offered a sheaf of letters by an American academic who had written several books on Amis. These letters stretch over 17 years and are mostly warm and affectionate, though in later letters there are glimmers of irritation. Amis had taken this man to lunch, met his wife and son, had him to his house, introduced him to his friends, and written letters of reference for him. But he had also, I discovered, written a letter the man did not show me. A photocopy of this letter was found among Amis's papers after his death and offers a damning verdict on the first three chapters of the man's most recent work, a study of Amis's fiction. Here are its concluding paragraphs: 'It is not that I find what you have written offensive in any way, or improper to its subject. It is that the level of your performance seems to me to be so low as not to earn a place on any publisher's list. Please realise that no imaginable rewriting would rectify the situation. The fact that I have left many passages of your typescript unmarked testifies to my weariness and boredom with them, not to their correctness or adequacy. I think it would be best if the book were to be withdrawn. Yours, Kingsley' I thought long and hard before publishing this letter - it was the single most difficult decision I faced in the selection process. In the end, though, I decided to include it, for several reasons: Amis's literary executors had already deposited the photocopy at the Huntington, so it was available to other scholars; it shows an important side of Amis - how ferocious he could be in his later years; it says something about his willingness to sacrifice personal feelings for what he seems to have seen as the welfare of his reputation as a writer; and not printing the letter would have left readers with a false or partial understanding of the relations between the two men. When informed of my decision the academic wrote that he understood, without being much pleased, adding that he remained baffled by Amis's sudden turn: 'It contradicts everything he communicated to me in person and in letters over the previous 17 years.' The business of annotating the letters, the third phase of my job as editor, could be fiendishly difficult, especially when dealing with letters to Larkin. These letters, the most brilliant in the book, are filled with private jokes, allusions, obscure abbreviations, associational leaps and word games. Most books, records, poems and songs, for example, are referred to by the first and last words in their titles, as in 'A Time' for A Dance to the Music of Time. Some are identified by the first letters, or first few letters, of their first and last words, as in 'GB' for 'Goodbye to Berlin,' or 'Appara' (an editor's nightmare this) for 'Appointment in Samarra.' Often the letters proceed associationally: 'I love the persistent mis-spelling of authors' names,' declares Amis in a letter of 25 May 1947, 'it's amazing how it lowers the tome wainsh the tone. Talking of Wainsh [ie John Wain]...' Misspellings are of several sorts. Some derive from typos (all of which have been retained, even when most obvious), as in 'tome' for 'tone,' 'teh' for 'the,' or 'thiknign' for 'thinking' (which to Amis 'sounds really extraordinary - a character in Ibsen? Pastor Thiknign?'); others are laboriously crafted, as in 'methsleeves' for 'themselves,' or 'darts B.A.' for 'bastards.' Then there are phonetic spellings, often parodies of the sort of prim, suburban pronunciation mocked in the fiction: 'ab8' for 'about', 'hay' for 'how', 'refained' for 'refined', as in Chapter 4 of Lucky Jim, where Margaret comments of Christine after their first meeting: 'Pity she's so refained, though.' Often I could only make sense of puzzling passages by reading the letters to which they responded. In this way I learned, for example, the identity of 'Bluebell' (Robert Conquest's dog) or 'engine driver Hunt', from a passage in a letter reading 'Praed, Hood, Gilbert - and engine driver Hunt' (Hunt turns out to be a subject, not an author, of light verse, from the pseudonymous Conquest limerick beginning 'A young engine driver called Hunt'), or the meanings of the abbreviations PWR, IWICSLMSK and BHQ (respectively, Pee-Wee Russell, 'I Wish I Could Shimmy Like My Sister Kate' and 'Bastard Headquarters', meaning God's Heaven, or, more generally, the place where things go wrong or get fucked up, said in one letter to be located in France). The most fiendish of the puzzles I encountered in the correspondence occurs in a letter to Larkin of 22 March 1982. Amis had broken his leg ('standing up, trying to avoid an alcoholic fall') and was recuperating in the Kinnell Ward of the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead: 'There's an old woman here who sings all day. Wordless maunderings based on Camptown Races... Yes, all day. She's French, actually. Do you remember about Kinnell or Kinell? Used to be (milite) the more proper of a pair, the other being Kinarsoles.' It was Denis Norden, an exact contemporary of Amis's at the City of London School, who explained to me the meaning of this passage. 'Milite' (Latin) I could get myself; in this context it means 'in military parlance'. 'Kinnell' or 'Kinell', Norden explained, are short for 'Fuckin'ell,' to go with 'Fuckin'arsoles.' Of the pair, then, 'Kinnell' is 'the more proper'. Presto! The critic P.N. Furbank then supplied a related marching song, one line of which runs 'Arsehole, arsole, a soldier of the King'. Such are the intricacies of scholarship. One passage defeated me. In a letter of 27 August 1950 Amis calls Larkin 'my inner audience', my watcher in Spanish, the reader over my shoulder.' 'Inner audience' is clear enough and 'reader over my shoulder' comes from Robert Graves, but what is a 'watcher in Spanish'? fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: James Wood on fiction as an art of gentleness
fields.body:
The Broken Estate: Essays on Literature and Belief

James Wood
Pimlico £12.50, pp318
Buy it at BOL

James Wood, arguably the best literary journalist writing in English today, thinks through and about literature as much as he evaluates it. Focusing in this book mostly on nineteenth- and twentieth-century novels, he elaborates a liberal ethic of fiction as an art of gentleness. The 'sympathetic interminability' of a novel is the opposite of dogmatism: good writers do not demand obedience from their characters, or readers.

In a number of essays, Wood traces the development of autonomy in the characters of Austen, Chekhov and Woolf. Woolf, he argues, achieves this most fully in To the Lighthouse. In passages where Mrs Ramsay forgets herself in her train of thought, it is as if she forgets to be a character in a novel at all, as if her absent-mindedness enables her to escape the author, and the reader with her.

But Wood's writing is crossed by a second theme. His ethics are all liberality but in his heart he is all fury. Just as Flaubert was turning style in the novel into a religious pursuit, he argues, Ernest Renan was turning the Gospels into fiction. The gentle scepticism of the novel infected religion, to generally bland effect.

All good critics are jealous beasts. 'Poor Melville, lucky Melville!' exclaims Wood as he celebrates Melville's terrified struggle with the silence of God. He knows that the collapse of religious belief in the West (the 'Broken Estate' of his title) has scarred over. We are increasingly indifferent. The great age of the novel, capacious and liberating, seems mostly over too. There is too little gentleness or fury. This paradox is the source of Wood's passionate restlessness. Long may he struggle with it.

webTitle: Look who's reviving the American dream

fields.headline: Look who's reviving the American dream
fields.standfirst: Mike Davis offers an impressive introduction to the culture of America's Latinos in Magical Urbanism
fields.trailText: Mike Davis offers an impressive introduction to the culture of America's Latinos in Magical Urbanism
fields.body:
Magical Urbanism
Mike Davis
Verso £12, pp162
Buy it at BOL

Magical Urbanism kicks off its first chapter with two startling racial indicators: 'Sometime during 1996, Latinos surpassed African-Americans as the second largest ethno-racial group in New York City. Four years later, California celebrated the millennium as the first mainland state to become a "majority-minority" society. Dramatically ahead of earlier projections, white non-Hispanics became a minority for the first time since the Gold Rush.'

The growing social clout of America's Latinos is demonstrably visible. For more than 60 years, Hispanic-Americans have channelled their redemptive energies into various metropolitan wastelands. Davis, a renowned analyst of race and class in America, now turns his eye on an unexamined US phenomenon.

The Latino reinvention of American cities boasts some awe-inspiring examples. In the blue-collar LA suburb of Huntington Park, Main Street, until recently a shabby collection of pawn shops and $6-a-night flophouses, has been restored to its original art deco colours and designs. On the other coast, even New York's Mayor Giuliani has had to acknowledge the revival of no-go areas such as La Colonia's tropical gardens and Mission Street.

On the recovery of inner-city America, Davis develops one masterful theory, that mainstream planning and architecture lags far behind the grass roots urban imagination. It's a seductive argument, one that acknowledges the inherently racist strategies of most American housing associations.

Yet the Latino population is still circumscribed by its economic vulnerability. In California, Latinos still suffer from the lowest ethno-racial median wage. On the east side of Los Angeles, city elders struggle to control runaway gang violence. While membership of black gangs is in decline, Latino gangs are booming. Latinos also are demonised for use of Spanish as their primary language. 'English for America' is a current campaign that argues for a linguistically fortified America, while a recent campaign by LA politician Pete Wilson was waged under the banner: 'They Keep Coming - 2,000,000 Illegal Immigrants'.

Racial hegemony - and its political ramifications - are a constant feature of Davis's work. Ten years ago, he wrote City of Quartz, the definitive study of metropolitan America, a close examination of LA's African-American citizens. Published a few months after the LA riots, it is still the most articulate thesis on black American culture. Few sociologists in America are as capable as Davis at collating strands of information from both mainstream and alternative media. Yet he is more than simply a biographer of the American underclasses. His books have done much to underpin leftist ideas normally shunned by the US media.

As an introduction to the dynamics of Latino culture, and the reluctance of mainstream America to support an over-achieving minority group, Magical Urbanism has few rivals.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Galaxy Craze's debut is a beautifully written combination of a coming-of-age story and a love story, plus Class in Britain, Ex Libris, In the Red Corner and Our Fathers
fields.body:
By the Shore
Galaxy Craze
Vintage £6.99, pp232
Buy it at BOL

Poignant, delicate, seductive, haunting: Galaxy Craze's debut novel would be a cliché were it not so good. Set in the early Eighties, in a rambling, converted schoolhouse on the English coast, By the Shore describes 12-year-old May's efforts to make sense of her mother Lucy's confusing relationships, and her own place in the grown-up world she is both drawn to and afraid of.

Over the weeks before Christmas, May's life - trying to make friends with the cool girls at school, dealing with her annoyingly serene younger brother Eden - is interrupted by a series of visitors: first, a dishevelled writer and his editor who may or may not be his girlfriend; then May's glamorous, feckless father whom she has not seen for three years. Half May's coming-of-age, half Lucy's love story, this evocative, bittersweet book is finely observed and beautifully written.

Class in Britain
David Cannadine
Penguin £7.99, pp249
Buy it at BOL

Anyone hoping to understand modern Britain should read David Cannadine's masterful Class in Britain, which traces the the way in which Britons have defined themselves and their society from the commercial boom of the eighteenth century through the emergence of class consciousness in the nineteenth century to Blair's New Labour vision. As Cannadine says, this book is 'as much about the history of ideas about society as it is about society itself'.

His style is both lucid and scholarly, dense with quotations from sources as diverse as Karl Marx and Jilly Cooper. It may just be semantics, but Cannadine makes the historical debate over whether British society is and has been a hierarchy or a class battlefield both readable and relevant.

Ex Libris: Confessions of a Common Reader
Anne Fadiman
Penguin £5.99, pp132
Buy it at BOL

Although there are many delightful moments in this collection of essays on bibliophilia, perhaps the most typically so is Anne Fadiman's first chapter, entitled 'Marrying Libraries', in which she describes how she and her husband, after six years of cohabitation, finally combined their lifetimes of books. He is a 'lumper' (books fill shelves haphazardly), she a 'splitter' (books carefully arranged on shelves according to author, chronology or subject, often all three): merging was no easy task. Fadiman's skill is to make their eventual compromise a metaphor for their happy marriage.

Ex Libris celebrates books and book-loving through topics that range from the joy of dusty second-hand bookshops to the importance of inscriptions to the pleasure of reading a book in the place it was written.

In the Red Corner: A Journey into Cuban Boxing
John Duncan
Yellow Jersey Press £12, pp338
Buy it at BOL

Cuba's boxers are, in the words of Angel Espinosa, one-time world champion, 'diamonds lost in rubbish bins'. Here, Observer sportswriter John Duncan plays Ry Cooder and lifts them up to the light, alternating his adventures in the chaos that is modern Cuba with the remarkable stories of the island's unsung heroes.

Although they have been the best amateur boxers in the world, on the whole, Castro's champions have refused to turn professional. Some, like Felix Savon who turned down Don King in 1996, have refused multi-million dollar purses. The year Duncan spent infiltrating Cuba's tight-knit boxing world taught him that some athletes compete for more than money; he also saw their courage and idealism misplaced and ill-rewarded.

Our Fathers
Andrew O'Hagan
Faber £6.99, pp282
Buy it at BOL

When he hears that his grandfather is dying, Jamie Bawn returns to the Glasgow of his youth to make peace with the past. His family's legacy is a troubled one, marked by Utopian dreams and bitter despair in the midst of a harsh reality. Effie Bawn, Jamie's great-grandmother, was a socialist activist whose desire for change was equalled only by her passion for the saints; Hugh Bawn, Jamie's dying grandfather, had been a renowned social reformer whose single-minded vision created Glasgow's notorious cities in the sky. As he watches over Hugh's last days and is reunited with the parents he has not seen since his teens, Jamie learns to accept his forebears' faults and take pride in the fierce spirits and bleak landscape that shaped him.

Nominated for the Booker Prize, Our Fathers is a very Booker-ish novel, worthy and on the whole well-written - only the unkind might say a little over-written.

The year Duncan spent infiltrating Cuba's tight-knit boxing world taught him that some athletes compete for more than money; he also saw their courage and idealism misplaced and ill-rewarded. Our Fathers Andrew O'Hagan Faber £6.99, pp282 Buy it at BOL When he hears that his grandfather is dying, Jamie Bawn returns to the Glasgow of his youth to make peace with the past. His family's legacy is a troubled one, marked by Utopian dreams and bitter despair in the midst of a harsh reality. Effie Bawn, Jamie's great-grandmother, was a socialist activist whose desire for change was equalled only by her passion for the saints; Hugh Bawn, Jamie's dying grandfather, had been a renowned social reformer whose single-minded vision created Glasgow's notorious cities in the sky. As he watches over Hugh's last days and is reunited with the parents he has not seen since his teens, Jamie learns to accept his forebears' faults and take pride in the fierce spirits and bleak landscape that shaped him. Nominated for the Booker Prize, Our Fathers is a very Booker-ish novel, worthy and on the whole well-written - only the unkind might say a little over-written.

webTitle: A two-legged dog is a man's best friend

fields.headline: A two-legged dog is a man's best friend
fields.standfirst: Three masters of the genre - Mosley, Robinson and Lovesey - are still in sparkling form
fields.trailText: Three masters of the genre - Mosley, Robinson and Lovesey - are still in sparkling form
fields.body:
Walkin' the Dog
Walter Mosley
Serpent's Tail £14.99, pp260

Buy it at BOL

In a Dry Season
Peter Robinson
Macmillan £16.99, pp456

Buy it at BOL

The Reaper
Peter Lovesey
Little, Brown £16.99

Buy it at BOL

Even for a man who doesn't like to be categorised, Walter Mosley is pushing the envelope with his Socrates Fortlow stories. The writer of the bestselling 'Easy' Rawlins mystery series introduced his philosophising ex-convict several years ago in a story cycle, Always Outnumbered, Always Outgunned, that caused bemusement among some mystery fans. Here was a character custom-made for a mystery series, a big man with a violent temper and 'rock-breaking hands' who had served 27 years in an Indiana prison for murdering a man and a woman in a drunken fury and was now eking out a living in the black enclave of Watts.

But his usual response to the situations in which he found himself was not to use his fists but his philosopher namesake's Socratic method. Instead of hardboiled guns and gore, Mosley was offering morality tales, in which Fortlow was constantly asking: 'What is the right thing to do here?'

Mosley was open about his didactic intent. He stated his hope that young, inner-city people would read the stories in a school or workshop, relate them to their own lives and in that way 'see some kind of importance in literature'.

Walkin' the Dog is the second collection of linked stories. It's some years since Fortlow's release from prison, and at the start of the collection he is still making his home in a two-room shack in an alley between two derelict buildings. But now he has a girlfriend, a job and a two-legged dog called Killer. He also has the police on his back. These responsibilities make doing the right thing even more difficult.

Each story teases out the moral implications of sometimes quite minor actions. So, for example, in 'Blue Lightning', Fortlow is offered a better-paying job but has to consider whether the extra pay is worth the freedom he would have to give up. In 'Promise', he has to balance keeping a vow made long ago to a dying friend with the consequences of that action.

Outlining the stories makes them sound trite or dull. They're neither. Nor are they worthy, a kind of consolations of philosophy for the inner-urban citizen. Sure, Fortlow is trying to find meaning in his own life and the lives of those around him but these are tough, realistic tales of suffering and hardship. Fortlow is no Dudley Do-Right; violence is always a lurking possibility and he has killed again since leaving prison. Walkin' the Dog is an absorbing, thoughtful read, so beautifully constructed and written that you never doubt for a moment these are real people in real situations.

Peter Robinson's novels are squarely within the conventions of mystery writing, even down to the characteristics expected of the cop in the British police procedural. His Detective Chief Inspector Alan Banks is a music-loving, poetry-reading man at odds with his boss; his family life is in turmoil and he's trying to cut down on the booze and fags. So far so familiar.

But what raises Robinson's series out of the routine is the thoughtfulness of the writing, the subtlety of the characterisation and the skill of the plotting. In a Dry Season, his tenth - and best - novel featuring Banks, demonstrates these qualities in abundance. Given that the main theme of the book is about uncovering the past, it has a wonderful central image, an abandoned village revealed at the bottom of a dried-up reservoir in Yorkshire.

When a boy finds a skeleton there, Banks is brought in by his antagonistic boss, Chief Constable 'Jimmy' Riddle, to head what looks like being a dull, routine investigation but quickly turns into a murder hunt. The course of Banks's investigation and his growing relationship with his colleague DS Annie Cabbot is one of two intertwined narratives in the novel.

A former resident of the village writes a first-person account of the events between 1941 and 1945 leading up to the murder. Robinson's storytelling gifts are at their best as he conjures up that era of rationing, Land Girls, jitterbugging and the tensions aroused when glamorous American airmen swept the local girls off their feet and into their beds. The result is a page-turning and complex mystery. Although the climax is overly melodramatic, In a Dry Season is a terrific work, deservedly on this year's short list for the Mystery Writers of America's Edgar for best novel of the year.

Peter Lovesey has won many awards around the world in a 30-year writing career. On Friday, he entered the British crime-writing hall of fame when he was awarded the prestigious Crime Writer's Association/Cartier Diamond Dagger for his contribution to mystery writing - 21 novels and three collections of short stories.

His twenty-second novel, The Reaper, an entertaining black comedy set in a traditional English village, is as bright and breezy as his first, Wobble to Death. The Reaper relates the exploits of Otis Joy, the handsome, charming but murderous vicar of the parish. So that he can keep his living, people are dying. You know from the opening pages that Joy is the murderer but the fun of the book is in seeing if he's going to get away with it as events start to spiral out of his control. A delight.
