fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Mark and Claire live an idyllic life. They are young, in love and have two beautiful children. And then it all goes wrong...
fields.body:
The Clematis Tree
Ann Widdecombe
Read by Sorcha Cusack
Running time 3hours, 20 mins
Orion Audio Books £8.99
Buy it at BOL

Mark and Claire live an idyllic life. They are young, in love and have two beautiful children. And then it all goes wrong. Jeremy, their son, is knocked down by a speeding car and left brain dead, and Mark and Claire's relationship deteriorates with the pressures of caring for a severely disabled child.

It would be easy to mock Ann Widdecombe for writing what appears to be a book about marriage and relationships when she has so famously had none of her own. But Ann Widdecombe's first novel is not a love story. Rather, it's a vehicle for her views on moral and religious commitment and anti-abortion issues. The hapless Mark, desperate to find a way out of his unhappy marriage, is a message to all husbands: 'You've made your bed, now lie in it.'

During the course of this abridged version of The Clematis Tree, three children are killed in a coach crash, another dies of cancer, and somebody has a stroke. So much tragedy in a story can become farcical.

But Sorcha Cusack (Kate Wilson in Casualty ) is a well-chosen reader. She delivers the lines with empathy and compassion, keeping a steady voice as she relays the tragedies that occur with alarming regularity.

Her soft, Irish brogue soothes the listener through each terrible occurrence and admonishes the disloyal Jeremy for any adulterous thoughts that Widdecombe may deploy along the righteous path of his solemn and unbreakable marriage vows.

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Charles Pooter has become such an enduring comic character that the word 'Pooterish' has found its way into the dictionary.
fields.body:
The Diary of a Nobody
George and Weedon Grossmith
Prion Humour Classics £7.99, pp194
Buy it at BOL

Charles Pooter, the Grossmith brothers' put-upon diarist, has become such an enduring comic character that the word 'Pooterish' has found its way into the dictionary, meaning 'self-importantly genteel or middle-class'.

The Diary first appeared in Punch, and was published in book form in 1892. The Grossmith brothers were both entertainers. George worked for some time with Gilbert and Sullivan operas, and Weedon, a trained writer, later became an actor-manager in a London theatre.

'I fail to see,' Pooter remarks in his epigraph, 'because I do not happen to be a Somebody - why my diary should not be interesting.' For us, in an age when any 'Nobody' is encouraged to publish their diary or memoir, part of the delight of Pooter's is in the historical detail: the domestic chores and everyday routines of late-Victorian suburbia. As William Trevor explains in his introduction to this edition: 'The pleasure is reading between the lines.'

webTitle: DiMaggio of science hits a last home run

fields.headline: DiMaggio of science hits a last home run
fields.standfirst: Stephen Jay Gould's penultimate collection of essays, The Lying Stones of Marrakech, is as fascinating as ever
fields.trailText: Stephen Jay Gould's penultimate collection of essays, The Lying Stones of Marrakech, is as fascinating as ever
fields.body:
The Lying Stones of Marrakech
Stephen Jay Gould
Jonathan Cape £17.99, pp372
Buy it at BOL

There is a depressing subtitle to the latest selection from the grand master of scientific essays. According to its dust jacket, The Lying Stones of Marrakech is to be Gould's 'penultimate reflections in natural history'. Having written more than 290 essays for Natural History magazine, without missing a single monthly deadline in 30 years, and having subsequently published this output in regular collections, the Harvard biologist has announced he is to halt his regular musings this year.

His aim is to follow his hero, Joe DiMaggio, and quit while he is ahead, a fair decision, though those seeking his guidance through science's most arcane corridors will find themselves the poorer. Gould has an infectious and joyful understanding of the intricacies of his subject, be it an appreciation of Carl Sagan, the dangers of scientific fraud or a brief homage to Mozart.

With Lying Stones, we have one of our last chances to appreciate these virtues and assess a scientist who has become a Western publishing phenomenon. I have relished his works for many years, looking forward to each volume's publication, and have never felt let down, though, as with any lengthy relationship, I have found over-familiarity has vexing consequences. For example, Gould's language, with his passion for words such as contingent, canonical, and, above all, maximal, can be pompous and repetitive.

Yet these blemishes are rare and certainly do not detract from the strength of his prose. Indeed, his quirkiness, his ability to coalesce seemingly unconnected topics, and his individual passion are qualities that help make him such a powerful writer.

Consider 'A Tale of Two Work Sites', an essay triggered by two seemingly unconnected events. While visiting Oxford, Gould was given a desk in the university museum, where Huxley and Wilberforce had famously debated Darwin's Origin of Species. On a different visit, to New York, he was placed in a building where a 1911 blaze killed 146 textile workers. Little would seem to link the two spots, yet Gould unravels a dark, connecting strand.

This starts with the birth of natural selection and leads to its distortion by early twentieth-century 'social Darwinists' who believed the great biologist's theories justified all sorts of inequalities, including sweatshop labour in death-trap buildings. The result was the 1911 Triangle Shirtwaist fire, in which Gould has more than a passing interest: two of his grandparents were then immigrant garment workers in New York, though they toiled at different factories.

The profound, often unpleasant personal consequences of misinterpreting scientific theory are therefore given a voice of intense authority. We shall not come across its like again.

fields.headline: Just deserts
fields.standfirst: Martin Buckley set out to circle the globe travelling only through deserts. Grains of Sand brings his journey to life
fields.trailText: Martin Buckley set out to circle the globe travelling only through deserts. Grains of Sand brings his journey to life
fields.body:
Grains of Sand
Martin Buckley
Hutchinson £17.99, pp448
Buy it at BOL
See the photographs

One day, Martin Buckley was sitting in his bath with a soggy map when he realised he could circumnavigate the globe by travelling entirely through desert. That was exactly what he did. He began by crossing the Sahara, flew to Chile and journeyed north over the Atacama; continued north through deserts in Mexico and North America; flew on to Australia and drove south through the Tanami to Ayers Rock, and finally stepped westward through China, Pakistan, Iran and Oman.

The route was 'a ragged one, winding across two hemispheres and making leaps across the oceans, but a route it was'. Grains of Sand, which describes his two-year odyssey, is the record of a very peculiar passion. Buckley's love of deserts is both sensual ('You plunge your hand into a dune's skin through the surface tension and penetrate a universe of sand, a Big Bang of glittering grains of rock') and deeply spiritual. As with all good travel books, the outer journey is paralleled by that into unknown realms within.

He begins in a state of exhaustion, having spent 'nearly a decade working too hard for an organisation whose ideals were being destroyed by gangsters called "managers" ' (the BBC, not very surprisingly), and by the end realises that in the desert he left behind 'a version of myself, someone focused, who seemed to know who and what he was'.

In lesser hands, this account of eight separate desert journeys might have been incoherent. The main reason why it isn't, and why it reads so well, is that Buckley is a born storyteller. He can't set foot outside his tent in the morning without perceiving what he sees as if for the first time; fortunately, his descriptive powers are well up to the mark.

His engagement with the remarkable men and women he meets, 'whose unpredictability remains constant', is no less intense. At times, this leads to moments of high comedy, as when he finds himself in a cycle-rickshaw on a 20-kilometre-long ride in the Chinese desert. Watching the rickshaw driver sweating to propel them both, he 'felt horror. How could I sit still while a man drove himself to exhaustion for my benefit? It was like a nightmare of Victorian exploitation'.

He insists that the driver move into the passenger seat and he take over the pedals. At their destination, the driver tells a sympathetic crowd how he has been duped and exploited by this 'foreign devil' and manages to increase his fare from five to 100 yuan. As so often in this book, the joke is on the author.

Buckley is at his best when crossing the Sahara, which takes up more than half his book's 448 pages. By comparison, the Americas and Australia seem episodic, but the narrative takes flight again when he crosses the Gobi. He is a powerfully visual writer, but Hutchinson shouldn't have excluded his photographs from the volume, publishing them instead on their website.

Read this book most of all for its prose, which sparkles with inventiveness, its unstinting compassion for the people and places it describes and its author's anarchic humour. It is the next best thing to crossing the deserts of the world oneself.

webTitle: Enough to make your toes curl...

fields.headline: Enough to make your toes curl...
fields.standfirst: Kathryn Harrison maps out the terrible consequences of physical damage in The Binding Chair
fields.trailText: Kathryn Harrison maps out the terrible consequences of physical damage in The Binding Chair
fields.body:
The Binding Chair
Kathryn Harrison
Fourth Estate £9.99, pp336

New York-based Kathryn Harrison is best known for her beautifully written but disturbing memoir about incest and emotional abuse, The Kiss. Without trying to explain why incest happens, Harrison's brave, economic and poetic text concerns itself with showing how it happened to her.

Like the narrator of The Kiss, May, the anti-heroine of Harrison's latest novel, The Binding Chair, was irreparably damaged during her childhood. But where Kathryn's damage is emotional and psychosexual, May's is physical. At the age of six, her grandmother binds her feet and changes her life forever. The blow-by-blow description that follows makes compelling reading.

First Yu-ying, May's father's mother, stands May in a clay bowl to make an impression of her feet; this will be the last time May will use the feet she was born with. Then May's existing shoes are burnt and she is offered a pair of tiny, red silk slippers with butterflies embroidered on the toes. Next, Yu-ying cuts May's toenails and then binds her four toes down against the heel of her foot.

'A bound foot is not,' the narrator informs us in a chilling tone, 'a foot whose growth has been arrested. A bound foot is a foot broken: a foot folded in the middle, toes forced down toward the heel.' May is surprised when her grandmother hurts her, but she is a good girl and does what she's told. But when Yu-ying forces her to walk on her bound feet, May refuses. Yu-ying responds by shaming and then abandoning her. Alone, needing her mother, May hobbles to find her, tears silently streaming down her face.

Harrison's somewhat sensationalist depiction of binding feels less authentic than Jung Chang's in Wild Swans. What saves her text is the way she develops May's bound feet into the key structuring metaphor of the novel. Thus, May's bound feet not only explain aspects of her character, they also connect disparate sections of narrative.

Foot binding is contextualised by a moral framework and the following themes: the price of beauty and the darker side of matriarchy. By binding her feet, Yu-ying believes she is ensuring May's future (they will increase her chances of finding a rich husband). On the other hand, in Harrison's version, the custom is barbaric, little more than a nineteenth-century crime.

Yet Harrison's moralistic perspective stops short of outright condemnation. On the contrary, the practice is presented in an ambiguous light: bound feet can also be beautiful, even erotic. She suggests a parallel between traditional Chinese culture and the Western obsession with plastic surgery.

Subsequent horrible husband abandoned, May then marries Arthur, a Jewish-Australian expatriate, but this marriage fails, too. Nevertheless, it is through Arthur that May first comes to know Alice, his niece, the other main character in the novel. Deprived of her mother's love (Alice's sister Cecily is the favourite), May fills an emotional hole in Alice's life and for May, Alice is the daughter she never had. The two develop a close bond.

On the plus side, May encourages Alice to think for herself and to express herself freely in her rebellion against her family and, in all fairness, Alice is a willing convert to May's cynicism and sophistication. But on the minus side, the relationship between the two women becomes destructive when May, widely overstepping her role as an aunt, entices Alice to promise she is 'hers', that is, her daughter, belonging to May, not to Alice's biological mother. From this moment on, Alice devotes her attention to her needy aunt, further distancing herself from her biological family. The cycle begun by May's grandmother is almost complete.

The Binding Chair's narrator cuts between May and Alice's points of view, beginning with the present tense in the South of France, and going back to the hodge-podge past in Shanghai. But where Kathryn's damage is emotional and psychosexual, May's is physical. At the age of six, her grandmother binds her feet and changes her life forever. The blow-by-blow description that follows makes compelling reading. First Yu-ying, May's father's mother, stands May in a clay bowl to make an impression of her feet; this will be the last time May will use the feet she was born with. Then May's existing shoes are burnt and she is offered a pair of tiny, red silk slippers with butterflies embroidered on the toes. Next, Yu-ying cuts May's toenails and then binds her four toes down against the heel of her foot. 'A bound foot is not,' the narrator informs us in a chilling tone, 'a foot whose growth has been arrested. But when Yu-ying forces her to walk on her bound feet, May refuses. Yu-ying responds by shaming and then abandoning her. Alone, needing her mother, May hobbles to find her, tears silently streaming down her face. What saves her text is the way she develops May's bound feet into the key structuring metaphor of the novel. She suggests a parallel between traditional Chinese culture and the Western obsession with plastic surgery. fields.headline: Absolutely fabulist
fields.standfirst: For the narrator of Gesualdo Bufalino's final novel, Tommaso and the Blind Photographer, stories are easier to live with than people
fields.trailText: For the narrator of Gesualdo Bufalino's final novel, Tommaso and the Blind Photographer, stories are easier to live with than people
fields.body:
Tommaso and the Blind Photographer
Gesualdo Bufalino
Harvill £9.99, pp183
Buy it at BOL

This final novel by the late, great Sicilian fabulist is about finding nobody at the end of life's hard road but yourself. Set in a monumentally nondescript apartment complex populated by oddballs and losers, its deeply dissociative narrator, Tommaso Mulè, has abandoned family and career to hide out in a basement flat and count the shoes passing by his window - moccasins, espadrilles, galoshes, clogs. Having forsaken the search for meaning, his only remaining comment on the world's marvels is: 'So what?'

Like Bufalino's previous work, most notably Night's Lies, his mini Decameron of condemned prisoners telling tall tales on the eve of execution, this novel explores the double nature of good fiction - its power to both reconstitute our world and divide us from it.

For Mulè, stories are a lot easier to live with than other people. As he collects rent, makes repairs and posts bills, he prefers to invent fictions about his neighbours rather than to learn who they really are. Stubbornly mired in the hard, dull routine of himself, Mulè doesn't like to live life. He only wants to elide it. For him, reality is just a pest, a grey, virulent mouse scurrying beneath the floorboards. You never find it and it never leaves you alone.

It is probably no wonder, then, that the neighbour with whom Mulè feels the closest kinship is a blind photographer known as Tiresias who, like the Greek seer blinded by his vision of a naked goddess, goes through life recording marvels - sunsets, beautiful girls, even landscapes - without witnessing them. 'What the eye doesn't see,' Mulè concludes, 'the heart doesn't grieve over.'

When Tiresias is murdered by a helmeted motorcyclist shortly after taking photos of high-profile public citizens at an all-night drug orgy, Mulè is suddenly entangled in a metaphysical murder-mystery straight out of Antonioni's Blow-Up or Stanley Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut. Soon he is engaged to recover the unseeing photographer's last roll of exposed film in which, it is assumed, all will be revealed. Clues begin springing up under his feet, and multitudinous solutions abound, with at least one of them leading right to Mulè's own front door.

Even Leah, the beautiful young girl who just moved in down the hall, is willing to pay him anything he desires in exchange for 'the Truth'. And Mulè, as usual, gets what he desires about the same time he realises he didn't really desire it in the first place. When you live inside your own head, of course, all the world has to offer is disillusion.

According to Bufalino, reality is a game we compose in order to make it through the night. And like most fabulist fictions, this book continually refers to other writers who enjoy laying 'traps and snares' for their readers: Poe, Dumas, Le Carré and, especially, Nabokov. Tommaso and the Blind Photographer is also reminiscent of Nabokov's great, often-neglected novel, Laughter in the Dark, about a blinded film-lover who ends up living a happy-family fantasy concocted by his gold-digging young young wife and her apish lover.

Yet Bufalino is a kinder writer than the usual trickster-metafictionist and he obviously feels compassion for those who get lost in the illusions the compose for themselves (such as chartered accountants, say, or door-to-door encyclopedia salesmen).

For Bufalino, as for Nabokov, all reality is virtual. And the most fantastic story any man ever tells is the story of himself.

fields.headline: Any port in a storm
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Harding  went to the gates of Fortress Europe to find out about aylum-seekers. He explains what he saw in The Uninvited
fields.trailText: Jeremy Harding went to the gates of Fortress Europe to find out about aylum-seekers. He explains what he saw in The Uninvited
fields.body:
The Uninvited: Refugees at the Rich Man's Gate
Jeremy Harding
Profile £5.99, pp128

Few people know that the European Union extends into Africa. Ceuta, the Spanish enclave on the Moroccan coast, is a little EU outpost. Now it has becomes a little EU fortress, for if you can get in there, the free-travelling way into mainland Spain and from there on to France and Germany lies open before you.

So now, with Brussels paying, Ceuta has barricaded itself behind a double-exclusion fence backed with rolls of razor wire, electronic sensors and closed-circuit television. And yet, as Jeremy Harding found when he went to Ceuta, people still hurl themselves at this fence. They set out from West Africa on a journey - walking across the Sahara, hitching lifts on trucks, guided and fleeced by the traffickers of Niger, Algeria and Morocco - which may last months.

Some in each group die on the way, mostly of disease and thirst. They bring a few women with them, bodies to be used as rape currency to get past frontier patrols. And when they get to Ceuta, they hide themselves in the sand, wait their moment and then rush at the wire. And some, 'slashing their legs to shreds', do get over it. Inside 'Europe', they join the 'Great Uninvited', those the Dover Express defines as 'human sewage'. But at least they have made it.

Marvellous, sharp-end reportage is a big part of this book. But what makes Jeremy Harding's writing so compelling is the way he interprets what he sees and hears. From Ceuta, he points out that the sheer horror of these immense desert pilgrimages fulfils, accidentally, a European requirement. It sieves out the applicants. Only the most able survive. 'These job-seekers,' says Harding drily, 'are among the most highly motivated in Europe.'

In the same way, he goes down to the Puglian coast of Italy to watch the patrol boats chasing the gommoni - the rubber dories which rush illegal migrants across the Adriatic from the Albanian shore - and finds that the traffickers can be brave and unselfish with their passengers as well as extortionate.

'I became suspicious of the ideas that the traffickers were the modern embodiment of evil.' They are crooks, often attached to mafias, but nobody else would do what they are doing - helping the helpless. Harding thinks of the bar in Casablanca and that fawning Peter Lorre figure. 'You despise me, don't you? But think of all those poor refugees who must rot in this place if I didn't help them.'

And up the coast at the Regina Pacis refuge camp, he meets a defiant priest who proclaims that the illegals have only two friends in the world: his refuge and organised crime. Harding traces the history of what he calls 'Europe's project of exclusion', the slow slinking-away from commitment to the 1951 Convention on refugee status towards a new dream of 'Fortress Europe', which he bitingly calls a 'dreary pastoral fantasy, in which the European Union resembles an Alpine valley surrounded by impregnable, snow-capped mountains'.

It is now almost incredible to recall the way in which France, for example, simply opened its frontiers between the world wars to hundreds of thousands of White Russians, Armenians fleeing genocide, German anti-Nazis and Jews, Spanish Republicans or Italian opponents of Mussolini. There were 8,000 Russians working in Renault at Billancourt alone and by 1939 six per cent of the population were of foreign origin.

Britain was generous too, once. Jeremy Harding suggests that the first real sign of a change came in 1900, when the SS Cheshire arrived at Southampton, in an uproar of publicity, with a party of South African Jews hoping to take refuge from the Boer War. They were depicted in the Daily Mail much as the same paper would describe Kurdish or Tamil asylum-seekers now - as dirty scum out to scrounge champagne and money out of the trustful British taxpayer.

It is ironic, as Harding observes, that those who passionately believe in the sort of globalisation which is based on the free movement of capital are equally passionately opposed to the free global movement of people.

But he is critical, too, of some liberal notions and nostrums about migration, refugees and asylum-seekers. It is a fine ideal to answer migrant pressure by transferring resources to the territories they come from, but it is not likely to work.

It is a myth that Third World immiseration, real as it is, forms the decisive cause for migration towards Europe or North America. The evidence is quite to the contrary - that a rise in GDP leads to a rise in emigration. For years, Mexico showed a combination of rapid growth and soaring emigration, legal or illegal. Sub-Saharan Africa, on the other hand, has so far sent only about four million emigrants out of the continent, and the greatest number of African wanderers and displaced families move only short distances to a neighbouring country.

Unfortunately, by trying to enrich the poor countries, the rich countries exacerbate the problem rather than solve it - even if the transfer of resources is good and inevitable for a host of other reasons.

The first key to understanding migration is understanding that the distinction between 'genuine asylum-seeker' (good) and 'economic migrant' (bad) is rubbish. Jeremy Harding allows this to dawn on himself gradually, and to great effect. In the refugee camp at Ceuta, Africans are envious because the Algerians pass the EU criteria of 'political persecution' and they do not, but they also consider - as people who have known real want and hunger - that the distinction between persecution by a state or a terrorist movement and persecution by starvation is utterly unreal.

The second part of wisdom is simpler: realising that in the end, legally or illegally, the rest of the world is going to get into this Sound of Music valley of ours, and that they will make it a younger, higher-earning and altogether less oppressive place.

webTitle: Cyber-cinema arrives with first internet production

fields.headline: Cyber-cinema arrives with first internet production
fields.standfirst: Cleese stars in Web's first click flick
fields.trailText: Film buffs clicked their way into history last night by logging on to the internet to watch John Cleese star in the first movie made for the World Wide Web.
fields.body:
Film buffs clicked their way into history last night by logging on to the internet to watch John Cleese star in the first movie made for the World Wide Web.

Cleese, 60, plays an alcoholic software pioneer in the $3 million comedy Quantum Project, filmed in Los Angeles earlier this year. Billed as a 'story of two electron-crossed lovers' the movie tells of Paul Pentcho, a scientist, who uses the laws of quantum physics, to 'create' a girlfriend, Lea.

Pentcho is played by Stephen Dorff, best-known as the fifth Beatle Stuart Sutcliffe in Backbeat. Fay Masterson, who co-starred with Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman in Eyes Wide Shut, plays Lea.

The film is directed by Eugenio Zanetti, who won an Oscar as art director of historical movie Restoration and worked as production designer on effects movies The Haunting and Last Action Hero.

SightSound.com, the firm behind the film, said it was delighted to be first to make an internet movie. Scott Sander, chief executive and president, said: 'We are excited that Stephen, Fay and John and the entire production cast and crew have joined us in making movie history.'

Producer Stephen Simon said: 'Now we appreciate what the creators of The Jazz Singer felt when they made the first talking film. We're adding another item to the history book.'

The 30-minute film is a co-production with Metafilmics, which won a special effects Oscar for Robin Williams's film What Dreams May Come.

It was written by David Aaron Cohen, whose credits include the Brad Pitt movie The Devil's Own. It mixes live action and three-dimensional computer effects.

Despite software glitches, many viewers paid the £4 they needed in order to download the pictures and sound which are remarkably clear with a broadband connection.

The number of people downloading movies to their TV set is expected to rise sharply over the next two to three years as broadband technology takes off. Cyber Dialogue analyst Peter Clemente said: 'We need a launch pad for downloading film on the Net and this film could be it.'

Mobile phones are also expected to carry internet webcasts soon.

webTitle: IRA agrees to open up its weapons dumps

fields.headline: IRA agrees to open up its weapons dumps
fields.standfirst:
The IRA statement in full

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA took the historic step yesterday of agreeing to open its arsenals to inspection, generating a wave of optimism that the Irish peace process was back on track.
fields.byline: Jason Burke, Henry McDonald and John O'Farrell, Belfast
fields.body:
The IRA took the historic step yesterday of agreeing to open its arsenals to inspection, generating a wave of optimism that the Irish peace process was back on track.

The republicans said arms dumps could be inspected at regular intervals by agreed representatives of an international decommissioning body to prove that weapons were not being used.

A statement by the group, whose previous refusal to begin disarmament led to the suspension of the Northern Ireland Assembly and Executive, said that 'in the context of the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement', the IRA was willing to put its arms 'completely and verifiably beyond use'.

The weapons would be dumped in 'such a way as to avoid risks to the public or misappropriation by others' - an apparent reference to dissident hardline republicans such as the Real IRA.

The noon announcement came after Prime Minister Tony Blair and the Irish Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, put forward new proposals that they said could allow a restoration of the suspended Assembly and a return to devolved rule for the six counties. The offer came late on Friday night after more than 30 hours of talks between the two heads of government.

Following the IRA's announcement, the Government confirmed that the crucial 22 May deadline by which the decommissioning process was supposed to be completed will be postponed for a year. This means the Assembly can resume work on that date, if David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, can win the support of the 860-strong ruling council of his party for its participation.

Blair and Ahern welcomed the IRA statement, and announced that former Finnish President Martti Ahtisaari and former African National Congress secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa would lead the inspections of the IRA weapons dumps.

Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson said the IRA move 'offers the opportunity to restart the institutions on a firmer footing than before'.

The Conservative Party also gave the breakthrough a cautious welcome.

But reactions from the Northern Irish Unionist community were mixed. Trimble said: 'There are some interesting things in this statement. It does appear to break new ground. There are some... very positive aspects but there are also some questions we have already raised with people that we want to just tease out.' He did not elaborate.

David Ervine, leader of the Progressive Unionist Party, said: 'We have from the IRA a better appreciation of intent than has ever hitherto been the case. We've got an opportunity here at our fingertips that we dare not throw away.'

Others rejected the deal outright. Robert McCartney, hardline leader of the United Kingdom Unionist Party, claimed Blair's position represented the 'ultimate surrender' to all IRA demands. Loyalist paramilitaries, such as the Ulster Volunteer Force, have yet to respond.

John Hume, the SDLP leader, welcomed what he called 'a very positive statement from the IRA'.

He said: 'I think it is making very clear that the gun has been taken out of Irish politics for ever.'

Observers said the IRA move is a radical step forward. With it, the Provisionals have given up a 300-year tradition of armed resistance to British rule in Ireland. The statement is the clearest indication so far that for the bulk of the IRA the 30-year-old war is over. However no one can be sure how many hardliners were opposed to yesterday's announcement.

There is a potential danger for the Sinn Fein leadership. Hardline republicans will paint this initiative as a sell-out, so a serious split in the ranks of armed Republicanism could follow.

This shift in mainstream Republican thinking marks another stage in the evolution of the Provisionals from the violent revolutionary movement of 1969 towards a democratic constitutional Irish nationalist political force. At the start of the present Northern Ireland troubles, IRA members refused even to recognise the validity of the courts in which they were tried for terrorist offences. As late as the Eighties, the IRA's political allies, Sinn Fein, ran its absentionist Assembly election campaign with the slogan, 'Smash Stormont.'

Yet 20 years later many of those committed to the movement appear to have given up armed struggle to ensure that Stormont, with Sinn Fein's participation, is restored.

Yesterday's statement comes after weeks of secret negotiations. Dozens of alternative solutions were floated by the two governments to break the impasse. Three weeks ago The Observer revealed the basis of the plan envisaged to save the Good Friday Agreement. This was:

* An IRA statement that the war was over for good.

* The Government accepting that it would re-establish the Executive.

* The IRA then giving Trimble's party a specific time frame for when the weapons would be put beyond use.

* The Unionists would then agree to go back into coalition government with Sinn Fein.

In fact, the IRA statement goes further than Trimble's UUP could have hoped for, by agreeing to let a third party inspect their arms dumps.

However, Unionists have pointed out that the IRA is still only referring to a 'cessation' of violence and has not yet renounced violence.The organisation's credibility has also been damaged by continuing punishment beatings on the streets of Northern Ireland cities.

The final act preceding this huge change seems to have been a meeting that took place within the past four weeks in Dublin between senior members of the Irish government and the IRA itself.

fields.bodyText: The IRA took the historic step yesterday of agreeing to open its arsenals to inspection, generating a wave of optimism that the Irish peace process was back on track. The republicans said arms dumps could be inspected at regular intervals by agreed representatives of an international decommissioning body to prove that weapons were not being used. A statement by the group, whose previous refusal to begin disarmament led to the suspension of the Northern Ireland Assembly and Executive, said that 'in the context of the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement', the IRA was willing to put its arms 'completely and verifiably beyond use'. The weapons would be dumped in 'such a way as to avoid risks to the public or misappropriation by others' - an apparent reference to dissident hardline republicans such as the Real IRA. The noon announcement came after Prime Minister Tony Blair and the Irish Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, put forward new proposals that they said could allow a restoration of the suspended Assembly and a return to devolved rule for the six counties. The offer came late on Friday night after more than 30 hours of talks between the two heads of government. Following the IRA's announcement, the Government confirmed that the crucial 22 May deadline by which the decommissioning process was supposed to be completed will be postponed for a year. This means the Assembly can resume work on that date, if David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, can win the support of the 860-strong ruling council of his party for its participation. Blair and Ahern welcomed the IRA statement, and announced that former Finnish President Martti Ahtisaari and former African National Congress secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa would lead the inspections of the IRA weapons dumps. Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson said the IRA move 'offers the opportunity to restart the institutions on a firmer footing than before'. The Conservative Party also gave the breakthrough a cautious welcome. But reactions from the Northern Irish Unionist community were mixed. Trimble said: 'There are some interesting things in this statement. It does appear to break new ground. There are some... very positive aspects but there are also some questions we have already raised with people that we want to just tease out.' He did not elaborate. David Ervine, leader of the Progressive Unionist Party, said: 'We have from the IRA a better appreciation of intent than has ever hitherto been the case. We've got an opportunity here at our fingertips that we dare not throw away.' Others rejected the deal outright. Robert McCartney, hardline leader of the United Kingdom Unionist Party, claimed Blair's position represented the 'ultimate surrender' to all IRA demands. Loyalist paramilitaries, such as the Ulster Volunteer Force, have yet to respond. John Hume, the SDLP leader, welcomed what he called 'a very positive statement from the IRA'. He said: 'I think it is making very clear that the gun has been taken out of Irish politics for ever.' Observers said the IRA move is a radical step forward. With it, the Provisionals have given up a 300-year tradition of armed resistance to British rule in Ireland. The statement is the clearest indication so far that for the bulk of the IRA the 30-year-old war is over. However no one can be sure how many hardliners were opposed to yesterday's announcement. There is a potential danger for the Sinn Fein leadership. Hardline republicans will paint this initiative as a sell-out, so a serious split in the ranks of armed Republicanism could follow. This shift in mainstream Republican thinking marks another stage in the evolution of the Provisionals from the violent revolutionary movement of 1969 towards a democratic constitutional Irish nationalist political force. At the start of the present Northern Ireland troubles, IRA members refused even to recognise the validity of the courts in which they were tried for terrorist offences. As late as the Eighties, the IRA's political allies, Sinn Fein, ran its absentionist Assembly election campaign with the slogan, 'Smash Stormont.' Yet 20 years later many of those committed to the movement appear to have given up armed struggle to ensure that Stormont, with Sinn Fein's participation, is restored. Three weeks ago The Observer revealed the basis of the plan envisaged to save the Good Friday Agreement. webTitle: 6,000 steel jobs in Wales under threat

fields.headline: 6,000 steel jobs in Wales under threat
fields.trailText: More than 6,000 jobs in the Welsh steel industry are set to follow Rover as the latest victims of the crisis in manufacturing.
fields.body:
More than 6,000 jobs in the Welsh steel industry are set to follow Rover as the latest victims of the crisis in manufacturing.

The flagship steel plant at Llanwern in South Wales, which employs 3,000 people, is threatened with imminent closure, while the future of a strip mill at Port Talbot, which employs 3,200 people, is also thought to be in jeopardy.

The steelmaker Corus, which owns the plants, warned Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers last week that they may be forced to shut Llanwern. Sir Ken Jackson, head of the Amalgamated Electrical and Engineering Union, told The Observer : 'Llanwern is on the brink. There is a very real threat of it closing.'

In a series of crisis talks last week, the unions and Corus told Byers of the devastating impact that the strong pound and the meltdown of the British car industry was having on UK steel manufacturing.

Rover and Ford account for 400,000 tonnes a year of Corus's strip steel, which comes from UK plants. This week Ford is also expected to announce another devastating blow to the British car industry with the end of car production at its Dagenham, Essex, factory.

Jackson warned Byers: 'The fallout from Rover has been underestimated, and the strength of the pound is causing Corus to haemorrhage profits.'

fields.headline: Life after This Life
fields.standfirst: Hearts and Bones is a well-written, empathetic twentysomething drama set in London. Metropolis, meanwhile, is... set in London
fields.trailText: Hearts and Bones is a well-written, empathetic twentysomething drama set in London. Metropolis, meanwhile, is... set in London
fields.body:
Sinead, from the BBC's sensitivesomething new drama series Hearts and Bones, looked a bit like Molly Ringwald after ECT, and talked as though she had a mouth full of strawberry shortcake and clotted cream. Just like a tenacious, little, marshmallow turd stuck to the sole of a trainer, Sinead was the 'friend' who nobody in the gang had quite managed to shake off, so she'll probably die in episode six.

Anyway, she was in love, neatly, with another redhead, Mark (the estimable Damian Lewis, late of the excellent Warriors), but he was oblivious to Sinead's feelings, having long been involved in a bit of inter-follicular miscegenation with a raven-haired beauty. Meanwhile, his intended, Emma, the mother of his son, was a bored and slightly tortured sensitivesomething played by Dervla Kirwan, who is almost as famous for her love life as she is for her acting.

However, Emma wasn't too keen on the idea of marrying Mark because she wanted to sleep with his brother, Richard, the blond butcher, (Hugo Full Monty Speer), who was involved with a (blond) hairdresser called Louise, (Amanda Holden). In real life, Holden is married to Les Family Fortunes Dennis and, over Easter, both could be seen in Happy Birthday Shakespeare, during which Holden had an affair with Neil Morrissey, whose character was married to Dervla Kirwan.

Anyway, if you still can't quite place Amanda, she is to be found on the cover of the current Radio Times (Dervla was on it last week) among a bunch of other shiny, young sorts in parochial version of the Vanity Fair 'new talent' covers.

But I digress. Emma doesn't want much out of life - just some wildly inventive sex with Richard, with whom she's convinced herself she's in love. But is Richard suddenly going to get promoted to head of the sausage department, keep her in cow pies till the pigs come home? I don't think so. Anyway, Mark is a teacher, probably with prospects.

The night before Emma marries Mark, she gets off with a colleague during one of those warm Asti Spumante, strip-lighting and novelty-balloon fests we recognise as the office party. So the next day, while Sinead reads a Native American poem ('You have made a building out of heart and bone...') at the register office and everybody sniggers, Emma plights her troth to Mark, wearing a livid-looking lovebite concealed under a scarf. Mark spots it later, though during the pub lunch-cum-reception, and just before the credits rolled, you could see that his world was about to implode quite redly.

So far, Hearts and Bones is everything that Metropolis isn't: well-written, empathetically acted, not too scarily hip, plausibly plotted, directed with intimacy and intelligence and boasting real red-headed actors playing genuine red-headed characters. In fact, despite the fact that you couldn't really care less about any of the characters, H&B is the model of a post-This Life sensitivesomething drama.

Metropolis, on the other hand, is quite an extraordinary piece of garbage. After watching the first two episodes, I thought I'd better make sure that this really was as bad as it appeared to be by watching the remaining six in one sitting.

By the end, I was nostalgic for the beginning, when things had merely looked crass and heavy-handed in an amusing sort of way, rather than exasperatingly, enragingly, depressingly and expensively crass and heavy-handed. Metropolis was written by Peter Morgan, who was responsible for the charmless romantic comedy Martha, Meet Frank, Daniel and Lawrence. Morgan had obviously used up too many first names in one go, so in the sparklingly-titled Metropolis, he reprises a Frank, this time giving it to his (dyed but meant to be real) red-headed character, an insurance- claims inspector whose pudding-basin hairdo starts off bright copper before a brief phase of dirty blondness, ending up gleaming and burnished again, like a Burne-Jones babe. But, frankly, tonsorial continuity was the least of Frank's problems - somewhere behind being completely and utterly redundant plotwise. But then he's not alone in that.

As in Hearts and Bones, Metropolis revolves around the lives of six former college friends muddling along together, preparing to knock loudly on the door of 30 shouting: 'Let me in, I'm a grown-up', but wondering quite why they've bothered staying friends. Apparently - and here's the science bit - six is the perfect number of characters for an ensemble comedy drama-cum-thriller-thing: enough to cover the bases vis-à-vis beauty, brains and losers, but not so many that you forget their names or who's sleeping with whom. Unless it's Friends, of course, where no losers are ever allowed, so help them God. In Britain, however, everybody can be both a loser and loathsome. Though to be a loser and loathsome and clichéd and unfunny as well is, I think, almost unforgivable. And to squander a bunch of young actors with everything professionally still to live for is clearly downright wicked.

There is a stalker character in Metropolis who is played so badly by James Purefoy that he should be grateful he has three distracting movies currently awaiting release. Portraying all-purpose psychosis, Purefoy adopts a terrifying, high-pitched, wheedling and eye-rolling routine which makes him look and as though he were auditioning to play Tinky Winky. And then there's Flora Montgomery as a Tory sleazebitchlet on the make, who is clearly very comfortable with non-gratuitous semi-nudity. Or, come to that, totally gratuitous semi-nudity. Unfortunately, even while wearing Agent Provocateur underwear, she smoulders like the young Princess Anne preparing to take a particularly exhilarating jump at Badminton.

Then there is James Fox who, very tragically - and at the age of, what? fifty- or sixtysomething? - is finally revealed to have been earning his living as an actor under completely false pretences for all these years. Wooden? The man arrived on set with instructions for self-assembly. Still, given that Fox's character is a billionaire, patrician financier called, er, Milton Friedkin, who lives in a hotel and owns all the gold in the world you can't really blame him. 'Arrr-harrr!' Milton tells his young lover at one point later in the series. 'Read the signs and everything falls into place.' This is advice the whole cast might have been advised to take to heart and bone.

Still, I think I may have to return to Metropolis in the next few weeks because I haven't yet had the opportunity to write about Gina Bellman, who this week crops up as an Armenian widow and seduces Frank. In the meantime, however, you can see the beautiful Ms Bellman on the front cover of Radio Times, right there alongside Hearts and Bones 's Amanda Holden and another of Metropolis 's feckless yoofs, Matthew Rhys. And Krishnan Guru-Murthy who, by some extraordinary oversight, has totally failed to land himself a part in a sensitivesomething comedy drama thriller series. Yet. Anyway, this week sees the start of yet another new sensitivesomething comedy drama series, on BBC 2. This one is called Coupling and, rather confusingly, stars Gina Bellman. And Jack Davenport, from This Life. I think I need a little lie down.

Da Ali G Show finished this week. I dismissed it when it started but I was wrong. Anyway, I'm in a slightly less sour mood this week, so I freely admit to a titter when Ali told Anita Roddick that 'me clothes are made out of an animal called a Crylic. It lives in Taiwan. Over 20 Crylics were used to make the pants'. And a howl, no less, when, on the brink of death, Ali found himself briefly in Heaven, in front of Jah. 'While I'm up here, I couldn't get another couple of inches?' he wondered. But Jah told it like it is: 'No, 11 is enough for any man.' Amen to that.

fields.headline: Supervirus threatens IT meltdown
fields.standfirst:
FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning
Sophos virus information
fields.trailText: Renegade computer programmers have developed dozens of 'superviruses' that each have the capability to inflict massive damage on global computer systems.
fields.byline: Jason Burke and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
Renegade computer programmers have developed dozens of 'superviruses' that each have the capability to inflict massive damage on global computer systems.

The new viruses have many times the destructive power of the 'love bug' which wreaked havoc last week, and there are fears that criminals and terrorists could use them to blackmail governments and private institutions.

Anti-virus experts say '20 to 30' variants of the new-generation viruses have been found by specialist researchers. None has yet been sent into circulation by its authors, though it would only take minutes to launch such an attack.

FBI sources last week described the new bugs as a 'very serious threat'. Experts at commercial anti-virus firms said such an attack could be 'a catastrophe'. 'It's a disaster waiting to happen,' said one. 'And it's a question of when, not if.'

The new viruses combine the speed of last week's love bug - the fastest-spreading virus ever seen - with the destructive 'payload' of older viruses such as 'Chernobyl', which last year irreparably damaged hundreds of thousands of computers in the Middle East and Asia by wiping their hard disks.

The most dangerous feature of the new viruses is that many are triggered simply by checking an e-mail in-box. Even if a user does not click on the infected e-mail - let alone open an attachment - the virus will cause huge damage and send itself to every other address in the computer's e-mail software.

'The capability to cause massive destruction now exists,' said Dan Schrader, chief security analyst with TrendMicro, a global anti-virus company. 'There has been an explosion of professionalism in virus-writing. The authors have increasing resources and experience behind them. Where these resources come from is ever more worrying.'

Investigators are still unsure of who was behind the bug sent to millions of computers worldwide last week. Police were closing in on their prime suspect last night. They said a 23-year-old living in a surburb of Manila, the capital of the Philippines, had been put under surveillance. Local investigators were preparing to seize computers that the bug's author is suspected of using.

There has also been speculation that the real responsibility lies elsewhere. Much of the love bug's computer coding - the programming instructions sent into computers when the e-mail's attachment is launched - appears to have been derived from a website in Germany visited by many hackers, particularly those linked to anarchist movements. A Swedish computer expert told newspapers yesterday that the author of the love bug was a German hacker known as Mikael.

At least 10 mutations of the love bug have now appeared. One bears a subject heading in Lithuanian, prompting authorities there to start an inquiry. Experts fear that hundreds of love-bug variants could appear in coming weeks.

There are also fears over a virus called Smash95 which it is thought will trigger itself on Bastille Day - 14 July. Though it has already been found on tens of thousands of computers worldwide, nobody is sure how it is spread. All that is known is that it has a destructive 'payload' or 'bomb' that will go off on the set date.

The FBI is leading the hunt for the author of the original program - technically known as a 'worm', not a virus - and says it is liaising with dozens of law enforcement authorities worldwide. Scotland Yard confirmed last night that its specialist computer crime unit was working with the Americans.

The stakes are high. It is estimated that the love bug has already caused more than a billion pounds of damage worldwide. The impact of a supervirus would be far greater.

Yesterday active virus writers in America and Europe told The Observer that the only thing stopping so-called 'cyber-vandals' launching the new superviruses was the fear of getting caught.

webTitle: Gates backs bid to 'buy' yachting champions

fields.headline: Gates backs bid to 'buy' yachting champions
fields.trailText: Bill Gates is bankrolling a multi-million-dollar bid by the United States to persuade the world sailing champions to abandon their native New Zealand and instead race under the Stars and Stripes.
fields.body:
Bill Gates is bankrolling a multi-million-dollar bid by the United States to persuade the world sailing champions to abandon their native New Zealand and instead race under the Stars and Stripes.

As well as money, the US is promising American citizenship to the New Zealand crew, holders of the prestigious America's Cup. America is out to regain yachting's biggest prize and has decided 'if you can't beat them, buy them'. Big-money deals are being offered to 20 of the 30 Kiwi sailors who won the trophy in March as incentives to switch countries.

Around $35 million is available to lure the backbone of the triumphant Kiwi team. The move is being made now so that any of the crew who swap loyalties will be able to meet a two-year residence qualification for sailors competing in the next America's Cup in 2003.

This attempt to buy back a trophy the US regards as its own has gone down badly in New Zealand. Brad Butterworth, Team New Zealand's tactician, said it would be 'devastating' if any of his victorious teammates succumbed to the combined appeal of Uncle Sam and greenbacks. fields.headline: News in Brief
fields.trailText: The teenage singer Charlotte Church was named British artist of the year at the first Classical Brit Awards at the Royal Albert Hall in London last night. Charlotte, 13, from Cardiff, has made a series of CDs and TV appearances.
fields.body:
Charlotte, 13, sings her way to artist of the year award

The teenage singer Charlotte Church was named British artist of the year at the first Classical Brit Awards at the Royal Albert Hall in London last night. Charlotte, 13, from Cardiff, has made a series of CDs and TV appearances.

The violinist Nigel Kennedy received an award for his outstanding contribution to classical music, while Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli's Sacred Arias was voted album of the year. Bryn Terfel, the Welsh baritone, was named male artist of the year, and Argentinian pianist Martha Argerich the top female artist of the year.

Animal campaigner ill

Animal welfare campaigner Baroness (Ziki) Wharton is seriously ill with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Doctors say it was not caused by the strain of it that is linked to mad cow disease. Wharton, 66, is vice-president of the RSPCA.

Kit Kat-eating driver gets a break as police quash fine

A driver fined £20 for eating a Kit Kat at the wheel is to have his penalty cancelled.

Kevin Storey, 33, of Grantham, was spotted eating the chocolate bar while driving at 68mph in a 50mph roadworks area of the M3.

He was given a fixed penalty ticket but police said yesterday that this was 'inappropriate' and agreed to quash the fine.

Huge cigarette haul seized

Customs officers have seized one of the biggest hauls of smuggled cigarettes ever brought into Britain.

It is believed that the ship - the Nika, which docked at Hessle, near Hull, on Friday after sailing from Riga in Latvia - may have been carrying as many as 15 million cigarettes. No one has been arrested in connection with the find, police said last night.

Arm surgery for gun victim

Surgeons were fighting to save the arm of a man blasted with a shotgun in his garden in Caterham, Surrey, yesterday. Police said his attacker fled in a white Ford Sierra.

Kashmir deaths

Twelve people including three Indian security officers and seven separatist guerrillas were killed in gun battles in India's northern state of Jammu and Kashmir yesterday. The death toll in the 10-year dispute over the Muslim region is now estimated to be more than 30,000.

Killer stabs six naval cadets

Five 19-year-old naval cadets have been stabbed to death and a sixth wounded in a single room of a city centre student hostel in the Ukrainian Black Sea port of Odessa. The bodies were found yesterday morning.

Day at races

The Queen yesterday opened Britain's most expensive racecourse grandstand.

The Millennium Grandstand at Newmarket Racecourse in Suffolk cost around £17 million and took 18 months to complete.

webTitle: GM medicine 'risks the lives of diabetics'

fields.headline: GM medicine 'risks the lives of diabetics'
fields.trailText: The lives of thousands of British diabetics were put at risk by multinational drug companies that 'intentionally and maliciously' suppressed information about the potentially lethal side-effects of a genetically engineered medicine, according to claims in US court documents.
fields.body:
The lives of thousands of British diabetics were put at risk by multinational drug companies that 'intentionally and maliciously' suppressed information about the potentially lethal side-effects of a genetically engineered medicine, according to claims in US court documents.

An American lawsuit launched in April against two drug corporations will embarrass Tony Blair, who this year cited synthetic insulin as an example of the benefits of genetically modified technology in producing 'life-saving medicines'.

Yet lawyers representing a victim of the man-made insulin in a class action case in New Mexico claim the genetically engineered medicine leads to 'confusion, distress, coma and even death'. The diabetic bringing the case, Susan Kawulok, said the product caused 'unbearable pain and loss of most use of my arms'.

Although no evidence has yet been put to substantiate claims that the firms acted improperly, the case could send shock waves through the pharmaceutical industry, which has invested millions in genetically engineered products.

Diabetics do not naturally produce enough insulin - a vital hormone that controls the level of sugar in the blood. Hundreds of thousands of British diabetics have to inject insulin each day to survive. Until the Eighties, this insulin came from pigs or cattle, but US drugs giant Eli Lilly and a Danish company, Novo Nordisk, developed a synthetic insulin using genetic engineering. The new medicines were hailed as a scientific breakthrough and branded as 'human' insulin to distinguish them from the animal-derived product.

Some 150,000 diabetics in Britain were switched to the new medicine and currently around 500,000 use these products. Although most diabetics have never had problems with the genetically engineered insulin, a significant minority have complained of serious side-effects.

Unlike the case with natural insulin, some diabetics do not get any warning their blood sugar level has fallen and are more likely to go into comas, known as hypoglycaemic episodes or 'hypos'. Some become violent or pass out while driving.

In February, a diabetic, Mervyn Fletcher, crashed his car in Wolverhampton, killing his mother-in-law, a passenger. He blacked out and swerved, ploughing across a roundabout and shunting another car 20 yards along a grass verge. Only later when he took glucose tablets did he realise what had happened.

Fletcher, a diagnosed diabetic for 15 years, had kept his driving licence. But two years ago his doctor had switched him from animal insulin to the genetically engineered product. At the inquest, Fletcher said: 'I didn't get any warning. I was devastated afterwards that this had happened. I've lost my mother-in-law.'

Last June Alasdair Padmore, a diabetic civil servant, stabbed his friend through the heart during a 'hypo'. He was cleared of murder because of his condition. He 'fought like a man possessed' with police when they tried to arrest him and told them he had no recollection of the incident.

Scientists defending man-made insulin claim there is no scientific evidence it presents a particular risk, and both Eli Lilly and Novo Nordish deny it has harmful effects. But last year it emerged that the British Diabetic Association suppressed a report highlighting the problems of those using synthetic insulin. The report was never published in full because the association believed it was 'too alarmist'.

A spokesman for the British Diabetic Association said: 'We will be watching this case with great interest. It highlights the need for manufacturers to supply animal insulin for the many who need it to survive.'

webTitle: Butterfly sought sun to beat bats

fields.headline: Butterfly sought sun to beat bats
fields.trailText: Spring has sprung, and butterflies are on the wing. And if one US scientist is correct, one of the most pleasing sights of early summer - brilliantly coloured insects fluttering from flower to flower - is thanks to an unexpected creature: the bat.
fields.body:
Spring has sprung, and butterflies are on the wing. And if one US scientist is correct, one of the most pleasing sights of early summer - brilliantly coloured insects fluttering from flower to flower - is thanks to an unexpected creature: the bat.

According to biologist Jayne Yack, bats spurred the evolution of modern-day butterflies by forcing them into the daylight hours to avoid being eaten.

'The general feeling is that butterflies as we know them were once more moth-like, and at some point they moved into the day,' she says.

Yack, a behavioural biologist at Carleton University in Ottawa, began working on this theory when she discovered a pair of ears located on the wings of a small nocturnal tropical butterfly, a Macrosoma heliconiaria, on Barro Colorado Island in Panama.

Yack used a hand-held device to emit sound at frequencies of around 25,000 vibrations per second, well beyond the range of human hearing, but sufficient to send the butterflies swooping. 'Classic bat-avoidance behaviour,' she says.

Ultrasonic hearing isn't unusual in the nocturnal insect world - praying mantises, grasshoppers and certain scarab beetles display the trait - but Yack's discovery marks the first time that such ears have been identified in butterflies.

Macrosoma butterflies are members of a class of butterflies called Hedylids, which are believed to be a 'living ancestor of modern butterflies', say Yack and a zoologist, Professor James Fullard, of Toronto University at Mississauga, writing in Nature.

Like many moths, they have ears sensitive to the squeaks emitted by bats which allows them to pinpoint these predators before being eaten by them.

However, this complex defence was later supplanted by an easier protection, one now adopted by all other butterflies outside this small tropical group of insect: they became day-flying creatures.

In other words, butterflies abandoned their sensitive sonar-detecting ears and began flying during the day as a way of simplifying their fight against bats. 'Dayflight in butterflies results from an intense selection pressure imposed by echo-locating bats more than 50 million years ago,' they state.

In short, the bat invented the modern butterfly.

webTitle: Moaning men push women to back of the health queue

fields.headline: Moaning men push women to back of the health queue
fields.trailText: Men are the real moaners about their health. By contrast, women are much more stoical about their ailments.
fields.body:
Men are the real moaners about their health. By contrast, women are much more stoical about their ailments.

Women have known this for a long time, of course, but now female certainty about the weakness of the male of the species has been supported by scientists. British researchers have found that men are more likely to exaggerate their medical woes, while women underplay them. More worryingly, these researchers say there is a widespread failure among doctors to appreciate this.

As a result, women are often denied proper health care for quite serious conditions - even heart disease - while men are given preferential treatment when they complain of these illnesses.

'It is widely assumed women are more ready than men to report illness and to seek help,' said Professor Sally Macintyre, of the Medical Research Council (MRC) social and public health sciences unit, in Glasgow.

'Men - by contrast - are thought to be reluctant visitors to surgeries. So when they do go, their complaints are somehow presumed to have a more serious content.'

Yet no study has conclusively supported this idea, she said, despite it being entrenched in the minds of medical practitioners. Recent work by her unit, and other groups, has found that it is men who are more likely to complain to doctors about illnesses, while women are more medically reserved.

One analysis carried out by Macintyre, using data collated by researchers at the MRC common cold unit, found that men were significantly more likely to 'over-rate' their sniffles, sore throats, headaches, and shivers compared with ratings given by clinical observers. By contrast, women under-rated their symptoms.

Similarly, a US study of men and women affected by osteoarthritis found that men were significantly more likely than women to report pain, whether or not they were undergoing treatment.

In a recent study of men and women in Scotland, it was found that men were almost twice as likely as females to say they suffered from long-term medical conditions in response to questions about illness in the most recent national census.

Other studies have been less conclusive and have merely found there is no difference between the sexes in their attitudes to illness. Yet it is still commonly assumed by doctors, surgeons, nurses and health workers that women complain more often about illness than men.

This 'tendency' is blamed on the fact that women are supposed to have greater concerns about their bodies because they undergo menstruation, childbirth and the menopause, while men are conditioned by society to be strong and stoical. 'It is an attitude that permeates the health service though there is no evidence to support it,' added Macintyre. 'Indeed, it points the other way.'

The assumption that men are stoical can also have serious consequences as researchers on both sides of the Atlantic have revealed. In one recent US study, male and female actors performed realistic scripts in which they played the parts of patients suffering from chest pains and shortness of breath. They were then examined by a group of 192 doctors who were asked to describe what they would do for their patients in similar circumstances.

The results were striking. The doctors plumped for two main diagnoses: either the patient had a severe cardiac problem or a psychosomatic condition in which emotional disturbance, not physical illness, was the cause. Their choice had a great deal to do with the gender of the actors.

'When confronted with the same presenting symptoms, vital signs, and test results depicted in a professionally acted way, physicians were much less likely to arrive at a cardiac diagnosis in women, treat women medically, believe treatments were necessary or to make health education and lifestyle change recommendations such as quitting smoking,' state the researchers from the New England Research Institute in Boston. By contrast, the doctors were more likely to rate women 'patients' as suffering from emotional problems and to suggest psychiatric treatment. In other words, if you complain of chest pains, you get intense cardiac care - if you are a man. If you are a woman, you could end up undergoing psychiatric treatment.

'Women aren't supposed to complain of heart disease and so doctors are less prepared to accept that they have it,' said Macintyre. 'We make all sorts of assumptions, based on unsupported stereotypes - for instance, that men are silent stoics, while women are whingers - but do not test them out before we act on them. We have got to change that kind of thinking.'

Myths of medicine

Medical mythology is not confined to ideas about female 'hypochondria' and male medical stoicism. There have been many examples of health authorities assuming a policy must be true, only to find it failing scientific scrutiny, such as:

Cot deaths

For years doctors assumed if parents laid children face down this would prevent them choking during sleep. This has been shown to be a possible cause of cot deaths.

Bike-ed

This campaign was to improve cycling safety for children in Australia. Serious accident rates began to climb. Researchers say the campaign encouraged youngsters to take to the roads before they were old enough.

Sunscreen use

Attempts to encourage people to use powerful sunblocking lotions to cut skin cancer rates have backfired. Individuals, believing they were now invulnerable, stayed so long in the open air they started to suffer early symptoms of skin tumours.

Toughened beer glasses

British breweries recently introduced stronger beer glasses to reduce serious cuts suffered by bar staff. The trial failed because the glasses still shattered.

Source: Dr Mark Pettigrew, MRC social and public health sciences unit, Glasgow

webTitle: Arkan's gang has stolen Turners held by Serb gang

fields.headline: Arkan's gang has stolen Turners held by Serb gang
fields.standfirst: Tate masterpieces were used in drugs deal by Serbian criminals, investigators say
fields.trailText: The two Turner masterpieces stolen from the collection of the Tate Gallery while on loan to a gallery in Germany are in the possession of Serbian gangsters connected to Balkan war criminals, investigators believe.
fields.body:
The two Turner masterpieces stolen from the collection of the Tate Gallery while on loan to a gallery in Germany are in the possession of Serbian gangsters connected to Balkan war criminals, investigators believe.

The two paintings, worth £12 million each, were stolen from the Schirn Kunsthalle, a gallery in Frankfurt, in July 1994. Thieves broke into the heavily guarded complex while alarms were turned off to allow security guards to make patrols. One guard was overpowered, tied up and gagged, and the two paintings - plus a third by the German Romantic artist Caspar David Friedrich - were snatched from their places on the wall. The thieves made their getaway in a car parked nearby.

There have been numerous reported sightings of the paintings, but their whereabouts have never been confirmed. However, art investigators have now told The Observer that the two Turners - Shade and Darkness: Evening of the Deluge and Light and Colour: Morning after the Deluge - are believed to be in the possession of Serbian criminals linked to the death squad leader Arkan, whose band of guerrillas was responsible for some of the worst atrocities during the Balkan conflict.

Arkan, who was shot dead in a restaurant in central Belgrade last January, was deeply involved in a wide variety of criminal enterprises, including drugs trafficking and the smuggling of arms into Serbia in contravention of UN sanctions. Arkan's murder started what appears to be a feud in the Serbian underworld.

Police and investigators hope that the violence among Arkan's former comrades - at least five have been killed in recent months - will help them reclaim the missing Turners.

'When I heard that Arkan had been killed I thought immediately that 2000 might finally be the year when we get these paintings back,' said Mark Dalrymple, a fine art loss adjuster with Tyler & Co who has been on the trail of the paintings since they were stolen. Police in Germany said they were unable to comment on their inquiries.

The Frankfurt theft was carried out by a German gang, but the paintings are thought to have changed hands a number of times in the weeks after the raid. The suggestion that the Turners were stolen to order by a collector has been dismissed by investigators. 'It is a fantasy that people steal paintings for somebody's private hoard,' said Helmut Seeman, managing director of the Schirn gallery.

Investigators believe the paintings were used as collateral for drugs deals - especially since a £160,000 reward for their return has been ignored. 'Whoever is holding them is well-heeled,' said Dalrymple.

Police say many of the gangs operating in Frankfurt and the north of Germany have Serbian connections. Much of the West's heroin is brought in through the Balkans from opium-refining laboratories in Turkey and Iran. Turkish gangs - often with London-based associates - pass the drugs on to a series of Balkan middlemen. A shipment can change hands a dozen times before reaching Germany or the UK, its value increasing with each step. It is thought the Turners were taken as part payment by members of Arkan's gang for one such batch of drugs.

Most were looted at the height of the Yugoslav conflict and hoarded until hostilities ended.

The raiders appeared to have targeted the painting specifically. Detectives from Yorkshire police said that they thought drugs gangs may have been responsible for the theft. Two men were recently convicted for the robbery and the painting was recovered.

The two Turners stolen in Frankfurt are key works, known as masterpieces of late European Romanticism. Turner conceived of the paintings as a pair in 1843 to depict the biblical story of the Deluge and to illustrate the German poet Goethe's theories on the emotional impact of colour.

The first painting, in ominous blues and blacks, depicts a hazy vision of animals entering the Ark. The second painting - of Moses after the storm has passed - is considered a classic example of Turner's ground-breaking use of colour.

The global criminal trade in art is second only to drugs in value, with £3 billion of art stolen each year. Huge numbers of paintings are missing, including 355 Picassos, 271 Mirós and 250 Chagalls. According to insurers, only one in five is recovered by police.

webTitle: Midwife crisis puts home births at risk

fields.headline: Midwife crisis puts home births at risk
fields.standfirst: Campaigners fear for safety of unsupervised deliveries as staff shortages hit hospitals
fields.trailText: An increasing number of women are having babies at home without medical supervision because of the acute shortage of midwives. Some are giving birth with nobody else present at all, because of a law that bans anyone not medically qualified, including the father, from attending.
fields.body:
An increasing number of women are having babies at home without medical supervision because of the acute shortage of midwives. Some are giving birth with nobody else present at all, because of a law that bans anyone not medically qualified, including the father, from attending.

A growing rejection of 'high-tech' hospital births - including Caesareans, forceps deliveries and large dosages of drugs - means home births are becoming ever more popular. However, staff shortages mean that many hospitals are refusing to send midwives to home births, sometimes even after labour has begun.

'We get more calls now because so many trusts are saying they won't send you a midwife,' said Beverley Beech, chairman of the Association for Improvements in the Maternity Services (Aims), which helps women arrange home birth services.

Fewer than two per cent of British births take place at home, but there are huge regional variations. In Torbay, the figure is around 20 per cent, while in Northern Ireland it is below one per cent.

There is no legal requirement on hospitals to provide a home birth service, and many are cutting back on it. Problems have been reported in Oxford, Reading, Wokingham, Durham and west Wales. Last month a Devon hospital wrote to mothers to cancel all home-birth services.

There are no figures on how many home births are unsupervised, but midwives are convinced the number is rising. 'The women having births at home alone are probably few in number, but the fact that they exist is a sad indictment of the NHS,' said Mary Cronk, an independent midwife who sits on the council of the Royal College of Midwives. 'It's increasing.'

Josie Rhys was determined to have her second baby at home after a traumatic experience in hospital with her first one. 'When I was pregnant again, I told them I refused to go in, but they wouldn't provide me with a midwife at home. They kept sending me a weekly letter with thinly veiled threats that they would take legal action if I didn't agree to come in.'

In the end, Rhys - whose name has been changed - had the baby at home with no midwife, attended by her husband, a plumber. 'He hadn't even done a first aid course. It says something if a plumber can do a better job than the professionals,' said Rhys.

However, her husband faces prosecution under the NHS Act, which makes it illegal for a person other than a registered midwife or doctor to attend a birth unless it is a sudden emergency. In the Eighties, a father, Brian Radley, was prosecuted for attending the birth of his child after his wife refused to go into hospital. The penalty was £500, paid anonymously by a doctor disgusted at the actions of the hospital.

Often women are promised that they will be provided with a midwife for a home birth but they are let down at the last minute. 'Women who have booked a home birth phone the hospital to say they are in labour and they're told to come in,' said Cronk. 'The woman has to make an awful decision about what to do. It's appalling that this is happening.'

Hazel, from north London, had booked a home birth with Homerton Hospital but was let down when she went into labour. After her waters broke, she phoned to request a midwife but was told she could not have one because of staff shortages.

'They hadn't warned me that could happen. After having my second child in hospital, I decided I'd never have a baby in hospital again,' said Hazel, who reluctantly gave birth in hospital.

Alison Hartley, from Newham in London, is expecting her third child. She is 18 weeks pregnant and wants a home birth, but Newham General Hospital has said it cannot guarantee a midwife. 'I'm really dreadfully un-happy about it and very worried. I've been pushed into a corner,' she said.

A spokeswoman from the Department of Health said: 'We are aware that there is a shortage of midwives in the NHS. That is why last year we launched a recruitment campaign encouraging nurses and midwives to return to the service. Over the past year, over 480 midwives have shown an interest in returning to the NHS.'

Aims: 01753 652781

www.aims.org.uk
