webTitle: Killer drug threat from mafia gangs

fields.headline: Killer drug threat from mafia gangs
fields.trailText: Law enforcement officials across Europe are bracing themselves for a massive assault on the drug market by the Russian mafia.
fields.body:
Law enforcement officials across Europe are bracing themselves for a massive assault on the drug market by the Russian mafia.

The collapse of traditional cocaine cartels in Colombia, combined with a crackdown on domestic drug production in their homeland, has led the Russian gangs to expand their international operations. Last week Colombia's national police chief, General Rosso José Serrano, admitted his success against Colombian gangs had left the Russian mobsters poised to become some of the top players in the drug world.

'The former Soviet states possess the ability to flood the world with cannabis products, cheap, highly dangerous synthetic drugs, and heroin manufactured in Central Asia,' he said. 'Their wide-ranging contacts with other criminal syndicates mean they can deliver virtually any narcotic to any interested consumer anywhere in Western Europe.'

Germany and Finland have reported increasing quantities of cannabis from independent states of the former Soviet Union appearing on the streets. Dozens of Russian-run illicit laboratories producing ecstasy and amphetamines are springing up in Eastern Europe.

Although Russia is producing large quantities of heroin, the biggest fear is that the gangs will begin exporting and selling large quantities of fentanyl, a synthetic analgesic 100 times more powerful than heroin, which has already created tens of thousands of addicts in Moscow.

Fentanyl is so potent that 100 grams can provide two million doses. The main active ingredient can be up to 1,000 times more powerful than heroin, greatly increasing the risk of accidental overdose. A grain the size of a sugar granule is enough to cause a user to stop breathing instantly. Death can be so sudden that many victims are found with needles still in their arms.

Because fentanyl mimics the action of heroin, its presence often goes unnoticed. Waves of sudden overdoses among addicts in Scotland and Bristol could be linked to drug batches that have been enhanced with the synthetic compound.

Criminals can boost their profits by mixing low-grade heroin with tiny amounts of the cheap-to-produce synthetic substitute. The end product gives the same 'buzz' as high-grade heroin but can be manufactured at a fraction of the cost. The drug has already been tracked to Germany and use is spreading across Europe.

In recent years, Russian gangs have become the chief suppliers of illegal precurser chemicals needed in the manufacture of drugs such as ecstasy, amphetamines and LSD. They have now realised they can greatly increase their profits by using the same chemicals to make the drugs themselves. Dozens of Russian-run illicit laboratories are springing up across East Europe manufacturing traditional drugs as well as the new heroin products.

webTitle: Africa's Aids fate hangs in balance

fields.headline: Africa's Aids fate hangs in balance
fields.trailText: Two British researchers were this weekend enmeshed in one of the most bitter scientific controversies of recent years. Virologist Gordon Stewart, of Glasgow University, and pharmacologist Andrew Herxheimer, from Oxford, have joined an Aids advisory board, set up by South African President Thabo Mbeki, which was today concluding its second day of deliberations.
fields.body:
Two British researchers were this weekend enmeshed in one of the most bitter scientific controversies of recent years. Virologist Gordon Stewart, of Glasgow University, and pharmacologist Andrew Herxheimer, from Oxford, have joined an Aids advisory board, set up by South African President Thabo Mbeki, which was today concluding its second day of deliberations.

The panel - meeting in Pretoria - has provoked widespread political and scientific fury because more than half its 33 members are medical heretics. These include US scientists Peter Duesberg and David Rasnick, who deny HIV causes Aids.

The involvement of these dissidents in developing Aids policy in a country in which one in 10 of its 43 million people are HIV-positive, and where rates are expected to rocket to more than 25 per cent this decade, has dismayed scientists and politicians globally.

Virtually all experts agree Aids is caused by HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) and not poverty, malnutrition and poor sanitation, as the dissidents claim. Dave Scondras, one of the few orthodox scientists on the panel, warned that Mbeki had to accept scientific studies. 'The panel should allow the President to move on ... People who deny HIV have never treated Aids, had Aids patients or gone to the funerals of friends with Aids,' he said.

Mbeki's bizarre flirtation with the Duesberg heresy was apparently born of a late-night encounter with the dissidents during a presidential cyber-surfing expedition. This led Mbeki to write a letter to various heads of state, including Clinton, in which he compared the treatment of Aids dissidents with the burning of heretics at the stake.

'The day may not be far off when we will once again see books burnt and their authors immolated by fire by those who believe that they may have a duty to conduct a holy campaign against the infidels,' he wrote. Horrified US state officials first thought the letter a bizarre hoax. When they saw it was genuine, they leaked it to the the Washington Post.

Just how much sympathy Mbeki's extraordinary views will get from the two Britons on his panel is not hard to judge. From Gordon Stewart, he is likely to get a great deal. Stewart, an emeritus professor at Glasgow University, has made no secret of his open support for Duesberg's stance, and claims there is a conspiracy to prevent such views being made public.

'Colleagues and I attempting to publish have met an unholy alliance intent on rejecting any papers that offer serious criticisms of the orthodoxy,' he says. 'The mainstream journals and media - whenever they are presented with reasonable doubts about Aids - close ranks like regimented clams.'

In fact, Stewart's anti-HIV views were given extraordinary prominence by the Sunday Times in the Nineties when then editor Andrew Neil claimed Britain had only two heroes 'when it comes to the truth about Aids'. One was Gordon Stewart. (The other was the paper's science writer Neville Hodgkinson.)

Then scientists developed drug cocktails, called protease inhibitors, which disrupted HIV replication and halted the development of Aids in patients. The fact that an anti-HIV drug could be used successfully to treat Aids victims made nonsense of the claims of Stewart and his supporters that the virus had no link with the disease. But they continue to peddle their conspiracy.

The second British scientist on Mbeki's panel is in a very different class. Andrew Herxheimer is a respected pharmacologist - based at the UK Cochrane Centre in Oxford, part of the NHS Research and Development Programme - who believes radical changes should be made to pharmaceutical licensing regulations in order to make them cheaper to manufacture in the Third World.

He has also criticised Glaxo Wellcome, manufacturer of the anti-Aids medicine AZT, for not releasing data from trials with the drug.

Herxheimer has come to the attention of Mbeki and his advisers. They are horrified at the cost of the drug - which is known to help block the transmission of HIV from infected mothers to their children - and have rejected requests for it to be given to pregnant women, even though one in three expectant mothers are now believed to be HIV positive in many parts of South Africa. Many observers believe Mbeki is in denial. By rejecting any link between HIV and Aids, he can therefore avoid taking the necessary, extremely expensive actions. Medical experts are outraged. 'South Africans are burying husbands, wives, relations and friends every day,' said Ashraf Grimwood, chair of the country's Nationals Aids Convention in New Scientist last week. 'People are terrified.'

The influence of scientists such as Herxheimer, and other 'orthodox' panel members such as Scondras and the French scientist and co-discoverer of HIV, Luc Montagnier, will therefore be crucial in dissuading Mbeki from his current Aids policy, and in saving thousands of lives.

It would also stem widespread criticism of Mbeki. Professor Mamphela Ramphele of Cape Town University, a doctor, has warned there is a 'lack of respect for a scientific base for health care planning' in South Africa coupled with a 'subtle but visible anti-intellectualism seeping into the body politic'. The government stance on Aids was 'nothing short of irresponsibility, for which history will judge it severely'.

What worries many intellectuals in South Africa is the manner in which Mbeki, after centralising political power in an expanded presidency, has isolated himself within a phalanx of 'yes men' and has shown himself intolerant of press criticism. Meanwhile, Aids continues to ravage his country.

webTitle: Tourism faces slump as Britons fly out and visitors fail to fly in

fields.headline: Tourism faces slump as Britons fly out and visitors fail to fly in
fields.trailText: The relentless rise of the pound means Britain's hotels, restaurants and attractions are suffering one of their worst years. As more Britons head overseas, fewer foreigners are arriving in Britain and those that do make it are spending less.
fields.body:
As the engines of your holiday plane rev up and you count the extra cash you will have available to spend in the taverna this summer, spare a thought for the British tourist industry.

The relentless rise of the pound means Britain's hotels, restaurants and attractions are suffering one of their worst years. As more Britons head overseas, fewer foreigners are arriving in Britain and those that do make it are spending less.

The downturn is so sharp that the British Tourist Authority has slashed its forecasts. Britain could slip from fifth in the international tourism league after the US, Spain, France and Italy to sixth and be overtaken by Germany.

Tourism officials had predicted a 3 per cent rise in visits this year to 26.5 million and 5 per cent growth in spending to £13.6bn. But the number of tourists and visitor spending rose by a meagre 1.5 per cent in January and February, and privately officials do not expect the figures to improve greatly over the summer.

Hotels, foreign language schools and restaurants say they fear their worst year. The manager of one leading language group in central London told the Observer: 'Registrations are down and students are complaining that they can hardly afford to eat sandwiches, let alone buy books they need. It is very difficult. Business is suffering and we are not alone.'

The Millennium Dome has blamed the strong pound for disappointing visitor numbers, particularly from France. Only two million people have visited the site, well below the figures the attraction needs to break even.

The story from hoteliers is the same. Managers at leading chains say that, while business travel is holding up, fewer people are taking weekend city breaks. The rising pound and slumping euro have had a particularly strong effect on US visitors. 'Britain is losing market share to France and Italy, which have become 15 to 20 per cent cheaper for a US visitor over the past year,' a BTA spokesman said.

Major European currencies have devalued against sterling by up to 30 per cent in recent years. In the past year alone the euro has slumped from nearly 72p to the pound to 60p.

Barbara Clark, of the Scottish Tourist Board, said: 'A lot of concern has been expressed from tour operators. We are concerned as long as the economic situation remains as it is.'

But the number of tourists and visitor spending rose by a meagre 1.5 per cent in January and February, and privately officials do not expect the figures to improve greatly over the summer. Hotels, foreign language schools and restaurants say they fear their worst year. The manager of one leading language group in central London told the Observer: 'Registrations are down and students are complaining that they can hardly afford to eat sandwiches, let alone buy books they need. It is very difficult. Business is suffering and we are not alone.' The Millennium Dome has blamed the strong pound for disappointing visitor numbers, particularly from France. Only two million people have visited the site, well below the figures the attraction needs to break even. The story from hoteliers is the same. Managers at leading chains say that, while business travel is holding up, fewer people are taking weekend city breaks. The rising pound and slumping euro have had a particularly strong effect on US visitors. 'Britain is losing market share to France and Italy, which have become 15 to 20 per cent cheaper for a US visitor over the past year,' a BTA spokesman said. Major European currencies have devalued against sterling by up to 30 per cent in recent years. In the past year alone the euro has slumped from nearly 72p to the pound to 60p. Barbara Clark, of the Scottish Tourist Board, said: 'A lot of concern has been expressed from tour operators. We are concerned as long as the economic situation remains as it is.'

fields.headline: Scotland in war on narcotics
fields.trailText: Drug deaths in Scotland last year are expected to exceed 300 for the first time. The figures have been released before the Scottish Executive's new drugs strategy, to be announced this week.
fields.body:
Drug deaths in Scotland last year are expected to exceed 300 for the first time. The figures have been released before the Scottish Executive's new drugs strategy, to be announced this week.

Scotland has an exceptional drug problem, with fatalities per head of population far higher than in England. Labour pursued the issue in the Holyrood election. The Drug Enforcement Agency they promised is now running.

This week the deputy Minister for Justice Angus McKay will reveal two new bodies to help the fight. In a speech to 32,000 school children at Glasgow's SECC he will announce a National Drug Misuses Research Programme.

It will be charged with co-ordinating drug-related research in Scotland and assessing international studies. The aim is that Scotland has the most up-to-date intelligence on drugs. The second development will be a prevention and effectiveness unit. This will monitor money spent on drug treatment and prevention activities. Civil servants say this will ensure no aid is wasted.

The Scottish Executive says it spends £250 million annually coping with the drug problem. This figure covers all government departments, the police, the health service and specific drug agencies.

fields.headline: The Square window
fields.standfirst: Old pictures, new views - the refurbished National Portrait Gallery is a triumph
fields.trailText: Old pictures, new views - the refurbished National Portrait Gallery is a triumph
fields.body:
Nobody would seriously suggest that portrait-painting is going through a great renaissance in Britain. Quite the contrary. There is something inherently uncomfortable, even kitsch, about trying to represent contemporary fame dressed in a double-breasted suit in paint on canvas. And yet the National Portrait Gallery is turning into one of the runaway success stories of contemporary museum-keeping: it has put on at least 250,000 visitors a year since its current director Charles Saumarez Smith arrived in 1994. With more than a million visitors a year the NPG is now in the first division of museums - up there with the Science Museum and the National Gallery.

Last week the Queen opened its new extension, giving the NPG a restaurant and a spectacular view, the two items at the top of any ambitious museum director's wish list, as well as extra gallery space. Saumarez Smith was lucky, or skilful enough to hit the Lottery-funders at just the right moment to sail through the funding process and to pluck out of thin air a sponsor, Christopher Ondaatje, with the enthusiasm and the cash to make up the shortfall.

Clearly it can't be the quality of most of the newly commissioned works that the gallery has acquired that is attracting people. When their subjects have faded from the newspapers they are likely to end up in the same dusty obscurity once reserved for those job lots of Tudor and Stewart monarchs painted by the yard to fill far-flung corridors in the House of Lords.

John Major, for example, is a man who was clearly never intended to be rendered in oil. His portrait in the NPG, showing the former PM on a particularly lurid sofa, demonstrates exactly why eighteenth-century artists depicted politicians in togas and laurel wreaths.

The portrait gallery has played a poor artistic hand shrewdly. It has skilfully flirted with the culture of celebrity - an Elizabeth Taylor exhibition opens in a week - without actually turning into Madame Tussaud's. What has really propelled the NPG forward is the way it has approached its building. In its early days architecture was the fledgling gallery's biggest handicap. Now it is one of its major assets.

It acquired its site in St Martin's Place in 1896, under the nose of its older neighbour, the National Gallery, and then only on the condition that its architect Ewan Christian designed half of the façade to look exactly like the National Gallery. Not surprisingly this had the effect of making the NPG utterly invisible, and it has suffered from a low physical profile ever since. Visitor numbers - 12,600 in the first year - were not helped by the fact that the collection was confined to the top floor, up the vertiginous stairs that Christian lovingly crafted in a eccentric blend of gothic and romanesque.

Recent directors have brought in a succession of architects to try to make sense of this difficult and awkward layout. The first of these was the pig-tailed, kilt-wearing Roderick Gradidge, an architect best known for his pubs, who tried to make something of the entrance hall. That has been swept away now as part of a wholesale reorganisation. John Miller and Partners, now completing the Tate Britain's new galleries, created a new secondary entrance and opened an elegant temporary exhibition gallery which helped to demonstrate that the NPG is not just the service entrance of the National Gallery, but a place worth visiting in its own right. Piers Gough strikingly restructured the Victorian displays without making them look ridiculous.

And now in a dazzling series of architectural moves, Edward Jones and Jeremy Dixon, architects of the Royal Opera House, have finally cracked the conundrum of a building in which 75 per cent of visitors never set foot above the first floor. The secret of the jigsaw puzzle was to free the NPG from the uneasy embrace of its neighbouring elephant. Not only did it look like an adjunct to the National Gallery, the only way it could expand was into its service yard - but it couldn't do that without the National Gallery's agreement. Jones and Dixon suggested a swap.

So, the National Gallery got the slice of NPG facing St Martin's Place, and in return the NPG got the right to develop the yard. Jones and Dixon have turned that yard into a breathtaking indoor white space, a slot that rises the full height of the building. It is the key to making the whole building work as a continuous circuit, rather than a set of discrete floors. The architects move you from the dark wood and carved-stone constraints of the old entrance hall, and usher you into the new space that explodes overhead. The sudden decompression propels you upward. A vertiginous escalator climbs all the way up.

Once visitors are at the top, they are rewarded by a restaurant with an even better view than the Tate Modern's in Bankside. From this angle you can see Nelson, but not his column, creating the impression that he is walking on water, and the London Eye millennium wheel away to the left.

If you choose not to eat, a series of stairs brings you down through the existing and new gallery spaces. There is a useful new room for the gallery's collection of Tudor portraits, vivid splashes of colour against dark walls, and another for the growing twentieth-century collection. Downstairs there is a handsome lecture theatre.

Architecturally they are a series of very different experiences that reflect the diversity of the NPG's holdings, running the gamut of architectural emotions from high seriousness to seduction. It is a transformation that is modest in its scale, and yet highly effective, a lesson in intelligent planning rather than a bombastic gesture.

Unlike some new museums you will not come to the National Portrait Gallery just for the architecture, elegant though it is. But it is certainly the architecture that manages to make the collection look good - better in some cases, perhaps, than it deserves.

webTitle: Excuse me while I miss the sky

fields.headline: Excuse me while I miss the sky
fields.standfirst: Constable's cloud studies tell you little about the weather but a lot about him
fields.trailText: Constable's Clouds
fields.body:
Constable's CloudsWalker Art Gallery, Liverpool, until 16 July, then National Gallery of Scotland, 11 August-29 October

You remember the scene: that bend in the river where the silver Stour glistens and the wheels of the hay wain barely trouble the water. All is still in the late summer heat. From the dog on the bank to the man in his cart, not a leaf stirs, not even a fly. Far above the treetops, the sun rises high in the Suffolk air, shedding its glow over Constable's paradise. Or does it? Look again and you will see that half of England's most reproduced painting is a dispiriting expanse of overcast sky.

It is entirely possible that people love The Hay Wain for its moody sky, that rainy, white glare that would in reality hurt the sight. But it seems more likely that we idealise Constable's weather, remembering it as consistent with the warm tranquillity below. In fact, it's a mass of muggy cumuli and shower-laden clouds, with no hope of a breeze to blow them away. Motionless, congested, thick with overlaid oil paint - this is the characteristic Constable sky.

Of all the English artists who ever painted summer, Constable is the only one for whom it never turned out sunny. There are no blue skies in his art, no cloudless days, no unfiltered sunlight. You get the feeling he would have been bored to death by a spell of high pressure. For more than 30 years, he stood in Dedham Vale, on Hampstead Heath or by the sea at Brighton, scrutinising the skies for less than clement weather.

Of the 80 works in this show, painted while droplets spattered his palette, only a handful are what he called 'skying' studies. But clouds dominate his art to such a degree that practically any show of his pictures might be called Constable's Clouds.

So why did he paint them so often and, given that fact, why are his clouds so oddly unimpressive, so little like the ever-changing expressions on the face of English weather?

Constable's clouds are completely static. They do not scud or race; they rarely burst with rain or part to reveal a sudden sunny shaft. They are never haloed with light or threaded with silver; they don't hover or spiral or even float. Far from being nebulous, they look claggy and solid. In fact, they don't much resemble vaporous forms at all.

Yet Constable is routinely praised as England's great weatherman, from whose paintings you can deduce the wind speed, cloud type or degree of rainfall at a given time and place on that nineteenth-century day. The curators of this show have even included a collection of meteorological instruments as if to reinforce the supposedly scientific accuracy of his work, a reputation which falters when you notice the absence of basic facts like afternoon shadows or motion during squalls.

Constable may have noted the climatic details on the back of his pictures, but you only have to look at these images to see that he was not a realist. Flatford Mill, which he loved, enjoys a kind of endless summer whereas Brighton, which he loathed, is punished with rotten weather. A 'fresh morning' on Hampstead Heath will become a turgid and sultry picture, the clouds too tightly packed for the movement of air. Read the accompanying captions and you soon see a parallel between Constable's oil sketches and his private letters, both of them expressive of mercurial moods.

Constable, of course, knew the emotional value of weather: the sky, as he famously put it, is 'the chief organ of sentiment' in any landscape. One explanation for his prolific cloud studies is that they amounted to a handy anthology from which he could select the moods for his showpiece paintings. Certainly, it's true that he could and did cheer up the weather for commercial purposes, just as the 'finished' paintings, with their heavy jewellery of highlights, dewdrops and scumbled silver flecks, look a thousand times more artificial than the quick, organic sketches.

Salisbury Cathedral from the Meadows, for example, has exactly this pick-and-mix appearance. In the foreground, Constable reverses The Hay Wain scenario, so that dog, man and cart face from left to right. The river is his standard gleam of flake-white streaks, curving towards the cathedral.

But above them is the most contrived melodrama that he ever painted: a madness of thick puffs, filthy cumuli and caramel-coloured storm clouds, upstaged only by the rainbow that ascends the canvas like a giant, polished banister.

To see this massive set-piece surrounded by small, informal sketches is to realise that Constable is nearly always better at six inches than six feet. Restricted to a tiny sheet of paper, he can't go quite so wild with the busy spatters and skirmishes that clog his larger works.

With a few liquid sweeps of oil, he can convey a Brighton deluge or diffuse the evening sun in a fine, light haze that is more persuasive than any of his grandstand effects, in which the subject is apt to disappear beneath a quagmire of oil paint.

Oil paint is both the medium and the message of his pictures. Where other artists might use transparent watercolour to catch the swift transitions of weather, Constable chooses the heaviest, slowest-drying paint. In the two hours it generally took him to fix each of these cloudscapes, the skies might have changed a hundred times - but never in his art. Oil paint suits Constable's moodiness, his conservatism, his devotion to stability. It suits his desire to control the weather.

webTitle: The Ottoman Empire rises again... in Salford

fields.headline: The Ottoman Empire rises again... in Salford
fields.trailText: La Bayadère, Paris Opera Ballet, Lowry Centre, Salford
fields.body:
La Bayadère Paris Opera Ballet, Lowry Centre, Salford

'An air of theatricality, festivity and anticipation will be generated,' promised the Lowry Centre's architect, Michael Wilford, when he submitted his plans. True to his word, the finished building gleams enticingly in the late spring sunlight, reflecting the sky and the water of Salford Quays on the outskirts of Manchester.

A corps of cleaners, workmen and ballet-dancers swept through the working areas before last Thursday's opening night, the first performance in England for 17 years by the Paris Opera Ballet. They brought Rudolf Nureyev's spectacular version of La Bayadère, his last production for the company before his death in 1993. The ballet, which shows off the dancers in depth, also serves to display the theatre that frames it. The Lowry's Lyric boasts the largest stage in Britain outside London. Its purple auditorium perfectly offsets La Bayadère 's glowing oriental costumes in Balinese blues, saffron yellow and crimson.

The Hallé Orchestra played Minkus's 1877 score (reworked by John Lanchbery) under the baton of Vello Pähn, director of the Paris Opera Orchestra when Nureyev's production was first mounted. The Hallé gave Minkus good value, enabling him to be poignant instead of rum-ti-tum. For all that La Bayadère is set in India, there is nothing authentically eastern in music or dance.

This production, with designs by Ezio Frigerio, drawn from ancient monuments in the Ottoman and Indian empires, is an exotic fantasy for stay-at-homes stuck in a cold climate.

Nureyev retrieved numbers that Russian choreographers had added over the century or so since the ballet's St Petersburg premiere, including a solo of his own making for the hero, Solor. He could not supply the missing final act for the ballet, however, so it ends, as did the Kirov's production, with Solor's vision of the Kingdom of the Shades, set in a tropical paradise garden.

The Paris Opera Ballet's dancers were not as spectacularly accurate as the Kirov at their best. La Bayadère is part of an eclectic POB repertoire rather than a signature ballet, and the refinements of Nureyev's coaching before his last illness seem to be dissipating.

The 32 bayadères in the Kingdom of the Shades were militarily abrupt, the soloists (and their tempi) unyielding. This was hardly a transcendent experience, especially with a Nikiya seemingly incapable of forgiveness.

Agnès Letestu is Darcey Bussell's age and height, though her career has not been as fast-track. An inner restraint limits her appeal; she lacks confidence in lifts, although her technique is beautifully unforced. Her Nikiya looks emotionally damaged from the start - no contest for her ruthless rival, Gamzatti, danced with imperious glee by Aurélie Dupont.

Jean-Guillaume Bart, the company's newest étoile , seemed to have little problem in choosing between them. He acts with his cheekbones and dances academically, rather than with the fire Nureyev imparted to his immediate successors.

Not the greatest performance by the Paris Opera Ballet, then, but a flawless debut for the Lowry Centre's main theatre.

fields.headline: Righteous brother
fields.trailText: Common
fields.body:
Common is known as one of the most enlightened, liberal-minded rappers on the planet. Yet his new album Like Water for Chocolate includes a track called 'Dooinit', in which he tells a rival MC: '...in a circle of faggots your name is mentioned'. That doesn't seem very enlightened.

'Well, that's one of my battle lines,' he argues, referring to the hip-hop phenomenon in which rappers 'battle' each other with verbal attacks. 'Where I'm from, being a homosexual ain't glorified,' he says. 'I ain't there to judge, but that's street talk and I don't think I'm politically correct anyway. That's not meant as an act of agression. It's part of the reality of everyday speech - in a way it's less hypocritical than all that PC stuff.'

It's a spurious explanation, but the sexism and homophobia so commonplace in American rap will always grate on the ears outside the battle context. It grates even more in Common's case because he is so conscious elsewhere on his gem of a second album. The opening track 'Time Travelling' sees him berate his macho uncle for not confronting his domestic problems. He satirises a hustler on 'A Film Called Pimp', and 'Song for Assata' is a moving tribute to exiled Black Panther Assata Shakur.

But the greatest strength of Like Water... is the awareness Common shows of his own flaws and contradictions. On 'The Question' he raps: 'If I'm an intellectual... I can't be sexual?/ If I wanna uh uh... does that mean I don't respect ya?'

Is that rhyme based on personal experience? 'In between my last record, One Day It'll All Make Sense, and this album, I had a lot of females saying to me: "I thought that you was this type of guy, you were conscious", and I was like, well first of all, I ain't perfect, and secondly, just because I'm down with the struggle, that don't mean that I can't have a social life.'

Yet his respect for women has marked Common out as a less imperfect MC than most. Almost uniquely, his two albums have had women on the cover - with their clothes on. The cover of Like Water for Chocolate is superb: a 1956 Gordon Parks photo of a young black woman in Alabama, dressed for church, drinking from a 'Colored Only' water fountain.

The album's title was inspired by the Lara Esquivel novel, but Common adds: 'There's a personal side too because the water represents the sign in me, Pisces. Chocolate is the soul, the blackness in the music.'

Stylistically, Like Water... is broader and richer than its predecessor, with Common rapping over anything from Afrobeat to funky disco to gospel-tinged R&B. 'I feel that rappers can be modern musicians and as such our minds have to be open to all sorts of music,' he says. 'I was definitely thinking on a world music level here. I listen to Buena Vista Social Club, Fela Kuti, Massive Attack, Omar...

'I wanted to put all of those elements into my music with no limitations. I want the brothers on the street to respect my music, but being true to myself is the most important thing for me.'

 Like Water for Chocolate is out now on Universal Records. Common plays the Jazz Café, London, on Wednesday and Thursday

Yet his new album Like Water for Chocolate includes a track called 'Dooinit', in which he tells a rival MC: '...in a circle of faggots your name is mentioned'. That doesn't seem very enlightened. fields.headline: Sounds like... squashed biscuit
fields.standfirst: Sonic Boom features a dazzling array of hissings, scrapings, explosions and scratches that erase memories of Muzak
fields.trailText: Sonic Boom features a dazzling array of hissings, scrapings, explosions and scratches that erase memories of Muzak
fields.body:
Sonic Boom Hayward Gallery/ QEH, London SE1

RPO Barbican, London EC2

Proms Season 2000

One of the first exhibits you see in the Hayward Gallery's Sonic Boom: The Art of Sound show is an old wind-up gramophone. On the turntable, coated in squashed biscuit and complete with His Master's Voice dog, a disc idly spins round under a bumping needle. The only sound emitted from the curvaceous brass horn is a hiss, like steam from a pressure cooker. In Sonic Boom Live, a concert to celebrate this pioneering exhibition, the artists whose work it was (Project Dark) went a step further. As the dénouement of what has become a cult performance of video and ear-piercing swishes, scratches and scrapings, they set light to a record-player which exploded to a show of jumping-jack fireworks then fizzled out.

As a metaphor for the death of the record industry, it had economy and wit. In the week that the first Classical Brit Awards celebrated the recycled vapidity which is now sold as 'Classical Music' (the violinist Vanessa-Mae was due to be at last night's ceremony with her new-born puppy), the message had particular piquancy. Not that this was the prime intention of Project Dark. Their work, like others in the exhibition, was a response to a request from the eclectic writer and musician David Toop to participate in the largest ever Sound Art show. The result challenges our notions of sound and silence more rigorously and entertainingly than the Brit Awards ever could, examining one key supposition: 'We think we know how to look. But do we know how to listen?'

John Cage addressed that question 40 years ago in his seminal book Silence. In an interview in this newspaper, he recalled how Schoenberg had once accused him of having no ear for music, which meant that as a composer he would always come up against a brick wall. 'I said, well then, I'll beat my head against that wall; and I quite literally began hitting things, and developed a music of percussion that involved noises.' He wasn't the first to make strange sounds and call it music - the Italian Futurists, with their anarchic Sound War evenings featuring Russola's 'intoning machines', were there in the 1920s. But Cage was the first to have a coherent alternative philosophy of music which embraced (with love) the totality of sound. Sonic Boom, with its dazzling array of installations - including a record-player driven by an exercise bicycle and a robotic, one-man jazz band - should be obligatory for all ears fatigued by the bleeps and Muzak of everyday life.

The Royal Philharmonic Orchestra's concert devoted to the music of Peter Maxwell Davies provided its own kind of sonic retort by drawing on vast orchestral resources and extremes of pitch and volume. Davies, now in his mid-sixties and still impish, if no longer quite the rebel he once was, has a close association with the RPO, who play his music with warm conviction. Ever prolific, he had two world premieres in this concert, though no special fanfare preceded the event.

The centrepiece was a horn concerto supplicatingly written for the versatile Richard Watkins. This single-movement work exploits the full spectrum of sounds of which the instrument is capable, making intimidating demands on the soloist. Watkins tossed off the runs and trills, flourishes and volleys of notes effortlessly, with well-disciplined support from the orchestra.

The other new work, entitled Roma, Amor, Labyrinthos, was an enormous, impressionistic, three-movement tone poem to the Eternal City in which the young Maxwell Davies studied composition in the late Fifties. Intentionally overblown and bombastic, with an intoning machine's-worth of low woodwind, trombones and tuba, it portrays a Rome of jackboots, traffic and baroque gesture. A misty central movement suggests the city's mysterious intimacy.

Davies's compositions in maturity lack the full taut economy of his earlier works, and at times sound in danger of being just a little too slack. But this was an enjoyable concert which would have been ideal as a live broadcast, tempting a nervous listener to try out contemporary music at its most approachable. No microphones were in sight.

Radio 3 may not have been in evidence at the Barbican. It certainly will be, however, when Maxwell Davies conducts his Symphony No 7 at the Albert Hall in July, one of 15 BBC commissions in the 2000 Season of Proms. The new programme of 72 concerts (10 of which will be televised) was announced last week in the fitting setting of St Sepulchre-without-New gate where Sir Henry Wood, beloved Cockney originator of the festival, is buried. The choir of King's College, Cambridge sang Britten's 'Jubilate' and a Bach 'Alleluia', reminding us that one of this year's themes is Music and God while another is Bach on his 250th anniversary.

This year's innovations include a day of concert by the young for the young, a programme of newly fashionable Cuban music and a brave revival of the Sixties idea of Poetry Proms. The big sellouts are likely to be Evgeny Kissin on the first night, Jessye Norman's solo recital and Simon Rattle conducting Parsifal, his first Wagner opera in Britain. Booking opens on 15 May. But if you can't get tickets don't despair: every concert will be streamed live on the Internet via the Radio 3 website. If all that sounds a bit passé, you could just try switching on the radio.

fields.headline: Elaine's Burmese daze
fields.standfirst: Only one person could upstage two scarlet-clad elephants... Elaine Paige
fields.trailText: The King and I | Poseidon | Normal
fields.body:
The King and I Palladium, London W1

Poseidon Young Vic Studio, London SE1

Normal The Bush, London W12

The King and I cost a king's ransom to stage (about £4 million) and was festooned with awards during its two-year run on Broadway. I was not looking forward to the first night at all. Nothing about the advance publicity, showing Elaine Paige looking like an overgrown Bo Peep, whetted my appetite for Rodgers and Hammerstein's golden oldie. So I went on my own - a matter of duty, not pleasure.

It is always a delight to have one's prejudices knocked to the ground, as if in a lethal kung-fu manoeuvre. And Jason Scott Lee (best known in the title role of Dragon: The Bruce Lee Story) playing the King was just the man to effect such a move. But first - did I say golden oldie? Golden was the word. Brian Thomson's gold and scarlet set is stunning: constellated, spangled, fantastically and rampantly oriental. Not content with having two curvaceous scarlet elephants with turquoise eyes framing the stage, the Milky Way is thrown in and even humble merchants' wares look like priceless jewelled trees.

The trouble with Elaine Paige is that she is always Elaine Paige first and the character she is playing second. But in the role of Mrs Anna, the widowed English teacher who has known what it is to love and thinks she knows what it is to teach, this does not matter. Paige hospitably makes room for the role and its gorgeous songs. Her habitual expression is that of someone who has just had a mouthful of eye-smartingly cold ice-cream, which she finds enjoyable but shocking at the same time. In her low-cut vanilla frock, there is something altogether soft scoop about Mrs Anna. She is everyone's favourite treat.

Paige is a wonderfully entertaining contrast to the King, just as she should be. Lee pulls off the unusual feat of shouting and disarming at the same time. He is like an impossible pupil, bare-chested and in gold breeches, a know-it-all who is afraid of his own ignorance. The King's wives make a beguiling chorus line, flashing not their legs but their extended gold nails like seductive starfish. And how I wished I'd taken my nieces along to gasp at their exotic dresses (costumes by Roger Kirk). Tuptim (Aura Deva) is a 'present from a Burmese prince' and looks like one - in sublime wrapping paper.

But the star of the evening is the King's senior wife Lady Thiang. Taewon Yi Kim (who sang the role in the New York cast) has a beautiful singing voice. Her 'Something Wonderful' is just that. Christopher Renshaw's production manages to be charming as well as spectacular. No one could resist the sight of the King's children - (we meet a selection of the 67). Each is delicately characterised: a swot, a dreamer, a flower girl, a boy who wants to run away. This show started life in Australia in 1991. In its new incarnation, I'd like to award it a medal (a gold one, of course, encrusted with jewels).

The longest kiss in the history of kisses is in progress at the Young Vic Studio. Standing on an island above the audience, Poseidon's helpers are wrapped - rapt too - in each other. Water curtains the stage and fills a dark moat below. Going to Poseidon is like stepping into a dream. It is a sequel to Icarus Falling, Primitive Science's first show, praised for its beauty.

Poseidon is unenthusiastic about his ravishing environs: he fears water. He wishes he had got Zeus's job. Patrick Driver plays Poseidon but his thoughts are decorously conveyed by a second actor (Jerry Killick) - a one-man Greek chorus. One of the conceits of the piece is that all around us there are gods pretending to be mortal. Photos of the gods in curly silver frames are produced. Hades looks especially gormless, like a favourite grandfather. We are asked: 'Isn't it funny what supreme beings will do in order not to be recognised?' You might want to take this with a pinch of salt.

If so, it will not be difficult: Poseidon's helpers tip salt into the sea from silver shakers while Poseidon miserably combs his moustache with a small fork. The helpers are a mysterious French-speaking couple; the girl (Solveig Simha) looks like a mermaid, her bodice encrusted with sequinned barnacles. Hermes (entertainingly played by Boz Temple-Morris) wears a long silver mackintosh and quaint green shoes with golden spikes. He has come to tell Poseidon that no one believes in him any more. This show makes a glittering tale out of redundancy. Something that Marc Von Henning, its talented writer-director, and Dick Bird, its superlative designer, will with luck never have to face.

There is more talent to gladden the heart this week, though Helen Blakeman's subject is as bleak as could be. Normal, capably directed by Mike Bradwell, is about women who are destructive. Holly (Emma Pike) might be considered sane. She is a student who makes money out of telephone sex. She is nasty, good-looking and lonely. She wants to have her breasts enlarged for a reduced fee. She tries to seduce the consultant with this aim in mind. Superficially, she could not be more different from her flatmate Kate. But Kate is lonely too and mutilates herself - she needs no surgeon. Both girls seduce the same man; the structure is accomplished, like being in a hall of mirrors where everything reflects back on itself.

This is Blakeman's second play. It is depressing but funny and compassionate too. Lisa Ellis plays Kate like a fledgling who needs to drop out of the nest when her mother (Marion Bayley) turns vulture. She almost finds a friend in Todd (Ben Crompton) who, when she says she has failed her exams, pays her this compliment: 'That is not the rucksack of an unintelligent lady.' I look forward to seeing more from the Blakeman rucksack.

 Susannah Clapp is on holiday

fields.headline: The trouble with Carrey
fields.standfirst:
Jim Carrey's excellent as Andy Kaufman, but at the end, we still don't know what made the comic tick

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Jim Carrey's excellent as Andy Kaufman, but at the end, we still don't know what made the comic tick
fields.body:
Man on the Moon (119 mins, 15) Directed by Milos Forman; starring Jim Carrey, Danny De Vito, Courtney Love

After fleeing from Nazi Germany, Fritz Lang spent two years travelling the United States, steeping himself in the culture before making his first Hollywood movie, the very American Fury in 1936.

Milos Forman did something similar when he quit Czechoslovakia after the Russian tanks rolled into Prague in 1968. He'd become the leading light of the Czech new wave with his quirky celebrations of non-conformity and eccentricity - Black Peter, Loves of a Blonde and The Firemen's Ball. Three years later, though pursuing similar themes, he emerged as an American director with Taking Off, his comedy of life on both sides of the generation gap produced by the emergence of the 1960s counterculture. It remains one of the best films on that turbulent period.

Since then, Forman has been at his best dealing with anti-authoritarian outsiders in America, such as the rebellious Randall P. McMurphy leading the asylum inmates of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and the libertarian porn-merchant defending free speech in The People v Larry Flynt. He's been least good revisiting Europe to direct the staid costume movies Amadeus and Valmont.

Forman might well have made Ed Wood, but instead he engaged the authors of its screenplay, Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, to write Man on the Moon, a movie about Andy Kaufman, the oddball comedian whose true aims are as difficult to pin down as Larry Flynt's.

Kaufman emerged from a middle-class Jewish home on Long Island to puzzle, amuse and disturb America for a decade before dying of a rare form of lung cancer in 1984 at the age of 35. He is best known outside America for his role as Latka Gravas, the syntactically-challenged immigrant engineer, one of the regular blue-collar eccentrics in the cult sitcom Taxi, which ran from 1978 to 1983.

This delightful piece of character comedy endeared him to the general public, but his significance resides in the way he set out to provoke, annoy and alienate both his audience and his colleagues. Kaufman invented an alter ego, or rather an alter id, called Tony Clifton, a slobbish, racist, third-rate Las Vegas club performer, usually played by himself but occasionally by his partner and fellow provocateur, Bob Zmuda, and they even managed to get Clifton ejected from the Paramount lot.

Kaufman deliberately got up the nostrils of women and Southerners by staging bouts of all-in wrestling between himself and female challengers in Memphis. He emptied an auditorium of student fans in Arizona by refusing to reprise Latka Gravas for them and instead reading the whole of The Great Gatsby in a fruity English accent. He booked Carnegie Hall for a concert, but confronted those who came to be outraged with a kitschy version of a Radio City Music Hall Christmas show complete with Rockettes and Santa Claus. Eventually, he achieved his ambition of estranging most of his followers and failing to be believed when he said he had cancer.

Kaufman was a role player in the tradition of that archetypal American figure, the chameleon confidence trickster and, in Jim Carrey's bravura performance, Kaufman is always performing. The movie is a single, extended turn that incorporates smaller ones on and off stage.

Forman uses his formidable skills as a documentarian and a director of actors to recreate TV appearances, club acts and stage shows. They're indistinguishable from the real thing and, in fact, the scenes involving Taxi are performed by Carrey with Christopher Lloyd, Marilu Henner, Judd Hirsch, Carol Kane and other members of the original cast. Of course, Danny De Vito can't play himself in Taxi as he's been cast as George Shapiro, Kaufman's devoted but constantly exasperated agent.

Shapiro, De Vito and Bob Zmuda have co-produced the film, with Kaufman's live-in girlfriend, Lynne Margulies (played on screen by Courtney Love), as 'creative consultant'. But either these friends are determined to preserve Kaufman's central mystery or they don't know what makes him tick.

'That kid is totally meshugga,' Andy's father says, using an affectionate Yiddish term for madness. 'You're insane but you might be brilliant,' says Shapiro after signing him up. 'I don't do jokes; I don't know what's funny; I'm just a song-and-dance man,' says Kaufman.

We're left to make up our own minds and to me Kaufman seems a descendant of two figures from the 1950s - Guy Grand, the malevolent practical joker in Terry Southern's The Magic Christian and Lenny Bruce - satirists who were obsessed with the essential absurdity of life who ventured beyond the realms of morality and reason.

Certainly, Kaufman denies people the traditional consolations of humour, though when he engaged in transcendental meditation, was he seeking something or sending it up? And when he took a sentimental turn, was he exposing American sentimentality or embracing it?

Observing the proceedings, incidentally, is Victor Schiavelli, a curious, very un-American-looking actor with a long, thin face, high forehead and piercing eyes, who has recurred in Forman's movies since he appeared in Taking Off as the supercilious hippie who instructs members of the Society for the Parents of Fugitive Children on the etiquette of pot-smoking.

Here, he's a TV executive, variously infuriated, baffled and amused by Kaufman and, one suspects, he's reflecting Forman's own response. I'd have to say, though, that Kaufman, whose Tony Clifton persona is close to Sir Les Patterson, is a good deal less funny than his postmodern contemporary, Barry Humphries.
fields.bodyText: Man on the Moon (119 mins, 15) Directed by Milos Forman; starring Jim Carrey, Danny De Vito, Courtney Love After fleeing from Nazi Germany, Fritz Lang spent two years travelling the United States, steeping himself in the culture before making his first Hollywood movie, the very American Fury in 1936. Milos Forman did something similar when he quit Czechoslovakia after the Russian tanks rolled into Prague in 1968. He'd become the leading light of the Czech new wave with his quirky celebrations of non-conformity and eccentricity - Black Peter, Loves of a Blonde and The Firemen's Ball. Three years later, though pursuing similar themes, he emerged as an American director with Taking Off, his comedy of life on both sides of the generation gap produced by the emergence of the 1960s counterculture. It remains one of the best films on that turbulent period. Since then, Forman has been at his best dealing with anti-authoritarian outsiders in America, such as the rebellious Randall P. McMurphy leading the asylum inmates of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and the libertarian porn-merchant defending free speech in The People v Larry Flynt. He's been least good revisiting Europe to direct the staid costume movies Amadeus and Valmont. Forman might well have made Ed Wood, but instead he engaged the authors of its screenplay, Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, to write Man on the Moon, a movie about Andy Kaufman, the oddball comedian whose true aims are as difficult to pin down as Larry Flynt's. Kaufman emerged from a middle-class Jewish home on Long Island to puzzle, amuse and disturb America for a decade before dying of a rare form of lung cancer in 1984 at the age of 35. He is best known outside America for his role as Latka Gravas, the syntactically-challenged immigrant engineer, one of the regular blue-collar eccentrics in the cult sitcom Taxi, which ran from 1978 to 1983. This delightful piece of character comedy endeared him to the general public, but his significance resides in the way he set out to provoke, annoy and alienate both his audience and his colleagues. Kaufman invented an alter ego, or rather an alter id, called Tony Clifton, a slobbish, racist, third-rate Las Vegas club performer, usually played by himself but occasionally by his partner and fellow provocateur, Bob Zmuda, and they even managed to get Clifton ejected from the Paramount lot. webTitle: Why does your money always turn into old rope?

fields.headline: Why does your money always turn into old rope?
fields.standfirst:
Of five Brit flicks out this week, four were made with Lottery money. Guess which is the only one worth seeing...

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Claire Dolan | Boiler Room | Trick | The Long Good Friday | Circus | The Last September | Janice Beard: 45wpm | House!
fields.body:
Claire Dolan (95 mins, 18) Directed by Lodge Kerrigan; starring Katrin Cartlidge, Colm Meaney, Vincent D'Onofrio

Boiler Room (119 mins, 15) Directed by Ben Younger; starring Giovanni Ribisi, Vin Diesel, Ron Rifkin

Trick (93 mins, 15) Directed by Jim Fall; starring Christian Campbell, John Paul Pitoc, Tori Spelling

The Long Good Friday (114 mins, 18) Directed by John MacKenzie; starring Bob Hoskins, Helen Mirren

Circus (96 mins, 18) Directed by Rob Walker; starring John Hannah, Famke Janssen, Peter Stormare, Fred Ward

The Last September (104 mins, 15) Directed by Deborah Warner; starring Maggie Smith, Michael Gambon, Fiona Shaw, Keeley Hawes

House! (89 mins, 15) Directed by Julian Kemp; starring Kelly Macdonald, Jason Hughes, Freddie Jones, Miriam Margolyes

Janice Beard: 45wpm (81 mins, 15) Directed by Claire Kilner; starring Eileen Walsh, Rhys Ifans, Patsy Kensit

Shown two years ago in competition at Cannes, Lloyd Kerrigan's Claire Dolan is a portrait of an existential high-class whore of a sort that has fascinated independent movie-makers ever since Godard's Vivre sa vie 40 years ago. Like Anna Karina in that earlier movie, Katrin Cartlidge despises her clients, is at the mercy of a sadistic pimp (Colm Meaney), and attempts to break away and live an ordinary life with a young lover (Vincent D'Onofrio).

This good-looking minimalist film is all hard, cold surfaces of anonymous New York bars, flats and hotel rooms, full of mirrors that mock the icy heroine. We never learn how Claire became a whore, but then this isn't a sociological movie but a study in loneliness, exile, alienation. I didn't believe a word of it and found it willed rather than imagined.

Ben Younger's business thriller, Boiler Room, has more blood in its veins, much of it in the form of transfusions from other pictures. The pale, pinch-faced Giovanni Ribisi plays a clever 19-year-old college drop-out who - to impress his father, a stern federal judge (Ron Rifkin) - takes a job with a corrupt stockbroking firm that seduces and fleeces avaricious investors on the phone. Just after it's struck us how much the induction lecture by demonic, fast-talking Ben Affleck resembles the opening of Glengarry Glen Ross, someone says 'Have you seen Glengarry Glen Ross ?' When we start recognising echoes of Wall Street, there's a scene of the young brokers swilling beer, eating pizza and watching a video of their hero, Gordon Gekko in Wall Street. Boiler Room seems an authentic depiction of their empty, desperate, immoral lives.

The other American movie, Trick, is a charming comedy about a shy young would-be composer of Broadway musicals (Christian Campbell) who shares a New York flat with an obnoxious straight friend, and can't find anywhere to have sex with the handsome go-go dancer (John Paul Pitoc) he picks up in a gay bar. As they search in vain, lust turns to love in a touching, old-fashioned way and they part at dawn, their romance still to be consummated. Tori Spelling is very funny as the hero's loud-mouthed actress chum (currently appearing off-off-Broadway in an all-girl version of Wilde's Salome) and there's a walk-on appearance as a waitress by Helene Hanff of 84 Charing Cross Road fame.

The other five pictures are British, four of them varying from the indifferent to the dreadful. All but one are products of the present Lottery-created glut, a situation reminiscent of a similar superfluity that resulted 50 years ago when a Labour government in dispute with Hollywood encouraged our film industry to put every available half-baked script into production.

The one good picture is a re-issue of the 20-year-old The Long Good Friday, one of the best British crime movies, in which a lot of people get electrocuted when some wires are crossed between the IRA and an underworld scheme to renovate the London docklands. Barrie Keeffe's dialogue is as sharp as a cutthroat razor and at the head of a fine cast Bob Hoskins gives a performance that can be spoken of in the same snarl as Edward G. Robinson's Rico Bandello in Little Caesar.

After The Long Good Friday, the flashy, Brighton-set Circus is a dull, derivative thriller in which gambler John Hannah and three imported American actors tangle with mobsters and a double-crossing plot more demented than ingenious. This is the useless suspects, reservoir dregs, the scrapings of two smoking barrels.

Adapted by John Banville from Elizabeth Bowen's novel, The Last September is the disappointing cinematic debut of the gifted stage director Deborah Warner. With a deal of incidental implausibility and an overall tedium, it covers sub-Chekhovian territory familiar from TV and movie adaptations of novels by William Trevor, J.G. Farrell and Jennifer Johnson about the last days of the detached Anglo-Irish landed gentry, as the IRA and the Black and Tans do battle around their country houses in the Troubles of 80 years ago. Inevitably, a young woman is torn between her upper-middle-class heritage and a handsome Irish revolutionary, who in this case looks uncannily like Brendan Behan after a night on the town.

The remaining two pictures - both arch, heavyhanded comedies - also feature Celtic heroines. Marginally the better, House! has a 'small-and-decrepit-is-beautiful' plot about a young girl (Kelly Macdonald) in South Wales using her hereditary psychic powers to save the rundown bingo hall where she works from being put out of business by a soulless rival establishment. To emphasise the Ealingesque associations, the hall's ancient proprietor (Freddie Jones) hears lines from the soundtracks of The Man in the White Suit and The Ladykillers as he contemplates the grand history of his crumbling establishment.

Bad almost beyond belief, Janice Beard: 45wpm has a fantasising, charmless Scottish heroine (Eileen Walsh) coming to London to work as a temp and save a motor company from extinction. With an undeveloped script, lame dialogue and a childlike view of the business world, this is an updating of one of those old George Formby and Norman Wisdom comedies. But instead of a gormless hero there's a gormless heroine - not a good idea - and a male replaces the vamping femme fatale, in this case an industrial spy posing as an office boy, who is played by the ubiquitous Rhys Ifans.

fields.headline: Nights of trite Latin
fields.standfirst: Harder! Faster! Sexier! Please don't sing another Spanish ballad, Ricky...
fields.trailText: Ricky Martin
fields.body:
Ricky Martin Palais Bercy, Paris

When the history of globalisation is written, some time next century, the years 1999 and 2000 may be seen as our first awkward steps. A time when the Internet seemed vaguely exciting; when confused youngsters assaulted statues of war heroes; and when Ricky Martin, worshipped for years by the Spanish-speaking quarter of the planet, first became a star in northern Europe and the United States by shaking his butt (as close as we had, then, to an international language) and singing in English about latin craziness.

On stage in Paris last Wednesday, dressed in the traditional internationalist garb of diaphanous black shirt and tight leather trousers, Martin paid earnest tribute to a 'Latin American leader' whose mission was 'to unite the world - and that's what we're trying to do tonight with our music.' Words which will send a chill down the spines of conspiracy theorists. As will the fact that 'Livin' La Vida Loca' was a number one hit in more than 20 countries.

'He hasn't done badly,' as a gay friend said, with a lasciviously raised eyebrow, 'for someone who can't sing and can't dance.'

This a little harsh. Martin's voice, though limited, is hardly a disaster of Ginger Spice proportions. On the faster songs, it is fine; only on the ballads, when he is required to emote, does it start to sound whiny and overstretched. Unfortunately the current single, 'Private Emotion', the one that sounds like a watered-down version of 'Hotel California', is a showcase for exactly this problem - which perhaps explains why it's been a relative failure, thus raising fears that Martin will be remembered as a one-hit wonder.

As for Ricky's dancing, my friend claimed that he has only three moves: a thrust to the left, a thrust to the right, and of course, a thrust forward. Outrageously, this critique ignores Ricky's pièce de résistance - the rumpshake. Even so, close analysis of the singer's moves at Palais Bercy reveals a surprisingly leaden, straight-limbed quality which you would not expect in a 29-year-old latino. Perhaps he's been overdoing the Stairmaster?

And a one-hit wonder? This show does not entirely dispel the notion. For the moment, the gulf between English and Spanish songs remains huge - and it is not a question of language, but of taste. 'Livin' La Vida Loca', though its lyrics are bathetically reminiscent of Cliff Richard's 'Devil Woman', is a flawlessly northernised pop song. Ricky plays it here first, dancing on the bonnet of a convertible sports car. A girl in a frilly bikini jumps out of the car's boot, and a group of dancers shake their asses in synchronised semi-raunch.

Boom! What a start! From there, you expect it to unfold into a classic modern pop show. But within 10 minutes, the crowd is bored and irritated, as the Spanish tracks take over. 'Bon-Bon de Azucar' is bad enough, all cocktail-bar piano and 'shoobee-doobee' vocals, melded on to a soft-metal chorus. But the next song, 'Vuelve', is truly awful: a syrupy ballad which suddenly explodes into a squealing rock opera. It's almost beyond parody.

Visually the show owes something to Ricky's days on Broadway (he was in Les Mis) - the choreography is like a cruder version of West End Story - while the video screens flash up images of Ricky (fast songs) or of purple stormclouds (ballads). The highlight comes when Ricky simulates sex with his own giant, pixellated leg, humping it like a small dog.

This occurs during 'Shake Your Bon-Bon', a song with gloriously daft lyrics ('Up in the Himalayas/ C'mon, I wanna lay ya') and, crucially, a pounding dance beat, which ushers in half an hour of solid salsa. Confetti falls from the ceiling. Firecrackers explode. Finally the young people of Paris are swept on to their feet, their hands waving in unison. By the end, my notes were unreadable because the stand where I sat was bouncing so hard.

Globalisation? As George Clinton nearly said, free your ass and your social and political infrastructure might eventually follow.

 Ricky Martin plays London Earls Court on Friday and Saturday

fields.headline: He's got perfect kitsch
fields.standfirst: It's Eurovision on Saturday, an event that is invariably more memorable for Terry Wogan's observations on costumes than it is for the songs. Terry loves the absurdity of it - a whole lot more than he loves the BBC
fields.trailText: It's Eurovision on Saturday, an event that is invariably more memorable for Terry Wogan's observations on costumes than it is for the songs. Terry loves the absurdity of it - a whole lot more than he loves the BBC
fields.body:
The lift goes up and up, and eventually stops at Light Entertainment Heaven, which many sensible souls would surely regard as a hellish place to be. Here on the fifteenth floor of a central London hotel, while foreign guests are tucking into their £13.95 Full English Breakfasts, BBC gods Terry Wogan and Alan Titchmarsh are engaging in cocklewarming green-room banter, the stuff of a hundred TV charity specials. 'It's you! You're following me!' says Wogan, though in fact he was the last to arrive. 'I saw you at the Ivy last night.'

'Were you there?' Titchmarsh bounces on the edge of his seat. 'So was Donald Sutherland!'

'I doubt', says Wogan, with morose sagacity, 'that he knew who either of us were.'

A surprisingly brown man in charcoal suit, periwinkle shirt and lemon tie, he prepares for his close-up by gazing out, a captain on the high seas, over Portland Place towards the smooth white cliffs of Broadcasting House where he has just finished his Radio 2 show. 'No, nothing for me there. I hope you're taking this from above,' he admonishes John, the photographer. 'At my age, I have to be shot from above. Jesus, with three chins, it's kindness.'

In between poses, he and Titchmarsh are comparing the cuts and grazes inflicted on them by broadsheet hacks. I find it rather shocking to hear Wogan - popularly believed to be the Beeb's equivalent of the Costas because of his ceaselessly sunny good nature - refer to one interviewer from another broadsheet, who said some quite unkind things about his hair, as 'fat and ugly'.

It occurs to me that this is a shot across the bow, and for a moment, I see him in an entirely different and rather exciting light, closer to the sinister Wogan figure he played in Bob Martin, a Godfather type who was malevolently territorial about Michael Barrymore's attempts to take over the Eurovision presenting slot. But then Titchmarsh expertly defuses the tension with a smooth 'So she didn't like you, then?' and Terry laughs, and it's another safe daytime moment. (In case you are curious, though the Wogan 'do' is certainly idiosyncratic, it does not really resemble 'a hairy croissant', and is convincingly threaded with white.)

For most of our meeting he is Velcro'd to his trademark tone of amiably surreal self-deprecation: a tone which echoes throughout the BBC's L.E. archive, from the Radio 2 breakfast show, which he has presented intermittently since 1972, through to Celebrity Squares, Come Dancing, Blankety Blank and the Eurovision Song Contest, due to kick off this Saturday in Stockholm.

Eurovision is perceived as his annual Finest Hour, or three. Though he has reported on it since 'just after the Napoleonic Wars', it has only comparatively recently become a plum date in the kitsch calendar, and the subject of camp West End musicals. Much of its popularity is due to Wogan's commentary, which has turned him into a cult figure and hero of Chris Evans. Not bad for a 64-year-old blazer-wearer who was widely believed to be washed up in 1992, when his knee-patting chat show was axed to make way for Eldorado.

Eurovision is as soft a target as room-temperature butter, but Wogan is, as the Guardian 's Nancy Banks-Smith observes fondly, 'a lifebelt presence' on the night: his observations on costumes, tunes, sets and the folk dances of the host country always nail the absurdity of the moment, and leave you rolling helplessly on the carpet.

It's a skill of which Wogan is vaguely dismissive. He is robust about what makes for popular broadcasting, saying that it invariably boils down to predictability and repetition. 'I'm reflecting what the viewer's thinking. Perhaps I say it just a beat before they say it. It's like answering questions on Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, just getting the answer in quickly.' He admits that he has marked his life out in Song Contests. 'It's like the Horse of the Year Show. It seems to come up every six weeks. You think: Oh God, not again!'

Whether or not you believe Wogan when he insists that the rest of Europe - and Israel, of course, let's not forget Israel - considers the Eurovision itself a cultural highpoint, 'a feast of fine music', is another matter entirely, and possibly not a laughing one.

'This year will not disappoint,' he declares. 'I have seen the previews. I would advise anyone, even if the worse for drink, to stay awake for the Swedish entry. Every so often the Swedes have a rush of blood to the head and take off to the far north and reinvent their Lapp traditions. I won't say more than that. I can only say that it is bizarre.'

Wogan is often accused of being bland but in fact he is a master of the bizarre: his Radio 2 show, peppered with catchphrases such as 'I'll put that in a glass case and throw sugar at it', is completely incomprehensible to the first-time listener. And yet the first-time listeners keep breaking the pain barrier and returning for a diet of 'maundering' and Roy Orbison records: audience figures are extremely healthy, more than seven million at the last count, not far off the eight million who were tuning in before he abandoned Radio 2 for TV in the mid-Eighties.

He gets 600 e-mails a day, many of which fuel whimsical digressions, but he never visualises his listeners: he has a horror of 'having to address an audience full of people'. It's certainly true that he makes a beeline for the seat alongside me on the banquette, making eye contact virtually impossible. And still, at this remove, his charm is ticklish and insistent: a feather duster wielded at arm's length.

As a schoolboy, he came home and firmly shut the garden gate behind him, to keep out the rest of the world. 'I've always wanted my own space, I've always been happy on my own. I'm not particularly gregarious, and that's probably ideal for being a broadcaster. I like talking to myself, maundering on.' When asked a few years ago about how his nationality had influenced his personality, he answered: 'A fear of silence. The Irish abhor a vacuum, particularly in conversation.'

On air, he is relentlessly, brilliantly trivial. 'Why should my opinion count for anything? I don't think you have a right, because of an accident, to lumber people with your subjective opinions. Better to keep your nose clean.' But this seeps over into the way he seems to view his life, too. When he tells me about a letter bomb being sent to him at Broadcasting House, he's much more interested in the gag ('All the traffic stopped! "A bomb for Terry!" The only thing is, this person could not have been a regular listener, because I was away at the time!') than in the 'loony' who sent it to him in the first place.

Michael Terence Wogan was born in Limerick, the son of a 'grocer's curate' at Leverett & Fry who went on to become managing director. Since his dad was also christened Michael, his mother called him Terry, which is 'not a name I've ever been tremendously fond of. I'd rather have been called something more manly... Rot Gonad, for instance.'

The elder of two boys (his brother works for Aer Lingus), Wogan was educated by Jesuits who extolled the values of humility and self-control. He describes himself as entirely without ambition, which makes it all the more odd that as a 21-year-old bank clerk, he bothered to respond to an ad for RTE newsreaders in the paper. Wogan's letter was one of 5,000 and yet, with no experience, he got the job. What had galvanised him to apply? Wogan is not helpful. 'I don't know. I was a great radio listener ... TV hadn't started in Ireland at the time, so we used to watch the BBC. Coming down the hill into Dublin, all you could see were these minor pylons, 40 to 50ft aerials, sticking up into the sky, getting fringe reception. I don't know why I got the job, to be honest.'

But he made a name for himself, and when Radio 1 launched, he was in the station's inaugural line-up, his Irishness rendering him safely classless. Eventually, he and Helen, whom he calls 'the current Mrs Wogan' (they've been married for 35 years), sold their house in Ireland and moved over to the Home Counties, where they raised three children. They have no plans to go back.

Wogan is reluctant to analyse his motives or success. Perhaps he is keeping his powder dry in preparation for his autobiography, which comes out in September, but he does seem almost superstitious when talking about his career, like a nervous traveller who suspects the plane might fall out of the sky if they stopped to think about the unlikeliness of flight. He never watches himself on telly, for instance. 'You might watch yourself and think, "Oh, that's an appealing thing I did there, oh, that's attractive", and then you might end up winking like Anne Robinson for the rest of your life, trapped in what you fancied was an engaging little habit.'

He hates preparation. While presenting Wogan, he was famous for doing as little research on his guests as possible. 'I'm a great believer in spontaneity, mainly because I don't have the capacity to take pains. My father used to take enormous pains. He was a fly fisherman, and we used to go out on a Sunday, and the sun would be going down before he cast the first fly out over the river. What he really liked to do was tie the flies and get ready, and naturally this built up resentment in a young man. If it didn't come easily, I walked away from it.'

Much of this insouciance is a pose, but Wogan is far less sentimental than I'd expected. The BBC, with whom he will always be inextricably linked in the popular imagination, comes in for a big rubbishing. Auntie's bloomers? More like Auntie's fig leaf. BBC Talent is 'nonsense. The BBC is inundated with tapes and videos and scripts every day of the year, and all you've got to do is employ somebody who actually knows something about scripts or presenters to analyse the mail. A total waste of time.'

Would he do a Des Lynam? 'Of course I would. I have no loyalty to the BBC. The BBC doesn't care about me. It doesn't give a toss about me!' He thinks he's washed up on telly, with the exception of the Eurovision, and is even toying with the idea of not renewing his Radio 2 contract when it runs out (if it gets that far. He implies, darkly, that the BBC may not want to keep him on). 'I'm giving it another two years and then I shall be so well advanced in years that I probably won't be able to get out of bed.'

Perhaps he means it; perhaps he doesn't. But his public is unlikely to let him go without a fight. As we say goodbye, Terry opens his brown briefcase and there, alongside what looks suspiciously like a tube of cover-up, is a strange object: a fabric portrait of the man himself, framed and ready to pop on the mantelpiece. 'It took a sub-editor on Cross Stitch magazine 60 hours to do this,' he says, in the same baffled tones that we will be hearing next Saturday. What on earth will he do with it? 'I'll put it in a glass case and throw sugar at it.'

Romania 'The Moon' performed by Taxi 'And I listen how the wind/ Is playing among the stars on night/ And I don't think I want more/ But I wait for the moon/ To play hide and seek into your hair/ My heart will always beat for you'

Belgium 'I want to Live' performed by Nathalie Sorce 'The wish to live for eternity/ The wish to live has gone past us/ The wish to life will remain enamelled/ Like in a book we have discovered again'
