webTitle: Are museums the bingo halls of tomorrow?

fields.headline: Are museums the bingo halls of tomorrow?
fields.standfirst: The underclasses don't want relics - they want subsidised cinemas and bowling alleys
fields.trailText: The underclasses don't want relics - they want subsidised cinemas and bowling alleys
fields.body:
We've all noticed how the Department of Culture has been frantically making Britain a land fit for Sunday outings in the past year or so, but what on earth was it up to last week, calling upon museums to 'develop their role as agents of social change'? Blimey, did I miss something? The last time I looked, museums were somewhere you went if Alton Towers got rained off. Now, it seems, they're there to help 'bring about real improvements in society and people's lives'. They're supposed to be 'the focal point for cultural activity in communities'. Oh dear.

Apparently, this is one of the Government's cunning plans to get tough on social exclusion, though interestingly not on the causes of social exclusion, which haven't altered much since time began - poor education, not enough money, bad breath, Ford Fiesta parked on bricks outside your house.

It's true that new museums have been springing up on the back of Lottery grants while the old ones have been busy making themselves more 'relevant' to ordinary punters. To be honest, I don't care what happens to Lottery money. It must be a terrible burden being flooded with millions of pounds every week and not being able to spend it on anything useful. And, let's face it, you can't really go wrong with public works - they're visible assets; they're ethically wholesome; they create jobs for plasterers.

And you can see how it might be politically exciting to imagine some social benefit accruing after all. Society's ills cured by Lottery funding through the back door - what larks! You can't blame them for wishing. What if people stopped smoking, and rioting, and landed themselves jobs as professors of Egyptology simply as a result of popping out to the local museum once a fortnight? But it's not going to happen.

No one is visiting all these millions of new museums. Even the good ones are half empty, especially those off the tourist map - the Armouries in Leeds and the Earth Centre near Doncaster both get rave write-ups but dismal attendance figures. I hope Chris Smith is right when he says the new Lowry will do for Salford what Frank Gehry's Guggenheim has done for Bilbao. It looked lovely and shiny on Newsnight last Thursday. And you could lump it in with a visit to the Coronation Street set, I suppose.

The trouble is museums will never be a focal point for community life. Poor old Chris is getting museums mixed up with pubs, which, far from excluding people, pretty much let anyone in - apart from transsexuals and folk who live in caravans.

And, anyway, what does he plan to offer those who already enjoy visiting museums, those to whom 'relevance' is irrelevant? Those who have genuinely come along to see, say, the finest collection of lawnmowers in the world - aficionados of the twirled multiblade and bevelled cuttings-box; sultans of strim who don't want to be dumbed-down with hands-on, interactive grass-cutting races or video installations featuring mowing patterns from around the world. Obviously, I'm not saying these people don't need help - by all means put in some new toilets and a chewing-gum machine - just not the full digital experience.

And don't hold your breath expecting children to pester their parents for a day at a museum, regardless of how much you dress it up as 'fun'. We've all seen families wandering around the V&A wishing they were dead. Of course, there are exceptions - dinosaurs and mummies had their glory days.

And the Romans, of course... now there was a society who knew a thing or two about bread and circuses. You didn't see the Emperor Titus wasting his time encouraging the populace to recite the Aeneid or take a coach excursion down to see the strange stone people of Pompeii; he packed 'em into the Coliseum to watch people less fortunate than themselves being eaten by wild beasts.

That's it! Instead of trying to make something more interesting, why not give 'those on the margins of society' what they're already interested in in the first place? Of course, learning can be fun, but it's not as much fun as mindless pleasure. Let's have free bingo halls, subsidised films, a municipal bowling alley in every town centre, a Lloyd-Webber musical in every church hall and dedicated rollerblading lanes running through the nation's highways and shopping malls! Come on, Chris, let the people decide.

After all, they're the ones buying the Lottery tickets.

fields.headline: A fellow of infinite jest
fields.standfirst: What do Michael Frayn and Paul Scofield have in common? Both have fallen victim to theatreland's most inventive practical joker, David Burke.  Peter Conrad  warily approaches the master of the leg-pull
fields.trailText: What do Michael Frayn and Paul Scofield have in common? Both have fallen victim to theatreland's most inventive practical joker, David Burke. Peter Conrad warily approaches the master of the leg-pull
fields.body:
What follows is funny and more than a little sinister. It is about a practical joke. Practical jokes rehearse a hostility which threatens to erode trust, subvert social relations and call reality itself into question. Then, after inducing a metaphysical dread, the triumphant joker dares his victim not to laugh.

This particular experiment in relativising sacred certainties began, aptly enough, during a debate about the possible destruction of our safe, solid physical world. In Michael Frayn's Copenhagen, Niels Bohr and Werner Heisenberg meet in 1941 to discuss the riddle of atomic fission, which will win the war for one side or the other. Last year, just before the play's transfer from the National Theatre to the West End, Frayn received from a woman called Celia Rhys-Evans a parcel of blotched, tattered papers, allegedly unearthed in the house where Heisenberg was interned when the bomb fell on Hiroshima.

He became convinced, as he enticed more details from his unknown source, that he was reading a secret history of the events his play had fictionalised. After many months of obsessed speculation, he discovered that it was a hoax, dreamed up by the actor David Burke while he was playing the guileless, near-saintly Bohr. Burke had written in a yellowing ledger with antique pens, wet the pages and then tumble-dried them to make them look authentically elderly. He and Frayn have now collaborated on Celia's Secret, a book about the maniacally elaborate prank.

Burke has a long history of forgery, fraud and psychological malfeasance. 'I can go straight for two or three years at a time,' he told me last week, 'but then this urge will come upon me.'

His first victim was Paul Scofield, with whom he appeared in a John Osborne play during the 1960s. Scofield, missing his stop on a train home, had pulled the emergency cord and nonchalantly disembarked between stations. Burke wrote him a reprimand, which purported to come from Sergeant Blenkinsop of the Railway Police. In turn, Scofield tricked Burke with a letter signed by a deranged fellow actor who wanted Burke to introduce him to Scofield. Burke panicked, fled from the theatre, then received another letter upbraiding him; Scofield smirked when accused.

Despite the occasional retaliation, Burke remains incorrigible and recently sent a spurious note to one of his colleagues in the Almeida's current production of Richard II. The subtly rancorous document was signed by a director with whom the actor had fought; nevertheless, he read it as a gesture of reconciliation. 'People will believe whatever they choose,' said Burke. How can he be criticised for deceiving others when they so earnestly deceive themselves?

Frayn, heroically candid and beatifically forgiving, acknowledges the dread and desperate paranoia he felt when he realised he had been duped. For a while, the world became frighteningly unstable, like the society of his crazed farce, Noises Off. He asks himself in Celia's Secret whether we are all 'living in a universal virtual reality generator, whose name is David Burke'.

In the book, Burke has a brief moment of self-doubt as his plots proliferate, requiring him to suborn accomplices. 'Was I turning into an Iago?' he asks. As it happens, W.H. Burke mentions the incident in Celia's Secret when describing how he devised the joke while listening every night to a long speech by Matthew Marsh. Actors, he believes, should maintain their sanity by remaining detached, rather than risk ing Day-Lewis's Stanislavskyan immersion. I asked him to tell me more.

'As the ghost disappears I said, "Farewell, farewell, remember me", then when I looked back, Dan had gone. We found him backstage on the floor, sobbing his eyes out. They sent the audience out to the bars, rustled up Dan's understudy, Jeremy Northam, who hadn't looked at the text for six weeks, got him dressed and sent him on as Hamlet in front of 1,200 people in the Olivier! Dan never played it again.'

'What,' I asked, 'if Day-Lewis had emerged beaming at the end of the show, clapped Jeremy Northam on the back and said to him, "It was only a joke"?' That, Burke admitted, accepting that there were limits to the joker's licence, would not have been funny.

Finally, he consented to my type-casting. He mentioned that he had written his part of Celia's Secret at the Union Jack Club in Waterloo, where he holes up when he can't get home to Kent. 'Oh you know it?' he asked, then looked at me doubtfully. 'Of course, it's only open to members of Her Majesty's Forces.' I questioned him about his military record. 'I was in the Royal Artillery between 1953 and 1955,' he said. 'I'd like to tell you I was a Russian interpreter with a sideline in code-breaking, but they put me to work as a humble typist.' Iago, I pointed out, was also a military man, a humble subaltern, disgruntled when he was passed over for promotion.

Practical jokes are warfare conducted by other, more devious means, and they target our putative friends, not our enemies. Burke's alias in Celia's Secret is simultaneously writing a novel with which she assails Frayn. 'It was a spoof of Enid Blyton, about a 16-year-old boy called Hans who makes world peace possible by discovering a formula to turn steel into rubber - you can't kill anyone with a rubber gun!' The fantasy sums up the jester's mixed motives: lethal aggression fortuitously forestalled, but only because the gun barrel loses its metallic stiffness.

Burke's blue eyes blinked. 'Well, then,' he said, 'I suppose I am Iago. So what should be done with me?'

'In the play, they haul him away to be tortured,' I replied.

Burke, however, swept off to Shoreditch, chuckling, where that evening he would lose his son, apostrophise tormented England, expire in anguish and then, quickly recovering from John of Gaunt's death, eat a hearty dinner.

fields.headline: Ginger's going grey...
fields.standfirst: Chris Evans used to be Channel 4's key to the elusive youth market. Now, with TFI Friday set to be ditched, he joins a long list of celebrities that teenagers don't want to know. But, asks  Michael Collins, could anyone else succeed where Evans has failed?
fields.trailText: Chris Evans used to be Channel 4's key to the elusive youth market. Now, with TFI Friday set to be ditched, he joins a long list of celebrities that teenagers don't want to know. But, asks  Michael Collins, could anyone else succeed where Evans has failed?
fields.body:
Ever since the birth of the teenager, any adult who has carved out a career by incorporating all the elements synonymous with an adolescent in-crowd - the spiky, irreverent activities that keep the grown-ups angry and aghast - has had a Bill Haley moment. Finally, Chris Evans has been confronted by his.

For Haley it was the day when the nation's youth, having pulled seats from cinemas and danced in the aisles, turned up at the airport and backed away on discovering rock and roll was being branded by a paunchy man with a kiss curl who was heading for 40. Now a kooky, bespectacled redhead is no longer the image that Channel 4 wishes to push as a brand as it pursues that elusive younger audience. (These days, viewer years are as odd as dog years: 'teenager' speaks for a 16- to 25-year-old demographic). Research in a recent internal Channel 4 report confirms that real teenagers would rather watch Sky One than the shows C4 offers them. Hardly any teenagers claim to watch TFI Friday, and fewer viewers in their early twenties are tuning in. It's an odd development.

According to Sky One's recently appointed general manager, David Bergg, the network is not pursuing an exclusively younger audience. He says Sky One's fan base is 'parents in their forties with three kids who spend all their time in a very expensive replica football kit. They've had multi-channel TV for a number of years... they go on holiday a lot and they read Nick Hornby'.

These parents and infants may soon be the only audience left for TFI Friday. Channel Four, in the wake of its in-house research, appears to be intent on putting Evans out of our misery, by seemingly dropping the idea of any further series. But with a contract until the end of the year, it is believed to be destined to run its annual course of 40 programmes.

Usually, TV bosses remove shows that fail to perform in ratings - curiously TFI pulls the same number of viewers (2.5 million) as it did two years ago - although it is beaten regularly by BBC2's reruns of The Simpsons. But it is something much more critical that Evans has lost - his appeal both to the empire builders at the channel and the ad men who need a niche. For C4, certain programmes perform a function even more important than entertaining the viewers - they help build the brand and help market the channel as a colourful, edgy, entertaining alternative that can stand out in a cluttered environment.

TFI, at least in C4's eyes, was once the perfect hybrid. It merged the saucy, slapstick aspects that were the legacy of youth television with a frontman inspired by the Zoo TV format that caught the eye of an audience living out their twenties in the Nineties. The whole experience was controlled by a kooky spontaneity roadtested in hospital and regional radio. But no longer: Evans - far from being seen as an irreverent anti-establishment figure - is now a media baron who invites his celebrity mates on to the show for an over-familiar chat in the studio. It's not quite Hello! TV but it isn't a million miles removed, and it is certainly a world away from the kind of brash subversive programmes with which C4 made a name (and brand) for itself in the early and mid-Nineties. Hence the channel chiefs' concern.

As a sign of this unease C4 and TFI have enlisted a 'fixer' to nurse the show into a state of remission before its inevitable demise. Step forward Seamus Cassidy - one of the longest-serving apparatchiks from the early days of C4, in his former role as head of comedy and entertainment. He is to be installed at the nerve centre of the Evans empire, Ginger Productions, for one day each week, reportedly due to his ability to keep the sovereign under control.

Cassidy was behind the commissioning of both TFI Friday, and the series that helped Evans to escape from the shelter of Planet 24, where he had been cast as a sizeable celebrity on The Big Breakfast. The plaudits that rained down on that show - Don't Forget Your Toothbrush - transformed it into the stuff of legend. It was said to have not simply brought a younger audience to a postmodern entertainment format, but did so in the Saturday night slot that had all but been written off since Saturday Night Live went off air, and the first generation of alternative comedians crossed channels.

In hindsight, much of the show's greater success, and Evans's windfall of cash, was down to the extent to which the programme was sold abroad. It was bought by many countries, who translated it to their mother tongue, and all but put a bouncy redhead with kooky glasses at the helm.

We find its legacy in a series such as Something For The Weekend which, with a wild, wacky blonde in leathers to the fore, and an emphasis on pricks and prizes, endeavours to fuse the essence of Evans with the stunts and pseudo-shock tactics of C4's traditional Friday night fare: The Word, The Girlie Show. The fact that an Australian network has recently bought the Weekend format, with other countries giving approving nods, suggests that we could be in for another lengthy haul.

The truth is, TFI Friday has never done what it said on the tin. Channel Four appears to have prolonged its life as though it was part of its cache of programmes made to keep the network in the columns of the Daily Mail. How's that for blind ambition? Not that Evans hasn't tried. In the past, when the going got tough, he simply stripped naked or incorporated elements of other entertainment shows to which his oeuvre was once touted as an antidote. It was as though Tarrant and Edmonds were in the house.

Controversy did however arrive, in the shape of a knuckle-rapping from the ITC, for making a child guest cry. From the outset, the show was doomed to become the TV equivalent of Oasis: it came up on the outside, but ultimately, became the centre of the worst case of excessive celebrity camaraderie. It was Chris and his friends: Gazza, Sporty Spice, Robbie, Kathy Burke, and the cast of any male-dominated British film. Valerie Solanas - she who shot Andy Warhol - once said that men had the opposite of the Midas Touch: everything they touch turns to shit. The same could be said of the credibility of every guest who sets foot on TFI Friday. Even the magnificence of Babybird, whose distinctive lo-fi, DIY pop was the antithesis of Evans's mainstream musical mates, seems to have been dulled by association with the show.

Credibility is the key to the reason that C4 no longer needs Evans as a main brand. This is why Ali G and Richard Blackwood have been warmed up in the wings, and exposed at every opportunity, until familiarity's first mate - contempt - is almost at the door. Its pursuit of credibility brings to mind that of Abbey National launching an account called Cahoots to make young investors feel they are part of their own club. Currently, the channel remembers the days of The Word fondly, and is eager to capture the audience that helped put it on the map. But the programme, like The Girlie Show was the last word, rather than the first, in what was previously termed 'youth' television.

It began in earnest with the professional ineptitude of the presenters and camera angles of Network 7. But like 'alternative' and 'gay', 'youth' became the word that anyone worth their salt moved away from because of the media figures who had come to symbolise it. The central presenters of The Word were essentially the kind that could have previously presented Why Don't You...?, with the right wardrobe and vocabulary grafted onto them.

The origin of the species of what later metamorphosed into youth television was a genuinely more credible animal. It's ironic that Danny Baker should now be a provider of stunts and jokes to TFI Friday, as he was one of the first, and best practitioners of the craft in the post-punk period of the Seventies. In the series he worked with Janet Street Porter on The London Weekend Show and 20th Century Box - two programmes in which the trends cited within the content emerged from a sub-culture of which the show's presenters were a part.

The nation's youth may have moved on - grown up, perhaps, even though many of those pursuing their interests are left looking in the same old places. It's not surprising that the nation's youth are now, more than any generation before, obsessed with pension plans, shares, and insurance. (Instead of forming bands, they take out bonds.) After all, look what has been done in their name by TV executives who assume that youth and infantilism are one and the same.

It is not simply that C4 is looking in the same places for subjects for youth programmes - it is also looking at the same faces to make them. The backroom staff who cut their teeth on Network 7, and came of age on The Word, now head the production companies that wheel out the same themes - Gail Porter's 'world of smut' on dotcomedy - for the current e-generation.

Technology, and in particular, interactive technology is the straw to which commissioning editors are now clutching in the hope of enticing a younger audience from the Net. This interactive element, fundamental to a market which used to be built almost exclusively on its appeal to teenagers - that of computer games - has become the keyword in broadcasting, at a time when the computer games industry is addressing itself to the whole family. (The forthcoming PlayStation 2 is to be marketed as a piece of living-room furniture, like a television, rather than a toy for the teenage bedroom).

Certainly 'interactive' is the word C4 bandies about in relation to its new E4 channel, the forthcoming Big Brother and How To Become An E-Millionaire. It's the perfect word to pull in a generation more IT-literate than its predecessors. And it's currently the only word TV executives have in their vocabulary on the subject of television and youth, in the absence of any knowledge of the trends or movements that actually occupy the minds of the young.

And there they are, stranded, like the Fifties preachers Tom Wolfe once wrote about, who did everything to 'reach the urban young people' and bring them back to the faith. They marched for causes, they played rock'n'roll at Sunday vespers, they set up beatnik coffee houses in church basements. And still there were no teenage faces to be found in the congregation.

But the programme, like The Girlie Show was the last word, rather than the first, in what was previously termed 'youth' television. It began in earnest with the professional ineptitude of the presenters and camera angles of Network 7. But like 'alternative' and 'gay', 'youth' became the word that anyone worth their salt moved away from because of the media figures who had come to symbolise it. The central presenters of The Word were essentially the kind that could have previously presented Why Don't You...?, with the right wardrobe and vocabulary grafted onto them. The origin of the species of what later metamorphosed into youth television was a genuinely more credible animal. It's ironic that Danny Baker should now be a provider of stunts and jokes to TFI Friday, as he was one of the first, and best practitioners of the craft in the post-punk period of the Seventies. In the series he worked with Janet Street Porter on The London Weekend Show and 20th Century Box - two programmes in which the trends cited within the content emerged from a sub-culture of which the show's presenters were a part. The nation's youth may have moved on - grown up, perhaps, even though many of those pursuing their interests are left looking in the same old places. It's not surprising that the nation's youth are now, more than any generation before, obsessed with pension plans, shares, and insurance. (Instead of forming bands, they take out bonds.) After all, look what has been done in their name by TV executives who assume that youth and infantilism are one and the same. It is not simply that C4 is looking in the same places for subjects for youth programmes - it is also looking at the same faces to make them. The backroom staff who cut their teeth on Network 7, and came of age on The Word, now head the production companies that wheel out the same themes - Gail Porter's 'world of smut' on dotcomedy - for the current e-generation. Technology, and in particular, interactive technology is the straw to which commissioning editors are now clutching in the hope of enticing a younger audience from the Net. This interactive element, fundamental to a market which used to be built almost exclusively on its appeal to teenagers - that of computer games - has become the keyword in broadcasting, at a time when the computer games industry is addressing itself to the whole family. (The forthcoming PlayStation 2 is to be marketed as a piece of living-room furniture, like a television, rather than a toy for the teenage bedroom). Certainly 'interactive' is the word C4 bandies about in relation to its new E4 channel, the forthcoming Big Brother and How To Become An E-Millionaire. It's the perfect word to pull in a generation more IT-literate than its predecessors. And it's currently the only word TV executives have in their vocabulary on the subject of television and youth, in the absence of any knowledge of the trends or movements that actually occupy the minds of the young. And there they are, stranded, like the Fifties preachers Tom Wolfe once wrote about, who did everything to 'reach the urban young people' and bring them back to the faith. They marched for causes, they played rock'n'roll at Sunday vespers, they set up beatnik coffee houses in church basements. And still there were no teenage faces to be found in the congregation.

fields.headline: Dentist cheats face probe
fields.standfirst: Observer campaign sparks Government clampdown to end £200m NHS fraud :The rip-off dentists
fields.trailText: The government is to act against cowboy dentists, following The Observer 's revelations that £200 million worth of unnecessary work is carried out each year and 90 per cent of all dentistry is substandard.
fields.body:
The government is to act against cowboy dentists, following The Observer 's revelations that £200 million worth of unnecessary work is carried out each year and 90 per cent of all dentistry is substandard. Meanwhile, whistle-blowing dentists continue to reveal details of the profession's systematic defrauding of the National Health Service.

Lord Hunt, the Minister responsible for dentists, has promised to introduce a system whereby dentists would audit each other's work and to bring the profession under closer scrutiny. He said: 'I am concerned about the variations in the quality of work.' Poor performers would have to be retrained, he said, and regional health authorities, which currently largely ignore dentists, would be responsible for monitoring them closely. The full reforms will be announced in July.

In a passionate plea to clean up the profession, one dentist wrote to The Observer, claiming that most of his colleagues were boosting their earnings by making false claims for NHS payments: 'I estimate that 10 per cent of the profession are blatantly fraudulent, with another 15 per cent working in the "grey areas". Add to that a further 30 per cent who are chancing it occasionally, and you have a majority of the profession who are committing some degree of fraud.'

Frauds include overcharging patients, claiming fees for work that wasn't done, and doing cheap treatments but claiming fees for expensive ones. The dentist concluded: 'Sadly, dentistry is a very dirty/shady profession, in dire need of exposure. There are many deeply caring and hard-working dentists out there who are being let down by the cowboys ... it is a profession that is slowly sliding into the mire.'

Another dentist, from the north of England, admitted: 'NHS dentists virtually can't work without fraud. People are forced into fraud because the fees are so low. It is very widespread. For the older ones, it is just how they work the system.'

The dentists detailed dozens of scams that are widespread in the profession, of which the most straightforward include:

* Charging full private fees for work, and then also claiming payment on the NHS.

* Charging the patient the NHS fee, but then claiming the patient is on benefits and entitled to free treatment, and recouping the full amount from the Government.

* Fitting a non-precious alloy crown, but claiming fees for an expensive precious metal one. 'It's a very safe form of fraudulent claim because you can only prove it by removing the work from the patient and analysing it,' said one dentist.

* Claiming fees for repairing braces, work which it is impossible to prove whether or not it has been done. 'Most practitioners will claim these fees on a regular basis to boost fee income, because they are never checked.'

* Dentists - who are entitled to claim a one-off £50 fee for opening over the weekend - line up many patients back to back on Saturday and claim the fee for each one. 'So many dentists totally abuse this,' said one dentist.

* A less common scam includes inventing patients and claiming fees for work that is not done. A reputable dentist said: 'I know this works, because I have done it to test out the system. I have been paid for non-existent treatment on non-existent patients. However I have refunded it.'

Another said he was shocked when he first started work after training: 'I was in a situation when it was almost forced on me. It is part of the philosophy of the practice. It's the way things are done and you just fall in with it.'

One dentist said: 'If you are clever about it, you do things that people can't check. The chances of getting caught are virtually nil.' Another dentist added: 'It's an absolute scandal that this is allowed to go on. There is no other form of business where monitoring of payments is so slack, and where the consumer doesn't know or understand what they are paying for. NHS dentistry is nothing more than a scam for the cowboys/girls, and it could be tightened up tomorrow if anyone had the courage to do it.'

Anthony Kravitz, chairman of the general dental services committee of the British Dental Association - the trade union for dentists - said he had no idea how much fraud there was, but insisted 'fraud of any kind cannot be tolerated and any dentist involved in fraudulent claims must be dealt with. Defrauding the NHS whether you are a patient or a dentist is totally unacceptable. We want to see fraud in dentistry eradicated because it diverts funding away from patient care. The systems for detecting fraud in dentistry are already in place and are far more developed in dentistry than in other areas of medicine.'

fields.headline: The good feud guide
fields.standfirst: It's Prada handbags at 15 paces as  Tatler  and  Harpers & Queen slug it out for the title of the glossiest glossy, says  Harriet Lane
fields.trailText: It's Prada handbags at 15 paces as Tatler and Harpers & Queen slug it out for the title of the glossiest glossy, says Harriet Lane
fields.body:
Wellington v Napoleon. Robbie Fowler v Graham Le Saux. When it comes to bitchy scraps, Tatler v Harpers & Queen is right up there with Julie Burchill v Toby Young. The ancient rivalry between the two glossies was given a shot in the arm this week with the publication of Tatler 's June issue, featuring an interview with the Duke and Duchess of York, in which they discussed the very, very remote possibility of remarriage.

Though neither placed any likelihood on this happening, this was merrily overlooked by the tabloids. 'I May Wed Sarah Again!' was the Mirror 's front-page lead and, if you wanted more, you could turn to page two, three, four and five to have a closer look at its 'Royal World Exclusive'.

All of which was a bit unfair on Tatler 's editor, Geordie Greig, who had gone to the effort of chumming up to the duke at some NSPCC shindig - and posting off a copy of his book about the friendship of their respective grandfathers - in order to secure the interview in the first place. He must have taken consolation from the fact that over at National Magazines, publisher of Harpers & Queen, hearts must be sinking faster than the Nasdaq.

Jane Procter, the last editor of Tatler, used to say that editing the magazine was 'not exactly rocket science'. Looking at the careful manoeuvrings of Greig, who inherited Procter's office last June, one is not so sure. All last week, he did the groundwork, dropping tantalising snippets to gossip columnists implying that Tatler 's circulation was, for the first time, overtaking that of H&Q. Never mind that his comments were based on figures that were released back in February. Fiona Macpherson, who edits H&Q, told the London's Evening Standard : 'He can say what he likes, but it's not accurate.'

Just when the pair had the diarists spinning at 78rpm, Greig proved that he did have something up his sleeve as well as his vintage gold watch - a royal scoop. In the bar at Claridge's, where Tatler girls repair after work, corks are popping. Royal stories are invaluable when it comes to pushing up circulation figures and advertising rates. 'It's overwhelming,' says one member of staff. 'The atmosphere here is completely mad.'

However, Macpherson, who is in her fifties and has been at Harpers (circulation 90,101) since 1994, remains untroubled. 'They're spending a huge amount, so they bloody well should have pulled the circulation up.' She claims not to have noticed any change in the Tatler formula since Greig's arrival. 'None at all. It's seamless. I understood it was going to be very literary, so I was expecting the New Yorker, but there are no signs of that.'

A former literary editor of the Sunday Times, 38-year-old Greig has the posh bit sewn up - Eton, Oxford and, as he pointed out in a rather excruciating piece last summer, 'my great-grandfather was the premier baron of England, Lord Mowbray, Segrave and Stourton, while my father's family have been royal courtiers for three generations' - whereas Macpherson's low-key manner and decided Scottishness (educated in Inverness, St Andrew's and D.C. Thomson in Dundee) have never intimidated the professional women, corporate wives and City girls who make up her readership.

Like its editor, H&Q is a little austere, workmanlike and can usually be relied upon to say the right thing. Particularly in a spat. 'It's interesting,' muses Macpherson, 'because Fergie has offered herself to us in the past, but we've always turned her down.'

Tatler (circulation 85,185) has always been louder, younger and more showy-offy. Over the last few months, it has started to show exciting signs of returning to the outright wickedness that characterised Tina Brown's tenure in the editor's chair. For instance, a new regular is an unforgiving 'Then and Now' photo-feature, guaranteed to raise socialites' hackles.

Greig's next challenge will be to boost the quality of the writing: a recent cover story on Madonna was as limp as steamed spinach. Perhaps there are some things that money just can't buy.

webTitle: Saint-Tropez to bulldoze jet set's beach party bars

fields.headline: Saint-Tropez to bulldoze jet set's beach party bars
fields.trailText: His name may not be as familiar as Brigitte Bardot's, but Paul Tomaselli has probably done as much as the Sixties screen star to turn the quiet fishing village of Saint-Tropez into a holiday haunt for the international jet set.
fields.body:
His name may not be as familiar as Brigitte Bardot's, but Paul Tomaselli has probably done as much as the Sixties screen star to turn the quiet fishing village of Saint-Tropez into a holiday haunt for the international jet set.

So Tomaselli was understandably miffed last week when the town council, in a drive to clean up the resort's image and rid the Riviera of its more unsightly excrescences, ordered him to pull down the summer restaurant he has run on Pampelonne beach since 1968.

La Voile Rouge, whose guests have included Jane Fonda, Robert De Niro, Sylvester Stallone, George Michael, Mick Jagger, Liza Minnelli, Charles Aznavour and - inevitably - the Spice Girls, was built in defiance of planning regulations but has long been tolerated as one of Saint-Trop's biggest draws.

But, after numerous complaints from local residents about the decibel level of the restaurant's music and the incessant roar of helicopters bringing in new arrivals from Nice airport, the council has ruled that La Voile Rouge be bulldozed to the ground.

'Why me?' asked Tomaselli, pointing out the 32 other illegal bars and eateries lining the beach. 'I'm one of the originals, one of the glories of the place.'

Tomaselli, who calls La Voile Rouge 'a genuine experiment in sexual and surreal philosophy', also enjoys fame as the man who launched the fashion for bare breasts on the Riviera by allowing his women customers to go topless.

With the help of French celebrities, including rocker Johnny Hallyday, he has promised to fight the council's decision through the courts, beginning with an appeal on a technicality.

The ruling of Saint-Tropez's planning committee, he claims, is illegal because it was elected by simple majority and not, as the rules stipulate, by proportional representation.

Although the village that the writer Guy de Maupassant described as 'a charming, simple daughter of the sea' first hit the headlines in 1956 with Bardot's breakthrough appearance in And God Created Woman, its charms were discovered in the late nineteenth century.

Artists and writers were drawn by the peninsula's spectacular light and the resort rapidly became popular. As early as 1937 the writer Colette was complaining about the number of American cars by the harbour and by 1989 Bardot declared that she could no longer live there and was 'leaving it to the invaders'.

In an effort to return the resort to an earlier, gentler age, the council admits it has chosen La Voile Rouge as a test case for all the illegally built bars and restaurants that clutter its beaches. 'They're ugly, noisy, not terribly safe and completely illegal,' a spokesman said. 'They've had a good run, but it's time to call it a day and return the beach to its state of natural beauty.'

The Saint-Tropez Beach Restaurant Owners' Association has said it will back Tomaselli and oppose any attempt to drive its members from the beaches they helped make famous. But they may have bitten off more than they can chew: the French Council of State is expected to rule this year that Pampelonne beach is an area of outstanding natural beauty on which no permanent structures of any kind should be allowed.

webTitle: Finance guru snared in porn queen's web

fields.headline: Finance guru snared in porn queen's web
fields.standfirst: He was a banker. She was a $100,000 hardcore movie star. Now he's on the skids after passing her secrets and she's on the run, reports  Ed Vulliamy in New York
fields.trailText: When chief executive officer James McDermott walked into the boardroom of Keefe, Bruyette and Woods for the most important meeting in the firm's history, he was a titan on Wall Street with an imperial view from the 85th floor of the World Trade Centre.
fields.body:
When chief executive officer James McDermott walked into the boardroom of Keefe, Bruyette and Woods for the most important meeting in the firm's history, he was a titan on Wall Street with an imperial view from the 85th floor of the World Trade Centre.

A rags-to-riches banker, McDermott was the prominent public face of high finance, a prodigy chief executive and television pundit on an annual salary of $4.4 million. Now he was about to become one of Tom Wolfe's 'Masters of the Universe'.

At that meeting on 6 May last year, Keefe, Bruyette and Woods was due to announce a public offering of 4.7 million shares which would raise $85m, with a personal stake of $20m for McDermott, but he had something confess: he had passed on trading information to a 'friend' now under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. He told colleagues only that the connection was 'personal'.

The 'friend' was his lover and confidante, Kathryn Gannon, or Marilyn Star, a porn queen with her own live-action website and a string of XXX-rated films, including Cirque du Sex and Strap up Sally. Before her tryst with McDermott, Star's marketing experience had been limited to her talents and a range of sex toys. Her films even feature fans who pay $800 to star in a scene with her.

With her director and camera crew, she tours restau rants and bars inquiring: 'Hey baby, you wanna get laid?' Star, McDermott's lover, was the lucky recipient of lucrative insider information on coming mergers and deals on Keefe, Bruyette's confidential 'watch list'.

After McDermott's revelation, the board adjourned and Keefe, Bruyette's public issue was cancelled. Three days later McDermott was invited to resign. For months, the decision remained a mystery, the firm successfully encouraging rumours it had pulled back from the brink because it was itself subject to takeover. It has taken a full year for the details to leak out from the World Trade Centre.

McDermott's destruction was complete last week when he became the first CEO on Wall Street to be convicted of insider trading. The reputations of he and his firm are in ruins. To complete his humiliation, the lover whom Marilyn Star had kept in tandem with McDermott - Anthony Pomponio - was convicted with him. Star passed information from McDermott to Pomponio, a New Jersey businessman she met at a porn fair.

Star is a fugitive in her native Canada, promising to resist extradition. She is shacked up at the Vancouver villa of her latest squeeze, her 'financier' Michael Gilley.

McDermott's life was built on the spree of banking mergers in the Nineties. From his office he returned home each night to an expansive mock-Tudor home. Waiting for him in the exclusive gated community of Braircliffe Manor were his wife, Darian, and his two teenage daughters. He seemed infallible.

Born a blue-collar kid in a roughneck neighbourhood of Queens, McDermott had worked nights to get himself to Fordham University. In 1977 he began his push to the top by joining Keefe, Bruyette's as a research analyst. The firm specialised in advising banks on mergers and acquisitions, and he became one of Wall Street's most respected and reliable analysts. His brilliance dazzled his employer, the firm's founder, Harry Keefe, who had hired him and hoisted him through the ranks.

Keefe also insisted that McDermott be the firm's poster boy - he became a touchstone for the world of finance, a regular feature on CNN and NBC television. He was a workaholic and known, ironically, 'for his ability to keep his mouth shut', said one ex-colleague - qualities which took him to head of research and in 1992 to the apex of the company.

In summer 1997, McDermott was flying high after making $4.4m in a single sales issue. Around then he logged on to Marilyn Star's website and suggested a rendezvous.

Born Kathryn Gannon, in Alberta, Canada, Star dreamt of becoming a ballerina. She took lessons and danced for Prince Charles and Princess Diana when they passed through for the World University Games. She moved to Calgary and the French Maid strip club. In 1994, she made a career-switch to become Mar ilyn Star, porn diva. In a later interview with Talking Blue magazine, she explained: 'I felt if I was going to get laid anyhow, why not on film?'

Everyone in California knows the 'Berry Man' from fruit produce packets. What they don't know is that 'Berry Man' is Bruce Akahoshi, a Japanese entrepreneur who was in Canada on business when he dropped into the French Maid club in 1994, and tipped the stripper $20.

Star needed US papers; the couple had sex and tied the marital knot at a quickie wedding in Lake Tahoe, Nevada, in 1994. They stayed together three years, Akahoshi following his wife around America - 'I'm basically a fruit and vegetable man,' he says now, 'and she is a beautiful stripper ... the sex was great but it was heartbreak.' Once in America, Star signed up with Videotown Pictures in California, earning $100,000 for one feature - 'it sickened me,' says Akahoshi. His wife, he noticed, 'became more of a dark and secret person' and one day in 1997 left a note saying she had gone for good.

Marilyn moved to Miami Beach, and took an apartment in the prestigious South Pointe high-rise block. By now she was making $800 a scene for hardcore videos, and according to Dion Giarusso, director of most of her films, Star was so successful she 'was only doing one full-length movie a year. She could afford to be an artiste.'

But as she grew more successful, she began to boast about a man she had been seeing in New York.

In 1998, Lionel Andre, a lawyer with the Securities and Exchange Commission, was assigned to investigate a brokerage called Charles Schwab, compiling a report on suspicious trading of shares in the Barnett Bank at the time of its merger with the giant Nations Bank. Andre found an account with a curious trading history, in the name of Gannon, which had the knack of picking small, regional bank stocks that were targets for mergers, before the share price rose.

The pattern was repeated with impressive regularity. On 16 June, 1997, for example, she spent $12,773 on 390 shares in the Central Fidelity Bank just ahead of a takeover by Wachovia, on the day of which she resold at a clean profit of $7,044. In the next nine months she snapped up shares in six other banks that merged or were the targets of mergers just days before the news hit the market, netting gains of nearly $90,000. Stranger still, Andre found an account at Schwab with traces that almost exactly matched Gannon's, belonging to Pomponio.

For all her guile, Gannon showed no signs of trading experience apart from a modest savings account; her investments were not what they seemed. As Marc Medoff - head of the Adult Press Service in Manhattan which covers the porn industry - puts it: 'Marilyn is a loving trusting person, but her PhD is in pornography, not high finance.'

Andre got a subpoena for Gannon's banking records in Miami, and found a trail of money from accounts at the Chase bank in New York, mainly in certified cheques signed by McDermott. Judge Kimba Wook had overruled prosecution attempts to tell the jury about Gannon's background and career: she was referred to as a 'dancer and actress', with the prefixes 'adult' and 'exotic' removed by the bench. All the jurors saw was a photograph from her driving licence. But, said one: 'We didn't think she was the Queen of England.'

Star slipped from Miami to Vancouver, where she vows to resist the extradition proceedings. She has broken her silence only once, in an interview to the Toronto Sun: 'This is their job?' she said, 'Chasing a little girl around the world? For God's sake, I'm an adult movie actress, not a professor of economics.'

She said she was 'manipulated - I trusted more experienced, powerful, wealthy men who I assumed were acting properly. I believed in them, they let me down. When everything comes out we'll see who turns out to be the sleazy ones, the guys on Wall Street, or the girls in Los Angeles who do sex scenes.'

webTitle: Snakes sideline saint as Italian village embraces its pagan past

fields.headline: Snakes sideline saint as Italian village embraces its pagan past
fields.trailText: Deep in the Abruzzo mountains, Christianity is fighting a losing battle for the soul of the ancient and bizarre festival of snakes.
fields.body:
Deep in the Abruzzo mountains, Christianity is fighting a losing battle for the soul of the ancient and bizarre festival of snakes.

For 1,000 years the Church has vied for the fealty of the village of Cocullo by supplanting its pagan god with a local saint. Once a year, on the first Thursday in May, priests in the crumbling church permit their flock to entwine a mass of snakes around the neck of a statue of St Domenic. Deformed buskers, shepherds and snake-catchers follow it through the village in a procession which is deemed Christian, though it is rooted in worship of the Greek god Apollo.

Last week, however, the veneer evaporated. After the procession locals and a new parish priest admitted what the hierarchy have long feared: the rite no longer belonged to the Church. Older, more primitive forces had returned.

The 15,000 people who parked at the foot of the Apennine mountains in central Italy and climbed to join Cocullo's 200 inhabitants did not come to pay homage to the saint. They came to hold, caress and wear snakes the way their forefathers did, 2,700 years ago. And to make money.

Around 700BC local shepherds, plagued by snakes, were advised by an oracle to appease Apollo by capturing the reptiles and placing them on his statue.

The tradition survived colonisation by the Romans but was amended, according to historians, by substituting the statue of St Domenic, a monk born in AD950 who had performed miracles, including curing snake bites.

The Church insists the snake festival is Christian. 'Domenic was real, his miracles were real, this is to honour him,' said Fr Carmelo Rotolo, 69. Paganism was dead and buried, agreed the left-wing mayor, Nicola Risio.

Yet for the first time in centuries, the Church was last week banned from a post-concert procession. 'It's nothing to do with them,' shrugged an organiser. Fr Alain, who arrived in Cocullo from Madagascar eight months ago, was appalled. 'I was shocked when I saw the ceremony. This is the only place in the world where this could happen. Old ladies came to the Mass but the men stayed away. They are fanatical about the ritual but don't feel the religious aspect.'

Cocullo survives on cheese-making but faces extinction as its population dies off. Nunzio Marcelli, 46, a shepherd, said the one day in the year when the town came to life was no longer in honour of the saint. 'If it's about anything now, it's money. The snakes represent something older than Domenic.'

Locals started lifting rocks and investigating caves three weeks ago. The snakes, which are not poisonous, were bagged and stored at home. Cocullo, which has no shops, bars, restaurants or hotels, woke up at dawn on Thursday to the sound of hundreds of traders setting up stalls. Donkey testicles, boar heads, popcorn, wine gums, sunglasses, rocking chairs, cordless drills and desk lamps were on sale.

Amputee beggars with wounds made to look fresh lined the narrow streets. Mothers twined snakes round the necks of infants and held them up to see St Domenic's statue, as men tried to add their snakes to the writhing mass.

As evening fell, people wanting to banish dental problems queued to ring the church bell with their teeth while the snakes were released into the wild. Until 60 years ago they were dumped in the town fountain and chopped up.

webTitle: Tigers close in on beaten Sri Lankans

fields.headline: Tigers close in on beaten Sri Lankans
fields.standfirst: Rebel guns reach key airfield as 28,000 troops trapped in Jaffna nervously await a bloody end to 17 years of war
fields.trailText: Rebel guns reach key airfield as 28,000 troops trapped in Jaffna nervously await a bloody end to 17 years of war.
fields.body:
At the far end of a military airport in Colombo, a Hercules aircraft sits in a hangar. Unfortunately for Sri Lanka's marooned army in the north, it does not work. Over the past two and a half weeks, as rebel Tamil Tigers advanced across the Jaffna peninsula, engineers were pondering how to fix the plane's broken exhaust duct.

In the unlikely event that the Hercules is mended, Sri Lanka's panicky military establishment faces another problem: it has no pilots capable of flying it. A second Hercules ordered from Britain as part of a £12 million deal has yet to arrive. Some 16 flights a day continue to supply the cut-off town of Jaffna, but the pilots who fly the leased Antonovs are Ukranian.

It is against this background of bungling and delay in provision of vital aircraft and weaponry, that the Sri Lankan government appears to be losing its 17-year-war against the Tamil Tigers.

Since 22 April, the Tigers have used devastating heavy artillery fire to push deep into the Jaffna peninsula, capturing a key military base at Elephant Pass and advancing to within 23 miles of Jaffna, their capital until 1995. The government yesterday claimed it had driven rebel soldiers from the naval base of Kilaly; the Tigers say they are still there.

Although government troops are not beaten yet, it seems a matter of time before Jaffna falls, in what would be Sri Lanka's answer to Saigon.

According to the few aid workers remaining in Jaffna, the mood there is tense. The latest Tiger offensive has driven 10,000 refugees into the town. 'They fled completely on advice. There was some notification that villages were going to be targeted. They had time to prepare things,' one aid worker said. 'They are camping out in schools and temples and places like that. We are providing them with plastic sheeting, bedding and clothing. There is a tremendous amount of anxiety. The shelling is pretty constant. It is going on all the time.'

The government insists life continues as normal, with schools and offices still open.

'There is no fighting in Jaffna yet. What worries us is how things will evolve,' another aid worker said.

All radio links to Jaffna were severed last week, when soldiers fleeing Elephant Pass blew up a transmitter. With the town cut off by advancing rebels, the only way in and out is via the military airbase at Palali, on the northern peninsula.

The Tigers need to advance only five more kilometres before the base's runway comes in range of their heavy artillery. This would force the military to evacuate. 'The situation is very worrying,' Isabelle Barras of the International Red Cross said yesterday. Some 45 UN personnel left yesterday by Red Cross boat, but other aid agencies are staying put.

Officially, Sri Lanka's government, headed by President Chandrika Kumaratunga, has ruled out any possibility of evacuating the 28,000 troops stuck in Jaffna. 'There is absolutely no truth in these reports,' army chief of staff Major General Lionel Balagalle declared yesterday. Instead, the President has embarked on an urgent quest for diplomatic support and fresh military hardware.

Several new Israeli jet fighters are expected to arrive in Colombo shortly, following Sri Lanka's resumption of diplomatic relations with Israel last week. Whether the jets are enough to turn the war around remains to be seen. 'In the worst-case scenario we will have to evacuate temporarily,' one senior government official admitted. 'You can't sacrifice 28,000 lives. But I don't think it is going to happen.'

Military analysts say any evacuation would be difficult. The Sri Lankan military is believed to have more than a dozen Israeli naval gunships. But it has no large frigates which could transport thousands of soldiers, diplomatic sources suggest. India last week ruled out assistance, following its disastrous intervention in the war between 1987-1990, though it may yet send a task force to rescue some of Jaffna's 500,000-strong civilian Tamil population.

But any sea operation is fraught with danger. The Tigers' enigmatic leader, Velupillai Prabhakaran, who operates from a secret base near Mullaittivu on Sri Lanka's north-east coast, has virtual domination of all major sea routes.

Soldiers on the front line near Kilaly, meanwhile, continue to die. 'The problem is that the Tigers, whenever they attack, do so with massive firepower,' one analyst said. 'The soldiers are caught hiding behind pathetic bunker lines. The Tigers advance with the kind of textbook strategies used by European armies.'

Kumaratunga's other response to the crisis has been an Orwellian public order act. Sweeping censorship has been imposed. The President has new powers to ban public meetings, seize printing presses, and close down newspapers. All journalists must submit stories to a military censor. Journalists have long been forbidden from visiting the battle zone. But the latest edicts mean Sri Lanka's 17-year-old war is now almost unreportable.

webTitle: Farewell, Faroes. Now it's just you and all those fish now

fields.headline: Farewell, Faroes. Now it's just you and all those fish now
fields.trailText: It has been a long time coming but, after more than 600 years, the Faroe islanders are finally shaking off the imperial yoke. The 18 islands, which lie to the north-west of Scotland, halfway between Iceland and Norway, are attempting to negotiate their independence from Denmark, under whose not-so-brutish regime they have lived since 1380.
fields.body:
It has been a long time coming but, after more than 600 years, the Faroe islanders are finally shaking off the imperial yoke. The 18 islands, which lie to the north-west of Scotland, halfway between Iceland and Norway, are attempting to negotiate their independence from Denmark, under whose not-so-brutish regime they have lived since 1380.

Last week, a delegation of islanders arrived in Copenhagen with their plans for the big break. Denmark has shown little enthusiasm for ruling the archipelago of 18 islands since the war (for the duration of which the islands came under British protection, keeping their protector well supplied with fish in return). In 1948, Denmark granted the islanders autonomous status.

They have their own flag and football team, and a seat on the Nordic Council, alongside Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Norway and others. They conduct their own affairs in their own language. In addition, Copenhagen throws in, each year, a financial package worth about 128 million euros (£75m). In addition Denmark pays an additional 35m euros (£20.5m) for policing, local justice, and education.

The first serious rumblings of discontent from independent-minded Faroese were heard in the early Nineties. A banking scandal in Denmark led to rumours that the Danish were ripping off the islanders. Two years ago Denmark said it would be prepared to accept whatever constitutional arrangements the 45,000 islanders wanted.

The Faroese want the subsidy to be phased out over 15 or 20 years. Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, the Social Democrat Danish Prime Minister, has said there is no question of Denmark remaining a milch cow to the islands once the two have parted. 'The transition phase will not exceed three to four years,' he said in March. After that, Denmark would not 'throw even a cent'.

The announcement has cooled the islanders' passion for freedom and worried their devolved coalition government which plans to put the independence question to a referendum in the autumn. Surveys already show 46 per cent of Faroese uncertain about unsubsidised freedom. They are hostile to joining the European Union, fearing it would lead to an invasion of its waters by French and Spanish trawlermen. But how, many Faroese are asking, can a nation of 18 islands, 95 per cent of whose income comes from fish, survive on its own?

Two years ago Denmark said it would be prepared to accept whatever constitutional arrangements the 45,000 islanders wanted. The Faroese want the subsidy to be phased out over 15 or 20 years. Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, the Social Democrat Danish Prime Minister, has said there is no question of Denmark remaining a milch cow to the islands once the two have parted. 'The transition phase will not exceed three to four years,' he said in March. After that, Denmark would not 'throw even a cent'. The announcement has cooled the islanders' passion for freedom and worried their devolved coalition government which plans to put the independence question to a referendum in the autumn. Surveys already show 46 per cent of Faroese uncertain about unsubsidised freedom. They are hostile to joining the European Union, fearing it would lead to an invasion of its waters by French and Spanish trawlermen. But how, many Faroese are asking, can a nation of 18 islands, 95 per cent of whose income comes from fish, survive on its own?

webTitle: US teenager unmasks the Net stalkers

fields.headline: US teenager unmasks the Net stalkers
fields.trailText: As Dalliances go, Katherine Tarbox's first foray into an America Online chatroom seemed a success. She found 'Mark', who appeared to be a soulmate. Six months later, she is likely to rue the friendship for the rest of her life.
fields.body:
As Dalliances go, Katherine Tarbox's first foray into an America Online chatroom seemed a success. She found 'Mark', who appeared to be a soulmate. Six months later, she is likely to rue the friendship for the rest of her life.

A new book published tomorrow exposes her first-hand experience of Internet paedophilia - and shows how vulnerable children are in cyberspace. Katie.Com tells of Tarbox's close call with an Internet predator in 1995, when she was 13. The book will strike a chord in the UK, where a number of recent cases have been unearthed.

In November last year, an unnamed deaf student from London told a court how she was indecently assaulted by a man she initially met on the Internet. Last week a mother from Milton Keynes described how she narrowly prevented her daughter from forming an intimate relationship with an Internet friend who turned out to be in his mid-fifties.

Tarbox first met 'Mark', 23, in an Internet chatroom in October 1995. The relationship flourished as he complimented Tarbox on her 'maturity' and 'talent'. A grade-A student and US nationally ranked swimmer, Tarbox says she was vulnerable to the praise. 'I was confused about myself,' she said from her boarding school in Connecticut. 'I guess he seemed like someone who finally connected with me. I am an over-achiever, and he was someone who seemed to understand what it was like to be good at everything.'

Six months later Tarbox agreed to meet him. On 12 March, 1996, she was in Texas with her swimming team, and 'Mark' booked himself a room at the hotel where they were staying. But when she went to meet him, 'Mark' revealed himself as Frank, 41. On learning of Tarbox's plans, another pupil alerted the police and her mother - narrowly avoiding her sexual assault. Francis John Kufrovich became the first successfully convicted Internet paedophile in the US, jailed under the 1996 Communications Decency Act. He was sentenced to 18 months.

In the US, Katie.Com has been billed as a confessional tour de force, a coming-of-age memoir that reveals the threatening potential of the Internet. Tarbox is on a reading tour of the East Coast that takes in TV appearances. Still only 18, why has she chosen to magnify her traumatic ordeal with a memoir?

'I think it's something that needs to be said,' she said. 'Many children go into chatrooms, and they're unsupervised. It has to be discussed: it's so easy to fall into the same situation I was in. If I can prevent that in any way, I feel like I'm doing something.'

A percentage of the proceeds from Katie.Com will be donated to Rainn, the Rape Abuse and Incest National Network.

fields.headline: Nuba face destruction
fields.standfirst: Julie Flint makes a terrifying 150-mile trek through Sudan's front line where troops are raping and killing an ancient tribe and destroying their crops. Here, hunger is now a weapon of war and scorched earth tactics an engine of annihilation.
fields.trailText: In a few  weeks, barring miracles, the children will begin to die - if not from hunger, then from disease. The skin on their upper arms is already falling into folds as hunger kicks in and the pounds begin to melt away.
fields.body:
In a few weeks, barring miracles, the children will begin to die - if not from hunger, then from disease. The skin on their upper arms is already falling into folds as hunger kicks in and the pounds begin to melt away.

Most families are living in the open, without clothes, blankets or clean water. The mud hut that calls itself a hospital contains nothing but flies. The young man in charge, a farmer turned health worker, says 200 children and 50 old people are already in urgent need of medical care. He is treating them with tree leaves and bark, but he needs anti-malarials and antibiotics.

He shrugs. 'I am doing my best. But I know it's nothing.'

Less than a year after international pressure forced Sudan's Islamist government to allow United Nations relief into the Nuba mountains for the first time in more than a decade, Khartoum is attempting to put the Nuba beyond the reach of relief by cutting off all access to the mountains and starving civilians out of areas controlled by the rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army.

In the past two months, moving in whenever UN teams move out, government forces have captured two of the three rough airstrips that make relief operations possible and have mounted a surprise assault on some of the Nuba's most productive land around the village of Tabanya.

The UN's silence has been almost as shocking to the Nuba as the attack on Tabanya that displaced 15,000 people and propelled them towards Kadoro - a mountain village of 150 families that has shared its own meagre supplies for more than a month and now has nothing more to offer.

'The UN's own first mission to the mountains was heavily shelled - but it has never said a word of criticism of the government,' said Walid Hamed, assistant to rebel commander Yusuf Kuwa.

'When it comes to the government, the UN is on its knees. All we are asking is equal treatment so people can decide freely whether they stay in SPLA areas or go to the government. But the government has the upper hand and the UN system is keeping silent.'

The Nuba are now in their thirteenth year of struggle for a democratic, secular state in which the country's African south would be the equal of its Arab north. Since the fundamentalist generals of the National Islamic Front came to power in 1989, an attempt to defeat the Nuba rebellion has grown into a scorched-earth holy war of annihilation against a people whose tradition of political and religious tolerance threatens the Front's whole project of a conformist Islamic extremism.

Today, hundreds of thousands of Nuba starved out of the mountains are imprisoned in 'peace villages' where men are armed and compelled to fight against fellow Nuba; where children are separated from their parents and conscripted into Islamic militias; where women are raped to dilute Nuba ethnicity.

Nuba who refuse to leave SPLA-controlled areas are being driven off the fertile plains and into the mountains where survival is a daily struggle. Even the UN acknowledges that women venturing down to the government-controlled plains to fetch water and mangoes are subjected to rape 'often of the most horrendous kind'.

As evidence of human rights abuses piles up, the government promises relief but fights with the oldest, and cruellest, weapon in its arsenal - hunger.

Rahila Kuku, a mother of five, was put to work gathering in the sorghum that was thick in the fields surrounding Tabanyaat the time of the attack on the village on 17 March. She says hundreds of prisoners, working at gunpoint, stripped the sorghum fields bare and loaded every grain on to trucks bound for government garrisons in other parts of the mountains.

Rahila escaped to Kadoro after being raped repeatedly over a month, but at the hospital has found only words of comfort - not the painkillers she wants. She says her body still hurts from the beatings she received and her breasts are sore. She suspects she is pregnant. If she is, she says, she will not harm the child. 'It's not his fault.'

Phoebe Tutu fled to Kadoro with nine children and a jerrycan when the first government troops attacked Tabanya at 4am. Forced off Kadoro mountain by hunger a little more than a week ago, she joined a group of 30 women foraging for food on the edge of government-controlled areas a four-hour walk away. The women were ambushed and four died. Phoebe was shot and wounded. Reduced to one small plate of sorghum a day, all her children are suffering from diarrhoea.

The government's capture of Toro airstrip near Tabanya has put the displaced almost beyond the reach of help. The nearest airstrip is now 75miles away - a three-day trek up granite mountains and down valleys where water holes are drying up and government troops lay ambushes for defenceless civilians.

On Easter Sunday, as the UN continued to turn a blind eye to the disaster unfolding around Tabanya five weeks after its fall, the first planeload of 4.3 tons of relief organised by the British charity Christian Aid touched down at an airstrip in the east of the mountains. It was the start of a 10-day round trip that required five camels, 250 porters and an armed guard of almost 100 men to be brought to a successful conclusion.

'At one stroke, the attack on Tabanya has cut people off from their harvest and also from easy access from outside,' said Christian Aid's Paul Savage. 'It now takes a huge logistical effort across insecure and dangerous areas to bring the smallest amount of help to the displaced. This is a planned and purposeful undermining of the Nuba's resilience and capacity to cope and exist.'

The toughest and most dangerous, part of the journey was the first leg - a 10-hour, all-night walk across a valley disputed by the government and the SPLA. Scouts preceded us and flanked us and in the middle of the night ordered a sudden change of route. Without warning, we left the rough track we had been following and took to the bush - looping northwards between thorn bushes and sweet-smelling acacia trees until we encountered a second, parallel track shortly before dawn.

Back in the safety of the mountains by the time the sun rose, we learnt that one of our radio messages had been intercepted and an ambush prepared for us by soldiers who the previous week had captured, and raped, two Nuba women.

The same soldiers climbed that same mountain the following week, under cover of darkness, and killed a Nuba farmer as he slept - the twenty-fourth civilian killed in random hit-and-run raids in the past month, according to Daoud Siddiq, head of a Nuba human rights team working in SPLA-controlled areas.

The second leg of our journey skirted the foothills of the Achiron mountains where government soldiers had kidnapped and then killed the headmaster of a local school a few weeks earlier. Shortly before reaching Dabker, the largest market in the region, our path was obliterated by a chain of bomb craters. The local SPLA commander, Ibrahim Mulfa, said government bombers went into action on 15 April exactly two hours after a UN team flew out of the mountains at the end of a campaign of polio vaccinations.

'No one was hurt,' he said, 'but a pig went down into one of the craters and died. We believe the government is using chemical weapons.'

SPLA officials have been obsessed with the idea of chemical weapons ever since President Clinton ordered the bombing of the al-Shifa factory in Khartoum in 1998, claiming it was part of a government chemical weapons programme. Nuba civilians know better. It is they who are being attacked, not the SPLA.

Zakariah Suleiman, an elderly farmer, was among those captured in the Tabanya offensive. For three days he was forced to work for the government forces.

'They burned all the far sorghum and collected all the near sorghum,' he said. 'They sent us out every day in large groups protected by soldiers. This is their weapon against us: hunger. They have taken everything from Tabanya - sorghum, beans, cowpeas and maize. Nothing is left.'

Like Rahila Kuku, Suleiman succeeded in escaping from Tabanya and fled to Kadoro - fully aware that he was running from hunger to hunger.

'I'm happy to be here whether I find food or not,' he said. 'I have left everything behind, but I don't care if I'm naked or clothed. Here I can go wherever I want to without asking for permission. It's not like over there, in Tabanya, where you are kept under guard and have to ask for permission even to urinate. I may die of hunger here, but I'll die free - not penned in like an animal.'

webTitle: Wild nights dry up as Madrid's killjoys call halt to late drinking

fields.headline: Wild nights dry up as Madrid's killjoys call halt to late drinking
fields.trailText: The authorities are determined to enforce opening hours which, to the horror of many, were reduced more than a year ago in response to complaints from residents in Madrid.
fields.body:
It is three o'clock on a Friday morning and the narrow streets around the Plaza Santa Ana are teeming with people looking for a good time. Shutters are going up around an old and gorgeously tiled bar, but down the street the energetic are queuing to get in to another drinking den. It's just a normal night in Madrid, where a post-prandial drink can last until dawn.

But that is changing - at least if the right-wing local government gets its way.

The authorities are determined to enforce opening hours which, to the horror of many, were reduced more than a year ago in response to complaints from residents. In theory, bars and pubs in the city must now shut at 2am between Sunday and Thursday, and at 3am at the weekend. Local police are now enforcing the law with unusual and unpopular vigour, fining bar-owners who stay open late. Revolution is brewing.

Last month, more than 40 bars around Huertas Street, just off Santa Ana, responded with a peculiarly Spanish strike: they stayed open until 6am. Several paid a stiff price for the protest, but are prepared to fight on for the right to party in a city where drunken brawls of the British variety are almost unknown.

'This government is making the city vulgar and also boring at night,' says an outraged José-Luis, who opened his small bar close to Huertas almost 20 years ago. 'Madrileños are used to going out late, and you can't issue a decree ordering people to go to sleep.' From behind the bar María-José explains: 'We don't open until 1am, so we can't just shut at 3am. There is no point.'

It is not just an economic issue, though. The manager of one of Madrid's most venerable bars follows the official timetable and has no intention of opening any later, but he is adamantly opposed to the new restrictions. 'We are on a tourist timetable - that is, people come to Madrid to do things they cannot do in other places, to have fun,' he says, pointing out that bars in the Balearic Islands or along the Costa del Sol stay open as long as they like. 'Are we going to limit this freedom to the coast? Are we going to allow permissiveness at the beach, but not in the capital?'

Strange as it might seem to a British readership brought up with First World War-era licensing laws, this issue really is seen as a question of civil liberties, since restricting opening hours goes against the universal Spanish principle that a person should be able to do exactly as he or she pleases.

The local predilection for conspiracy theories lays the blame for the current campaign firmly at the tapping toes of the big discotheques and out-of-town leisure centres, which supposedly want city-centre bars closed in order to drum up a new clientele. Having fun is a serious business in Madrid: the city has more than 6,300 watering holes - which works out to around 475 locals per bar - taking around 475,000 million pesetas (£2,715m) per year.

Discos and nightclubs, which are allowed to function until 5am or 6am and often stay open until mid-morning, must fulfil more rigorous conditions regulating security, fire escapes and disabled access, as well as paying higher taxes. They want a clear run at the late-night trade.

City officials say the new rules are intended to curb bad behaviour by the young - as a wholesome alternative, municipal sports centres are being opened later to offer tennis, aerobics and cultural events.

fields.headline: Ireland expects
fields.trailText: There is life yet in the Northern Ireland peace process. The ambitious proposal from Tony Blair and the Irish Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, to extend by a year the deadline for arms decommissioning and to reinstate the Northern Ireland Assembly later this month, has recognised what for many has been self-evident - that the issue of decommissioning has become a destructive distraction from the transformation that the Good Friday Agreement has wrought in Northern Ireland in the last two years. Many Unionists will decry as a betrayal the latest proposal to allow the resumption of the Assembly while letting decommissioning drift further down the timetable. They will also complain, rightly, that punishment shootings by the IRA have dangerously eroded confidence in their good faith.
fields.body:
There is life yet in the Northern Ireland peace process. The ambitious proposal from Tony Blair and the Irish Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, to extend by a year the deadline for arms decommissioning and to reinstate the Northern Ireland Assembly later this month, has recognised what for many has been self-evident - that the issue of decommissioning has become a destructive distraction from the transformation that the Good Friday Agreement has wrought in Northern Ireland in the last two years. Many Unionists will decry as a betrayal the latest proposal to allow the resumption of the Assembly while letting decommissioning drift further down the timetable. They will also complain, rightly, that punishment shootings by the IRA have dangerously eroded confidence in their good faith.

But in the pressure-cooker environment since the suspension of the Assembly in February, it has become clear that a reaffirmation of what the Agreement represents was overdue. In this context, Blair and Ahern's attempt to breathe new life into a moribund process is as politically courageous as anything that first led to the Agreement. What is necessary is that the other parties show the same willingness to take risks.

The IRA's statement yesterday that it would open its weapons dumps to regular inspections is a step forward. But the IRA must also accept that to reassure the loyalist community, these inspections should be unannounced. Punishment attacks must also halt now.

David Trimble will have a bigger hill to climb in trying to sell the proposals to a Unionist Council that is split against him. Already, however, the signs are encouraging that enough may be on offer to break the log-jam. But what happens next is crucial. The peace process is still vulnerable to those who would make mischief. Encouragement is necessary on both sides to demonstrate that London and Dublin have not lost faith. As the Middle East peace talks show, no peace process is a quick fix. All parties are in for the long haul.
