In this context, Blair and Ahern's attempt to breathe new life into a moribund process is as politically courageous as anything that first led to the Agreement. What is necessary is that the other parties show the same willingness to take risks. The IRA's statement yesterday that it would open its weapons dumps to regular inspections is a step forward. But the IRA must also accept that to reassure the loyalist community, these inspections should be unannounced. Punishment attacks must also halt now. David Trimble will have a bigger hill to climb in trying to sell the proposals to a Unionist Council that is split against him. Already, however, the signs are encouraging that enough may be on offer to break the log-jam. But what happens next is crucial. The peace process is still vulnerable to those who would make mischief. Encouragement is necessary on both sides to demonstrate that London and Dublin have not lost faith. As the Middle East peace talks show, no peace process is a quick fix. All parties are in for the long haul.

fields.headline: The zest of British...
fields.standfirst: With the Tate Modern opening this week,  Tim Adams  offers a beginner's guide to those who don't know their Bankside from their backside
fields.trailText: With the Tate Modern opening this week,  Tim Adams  offers a beginner's guide to those who don't know their Bankside from their backside
fields.body:
A is for Apocalypse, this autumn's prematurely-hyped exhibition at the Royal Academy which promises to refuel the Daily Mail outrage that met its predecessor, the 'epoch-making' Sensation exhibition. Apocalypse will feature a life-size figure of the Pope having been struck by a meteorite, and photographs by Wolfgang Tillman who is famous for depicting his lover masturbating. The show is not, according to its curator Norman Rosenthal, about 'shocking people'. 'But it is,' he explains helpfully, 'about shock.' Rosenthal plans to mount a similar show annually. He does not say what he will call the event that comes after Apocalypse.

B is for Bowie, chameleon-like rock guru, whose current incarnation sees him as a major collector of contemporary art, proprietor of the journal Modern Painters, dauber of neo-Cubist paintings and designer of wallpaper for Laura Ashley. Though less respectful artists accuse of him of being a dabbler, Bowie is beaten only by Madonna as a celebrity spot at gallery openings. B is also for Joseph Beuys, the late German artist famous for empty coat-hangers, and for the phrase 'x is the new Beuys', routinely applied to all artists fresh out of Goldsmith's College.

C is for the writer and TV presenter Matthew Collings, the mutton-chopped, monosyllabic chronicler of the mini-Renaissance in British art. It is also for the Chapman Brothers, Jake and Dinos, its enfants terribles. Collings trenchantly and typically describes the Chapmans' plastic sculptures of mutant young girls with dildoes for noses as 'seemingly very tied to the problems of real modern life'. And he keeps an ever so straight, slightly puzzled, face while he does so.

D is for Damien Hirst, responsible for first putting British artists on tabloid front pages. At art school, when confronted with a blank canvas, Hirst posed one of the seminal questions of post-postmodern aesthetics: 'What do I do now,' he mused to himself, 'paint a fucking horse or a dog or something?'

E is for elephant dung, lumps of which, when adhered to a painting of the Virgin Mary by Turner Prize winner Chris Ofili, got up the nose of New York's Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. Giuliani, a Catholic, apparently missed the witty observation on Ofili's cultural heritage that the excreta offered, and attempted instead to ban the Sensation show in which it figured. His actions brought such notable art radicals as the situationist Hugh Grant flocking to the opening in support of the seminal role of extravagant faeces in modern culture.

F is for formaldehyde, medium of choice for contemporary artists plagued by the big questions: death and pickling. These haunted figures also have a hankering for all things stainless steel, especially old dentists' drills and their aunt's medicine cabinet, the contents of which are taken as mute reminders of mortality: Alka Seltzer thus becomes the modern momento mori; Elastoplast our Yorick's skull.

G is for Gilbert and George, reluctant gay dads of the newer wave of British artists, the anal retentive Morecambe and Wise to the younger generation's more relaxed Vic and Bob. G is also for Groucho Club, where said relaxed artists torture themselves about what it all means, and allow their more inspired work to quietly gestate while they pick arcane fights with former agents.

H is for Hoxton, the district of east London to which most of the above eventually stagger home. British artists enjoy a symbiotic relationship with British property developers: like the smell of freshly baked bread and recently ground coffee, their very presence in the vicinity of a derelict warehouse ups its asking price fivefold. Before long, to the delight of locals, there is a Starbucks on the corner and an organic deli in the basement. See also: Southwark, Bermondsey etc

I is for installation, a useful catch-all term for what artists are up to when not at the Groucho Club. An installation can be an odd blue light, a nest of maggots or a fried egg, but such things can only become installations when they are married to a concept. The offspring of an installation and a concept is what we now understand as art. I is also for irony, without which many concepts would just be desperate ideas.

J is for gallery owner Jay Jopling, the Eton-educated, Savile Row-suited son of a Tory peer, who personifies the seismic shift in the class attitudes brought about by the hotspurs of the new new thing. Through his gallery, White Cube, Jopling represents the likes of Tracey Emin and sculptor Antony (Angel of the North) Gormley. He is, his more unwashed clients are at pains to explain, such a deeply establishment figure that, when viewed in a certain light, he is radically anti-establishment. This fine distinction is only apparent to the carefully trained artistic eye.

K is for Anish Kapoor, Bombay-born artist famed as an explorer of 'negative space'. It is also for Jeff Koons, sculptor of porcelain Michael Jacksons and ex-husband of porn star La Cicciolina.

L is for Lottery, the serendipitous benefactor to the new golden age of galleries, including Tate Modern which opens to the public on Friday. The National Lottery is, of course, proof positive that most ordinary people in Britain are tireless in their support of contemporary visual art and are also more than happy to support the bar bills of its practitioners. L is also for loft, chosen abode of those who want to share in the new, wild artistic lifestyle: pension fund managers, perhaps, or auditors.

M is for Madonna, without whose imprimatur no gallery extension would ever be taken remotely seriously. M is also for Tate Modern, of which Madonna is the unofficial mascot. The correct response to the question 'What's the new Tate like?' when posed by cultural historians and cab drivers is, of course: 'I don't know, but Madonna will be at the opening...'

N is for Bruce Nauman, cowboy high priest of conceptualism, who early in his career made a memorable half-hour video of himself juggling with his testicles. Nauman now lives in New Mexico, where he whispers to horses and makes hellish carousels out of taxidermist's moulds. N is also for nihilism, neo-conceptualism and nonsense.

O is for opening, the raison d'etre behind much of the best offerings in modern art. It is during the opening that new concepts are revealed for the first time, and their progenitors have a chance to explain them with full rigour to an ever-anxious public. Openings are generally sponsored by large corporations with a desire to seem non-corporate; Absolut vodka is mandatory.

P is for painting, which no one can be bothered much with now, except iconoclasts such as Gary Hume, who does it in an ironic, conceptual kind of way, and Damien Hirst who has his assistants colour in dots on a canvas which he can sell for £60,000. Hirst is apparently angry with British Airways who he believes have borrowed his coloured dots concept for their logo to promote the cheap and cheerful airline, Go. It's a terrible rip-off, he complains.

Q is for Quo Vadis, a restaurant owned by Marco Pierre White and decorated at one time by Hirst. The artist's installations were removed by White after it was claimed they put diners off their food. Even so, the collaboration proved that art is now capable of invading every sacred corner of our cultural life, even the contemporary holy of holies: the designer kitchen. Q is also for Marc Quinn, an artist whose work, some suggest, provides a commentary on this cross-fertilisation between visual and alimentary art. (Quinn makes figurative heads out of blood: sculptural black puddings.)

R is for Norman Rosenthal, the P.T. Barnum of the Royal Academy, and the man responsible for Sensation and, now, Apocalypse. In between times Rosenthal has also put together the Monet in the 20th Century exhibition, which was modern at least in the amount of money it took and the T-shirts it shifted. R is also for rock and roll, as in 'Britart is the new...' or 'Monet is the new...'?

S is for Nick Serota, the saintly driving force behind Tate Modern which promises to do for London roughly what the Guggenheim did for Bilbao, only more so - bring in planeloads of American tourists. S is also for Saatchi, Thatcher's adman who early on cornered the market in British extremism and subsequently flogged it to anyone who would listen. And, coincidentally, it is for shark.

T is for Turner Prize and also for Tracey Emin, who have shared many long and extremely emotional evenings together. T is also for Tracey's tent. Crawling inside it to read the embroidered names of everyone she had ever slept with was, for some, the artistic epiphany of the past decade. For others it served as a reminder of wet family holidays in Wales.

U is for underground, the place that most of the loft-owning and headline-making artists claim to inhabit.

V is for value for money. In a recent documentary Tracey Emin was filmed making crude little pencil sketches of her naked self. Each sketch took about a minute. Jay Jopling later suggested that he sold these drawings for up to £3,000, and that represented 'good value for money'.

W is for Rachel Whiteread, Gillian Wearing, Sam Taylor Wood and the Wilson Twins (Jane and Louise), who with their own feminine lusts for life prove that art is no longer to be regarded as a Kirk Douglas-type guy thing.

X is (almost) for explosion, like the one that blew Cornelia Parker's garden shed to smithereens, only for her to hang it all back together as a shed installation (not one you could keep the lawnmower in). X is also for the generation of slackers who hang out at openings.

Y is for YBA (Young British Artist), an acronym which has widely given way to MABAWIP (Middle Aged British Artists With Investment Portfolios).

Z is for zeitgeisty, a description that was once never far from the lips of any worth-their-salt critic of the YBAs, but now it is somewhat just a little twentieth century. See also: Britart; enfants terribles ; postmodernism...

fields.headline: Tate and style
fields.trailText: London is emerging as Europe's contender for world city. To take a boat down the Thames is to witness an extraordinary array of buildings and architecture, most notably on the south bank, that has blossomed over the last 20 years. On Friday, Tate Modern, converted from the disused Bankside power station, will open to the public. It is the latest addition to London's stock of striking public buildings.
fields.body:
London is emerging as Europe's contender for world city. To take a boat down the Thames is to witness an extraordinary array of buildings and architecture, most notably on the south bank, that has blossomed over the last 20 years. On Friday, Tate Modern, converted from the disused Bankside power station, will open to the public. It is the latest addition to London's stock of striking public buildings.

The whole concept is a decisive challenge to the usual British reluctance to embrace the creative, the intellectual and the bold act of architectural flair. The power station has proved an inspiring context to house modern art, and the Tate's director, Sir Nicholas Serota, has gone one step further by grouping the exhibits by theme. The viewer is invited to look for connections and serendipity between the pictures, so that a visit becomes a democratic engagement with the art, rather than the usual sense of a gallery being a history book through which the viewer has to walk deferentially. Above all, it is suffused with youth and energy.

Nicholas Serota and the Tate should be warmly congratulated. They have pulled off a daring and radical innovation that will enlarge the country's imagination and cement London's standing as the emerging art capital of Europe. They may even persuade conservative sceptics that modern art has a purpose and a point. Go and see it.

webTitle: Why The Big Breakfast just got smaller

fields.headline: Why The Big Breakfast just got smaller
fields.trailText: Now that Liza Tarbuck is leaving The Big Breakfast, it would be interesting to know whether she actually had it written into her contract that she wouldn't have to pretend to fancy Johnny Vaughan like Denise Van Outen or Kelly Brook had to. A bit like in the 70s, when Kate Jackson insisted on having it written into her Charlie's Angels contract that she wouldn't have to strip down to a string bikini quite as often as her co-stars, Farrah Fawcett and Jaclyn Smith.
fields.body:
Now that Liza Tarbuck is leaving The Big Breakfast, it would be interesting to know whether she actually had it written into her contract that she wouldn't have to pretend to fancy Johnny Vaughan like Denise Van Outen or Kelly Brook had to. A bit like in the 70s, when Kate Jackson insisted on having it written into her Charlie's Angels contract that she wouldn't have to strip down to a string bikini quite as often as her co-stars, Farrah Fawcett and Jaclyn Smith.

This is the kind of thing you'd probably have to think about when you're a no-nonsense female television presenter in a high-profile dollybird slot: how to hold on to your dignity when your two immediate predecessors surrendered theirs so readily. First, Van Outen, the ultimate postmodern eye candy, who, with her schoolgirl bunches, motel-sex clothing and wipe-clean innuendo, turned Überslutdom into an 'am' concept. Then, poor, lovely, useless Kelly Brook, whose style of reading the autocue seemed to require a bookmark. On her arrival, Liza Tarbuck was heralded as the human antidote to the breakfast-babe virus, and indeed she was.

Unfortunately, she unwittingly became the incubator of a totally different and highly dangerous media bug - that of patronisium bigum chickum (patronise the fat chick). I couldn't have been the only female viewer to feel subtle sisterly pressure to like Tarbuck better, and rate her work more highly, simply because she was, frankly, a bit of an anti-babe. Prior to The Big Breakfast, I'd seen her hosting a couple of other shows, and vaguely noted that she was an able, quick-witted presenter who, though personable, bore a passing resemblance to Mrs Bun, the baker's wife from the Happy Families card game.

A fleeting thought, soon forgotten. Who could have envisaged that when Tarbuck joined The Big Breakfast her looks, or perceived lack of them, would soon be all anybody could talk about.

It isn't so much their detractors that women like Tarbuck have to watch out for, it's their supporters. There seems to be a current feel-good trend in certain sectors of the media for people to be seen to champion someone who they think is photogenically challenged. In Tarbuck's case, Channel 4 might as well have issued a press release: 'She's frumpy! She's ordinary! She's a bit of a dog! Let's make it happen!' Even The Sun urged us to phone its hotline if we wanted to see Liza 'given a shot'. It serves us well to remember that, in the eyes of the general public, Liza Tarbuck is probably considered to be perfectly nice looking. It's the media that's decided she's a bow-wow, and should be supported in her time of 'need'.

Kathy Burke has probably been suffering this kind of condescending claptrap for years. Ditto Pauline Quirke. Everywhere you look, pundits twitter away patronisingly about how 'refreshing' it is to see 'someone like Liza Tarbuck' get The Big Breakfast job. They mean 'someone' fat, 'someone' not so obviously pretty, 'someone' who, in more glamorous times, would have been gunned down the second she attempted to walk on to a TV set. However, no one dares say that. Instead, they keep referring to Tarbuck as a 'funny girl', and we all know what they meant when they called Barbra Streisand that.

This episode speaks volumes about the patronising assumptions the media makes about British womankind. The media obviously views us as a collective of bitter, jealous fairy-tale stepmothers, who scream and reach for the poisoned apple whenever confronted with youth, charm and beauty. In truth, far from being twisted up with competitive envy, the vast majority of women love looking at other beautiful women, whether they be on the television, in magazines, or simply walking along the high street. I've followed women into nightclub loos to have a better look at them before now.

Getting back to Tarbuck, despite the hype, her 'real woman' sojourn at The Big Breakfast hasn't changed anything - you only have to see BB regulars, Donna Air and Gail Porter, shivering in their itsy-bitsy T-shirts in the studio to realise that the glamour quotient was never going to be allowed to fall below a certain level. Moreover, it should be noted that, despite Tarbuck's presence, viewing figures have continued to fall. Ergo, it could be argued that, in brutal TV terms, Tarbuck simply lacked the requisite looks for the job, just as Brook lacked the brains.

In turn, both Tarbuck and Brook lacked Van Outens' innate talent for sending male Britons off to work with a spring in their step, and soft porn on the brain. And all three of them were doomed to be dwarfed by Johnny Vaughan's gargantuan ego - breakfast-TV geishas forced to sit, bowing and giggling, at their master's feet. Which is another story. It certainly seems significant that, while Vaughan was the only constant during the slide of Big Breakfast viewing figures, it was always his handmaidens who got the blame.

Alarm belles to barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

I've followed women into nightclub loos to have a better look at them before now. Getting back to Tarbuck, despite the hype, her 'real woman' sojourn at The Big Breakfast hasn't changed anything - you only have to see BB regulars, Donna Air and Gail Porter, shivering in their itsy-bitsy T-shirts in the studio to realise that the glamour quotient was never going to be allowed to fall below a certain level. Moreover, it should be noted that, despite Tarbuck's presence, viewing figures have continued to fall. Ergo, it could be argued that, in brutal TV terms, Tarbuck simply lacked the requisite looks for the job, just as Brook lacked the brains. In turn, both Tarbuck and Brook lacked Van Outens' innate talent for sending male Britons off to work with a spring in their step, and soft porn on the brain. And all three of them were doomed to be dwarfed by Johnny Vaughan's gargantuan ego - breakfast-TV geishas forced to sit, bowing and giggling, at their master's feet. Which is another story. It certainly seems significant that, while Vaughan was the only constant during the slide of Big Breakfast viewing figures, it was always his handmaidens who got the blame. Alarm belles to barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Restaurateur Antonio Carluccio and his mushroom supplier Drew Macpherson share a passion for funghi. And from both a culinary point of view and a business angle, their friendship has brought rich pickings
fields.trailText: Restaurateur Antonio Carluccio and his mushroom supplier Drew Macpherson share a passion for funghi. And from both a culinary point of view and a business angle, their friendship has brought rich pickings
fields.body:
Antonio Carluccio My first contact with Drew was many, many years ago when he told me he was picking mushrooms in Scotland, and wondered if I'd be interested in being supplied by him. I said yes, naturally, as I was buying mushrooms from all over the place for the Neal Street Restaurant, which I had taken over from Terence [Conran] in 1981.

Mushrooms have always been my passion, and when I saw that he was reacting to my writing and filming about mushrooms, I thought it was lovely that someone in England had caught the commerciality of that, because in Europe it's always been a big business, whereas in England it was just taking off.

When I first started taking mushrooms from Drew, he explained that he was putting together a sort of net of pickers and making it a really commercial thing. He sent the mushrooms down to me by aeroplane and would personally escort them to the plane, and they were lovely mushrooms: chanterelles, ceps, whatever was in season, and all of the highest quality. At the same time, my name as a mushroom expert was growing and I had people contacting me from various parts of the world asking if they could buy mushrooms from me. But I couldn't touch this commercial side of things as I had too many other things to get on with, so I passed on all those contacts to him.

Drew and I got along straight away. Originally, I wanted to run a mushroom company myself, but I decided it would be better to leave it to someone who had the time to do it properly. And one benefit of passing on all my business contacts to him is that he gives me a very good price for the mushrooms I use in the restaurant.

I think Drew was the first person who realised the growing importance of mushrooms in this country. He was the first one and is now the biggest one.

I would say he is as passionate about mushrooms as me, but it is a different passion. He likes mushrooms, but more from a commercial standpoint, whereas I like mushrooms from a culinary point of view, and the real hunt of it.

In Italy, you are taken mushroom picking as soon as you can walk. I started to learn the difference between mushrooms when I was about six. It's a fantastic pastime. You are in the woods with nature and you are part of it, collecting something that's lovely to look at, lovely to smell and lovely to eat. What more could you want? They say it's best to go in the morning to avoid competition, but in this country if you go in the afternoon they're still there.

I remember passing a group of 10 wonderful porcini on the side of a road once and I thought I'd like to go home and pick up the camera and take a picture of them. In Italy it would be impossible to do that. They wouldn't even have grown that large But here they were large and in their prime, and I had time to go home, pick up the camera and go back and photograph them before picking them. Nobody had taken them.

Drew makes my business a lot simpler. Before he came along I was getting my mushrooms from all over the place. I once put an advert in the Polish daily paper in London saying that I would buy the surplus of any reader's hunts, and we had a queue of people outside the restaurant with two or three kilos of mushrooms each. It was really lovely, and I still have contact with some of them. I also have people from Wales and Cornwall who send me their mushrooms, but I buy the bulk from Drew, as we use at least 100 kilos a week. Drew is very much a gentleman. He's invited me to Scotland several times, but I rarely have the time to go, though I do want to spend more time with him, picking mushrooms or whatever. Drew and I are a funny combination, although we work very well together. We are a sort of unspoken team. It's not arranged, but we certainly think of each other when it comes to business. Like me, Drew also appreciates the flavour of mushrooms. He loves every aspect of them. It's fantastic that you can make a business out of something you really like, which is something we have both managed to do.

Drew Macpherson The first time I met Antonio was when he came up to Scotland with one of his suppliers in about 1988. My company had just started on its wild mushrooms then, and we met, got on well and have been working closely ever since.

At that point, my business was embryonic. When I met Antonio we had about 20 pickers, now we have 300 or so, and they vary from people who do it seriously to grannies who just go out for a walk in the afternoon. No one is actually employed by us they just bring what they pick to our collection points.

There's no getting away from the fact that Antonio is Mr Mushroom. He's been the chief exponent for the wild mushroom industry in Britain and he's the one who's bought it to prominence. When we both started out, the mushroom market in the UK was quite small, it was a niche market, but now it's quite mainstream. Our businesses have basically grown together. Antonio is a hugely amusing character and a loyal friend. When we meet up, which nowadays is all too rare, it's a good laugh. I like to see him about four times a year, but he's in London and I'm in Scotland, and his schedule is very demanding.

He's been up to Scotland a couple of times and we go out and pick, and that's when he's at his best. Put him in a wood where there are mushrooms and porcini and he just goes funny, he loves it. It's like that saying that any Italian will swap their grandmother for a decent cep. He has a deep understanding of the whole thing and gets a huge kick out of it, and that comes across in all his books and in everything he does. He's much more passionate about the subject than I am - it's almost as if he's involved on an emotional level.

Antonio is very charismatic and he captivates people using the knowledge he has of his subject. He's got all the stories and anecdotes. I've seen him when we were filming for the BBC up in Scotland and he was there with a gas stove in the middle of a forest whipping up a wild-mushroom risotto for the crew who were completely won over by him.

One of his strongest character traits is that he's enormously generous and he doesn't territorialise. He does what he does and he wants as many people to share in that as possibly can. What he does has directly affected our business throughout the years. If he brings out a book on wild produce, the demand increases, and then we meet that demand. We were just starting out when he and I met, and he gave us a big leg up and he's continued to do that ever since.

It's a relationship that works very well, but I don't know that it would work with anyone else. My life has been enriched by knowing Antonio. He's a strong character, and I'm particularly pleased that he chose to take us under his wing.

webTitle: Will end of loyalty cards make Safeway a safe bet?

fields.headline: Will end of loyalty cards make Safeway a safe bet?
fields.trailText: It does not take a lot of brainpower to work out that loyalty cards are pretty useless when every store has got one. But it seems it takes the arrival of a new chief executive to make a store group brave enough to ditch one.
fields.body:
It does not take a lot of brainpower to work out that loyalty cards are pretty useless when every store has got one. But it seems it takes the arrival of a new chief executive to make a store group brave enough to ditch one.

Safeway was already questioning the value of its ABC card when Carlos Criado-Perez took over as chief executive last November. But it was his decision to focus on getting new customers, rather than persuading the existing ones to spend more, that finally led to its demise. When every potential customer has a range of loyalty cards, all offering pretty much the same benefits, it takes something extra to attract them into the store.

Safeway was already spending £30 million on price cuts to do just that - with reasonable success, judging by the 10 per cent rise in sales volumes achieved in the first three months of the year. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that Criado-Perez decided to see what could be achieved by switching the £60m annual cost of the ABC card into more targeted promotions.

Even allowing for the smoke and mirrors which usually accompany any supermarket price-cutting campaign, offers such as half-price cornflakes and 40 per cent off washing powder look serious. The impact on margins should be less severe than this suggests: Safeway admits that almost three-quarters of the £500m cost of these promotions this year will be financed by cutting discounts on peripheral items. The question is, will the campaign change shoppers' perception of its price positioning enough to win them back from rivals?

The results from the existing £30m campaign are encouraging. It estimates that it has added 750,000 shoppers, an 8 per cent increase.

While that has been at a cost of a 4 per cent cut in prices, around twice the level of deflation in the rest of the industry, the volume increase is more than compensating.

Can that continue? The initial campaign will already have attracted more cost-conscious shoppers. It is unlikely that multiplying the cost of the promotion by four will multiply the benefits by four, although Safeway hopes that it will encourage more of them to use its stores for their main, rather than their secondary, shopping.

But rivals are unlikely to stand back and watch their customers defect to Safeway; the more they retaliate, the more Safeway's benefits will be competed away. It is trying to differentiate itself by focusing just on fresh food and service, eschewing the cheap televisions, t-shirts and telephones that are littering the stores of its rivals. But it has still to demonstrate that it can offer what it promises.

It is coming from a long way behind. As finance director Simon Laffin points out, its sales per square foot still languish more than 10 per cent behind its rivals. If it gets its strategy right this time, it could end up being one of the fastest-growing food retailers. That may make a forward multiple of 12.5 times earnings look cheap.

Cement does not yield

When the history of the technology bubble comes to be written, the escape of cement maker Blue Circle from the clutches of French rival Lafarge is likely to be seen as a key turning point.

Just four months ago, investors were so convinced that the old economy had had its day that they would have accepted just about any cash offer for their shares in boring old builders, metal bashers, retailers and the rest.

Now, the realisation is slowly dawning that, while technology may be the growth story of the future, the prices of many new-economy stocks is discounting that growth into infinity. And, while old-fashioned companies may not match them in growth rates, they also do not match them in valuation. Quite simply, they had become too cheap.

Blue Circle is fortunate that the realisation came just in time to stop its shareholders accepting Lafarge's penny-pinching offer. Chief executive Rick Haythornthwaite and his team now have to justify their faith. That will be challenging. Malaysia is undoubtedly worth more than Lafarge gave it credit for, but it is still dogged by overcapacity and low prices. The zeal to deliver promised cost cuts often diminishes when the threat of takeover dies.

But Lafarge has shown no inclination to ditch its 29.6 per cent stake, so Blue Circle would be wise to keep its mind focused on the £116m of efficiency gains.

Blue Circle's victory should make other bargain-hunters pause and reconsider. Old economy companies can take heart.

Consolidation cocktail

If Rick Haythornthwaite is the man charged with keeping Blue Circle independent, Philip Bowman, who holds the same post at Allied Domecq, could be seen as the boss whose job is to make his company more saleable. He makes no secret of the fact that further consolidation in the drinks industry is inevitable. What he is trying to do is to make sure that Allied has some say in how that happens.

Yesterday's results were a creditable start. The performance of the drinks business highlights why consolidation is essential. Volumes of its four core brands, including Ballantines and Beefeater, rose by 4 per cent, although growth in Tequila was held back by the shortage of agave, the Mexican cactus which is a key ingredient of the fiery drink.

But that was in a strong market, and was overshadowed by the likes of Courvoisier and Tia Maria, which are not the group's prime focus. That highlights the fact that its core portfolio lacks the knock-out brand in a number of key areas, such as vodka.

Baskin-Robbins and Dunkin Donuts, banded together as Quick Service Restaurants, increased profits by more than 50 per cent. Allied now looks to have sold its pubs and leisure interests, but shareholders can assume that the $22 million (£14m) investment programme which is improving the results is really aimed at making it more saleable.

The shares have had a strong run recently, and gained another 10p immediately following the results, despite the warning that the agave shortage and investment in Baskin-Robbins mean that growth will slow in the second half of the year.

On a forward multiple of less than 12, the shares are not expensive. But they are unlikely to move much until there is more concrete evidence that Allied is being proactive in seeking out consolidation.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: One lucky beneficiary of a bid for Sports Internet, the online news and betting firm, could be sportswear outfit Hay & Robertson, one of our favourite shares of last year.
fields.body:
One lucky beneficiary of a bid for Sports Internet, the online news and betting firm, could be sportswear outfit Hay & Robertson, one of our favourite shares of last year.

H&R, if you remember, sold a 49 per cent stake in Sports e-tail, its own Internet commerce division, to Sports Internet earlier this year for £6 million in cash and £14m in shares. That gave it a 6 per cent stake in Sports Internet, which may bring in a tidy profit if a bid does materialise.

More importantly, if the suitors are indeed the likes of BSkyB or cable company NTL, it brings in a powerful partner for H&R's e-commerce activities, which already extend to marketing England and Manchester United strips, as well as its own Admiral and Kangol brands.

We last recommended H&R shares at 193p last November and by January they had doubled to 390p. After all the turbulence on the stock market, the shares have now slipped back to 243p. That's still a nice profit, though. Hold on for further positive news.

Flight to fancy

People looking to pick, for their Peps and Isas, small stocks with a good record and promising future, may want to check out Watermark Group, the brand promotion and merchandising company. As broker Charles Stanley points out, Watermark is the only firm to have graduated so far from Ofex and Aim to a full listing.

Over the past five years, sales have risen by 23 per cent compound. Yet at 16 times prospective earnings the stock is rated at a substantial discount to the media sector.

Watermark provides promotional merchandise for a blue chip list of airlines, travel firms, consumer product companies and charities. It is also into sales promotion and the management of spectacular outdoor events for the likes of Walt Disney's Buena Vista, Ben & Jerry's and the Millennium Commission.

Most recently, for a nominal sum, it also took a 10 per cent stake in FlightStore, a new firm set up to sell branded products in-flight through seat-back TVs. The idea is that passengers will be able to browse through a catalogue on their in-flight screens and order with a credit card for delivery to a specified address. At the moment the number of long-haul passengers with access to screens is 100 million: this is forecast to rise to 500 million by 2003 - clearly a growth market with huge untapped potential.

Charles Stanley has set a target price of 100p for Watermark shares, against 76.5p now. At a PE of 20, that is still a sector discount. And every £100m of value created by the promising FlightStore would add 40p to Watermark's share price. Well worth a look.

Jelly poor show

Those of you who took our advice to avoid like the plague the Internet 'wonder stock' Jellyworks have reasons to be cheerful. Since we last commented on them, the shares have plunged from 87p to just 31p now. Even so, despite their fall from grace, that's still more than five times the 5p placing price in December, so the founding Rowland family is still sitting on a tidy profit.

So what has been clobbering the shares (apart from spoilsport columns like this, that is)? The swift exit of chairman Ed Guinan in February didn't help. Guinan's business record is none too hot and there's more to come on his financial affairs. But as for his role as an ace Net investment spotter, suffice it to say - surprise, surprise - that Jellyworks hasn't heard from him for a while.

Having dropped its City PR agency, The Communication Group, Jellyworks is working on revamping its image from an 'Internet incubator' (whatever that means) to a straightforward investment firm. No amount of spin, however, can disguise a bad investment. Continue to avoid.

Since we last commented on them, the shares have plunged from 87p to just 31p now. Even so, despite their fall from grace, that's still more than five times the 5p placing price in December, so the founding Rowland family is still sitting on a tidy profit. So what has been clobbering the shares (apart from spoilsport columns like this, that is)? The swift exit of chairman Ed Guinan in February didn't help. Guinan's business record is none too hot and there's more to come on his financial affairs. But as for his role as an ace Net investment spotter, suffice it to say - surprise, surprise - that Jellyworks hasn't heard from him for a while. Having dropped its City PR agency, The Communication Group, Jellyworks is working on revamping its image from an 'Internet incubator' (whatever that means) to a straightforward investment firm. No amount of spin, however, can disguise a bad investment. Continue to avoid.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: We wonder whether Geordie Greig, the editor of the Tatler, might like to check into the exclusive Liary - Stephen Glover's retreat for the terminally confused on the castaway island of Talentfree - following a story in the Tatler that delighted the tabloids: Fergie and Andy may remarry.
fields.body:
This lad's no Geordie

We wonder whether Geordie Greig, the editor of the Tatler, might like to check into the exclusive Liary - Stephen Glover's retreat for the terminally confused on the castaway island of Talentfree - following a story in the Tatler that delighted the tabloids: Fergie and Andy may remarry. We would not for one moment cast doubt on the accuracy of this excellent story, but we have discovered after extensive investigations that Mr Greig is not in fact a Geordie. He apparently lives not on the tenth floor of the Byker Wall but in a gracious home in Kensington, nor is he a part-time editor of the Toon Army fanzine. More shockingly he does not even 'smirk tabs' or go oot wi' lasses.

Love at first website

Elsewhere, the Love Bug has bitten at least two large media organisations on their electronic bottoms, firstly the BBC, where areas of the Corporation were temporarily taken out of email action, and secondly News International, where the rush of hacks at the Sunday Times to open any emails entitled 'I Love You' was so great that the IT room at Wapping practically burst into flames. However, we don't think the total electronic shutdown will stop the ST sourcing its excellent run of highly accurate news stories somehow.

BBC accuracy shock

The biggest shock of the week would have to be from the BBC, which finally produced an accurate exit poll - this time, on the election of the London Mayor. They even produced a press release to celebrate the fact.

Ambitions above one's station

The buzz at Canary Wharf Towers is not of Conrad Black flogging the Wyoming Examiner, it is of the ambitions of Dominic Lawson, editor of the Sunday Telegraph, whose award for Newspaper of the Year seems to have spurred him on to consider more elevated stations, such as that of editor of the Daily Telegraph. Unfortunately, this is a seat currently occupied by cohort Charles Moore, who despite the efforts he is expending on writing his biography of Maggie Thatcher, shows no signs of wishing to move on. Lawson, who has already 'stalked' Moore by moving his family home out to Sussex, is now, according to the idle chitchat of Telegraph types, practically measuring up Charles's office.

But what would inspire Black to shuffle his editors? Well, possibly the threat of Lawson packing his bags and going to the Times, where the editorship is still on hold after Peter Stothard's departure on extended sick leave.

We seem to remember that a couple of years ago Rupert Murdoch dined with young Dominic - and News International insiders at the time noted their proprietor's admiration for Lawson Jnr's work. Quelle intrigue, as they say in Quebec.

fields.headline: Genie stays in its bottle
fields.standfirst: Faisal Islam and William Keegan examine the arguments for and against intervention in the currency markets to stop the rise and rise of the pound.
fields.trailText: Faisal Islam and William Keegan examine the arguments for and against intervention in the currency markets to stop the rise and rise of the pound.
fields.body:
Faisal Islam

'Just say no' would be an appropriate description of the Government's attitude to currency market intervention. Tempting as a weaker pound would be for Labour heartlands, Gordon Brown and Tony Blair refuse to give the economy its fix.

The Prime Minister recently told the BBC that artificially lowering the value of the pound would be a 'big mistake' that would land the Government with far worse problems.

But debate is now raging from financial journals to the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee. On at least three occasions, the MPC has given consideration to the idea of using some of the Bank's £9 billion reserves to help calm the pound.

However, the Bank is very much in tune with the Treasury's position of non-intervention. A number of high ranking officials - including deputy governor Mervyn King - are implacably opposed to intervention.

In any event the MPC's remit can only stretch to consideration of the exchange rate as it helps in attainment of the inflation target. The inflation-busting credibility of the committee in the eyes of the markets depends on myopic focus on inflation. Monetary policy cannot simultaneously target inflation and the exchange rate .

Those advocating intervention to depress the pound lay the responsibility firmly at the Government's door. 'In action or in inaction, it cannot shelter behind the MPC,' says Gerald Holtham, global strategist at Norwich Union Investment Management,and former head of the IPPR,who has been in the vanguard of arguing for an intervention to cool down the pound against the euro (Observer Business 9 April).

Currency market intervention has not been tried since the Exchange Rate Mechanism debacle of 1992, when the Government intervened to prop up sterling by using foreign exchange reserves. But ultimately this wasn't enough and the pound famously fell out of the ERM.

The Government's abstinence from intervention has coincided with sterling soaring against the euro, the key exchange rate for British exports - about 50 per cent of exports are made to euroland.

In the early Eighties, the US curtailed interventions, and the dollar soared. By 1985, the overvalued dollar was causing global distortions: the exchange rate against the pound had increased by 100 per cent. That September, the G7 finance ministers and central bankers agreed on the Plaza Agreement - a co-ordinated effort to puncture the dollar bubble: $10 billion was spent in six weeks. A fortnight later the dollar had fallen 10 per cent against the yen, and a year later by over a third.

Critics claim the action coincided with the dollar's peak, rather than being the cause of its fall. The Louvre Accord to stabilise the dollar in 1987 did not reverse its decline - . conforms to a general rule that says it's easier to temper a rising currency than to prop up a falling one.

The pound's withdrawal from the ERM, at a cost to the taxpayer of £3bn, showed the impotence of central bank reserves when faced with the full might of the currency markets. The global value of currency trading is some $1.5 trillion a day, almost three times the value of total central bank reserves.

The temptation to leave the markets alone is based on a belief in the efficiency of a market trading a uniform product in such huge volumes. But exchange rates do not always reflect the under lying economic fundamentals. Evidence of the inefficiency of currency markets driven by herd behaviour rather than rational expectations is plentiful.This psychological model of market behaviour has important implications for the potency of intervention. Private banks and speculators dwarf central banks as players in currency markets, but intervention can send effective signals to the market.

Realistically, interventions need to work with the grain of market thinking, and a signal is more credible when the intervention is accompanied by supportive policies. So, in 1992, the then Chancellor's intervention was seen as indecision, and punished accordingly. In 1995, a concerted effort to prop up the dollar succeeded by piling in on the back of a 'friendly trend', forcing the dollar up to six-month highs against the yen.

The strong pound may partly be explained by the market's belief that the Government is 'philosophically opposed' to intervention. Thus any intervention in the UK would represent a surprise policy change, and wipe off that premium relatively easily, in anticipation of future interventions.

But a falling market is difficult to control. The fall in the dollar caused by the Plaza Agreement was so great that within 18 months the Louvre Accord was required to stabilise it. As well as the inflationary worries - a tumbling currency would cause more expensive imports - there is a real danger that a fall could spiral out of control.

Intervention is a difficult business to get 'right'. Once the genie is out of the bottle, markets will wonder at what point the Government may intervene at the bottom end - adding to volatility and uncertainty.

Sterling's strength is a reflection of the euro's weakness. The economic fundamentals point to undervaluation, yet it continues to sink.

The mechanics of intervention are complex. But the MPC need not be involved. Holtham suggests giving the euro a jolt and cooling the pound by exploiting differences between pound and euro bond yields. This sterilised intervention could be funded by using the £22.5bn receipts from the mobile phone auction. This move might help depress the pound, and could also prove lucrative compared with repaying the public debt.

'What sense can it make to buy [back] paper yielding 4.5 per cent in a currency you believe to be overvalued, rather than buying paper yielding 5.5 per cent in a currency you believe to be undervalued?' says Holtham 'It is a crime against the taxpayer. Since buying the right paper might depress the pound, not doing so is also a crime against British industry.'

Abstinence from intervention stems from the experience of 1992. Previously there was too much faith in the power of currency intervention. Now there may be too little. It's simply a question of whether the health of manufacturing industry is worth the risk.

William Keegan

The eurozone shouldn't panic - yet Crisis? What crisis? The press and airwaves have been full of gloom and doom - or schadenfreude, depending on your point of view - about the euro as it plumbs 'historic' depths or 'lifetime lows.'

Yet the very week in which it fell below its latest (non-) resistance point of 90 cents (having previously dropped through $1.10 cents and $1) the UN Economic Commission for Europe (ECE) confidently pronounced: 'The economic prospects for western Europe now appear to be better than at any time in the last decade.'

In its annual Economic Survey of Europe, the ECE declared: 'In the second half of 1999, the region finally shook off the sluggishness of activity which had marked 1998 and early 1999, and by the third quarter (and probably the fourth as well) Gross Domestic Product was growing at an annual rate of around 3.5 per cent.'

According to the ECE, higher exports helped to get the recovery going in the early part of 1999, 'but given the high levels of interdependence of the European economies, this quickly had multiplier effects on demand through most of the EU. Business and consumer confidence strengthened considerably.'

Thus exports were helped by improved price competitiveness resulting from the strong dollar (or weak euro) as well as by the revival of east Asian and other markets, and the sheer strength of demand from the US.

By the second half of 1999, net exports were making a strong positive contribution to western European economic growth, although private consumption was the 'mainstay' of the recovery.

But that was western Europe as a whole, including the UK. The annual report of the European Central Bank (ECB), which concentrates on the 11 eurozone countries, reminds us the UK is the largest marketwith 19.3 per cent of eurozone exports.

Separate British statistics show that the volume of UK exports fell by the equivalent of an annual 10 per cent during 1999's fourth quarter, while imports rose at a similar rate. The weak euro and the strong pound were combining to assist the eurozone's economic recovery; and the lack of UK price competitiveness was also allowing our continental neighbours - whom New Labour ministers had been shamelessly lecturing on how to run an economy - to beat the UK in exporting to third markets.

The eurozone economies had undergone five years of fiscal tightening, as part of the 'Maastricht process', in the run-up to the start of the single currency in January 1999. The International Monetary Fund executive board praised the impact of the 'timely monetary easing' (ECB interest rates were reduced from 3 per cent to 2.5 per cent on 8 April last year) on economic growth.

John Llewellyn, global chief economist at Lehman Brothers, says: 'Growth picked up almost as soon as fiscal policy returned to neutral in 1999, and is now solid and broadly based.'

While the IMF is concerned that the ECB could damage the recovery by raising rates too enthusiastically (they are now back to 3.75 per cent). Llewellyn, a former top economist at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, maintains that the ECB policy poses no threat, and that the central bank is 'slowly taking interest rates back to neutral.'

Given the timelags in the economy, the full impact of the decline in the euro on higher growth and lower unemployment has yet to be fully felt. And given the still-high level of unemployment in the eurozone, there is no obvious reason why core economies such as Germany should be concerned about the devaluation of the euro since 1 January 1999.

On the contrary. Taking the fall in the euro's rate against the dollar since its inception involves comparisons with what is essentially an artificial benchmark. As Paul Chertkow, of the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, has pointed out, the trading range of the 'synthetic euro' - the euro or its equivalent before 1 January 1999, was between $1.70 in December 1979 and $0.69 in February 1985.

The ECB has been pretty consistent in saying, during a number of euro 'scares', that it would be concerned about the falling euro only if it began to threaten achievement of its inflation target of 0 to 2 per cent.

Last week the ECB's vice-president, Christian Noyer, conceded the recent slide 'puts pressure on price stability'. But the French are keener than the Germans, and so far the benefits to growth of the falling euro seem to have outweighed the inflationary disadvantages.

Noyer ended the week saying: 'Intervetion is a tool in our hands. We may use it if deemed necessary.'

webTitle: If risk avoidance becomes stupidity - it's time to act

fields.headline: If risk avoidance becomes stupidity - it's time to act
fields.standfirst: Acting to damp the pound is a win-win strategy, argues John Williamson
fields.trailText: The article by Willem Buiter and Anne Sibert would have been state of the art about a decade ago. An influential committee of the G7 headed by Phillippe Jurgensen had pronounced in favour of the position they espouse, namely that foreign exchange intervention never has any effects except maybe in the very short term. But at least two new studies since then, both using data previously unavailable, have cast doubt on this view.
fields.body:
The article by Willem Buiter and Anne Sibert would have been state of the art about a decade ago. An influential committee of the G7 headed by Phillippe Jurgensen had pronounced in favour of the position they espouse, namely that foreign exchange intervention never has any effects except maybe in the very short term. But at least two new studies since then, both using data previously unavailable, have cast doubt on this view.

One was by two leading American economists, Kathryn Dominguez and Jeffrey Frankel, who summarised their work in a book called Does Foreign Exchange Intervention Work? published by the Institute for International Economics in 1993.

On the basis of a detailed study of daily intervention in the dollar-deutschmark market during the second half of the Eighties, they conclude (p140) that '...foreign exchange intervention can "work" if properly conceived and executed. Intervention represents a more potent policy instrument than most officials, and especially most outside analysts, have in recent years imagined it to be.'

But, importantly, their analysis shows that secret intervention is useless: it is intervention that the market knows about that has an impact. The obvious implication is that intervention operates by changing the expectations of at least some market participants.

Another study was by three economists at the Banca d'Italia, who published their work in a chapter of a 1994 conference volume published by Cambridge University Press called The International Monetary System. Their analysis also used unpublished data, in this case on daily interventions in the dollar-deutschmark and dollar-yen markets over the period 1984-1991. They found that most episodes of concerted intervention had been successful in achieving desired turning points in short-run exchange rate trends, even though in some cases interest rates had moved in a contrary direction to that needed to support the exchange rate change.

The finding that it matters whether intervention is concerted (supported by both the central banks involved) suggests once again that it has an impact because it alters the expectations of market participants.

This does not make much sense to economists sufficiently inspired by conventional models of how the exchange markets work. Many atomistic participants are independently calculating the path back to equilibrium implied by current and expected future interest differentials.

It makes a lot more sense if one believes (as asserted in paragraph 36 of the recent Report of the Market Dynamics Study Group of the Financial Stability Forum) that '[at certain times] markets [for foreign exchange] seem to be influenced in significant ways by herding, feedback effects, hedging strategies, and the presence or absence of key market players'.

Over time, the role of these factors is normally expected to dissipate as fundamentals come to play an increasingly important role. In some circumstances, however, markets can become one-sided, with 'short-run' factors threatening to have larger and longer-lived impacts.

If one recognises this as the world we live in, Gerry Holtham's proposal to buy long-term euro bonds financed by the issue of long-term sterling debt makes excellent sense. To the extent that this operation would move the sterling rate closer to equilibrium, British manufacturing would get the relief it needs.

If it is ineffective in shifting the exchange rate, the British taxpayer gains a reduced interest burden amplified by the likelihood of a capital gain as the euro appreciates relative to the pound in the future, for the infinitesimal risk that the pound may appreciate even more than now relative to the euro in the long run.

Refusing such a win-win strategy with a sneer about it being risky to run a hedge fund is to act like the proverbial economist who refuses to pick up a $100 bill on the argument that if it were real someone else would already have picked it up. There is a point at which risk avoidance becomes stupidity. It is time to act.

John Williamson is Senior Fellow, Institute for International Economics

If it is ineffective in shifting the exchange rate, the British taxpayer gains a reduced interest burden amplified by the likelihood of a capital gain as the euro appreciates relative to the pound in the future, for the infinitesimal risk that the pound may appreciate even more than now relative to the euro in the long run. Refusing such a win-win strategy with a sneer about it being risky to run a hedge fund is to act like the proverbial economist who refuses to pick up a $100 bill on the argument that if it were real someone else would already have picked it up. There is a point at which risk avoidance becomes stupidity. It is time to act. John Williamson is Senior Fellow, Institute for International Economics

fields.headline: Big Tobacco in the balance
fields.standfirst: Cigarette companies face a day of reckoning in Florida courts, reports Heather Connon
fields.trailText: A week tomorrow, 12 jurors in Florida will meet to decide whether, and by how much, they should punish the tobacco industry. The case, which is expected to last for up to two months, is already being hailed as a landmark.
fields.body:
A week tomorrow, 12 jurors in Florida will meet to decide whether, and by how much, they should punish the tobacco industry. The case, which is expected to last for up to two months, is already being hailed as a landmark.

The anti-smoking lobby says it marks the beginning of the end for the industry. The tobacco companies dismiss it as just another court procedure, which will be overturned on appeal.

Both would agree on two things. The Engel case is the first class action against tobacco companies to be heard in a US court. It is also the first significant case to be heard since the industry agreed to a settlement under which US states, including Florida, receive a share of $246 billion (£160bn) over the next 25 years in exchange for giving up the right to take legal action against tobacco companies. These are both having a significant influence on proceedings.

Big Tobacco - the generic name for the big manufacturers such as Philip Morris, RJ Reynolds and Brown & Williamson, US subsidiary of British American Tobacco - has already been found guilty by the Florida jury of fraudulently conspiring to make a dangerous, addictive product that causes cancer, heart disease and other illnesses. Last month it awarded a total of $12.7m compensation to Mary Farnan, Angie Della Vecchia and Frank Amodeo, three representatives of the class of Florida smokers behind the Engel action.

Next week's hearing is to decide on punitive damages, which some estimate could go as high as $300bn. That has raised before the industry the spectre of bankruptcy. Worse, court rules say defendants have to post a bond, equal to the amount of damages awarded, before they can appeal. That raised the prospect of the industry going bust before it had the chance to argue its innocence.

The anti-smoking camp claims the $300bn figure was dreamt up by the industry as a tactic to frighten the states into giving them protection. If so, it has worked. Late on Friday the Florida Senate passed a Bill limiting the amount of any bond to the lower of $100m or 10 per cent of the tobacco companies' net worth.

Some say that simply codifies existing Florida law, which prohibits a damages award so high that it puts a company out of business. All the tobacco companies could easily pay that level of bond.

More interesting than the amount, however, is the logic behind it. The Florida legislature was driven less by concern about the financial stability of the tobacco industry - although it is one of the tobacco-growing states - than by the prospect of $18bn in revenue disappearing. A bankrupt industry would hardly be able to carry on paying the $246bn agreed under the state settlements.

That is an interesting side-effect of the states' settlement with the industry. Not only does it stop them taking legal action against cigarette makers, it could also encourage them to protect the tobacco industry against legislative onslaughts from others. Indeed, a number of other states have already introduced legislation limiting the amount of bond payments.

'Although it seemed obvious that the (agreement) would create a financial partnership between the leading US tobacco manufacturers and the states,' said Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the New York broker, 'the Engel punitive damages bonding process provides the first conclusive evidence that the agreement can have a real worldwide legislative impact.

'These efforts are truly extraordinary and make us increasingly optimistic that, if faced with similar financial risks, other states may take similar protective action.'

Anti-tobacco campaigners are furious, seeing the legislation as just another way of protecting the interests of Big Tobacco. They are pushing the states to sever their links with the industry by securitising their payments, as a few states, New York among them, have already done. That does give them the money in a lump sum - though they have to settle for a bit less than they would get by taking it in instalments - but it does not fully break their ties with the industry. If the tobacco companies default, the securitisation company simply claims back from the states.

But there is another spin-off from the settlement which could benefit the industry. It gives them another legal defence, and the signs are that the industry is already taking full advantage of it. Under the agreement, the tobacco companies had to cut their advertising, particularly when it could be seen by young people, fund anti-smoking campaigns and pay for a foundation to study smoking-related diseases. This all had to be paid for from an increase in the price of tobacco which, the states hoped, would reduce the level of smoking. It is policed by the attorney-generals of the states, who act against any breach of the terms.

That means the industry can claim it is reformed. It has already been punished by making the payments (although, given that the cost has to be recouped through price rises, that is rather tenuous) so should not be punished again. It has admitted the error of its ways and is making amends. It can also claim that its behaviour is being thoroughly policed by the states, so the courts no longer need to mete out punishment in damage awards.

That argument is likely to be heavily used in Florida in the coming months - indeed, Philip Morris has already started the campaign with newspaper ads emphasising its changed attitudes. It may not be that successful. Philip Morris and RJ Reynolds used these arguments in California, but Lesley Whiteley, a woman who did not even start smoking until after the health warnings started appearing on cigarette packets and who had a history of marijuana abuse, was awarded $1.7m compensation and $20m punitive damages.

It is one of the three cases which have gone against the tobacco industry and are now on appeal. Engel will also be subject to an appeal immediately it ends. Indeed, the industry has been trying to get it thrown out since it was filed in 1994.

It has argued that smokers, who smoke different brands, for different periods, and have different illnesses, cannot be treated as a class. And it has argued that it is impossible to determine punitive damages for every smoker until the courts have decided on their level of compensation. There could be as many as a million Florida smokers, and if compensation had to be determined first the whole process could take years. So far, however, the higher Florida courts have refused to intervene.

The industry is confident it will eventually win. It insists the class action will be thrown out by the higher courts - and it always appeals right to the Supreme Court if necessary. It is also confident that the three individual victories will be overturned.

History provides some justification for this optimism. Since the first suit was launched in 1954, only 50 cases have come to court. All victories in lower courts have been overturned on appeal. No class action has ever been successful - although two, in Maryland and Louisiana, are still pending, probably awaiting the outcome in Florida.

But the pace of litigation continues to accelerate. More than 300 cases are pending and prosecution lawyers - who have still not made a penny out of tobacco litigation - are finding more and more ingenious ways of getting under tobacco's defences.

The anti-smoking lobby believes that the three recent individual victories and the decision to allow the Florida class action to proceed are hugely significant. Richard Daynard, chair of the Tobacco Products Liability Group, says the key is the recent discovery of documents showing that the tobacco companies knew of the risks years ago but covered them up. 'In every case where they have been used, the plaintiff has won.'

The history of tobacco litigation suggests that victories are usually short-lived. Will that be true of the current crop of cases? That will take longer than the duration of the Engel case to find out. But the future of Big Tobacco depends on it.

Dragging on: 50 years of US smoking tussles

1954 First lawsuit by lung cancer victim alleging negligence. Dropped after 13 years' wrangling.

1964 Surgeon General releases reports concluding that smoking causes lung cancer.

1965 Federal Cigarette Labelling and Advertising Act requires warnings on packets.

1967 Government insists on one anti-smoking advertisement for every three cigarette ads.

1971 Broadcast ads for cigarettes banned.

1972 Airlines told to create non-smoking sections.

1981 Life insurers offer discounts to non-smokers.

1984 Tougher warnings on cigarette packets.

1988 Smoking banned on short domestic flights. Surgeon General concludes nicotine is addictive.

1992 Nicotine patches introduced.

April 1994 Executives of top seven US tobacco firms swear to Congress that nicotine is non-addictive.

May 1994 Proof that tobacco executives discovered smoking's risks before Surgeon General's declaration. Mississippi files first of 24 state lawsuits.

March 1996 Liggett Group, the smallest of major tobacco firms, settles with five states.

April 1997 Federal judge rules that government can regulate tobacco as a drug.

June 1997 Landmark settlement calls for unprecedented restrictions on cigarettes and on tobacco makers' legal liability. Industry to spend $368 billion over 25 years, mainly on anti-smoking campaigns.

July 1997 Mississippi agrees $3.6bn deal.

August 1997 Florida reaches$11.3 bn settlement.

January 1998 Texas settles for $15.3 bn.

Tobacco executives admit to Congress that nicotine is addictive, and smoking may cause cancer.

May 1998 Minnesota and insurers Blue Cross and Blue Shield reach a $6.6bn settlement. Senate rejects $1.50 a pack cigarette tax increase.

November 1998 Forty-six states embrace $206 bn settlement with cigarette makers over bills for treating sick smokers..

September 1999 Justice Department sues industry for billions spent on smoking-related health care, and accuses it of 'coordinated fraud and deceit'.

December 1999 Government and industry argue in the Supreme Court over whether the Food and Drug Administration can regulate tobacco as a drug.

February 2000 Tobacco farmers sue cigarette makers for $69bn alleging conspiracy to undo federal regulations on tobacco prices.

March 21, 2000 Supreme Court says the government can't regulate tobacco as an addictive drug.

webTitle: Horton back at helm of ports bid

fields.headline: Horton back at helm of ports bid
fields.trailText: Sir Robert Horton could soon return to the helm of a UK listed company - as chairman of Associated British Ports.
fields.body:
Sir Robert Horton could soon return to the helm of a UK listed company - as chairman of Associated British Ports.

The colourful former head of privatised rail operator Railtrack and oil giant BP is thought to have been approached by Japanese bank Nomura to spearhead its planned bid for the UK's largest port operator.

Horton heads a list of contenders being considered by financier Guy Hands, head of Nomura's principal finance group, to head a buyout.

Last week ABP chief executive Bo Lerenius rejected an approach by Nomura which valued the company at £1.1 billion, or 320p a share.

But analysts say ABP could well accept, and offer closer to 400p a share.

However, Nomura's hands are full at the moment. It is negotiating to buy Welsh multi-utility Hyder for more than £400 million, and may not return to the ABP table until negotiations have progressed further.

Its bid for Hyder could be trumped by a consortium including Western Power Distribution (WPD), Southern Company of the US and United Utilities.

Last week WPD faced a setback when one of its backers, Barclays venture capital arm, distanced itself from the bid, but it is understood to have secured backing from elsewhere.

webTitle: Wear your website on your sleeve

fields.headline: Wear your website on your sleeve
fields.trailText: A scarf that has a built-in voice-activated radio; spectacles that double as monitors; waist-mounted computers that transform anyone who wears them into a wireless modem; and eye-catching bikinis with sensory pads that monitor the wearer's vital signs are set to hit the fashion catwalks later this month
fields.body:
A scarf that has a built-in voice-activated radio; spectacles that double as monitors; waist-mounted computers that transform anyone who wears them into a wireless modem; and eye-catching bikinis with sensory pads that monitor the wearer's vital signs are set to hit the fashion catwalks later this month. Internet World at London's Earls Court will be home to some of the world's top models showing off the latest in wearable computing devices made by Charmed Technology, a spin-off of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab.

The event's director, Phil Nelson, denied the devices were mere gimmicks. 'With Europe in a prime position to dominate the wireless market, it is vital that UK businesses embrace these advances,' he said.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.trailText: The Fleming Global Life Sciences Fund
fields.body:
The Fleming Global Life Sciences Fund

Contact: 0800 269 843

Aim : Long-term capital growth from investing in healthcare and life sciences industries throughout the world.

Bells & whistles : 'The application of massive processing power to the task of sequencing and mapping the human genome is revolutionising the speed and quality of the whole drug discovery process ... Vast financial resources will need to be expended by the pharmaceuticals industry in its search for new drugs, treatments, delivery systems and care. These will create very significant investment opportunities with the potential for commensurate returns,' says Flemings.

How it works : The fund, part of Fleming's Luxembourg Flagship Fund range, will be initially invested in US companies, but with additional investments in the UK, Switzerland and Far East. It will concentrate on companies that provide the technology to enable development of new scientific techniques and production of drugs rather than the multinational pharmaceutical companies themselves. The portfolio will include biotech/genomic companies, medical device and drug delivery system manufacturers and related health information technology and healthcare companies. The fund will be managed from New York by Christopher Jones, head of Fleming's US small cap team since 1993, supported by two analysts in New York, one in London, one in Tokyo.

Minimum : US$5,000 or equivalent in Sterling.

Charges : 5 per cent initial, 1.5 per cent annual.

Tax : Returns are paid gross, but must be declared on your tax return in the year they are received.

Risk : High.

Should you invest? Mark Dampier of Bristol independent financial advisers Hargreaves Lansdown says that, although the fund is likely to be extremely volatile, he still thinks it attractive. 'It's all on a wing and a prayer. But some of the developments in biotechnology are very exciting and could end up making some of the returns earned on technology companies look tiny if they work.' Amanda Davidson at London independent financial adviser Holden Meehan agrees: 'We like it with the caveat that it's going to be a very bumpy ride.'

Points out of 10 : Dampier 8, Davidson 6.
