webTitle: Six go wild at the seaside

fields.headline: Six go wild at the seaside
fields.trailText: God knows I'm not one to complain, but if we really must kowtow to every time-warped Napoleonic tradition of Spring Bank Holiday that involves us having to traipse off to Southend in search of vulgar entertainment at the first sign of rain, why not wait until August, when everybody from Essex has gone to Florida? But my wife is busy packing the Enid Blyton-issue tartan rug and powdered-egg sandwiches and flask of tea, and wondering whether we ought to have traded the car in for something without heating or suspension. 'It'll be fun!' she trills. It won't, of course. I help in the kitchen, banging things around with the exaggerated tight-lipped efficiency of someone snatching moral victory from the jaws of doing what he's told, until she sends me out to sit in the car for being childish and recalcitrant.
fields.body:
God knows I'm not one to complain, but if we really must kowtow to every time-warped Napoleonic tradition of Spring Bank Holiday that involves us having to traipse off to Southend in search of vulgar entertainment at the first sign of rain, why not wait until August, when everybody from Essex has gone to Florida? But my wife is busy packing the Enid Blyton-issue tartan rug and powdered-egg sandwiches and flask of tea, and wondering whether we ought to have traded the car in for something without heating or suspension. 'It'll be fun!' she trills. It won't, of course. I help in the kitchen, banging things around with the exaggerated tight-lipped efficiency of someone snatching moral victory from the jaws of doing what he's told, until she sends me out to sit in the car for being childish and recalcitrant.

'OK, but I'm not playing bingo,' I say.

We head off into the drizzle, and needless to say, I'm not the most alert person in charge of a vehicle, thanks to our infant Mussolini, who has been arriving in our room on the dot of 4.40 every morning for duvet-removal duties ever since my wife made the strategic error of dismantling his cot and giving him a bed without bars before he is old enough to appreciate the difference between daylight and the glow of a clock radio. Luckily, the 200-mile tailback on the M25 does give me time to snatch a quick siesta, disturbed only by the squeal of brakes and occasional jarring shunt from the car behind, and it's not that long before we are reversing into a space next to the concrete municipal toilet block and promenading the bustling ketchup-smelling seafront, my wife handing round Maltesers against the cold and me carrying her duffel bag which she has had relined with lead ingots for the holiday season ('It's only a bottle of squash and a packet of custard creams, for goodness sake!').

What now? Well, Southend has the longest pier in the world, and so is particularly attractive to sprightly but vague geriatrics who need to be humanely restrained from walking to France, or simply people with nowhere better to go. We catch the little train down to the end, which has an amusement arcade and a variety of stalls selling lard-based products to people on obesity holidays, but by now we are starving hungry ourselves, what with the salt breeze and not having eaten anything for 10 minutes. Luckily there's an old-fashioned cafe with a view of the gasometer where we order cod and chips, and a nice tuna salad for my wife, who is on a diet after bingeing on the children's Cadbury's Mini Eggs all week until she noticed her trousers were getting shorter.

I have to say, this is quite a homely place, with fishy tablecloths and the teenage staff is so polite that I find myself on the point of asking when they last had contact with the outside world. And, OK, I have to send my mushy peas back to be thawed just a fraction more, and the tables are so close together I fall into the habit of helping myself to someone else's onion rings, but as a corner of England that is forever putting signs up saying 'Coaches Welcome!' (though, obviously, you'd have to park it in the sea), I've seen worse. And then would you believe it - the sun comes out. So down we go to the beach, where the kids shovel sand in each other's eyes for an hour or so while we relax in our deckchairs, watching the police helicopter clattering overhead and listening to the greaseball rock'n'roll trio treating a nipple-pierced audience of boot-tapping, leather-eared bikers to a repertoire designed to demonstrate that knowing only three chords need be no bar to playing the same tune over and over again.

All that is left to do is take the kids round Adventure Island and spend all our money on rides that shake the fillings out of your teeth. We come off the Rapid River and stand at the kiosk looking at unflattering photos of us getting soaked. 'Why not have your picture on a keychain?' the sign asks, with absolutely no trace of expecting anyone to think that might remotely be a bad idea.

And then what luck! The nine-year-old comes rushing up with a £1 coin he has found in the Gents. Just enough to buy four sticks of rock!

'Not before you wash those hands,' says my wife.

She can be such a spoilsport.

 Smutty postcards to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Fast Forward
fields.trailText: The loafer's guide to popular culture. This week: Lauren Slater
fields.body:
Seems you can't move these days for Laurens or Lauryns. True, but unlike the Booths, Bacalls and Hills, Lauren Slater has a bona-fide USP: she's a champion of 'fictoir' or, if you prefer, 'memtion'.

Come again? A mixture of fiction and memoir, as displayed in her new book, Spasm - A Memoir With Lies, an account of how she may - or may not - have had epilepsy as a teenager, based - or maybe not - on her fraught adolescent diaries. 'A metaphor of illness, expressing resonant and complex truths about the self that simple documentary fact could never describe,' froth the publishers, who have delayed publication of the tome until they can work out how to classify it and its unreliable narrator.

Is it a cry for help? If it is, it won't be her first. Her previous books, Welcome to My Country and Prozac Diary, respectively detail her work as a psychologist with schizophrenic males in Boston, and her decade under the drug that helped her deal with the tide of manic depression, agoraphobia, self-mutilation, bulimia and obsessive-compulsive disorder that engulfed her at 10. 'My subject is melancholy,' she says, melancholically. 'That's how I see the world.'

Not exactly side-splitting stuff, then? But hopefully uplifting, in a Frank McCourt I-Will-Survive School of Lit kind of way. Slater can certainly write (she's made serial appearances in Best American Essay collections and, fittingly, won the 1993 New Letters Literary Award in 'creative non-fiction') and Spasm, which 'embroiders and exaggerates' the author's pubescent ailments to tell 'a greater truth', should appeal to ambulance chasers.

Why not just call it autobiography? Slater distrusts 'the whole genre of self-exposure', and it's perhaps not uncoincidental that one of Prozac's side effects is thought to be memory deficit, but it may also be that her current life's comparatively even keel needs fictoir-ing up a bit; Prozac enables her to function at '70 per cent, on a good day'. But she's not succumbing to complacency: 'I sometimes plan my death,' she reports. 'There's part of me that's forever grim.'

So she has plenty left to plumb? Indeed, but rumours that a recent toe-stubbing incident have inspired a harrowing three-volume 'memtion' have yet to be confirmed.

webTitle: Sound decisions - but can I mix in a little excitement?

fields.headline: Sound decisions - but can I mix in a little excitement?
fields.standfirst: Stephen Muldowney wants to be prudent - but not yet, he tells  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Vital statistics
fields.body:
Vital statistics

Stephen Muldowney

Age: 28

Lives in: Dorset

Occupation: Sales and marketing for telecoms company

Earns: £23,000

Mortgage: None, rents accommodation at £215 a month

Debts: Student loans of £6,500; overdraft £1,000

Investments: Cash Isa £2,800

Pension: Has been offered membership of a company scheme

Aims: To find out best way to prioritise debt repayment, car and property purchase and investment plans.

'Where do I go from here? asks telecoms expert Stephen Muldowney. He would like to do a number of things with his money, but can't decide on priorities.

He graduated from university just over two years ago and like most ex-students, still has debts. He has managed to pay off more than half of the £2,500 overdraft he had when he finished studying and recently moved his account to a bank that offers a large interest-free overdraft on graduate accounts.

Stephen is paying back the Student Loan Company at £150 a month, but is not sure whether this is a good idea. 'As these student loans are low interest, would it perhaps be better to reduce my payments to the minimum of £80 a month and use the other £70 for something else.'

The something else includes buying a car and buying a home. At present Stephen gets about using public transport and begging lifts from friends. But he lives in the country and is about to take his driving test, so will probably want a car fairly soon.

Stephen has saved £2,800 in a cash Isa with this purpose in mind, though he now wonders whether he would do better with a graduate loan from his bank (HSBC) for the car. He could then use the Isa money as a deposit for a house. At present Stephen is in rented accommodation, but feels he should get a foot on the property ladder. 'It seems to be impossible to save fast enough to keep up with rising house prices.' Indeed he wonders whether property should take priority over buying a car. He points out that he could get a 100 per cent graduate mortgage from his bank.

The company Stephen works for (which employs 130 staff) is starting a pension scheme in September, to which he will contribute 5 per cent of his salary. He thinks the company will also contribute 5 per cent.

At the same time as wanting to make sound financial decisions, Stephen does not want to miss out on the excitement of investing in shares. So instead of clearing his £1,000 interest-free overdraft, he is considering using some money to invest in telecoms shares, which he feels he knows something about due to the nature of his work. He has already opened a trading account with online broker E*trade. He intends to buy shares in a couple of companies and hold them for, say, two years.

Adviser 1: Martin Jones

Stephen has graduated with significant debts, but these are all at favourable rates of interest and repaying them should not be his priority.

The interest on the Student Loans Company debt is effectively equal to inflation. Graduate overdrafts at nil interest are an even more attractive form of borrowing, but I suspect that at some stage these loans will revert to the bank's normal rate of interest, so he should be ready to repay these then. In the meantime, he should maximise his cash flow by repaying the minimum £80 per month to the Student Loans Company.

Someone living in semi-rural Dorset must need a car, and Stephen should budget to buy one soon. Buying a small car would allow him to take advantage of the cheaper road tax for small cars.

He may be able to get a 100 per cent graduate mortgage from his bank, but he should check this does not involve a mortgage indemnity guarantee (MIG) premium - a penalty charged by lenders where a high percentage of the property's value is borrowed. If this was added to the mortgage Stephen would be in negative equity. With a 100 per cent mortgage he may also find it difficult to sell without taking a capital loss.

If he does decide to buy a property, he should look for one for less than £60,000, so as to avoid paying stamp duty of 1 per cent on the whole purchase price. He should definitely join his employer's pension scheme, but given his debts it is best to avoid buying shares for now.

Martin Jones works for chartered accountant Blick Rothenberg.

Adviser 2: Gordon Wilson

Stephen has been very prudent, taking advantage of his bank's enlightened attitude to graduates. He has reduced the cost of his debt where possible, and is using the ideal vehicle for short-term, tax-free saving, a cash mini-Isa.

I think he should invest in property before buying a car. Buying a property close to work or somewhere with good public transport would reduce the immediate need for a car. Buying property first would give him a clear idea of how much he has left for a car.

A flexible mortgage would allow Stephen to reduce his mortgage debt as he goes along, but increase it if he wanted to buy a car. This way he would have a car loan at mortgage interest rates.

Stephen also needs to consider his future career. If he is likely to move in the next two years, buying now may not be a good idea: the property market could falter, and even if it doesn't, the costs of buying and selling are significant.

I would encourage any employee to join an occupational pension scheme: this is likely to be more cost-effective than a personal arrangement. Stephen's employer will contribute a valuable 5 per cent, and there may well be associated benefits such as life insurance and income protection.

But Stephen's idea of borrowing to invest in shares is highly speculative and second only in terms of risk to borrowing money to bet on the Grand National. I would encourage Stephen to wait until he has spare money of his own to speculate with.

Gordon Wilson works for financial adviser Aitchison & Colegrave.

· Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Learn the new language of e-speak

fields.headline: Learn the new language of e-speak
fields.standfirst: Jamie Doward reveals everything you ever wanted to know about how to survive hackers, firewalls and etailers
fields.trailText: Browser: Software that allows you to view web pages. They are the gateways to the Internet. The most popular are Microsoft's Internet Explorer and Netscape's Navigator.
fields.body:
Browser: Software that allows you to view web pages. They are the gateways to the Internet. The most popular are Microsoft's Internet Explorer and Netscape's Navigator.

Cookie: Think of this as a token which a company's website places on your computer's hard disk after you have visited. Every time you revisit the site you carry the cookie with you, allowing the website to identify who you are. Cookies can carry loads of information about a user from credit card details to what their last purchase was.

Digital signature: This is an electronic form of your autograph. Its function is to guarantee that the sender of a message is who they say they are. The signature is protected using encryption methods and will carry vital data including the user's name and a serial number.

eTailer: A retailer which sells solely through the Internet. Well known names include Amazon and Boo.com.

Firewalls: A sophisticated system installed on a network to prevent hackers (see below) from gaining access. They also provide defences against computer viruses.

Hacker: Pejorative term often used to describe an individual who seeks to access/vandalise computer systems. However the strict definition of a hacker is someone who likes to use technology to explore. Those who use technology to break into systems are actually called 'crackers'.

IP address: All computers that are linked to the Internet need an IP address. This means if someone sends a message over the Internet the recipient has a return address.

Internet Service Provider: This is the company which provides you with access to the Internet, turning your phone line into a gateway to cyberspace. There are scores of ISPs around so picking the right one is important. All will offer you your own e-mail service, and many allow you to build your own websites. The big names - AOL, Freeserve, BT Click, LineOne - also come with loads of content, so that when you access the Internet through the ISP you have a choice of services and information. Most ISPs are offering unlimited access to the Internet in return for monthly payments. It is worth shopping around as prices can vary dramatically.

Key: The data used to encrypt a message or transaction. A key is made up of bits, short for binary digits. These are the Internet's units of data measurement. Eight bits make up a byte.

Modem: You'll need one of these if you want to access the Internet over your phone. It stands for modulator-demodulator and essentially translates data into noise which is then relayed down a phone line for interpretation at the other end.

Operating system: Think of this as a computer's brain. It is an embedded software system which acts as the intermediary between the hardware (your computer) and the applications suite (all those software packages such as Word and Office) on your device. More than 90 per cent of the world's PC operating systems are made by Microsoft.

Packet: A unit of data sent across the Internet. Packet data refers to the method whereby data is broken up into chunks, each with a forward address attached, and then sent over the Internet..

Password/passcode: The word you type in to a computer system to secure entry. Research suggests many people use obvious passwords, thus increasing the chances of someone working them out. Experts suggest using a mixture of letters and numbers .

Portal: A website or cluster of websites visited by large volumes of users. Many are search engines - like Yahoo! and Lycos - which help you find your way around the web.

Router: These computers sit on networks and work out how best to send packets of data to their destinations. The more sophisticated the system the more routers - keeping congestion to a minimum.

Web Server: Computer program that transmits web pages in response to a request from a user's browser. Like routers, the biggest etailers and financial institutions will use hundreds of servers to ensure clients are not kept waiting because of congested systems.

Virus: Software which is designed to cause damage to a computer system. Once disseminated via disks, the explosion in e-mail attachments means viruses are a daily reality. Often they are relatively harmless but experts fear they are becoming more pernicious, eating into hard drives and bringing systems to a halt.

Wap: Wireless Application Protocol. This is a set of agreed standards which allow mobile phones to access the Internet. Essentially Wap-enabled web pages are stripped down versions of the original sites which are accessed via PCs. This means that web pages, complete with the most important information (such as your bank balance) can be downloaded to your phone quickly and efficiently. Downloading normal web pages takes for ever.

webTitle: Time for a return to victorious values

fields.headline: Time for a return to victorious values
fields.trailText: New-economy shares may have the odd bout of nervousness, and investors may have an occasional flirtation with the old-economy stalwarts, but for much of the past decade there has been only one rule of thumb: cheap stocks get cheaper and expensive ones get pricier.
fields.body:
New-economy shares may have the odd bout of nervousness, and investors may have an occasional flirtation with the old-economy stalwarts, but for much of the past decade there has been only one rule of thumb: cheap stocks get cheaper and expensive ones get pricier.

Fleming Asset Management, one of a growing number of investors that thinks the tide may be turning, is launching its UK Strategic Value Fund with the aim of profiting from the reversal.

Like all sensible investors, Fleming is hoping to buy cheap and sell dear but, perhaps because of the recent unpopularity of value funds, it has introduced a few bells and whistles to make the process seem more scientific.

It will screen stocks on a variety of measures, including old-fashioned ones such as price-earnings ratios and how market value compares with sales and the asset values. And it will not be tempted into running a covert growth portfolio: it will only buy those companies that stand at a discount to the rest of the market and will sell them when their value moves into line.

Screening is the easy part. Even a relatively unsophisticated investor can work out that banks and retailers, for example, look cheap at the moment. The trick is working out which look cheap because their businesses are in terminal decline and which are unjustly neglected by investors. Some eminent investors - and not just the infamous Tony Dye, formerly of PDFM - have failed to spot the difference.

Chris Tracey, investment director of Fleming, admits there are risks. But there is also the prospect of generous rewards: when value investing returned briefly to favour early in 1999, stocks that qualified for the description outperformed by 40 per cent.

He believes the time is ripe for a return to value styles. Interest rates should peak around the turn of the year, and trade buyers are taking advantage of low prices to mount cheeky bids - firms as diverse as Blue Circle, Charter, Associated British Ports and Thomson Travel are facing hostile cash bids.

Tracey points out that Abbey National and Lloyds have both been sharply de-rated: Abbey is at about half its high for the year. 'Even if you believe that, in the long- run, in a low-inflation world, growth stocks will outperform, academic studies show that value stocks will also do well,' said Tracey.

Fleming is limiting itself to FTSE 100 and 250 stocks; as a rule of thumb, it is likely half the portfolio will come from each index. That may sound like a blue chip fund but it will not be: Tracey warns that the price is likely to be volatile and the fund should not be bought by anyone of a nervous disposition. The £2,000 minimum investment emphasises that.

But there are signs that the technology bubble is gradually deflating, if not actually bursting, and that investors are starting to pay more attention to the underlying worth of what they are buying. That should mean that the yawning gaps between some new- and old-economy stocks will start to narrow.

Fleming has a good reputation for managing this type of fund. Experienced investors with the money to lock away for at least three years could find the Fleming launch nicely timed.

webTitle: Sell and stay safe as houses

fields.headline: Sell and stay safe as houses
fields.standfirst: You needn't put yourself in danger showing strangers round your home, writes  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: THE alleged abduction of a woman, her two children and a family friend by a man sent by an estate agent as a potential homebuyer highlights the vulnerability of people trying to sell a property.
fields.body:
THE alleged abduction of a woman, her two children and a family friend by a man sent by an estate agent as a potential homebuyer highlights the vulnerability of people trying to sell a property.

The National Association of Estate Agents insists there are few problems like the one faced by Marilyn Rowell in Leeds last month. Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, its chief executive, says: 'There are 1.5 million house sales in the UK each year, each involving an average of six to seven viewings. Fortunately this type of incident is very rare.'

He says sellers can reduce the risks by arranging all viewings through their estate agents and, where possible, asking the agent to show people around.

However, he admits: 'Experience shows that some sellers prefer to show people around themselves, and that sometimes this also occurs if an agency does not have staff available at a mutually convenient time'.

The desire to win quick sales in a busy market is encouraging both vendors and some agents to skip common sense safety precautions, according to the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, a charity named after a young London agent who disappeared in July 1986 when she went alone to show a house to a 'buyer'.

Sellers should demand that their agent attend each viewing, says trust spokeswoman Sian Rees. 'You are within your rights to insist. This will put off anyone who is not a genuine buyer and [ensure] you are not alone in the house with people you know nothing about.'

Rees thinks the onus is on estate agencies to ensure the safety of their staff and clients. All agents should be trained to write down details of prospective viewers, including their addresses and telephone numbers at home and at work.

The agent should ring the prospective buyer at their workplace to check that the identity they have given is correct. Buyers should always be asked to come into the estate agency before going to view a property, so everyone in the office sees them and can identify them if problems occur later.

But what about the increasing number of people who are choosing to save money by selling their homes themselves, often using Internet websites? Some sites, such as Houseweb and Easier have tried to protect vendors by requiring potential buyers to email the companies if they want to view a particular property. This means they can screen out cranks, and keep details in case of problems.

Easier also includes information on how ensuring your safety during a viewing. And from 15 May the company will link up with security firm Group 4 to provide escorted viewings and keyholder services for vendors who use Easier to sell their homes.

Group 4 will provide staff to escort potential buyers around properties, with or without the owners present.

The service costs an initial fee of £50 for key collection, a comprehensive inspection and briefing on the property and the first month's keyholding fee. The vendor then pays a key-holding fee of £30 a month and £20 an hour for each viewing overseen by Group 4.

While this may sound expensive, someone selling their property after three months and seven viewings will still have to pay only £250 - a snip compared with the 2 per cent of property value that vendors typically pay estate agents.

Crooks, keep out

 WHERE possible use an estate agent and insist that they accompany viewers.

 Ensure the agent (or you, if you are selling your home yourself) obtains - and checks - the following details from prospective viewers: name, home and work addresses and telephone number(s), the number of people coming to view, including children, and an 'emergency' number in case you have to cancel the appointment.

 If you won't be accompanied by an agent, ask a friend or neighbour to be present. If your viewer wishes to rearrange the time and date, ring back to confirm the new details only when you are sure you will have company.

 Fix viewings in daylight.

 Never leave valuables in easily accessible places.

 Always stay with viewers.

 Don't give details of security systems or safes until your home is sold.

 If you feel uneasy about your visitors, make an excuse for them to leave.

 If you feel scared, call the police immediately.

Buyer beware

 Visit properties with an estate agent. If you set up an appointment with the home owner, ask for a phone number so you can ring and check that the person is who they say they are.

 Do not visit properties on your own - take a friend or relative.

 If you have to go on your own, tell someone where you are going and when you will be back.

 View in daylight.

 If you have a mobile phone, ask someone to ring you during the viewing and say you can't speak because you are at that particular address.

 If you feel at all uncomfortable , leave. Don't worry about being impolite. Just leave. Then let the estate agency or Internet advertising site know as soon as possible.

Source: Easier.co.uk and the Suzy Lamplugh Trust

Crooks, keep out  WHERE possible use an estate agent and insist that they accompany viewers.  Ensure the agent (or you, if you are selling your home yourself) obtains - and checks - the following details from prospective viewers: name, home and work addresses and telephone number(s), the number of people coming to view, including children, and an 'emergency' number in case you have to cancel the appointment.  If you won't be accompanied by an agent, ask a friend or neighbour to be present. If your viewer wishes to rearrange the time and date, ring back to confirm the new details only when you are sure you will have company.  Fix viewings in daylight.  Never leave valuables in easily accessible places.  Always stay with viewers.  Don't give details of security systems or safes until your home is sold.  If you feel uneasy about your visitors, make an excuse for them to leave.  If you feel scared, call the police immediately. Buyer beware  Visit properties with an estate agent. If you set up an appointment with the home owner, ask for a phone number so you can ring and check that the person is who they say they are.  Do not visit properties on your own - take a friend or relative.  If you have to go on your own, tell someone where you are going and when you will be back.  View in daylight.  If you have a mobile phone, ask someone to ring you during the viewing and say you can't speak because you are at that particular address.  If you feel at all uncomfortable , leave. Don't worry about being impolite. Just leave. Then let the estate agency or Internet advertising site know as soon as possible. Source: Easier.co.uk and the Suzy Lamplugh Trust

webTitle: A lone hero stands up to the big banks

fields.headline: A lone hero stands up to the big banks
fields.trailText: Silence has descended over the battlefield where Government and consumers have been slogging it out with the banks.
fields.body:
Silence has descended over the battlefield where Government and consumers have been slogging it out with the banks.

Since Don Cruickshank, the government-appointed investigator, delivered his damning report on the banks two months ago, little has been said about tackling the problem of the annual £5 billion of excess profits that Cruickshank says the banks are generating.

The Government will not escape without a fight. Liberal Democrat MP Vincent Cable plans to raise the issue in Parliament again this week. He has also written to Trade Secretary Stephen Byers alleging that the banks are breaching competition law. Cable's belief, which is shared by smaller banks and building societies, is that large banks such as Barclays are preparing to use their dominance in the cash-machine network to increase their already enormous share of the current account market. Cable has put down an early-day motion and tabled a question in Parliament. The Department of Trade and Industry is passing the buck to the Office of Fair Trading, which says it is 'monitoring the charges issue closely'.

Straight talk from Cable is very welcome.

 Friends Provident has succumbed to mounting pressure and put itself on course for demutualisation. The Friends board is recommending demutualisation and the result of the vote is a foregone conclusion. The only question is whether Friends makes it to the market as an independent company or is taken over. Either way, policyholders can start planning how to spend their windfalls now.

fields.headline: Gordon's gift hides snags
fields.standfirst: Check the small print of employee share schemes, says  David Prosser
fields.trailText: Investors will be able to save up to £10,500 a year through employee share ownership schemes following the Budget. But Chancellor Gordon Brown has structured the regime so that people will have to read the small print carefully to maximise the returns.
fields.body:
Investors will be able to save up to £10,500 a year through employee share ownership schemes following the Budget. But Chancellor Gordon Brown has structured the regime so that people will have to read the small print carefully to maximise the returns.

The centrepiece of the system is a new all-employee share ownership scheme to be launched this year (see box). Staff taking part will receive up to £6,000-worth of free shares from their employers each year, though half the allocation will depend on them making a £1,500 investment of their own. Save As You Earn schemes (see box) will continue alongside the new scheme, allowing investors to put a further £3,000 a year towards paying for shares in their firms.

Sally Russell, of Proshare, the body which promotes wider share ownership, says: 'It's a great Budget for us.'

Nevertheless, there are two catches with the new system. First, investors will face a degree of risk. Those who buy shares will do so at the prevailing market price of the company, and this could subsequently fall.

However, David Cassidy, chairman of Chester-based financial adviser Nelson Money Managers, argues that this is a risk worth taking. For one thing, employees will be able to buy shares out of their pre-tax income - so a £1,500 purchase will cost a higher-rate taxpayer only £900. Also, the £6,000 you receive in free shares will compensate for all but the most dramatic fall in value of the stake you pay for yourself, Cassidy points out.

'There is an element of risk, but this is still a fantastic offer,' he says.

The second catch is more of a problem. Investors who keep shares granted through the new scheme for at least five years will pay no income tax or national insurance on their holdings. But capital gains tax (CGT) will potentially be payable on profits from selling the shares after that, just as it is with SAYE schemes.

The CGT problem is particularly acute for members of SAYE schemes, where the acquisition cost of shares is deemed to be the price at which you are given the option to receive them. In the new scheme, the base cost of your shares will be their price on the day they emerge from the plan, which for most people is after five years. So if you sell your shares straight away, there will be no tax to pay.

Many investors will make sizable contributions to employee share ownership schemes and will accrue large profits on shares that they retain. It will be vital to minimise tax when you realise these gains.

The good news is that the Chancellor has effectively cut the rate of CGT on profits from shares granted through employee share ownership schemes. These shares now count as business assets, thus qualifying for generous taper relief announced in the Budget. It cuts the taxable proportion of a capital gain: the longer you hold an asset, the more relief you get. The effective rate of CGT on shares granted through employee ownership plans has fallen to 10 per cent on sales made after four years or more.

However, to minimise your CGT bill you need to consider carefully when to sell such shares. In the new plans, investors will have to hold them for at least five years to avoid income tax, so they should qualify for the maximum level of taper relief.

 The new all-employee share ownership scheme will enable employers to offer shares in three ways. First, all members of the new scheme will be allowed to receive up to £6,000 of free shares in their company each year. In addition, employees will be able to buy £1,500-worth of shares each year from their pre-tax income, and employers can match these by offering up to two more free shares.

 The new scheme will run alongside save-as-you-earn (SAYE) schemes, which give employees the option of buying shares in their company once they have contributed for a minimum period to a savings plan. At the end of their plans, members qualify for a cash bonus. On maturity, you can use the sum saved, plus bonus, to buy shares in your company.

 Approved profit-sharing schemes, meanwhile, will be abolished in 2002. Under these plans, your company uses a percentage of profits to buy its own shares, which are then distributed free to employees. You may receive shares worth up to 10 per cent of your annual salary each year, subject to a maximum of £8,000 of shares.

This article is taken from the May issue of 'Money Observer', on sale at newsagents, price £3.50. For 12 issues at £31.97, a saving of £10, call 0870 8701324 and quote reference MYEG002.

webTitle: Nice work - if you can afford it

fields.headline: Nice work - if you can afford it
fields.standfirst: Vast gaps in salary expectations make many think twice about choosing a 'worthwhile' career, writes  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: However altruistic and caring you are, you can probably not afford to become a teacher or a nurse. And you might want to think twice about becoming a doctor or vet.
fields.body:
However altruistic and caring you are, you can probably not afford to become a teacher or a nurse. And you might want to think twice about becoming a doctor or vet.

Although the salaries paid to someone starting out in teaching (£16,050) or nursing (£14,890) are comparable to those paid at the start of other professions, they are quickly outstripped. A teacher with seven years' experience will earn a maximum of £23,958, and cannot expect to earn much more during the rest of his career unless he takes on extra responsibilities. A doctor or vet with a similar length of experience will probably earn between £30,000 and £40,000. In contrast a City solicitor, accountant or trader could easily be topping £100,000.

This disparity in salaries has caused many vocational workers to reconsider their careers. Tim, who switched to journalism after being a secondary-school teacher for eight years, says: 'I could see I was never going to make any money. I was going to be doing the same job in 30 years' time for more or less the same money. It was a depressing prospect. A lot of people who go into teaching for genuine vocational reasons discover fairly soon that their chances of making a decent living are slim. I know many people who have left for more lucrative careers.'

Others are being deterred before they even enter the training stage. Only 9,208 graduates have applied for 14,383 secondary teacher training places this year, indicating that students view the prospect of low earnings in a dim light. Other vocational careers, such as nursing, are seeing similar shortfalls in applicants.

Many students are being forced to consider higher paying careers because of the large debts they have built up during their education. Research published by Barclays last week shows that the average student debt on graduation was £5,286 in 1999, with 80 per cent owing money to the Student Loan Company, 61 per cent to banks and 28 per cent to credit card companies.

Some companies have used student penury as a chance to attract the cream of graduates by offering golden hellos. Reuters, Tarmac Quarry Products and HSBC have all offered joining bonuses of £2,000 or more to ensure they get the right candidates. Even the Government has joined the fray, by announcing that trainee teachers on postgraduate course will be paid £6,000, plus £4,000 extra for those in subjects where there is a shortage, such as science, maths, languages and technology.

But such carrots pale into insignificance with the starting salaries offered by City law firms. Gouldens, which concentrates on banking, property and general commercial work, starts its first-year trainees on £25,000 rising to £40,000 on qualification, and throws in sports club membership, Bupa medical insurance and a season ticket loan as perks. And Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, a US firm practising corporate law in London, pays first-year trainees £33,000 rising to £59,000 on qualification.

fields.headline: The pros, cons, and costs
fields.trailText: Medicine
fields.body:
Medicine

Academic qualifications: High grades in sciences (chemistry is particularly important), followed by a five or six year degree in medicine and surgery.

Cost during education: Larger overdraft for a five or six year degree. To this add the cost of a stethoscope (£65 to £125 ), an ophthalmoscope (£110 to £150) and white coats at £25 each. You will also have to pay for the exams to become a member of the Royal College of your choice.

Part 1 exams for the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health cost about £210, while part 2 exams cost £460.

Starting salary: £17,260 as a house officer.

Salary and position after 10 years: You may still be a specialist registrar, earning £30,670 to £35,080. But you could be a consultant on £48,905, an associate specialist on £28,995 plus, staff grade on £26,150 to £34,710, or a GP on an average of £54,220.

Career pros and cons: To quote several doctors, the money is rubbish for the amount of training, hours and stress involved. In the early years you can expect to be used and abused. However, many doctors find this is more than compensated for by a high level of job satisfaction.

Veterinary science

Academic qualifications: High grades in chemistry and other sciences or maths at A level, followed by a veterinary degree.Courses last five years except at Cambridge, where it lasts six.

Cost during education: Cost covered by LEAs for British students, but expect to pay around £600 for overalls, white coats, steel capped wellies, medical equipment and books.

Starting salary: £15,000 to £20,000 in a mixed country practice.

Salary and position after 10 years: An experienced assistant can earn up to £40,000.

Career pros and cons: There are a few wealthy vets, but this is a career you do for love, not money.

Public relations

Academic qualifications: Degree preferable.

Cost during education: No extra costs.

Starting salary: £18,000 as an account executive in an agency, or £12,000 as an assistant or administrator in a in-house press office.

Salary and position after 10 years: A director of an agency would expect to earn from £35,000 in a small two-man band to £500,000 at a big City firm. The average falls between £60,000 and £80,000. An in-house PR may be a head of department, earning about £100,000 in London.

Career pros and cons: Intellectually challenging and financially rewarding.

Law - barrister

Academic qualifications: You need a good 2nd class or 1st class degree. If you've taken a non-law degree, you must take the one year Common Professional Examination (CPE), followed by the one year Bar Vocational Course. You then apply for a pupilage in a set of chambers, consisting of six months non-practising and six months of handling cases.

Cost during education: The CPE costs from £3,000 to £5,000, and the Bar Vocational Course £6,000.

Starting salary: Depending on which chambers you are attached to, you are likely to be paid during your pupilage (anything from £12,000 to £25,000). A first-year tenant can expect to earn £17,000 plus.

Salary and position after 10 years: Figures compiled by BDO Stoy Hayward show that the average earnings range is from £61,200 to £124,300 for barristers with 10-years-plus experience. But this depends very much on the type of work.

Career pros and cons: Provided you pick the right branch of law, you can earn a great deal of money. However, persuading your clients to actually pay is a different matter, and barristers are not allowed to sue for outstanding money.

Law - solicitor

Academic qualifications: A good 2nd class or 1st class degree. If you've taken a non-law degree, you must take a one-year course leading to the Common Professional Examination (CPE). This is followed by the one year Legal Practice Course (LPC). If you have taken a law degree, you can skip the CPE but must take the LPC.

Cost during education: The CPE costs from £3,000 to £5,000, and the LPE about £4,000. No student loans are available.

Starting salary: The legal minimum for trainees on their two-year articles is £10,000 a year. At the other extreme, trainees in City law firms may start on £20,000.

Salary and position after 10 years: £25,000 to £45,000 if working for a small-town firm concentrating on family law and legal aid work, to £90,000 to £150,000 for the salaried partner of a City firm.

Career pros and cons: A career that offers a massive range of experiences. Earning potential is very good - some partners in City firms have clocked up more than £1m a year

Civil engineering

Academic qualifications: Reasonable A Levels or equivalent. A 3-year BEng is the benchmark for an Associate of the Institution of Civil Engineers, a 4-year MEng for a Member.

Costs during education: No extra costs.

Starting salary: £12,500 to £21,000, sometimes with added benefits.

Salary & position after 10 years: £20,000 - £50, 000 dependent on ambition and ability.

Career pros and cons: Civil engineers aim to balance aspirations for ever-increasing prosperity and the trappings of a civilised life against the conservation of resources and protection of the environment.

This means they make a real difference to people's lives. The work is varied and challenging, often involving long hours during critical phases. All sectors admit to a shortage of good graduates.

IT

Academic qualifications required : Science and maths A level, a degree - not necessarily computer sciences but one that carries some computer studies.

Cost during education: No extra costs.

Starting salary: About £20,000 for an IRT developer, more for someone going into e-commerce.

Salary and position after 10 years : About £100,000 as an IT project manager or contractor.

Career pros and cons: The market for IT specialists is extremely strong and well paid at the moment. Working on contract is lucrative, but ultimately your career could be limited - companies will not pay for you to train on new systems.

Journalism

Academic qualifications: Most editors will look for a degree plus an National Council for the Training of Journalists course or post graduate diploma. To get on these courses you have to show a real commitment to journalism by spending time working for your college paper, local paper or radio station.

Cost during education: A one year NCTJ course (for people at A level standard) costs about £1,000, while a 20-week fast track course for postgraduate costs from £500 to £600. Cardiff's one-year post graduate diploma costs £3,790 while City University charges £3,550. Very few grants are available for the post graduate course. Most people apply instead for career development loans.

Starting salary: £11,000 on a local paper, and about £25,000 on a national.

Salary and position after 10 years: Anything from £15,000 to £20,000 as a senior reporter or features writer on a local paper. About £40,000 as a reporter on a national, up to about £160,000 as a columnist or £150,000 to £300,000 as an editor.

Career pros and cons: You are likely to cover a wide variety of subjects and meet many different types of people, including those who wield considerable power. Getting a scoop gives a real buzz. However, forget any ideas about glamour. And there is no job security, especially on the nationals.

Accountancy

Academic qualifications required: A levels or equivalent, although 92 per cent of trainee accountants are graduates - each accountancy firm will have its own requirements. You apply to firms for a training contract, which lasts a minimum of three years and maximum of five. In the first year you are expected to sit professional exams. In your final year you do the advanced stage, which takes the form of a written case study. Either before or after the advanced stage, you must also take a test of advanced technical competence.

Cost during education: No extra costs.

Starting salary: First year trainees last year were paid an average of £14,500, while those in London earned an average of £16,500. In your first year as a qualified chartered account you can expect to earn from £25,000 to £28,000.

Salary and position after 10 years: Someone who has remained in practice could be a salaried or equity partner of the firm, earning in excess of £100,000.

Career pros and cons: The training process and exams are intensely boring, and trainees are treated as auditing fodder to be despised and maltreated by company in-house accounting staff. The culture of the profession tends to be quite narrow minded. On the positive side, if you are joining a large firm there are likely to be many trainees around your age, providing an instant social life. Once you've qualified, the money is good, and if you switch into business your progression up your company is likely to be fast.

Investment banking

Academic qualifications: A good degree, 2.1 or higher.

Cost during education: No extra costs.

Starting salary: About £20,000.

Salary and position after 10 years: You could easily be on a salary of £150,000 to £200,000, and bonuses do, in some cases, push remuneration to over £1 million.

Career pros and cons: Bonuses are not guaranteed - they depend on the profits made by the bank or investment firm during that year, and your portion of the bonus fund depends on your position, your performance and the regard your boss has for you. Traders and analysts start at 7am - not for night owls. Other areas of investment banking can involve extremely long and unsociable hours. On the plus side, you can derive a lot of satisfaction from seeing your ideas being put into action. And let's not forget the money!

Fund management

Academic qualifications: A degree and possibly an MBA.

Cost during education: No extra costs.

Starting salary: About £22,000 (as a trainee analyst or researcher).

Salary and position after 10 years: A fund manager, handling institutional and retail money, typically earns between £70,000 and £80,000, plus a bonus based on the fund management company's annual profit. The bonus often equals the basic salary.

Career pros and cons: You are treated as a senior at a very junior level. The trainee analyst goes on to become a fully fledged analyst, who will have access to the chief executives and finance directors of major companies, and they will take you seriously because you have a lot of power over the money invested in their business. Compared with other forms of investment banking, the hours are quite regular. However, fund managers are judged entirely on their performance, and their failure can be very high profile.

But this depends very much on the type of work. Career pros and cons: Provided you pick the right branch of law, you can earn a great deal of money. However, persuading your clients to actually pay is a different matter, and barristers are not allowed to sue for outstanding money. Law - solicitor Academic qualifications: A good 2nd class or 1st class degree. If you've taken a non-law degree, you must take a one-year course leading to the Common Professional Examination (CPE). This is followed by the one year Legal Practice Course (LPC). If you have taken a law degree, you can skip the CPE but must take the LPC. Cost during education: The CPE costs from £3,000 to £5,000, and the LPE about £4,000. No student loans are available. Starting salary: The legal minimum for trainees on their two-year articles is £10,000 a year. At the other extreme, trainees in City law firms may start on £20,000. Salary and position after 10 years: £25,000 to £45,000 if working for a small-town firm concentrating on family law and legal aid work, to £90,000 to £150,000 for the salaried partner of a City firm. Career pros and cons: A career that offers a massive range of experiences. Earning potential is very good - some partners in City firms have clocked up more than £1m a year Civil engineering Academic qualifications: Reasonable A Levels or equivalent. A 3-year BEng is the benchmark for an Associate of the Institution of Civil Engineers, a 4-year MEng for a Member. Costs during education: No extra costs. Starting salary: £12,500 to £21,000, sometimes with added benefits. Salary & position after 10 years: £20,000 - £50, 000 dependent on ambition and ability. Career pros and cons: Civil engineers aim to balance aspirations for ever-increasing prosperity and the trappings of a civilised life against the conservation of resources and protection of the environment. This means they make a real difference to people's lives. The work is varied and challenging, often involving long hours during critical phases. All sectors admit to a shortage of good graduates. IT Academic qualifications required : Science and maths A level, a degree - not necessarily computer sciences but one that carries some computer studies. Cost during education: No extra costs. Starting salary: About £20,000 for an IRT developer, more for someone going into e-commerce. Salary and position after 10 years : About £100,000 as an IT project manager or contractor. Career pros and cons: The market for IT specialists is extremely strong and well paid at the moment. Working on contract is lucrative, but ultimately your career could be limited - companies will not pay for you to train on new systems. Journalism Academic qualifications: Most editors will look for a degree plus an National Council for the Training of Journalists course or post graduate diploma. To get on these courses you have to show a real commitment to journalism by spending time working for your college paper, local paper or radio station. Cost during education: A one year NCTJ course (for people at A level standard) costs about £1,000, while a 20-week fast track course for postgraduate costs from £500 to £600. Cardiff's one-year post graduate diploma costs £3,790 while City University charges £3,550. Very few grants are available for the post graduate course. Most people apply instead for career development loans. Starting salary: £11,000 on a local paper, and about £25,000 on a national. Salary and position after 10 years: Anything from £15,000 to £20,000 as a senior reporter or features writer on a local paper. About £40,000 as a reporter on a national, up to about £160,000 as a columnist or £150,000 to £300,000 as an editor. Career pros and cons: You are likely to cover a wide variety of subjects and meet many different types of people, including those who wield considerable power. Getting a scoop gives a real buzz. However, forget any ideas about glamour. And there is no job security, especially on the nationals. Accountancy Academic qualifications required: A levels or equivalent, although 92 per cent of trainee accountants are graduates - each accountancy firm will have its own requirements. You apply to firms for a training contract, which lasts a minimum of three years and maximum of five. In the first year you are expected to sit professional exams. In your final year you do the advanced stage, which takes the form of a written case study. Either before or after the advanced stage, you must also take a test of advanced technical competence. Cost during education: No extra costs. Starting salary: First year trainees last year were paid an average of £14,500, while those in London earned an average of £16,500. In your first year as a qualified chartered account you can expect to earn from £25,000 to £28,000. Salary and position after 10 years: Someone who has remained in practice could be a salaried or equity partner of the firm, earning in excess of £100,000. Career pros and cons: The training process and exams are intensely boring, and trainees are treated as auditing fodder to be despised and maltreated by company in-house accounting staff. The culture of the profession tends to be quite narrow minded. On the positive side, if you are joining a large firm there are likely to be many trainees around your age, providing an instant social life. Once you've qualified, the money is good, and if you switch into business your progression up your company is likely to be fast. Investment banking Academic qualifications: A good degree, 2.1 or higher. Cost during education: No extra costs. Starting salary: About £20,000. Salary and position after 10 years: You could easily be on a salary of £150,000 to £200,000, and bonuses do, in some cases, push remuneration to over £1 million. Career pros and cons: Bonuses are not guaranteed - they depend on the profits made by the bank or investment firm during that year, and your portion of the bonus fund depends on your position, your performance and the regard your boss has for you. Traders and analysts start at 7am - not for night owls. Other areas of investment banking can involve extremely long and unsociable hours. On the plus side, you can derive a lot of satisfaction from seeing your ideas being put into action. And let's not forget the money! Fund management Academic qualifications: A degree and possibly an MBA. Cost during education: No extra costs. Starting salary: About £22,000 (as a trainee analyst or researcher). Salary and position after 10 years: A fund manager, handling institutional and retail money, typically earns between £70,000 and £80,000, plus a bonus based on the fund management company's annual profit. The bonus often equals the basic salary. Career pros and cons: You are treated as a senior at a very junior level. The trainee analyst goes on to become a fully fledged analyst, who will have access to the chief executives and finance directors of major companies, and they will take you seriously because you have a lot of power over the money invested in their business. Compared with other forms of investment banking, the hours are quite regular. However, fund managers are judged entirely on their performance, and their failure can be very high profile.

webTitle: For the sake of the children

fields.headline: For the sake of the children
fields.standfirst: How the doctor, the PR and the lawyer measure up
fields.trailText: Donna McShane has spent the past 10 years training for her career as a paediatrician. Although she qualified as a doctor several years ago, her education continues as she trains to become a consultant.
fields.body:
Donna McShane has spent the past 10 years training for her career as a paediatrician. Although she qualified as a doctor several years ago, her education continues as she trains to become a consultant.

The process starts with a medical degree. The first two years are spent studying anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, pharmacology, psychology, statistics and behavioural sciences. The third year brings clinical attachments plus microbiology and pathology, while the fourth and fifth years involved clinical work. Each block is followed by a written exam.

While this sounds daunting, Donna says it is relatively difficult to fail - students who fail an exam can resit, take a year out or redo the year.

Even as a student you spend a lot of time on the wards getting hands-on experience. You are also expected to follow the consultant on their rounds.

Donna says: 'In the first two years you learn by rote. For the next three years you have to motivate yourself to go to lectures in the morning and be humiliated by the consultant in the afternoon.'

The degree is followed by a year in a 'house job' - six months in adult medicine and six months in adult surgery. Donna says: 'You are "house dog" - you get all the rubbish jobs. The point is to get through safely. At the end of the year you register with the General Medical Council.'

Donna very quickly decided to specialise in paediatrics: 'Children are very resilient - they get better very quickly. They tend to bounce in and out of hospital - that doesn't happen in adult medicine.'

She has been a specialist registrar for four years, and will soon become a junior consultant.

Donna works a 56-hour week, including one in every five nights and one in every three weekends. She is currently earning about £36,000 (including overtime) - a salary she considers insulting for the amount of responsibility.

'The Government goes on about how important health is, but there is a total lack of respect. Doctors on a social scale are equivalent to accountants and lawyers, but there's no way our finances come up to that level. The Government is relying on the fact that we have job satisfaction.'

Living out a dream

After three and a half years of handling press relations for Air France, Elizabeth was approached to cover sales and marketing for the Monaco Tourist Office in London. She was again head hunted, this time to the French Tourist Office, her 'dream job'. Her role was to get the message across that France was an ideal place to travel, identifying the specific audience for different areas of France and targeting the media that served that audience.

'I did this job for just over three years until my little boy was born. But I found trying to mix PR and family life a nightmare.' Elizabeth has now struck a happy medium running her own consultancy from her home in Somerset. She is working two to three mornings a week promoting Normandy and the French Alps, which gives her enough time to look after her son as well.

Elizabeth earned £10,000 a year in her first PR role, and this increased with each job change. When she left the French Tourist Board four years ago she was on £25,000. Now she says she is earning about 15 per cent of that salary.

A question of judgement

Nathan Tavares intended being a test pilot when he first went to university but he switched his interest to law.

'I was offered articles by a firm of City solicitors, but I wanted to be an advocate and being self-employed was important.

'I was lucky to receive an offer from my particular chambers because the people there seemed to have developed a good working environment.' Competition for a tenancy (a permanent place) in chambers is intense. Nathan says: 'You have to have pretty good judgment about when to be seen and not heard.'

Clients are often very slow at settling their accounts - it is quite common for bills to remain unpaid for a year or more. Nathan has become experienced at living on income from the previous year's work. He must contribute to his chambers' expenses and has to pay for a desk, computer, stationery, travel, a wig and gowns. However, many expenses are tax-deductible.

His main complaint is the long hours and the need to drop time-off plans because a case has come in requiring immediate attention.

fields.headline: So that's the Toilet Game...
fields.trailText: Classic FM | Bam Bam Breakfast | Latins from Manhattan | Bach the Teacher | Between Ourselves | Living Death
fields.body:
Classic FM
Bam Bam Breakfast Kiss FM
Latins from Manhattan R2
Bach the Teacher R3
Between Ourselves R4
Living Death R5 Live

Mea culpa. You have not been getting the service you pay for from this column, as I discovered to my chagrin on Tuesday night at the Sony Radio Awards ceremony in London. Two stations which I rarely, if ever, mention bagged two of the top honours: Kiss FM for its breakfast show, Bam Bam Breakfast, and Classic FM, which was voted Station of the Year.

The main reason I don't write about commercial music stations is, well, that there isn't that much to write about. They are slick, professional, uncontroversial and, from a reviewer's point of view, as anodyne as invalid food. Take Classic FM, whose programme trails sound like ads for tranquillisers, full of words like 'easier, smoother, relaxing' and whose presenters have the same soothing voices as nurses inquiring whether, as you regain consciousness after the anaesthetic, 'you'd like a nice cup of tea, dear'.

Slow second movements, preferably from Mozart piano concertos or Haydn symphonies, is what Classic FM listeners like and, by golly, they get them by the cartload. I like second movements too, but in context, i.e after the first movement and before the third. Full-length symphonies, however, don't allow for the all-important ads for hair restorer, financial services and Sanatogen Tonic Wine. No need to ask who listens to Classic FM.

On Wednesday, I test-drove the Bam Bam Breakfast music machine. It's fast, smooth, reliable - a tad monotonous, maybe, all that throbbing bass, but an obvious buy for kids who go clubbing. In between tracks, the Bam Bam presenter invited listeners to phone in with contributions for something he called 'The Toilet Game'. Not being a regular listener, I didn't know the rules but listened with interest to suggestions that Bam Bam should feature a long, wet fart from someone who'd had a curry the night before.

'What particular angle are you after?' I had asked the Evening Standard reporter at the Sony awards dinner. She said her readers were interested in who the father of Ulrika Jonsson's baby was. Ms Jonsson was one of the presenters. Had it not been for the Sony Awards, I should have devoted this column to the excellence of four programmes I heard last week: Latins from Manhattan, which looked at the influence of Italian crooners on American popular music; Bach the Teacher - no scales, no arpeggios, his pupils loved him; Between Ourselves, an interview with two gay fathers about their children; and Living Death, Tom Mangold's disturbing report on the treatment of Britain's most dangerous prisoner.

It's no coincidence that these are all from the BBC, which won 17 of the 24 Sony Golds. Of course, we have to have commercial radio, but when it comes to true quality there is no contest.

webTitle: Town fights to free jailed carer

fields.headline: Town fights to free jailed carer
fields.standfirst: Doubts mount in case of woman sentenced to life for aunt's death
fields.trailText: Doubts mount in case of woman sentenced to life for aunt's death
fields.body:
Susan May, according to her friends, is the type of woman who would turn her car around to give you a lift home if she saw you walking in the street.

She was also the sort to give up a part-time job she loved to devote her time to caring for her elderly mother and her aunt. But although her life revolved around her small, close family, May had one secret she kept from them all - and which, some believe, put her behind bars.

Her friends now use three different buses to reach the jail where the mother-of-three is serving a life sentence for the battering and suffocation of 89-year-old Hilda Marchbank, the aunt she adored.

Her conviction shocked the little Lancashire town of Royton where May lived and where, in March 1992, the badly beaten and half-naked body of Marchbank was found in her ransacked and bloodstained home.

May's secret - a lover 15 years her junior - presented a motive: she had killed her aunt to get money to lavish on him.

But after seven years in jail, May has attracted support from high-profile campaigners against miscarriages of justice. This week Billy Power and Paddy Hill of the Birmingham Six, Jimmy Robinson of the Bridgwater Four and Labour MP John McDonnell will speak at the House of Commons on May's behalf.

Her friends have been given new hope by the findings of an investigation by the Criminal Case Review Commission, set up last year by the Government to scrutinise the safety of disputed criminal convictions.

The CCRC's re-evaluation of a piece of evidence that helped convict May in spring 1993 has resulted in the case being referred back to the Court of Appeal. A hearing is expected later this year.

The court at the time heard that a bloodied fingerprint found next to the light switch on the wall of Marchbank's bedroom - the only piece of forensic evidence against her - was May's. It was never proven whose blood it was and now some experts believe the print may not have been blood at all, but dirt. Fibres found in Marchbank's hand have never been identified, nor have a man's footprint in the house or a red car parked outside the house on the day of the murder. Behind Marchbank's house is an estate where heroin addicts are known to burgle homes to feed their habit.

An earlier appeal, in 1997, failed - as did 21 of the 22 complaints May filed against Greater Manchester Police. The Police Complaints Authority ruled on her grievances last month, seven years after they were first made. It rejected perjury by officers but accepted that the detective superintendent who interviewed her did not follow correct procedures. He has since retired from the force.

What those who believe in her innocence are convinced of is that May's downfall was partly caused by the lies she told police to keep her affair secret. Chris Ross, 33, was the estranged husband of her friend and neighbour.

'At that point Susan thought she was a witness, she had found her aunt's body after all, and when the police asked her if she was having an affair with Chris she said no, she thought it was none of their business,' Dorothy Cooksey, May's childhood friend, told The Observer .

'She didn't want her family to know and family was always the most important thing in the world to Susan.'

But in May's lie police saw a motive for murder: she had milked Marchbank of money to pay for her 'toyboy' and then, when she feared the cash was running out, she killed her aunt to benefit from the will.

Ross had received £2,000 towards a sports car, and a Florida holiday had been paid for on May's credit card.

But campaigners point to a different story. Over 15 years and with the full knowledge of her accountants, Marchbank had paid some £140,000 to May and her sister, women she regarded as daughters and who repaid her with care. The bulk went to May as the main carer: she visited the old lady three times a day to cook and clean.

Ross earned £24,000 a year. May herself received regular payments from her mother's property interests. Neither was poor. 'The sports car is jointly owned,' Ross said after the trial, adding that he had paid off May's credit card bill after the holiday.

If May had worried about losing Ross when the money ran out, her fear was groundless. For the past seven years he has supported her with visits and letters - one of nearly 200 Royton people involved in the campaign.

Families of convicted murderers can often be driven from close-knit communities by the stigma of association but the May children are cushioned by sympathy.

Katy May, 28, lives in the house where her mother was born and when May was jailed looked after her grandmother until she died 'heartbroken' several months after the trial.

It seems as though Royton is united in disbelief at May's guilt. They believe a panicked burglar who turned killer is still at large.

fields.headline: Food of the month
fields.standfirst: You may not feel like rollerblading or hang-gliding, but modifying your diet can significantly
fields.trailText: Jane Clarke: You may not feel like rollerblading or hang-gliding, but modifying your diet can significantly
fields.body:
Unlikely as it may sound, I couldn't wait to start my periods when I was a teenager, being keen to wear the badge of womanhood. These days however, like many women, I can understand why periods are nicknamed 'the curse': they can make a significant portion of your life utterly miserable. It's hardly surprising that the majority of menopausal women report their relief at having stopped menstruating. Indeed, this is why some resist taking hormone-replacement therapy (HRT), because, depending on the type of drug prescribed, HRT can prolong the years during which they have to endure menstrual bleeding.

One of the main reasons women dread their 'time of the month' is the pain, which may force them to spend days off work lying in bed, clutching a hot-water bottle and feeling dopey from the side-effects of strong painkillers. Nor does age always bring relief: despite assurances from many doctors that the passage of time lessens the pain, it can be just as bad - and sometimes worse - as you grow older. Child bearing doesn't necessarily make any difference either. Painful periods should always be investigated in case you have an underlying medical problem, but if you're given the all-clear and told that you will simply have to live with it, it's worth reviewing your diet. Although food won't necessarily render your period pain-free, numerous women whom I've treated have found that making basic alterations to their diets can lessen their menstrual trauma.

Scientific studies carried out over the past few years have found that women whose diet is low in fish seem to suffer more from period pain. Oily fish in particular have an essential role to play in alleviating menstrual pain. These fish contain an omega-3 fatty acid which both helps the body to produce natural, painkilling substances and reduces inflammation within the uterus by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandin PG2 alpha, a hormone-like compound that stimulates the uterine muscles. Eating at least one portion of oily fish, such as a couple of sardines, once a day on the three and four days leading up to menstruation can make period pain more bearable.

Further studies have also shown that following a diet low in fat and rich in fresh fruit and vegetables, high-fibre foods and lean proteins can significantly reduce menstrual problems. As well as hindering the action of omega-3 fatty acids, butter and other animal fats restrict the potentially beneficial effects of gamma linoleic acid, another fatty acid that can help to regulate your body's production of prostaglandins and thus reduce period pain. Gamma linoleic acid is found in the oil of evening primrose, an essential oil that you can buy in several strengths. Many women experience significant relief from period pain when they take evening primrose oil on a regular basis, but if you suffer from an underlying medical condition, consult your doctor before taking it. Similarly, although some herbalists recommend that women with period pain take cramp bark (Viburnum opulus), black haw (Viburnum prunifolium) and white peony (Paeonia lactiflora), consult a qualified herbal practitioner before trying them yourself.

You can also enlist the aid of vitamins and minerals in the battle to overcome debilitating menstrual pain. Vitamin E appears to reduce pain by encouraging the body to produce endorphins (commonly known as 'happy hormones'), which can work to banish pain. Foods rich in vitamin E include nuts, seeds, avocados, blackberries, mangoes, tomatoes, sweet potatoes, watercress and wholegrain cereals. Conveniently, all of the above-mentioned foods also contain vitamin B6 (as does milk), which works to maximise the transfer of magnesium to the cells of the uterine muscle. Nature therefore enables us to absorb and metabolise beneficial nutrients from food, which is a much healthier and tastier option than resorting to vitamin or mineral supplements.

In order to glean the optimum benefits from these foods, start eating them during the week before your period starts and for the first few days of bleeding. If you still suffer from period pain, remember that warmth frequently reduces muscular cramps, so try snuggling up with a hot-water bottle, relaxing in a warm bath or sipping a warm, soothing drink. There is also some evidence to suggest that women who have iron-deficiency anaemia suffer particularly badly from menstrual pain, so if you suspect that your body's iron levels are low, ask your doctor for a blood test. If this is found to be the case, you may be advised to boost your intake of iron-rich foods, such as lean red meats, pulses and dark green, leafy vegetables. webTitle: New BA boss to force redundancies

fields.headline: New BA boss to force redundancies
fields.trailText: The new boss of struggling British Airways, Rod Eddington, plans to order the first compulsory redundancies in the airline's history as he axes loss-making routes
fields.body:
The new boss of struggling British Airways, Rod Eddington, plans to order the first compulsory redundancies in the airline's history as he axes loss-making routes

Eddington took up his post last week with a warning to staff that BA must behave as a business, not a national institution. He told The Observer it could not prop up persistently unprofitable services, or avoid compulsory redundancies.

'That is not a tough message; that is reality,' he said.

Bob Ayling, who was sacked earlier this year and replaced by Eddington, had drawn up plans to cut up to 8,000 jobs from a worldwide staff of 60,000.

Eddington will now make his own assessment. He could not put a figure on the number of job losses, but said the fresh review 'may have me saying it is 2,000 or 10,000'.

However, he spelt the end for BA's longstanding policy of making all staff cuts through voluntary redundancy and early retirement.

'There is no magic formula for dealing with people in areas where you are reducing jobs. You try to use natural turnover and voluntaries, but you have to accept there will and must be compulsory redundancy. You have to be open with people,' he said.

The new chief executive aims to balance harsh cost-cutting measures with extra spending on customer service, close attention to battered staff morale and expansion of successful, core parts of the airline.

Eddington is also likely to phase out BA's controversial 'Utopia' multi-coloured tailfin designs and replace them all in the next two years with the popular 'Chatham' version of the Union flag that graces Concorde.

But with BA preparing to announce in two weeks' time that it lost at least £250 million last year, Eddington has promised action to turn the business around.

Ayling tried to slash costs but was unable to force his plans through without provoking strike action in the heavily unionised company. Staff morale and customer service levels never recovered. Lucrative business travellers began deserting the airline in droves.

Eddington said: 'If you try to attack the cost base but undermine the quality of the revenue stream in the process, it is self-defeating.'

He said he was 'passionate' about innovative products on board the aircraft, such as BA's planned beds in business class.

He supports the airline's current strategy of using smaller, more efficient aircraft to improve profitability across parts of the network.

Many of BA's domestic and European services and flights to and from the UK regions make large losses.

Eddington said it was possible to improve performance on some routes by reshuffling aircraft, but added: 'We will not be flying to places where we feel we cannot make money in the short, medium and long term.'
