webTitle: Rover on brink as Phoenix bid wobbles

fields.headline: Rover on brink as Phoenix bid wobbles
fields.trailText: Rover's future is hanging by a thread this weekend amid uncertainty over whether potential saviour Phoenix can find the private money it needs and strong hints that the Government will refuse financial aid for a rescue package.
fields.body:
Rover's future is hanging by a thread this weekend amid uncertainty over whether potential saviour Phoenix can find the private money it needs and strong hints that the Government will refuse financial aid for a rescue package.

Doubts persist about the consortium headed by former Rover boss John Towers securing the necessary funding to persuade BMW to hand over the struggling car firm. But sources close to Towers said they were optimistic that a deal could be signed within days.

Senior government sources have indicated that funding promised last year to BMW to redevelop Rover would not be available to the new consortium; any other state aid was also unlikely.

Rover's future will become clearer after a BMW board meeting on Thursday, a day before Ford chief Jac Nasser is expected to announce the end of car production at his firm's Dagenham plant in east London.

Both senior industry and government figures have told The Observer they do not believe Phoenix has sufficient backing to take on Rover.

BMW is under severe pressure from shareholders to end the Rover crisis, and the debacle could lead to the sack this week for chief executive Joachim Milberg.

Talks between BMW and Phoenix resume tomorrow. Towers met Trade Secretary Stephen Byers last Friday and insisted that his plan to build 200,000 cars a year at Longbridge and cut no more than 1,500 jobs was viable.

Unexpectedly, Towers did not ask for state backing, and Treasury sources said Byers had no chance of securing any for Phoenix from Chancellor Gordon Brown.

However Phoenix sources say that Towers has secured a £200m borrowing facility from an unnamed financial institution. This is a vital piece in the rescue jigsaw, which Phoenix claims now includes £700m in assets and £500m in cash to be handed over by BMW to sweeten the disposal.

Richard Burden, Labour MP for Birmingham Northfield, said: 'It seems to me that Phoenix has the basis of a credible bid.'

fields.headline: Gold rush isn't over yet
fields.standfirst: Alexander Garrett  on  the big fish still out there  in cyberspace
fields.trailText: If buying wine on the Internet sounds a fine idea, why not visit boursotwines.com, and click for a share prospectus as you order your claret? Or if downloading computer games such as Pokémon and Lemmings Revolution is more appealing, point your joystick at softwarefirst.com and click on their share offer. Customised radio stations for websites? Tune in to stickyfm.com and listen in to their public offering.
fields.body:
If buying wine on the Internet sounds a fine idea, why not visit boursotwines.com, and click for a share prospectus as you order your claret? Or if downloading computer games such as Pokémon and Lemmings Revolution is more appealing, point your joystick at softwarefirst.com and click on their share offer. Customised radio stations for websites? Tune in to stickyfm.com and listen in to their public offering.

The Internet investment bubble is looking severely deflated, but there is no shortage of new dot.com companies hoping to attract investors over the next few months. Whether they will be successful remains to be seen, given the derisory performance of the most-hyped Internet share issue to date, lastminute.com.

Before the Internet arrived, private investors often had a hard time getting their hands on new share offerings: most went straight into the hands of institutions. Freeserve was among the first to change all that, offering its own shares to subscribers on a preferential basis, direct from its website. With many Internet shares soaring to immediate premiums of 100 per cent or more, getting in on the initial public offering, or IPO, became the name of the game, with some pundits saying: if you like the website, buy the shares.

A number of Internet companies have put much of the process of buying their shares online. Typically, you can register your interest online, view a prospectus online - or download it - and even fill in an application on your computer screen.

Interactive Investor is a financial services website which recently floated on the stock market. According to marketing communications manager Candice Hodgson, it wanted its subscribers to have the maximum possible access to the share offer, and of 127,000 who registered for a prospectus, some 82,000 subsequently bought shares. Interactive Investor has also provided online administration for other share flotations, including lastminute.com and recruitment site stepstone.com, collecting registrations and hosting the web-site from which the prospectus can be downloaded.

Hodgson says: 'The main advantage for the investor is speed. You don't have to wait for a prospectus to arrive by post; you can look at it straight away and decide quickly if you want to invest.' Most floating Internet companies still offer the chance to receive a paper prospectus and apply for shares by post.

Share prices of Internet companies have clearly taken a battering in the past couple of weeks, but investors may figure that the Internet is not going to go away, and there are still opportunities worth investing in. Alan Durrant, UK equities director at Bristol stockbroker Hargreaves Lansdown, advises: 'The basic principle is the same as for any share: you shouldn't buy companies on less than a three-year view, and you certainly shouldn't buy on a 10-minute view.'

Many of the impending flotations will result in shares being available only on Ofex (a trading facility that enables dealing in the shares of smaller unquoted companies), and Durrant warns that they may be far easier to buy than to sell. Unlike the Stock Exchange, which has market makers who will buy your shares with their own money, Ofex can become virtually illiquid in a seller's market.

The challenge for those wanting to invest in Internet companies is to choose winners. Established companies, including US giants Amazon, Cisco and Microsoft, may be a better bet, and are heavily discounted.

Meanwhile, spotting the next amazon.com may not be quite the gold rush it was a few months ago, but there are sure to be many more Internet companies emerging, and for those who spot the potential early enough, there will still be handsome profits to be made.

fields.headline: New deal - virtually
fields.standfirst: Thousands buy and sell at the click of a mouse, writes Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Investors are finding that one of the most effective uses of the Internet is for share dealing. Low charges, real-time share prices and vast quantities of company information have made this possible for anyone with a PC and a modem.
fields.body:
Investors are finding that one of the most effective uses of the Internet is for share dealing. Low charges, real-time share prices and vast quantities of company information have made this possible for anyone with a PC and a modem.

Trading has increased dramatically. Figures for the first quarter of this year are expected to show that online business accounted for 20 per cent of all 'execution only' deals - those where shares change hands without the advice of a broker.

Internet trading has become less frenetic since the market fell back, but more deals are being done now than a few months ago, says Charles Schwab, one of the first broking firms to offer an online service. Such deals account for 55 per cent of its trades.

At first, its online investors 'tended to be younger people who were Internet users and looking for practical ways in which they could make it work for them', says Schwab's head of customer research, Nigel Reynolds 'Now they have been joined by more seasoned investors, who are using the Net because it is quicker and easier than other methods.'

Richard Bethell of ComPeer, an organisation that monitors private-client share dealing, believes Internet broking has been helped by favourable market conditions - and its accessibility.

He has seen a trend towards smaller deals. 'Brokers have pitched their Internet commissions so low that it makes it economical to deal in amounts of £1,000,' says Bethell.

'It means clients can construct a portfolio of shares with as little as £10,000, which would simply not have been possible in the past.'

Brokers' commissions start at £9.95. Convenience, speed and access to information are other advantages.

There are now about 20 brokers offering Internet services, and some have introductory offers. DLJdirect, for example, will refund the stamp duty on UK share trades, currently 0.5 per cent per trade, to new customers for one month from opening an account. However, Paul Lubbock, the firm's head of marketing, urges prospective investors to visit a variety of sites first.

'Seventy-five per cent of our site is open to non-account holders and offers a portfolio demo programme to give investors the opportunity to try before they buy,' Lubbock says.

Lists of online brokers can be found at www.find.co.uk.

Michael Scott, who has written a book about online brokers, says: 'There is no one broker which offers the best of everything, and investors need to consider their own requirements before making their choice.'

You should also check whether a broker offers dealing on a real time or email basis. An email system can take 20 minutes or so to go through, which can make a difference to the price at which the deal is done.

All online brokers must be regulated by the Securities and Futures Association, but if you are in any doubt, check with the Financial Services Authority on 0845 606 1234.

webTitle: High-tech Frankfurt is first among equals enemies

fields.headline: High-tech Frankfurt is first among equals enemies
fields.standfirst: London is the junior partner, despite doing twice as much business, writes Paul Farrelly.
fields.trailText: The age of the gentleman amateur is over in the City. The invasion of the Wall Street investment banks after Big Bang in 1986 daubed the writing indelibly on the wall, and last week's merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges seals his fate.
fields.body:
The age of the gentleman amateur is over in the City. The invasion of the Wall Street investment banks after Big Bang in 1986 daubed the writing indelibly on the wall, and last week's merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges seals his fate.

Formally unveiled as a merger to take on Europe and the world, the new market - to be know as 'iX', or international exchanges - is in fact a triumph of German technology over age-old London tradition. Vorsprung durch Technik, as the advertising slogan went.

Share trading in the City may still be worth more than twice as much as in Germany, and our quoted companies more than double the number and value of theirs. But the 50/50 terms reflect the march Frankfurt has stolen in hi-tech stocks (its high growth Neuer Markt is Europe's biggest, and the dominance is assured by a parallel link-up last week between iX and New York's Nasdaq exchange) and in new financial instruments, such as futures and options, as well as lower-cost electronic share trading systems. After two years of one-off talks, indeed, London struggled to achieve face-saving parity in the new market, which will be run nonetheless by Werner Siefert, Frankfurt's ambitious chief executive.

'Yes we have the largest market share, but frankly we don't have the derivatives or the attractive trading and settlement systems,' one stock exchange source conceded.

The relevance of the deal is not limited to a relative handful of highly paid bankers, brokers and fund managers, who deal in billions every day. Such experts have long looked at investing in pan-European industry sectors, not just in the UK firms listed on the shares pages of the daily newspapers. For them the existence of 15 European exchanges, with different ways of trading, has been a growing irritation that raised costs and cut profits.

The implications of the Frankfurt deal will be keenly felt by the ordinary investor, too. The merger hastens the day when all share trading will be done not in pounds but in euros.

The big pension funds were quick to raise their concerns last week. They pay out, of course, in sterling, and are deeply worried about exchange-rate risk - as long as the pound stays out of the single currency. That hot topic is as relevant to making this merger work as it was to Rover and BMW and, as the fine detail is thrashed out over the coming months, will catapult the merger into the political arena.

For the moment, it is up to companies to choose whether to list share prices in pounds, euros or both. For the blue chip firms, whose share dealings will be based in London, the status quo is an easy option. But for the high-tech and dot.com companies which have so entranced ordinary punters, the decision will be harder, as they will be traded in Frankfurt.

Currency is just one of several fudges - including different regulatory systems and the sheer cost of putting in the German trading system here - which could yet scupper the marriage.

For now, however, the exchange chiefs are upbeat after stealing a march on Euronext, the main European rival formed last year by the merger of the Paris bourse with the Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges in a brazen challenge to the dominant powers.

In that sense, last week's alliance does hark back to gentlemen joining forces to engage a traditional enemy. 'This is the Duke of Wellington and a better equipped Marshal Blucher cutting a budding Napoleon down to size,' one banker said.

The invasion of the Wall Street investment banks after Big Bang in 1986 daubed the writing indelibly on the wall, and last week's merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges seals his fate. Formally unveiled as a merger to take on Europe and the world, the new market - to be know as 'iX', or international exchanges - is in fact a triumph of German technology over age-old London tradition. Vorsprung durch Technik, as the advertising slogan went. Share trading in the City may still be worth more than twice as much as in Germany, and our quoted companies more than double the number and value of theirs. But the 50/50 terms reflect the march Frankfurt has stolen in hi-tech stocks (its high growth Neuer Markt is Europe's biggest, and the dominance is assured by a parallel link-up last week between iX and New York's Nasdaq exchange) and in new financial instruments, such as futures and options, as well as lower-cost electronic share trading systems. After two years of one-off talks, indeed, London struggled to achieve face-saving parity in the new market, which will be run nonetheless by Werner Siefert, Frankfurt's ambitious chief executive. 'Yes we have the largest market share, but frankly we don't have the derivatives or the attractive trading and settlement systems,' one stock exchange source conceded. The relevance of the deal is not limited to a relative handful of highly paid bankers, brokers and fund managers, who deal in billions every day. Such experts have long looked at investing in pan-European industry sectors, not just in the UK firms listed on the shares pages of the daily newspapers. For them the existence of 15 European exchanges, with different ways of trading, has been a growing irritation that raised costs and cut profits. The implications of the Frankfurt deal will be keenly felt by the ordinary investor, too. The merger hastens the day when all share trading will be done not in pounds but in euros. The big pension funds were quick to raise their concerns last week. They pay out, of course, in sterling, and are deeply worried about exchange-rate risk - as long as the pound stays out of the single currency. That hot topic is as relevant to making this merger work as it was to Rover and BMW and, as the fine detail is thrashed out over the coming months, will catapult the merger into the political arena. For the moment, it is up to companies to choose whether to list share prices in pounds, euros or both. For the blue chip firms, whose share dealings will be based in London, the status quo is an easy option. But for the high-tech and dot.com companies which have so entranced ordinary punters, the decision will be harder, as they will be traded in Frankfurt. Currency is just one of several fudges - including different regulatory systems and the sheer cost of putting in the German trading system here - which could yet scupper the marriage. For now, however, the exchange chiefs are upbeat after stealing a march on Euronext, the main European rival formed last year by the merger of the Paris bourse with the Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges in a brazen challenge to the dominant powers. webTitle: Unilever ready to seal deal with US Bestfoods

fields.headline: Unilever ready to seal deal with US Bestfoods
fields.trailText: Unilever's £12 billion cash bid to become the world's second-largest food manufacturer behind Nestlé by taking over American food giant Bestfoods inched closer to success this weekend.
fields.body:
Unilever's £12 billion cash bid to become the world's second-largest food manufacturer behind Nestlé by taking over American food giant Bestfoods inched closer to success this weekend.

Sources in the United States indicated that the Anglo-Dutch Persil-to-Magnum group, whose attempt to seal a friendly deal with Bestfoods collapsed last week, has won support from Bestfoods shareholders totalling close to 10 per cent.

Unilever, led by chief executive Niall Fitzgerald, is understood to have the backing of Montag Caldwell, which holds 4 per cent of Bestfoods, and Fidelity and Capital Group.

Support for a Unilever bid comes as HJ Heinz, led by Irish business tycoon Tony O'Reilly, late last week started talks with Bestfoods to merge the two firms. Similar talks collapsed last year.

But US analysts believe there is little chance that Bestfoods shareholders will accept a Heinz 'paper deal'.

Unilever has not yet formally tabled a Bestfoods bid. Talks aimed at sealing a friendly takeover between the two food giants broke down last week when Bestfoods, which has annual sales of £5.75bn, rejected Unilever's $66-a-share bid as 'financially inadequate'.

Analysts believe Unilever will use its first-quarter results announcement this Wednesday (which could see pre-tax profits before exceptionals come in at £635 million) to kickstart a hostile bid. Unilever refused to comment.

American investment bank sources say $73 cash would persuade waverers among Bestfoods shareholders. But Unilever has little scope to up a bid since it returned £5bn to shareholders last year.

Bestfoods owns world-famous brands such as Hellmann's mayonnaise and Knorr Soups, and is one of the highest rated food stocks on Wall Street.

Unilever wants the US food giant because it is concentrating its might on 'international power brands'. Earlier this year, Unilever said it was focusing on its top 400 brands.

fields.headline: Thames Valley or Rhine Valley?
fields.standfirst: Is the Anglo-Saxon style best suited to the Internet era?  Simon Caulkin  wonders
fields.trailText: Is there such a thing as a European management style, and does it have a future in the face of the US economic juggernaut?
fields.body:
Is there such a thing as a European management style, and does it have a future in the face of the US economic juggernaut?

This was a good question with which to launch European Business Forum, a heavyweight business journal bankrolled by PricewaterhouseCoopers and supported by a bevy of European management institutions, including the LSE.

The question is important, not least because it brings into focus another: why do the assumptions underlying the majority of management books and courses at the Continent's top business schools follow not the European but overwhelmingly the Anglo-Saxon model - emphasising the primordial discipline of the capital markets, the goal of shareholder value and heroic leadership?

One answer could be that the Anglo-Saxon view is right. This is the tack taken by Andrew Campbell, director of the Ashridge Strategic Management Centre who, in a typically robust intervention, likens the new theories - basically, the theory of competitive advantage developed by Michael Porter, the resource-based view of strategy (which says a firm should concentrate its efforts where it has distinctive capacities), and the capital asset pricing model (which says that it must earn at least its cost of capital) - to the contributions of Newton and Locke in the eighteenth century.

That rush of common sense which saw the peoples of Europe and America throw off centuries of dogma and tradition is now being paralleled in management, Campbell believes. He contrasts 'the new Anglo-Saxon enlightenment' with the 'Rhine model', based on stability, social solidarity and long-term survival, which he believes is a recipe for management decline.

Europe has some large underperforming companies (Philips, Deutsche Bank, Suez). It is also true that as European firms go global they inevitably adopt some Anglo-Saxon attitudes. But that is not the whole story. Also striking is the way many of Europe's most vibrant companies - Nokia and Ericsson, Renault and Volkswagen, for example - are the product of countries whose attitudes are more Rhineland than Thames Valley.

What's more, as Bob Bischof points out in his contribution, on closer examination the British 'economic miracle' is no such thing: unemployment is retreating faster than elsewhere in Europe, but, er, that's it. 'Britain reminds one of a company which is losing market share at home and abroad, which under-invests and therefore falls behind in the productivity stakes, which does not train its workforce properly. It has a lousy R&D record and employs more and more people - hardly a recipe for long-term success. 'It also has a range of nasty social problems, inevitable side-effect of 'flexibility' - shift work and part-time work that is so badly paid that both parents need a job.

Under pressure to deliver short-term profits with a poorly trained workforce and lousy infrastructure, British management has evolved a model to match. Trouble is, real-life management is not a model but a series of problematic factors, such as people, relationships and strategy, and here the resource advantage seems squarely with the Continentals.

Since the war, the 'fit' of the Rhine model of management (long-term relationships, investment in human capital, heavy R&D) with the economic environment has been far better than that of the British model. The question now is which is best suited to the quickfire, entrepreneurial Internet era.

This is where the British model, with its 'flexible' workforce, is supposed to come into its own. But the outcome is not a foregone conclusion. For example, between the trumpeted Anglo-Saxon facility to hire and fire and the Continental ability to deploy well-educated workpeople to a number of different jobs, I know which I'd bet on.

The roaring success of Germany's Neue Markt; the re-emergence of Sweden as an economic force; and the vibrancy of the Nordic start-up scene suggest it may be more productive to inject Anglo-Saxon enterprise into an efficient Rhine-type infrastructure than the reverse.

As for other reasons why the Anglo-Saxon management model should seem to carry all before it, two more cynical ones come to mind. One is the freedom it gives chief executives to pay themselves what they want. The second is a brilliant sales job. Under scrutiny, the model isn't so much Anglo-Saxon as US, not so much US as Wasp.

As a recent study concluded, management culture and ideology are 'dominated by services offered by a few consulting firms, a few management books, a few business magazines, and a few management development programmes,' almost all originating from Boston.

There's nothing resembling this concentration anywhere else, and not the least of its skills is its ability to win over anxious chief executives. But the fact that the product sells doesn't necessarily mean it is right or even good.

In management, as in any field, there is virtue in plurality - indeed, diversity could be one of Europe's most important business assets. In the marketplace of ideas, Europe has badly needed a forum in which to develop its own distinctive theories to answer the case made so trenchantly by Campbell. The EBF has a long way to go before it becomes a rival to the Sloan Management Review or HBR, but it is a step in the right direction. Let the debate continue.

webTitle: How to prepare for a holiday

fields.headline: How to prepare for a holiday
fields.trailText: 1. Understand that a holiday can be a terrible psychological ordeal for workaholics. Used to feeling indispensable and responding to deadlines and crises, you can get depressed at the apparently aimless projects of enjoying yourself or walking in beautiful countryside. And holidays are a danger point for many families, who experience far more friction when they spend these supposedly happy times together.
fields.body:
1. Understand that a holiday can be a terrible psychological ordeal for workaholics. Used to feeling indispensable and responding to deadlines and crises, you can get depressed at the apparently aimless projects of enjoying yourself or walking in beautiful countryside. And holidays are a danger point for many families, who experience far more friction when they spend these supposedly happy times together.

2. Expect some degree of depression or a minor ailment such as a cold if you have been pushing yourself too hard. Your body may take advantage of this time off to take a proper rest.

3. Don't encourage your colleagues to bitch about you in your absence by leaving a series of unexpected tasks and catastrophes to deal with. Human nature is such that even the most popular people get blamed by colleagues when they are away for errors totally unconnected with them. If you work with incompetents, make sure you leave written notes (and keep copies) about what to do when you are away.

4. Try not to take your laptop and mobile to the beach with you. You may fall into the group of driven people who, according to psychologist Professor Cary Cooper, love to work and play at the same time. 'Because they have an infrastructure around them - the mobile and the laptop - they can relax and work at the same time. But if it interferes with your significant others on holiday, it's bad.'

5. Understand that colleagues left behind compare you with the people who stand in for you. If you rule with a rod of iron, there will be sustained celebrations. Even if you are popular, expect some new approach to arise which works better than your way of doing things.

6. Appreciate the sad truth that cowardly bosses often sack people when they are out of the workplace. The holiday season is an ideal firing time because they don't have to look you in the eye. It was no coincidence that Mikhail Gorbachev was toppled when he was at his country cottage in August. Make preparations: take home copies of useful memos, buttress your relationships with allies and hone your contacts list.

webTitle: Can they limit when I take my holidays?

fields.headline: Can they limit when I take my holidays?
fields.trailText: My employers have very tight rules on the carrying over of holiday from one year to the next. The year runs to the end of March - and we can then take just five days over, but they must be used or lost by the end of May. Are they allowed to do this?
fields.body:
My employers have very tight rules on the carrying over of holiday from one year to the next. The year runs to the end of March - and we can then take just five days over, but they must be used or lost by the end of May. Are they allowed to do this?

Basically, yes, they can. The terms should be laid out in your contract of employment - or in some other memo from, or agreement with, your managers or personnel department.

Research from Industrial Relations Services shows that 41 per cent of employers currently operate this type of rule. But organisations have become far more flexible over the last decade. In 1989, about 75 per cent of employers had this kind of stipulation. Rules are now more likely to be found in the manufacturing sector - where two-thirds of them work in this way. This is, presumably, to maintain plant efficiency.

The main wrinkle here is the Working Time Regulations 1998, which require employees to be given a minimum of 20 days paid holiday a year. Bosses are, therefore, responsible for ensuring that their staff are in a position to take their holidays. The statutory leave entitlement cannot be replaced by payment in lieu.There is nothing in the rules to prevent workaholics sacrificing the time off.

 Statistics from the IRS Employment Review

Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Paperless banking offers rich rewards
fields.standfirst: Higher interest is one reason why thousands like to bank by PC, says  Rachel Fixsen
fields.trailText: From NatWest to Smile, banks are making their services available on the Internet, and new legislation removing the need for written signatures could soon cut out paperwork altogether.
fields.body:
Every major bank in the UK is taking steps into cyberspace. From NatWest to Smile, banks are making their services available on the Internet, and new legislation removing the need for written signatures could soon cut out paperwork altogether.

High-street banks such as Barclays, NatWest and LloydsTSB now have websites where customers can perform a variety of banking tasks, including checking account balances and transferring funds from one account to another.

The new electronic communications channel has proved popular with customers. So far, just over 800,000 customers have signed up for Barclays' online banking service, and this number is growing at around 4,000 a day.

There are now three banks operating in the UK which are accessed almost exclusively through the Internet - Prudential subsidiary Egg, Spanish-owned First-e and Smile, a subsidiary of the Co-operative Bank. All three run savings accounts which pay competitive rates of interest, but so far only Smile is offering a current account as well. First-e says it plans to introduce current accounts for UK customers by the end of June.

So what are the advantages of Internet banking? Firstly, pure Internet banks tend to pay much higher rates of interest. The cost of running an Internet-based bank is much less than that of a conventional bank - it does not have to establish expensive branches or hire the thousands of staff to run them. According to Smile spokesman Dave Smith, the infrastructure costs of running an Internet bank are about a tenth of those of a conventional branch-based bank, and these savings can be passed on to customers.

While branch-based current accounts pay a pittance in interest on credit balances, if they pay anything at all, Smile is offering 4.85 per cent gross on current account credit balances. The bank also offers a savings account paying 6 per cent gross (if you hold a Smile current account), and a mini cash Isa paying 7.25 per cent gross.

First-e offers an instant access savings account through its website: this pays 6.81 per cent interest on balances as small as £1. However, as a foreign bank based in Dublin, it pays interest gross, which means the customer is responsible for paying income tax.

Secondly, online banking is very convenient. You can pay your bills at any time of the day or night. You also have access to statements which are right up to date.

Although it is now possible for just about every banking transaction to be conducted entirely over the Internet, to comply with EU regulations, written signatures are still required when opening an account or applying for credit facilities. But the Electronic Communications Bill, expected to get royal assent this month, will give electronic signatures legal status, paving the way for entirely paperless banking.

However, the number of people in the UK who can actually use any of these services is still relatively low. Just 6 million adults now have access to the Internet through their PCs. This is why the banks are now making moves into digital television, forging deals with satellite and cable TV companies to offer interactive services through television sets.

HSBC forecasts that 71 per cent of retail banks will either offer interactive TV banking within the next six months or are negotiating with digital providers to develop such products.

The market now opening up to banks is far wider than PC banking, with predictions that within three years 26 million adults in the UK will be able to carry out financial transactions via television.

Smile's better for a busy broker

It was the convenience of online banking that appealed to Gill Henry. As business development manager for a London-based mortgage broker, she just didn't have time to keep visiting her bank.

'I use online banking all the time,' says Gill, from Islington. 'Work is very hectic, and I don't get the chance to pop out at lunchtime.'

Having used the Internet to access her Nationwide current account for about a year, Henry decided six months ago to apply for a credit card with new Internet-only bank Smile.

She admits it was the catchy advertisements that originally lured her to Smile. But once she had applied for the card, she was surprised how simple the whole process was. It took two minutes to get an answer to her application, and a credit agreement was posted for her to sign.

Having access to up-to-date statements at any time gives you more control over your finances, she says. 'You always know what you've got in your account.' Henry doesn't share the frequent impression that online banking is too impersonal, although she says there are certain matters she would want to discuss face to face.

She now does most of her banking from her desk at work, where she has access to the Internet. But she also has a laptop computer, giving her access from home.

fields.headline: Dress (down) for success
fields.standfirst: The office suit has had its day, reports  Alexander Garrett
fields.trailText: New economy, new wardrobe. The hype surrounding e-commerce and technology companies in recent months has unleashed a stampede to throw away stuffy old pinstripe suits and school ties. Those most keen to be in on the act have been the City bankers, consultants and other professionals seeking to ingratiate themselves with dot.com entrepreneurs. Dress-down Fridays have become dress-down everyday, as the armies of highly-paid business advisers try to look more like hip young digerati, and gain a share of the rapidly inflating bubble of Internet-generated wealth.
fields.body:
New economy, new wardrobe. The hype surrounding e-commerce and technology companies in recent months has unleashed a stampede to throw away stuffy old pinstripe suits and school ties. Those most keen to be in on the act have been the City bankers, consultants and other professionals seeking to ingratiate themselves with dot.com entrepreneurs. Dress-down Fridays have become dress-down everyday, as the armies of highly-paid business advisers try to look more like hip young digerati, and gain a share of the rapidly inflating bubble of Internet-generated wealth.

Taken together with the decline in the sales of men's suits - outfitters such as Burton, Moss Bros and Austin Reed have all reported falling revenues - it is hard to escape the conclusion that something is changing in the way people dress for work, as rigid dress codes are thrown out of the window and workers turn up in more casual attire. What is less clear is whether this is a temporary fad, and how widely it will extend into the workplace.

City firms such as Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston have adopted a less formal dress code in recent months; and accountant Arthur Andersen announced in January its 7,000 UK staff would be free to wear whatever they wanted - within reason. Paul Clark, Andersen's spokesman, says: 'We thought our people would think better and work better if they felt more comfortable with what they were wearing.'

Since the new policy was introduced, he says, around 50 per cent of staff have continued to wear formal suits, while the rest have opted for a more casual look. If an employee has a meeting with a client, they are expected to wear what they consider appropriate, he says, and the company has the confidence that they will judge wisely.

The laissez faire approach to dress at Andersen was introduced partly at the prompting of its corporate identity consultant, Enterprise IG, whose sales and marketing director Simon Williams says it is not a PR gesture. 'It's something the staff have asked for, and they think it's absolutely fantastic,' he says. He believes that the move to more casual attire is being driven by people working for global businesses, who are rejecting the formal dress of their own country in favour of a more relaxed, international look.

Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, has his own theory about how the move to casual work dress has come about. 'There are people working in consultancies and technology businesses who want to emulate the look of the whiz-kid American businessman. What they don't realise is that Americans have their own uniform; it's not pinstripe suits, but it's brown trousers, blazer, button-down shirt and striped tie.'

He says that in the UK, the suit and tie has become endangered because it is identified with the Old Economy, and nobody wants to be seen as out of touch. But it remains to be seen whether the more casual look - 'smart casual' as it is often described - will percolate out to the workplace as a whole.

Even if open-necked shirts and polo-necked sweaters ever catch on with middle management, Cooper believes that retailers and banks will be reluctant to allow their customer-facing staff to adopt such casual garb. 'I think the management will worry that some of the people won't get it right,' he says.

And there is scepticism about dressing down from other quarters. Johnnie Boden, former City banker and founder of the Boden mail order catalogue, says: 'Men are fundamentally pretty unimaginative creatures. For years they thought they were enslaved to dull suits, but now they are facing this great conundrum: what to wear?'

And Hugh Holland, managing director of Saville Row tailor Kilgour French & Stanbury, says: 'A suit is designed to enhance your good parts, and hide your bad parts. Casual clothing is non-structural; if you're a fat slob, then you look like a fat slob when you wear it.'

He believes that buyers of tailored suits will continue to want to look smart, and thinks the decline in sales of ready-to-wear suits has as much to do with post-millennial angst and the weaker stock market as it has to do with the New Economy.

On one thing, all are agreed: talk of a new dress code is basically a Man Thing. 'There was a period when women first entered men's jobs when they wore pinstripe suits,' says Cooper. 'Then they entered a phase when they simply wore what was appropriate. Women have always dressed for the occasion, and they've always been more socially sensitive and adaptable.'

Johnnie Boden agrees that women have long shaken off the shackles of formal dress at work, but he predicts that for men, flirting with casual garb may be a short-lived affair. 'In some of these companies, you will find that somebody will make a complete horlicks of it, get it completely wrong, and then they'll say: let's go back to wearing suits.'

Style counsel: How to go casual without looking naff

Don't confuse casual with scruffy. A pair of jeans with fraying knees or an unironed shirt will simply make you look like the office scarecrow, and will tell colleagues that, at heart, you're just a slob.

Don't wear a tie with jeans or combat trousers. Some men think this is dressing down; but actually you'll look like a stiff-neck desperately trying to look relaxed.

Don't rely on designer labels. It'll cost you a small fortune, and is no substitute for developing you own style. Besides, half your colleagues will probably be none the wiser.

Don't dress too flamboyantly. The object is to look well-groomed and relaxed, but efficient and worthy of respect. If you turn up decked from head to toe in silver lamé, people will assume you've come straight from a night out on the tiles at Annabel's.

Do choose clothes that flatter your figure. Suits - both men's and women's - are designed to do just that, while jeans and T-shirts can show your contours at their worst.

Do spend money on your dress-down kit. If you're going to wear it for a good proportion of your working life, you need to invest. It's no use trying to make your weekend garb last twice as long.

Do wear a suit without a tie. A lounge suit - not double-breasted - with a plain cotton shirt can make men look extremely cool.

Do focus on accessories. A pair of smart loafers, or a Dunhill briefcase, can be a subtle way of telling the world that, for all your casual attire, you are to be taken seriously.

webTitle: Pile them high, sell them cheap

fields.headline: Pile them high, sell them cheap
fields.standfirst: Supermarkets are coming to a fund near you,  Jamie Doward reports
fields.trailText: The supermarket war is hotting up. But we are not talking high streets and baked beans: this time it's the investment fund supermarkets which are scrabbling to establish pole position in the rapidly growing online investment market.
fields.body:
The supermarket war is hotting up. But we are not talking high streets and baked beans: this time it's the investment fund supermarkets which are scrabbling to establish pole position in the rapidly growing online investment market.

Fund investors are being promised a revolution. At the click of a button, they will have access, not only to the fund products of 160 or more UK investment groups, but to authorised funds worldwide.

Investors will be able to get information on funds, compare performances, buy and sell funds and then receive one consolidated statement across all their holdings. Instead of committing their annual £7,000 ISA entitlement to one provider, they will be able to spread their ISA investment across funds from different managers.

And, like the high street, the fund supermarket will 'pile it high and sell it cheap'. Experience from the United States, where the concept has operated for years, shows that under consumer pressure, the front end loads on funds - the initial charges from 3.5 per cent to 5 per cent or more - tend to narrow and even disappear once funds start appearing on supermarket shelves.

It's early days but battle lines are being drawn. Egg was the first into the supermarket arena, offering a choice of 169 funds from 12 management groups. Now in the process of flotation, marketing director John Casey couldn't reveal much about future plans, but said that Egg is in the process of taking on additional funds, and extending the range to non-UK based managers.

Fidelity Investments, the biggest player in the US supermarket business with 4,100 funds and assets of more than $175 billion, will launch its UK investment supermarket (ISM) to existing online investors in June.

Executive director Ann Davis wouldn't give the names of the groups whose funds will be available on the Fidelity shelves, but they will include some of the bigger names in the ISA market and some 300 funds, providing a fair degree of choice.

Asked why competitor groups would want to sell via Fidelity's supermarket, Davis say 'the whole nature of distribution channels is changing. There are so many different ways people can invest, and companies just see this as another way of selling funds'. Fidelity sold funds worth around £40 million online in the last ISA season, and currently transacts between 10-15 per cent of its business this way. 'The change is already happening, regardless of fund supermarkets,' she says.

Mike Attree, e-commerce manager at discount brokers TQ Direct sees a similar pattern. 'Last ISA season we only had six online ISA providers but people were narrowing their selection to just those six simply because it was the easiest way to deal.' On the face of it, discount brokers - execution only brokers which sell unit trusts and ISAs, rebating part or all of the initial commission to customers - could be casualties in the supermarket war. Their big selling point is how much cheaper it is to buy funds through them. Once the supermarkets get going however, this edge could disappear.

Attree's view is that if you can't beat them, join them. TQ Direct is setting up its own supermarket which should be up and running this autumn. 'We already have the relationships with the groups and we are an established player with a percentage of the market,' he says.

'Investors shopping purely on price might still go to a discount broker,' says Davis. 'We aim to be competitive, but we may not be the cheapest.' She sees a number of different types of supermarket springing up in the UK whereas in the US, Fidelity and Charles Schwab have carved up the market between them. She points to the fact that the Fidelity route provides IFAs with access to its supermarket, whereas the Egg version is just for customers who deal direct.

One way that supermarkets may appear is via FundsHub, a Chase Manhattan/Investia joint venture which provides the technology to enable anyone to set up their own supermarket. The first FundsHub supermarket should be up and running by September, roughly the same time that Schwab is planning to launch its UK fund supermarket. Schwab offers around 1,500 no-load funds in the US, but will start in the UK, on a 'fairly modest scale, concentrating on no-load and low-load funds,' says spokeswoman Jane Drew.

The supermarket is coming and buying funds may never be the same.'This is good news for the consumer,' says Attree. 'Investors will find it easier to deal and will get funds cheaper.'

fields.headline: Good home sought
fields.standfirst: Keep your savings options open to take advantage of rate rises, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Savers looking for the best 'home' for their money will be reviewing the situation after base rates were kept on hold at 6 per cent last Thursday.
fields.body:
Savers looking for the best 'home' for their money will be reviewing the situation after base rates were kept on hold at 6 per cent last Thursday.

With the average instant access account paying 1.72 per cent, according to research organisation MoneyFacts, you need to box clever if you want your savings to work for you. Many strategies are open to savers now, but the most important aspects for them to consider are the range of products and their own particular circumstances.

On products, the market is far more varied than it was even two years ago. At the more cautious end of the market are National Savings, guaranteed income bonds, fixed rates and trackers, which guarantee to offer no less than a certain amount below the base rate. Riskier, less predictable accounts are the variable-rate accounts, some of which are operated via the Internet or by post.

Financial advisers are warning against buying National Savings at the moment - 'Rates are appalling,' says Colin Jackson of Baronworth - and also against locking into fixes because of an expected rate rise in the next few months.

'We're not quite at the top yet,' says Janine Starks of Chase de Vere. 'We could have another couple of rises by the end of the year. Being in a variable-rate account is a good place to be.'

Jackson advises smaller savers not to 'lock in for more than one or two years'. 'We'll see an interest rate increase of at least 0.25 or 0.5 per cent by the end of the year,' he said.

Many fixed-rate products, including guaranteed interest-rate bonds (GIBs) and National Savings, are offering lower rates over five years than over one or two years, a strong indication that the market expects interest rates to rise and fall slightly in that period. Chase de Vere warns savers looking for guarantees that many banks and building societies are offering guarantees with an attractive-sounding bonus, but often the bonus disappears in a short time.

Northern Rock, for example, has a 0.75 per cent bonus for £10,000 deposits on its 90-day notice account; this disappears on 1 October. Bristol & West's Call One Postal 50 account has a lower guarantee - that the rate will not go more than 0.33 per cent lower than base, but that lasts until 5 May 2004. The rate being paid now is 5.92 per cent.

fields.headline: Standard mailings battle
fields.trailText: Fred Woollard, the Monaco-based investor behind the campaign to float Standard Life, asked the insurer to print and distribute his arguments in favour of demutualisation with their mailings to members.
fields.body:
Fred Woollard, the Monaco-based investor behind the campaign to float Standard Life, asked the insurer to print and distribute his arguments in favour of demutualisation with their mailings to members.

The insurer has rejected his request but has agreed to include a 500-word statement putting his case in its document, which will be mailed to members later this month.

Woollard's request to Standard Life was based on the insurer's own Mori opinion poll. This found that 25 per cent of members would vote for demutualisation; 23 per cent said they would say no. More than half either did not know or would not vote.

'Given that it is the policyholders' money, not the company's, that is being used, it seemed wrong to spend that money in a manner which the majority of policyholders disagreed with,' said Woollard. 'At the minimum, we should get access to policyholders and equal funding to put our arguments.'

Woollard cannot carry out his own mailing because Standard is prevented by the Data Protection Act from releasing names and addresses of its policyholders.

Standard's mailing is expected to be at least 20 pages long, and Woollard was asking for an equal number of pages to set out his case. That would have doubled the cost, expected to run to several million pounds.

Standard's case for preserving its mutual status suffered a setback last week when Friends Provident, one of the few remaining large mutuals, said it was to float on the stock exchange.

Friends Provident has been under attack from carpetbaggers who mounted a demutualisation campaign via the Internet, but has taken the decision on its own initiative rather than waiting until a members' vote forces its hand.

webTitle: It can still pay to ride the technology tiger

fields.headline: It can still pay to ride the technology tiger
fields.standfirst: Take a look at the specialist funds, writes  Alexander Garrett
fields.trailText: Most independent advisers agree that technology remains one of the best prospects for long-term investment.
fields.body:
For all their well-honed marketing skills, the money managers at Jupiter Asset Management would have to concede that the birth of their baby, Jupiter Global Technology unit trust, has not gone entirely to plan. The fund was launched on 1 March, just weeks before technology stocks began to tumble. Investors, who put £132 million into the issue, saw the value of stocks fall from a starting price of 50p to 35p at the end of last week.

Yet most independent advisers agree that technology remains one of the best prospects for long-term investment. Brian Ashford-Russell, head of the technology team at Henderson Investors, which manages the best-selling Henderson Global Technology unit trust, says the fund - which can be held in an Isa - fell by 35 per cent from its peak price, but has come back to within 20 per cent of that peak. Investors who bought as recently as October are still looking at a gain of almost 100 per cent.

Ashford-Russell says it would be premature to rule out further falls in technology shares, and admits prices for some stocks in particular had got out of hand. 'The shares that had risen fastest fell the most sharply.' But he says US technology stocks have already made a better recovery than their European counterparts, and he is planning to increase his North American holdings to about 60 per cent of the fund.

First-quarter results from some US technology companies - especially cyclical companies such as semiconductor manufacturers - have been 'extraordinarily' strong, says Ashford-Russell, providing a good outlook for the year. But he cautions against expecting a repeat of 1999's dazzling performance, when £100 invested in January grew to £282 by December. 'Last year was an aberration. Investors should really be looking for percentage returns in the low- to mid-twenties,' he says.

Henderson Global Technology and Aberdeen Technology were both set up in the early Eighties and are the longest-running technology funds. But there has been a spate of launches in recent months from managers such as Jupiter, M&G, Fidelity and Gartmore. For investors, what was once a fairly simple choice has become more complicated.

Funds such as Framlington's NetNet and Sarasin's Webs@r offer specific exposure to the Internet, while Close Brothers offers a tracker fund for the UK's new TechMark index.

Generally speaking, these funds have fared worse in the recent correction than globally focused technology funds, which usually have a higher exposure in North America. Mark Dampier, head of investment at IFA Hargreaves Lansdown, says: 'In the UK and Europe, technology shares are probably more overvalued. There is far less supply, but the same level of demand.'

Dampier singles out Aberdeen Technology as a fund which has shown consistent commitment to investment in the sector over many years, and has not allowed a fund manager to dent its performance. But he thinks Jupiter's new fund should not be written off. 'I'd want to wait another month to see how well they're really doing,' he says.

Some investors in technology funds rushed to cancel their cheques when the market fell at the beginning of April, but Dampier believes they were shortsighted. He advocates that those considering an investment now should drip their money in, and take advantage of any further price falls to increase their holding.

The flood of new technology funds may well slow to a trickle now that the sector has taken a knock. But few advisers will be telling their clients to sell their investments, and after years in the wilderness, technology has put itself on the UK investing map. Investors should, however, be wary of becoming overexposed.

Brian Ashford-Russell, head of the technology team at Henderson Investors, which manages the best-selling Henderson Global Technology unit trust, says the fund - which can be held in an Isa - fell by 35 per cent from its peak price, but has come back to within 20 per cent of that peak. Investors who bought as recently as October are still looking at a gain of almost 100 per cent. Ashford-Russell says it would be premature to rule out further falls in technology shares, and admits prices for some stocks in particular had got out of hand. 'The shares that had risen fastest fell the most sharply.' But he says US technology stocks have already made a better recovery than their European counterparts, and he is planning to increase his North American holdings to about 60 per cent of the fund. First-quarter results from some US technology companies - especially cyclical companies such as semiconductor manufacturers - have been 'extraordinarily' strong, says Ashford-Russell, providing a good outlook for the year. But he cautions against expecting a repeat of 1999's dazzling performance, when £100 invested in January grew to £282 by December. 'Last year was an aberration. Investors should really be looking for percentage returns in the low- to mid-twenties,' he says. Henderson Global Technology and Aberdeen Technology were both set up in the early Eighties and are the longest-running technology funds. But there has been a spate of launches in recent months from managers such as Jupiter, M&G, Fidelity and Gartmore. For investors, what was once a fairly simple choice has become more complicated. Funds such as Framlington's NetNet and Sarasin's Webs@r offer specific exposure to the Internet, while Close Brothers offers a tracker fund for the UK's new TechMark index. Generally speaking, these funds have fared worse in the recent correction than globally focused technology funds, which usually have a higher exposure in North America. Mark Dampier, head of investment at IFA Hargreaves Lansdown, says: 'In the UK and Europe, technology shares are probably more overvalued. There is far less supply, but the same level of demand.' Dampier singles out Aberdeen Technology as a fund which has shown consistent commitment to investment in the sector over many years, and has not allowed a fund manager to dent its performance. But he thinks Jupiter's new fund should not be written off. 'I'd want to wait another month to see how well they're really doing,' he says. Some investors in technology funds rushed to cancel their cheques when the market fell at the beginning of April, but Dampier believes they were shortsighted. He advocates that those considering an investment now should drip their money in, and take advantage of any further price falls to increase their holding. The flood of new technology funds may well slow to a trickle now that the sector has taken a knock. But few advisers will be telling their clients to sell their investments, and after years in the wilderness, technology has put itself on the UK investing map. Investors should, however, be wary of becoming overexposed.

webTitle: Five interview blunders which will blow your chances of the jackpot

fields.headline: Five interview blunders which will blow your chances of the jackpot
fields.standfirst: And you won't be able to phone a friend to help you out
fields.trailText: Many graduates looking for their first job unwittingly sabotage their chances by making common, but easily avoidable, interview mistakes. They will agonise over their CVs and covering letters but rehearse only minutes for what arguably is the most vital step in the whole job hunting process.
fields.body:
Many graduates looking for their first job unwittingly sabotage their chances by making common, but easily avoidable, interview mistakes. They will agonise over their CVs and covering letters but rehearse only minutes for what arguably is the most vital step in the whole job hunting process.

Here are five common interviewing blunders that can cost you the job:

1 . Arrive unprepared

Before setting foot in the company's offices, be sure you're well-versed in as many of the firm's products or services as possible. Try to make sure you can discuss knowledgeably how your skills and background will mesh with those of the company. And if you have a portfolio or other body of work which might strengthen your case, bring it too.

Research - or, rather, the information that research unearths - gives you the edge in an interview. It can affirm your interest in a company or position and it can help you sell yourself as a qualified applicant. With background information at your disposal, you can more easily draw parallels to connect your own experience and skills with what you know the employer needs.

Take advantage of libraries, bookstores, university career services and the internet. Each resource can also be a useful way to find company information, either from companies' websites, or from third party research.

2 . Wear the wrong clothes

No matter what the corporate culture is - whether khakis and polo shirts or three-piece suits - you should still dress professionally for that first interview. Simple, no-frills business attire for both men and women are still the standard. No heavy fragrances, loud clothes or flashy jewellery.

Dress smartly and comfortably. You will be judged in some respects by what you wear. When in doubt, dress conservatively.

3 . Talk too much Some graduates are so eager to impress that they scarcely allow questions to be asked. You wouldn't be in the interviewer's office if you hadn't already demonstrated your appeal. Use the actual interview to impress the interviewer with your listening skills, and then thoughtfully lay out why you'll be an asset to the company.

Remember to listen - communication is a two-way street. If you are talking too much, you will probably miss cues concerning what the interviewer feels is important.

Reflect before answering a difficult question. If you are unsure how to answer a question, you might reply with another question. For example, if the interviewer asks you what salary you expect, try answering by saying "That is a good question. What are you planning to pay your best candidate?"

4 . Undervalue or overvalue yourself

The first won't necessarily cost you the job, but the second definitely could. In either case, it pays not to bring up salaries too early, if at all, in the first interview. Once the company has made its offer, then it's appropriate to ask for between 10 and 20% more than that, depending partly on what other offers you've received. If you're right for the job, you'll get a reasonable offer.

If you're not in a position to showcase a portfolio of any kind, bring tangible experience to the table. For example, many employers now use behavioural interviewing techniques - they believe that past behaviour is a likely indicator of future behaviour. So if you're asked about a general skill, provide a specific example to help you take advantage of the interviewer's expectations.

5 . Act desperate for the job

Even if you've been on the job market for some time, the last thing most hiring managers want is someone who looks too eager. If you've been asked in for an interview, then the company believes you have something to offer because of your skills and experience.

Don't derail that by acting too eager or nervous, or by asking questions such as, "When would you want me to start?" Instead, appear confident, relaxed and in control.

Why should you get the job? You have to believe you are the best person for the job, or you won't convince anyone else. Granted, you may not have all the necessary experience, but you got into the interview, didn't you?

webTitle: How to ... right a wrong at work

fields.headline: How to ... right a wrong at work
fields.standfirst: Have you ever been accused of a crime you did not commit?
fields.trailText: Take a close look at your contract of employment and you will see that you can be sacked for anything under the guise of gross misconduct. But what happens if you are entirely innocent?
fields.body:
Take a close look at your contract of employment and you will see that you can be sacked for anything under the guise of gross misconduct. But what happens if you are entirely innocent?

When maths teacher Adrian Wells described to a conference how his career was almost ruined by a pupil who had falsely claimed he had hit him, he was very close to tears. Although the boy later withdrew the allegation, the teacher from Aberystwyth went through what he described as "three months of self-doubt that left my self-confidence shattered" - and he had been able to clear his name.

Such accusations against teachers are all too common. But false and even malicious claims made by colleagues are also on the increase in the wider workplace.

Read any national newspaper and it's not hard to find a report of a company being taken to an industrial tribunal by a wronged employee - the only question is, how do you stop it getting to that stage?

According to most falsely-accused employees, their first reaction is "I can't believe this is happening to me" - although it's quickly followed by deep unease when they realise how potentially serious the charges are.

Wells was advised to write a detailed account of what had happened immediately after the allegation was made and was only allowed to continue working because of the headmaster's speed in amassing the evidence.

Although it was not the first allegation the boy had made, Wells was still put through the "trauma" of being interviewed by the police, only for the case to be dropped. Another teacher from Gwent was not so lucky and was suspended for six months after a similar allegation. He said he was left in an isolated "personal agony" - again the allegation was withdrawn.

Another man who received the backing of his managers is Ben*. Ben is currently in the process of being taken to an industrial tribunal by a black woman claiming he discriminated against her on grounds of race. So sensitive is he about the accusation that he will only describe himself as "a manager" and many of his friends have no idea what he is going through.

While he knows he has been fortunate that his managers have stood by him and that he is innocent of the charge, he still describes the experience as one of the "most stressful of his life".

Part of the problem is that such proceedings can take months to be finalised and if you've been suspended this can make the waiting even more stressful. Most companies immediately suspend staff suspected of any wrong-doing pending the inquiry.

James * was suspended by NatWest Bank after throwing a punch at a colleague. He would have been out for gross misconduct, but according to Martin Bloore of the Banking Insurance & Finance Union there were extenuating circumstances and he kept his job.

James was working in a call centre to which he had been transferred after an office near to his home was closed. Despite a long journey to work, he was recorded taking more calls than his colleagues in what was described as a very busy department.

Despite complaining to managers that he was over-worked and increasingly stressed, the matter was not addressed. After a seemingly trivial comment from a colleague, he snapped and punched one of his best friends.

Although he was suspended for two months, the union argued that the management's failure to address the issues had indirectly led to the fight.

Bloore maintains it was James's initial approach to his managers that resulted in his re-instatement. It also helped that the union was there to guide James through the procedure.

If you don't remember anything else ...

According to Denis Murphy, who used to sit on the East London Industrial Tribunal, the first thing you should do if accused of misconduct is to examine the small print of your company's disciplinary procedure.

"All companies will have a code that will include a right of appeal and it's important to follow it to the letter. Employees are usually allowed to be accompanied by a union official or a colleague at any meetings, and again, you should conduct yourself exactly as it is outlined in the company's document." Murphy says the way that the procedure is followed is often as important as the alleged offence as most tribunal decisions rest on whether the procedure was adhered to correctly.

Although he maintains the employee should always try to resolve the issue before it gets to a tribunal, Murphy says staff who feel they have been genuinely mistreated should not be afraid to go to arbitration to resolve the matter.

"All the tribunal will decide is whether the firm's behaviour was that of a reasonable employer - and then award accordingly," he says.

*Ben and James are aliases

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to granting and receiving office favours

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to granting and receiving office favours
fields.trailText: A. Open invitation | B. Exchange rates | C. Trading partners
fields.body:
A. Open invitation

Would you do me a favour? How do you normally react to this innocuous but potentially open-ended question? Be wary of giving an enthusiastic yes - that makes it difficult to say no later. Nobody expects commitment at this stage, but if you're rash enough to give one in an effort to please, you could end up in an awkward position. Initial refusal or suspicion could result in a lost opportunity. The safest response is a grunt; it puts the onus firmly back on the asker.

B. Exchange rates

Favours are the currency of co-operation and casual though they may seem, rates are carefully watched, with credits and debits subtly changing the balance of power in a relationship. To ask puts you in debt; to bestow gives you the upper hand - temporarily. Making someone so indebted they can never repay turns gratitude to resentment. Unreturned favours are rarely forgotten and once you have a dodgy credit rating it's hard to get the services you need. Equilibrium is all.

C. Trading partners

Be choosy about trading partners. Not everyone will share your sense of moral decency. Save your generosity for like-minded individuals. Be wary of those who disguise requests as opportunities you'll benefit from. Shun anyone who believes allowing you to do something for them is a privilege, avoid the pathetically grateful and be circumspect about dispensing favours not asked for. Chances are they'll be seen as interference rather than assistance.

webTitle: Help: I'm afraid of letting go!

fields.headline: Help: I'm afraid of letting go!
fields.standfirst: I've recently been promoted but find it impossible to give up doing most of the tasks that used to be my responsibility. It's more than I can cope with but there's no one else who can do them properly. Nick R, database manager, Preston.
fields.trailText: I've recently been promoted but find it impossible to give up doing most of the tasks that used to be my responsibility.
fields.body:
There are bound to be others who can do as good a job as you did, but they won't even try if you exude distrust or contempt. Your current level of competence doubtless owes much to those who provided encouragement whilst tolerating mistakes.

A telling measure of managerial skill is how well you delegate. Mastering the art of redistributing work also provides the passport to an easier life. Although it's hard to stand back and watch someone stumble over seemingly easy tasks, you can't hold on to everything.

Once a workload reaches saturation point your performance suffers and you start making mistakes. Being responsible for everything and everyone is not sustainable - let go. Managing people effectively means recognising what each can do and assigning tasks accordingly.

The simplest way to encourage confidence and competence in others is to get off their backs. Nurture motivation through training, moral support and financial incentives. Accept others have the ability to achieve results even when their methods are different from yours.

Allow for mistakes and false starts - you were a learner once too. Be clear about levels of autonomy and establish boundaries between their and your responsibilities. Do a bit of monitoring and feedback - then sit back and feel your blood pressure drop.

Contact Irene Krechowiecka at ijk@excite.com

webTitle: Agents of influence? Oh behave yourself! But exchange programmes could be just a cover

fields.headline: Agents of influence? Oh behave yourself! But exchange programmes could be just a cover
fields.trailText: Imagine spending a year or two after university working for a foreign government. You have a relatively undemanding job which sits well on a CV, a good salary with plenty of time off for sightseeing, and you have all your visa and accommodation worries taken care of. All you are expected to do in return is to help out as an assistant in the state's secondary schools, before returning home to start your real career.
fields.body:
Imagine spending a year or two after university working for a foreign government. You have a relatively undemanding job which sits well on a CV, a good salary with plenty of time off for sightseeing, and you have all your visa and accommodation worries taken care of. All you are expected to do in return is to help out as an assistant in the state's secondary schools, before returning home to start your real career.

If this were a job in the Soviet Union during the Cold War, most students might wonder about the motivation for this munificence. However, with such a scheme now the second biggest employer of UK graduates (after the UK government) it may be time to ask whether participants are aware of the possible long-term interests of their hosts.

The scheme in question is the Japan Exchange and Teaching Programme (JET) which is financed and run by the Japanese ministries of home affairs, education, and foreign affairs. Established in 1987 with 150 UK participants, JET has expanded to the point where this year it is flying out around 3,000 international graduates more than 600 from the UK).

JET sells itself to participants as an English language teaching programme, (the T part of the acronym), while the second goal is "to promote international exchange at the grass roots level by fostering ties between Japanese citizens and JET participants" (the E part of the acronym).

However, could it be that it is not merely Japan that is being internationalised in this transaction, and that it is the JETs who are being 'Japanesed'?

Some former participants question whether the Japanese government has got its stated aims the right way round.

"I don't think teaching is the primary objective of the programme at all," says Pat Quinn, a Canadian participant who left the programme in 1992 and who now works in international trade. "The teaching and the loosely defined 'internationalisation' parts of the programme were only secondary short-term objectives which gave the Japanese a reason for getting us to the country. The long-term objective was to build a group of young 'friends' for Japan who might in time become cultural, political or business leaders."

"I think it probably was initiated as a teaching programme," suggests Simon Everson, who left the programme in 1993, and who is now head of English at an independent school. "However, it may have been expanded once they saw the advantages provided by all these returning JETs. But to give the Japanese government such powers of foresight goes against everything that I saw in Japan."

Those who claim that the programme is only secondarily a teaching scheme point to three inconsistencies: first, they allege a lack of interest in employing trained teachers; secondly, they ask why grammar-translation based university entrance exams have not been changed in favour of more communicative tests; and thirdly, they wonder why JETs keen on staying in Japanese education are not allowed to renew their one-year contract more than twice.

But the Japanese Embassy denies that the back-home impact of the programme is anything more than an advantageous side-effect of what is a genuine attempt to improve English language skills in Japan.

"It is definitely for English language purposes," says Mr Tsuyoshi Enomoto, second secretary at the embassy. "The schools want to focus more on speaking and listening, so it is essential to bring native speakers in. Of course, I am happy that because of the programme many Western people have had experience of the real Japan. It is a very good opportunity for them, but also for us, to understand each other."

This official line might understate the advantages to Japan of the programme, but that needn't mean that there is anything approaching a conspiracy taking place. All governments have long been aware of the value of attracting young foreigners who return to their home countries and naturally foster ties with the country that gave them their first real experience of independence.

The British Council for example makes strenuous efforts to identify those most likely to succeed and offer them scholarships to the UK.

For a minority language nation like Japan, however, competing for young motivated talent cannot be easy. The only groups that generally want to go there in anything approaching significant numbers tend to be financiers and martial artists - and it is unlikely that these two groups are sufficiently diverse to produce many opinion formers.

Is it too fanciful, therefore, to suggest a link between the misunderstanding and negative image of Japan that was prevalent in the West during the mid-eighties and the inception and subsequent expansion of the programme since then?

Replying to this charge, the embassy points out that the reason for the expansion is simply down to demand from schools. But even if the national government is shy of acknowledging the long-term diplomatic advantages of the programme, local government in Japan seems happy to encourage it.

Sarah Collins is a recent returnee and was asked to be an official cultural envoy for her region of Japan. "Over time, I think the teaching is getting less and less crucial," she says. "There are now many Japanese teachers who have studied abroad and who have excellent language skills.

"It is the cultural exchange that is becoming more and more important, and this may turn out to be one of the most important results of the programme in the long term."

Whether or not the JETs can be called 'agents of influence' is open to debate. But whether they are termed diplomatic assets, grass roots ambassadors, official cultural envoys, or simply JET alumnae, it amounts to the same thing.

There are now a large group of professionals in a range of fields with first-hand experience of Japan. The first of the JETs are currently approaching their late thirties and are just about to enter the most influential stage of their careers. (Your correspondent is one of them.) And it may not therefore be long before the massive investment in the JET Programme starts to pay off outside Japan.
