Those who claim that the programme is only secondarily a teaching scheme point to three inconsistencies: first, they allege a lack of interest in employing trained teachers; secondly, they ask why grammar-translation based university entrance exams have not been changed in favour of more communicative tests; and thirdly, they wonder why JETs keen on staying in Japanese education are not allowed to renew their one-year contract more than twice. But the Japanese Embassy denies that the back-home impact of the programme is anything more than an advantageous side-effect of what is a genuine attempt to improve English language skills in Japan. "It is definitely for English language purposes," says Mr Tsuyoshi Enomoto, second secretary at the embassy. "The schools want to focus more on speaking and listening, so it is essential to bring native speakers in. Of course, I am happy that because of the programme many Western people have had experience of the real Japan. It is a very good opportunity for them, but also for us, to understand each other." This official line might understate the advantages to Japan of the programme, but that needn't mean that there is anything approaching a conspiracy taking place. All governments have long been aware of the value of attracting young foreigners who return to their home countries and naturally foster ties with the country that gave them their first real experience of independence. The British Council for example makes strenuous efforts to identify those most likely to succeed and offer them scholarships to the UK. For a minority language nation like Japan, however, competing for young motivated talent cannot be easy. The only groups that generally want to go there in anything approaching significant numbers tend to be financiers and martial artists - and it is unlikely that these two groups are sufficiently diverse to produce many opinion formers. Is it too fanciful, therefore, to suggest a link between the misunderstanding and negative image of Japan that was prevalent in the West during the mid-eighties and the inception and subsequent expansion of the programme since then? Replying to this charge, the embassy points out that the reason for the expansion is simply down to demand from schools. But even if the national government is shy of acknowledging the long-term diplomatic advantages of the programme, local government in Japan seems happy to encourage it. Sarah Collins is a recent returnee and was asked to be an official cultural envoy for her region of Japan. "Over time, I think the teaching is getting less and less crucial," she says. "There are now many Japanese teachers who have studied abroad and who have excellent language skills. "It is the cultural exchange that is becoming more and more important, and this may turn out to be one of the most important results of the programme in the long term." Whether or not the JETs can be called 'agents of influence' is open to debate. But whether they are termed diplomatic assets, grass roots ambassadors, official cultural envoys, or simply JET alumnae, it amounts to the same thing. There are now a large group of professionals in a range of fields with first-hand experience of Japan. The first of the JETs are currently approaching their late thirties and are just about to enter the most influential stage of their careers. (Your correspondent is one of them.) And it may not therefore be long before the massive investment in the JET Programme starts to pay off outside Japan.

fields.headline: The eyes of the beholder
fields.standfirst: From porn diaries to naive nudes:  Maxim Jakubowski  conducts an erotic review
fields.trailText: From porn diaries to naive nudes: Maxim Jakubowski conducts an erotic review
fields.body:
Digital Diaries
Natacha Merritt
Taschen, £16.99, 256pp

Digital Diaries at Taschen.com

Naked London
Greg Friedler
Norton, £15.95, 160pp
Buy it at BOL

Screen Tests, Portraits, Nudes 1964-1996
Gerard Malanga
Steidel, £24.95, 192pp

Half a century ago, Anaïs Nin consigned her darkest thoughts and obsessions to her diaries (and her jolly fantasies of unbridled sexuality to her erotic stories). Her contemporary counterpart is Natacha Merritt, whose Digital Diaries capture her life on digital camera, storing pixels of a explicit nature on computer disks for posterity.

Born in 1977 and growing up in San Francisco in a household she now describes as "very unrestrictive", she followed her childhood dream of becoming a lawyer and studied at the Sorbonne in Paris before quickly dropping out when she acquired her first digital camera. Spotted on the internet by famous New York fetish photographer Eric Kroll, Merritt was brought to the attention of Benedikt Taschen, whose publishing house has constantly challenged erotic taboos, with books by Roy Stuart, Elmer Batters, Nobuyoshi Araki, Charles Gatewood and other visual pirates of the world of erotica.

Her first book - bold, dark, disturbing and provocative - is unlike any other. Her unposed photographs of herself and sexual partners in repose and at play provide a fascinating insight into the mind of a woman whose life is captured wholesale by the camera. As Merritt herself puts it, "All my thoughts and feelings, I used to write down. As soon as I had a camera, I stopped writing and recorded my thoughts and feelings with photographs."

The portfolio covers six years of Merritt's love life, from orgasm with her first lover at 15 via unbridled S&M images of ropes across bare bodies to more recent encounters of a similarly in-your-face nature that somehow never lose their innocence. Like Cindy Sherman, Merritt is both the subject and the observer of her life, but her gaze is unfailingly sexual and even crude. A slim, dark-haired girl with kiss-me-sadly eyes, she appears to roam the anonymous hotel rooms of American cities on an unending quest for the ultimate in self-revelation, haphazardly framing her body and those of her fleeting lovers at arm's length; seizing the sexual moment in a frenzy of amatory and photographic improvisation.

There is beauty here as well as pornography, and a distinct female voice that takes candid self-revelation to new heights of wonderful indecency. The accumulation of isolated body parts, intricately dishevelled limbs, impersonal hotel bathrooms, beds and decor and indiscreet apertures holds a hypnotic fascination for the onlooker, but it is the eyes of Merritt and her partners in voyeurism that will stay with me for a long time - intangible, electronic digital images which lived as a series of 0s and 1s before they were printed out here. It makes me wonder what Sylvia Plath's diaries might have looked like if digital cameras had existed back then.

Drastically less erotic are the photos of ordinary Londoners in Greg Friedler's Naked London, which is a companion volume to the photographer's similar books on denizens of New York and Los Angeles. The book is made up of people like you and me in all our fleshly imperfections, posed artlessly against a neutral background, alternately clothed and unclothed. Fascinating for spurious sociological reasons - are all recruitment specialists similarly endowed, and how many female office workers actually shave their pudenda? - this is nonetheless a volume where the flesh is drab. The subjects are courageous in exposing their frailties and secrets, but the banality of the nudity on display here is disheartening and at times quite anti-sexual.

Gerard Malanga's Screen Tests, Portraits, Nudes 1964-1996 collects the best photography of the Andy Warhol associate, film-maker and poet. The usual suspects from the New York art scene of the last three decades all feature heavily: youthful, vital images of Sam Shepard, Patti Smith, Iggy Pop, Roman Polanski, Lou Reed and John Cage in their creative prime, captured by Malanga's artful but friendly lens, as well as memorable portraits of Charles Bukowski, Cybill Sheperd and Tennessee Williams which unfailingly capture the artistic spirit of the subjects.

But the revelation for me was the section of nudes. This is erotic photography at its very best, with little need for genital close-ups or other cliches. Mostly taken in the 1980s, Malanga's women are usually blonde, frightfully luminous and embody sexual innocence in all its splendour - long-limbed bodies and quiet beauties captured in sunlight, with every mole or minor blemish a sheer adornment. As early as 1974, the great photographer Walker Evans said that "arguably, Gerard Malanga is one of the best young American photographers". The all-too short nude section of his book reminds us of the fact. How Nabokov would have loved these women, caught like butterflies in the light of the male gaze.

webTitle: Love Poem, Flowers in the Kitchen, Going Places

fields.headline: Love Poem, Flowers in the Kitchen, Going Places
fields.trailText:
You remind me

define me

incline me...
fields.body:
Love Poem

You remind me
define me
incline me.

If you died I'd.

Flowers in the Kitchen

On buying her flowers
she said

"There's no food in the kitchen
and we can't eat flowers."

On buying her food
she said

"You don't buy flowers any more."

Going Places

Another
cigarette ash
television serial filled
advert analysing
cupboard starving
front starving
front room filling
tea slurping
mind chewing
brain burping
carpet picking
pots watching
room gleaming
toilet flushing
night,
with nothing to do

I think I'll paint roads
on my front room walls
to convince myself
that I'm going places.

fields.headline: The List
fields.trailText: Eric Hobsbawm on what the history of the new century will be about, plus Legal Blunders and The Pig: A British History
fields.body:
The New Century
Eric Hobsbawm, with Antonio Polito
(Little, Brown, £16.99)
Buy it at BOL

So, you want to know what society and politics will be like in the 21st century. Do you consult a tame pseudo-philosopher in cross-gartered New Labour stockings and learn to blabber ingratiatingly about the Third Way, or do you listen to Hobsbawm? Come on, it's not a trick question.

This excellent little book sees Hobsbawm conversing with his co-author about the state of the world today, and what historians might consider important 50 or 100 years hence. Hobsbawm's characteristic erudition and charm underwrite his bracingly provocative viewpoints on subjects ranging from the Kosovo war (the debate about its justice, Hobsbawm says, misses the point: rather than being something shockingly new, it was a last gasp of old-fashioned Western imperialism), to globalization (a global economy is nothing new; the dissolution of time and space is) and the seeming collapse of the Left (the "market-research" logic of politics adopted by Blair destroys the sphere of public debate).

Hobsbawm also mounts a spirited defence of his oft-maligned communism: "I know very well that the cause that I embraced has proved not to work. Perhaps I shouldn't have chosen it. But, on the other hand, if people don't have any ideal of a better world, then they have lost something. If the only ideal for men and women is the pursuit of personal happiness through the attainment of material assets, then humanity is a diminished species." Amen.

Legal Blunders
Geoff Tibballs
(Constable, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Only the other week I was accosted in the pub by a barrister, a perversely avid reader of this column who complained sneeringly about my habit of "reducing everything to Nietzsche". I therefore triumphantly refute him thus, with this compendium of legal incompetence, from the amusing (the judge who forgot to sentence a criminal to death) to the seriously worrying (the fitting-up of Stefan Kiszko). In her introduction, Helena Kennedy breezily admits: "The legal profession seems to be a magnet for the eccentric." I think I've proved my point.

The Pig: A British History
Julian Wiseman
(Duckworth, £12.95)
Buy it at BOL

Serious about his pigs, this Wiseman. Don't look in here, he says, for "sentimental coverage of the pig (the dreadful 'Miss Piggy', the appalling 'Babe', the ridiculous 'Tamworth Two')". Bah - as if we would. We want the facts, man: the hyper-detailed story of pig husbandry and pig-munching over the last thousand years. Should come in very useful to a select portion of the population, generously festooned as it is with meat-gain charts, comparison of pig breeds, and many luscious pictures of pigs. Look at too many, though, and you become rather uneasy. You begin to fear the pig. "They call thee mine ape, thou foaming fool, but I call thee my grunting-pig..." Indeed, Zarathustra didn't like them either.

fields.headline: Shallow throat
fields.standfirst: Get on with it? If only David Leavitt would...
fields.trailText: Get on with it? If only David Leavitt would...
fields.body:
Martin Bauman: A Novel
David Leavitt
Little, Brown, £16.99, 466pp
Buy it at BOL

The confessional genre, the colossal growth area in non-fiction of recent years, has attracted a healthy readership and a rather unhealthy amount of critical disdain. Why, detractors protest, must writers shine a light on the shabby corners of their lives simply because they have the professional knowhow to do so? And why do the rest of us trust in their pronouncements on life's grim events sooner than we would trust our own judgment? From the writers' corner comes the well-rehearsed reply that they can do nothing else with their experiences: like the shark, they must keep swimming, or die.

What then are we to make of a novel that seeks to imitate this genre, and takes as its subject the very business of literary creation? In Martin Bauman: A Novel, David Leavitt pretends to be a writer writing about writing - although his narrator does little but talk about himself. And that, it would seem, is the point: for his tale of boundless self-regard and uninhibited solipsism amounts to a vicious parody of the vacuousness and arbritrariness of literary reputation - and, by extension, of creativity itself.

Which is not to say that it works. It helps if a parody is funny, and Leavitt - or Bauman - rarely is. Instead of humour we get almost 500 pages of minutely drawn, exhaustively and exhaustingly nuanced self-examination. During the course of this mammoth whack of prose we follow Bauman from his days as a writing student, under the tutelage of the scathing icon Stanley Flint, to his emergence as part of a New York literary bratpack. His fame, we under stand, is based on a youthful coming-out story published in "the magazine" (the preciousness of which makes it instantly recognisable as The New Yorker), a short-story collection entitled The Deviled-Egg Plate and a novel, The Terrorist.

Of these works, we learn little save the barest plot details; of the circumstances surrounding their publication, we learn everything. From the "thickly slavered, full-gloss" paint on the walls of "the magazine" to the promotional notice for The Terrorist in Publishers' Weekly, from Bauman's first cocktail party to the snapshot of him playing Scrabble with other bratpack writers, the book faithfully chronicles every lurch, stagger and pose of the neophyte scribbler's career.

Grafted on to a grim but strangely unconvincing portrait of the Manhattan literary scene in the 1980s is Bauman's true confession: that he is frightfully ambitious, and that his desperation to reach the top started with his discovery that you could cheat your way through school tests. After that, the wholesale plundering of his own life and those of his family and friends seemed a foregone conclusion.

As a counterpoint to this guilty secret stands the brazen king-maker Flint, whose assessment of Bauman has always been frank - "it's easy for me to imagine you turning into a hack, settling for cheap success, and not because you're greedy, but... you desire too desperately to please" - and who moves mysteriously from editor to writing teacher to publisher to writer, somehow preserving, on seemingly slender grounds, an impregnable reputation. For Bauman he is both mentor and tormentor, an elusive eminence grise paradoxically assuming the role of chief ghost at the feast.

"Flint's first principle" is "Get on with it!", with a rider that warns of the dangers of literary "throat-clearing". Leavitt's conceit is that Bauman does anything but get on with it and nothing but clear his throat. Stringing together vignettes that plod through lived experience and skim silently over anything of import, he reveals himself to be an obtuse and clumsy writer: "Now, as I finished high school, the future that lay before me was one in the potentialities of which I could revel, for it was a blank page, as yet unsullied by the smudges and erasures, the torn edges and ink blotches, of its own experiencing."

The clue to his nature lies in less overwrought utterances, as when he walks through Manhattan with his new boyfriend: "Blushing, I kept looking over my shoulder to see if anyone was staring at us. No one was." Non-staring, it becomes obvious, is intolerable.

Leavitt has had his fair share of literary notoriety (refer to Stephen Spender's estate for details of the furore over his withdrawn novel While England Sleeps), and it's hard not to see much of this roman à clef as nifty score-settling. More unsettling than any game of spot-the-celeb is the idea that the author and "the author" of this work are one and the same. The parallels between them are plain enough: but one hopes that Leavitt, whose previous work has demonstrated a delicacy of wit and a nicely understated sense of irony, has not accompanied his narcissistic alter ego too far down this particularly pedestrian route.

fields.headline: Freedom fighter
fields.standfirst: Mike Marqusee converts Nicholas Lezard  with his biography of Muhammad Ali, Redemption Song
fields.trailText: Mike Marqusee converts Nicholas Lezard with his biography of Muhammad Ali, Redemption Song
fields.body:
Redemption Song: Muhammad Ali and the Spirit of the Sixties
Mike Marqusee
(Verso, £10)
Buy it at BOL

Dear me, another book about Muhammad Ali. How many is that now? About 50-odd, still in print, I'd say. Boxing, writing's exact opposite, attracts quite a few writers, perhaps for that very reason. Not me, though. And, not knowing or caring much about boxing, I didn't know or care much about Muhammad Ali, who as far as I was concerned was someone who introduced a tiresome vein of self-proclamation into sport ("I am the greatest", etc) and is now, as one of "sport's elder statesmen", someone about whom you are not allowed to entertain heretical thoughts.

So I was prepared for a book that I would have to read through the fog of my own indifference. But it's not quite like that. Marqusee is perfectly aware that the world and his dog has written a book about Ali, not to mention a book about the 1960s, but here he gives us the radical Ali, the friend (and then ex-friend) of Malcolm X, the potent symbol of Elijah Muhammad's Nation of Islam, the man whom The New York Times refused, for years, to call anything but Cassius Clay - or simply "Clay", in contradistinction to that newspaper's fusty correctitude when dealing with white people.

The New York Times does not emerge from this book with any honour. Indeed, I had no idea how despicable its pronouncements during the 1960s could be. Getting Ali's name right was a serious matter, as Ernie Terrell found to his cost in 1967, when he called him "Clay" during a pre-match press conference. "Uncle Tom! What's my name?" shouted Ali, in the ring, as he pummelled Terrell to bits. It was, Terrell presumably learned, a rhetorical question, of a kind. (Terrell, to his credit, never complained.)

Ali learned a different kind of rhetoric when he said this: "I ain't got no quarrel with them Vietcong." The poison that was heaped on his head, by just about everyone, is almost unimaginable now (imagine the bleats of outrage in Wednesday's gutter press about a few paint-throwers in Whitehall, multiplied in ferocity by a factor of 20).

It is, in retrospect, surprising that he managed to get through the decade alive. There is an aside that deals with the assassination of Patrice Lumumba, reminding you not only that being a democratically elected leader did not make you safe; and also that while the Eisenhower administration ordered Lumumba's death, it was the Kennedy administration that executed the order. About 50-odd, still in print, I'd say. Boxing, writing's exact opposite, attracts quite a few writers, perhaps for that very reason. Not me, though. webTitle: Life's too short to stuff a mushroom

fields.headline: Life's too short to stuff a mushroom
fields.standfirst: Foodie Nigel Slater tells Nicholas Wroe why cooking should be fun and fast
fields.trailText: Foodie Nigel Slater tells Nicholas Wroe why cooking should be fun and fast
fields.body:
When Nigel Slater says that his early reading was exclusively devoted to cookery books, the first reaction is to brace oneself. This is par for the course for a food writer, and it usually ends up with a hymn of praise to Saint Elizabeth David, whose passion and prose set them on the path of good taste.

"Elizabeth David?" laughs Slater. "I'd never heard of Elizabeth David. That was not my family thing at all. We weren't olive-oil-and-garlic people. We were very much meat-and-two-veg-in-the-Midlands people. When I was a child my parents tried spaghetti. Once. They didn't like it."

Slater explains that the cookery books he devoured (to the exclusion of textbooks, novels or anything else) were really recipe books. "No introductions or narrative," he recalls, "just a set of instructions and everything decorated with glacé cherries or angelica. Things like the all-colour Hamlyn cookbook or the Penguin books by Margaret Costa. You occasionally still see them in second-hand shops. They were wonderful things."

Unsurprisingly, Slater says he never thought of doing anything else except cooking. He was the boy in the apron who did domestic science at a mixed school. "And I think there was a girl somewhere else doing metalwork who is now a librarian in Islington." After school he went to catering college, and then had a wandering apprenticeship when he picked names of restaurants he fancied out of the Good Food Guide and asked if they would take him on as a trainee.

"I loved the actual cooking and I loved the prep beforehand. But that whole kitchen-buzz thing just didn't get me. It's the reason many chefs say why they do it. But for me it just seemed all a bit of a hassle. There is an urgency that you need to get the food from the pan onto the plate and out to the customers. I just couldn't get that side of it."

This apparent unsuitability for the rigours of kitchen life didn't stop Slater from working in an upmarket café just off Grosvenor Square, where he got his break into writing. A customer was starting a new food magazine and she asked if Slater knew anyone who could test recipes for her. Slater volunteered.

"I tested a few things for her and then she asked me to have a go writing the recipes. My first piece was about apples and it was published. It was one of those lucky accidents. I had washed up in restaurants and peeled vegetables so I had no literary background at all. I wouldn't have got into it any other way."

He then became the food editor of Marie Claire magazine from its launch. He says he so much enjoyed journalism, and styling food for the glossy photographs, that when he was first asked by a publisher to write a book he said no. But the publisher was flatteringly persistent, saying that they published Jane Grigson and Elizabeth David - by now he was aware of her - and they would like to publish him as well. Slater relented, but only on the condition he could write about the food he cooked when he got home at nights. It was an inspired decision.

"I was so fed up with the whole Marks and Spencer's quick-meal-and-microwave thing. The theory was we would all go over to pre-cooked meals, but in fact there was and is a massive enthusiasm for real cooking. The publisher said: 'Just collect the recipes of the things you cook at home.' "

It was an idea that had found its time. In 1992 Slater's Real Fast Food: 350 Recipes Ready-to-Eat in 30 minutes neatly squared the circle for a generation of wannabe foodies for whom life really was too short to stuff a mushroom. His exuberant appreciation of salty chips, cold beer and fish-finger sandwiches - with tomato sauce - gave added credibility to his pronouncements on marginally more complex dishes. And decisively, the book was not only practical, but deliciously readable, thanks to Slater's invitingly informal prose style.

"A lot of the reviews said that they liked the introductions to the recipes. And I felt comfortable using the words 'I' and 'me' a lot. Not many people were doing that at the time and it seemed I was giving a little bit more than just a recipe. It was about how that recipe fitted into my life."

Slater followed up with Real Fast Puddings and The 30 Minute Cook. He has also done his share of television and writes a column in the Observer. The paperback of his latest book, Real Food, has just been published, in which he explores eight key foods: sausages, ice-cream, potatoes, garlic, chicken, cheese, chocolate and sandwiches. It is enticing stuff served up with Slater's trademark passionate approach. Hot potatoes are apparently, "the culinary equivalent of a Big Fat Hug".

He has a new book out in the autumn, and is then planning what sounds like the logical extension to his personal approach to food. "It's a somewhat autobiographical book without any recipes," he says. "I suppose we've gone full circle to Elizabeth David. Her recipes could be impossibly vague, because at that time we weren't as spoon-fed as we are now. I find that very attractive. The idea that someone could cook their supper without being told every minute detail appeals to me a lot.

"It breaks my heart that people won't cook a recipe because they haven't got one ingredient. It comes from the idea that you have to cook as the book says, otherwise it will kill you. I suppose my work aims to redress that."

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Glorious stuff, physics, but how often schools have murdered it...
fields.body:
ABC of Relativity
Bertrand Russell
(Orion, £8.99, 180 mn)
Buy it at BOL

Glorious stuff, physics, but how often schools have murdered it. If only we'd all had Derek Jacobi delivering Russell's sparkling introduction to Einstein. Russell's aim in 1958 was to guide folk with no knowledge of maths or physics through the theories of special and general relativity, to clarify the puzzle to which Einstein's theory was the answer. His limpid prose and stimulating analogies succeed with the reader and - thanks to Jacobi's zestful performance - with the listener too.

This wonderful recording, one of a new series of 20 Talking Science audiobooks, is no breeze, though. Expect to play morse code on the rewind button. This is a rarity: an audiobook which entices rehearing. But mind you're not too beguiled on the M1 by the revelation that billiard balls don't really bounce off one another or that your speed is irrelevant to electrons. Just look forward to crushing the next bore who says that everything's relative. It's not. Apparently.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Some things never change... plus Gilbert & Sullivan's London
fields.body:
The East End
Alan Palmer
(John Murray, £10.99)
Buy it at BOL

Immigrants, racism, slums, sweatshops, noisome industries or under-employment - how familiar to London's new mayor would seem 16th-century life in Tower Hamlets and Hackney. We would have liked more on the capital beyond Whitechapel before 1800, when its different-realm nature (church-owned land meant short leases, meant rotten properties, meant poverty-row tenants) was established. Loved the teeming detail, like the Ashkenazim pencil-makers arriving from Bavaria; but it's too fast on to the Bread Riots - McDonald's would have been razed not raided in an East End revolt - and the Shadwell serial throat-slitter of 1811. A ref book rather than a read.

Gilbert & Sullivan's London
Andrew Goodman
(Faber, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Anorak devotions to a single subject - Savoy Operas and the metropolis in which they triumphed - inform better than general histories: for we all live inside our own narrow worlds within an era, and precision about these restores reality. Whatever the named location, G & S's works were created out of the physical city, fantasies of the Tower and the Law Courts. Written in the fake-genteel way of such works, but includes a revelatory photo of the Gaiety Theatre - so that's what the height of empire Aldwych loomed like, thumpingly imperial; and a strong sense of the red-hot terracotta and brick of passionate Brompton in its aesthetic prime.

The Diary of Samuel Pepys, Vols I and II
(HarperCollins, £14.99)
Buy it at BOL

Yuppie Pepys on the rise in post-Restoration but pre-plague and fire London: My Lord Mayor and the whole City in armes owing to a great stirr of Fanatiques killing six or seven men by night, not that it deterred Sam from buying a shilling twelfth-night cake and noting that the theatre's boy player was "the prettiest woman in the house". This is London small, stinking and still mostly wood-built - Pepys has joiners infesting his house building him a new staircase - and the stage for Charles II's "coronacian day", the city with light like a glory round about it from the "bonefyres". Pepys got so drunk he woke wet with his spewing. London human-sized, as it was meant to be.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Sometimes you just need cheering up, and what better than a scathing satire on American politics? Plus The Dope Priest, When Dreams Travel, Pixel Juice and As it is in Heaven
fields.body:
George Bush Dark Prince of Love
Lydia Millet
(Virago, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Sometimes, you just need cheering up. And what could be better than the story of an overweight ex-con living in a boondocks trailer park who develops an enormous crush on George Bush? But Rosemary, who takes life lessons from the Contra scandal and argues vociferously with TV pundits ("My Democrat colleague hasn't done his homework on this one, Peter," she chips in cheerfully), is no ordinary loon: bucketloads of savvy and scathing wit allow Millet to satirise American politics and what sociologists call "the underclass" with great panache. One only wishes she would make the trip across the pond for the English version.

The Dope Priest
Nicholas Blincoe
(Sceptre, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Blincoe is one of the sharpest young writers around, and far more intelligent than the caperish plots of his novels might suggest. This latest offering has perhaps the most mind-boggling storyline to date: two dodgy geezers who flee London to pull off a shady property deal on the West Bank. Among their most immediate problems are how to get something decent to smoke in order to make sense of it all. But amidst all the far-fetched antics - Israeli secret servicemen, Russian drug barons and a singing nun all make an appearance - there is a shrewd analysis of the lawlessness and mayhem of the Middle East.

When Dreams Travel
Githa Hariharan
(Picador, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

This elegant re-telling of The Thousand and One Nights revolves around Shahrzad, who must captivate her sister and both of their husbands with stories. She begins her work with a statement of the limits of her power: "I don't have a sword, so it seems I cannot rule. I cannot rule, I cannot travel, I don't care to weep. But I can dream." It is those "secret dreams", suggestive, powerful, and ultimately redemptive, that make up this strange, imaginative book. Hariharan is part of a recent wave of writers to emerge from India, and with this novel she proves herself no less an accomplished mythmaker than the best of them.

Pixel Juice
Jeff Noon
(Anchor, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

"In the first shop they bought a packet of dogseed, because Doreen had always wanted to grow her own dog." You come across that pretty early on in Jeff Noon's short stories (actually, too staid a term for these weird fragments), and that's about as sane as it gets. Elsewhere, there are instructions for Pimp! - The Board Game, a Marilyn Monroe "celeborg", a bleeding baby allergic to the letter Q (unfortunately, his name is Quentin), and a caged worm. God knows what really goes on inside Noon's head - and you almost certainly wouldn't want to be there yourself - but in a way we're glad he writes it all down.

As it is in Heaven
Niall Williams
(Picador, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

Not one for the cynics among you, Williams's west Ireland tale recounts the sorrows of lonely schoolteacher Stephen and his tailor father Philip, who has never got over the deaths of his wife and daughter. Just as they begin to believe nothing will ever change, Gabriella, a beautiful Italian violinist, arrives on the scene to put things right. The question remains: can Philip fashion a suit so wonderful that it will win his son the musician's heart? Yes, it might sound a little on the corny side, but Williams manages to keep the sentimentalism in check, and he is a subtle and graceful enough writer to make it all work.

fields.headline: Big in first novels
fields.trailText: A life lived at one remove, a revolutionary take on Judaism and a Lahore drop-out...
fields.body:
The tenants of Edward Carey's Observatory Mansions (Picador, £9.99) are a peculiar bunch. Among the occupants of this isolated, decaying apartment block stranded on a traffic island are a woman who thinks she's a dog, a retired schoolmaster who leaks water from every pore, a couple of catatonic pensioners, and a sinister porter.

Carey's surreal world owes more than a nod to Mervyn Peake and Djuna Barnes. The narrator, Francis Orme, appears to be an obsessive-compulsive fetishist: unable to tolerate the sight of his own hands, he wears white gloves. Once a pair has outlived their purpose, they are carefully filed away in his "glove diary". These are not the only things he obsessively catalogues: in the cellar he is assembling his life's work - a stash of stolen objects which he calls his "Exhibition of Love".

Orme lives his life at one remove: never touching anything first-hand, gleaning vicarious meaning from objects that were once meaningful to someone else. With this extraordinary character, and the appealingly deranged inhabitants of Observatory Mansions, Carey has created an imaginary world brimming with the weird, the wonderful and the unexpected.

"I don't know about the rest of y'all, but I knew she wasn't Jewish the minute I laid eyes on her." So says a member of Tova Mirvis's The Ladies Auxiliary (Picador, £10). Batsheva, a blonde single mother in tight-fitting top and tattoo, moves into a strictly orthodox Jewish Southern neighbourhood. By sundown, after a rapid fire of telephonic exchange, the whole cast of characters have established who she is and why she's there.

Batsheva's free-love tactics and revolutionary attitude to Judaism energise young mothers, adolescent schoolgirls and the Rabbi's son alike; needless to say, the old guard don't like it. Having set up this archetypal conflict between religion by rote and an all-embracing spirituality, Mirvis crafts an assured and enjoyable debut. And for once the publisher has got it right: if you like Anne Tyler, you'll love this.

Moshid Hamid has set out to expose a Pakistan unknown to most outsiders. In Moth Smoke (Granta, £10) the central character, Daru, is on trial for murder. As the story flits in and out of a first-person monologue (the other characters speak in off-stage interludes to the main plot), we learn the chain of events that has brought him to this point.

Sacked from his enervating job, Daru's lower middle-class status defeats him - it seems nothing can be achieved in jet-set Lahore without a foreign degree or a big enough bribe, so Daru collapses into a heroin-induced stupor. Among the occupants of this isolated, decaying apartment block stranded on a traffic island are a woman who thinks she's a dog, a retired schoolmaster who leaks water from every pore, a couple of catatonic pensioners, and a sinister porter. fields.headline: Art for partners' sake
fields.standfirst: Dylan Evans discovers the scientific rules of sexual attraction
fields.trailText: Dylan Evans discovers the scientific rules of sexual attraction
fields.body:
Promiscuity
Tim Birkhead
Faber, £9.99, 256pp
Buy it at BOL

The Mating Mind
Geoffrey Miller
Heinemann, £20, 528pp

Everyone has heard of natural selection, but how many know about Darwin's other dangerous idea - the theory of sexual selection? He wrote a book about it in 1872, but the idea fell on deaf ears. Nowadays it is one of the hottest areas of research in evolutionary biology, as two new books make clear. Promiscuity by Tim Birkhead and The Mating Mind by Geoffrey Miller both explore the effects of sexual selection, though in rather different ways.

Tim Birkhead, professor of behaviour and ecology at Sheffield University, has spent many years researching the reproductive biology of birds - which is what prompted Darwin to develop the theory of sexual selection in the first place. Darwin was particularly troubled by the peacock, whose exuberant tail appeared to flaunt the logic of natural selection. Not only do big, bright tails seem biologically useless, they can be detrimental to the owner's health, attracting predators and making it harder to escape. It seems that such ornaments should not evolve, and yet nature is full of them, from monkeys with red and white faces to beetles with carapaces of gold and sapphire.

Darwin solved this riddle by proposing that animal ornamentation evolved to attract sexual partners. If peahens prefer to mate with those peacocks who have the biggest, brightest tails, then the peacocks with tiny drab ones won't pass on the genes for such tails. From the gene's point of view, if you fail to produce any offspring, it doesn't matter how long you survive; your genes die with you.

As the example of the peacock shows, sexual selection is usually about male competition and female choice. If natural selection is a blind watchmaker, sexual selection is a keen-eyed judge at a beauty contest in which the competitors are usually males. Darwinians are often accused of promoting an androcentric view of sexuality, but the theory of sexual selection tells a different story. Rather than viewing females as mere portable wombs, sexual selection theory portrays them as cunning sexual strategists.

In Promiscuity, Tim Birkhead argues that male competition and female choice do not stop at the moment of copulation but continues right up to fertilisation, though in the post-coital stage the competitors are no longer males but their sperm.

When a female has sex with more than one male during the same fertile period, the sperm from her various partners battle it out inside her reproductive tract for the right to fertilise her eggs. Female choice continues to operate inside the female body, as sperm from one partner may be preferred over the sperm from the others.

Birkhead illuminates the murky world of sperm competition with a stunning variety of examples: from the catfish who get pregnant by giving their partners blowjobs to the insects who take cradle-snatching to an extreme by inseminating females before they emerge from their pupal shrouds, the reader is treated to a veritable cook's tour of reproductive biology.

If there is one consistent theme to emerge from this bizarre variety, it is that female sexual fidelity is extremely rare in nature. For a long time biologists assumed that promiscuity was a predominantly masculine trait; the research on sperm competition has changed all this. As Birkhead points out, sperm competition would not exist in a species unless the females typically mate with multiple partners during the same fertile period. Biologists have thus been forced to abandon their belief in the myth of the monogamous female.

The Mating Mind is also about sexual selection, but differs from Promiscuity in two important ways. First, while Birkhead writes about a whole variety of organisms, Miller focuses exclusively on just one species - a rather curious bipedal ape known as Homo sapiens. Second, whereas Birkhead sets out the consequences of sexual selection for anatomy and behaviour, Miller explores the effects of sexual selection on the mind.

Put these two points together and you get a provocative thesis: the most distinctively human aspects of our minds evolved not by natural selection but by sexual selection. The things we think of as most "human", such as our capacities for art, morality and language, Miller argues, did not evolve because they provided any survival benefit, but rather because they helped our ancestors to seduce their lovers. Art and creativity are not survival gadgets but courtship devices.

Miller is an evolutionary psychologist, but his views on mental evolution are rather different from those of his Darwinian colleagues. Most evolutionary psychologists have adopted a "survivalist" view of evolution that neglects the importance of sexual selection. Steven Pinker, for example, thinks that art and creativity are mere by-products of mental capacities that evolved for more practical purposes. In his book How the Mind Works, art, morality and creativity were relegated to a speculative final chapter. To many people, including Miller, this renders evolutionary psychology rather unsatisfying. The human mind may well consist mainly of basic mechanisms for things like vision and locomotion, while morality and art may be mere icing on the cake, yet it is the icing we really care about.

In Miller's book, the icing is the point: language, art and morality are presented as adaptations designed for sexual ends. But before you shout "reductionist", remember that sexual selection is driven by mate choice: minds take centre stage in evolution. Miller does not want to reduce psychology to biology; on the contrary, he sees psychology as a powerful force in shaping biology. The reason we possess the capacity to tell jokes and compose symphonies is, he claims, because our ancestors preferred funny, creative partners to dull ones. What emerges is a vision of the Stone Age in which love was just as important, and almost as complex, as it is today. Miller argues persuasively that this is "probably the least reductionistic theory of the mind's evolution one could hope for that is consistent with modern biology".

In suggesting that our artistic capacities function as sexual adverts, Miller is not suggesting that all art is motivated by some unconscious wish to have sex. Just as a peacock does not need to sublimate his libido to grow a pretty tail, so our capacity for art can be a sexual display without any dark Freudian motives to underlie it. All that is needed for Miller's theory to work is that our ancestors preferred to mate with artistic partners.

We then need to explain why they had this preference, but Miller has an answer for this too. He argues that works of art have, until very recently, been very reliable indicators of the artist's fitness. To produce a beautiful object such as a statuette or, indeed, a handaxe required dexterity, strength, good eyesight, careful planning and patience. The preference for mating with good artists evolved by piggy-backing on the good genes that children would inherit from artistic parents.

Nowadays, of course, things are very different. Machines can turn out thousands of perfect objets d'art much more quickly and efficiently than any human being, so qualities such as symmetry and intricate detail no longer serve as reliable indicators of artistic talent. Thankfully, however, there are still some things that machines cannot do as well as humans, such as write fascinating books like these two. Language still provides humans with a wonderfully reliable way to show off their biological fitness. If we judge these books by the theory Miller propounds, both he and Birkhead should be very pleased with themselves: their peacock's tails should attract a lot of admirers indeed.

 Dylan Evans works at the London School of Economics and Political Science.

fields.headline: Awards are gained and lost
fields.trailText: The Jewish Quarterly-Wingate Literary Prizes, drawing a veil over the Honeymoon party and Goldbach's Conjecture still unproved...
fields.body:
 A packed night on the tiles saw the Loafer scuttling between parties. On the one hand, there were the annual Jewish Quarterly-Wingate Literary Prizes, which began with a rather unusual and disturbing act of rescindment. The 1997 Non-Fiction prizewinner, Binjamin Wilkomirski, was stripped of his award after his "memoir", an account of childhood experiences in Auschwitz and Majdanek, was found to belong more properly in the fiction category.

Rather than attempt to recover the £4,000 prize money, the Wingate Foundation generously put their hands in their pockets, and the three runners-up, Louise Kehoe, George Steiner and Silvia Rodgers, each received an unexpected £1,333.

All of which cast a rather long shadow over the presentation of this year's prizes: to Wladyslaw Szpilman, for his true-life account, The Pianist, and to Howard Jacobson, who picked up the Fiction Prize for The Mighty Walzer. The irrepressibly cheerful Jacobson pocketed a cheque for £4,000, but seemed more attached to the African violet, presumably a stray table decoration, that he was clutching on his way out.

 And so, with unseemly haste, to Amy Jenkins's party for Honeymoon, held at current in-spot (ie, another set of huge rooms with mystifying plumbing arrangements), the Sugar Reef. Unabashed by what we might call "mixed reviews", Ms Jenkins appeared resplendent in a white wedding dress, complete with a modesty-preserving veil. The unkind wag who dared to breathe the words "Miss Havisham" knows who he is, but the Loafer is feeling kind, so his anonymity is assured - for the moment.

 Faber's challenge to eager number-crunchers to solve the problem at the heart of Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture has been bearing strange fruit. From a budding Ruth Lawrence: "I am a 12 year-old highly advanced mathematician." There have also been certain entries more geared towards the $1 million prize money than a boundless love of number theory. A man encloses a postcard from his wife, living abroad and desperate to clap eyes on him again, as proof of his need for the dosh, while an overseas correspondent issues a rather more concrete claim: "I would be very grateful if you could advise me when I can travel to London to present my proof of the theory in person. I shall be travelling with my mother." Hmm. On present showing, Faber's cash seems safe.

webTitle: You too can tip the world

fields.headline: You too can tip the world
fields.standfirst: Has Malcolm Gladwell found the secret to fast-changing modern world in The Tipping Point?
fields.trailText: Has Malcolm Gladwell found the secret to fast-changing modern world in The Tipping Point?
fields.body:
The Tipping Point: How Little Things Can Make A Big Difference
Malcolm Gladwell
Little, Brown, £14.99, 279pp
Buy it at BOL

Read an extract

Malcolm Gladwell wants to be our teacher. He has painstakingly prepared a lesson and transcribed it into book form. His subject is very broad: how and why the modern world alters so unpredictably. And he has written about it in the mild, relentless sentences of a classroom evangelist.

"I'm going to take you to Baltimore, to learn from that city," he says. "I'm going to introduce three fascinating kinds of people who play a critical role in our tastes and trends and fashions. I'll take you to a hi-tech company in Delaware... to the subways of New York City..." The product of all this conscientious continent-crossing will be more than a mere book. It will "answer questions that lie at the heart of what we would all like to accomplish as educators, parents, marketeers, business people, and policymakers".

The Tipping Point is a very American publication. It is part popular science, part cultural studies, part state-of-the-nation assessment; but most of all it bustlingly reads like a self-help volume. Gladwell, a smart journalist rather than an academic, cites fashion crazes and syphilis outbreaks in the same bright tone. The people he eagerly interviews are entrepreneurs, civic reformers and academics keen to share their discoveries. From them he synthesises a theory about how we live now that is simple, free of politics, and either piercingly clever or quite banal.

Gladwell thinks that America, and by implication the rest of the rich world, is ruled by epidemics. Our consumer choices and wider behaviour have become erratic because we are constantly contaminating each other with our preferences. A few people wearing particular shoes in a certain nightclub; the well-publicised actions of a single vigilante; a local shift in public manners in a particular spot: all of these can spread, slowly at first, then suddenly and widely. "The Tipping Point" is Gladwell's metaphor, tirelessly pursued through nearly 300 pages, for the moment when a tiny fad goes mass.

It is not a completely original notion, as he bravely admits on page 12. During the 1970s, American sociologists studying "white flight" from inner-city suburbs noticed that if the black population of an area reached roughly a fifth of the total, then the area would "tip": almost all the white people would abruptly move away. Gladwell does not dwell on this rather suspect use of the verb, but expands the metaphor's application and offers many vivid examples of his own. In 1984, for example, the first cheap fax machine went on sale in the US. For the next three years, it sold in the low thousands. Then, in 1987, a million customers bought one - sending faxes had become a business practicality, part of everyday life.

Gladwell's explanation is that a minority of us make expert but unintentional advocates for new practices. With an amateur sociologist's flourish, he calls these people "Mavens, Connectors, and Salesmen". They are charming; they have connections; they are unafraid to wear strange new trainers. Gladwell is thorough at drawing out what makes such individuals influential, and summarises much interesting research about the power of small physical gestures and word of mouth.

Yet a suspicion hovers that too much of the analysis here is faintly second-hand - or merely common sense. The agents of cultural change that Gladwell says he has discovered have been noted under different names before: "early adopters" have long featured in articles and books about the popularisation of computers and other gadgetry. Likewise, his examination of fashion subcultures as clues to the currents at play in society is a trick that dates back at least to British writers such as Dick Hebdige during the 1970s. And we all already know that some people have vastly more acquaintances and influence over their friends than others.

There is, too, something naive about Gladwell's surprise at present-day fickleness. "We are all, at heart, gradualists," he maintains early on, "our expectations set by the steady passage of time." Later, he insists: "We all want to believe that the key to making an impact... lies with the inherent quality of the ideas we present." But is this faith in a steady, merit-driven world really shared by many people? Has it ever been?

The book becomes an extended reminder that Americans are not always as modern-minded as we imagine. Their huge, sprawled-out, suburban country has only fairly recently acquired a national grapevine and the accelerations of national life that go with it. MTV and the internet owe much of their success there to creating "tipping points" where few previously existed. Gladwell wisely limits his examples to his own country, but to a European, used to gossip and cities, social claustrophobia and events spinning in quick cycles, he seems a bit slow on the uptake.

His conclusion avoids speculations about America's changing media and society for something folksier. "Look at the world around you," he implores. "With the slightest push - in just the right place - it can be tipped." Well-meaning individuals, he argues, should focus their energies in highly specific directions (he cites the removal of graffiti as the catalyst, in recent years, for the New York subway becoming safer). But this feels like too neat an end to the lesson. Having described a world of flux and unpredictability, Gladwell has come up with a rigid set of rules to explain it. These will only last until the next clever American social critic comes up with a catchphrase. The Slipping Point, anyone?

Gladwell wisely limits his examples to his own country, but to a European, used to gossip and cities, social claustrophobia and events spinning in quick cycles, he seems a bit slow on the uptake. His conclusion avoids speculations about America's changing media and society for something folksier. "Look at the world around you," he implores. "With the slightest push - in just the right place - it can be tipped." Well-meaning individuals, he argues, should focus their energies in highly specific directions (he cites the removal of graffiti as the catalyst, in recent years, for the New York subway becoming safer). But this feels like too neat an end to the lesson. Having described a world of flux and unpredictability, Gladwell has come up with a rigid set of rules to explain it. These will only last until the next clever American social critic comes up with a catchphrase. The Slipping Point, anyone?

fields.headline: Lore of the letters
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  dives into Richard A. Firmage's nutritious alphabet soup, The Alphabet Abecedarium
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom dives into Richard A. Firmage's nutritious alphabet soup, The Alphabet Abecedarium
fields.body:
The Alphabet Abecedarium: Some Notes on Letters
Richard A. Firmage
Bloomsbury, £14.99, 307pp
Buy it at BOL

Your favourite letter is always the first letter of your first name. It's your mark - your initial - and, like a comfort blanket or a favourite toy, your first object of affection. You feel proprietary towards it. You want to protect it. Some people like to wear theirs on a signet ring or a necklace, like an amulet or a memento mori. As time goes on you learn to share, of course, and other letters are added, until finally you enter into a full relationship with the whole alphabet. Churchill, who had to work to cure his lisp, wrote, "I can't be haunted by the idea that I must avoid every word beginning with an S." Quite. Sorry. Smoke. Snacks. Smut.

But as you come to master and possess the alphabet, so it comes to possess you. From childish self-obsession you pass on to adolescent pencil-case doodlings and signature fumblings, before you find yourself hooked and hitched. Inevitably, the fires of passion die down, and it seems impossible to recover that early sense of adventure and romance and fun. You become complacent. Perhaps this is why people become linguists, or poets: to preserve that raw excitement and the thrill of the chase.

In order to rekindle any relationship you need to rediscover your loved one's uniqueness; you need to be reintroduced, and seduced. To reacquaint yourself with the thrills of the big 26 you could try this: go to your local DIY store and get them to unlock the cabinet containing the spray paints. Choose a colour: the bolder the better. Find a wall. Wait until no one else is around. And then write your name in big fat bubbly letters six feet high.

Alternatively, you could read Richard Firmage's The Alphabet Abecedarium, a bursting sentimental history of letters, which sets out to conjure up the beauty and strangeness of that all too familiar ABC. Firmage's is that rare thing, an intelligent book with décolletage.

Firmage has 28 rather than the expected 26 chapters; the first 26 are A-Z, 27 is "A-Z" and 28 is "&". The subject of at least one of these chapters is guaranteed to be of interest to you. Writing about my own personal favourite, Firmage speculates that "it represents the oneness of God and also symbolises power descending to man from on high and man's yearning towards higher things. Perhaps the straight form of the letter influenced Socrates to speculate in Cratylus that iota was expressive of penetration - 'the subtle elements which pass through all things'." I always thought as much.

Of course, the study of words makes you horribly self-conscious, and can send you mad in the end. Alexander Cruden went mad. WC Minor, one of the more prolific contributors to Murray's original OED (and the subject of Simon Winchester's recent bestselling The Surgeon of Crowthorne), was patient number 742 in Broadmoor. And the study of letters is more mind-boggling still.

Firmage, for example, has a tendency to both swank and ponder, and he relies for evidence and anecdote on eccentrics such as Renaissance designer Geoffrey Tory and a mysterious someone called Zolar's rather windy and rose-pink Encyclopedia of Ancient and Forbidden Knowledge (1970). Firmage forces gorgeous fact upon gorgeous fact: the outcome is more like exotic book-patterned wall-paper than a book. You can't actually read it: you just ogle.

But The Alphabet Abecedarium does have its desired effect: it reminds you of your first love. It makes you want to go and play hangman, or Scrabble, or "I Love My Love", a game mentioned in Pepys and Dickens but immortalised by Max Bygraves, in which you have to work through the alphabet describing your sweetheart (or, in a chaste Victorian variation, the parson's cat). Suffice it to say, then, that The Alphabet Abecedarium is agreeable, becoming, careful, desirable, egregious, fidgety, garrulous, humorous, industrious, judicious, keen, lively, merry, natty, obsequious, poppy, querulous, regular, sociable, tasteful, useful, vivacious, worthy, xanthippic, yearning, zealous and &.

fields.headline: Ploughing the sea
fields.standfirst: Robert Harvey's The Liberators is an old-fashioned maps and chaps history of the freedom struggle in Latin America
fields.trailText: Robert Harvey's The Liberators is an old-fashioned maps and chaps history of the freedom struggle in Latin America
fields.body:
The Liberators: Latin America's Struggle for Independence, 1810-1830
Robert Harvey
John Murray, £25, 561pp

Robert Harvey is a clever and genial fellow who was sent to Latin America by the Economist in the 1970s to counter what was perceived as the left-wing propaganda being published in Britain at the time by, among others, this newspaper and the present writer. After he had gorged on a heavy diet of right-wing military dictatorships, his views slowly mellowed and he fell in love with the ambiguities and contradictions of the continent and began to write about it with passion and verve.

Apart from a brief and misguided detour into the House of Commons in the Conservative interest, Harvey has led a blameless life as a Daily Telegraph columnist and popular historian, resurrecting significant but forgotten figures such as Robert Clive and restoring them to the Conservative pantheon. Now he has directed his talents towards the extraordinary story of the Latin American liberators, among whom Harvey numbers Bolívar, Miranda, San Martín, O'Higgins, Cochrane, Itúrbide, and the Brazilian emperor Pedro I. These names would not be on every historian's list, but reflect the enthusiasms of an old-fashioned historian, biased towards colourful and sexually voracious characters whose exploits the reader will enjoy hearing about.

British amnesia about Latin America's freedom struggle can best be explained by guilt about missed opportunities. Britain incorporated Haiti into its empire, invaded Nicaragua, sent armies to Argentina, made plans to capture Chile and to seize Mexico; yet after two decades of diplomatic incompetence and military bungling these ambitious plans were set at nought. With an entire continent available at a giveaway price, Britain secured only a tiny Central American foothold from Spain, the miserable territory of British Honduras. The rest of Latin America achieved its independence and freedom largely through its own efforts, and by the vision of its liberators, among whom Simón Bolívar remains preeminent.

A secondary reason for the historical amnesia about the liberators is the large question mark that hovers over their legacy. Bolívar famously wrote that he had ploughed the sea, and for the great bulk of the people, notably the native Indians and imported black slaves, independence from Spain made life worse. Unbridled white-settler societies invariably cause more damage than benign imperial bureaucracies, and the slaughter of Latin America's Indians in the 19th century was greater than in the previous three centuries of Spanish rule.

The fruits of independence were so grim that details of the independence struggle itself have been downplayed in Europe and in North America, and the tales of derring-do that led to a change in the continent's political superstructure in the years between 1810 and 1830 have long mouldered on the library shelves.

In Latin America itself, a continent with a ruling elite caught in a cultural timewarp, the story has never died. Newspapers regularly carry comment on the life and works of the independence heroes, filmmakers re-enact the heroics of 19th-century battles and politicians from Castro to Pinochet revive the memory of figures of the past.

These stories are now so encrusted in folk myth and allegory that it is often difficult for the outsider to get the true measure of protagonists and events. Harvey writes with feeling of "the itch to debunk" in the face of such hero-worship, yet such is his admiration for his cast of characters that he stifles this admirable journalistic trait. Bolívar, in particular, is restored to his proper place in history, his generalship putting him on a par with Julius Caesar and Augustus, Alexander the Great, Tamerlane and Genghis Khan.

Harvey's achievement has been to reassess the story for a new generation of readers outside the continent, recovering some of its excitement and panache. His larger failure is his inability to tackle adequately the Liberators' legacy. Uninterested in the fate of the blacks, Indians or the common people, he falls back on the hope that things may now be improving and the ideals of the Liberators may be worth reviving.

Like all good conservative historians, he reconstructs the past with the eye of a romantic novelist. Untainted by any knowledge or sympathy for economics or sociology, his book is delightfully archaic, largely about maps and chaps. The pen portraits of his heroes are deftly done: their mistresses are "pretty" or "beautiful", the villains "sinister". However, for the general reader he succeeds well in bringing the Liberators glowingly to life.

 Richard Gott's book, In the Shadow of the Liberator: Hugo Chávez and the Transformation of Venezuela, will be published later in May.

fields.headline: 'Twist' and 'Mox'
fields.standfirst: Two exclusive new short stories by Melissa Bank, bestselling author of The Girl's Guide to Hunting and Fishing, inspired by coupledom and the passing of time
fields.trailText: Twist
fields.body:
Twist

After a few weeks, I ask Jack if he wants to meet Billy.

"I don't know," he says. "Do you want to meet my last girlfriend?"

Since I know they're estranged, I say, "I would if she was your best friend. I would if she was the most important person in your life."

On our way to Billy's, Jack says, "Now would be a good time to tell me that I have nothing to worry about." He suggests I assure him that there's no chance I'll ever go back with Billy. "Or tell me how much you fought."

"We didn't fight," I say.

He says, "Maybe I haven't made myself clear."

I kiss him on the mouth. "Would it help if I told you we never had sex?"

He thinks I'm joking. "It would be better if you said you never had it in the last year," he says. "Or that it was never really good."

I repeat: "We never had sex."

"Why?"

"We weren't that kind of couple," I say.

"You mean the couple kind?"

"We were a couple," I say. "We just didn't have sex."

The cab pulls up to Billy's building. Usually Jack insists on paying the fare, but he doesn't even seem to notice the cab has stopped. I hand a ten to the driver. "Keep $7, please," I say.

On the sidewalk, Jack says,"I don't understand."

I hesitate. It doesn't feel like my secret to tell. Even now, Billy doesn't tell people he's gay. He's never even told his parents, though he insists they know; he says, "In the South, talking about your personal life is considered bad manners." The first time he told me that, I said, "Whereas having sex in truckstops is genteel?"

He said, "It's private."

Billy has lit about a hundred tea candles, and his apartment looks almost religious. Though it's summer, I sing, "Silent night, holy night," as we walk in. Jack takes in Billy's living room - the bleached wood floors, the pure white sofa, the fresh white tulips - and turns to meet Billy, himself in a white shirt and white pants.

The two shake hands, and Jack says, "I wasn't prepared for this."

Suddenly, I'm worried about what Jack will say; I feel protective of Billy the way I did of my grandfather when I was little and heard boys cursing in the street.

But Jack says, "I think I should've showered more thoroughly."

Billy laughs and says that he only invites people over so he can clean up afterward.

"Really," I say to Jack, "trash the place."

Billy asks what we want to drink.

"You can have anything you want," I tell Jack, "as long as it's clear."

Jack says, "Martini?"

"Olive or twist?" Billy asks.

I do the twist.

"Oliver Twist," Jack says. "You think that's how Dickens came up with the title?"

"Probably," Billy says. "He did come up with 'Master Bates, with his hands in his breeches-pockets, and his face twisted into a look of semi-comical woe.' "

They go from English literature to French, down to South America and north to the New Yorker. They disagree on everything, but happily, and I realise they are getting along man-style.

At dinner, they ask first-meeting questions, but it's as though they're just going through formalities they're already way past. Billy says, "I hear you're a big wheeler-dealer."

Jack says, "I'm more of a wheeler-wheeler, since none of the deals are going through."

I am ecstatic watching my males bond.

At dessert, Kind Of Blue comes on, and they talk about how it was recorded in a single session and defined the art of improvisation. Jack tells a story about what a slob Miles Davis was, and makes his voice hoarse imitating him: "So what? I play the music. Someone else cleans up. That's the deal."

They laugh and I laugh, too, but I get this pang. I remember the way I used to when Billy had men over; I'd pretend that I belonged, even though I felt like a Naugahyde ottoman among chintz divans, and suddenly I am more than kind of blue.

I am thinking it is past time to go when Billy excuses himself to get his saxophone. I am having trouble looking at Jack, so I clear the dishes, and he helps. He notices the picture of me and Billy on the refrigerator. It was taken during art school, and we're dressed sort of alike; at a glance, we could pass for twins. Looking at the picture, Jack says, "I can't decide whether you're cute or sick."

I say, "I can't decide whether you're cute."

Right away I wish I could take it back and I try to. I say, "I'm just kidding."

"Very funny," he says.

In the living room, Billy begins to play his saxophone, and I say, "Go, cat, go," even though I'm thinking, And Miles to go before I sleep.

Billy plays beautifully; he always does. When he finishes I applaud along with Jack, but I think, I am the sound of one hand clapping.

In the cab, I pretend to doze on my boyfriend's shoulder; back at his apartment, I pretend to fall asleep in his bed.

I hear him brushing his teeth. He opens the refrigerator, drinks from the bottle of water, turns off the lights, and climbs up to the loft bed with me. He puts his arms through mine, his hands on my breasts.

In sleep, he nuzzles into me. That's good, I think. But then: He's asleep; he could be dreaming about anyone.

This is the first night we haven't made love; that's bad, I think. But then: I'm the one who faked sleep.

I remember the muscle I used in order not to know what I knew about Billy early on, and I ask myself if I am using that muscle now.

I remember telling Billy, "But we're the perfect couple," and his response: "Except we don't couple." Now, all these months later, I'm stunned not by his words but mine. They echo here in the quiet of my new boyfriend's apartment.

When I wake up, Jack is making coffee. From my perch, I look down at his apartment, at the map of Iowa tacked to his wall, the records in crates, the futon sofa, and I think, No gay man could live in such a profoundly undecorated apartment. But then I think, Oh, good, now I'm relying on stereotypes to figure out my life.

Then Jack comes up to the loft and sets my coffee and his on the ledge. He lies beside me in his boxer shorts.

I try to act normal. I say, "Did you like Billy?"

"I did," he says. "You were the one I had the problem with."

I feel as naked as I am, and I pull the sheets up to my neck. "I guess I knew that," I say.

"It was fine with Billy," he says. "But it might not have been. He's your ex-boyfriend, even if he is gay. You could've looked out for me a little. I would've done that for you."

I know he would have, which is just one reason I don't want to lose him. "I'm sorry," I say.

"It's okay," he says. He looks at me then, in a way that Billy never has or will.

But I've never been more aware of how little I know about loving a man straight on. It feels impossible to figure out and do at the same time; it seems to require eye-hand coordination I don't have.

Then he picks up a corner of the sheet and pulls it down. I think only a twisted sister would resist what she herself wants, and I do not resist. I am the chicken who crosses the road and gets to the other side.

Mox

After dinner, Lisa tells me we need to talk.

I'm at the sink. She's at the table.

I say, "Sure," as though I have nothing to worry about, as though this talk could just be the talk she was talking about when she said we never talk.

I clear the rest of the dishes as slowly as I can without appearing deliberately slow.

When I reach for her wine glass, she says, "I'm still drinking this," with the quiet authority I have heard her use with insistent telemarketers and my right-wing colleagues.

"Sorry," I say, and then hesitate. In counselling Lisa complained that I seem to speak without feeling; so I ask myself, Am I sorry? I am, though not for taking her wine glass. I let the "sorry" stand.

I get the wine from the refrigerator and refill my own glass too full, conspicuously full, as though I know that our talk calls for anaesthesia. No - the less prepared for her news I appear, the harder it will be for her to deliver. I pour the equivalent of a gulp back into the bottle; a sip runs down its neck.

When I offer the bottle to her, I realise that I should've poured her glass before mine. "Thanks," she says.

I say, "You're welcome," a phrase strangers but not couples use; thank you - yes, you're welcome - no. Although I am trying to remain calm, it is clear to me on some level that the situation is panic-worthy - whatever level it is that makes a man say "you're welcome" instead of nothing.

She says, "Come sit down."

I say, "I just want to finish up," as the idea occurs to me, a good idea, a great idea: I will load the dishwasher, which is her job, thereby showing her that I am capable of spontaneous reversals. I will change before her eyes.

With gusto, I rinse our water glasses, bowls and plates; with devotion, I rinse the silverware, one utensil at a time. I would happily wash the pots and pans, but this would come across as my usual ostentatious display of generosity.

Instead, I reorganise the dishwasher to make it easier for Lisa to empty tomorrow. I am putting forks with forks and knives with knives when she says, "Max."

"Max," she says, not "Babe" or "Honey" or even "Mox", the nickname she uses to tease me out of what she has termed my Germanic severity. "Hey Mox," she said only a month ago, while I was grading papers from my graduate seminar, "why so shtern?" To explain, I quoted from the most dismal example. Only now do I recognise the narrative shift in her tone - from present to past, second person to third; she was already in the living-room-to-be of her future, saying, "I used to call him Mox."

Now I think of saying to her, Why so shtern? A joke would be just what she wouldn't expect from me, a joke is just what I need.

Instead, I say, "One sec," or I think I've said it; maybe I just meant to. On my way to the bathroom, I imagine her saying, He'd just walk out of the room while I was talking. So, I call out, "One sec," just in case.

In the bathroom, I look in the mirror. I try to see my face not as mine but hers - the face she has been looking at and doesn't want to look at any more. I pull at my jowls. I unfurrow my brow. Relax, I tell myself. Cheer up!

When I come out, I am smiling like an idiot. I sit down with her, waiting for her to see the open and cheerful man I have become.

She's wearing the sweater with the extra-long sleeves, the one I think looks misshapen. "That's a pretty sweater," I say.

She says, "I thought you didn't like it."

The old me would say, If you know I don't like it, why do you wear it? The new me says, "I love it!" and as I say it, I do. The sleeves are so long that only the tips of her pale, pretty fingers show. She looks like a little urchin, so vulnerable! But clean, too: Her nails are pink and white rimmed, shiny with clear polish.

She notices me looking at them, and she pulls the sleeves all the way down. I am the author of this reaction; I am the one who taught her that I notice only what I am about to criticise. She tells me that it's time to quit.

She goes on, explaining why, but her voice is just sound to me; I can't make out words. Then I remind myself that I am no longer the man she is describing. I think, I am another man. I am a new man. I am the next man she will love. I change every "you" to "he". Now I can listen with compassion. I listen with love. With my eyes, I tell her that I understand and agree completely. I want to say, You think he crushed you! Wait till you hear what he did to me! But I remember the counsellor saying, "Don't interrupt."

When she stops, I say, "Go on," just as the counsellor did. "Please."

The counsellor would observe that I am thinking of what to say next, instead of listening to her. As the counsellor, though, I forgive myself: first, because forgiveness is essential to moving beyond difficulty; and, second, because I'm not thinking of my arguments or of undermining hers. All I want is to make her happy.

In my head, I ask for help; I even bring my palms together as though in prayer. The phrase We are all God's children comes to me. Of course! She hasn't mentioned children for years; she must have been hoping I would raise the subject, and now I will.

I'll tell her that we can have as many as she wants. I will finally give her the joy she deserves! Joy in abundance! Joy overdue! I will tell her that we can name the first boy after her father! We can name all of them after her father! Leo I! Leo II! Leo III! I am trying not to smile. I am careful not to interrupt.

It is Lisa who interrupts herself. She says, "Are you okay?"

I say, "I've never been better," with all of the feeling I feel right now.
