fields.bodyText: Twist After a few weeks, I ask Jack if he wants to meet Billy. "I don't know," he says. "Do you want to meet my last girlfriend?" Since I know they're estranged, I say, "I would if she was your best friend. I would if she was the most important person in your life." On our way to Billy's, Jack says, "Now would be a good time to tell me that I have nothing to worry about." He suggests I assure him that there's no chance I'll ever go back with Billy. "Or tell me how much you fought." "We didn't fight," I say. He says, "Maybe I haven't made myself clear." I kiss him on the mouth. "Would it help if I told you we never had sex?" He thinks I'm joking. "It would be better if you said you never had it in the last year," he says. "Or that it was never really good." I repeat: "We never had sex." "Why?" "We weren't that kind of couple," I say. "You mean the couple kind?" "We were a couple," I say. "We just didn't have sex." The cab pulls up to Billy's building. Usually Jack insists on paying the fare, but he doesn't even seem to notice the cab has stopped. I hand a ten to the driver. "Keep $7, please," I say. On the sidewalk, Jack says,"I don't understand." I hesitate. It doesn't feel like my secret to tell. Even now, Billy doesn't tell people he's gay. He's never even told his parents, though he insists they know; he says, "In the South, talking about your personal life is considered bad manners." The first time he told me that, I said, "Whereas having sex in truckstops is genteel?" He said, "It's private." Billy has lit about a hundred tea candles, and his apartment looks almost religious. Though it's summer, I sing, "Silent night, holy night," as we walk in. Jack takes in Billy's living room - the bleached wood floors, the pure white sofa, the fresh white tulips - and turns to meet Billy, himself in a white shirt and white pants. The two shake hands, and Jack says, "I wasn't prepared for this." Suddenly, I'm worried about what Jack will say; I feel protective of Billy the way I did of my grandfather when I was little and heard boys cursing in the street. But Jack says, "I think I should've showered more thoroughly." Billy laughs and says that he only invites people over so he can clean up afterward. "Really," I say to Jack, "trash the place." Billy asks what we want to drink. "You can have anything you want," I tell Jack, "as long as it's clear." Jack says, "Martini?" "Olive or twist?" Billy asks. I do the twist. "Oliver Twist," Jack says. "You think that's how Dickens came up with the title?" "Probably," Billy says. "He did come up with 'Master Bates, with his hands in his breeches-pockets, and his face twisted into a look of semi-comical woe.' " They go from English literature to French, down to South America and north to the New Yorker. They disagree on everything, but happily, and I realise they are getting along man-style. At dinner, they ask first-meeting questions, but it's as though they're just going through formalities they're already way past. Billy says, "I hear you're a big wheeler-dealer." Jack says, "I'm more of a wheeler-wheeler, since none of the deals are going through." I am ecstatic watching my males bond. At dessert, Kind Of Blue comes on, and they talk about how it was recorded in a single session and defined the art of improvisation. Jack tells a story about what a slob Miles Davis was, and makes his voice hoarse imitating him: "So what? I play the music. Someone else cleans up. That's the deal." They laugh and I laugh, too, but I get this pang. I remember the way I used to when Billy had men over; I'd pretend that I belonged, even though I felt like a Naugahyde ottoman among chintz divans, and suddenly I am more than kind of blue. I am thinking it is past time to go when Billy excuses himself to get his saxophone. I am having trouble looking at Jack, so I clear the dishes, and he helps. He notices the picture of me and Billy on the refrigerator. It was taken during art school, and we're dressed sort of alike; at a glance, we could pass for twins. Looking at the picture, Jack says, "I can't decide whether you're cute or sick." I say, "I can't decide whether you're cute." Right away I wish I could take it back and I try to. I say, "I'm just kidding." "Very funny," he says. In the living room, Billy begins to play his saxophone, and I say, "Go, cat, go," even though I'm thinking, And Miles to go before I sleep. Billy plays beautifully; he always does. When he finishes I applaud along with Jack, but I think, I am the sound of one hand clapping. In the cab, I pretend to doze on my boyfriend's shoulder; back at his apartment, I pretend to fall asleep in his bed. I hear him brushing his teeth. He opens the refrigerator, drinks from the bottle of water, turns off the lights, and climbs up to the loft bed with me. He puts his arms through mine, his hands on my breasts. In sleep, he nuzzles into me. That's good, I think. But then: He's asleep; he could be dreaming about anyone. This is the first night we haven't made love; that's bad, I think. But then: I'm the one who faked sleep. I remember the muscle I used in order not to know what I knew about Billy early on, and I ask myself if I am using that muscle now. I remember telling Billy, "But we're the perfect couple," and his response: "Except we don't couple." Now, all these months later, I'm stunned not by his words but mine. They echo here in the quiet of my new boyfriend's apartment. When I wake up, Jack is making coffee. From my perch, I look down at his apartment, at the map of Iowa tacked to his wall, the records in crates, the futon sofa, and I think, No gay man could live in such a profoundly undecorated apartment. But then I think, Oh, good, now I'm relying on stereotypes to figure out my life. Then Jack comes up to the loft and sets my coffee and his on the ledge. He lies beside me in his boxer shorts. I try to act normal. I say, "Did you like Billy?" "I did," he says. "You were the one I had the problem with." I feel as naked as I am, and I pull the sheets up to my neck. "I guess I knew that," I say. "It was fine with Billy," he says. "But it might not have been. He's your ex-boyfriend, even if he is gay. You could've looked out for me a little. I would've done that for you." I know he would have, which is just one reason I don't want to lose him. "I'm sorry," I say. "It's okay," he says. He looks at me then, in a way that Billy never has or will. But I've never been more aware of how little I know about loving a man straight on. It feels impossible to figure out and do at the same time; it seems to require eye-hand coordination I don't have. Then he picks up a corner of the sheet and pulls it down. I think only a twisted sister would resist what she herself wants, and I do not resist. I am the chicken who crosses the road and gets to the other side. Mox After dinner, Lisa tells me we need to talk. I'm at the sink. She's at the table. I say, "Sure," as though I have nothing to worry about, as though this talk could just be the talk she was talking about when she said we never talk. I clear the rest of the dishes as slowly as I can without appearing deliberately slow. When I reach for her wine glass, she says, "I'm still drinking this," with the quiet authority I have heard her use with insistent telemarketers and my right-wing colleagues. "Sorry," I say, and then hesitate. In counselling Lisa complained that I seem to speak without feeling; so I ask myself, Am I sorry? I am, though not for taking her wine glass. I let the "sorry" stand. I get the wine from the refrigerator and refill my own glass too full, conspicuously full, as though I know that our talk calls for anaesthesia. No - the less prepared for her news I appear, the harder it will be for her to deliver. I pour the equivalent of a gulp back into the bottle; a sip runs down its neck. When I offer the bottle to her, I realise that I should've poured her glass before mine. "Thanks," she says. I say, "You're welcome," a phrase strangers but not couples use; thank you - yes, you're welcome - no. Although I am trying to remain calm, it is clear to me on some level that the situation is panic-worthy - whatever level it is that makes a man say "you're welcome" instead of nothing. She says, "Come sit down." I would happily wash the pots and pans, but this would come across as my usual ostentatious display of generosity. Instead, I reorganise the dishwasher to make it easier for Lisa to empty tomorrow. I am putting forks with forks and knives with knives when she says, "Max." "Max," she says, not "Babe" or "Honey" or even "Mox", the nickname she uses to tease me out of what she has termed my Germanic severity. "Hey Mox," she said only a month ago, while I was grading papers from my graduate seminar, "why so shtern?" To explain, I quoted from the most dismal example. Only now do I recognise the narrative shift in her tone - from present to past, second person to third; she was already in the living-room-to-be of her future, saying, "I used to call him Mox." Now I think of saying to her, Why so shtern? A joke would be just what she wouldn't expect from me, a joke is just what I need. Instead, I say, "One sec," or I think I've said it; maybe I just meant to. On my way to the bathroom, I imagine her saying, He'd just walk out of the room while I was talking. So, I call out, "One sec," just in case. In the bathroom, I look in the mirror. I try to see my face not as mine but hers - the face she has been looking at and doesn't want to look at any more. I pull at my jowls. I unfurrow my brow. Relax, I tell myself. Cheer up! When I come out, I am smiling like an idiot. I sit down with her, waiting for her to see the open and cheerful man I have become. She's wearing the sweater with the extra-long sleeves, the one I think looks misshapen. "That's a pretty sweater," I say. She says, "I thought you didn't like it." The old me would say, If you know I don't like it, why do you wear it? The new me says, "I love it!" and as I say it, I do. The sleeves are so long that only the tips of her pale, pretty fingers show. She looks like a little urchin, so vulnerable! But clean, too: Her nails are pink and white rimmed, shiny with clear polish. She notices me looking at them, and she pulls the sleeves all the way down. I am the author of this reaction; I am the one who taught her that I notice only what I am about to criticise. She tells me that it's time to quit. She goes on, explaining why, but her voice is just sound to me; I can't make out words. Then I remind myself that I am no longer the man she is describing. I think, I am another man. I am a new man. I am the next man she will love. I change every "you" to "he". Now I can listen with compassion. I listen with love. With my eyes, I tell her that I understand and agree completely. I want to say, You think he crushed you! Wait till you hear what he did to me! But I remember the counsellor saying, "Don't interrupt." When she stops, I say, "Go on," just as the counsellor did. "Please." The counsellor would observe that I am thinking of what to say next, instead of listening to her. As the counsellor, though, I forgive myself: first, because forgiveness is essential to moving beyond difficulty; and, second, because I'm not thinking of my arguments or of undermining hers. All I want is to make her happy. In my head, I ask for help; I even bring my palms together as though in prayer. The phrase We are all God's children comes to me. Of course! She hasn't mentioned children for years; she must have been hoping I would raise the subject, and now I will. I'll tell her that we can have as many as she wants. I will finally give her the joy she deserves! Joy in abundance! Joy overdue! I will tell her that we can name the first boy after her father! We can name all of them after her father! Leo I! Leo II! Leo III! I am trying not to smile. I am careful not to interrupt. It is Lisa who interrupts herself. She says, "Are you okay?" I say, "I've never been better," with all of the feeling I feel right now. © Melissa Bank, 2000. All characters in these stories are fictitious and any resemblance to real persons, living or dead, is purely coincidental.

fields.headline: Wild and whirling words
fields.standfirst: Frank Kermode treads the middle way between high theory and unmediated amateurism in Shakespeare's Language
fields.trailText: Frank Kermode treads the middle way between high theory and unmediated amateurism in Shakespeare's Language
fields.body:
Shakespeare's Language
Frank Kermode
Allen Lane, £20, 320pp
Buy it at BOL

A couple of years ago I asked Derek Walcott, one of the finest living poets in the language and certainly the most Shakespearean, if he found it oppressive to live with the daily anxiety of Shakespeare's influence. Not really, he replied. The more he read Shakespeare, the more he learned by heart, the less awestruck he became. He was increasingly aware of the passages of flat, wordy or obscure verse among the greatness. He had achieved a kind of respectful intimacy with Shakespeare. This is the relationship proposed by the poet John Berryman, who once wrote that to be constantly "incredulous" before Shakespeare's achievement is a little naive, smacking of what Kierkegaard called "playing the game of marvelling at world-history".

The same might be said for Frank Kermode. He has no time for some of the current theoretical developments, especially those that claim to find Shakespeare's reputation inflated or imagined, or undeservedly enforced by the school examination apparatus. Yet he is equally uninterested in Shakespeare idolatry, whereby no passages in the plays are permitted to show signs of haste or confusion, and Shakespeare is petrified into the marble of "genius". You might say that this is Kermode treading his customary middle way between high theory and unmediated amateurism, but Shakespeare's Language is a magnificent book, the honey of a lifetime's visits to the Shakespearean garden, and makes great virtues of reasonable in-betweenness.

For Kermode is bold enough to say that Shakespeare's original audience could not possibly have followed the poetic complexities of his greatest soliloquies and speeches, any more than we are able to follow all of their densities today. Furthermore, there are plenty of passages which are not just difficult but apparently unnecessarily obscure, sometimes muddled as passages of thought or explication. Kermode is especially interested in what he calls the "new style" that began to show itself in Richard II and Henry IV parts 1 and 2 and bloomed into the kinetic, knotted, dangerous soliloquies of Macbeth, Hamlet and King Lear. This new style, characterised by an intense brooding on sets of words and images, at times "takes the poet beyond the limits of reason and intelligibility".

What a pleasure it is to read a critic so learned, so rammed with scholarship, who at the same time endeavours to read Shakespeare as a writer, fallible like any other. Above all, Kermode sees Shakespeare at all times as a dramatic poet, a writer for the stage who lends his verse to his characters. He sees that Shakespeare discovered how he might use analogy and metaphor as the acutest representation possible of a mind engaged in thought. It is no exaggeration to say that, for Shakespeare, the mind is metaphor.

But there are many passages in the plays about which even scholars argue. What hope of instant exegesis has the ordinary listener? Kermode selects a speech from Richard II in which Bushy, the King's favourite, is consoling the Queen and developing a complex analogy about shadows, false and true sorrow, eyes, tears and perspective. As Kermode remarks, it is difficult to be entirely clear what Shakespeare or Bushy is saying here. But the important thing is that Bushy is "thinking": he "has hit upon a difficult analogy and is working it out as cleanly as he can". The speech is "one of a kind not infrequently to be found in Shakespeare, where a complicated idea fails to find perfect expression". Such passages were often censured by Dr Johnson, who then attempted to tidy them up.

Nowadays, we bathe in ambiguity, award each word seven lives and always give the poet the benefit of the Empsonian doubt. But though he is as equipped as any modern critic at teasing out meanings, Kermode has a Johnsonian robustness, and examines the idea that in such passages Shakespeare is trying, and failing, to work something out. "The exciting thing about Bushy's speech is that in it we find Shakespeare struggling with a sentiment rendered stubborn by the circumstance that the speaker appears to be thinking, is doing his intellectual best to get his consolation across, and is getting slightly muddled in the process, the slight muddle being a by-product of the effect to represent intellection."

In other words, Shakespeare's dramatic poetry is an enormous effort to represent the mind. Like Harold Bloom (though Kermode's book is much better than Bloom's recent book on Shakespeare), Kermode sees the beginning of western individuation in Shakespeare, and Hamlet as the great shift in literary characterisation. Kermode is also aware - though he might have pressed this point even further - that a curious paradox hangs from the idea of a dramatic poet using metaphor and analogy to represent the turbulence of his characters' minds. For this means that Shakespeare, as it were, donates his own cherished metaphors to his characters.

In the speech by Bushy, for instance, is Shakespeare trying to say something about shadows and tears and himself getting "muddled"? Or is he perfectly capable of greater clarity, but deliberately muddling things a little in order to give us the most direct sense possible of a mind struggling to express itself?

This is an inevitable tension in dramatic poetry. For instance, when Cornwall shouts out that his servants should bind fast Gloucester's "corky arms", listeners get a characteristically Shakespearean thrill of pleasure at the delicious justice of the word - the old man's arms, white and crumbly, like cork. But it is hardly likely that a vicious aristocrat would have expressed himself as beautifully as this, and most listeners decide for them selves that this is Shakespeare the poet having his say - inserting into a character's mouth a line of unlikely but lovely poetry.

It is, then, always a matter of balance. Shakespeare is supremely at the service of his characters, yet always, necessarily, asserting himself as a poet. It seems likely not that he deliberately muddled things in order to let his characters seem muddled, but that metaphor and analogy have an inevitable, inherent chanciness of which he was fully aware. Metaphor is notoriously open to "failure"; part of what makes Shakespeare so daring is that he is constantly running this risk. (Melville is his modern heir.)

Kermode takes us through the major tragedies and the last plays, paying very acute attention to questions like these. He is a marvellous reader of the way Shakespeare gives different idiolects to different characters and dares to introduce low comedy into tragic situations, even at the risk of disrupting the "high" effect.

It was this mixing of high and low which so troubled the young Schiller, as he tells us in his essay "Naive and Sentimental Poetry". One of Kermode's examples is the Nurse's foolish, repetitive, pretentious lamentations over Juliet's apparent corpse in Act 4 of Romeo and Juliet. An extraordinary moment to risk laughter, says Kermode. Yet the Nurse is just the kind of person who would be "sly enough to imitate the mourning of her betters". In other words, she is comically inauthentic, even in grief, and Shakespeare wants to shows us this. From this kind of contradictory reality is built modern fictional character, and Shakespeare is both its founder and still its greatest practitioner.

Kermode is a great critic of the way Shakespeare bends his poetry in the service of different characters. Discussing The Tempest, he remarks that Shakespeare had to create a special language for Ariel, who is not human. Early in the play Ariel tells how he has left the newly shipwrecked Ferdinand sitting by himself "in an odd angle of the isle", "cooling of the air with sighs" with "his arms in this sad knot".

Kermode comments that this curious picture is just how a non-human might represent a grieving earthling: "The small, sympathetic caricature is a sketch of a mourning human made by one who is familiar with the notion that humans feel sorrows and express it in their own ways." That is so finely observed that one will never again encounter that description of Ferdinand without thinking of Kermode's commentary. There are moments like that throughout Coleridge's criticism; Kermode proves himself Coleridge's worthy heir in this superb book.

fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: Game of patience waiting on Royle flush
fields.trailText: On why the Sky Blues fans are desperate NOT to win the FA Cock-up Trophy this time.
fields.body:
Tomorrow morning the supporters of Manchester City will awake to what they trust will be a sky blue dawn. This presumes, of course, that they have slept a wink all night.

For decades followers of City have been easily identifiable by the bags under their eyes. Do not believe for one moment that the ads for Horlicks invented night starvation.

Manchester City have been serving up regular loads of Horlicks, or something which sounds remarkably similar, since the late 1930s when they somehow managed to get themselves relegated the season after winning the championship and went down, moreover, despite outscoring the rest of the old First Division.

"If there were cups for cock-ups we'd win the lot," declared Francis Lee as City's last spell of sustained success withered on the vine in the 70s. Today City, their directors, players, manager and supporters, will fervently hope that the game at Ewood Park does not turn out to be the final of the FA Cock-up Trophy.

On paper their task looks dangerously simple. Barring a freak score at Ipswich they need only draw with Blackburn to join Charlton in the Premier League next season.

Should Ipswich fail to beat Walsall at Portman Road the effect will be the same but City cannot leave that much to chance. Even now the mere thought of the play-offs will be enough to send the average City fan in search of the Samaritans.

Just over a week ago a 1-0 victory over Birmingham City at Maine Road brought joyous home supporters on to the pitch after the final whistle in happy anticipation of promotion being less than 24 hours away. Then Ipswich went and spoilt it all by winning 3-1 at Charlton the following day.

It is difficult to imagine hardened Manchester City fans, a wonderfully wry bunch, becoming caught up in such premature celebrations. The mind goes back to the last time City won promotion to the top division in 1989. They made a meal of it then.

Needing a win from their penultimate fixture to go up they appeared to have put the issue beyond doubt when they led Bournemouth 3-0 at half-time. Yet even then Maine Road was sceptical. "If they get one they'll get three," the fans were telling each other over their half-time tea.

Sure enough, Bournemouth forced a 3-3 draw and City were not promoted until they had held Bradford to 1-1 at Valley Parade the following weekend. It takes a lot of pa tience to support Manchester City.

All football supporters grumble. As with farmers, nothing is ever quite right. But City fans have been more put-upon than most which is why, with due deference to Ipswich, a splendid club with a forward-thinking chairman and an astute manager, many non-partisans will be wishing Joe Royle's team well at Blackburn tomorrow lunchtime.

Manchester City were in the Premier League as recently as 1995-96 but it seems much longer. In the last two seasons before the Football League split up they finished fifth in the First Division. And on a September afternoon in 1989, thereafter proclaimed a holy day on Moss Side, they beat Manchester United 5-1.

Their last decline began in 1993 when Peter Reid, City's most successful manager since Joe Mercer, was summarily dismissed before the season was a month old. Until the arrival of Royle, a dab hand at salvage operations, just over two years ago Manchester City were a rusting hulk, holed below the water-line and crewed with the expertise of the good ship Venus.

Now the hoists, cables and pulleys have all but done their job. The right result at Ewood tomorrow and City will sail back into the Premier League next season amid much splicing of mainbraces.

Already, however, doubts have been raised about the ability of Royle's team to survive in Premier League waters which are rougher than those in which they sank four seasons ago. Without a substantial and costly refit, it is argued, this City side will be ripe for relegation.

Such comments may be ill-timed and nobody is likely to put the point to Royle should Manchester City get the result they need tomorrow. All that concerns Maine Road for the moment is reaching the Premier League. Then and only then will City and their supporters start to wonder about what happens next.

Yet there is little doubt that, should the close season find City fans anxiously awaiting the new fixture lists, while smacking their lips at the prospect of renewing local hostilities with United, Royle will need to attend many a summer boot sale in order to bring his squad even remotely in line with what is required to survive.

Maine Road may have only a fraction of Old Trafford's spending power but the size of the support which has sustained the team since it dropped to the Second Division, plus the increase in television and sponsorship revenue, should ensure that the side is strengthened in important areas, notably defence.

It would remain to be seen whether the extraordinary scoring technique of Shaun Goater, the First Division's leading scorer with 28 goals, could prompt any emotion in Premiership defenders other than helpless laughter. Good man Goater, but another Kevin Phillips he is not.
fields.bodyText: Tomorrow morning the supporters of Manchester City will awake to what they trust will be a sky blue dawn. This presumes, of course, that they have slept a wink all night. For decades followers of City have been easily identifiable by the bags under their eyes. Do not believe for one moment that the ads for Horlicks invented night starvation. Manchester City have been serving up regular loads of Horlicks, or something which sounds remarkably similar, since the late 1930s when they somehow managed to get themselves relegated the season after winning the championship and went down, moreover, despite outscoring the rest of the old First Division. "If there were cups for cock-ups we'd win the lot," declared Francis Lee as City's last spell of sustained success withered on the vine in the 70s. Today City, their directors, players, manager and supporters, will fervently hope that the game at Ewood Park does not turn out to be the final of the FA Cock-up Trophy. On paper their task looks dangerously simple. Barring a freak score at Ipswich they need only draw with Blackburn to join Charlton in the Premier League next season. Should Ipswich fail to beat Walsall at Portman Road the effect will be the same but City cannot leave that much to chance. Even now the mere thought of the play-offs will be enough to send the average City fan in search of the Samaritans. Just over a week ago a 1-0 victory over Birmingham City at Maine Road brought joyous home supporters on to the pitch after the final whistle in happy anticipation of promotion being less than 24 hours away. Then Ipswich went and spoilt it all by winning 3-1 at Charlton the following day. It is difficult to imagine hardened Manchester City fans, a wonderfully wry bunch, becoming caught up in such premature celebrations. The mind goes back to the last time City won promotion to the top division in 1989. They made a meal of it then. Needing a win from their penultimate fixture to go up they appeared to have put the issue beyond doubt when they led Bournemouth 3-0 at half-time. Yet even then Maine Road was sceptical. "If they get one they'll get three," the fans were telling each other over their half-time tea. Sure enough, Bournemouth forced a 3-3 draw and City were not promoted until they had held Bradford to 1-1 at Valley Parade the following weekend. It takes a lot of pa tience to support Manchester City. All football supporters grumble. As with farmers, nothing is ever quite right. But City fans have been more put-upon than most which is why, with due deference to Ipswich, a splendid club with a forward-thinking chairman and an astute manager, many non-partisans will be wishing Joe Royle's team well at Blackburn tomorrow lunchtime. Manchester City were in the Premier League as recently as 1995-96 but it seems much longer. In the last two seasons before the Football League split up they finished fifth in the First Division. And on a September afternoon in 1989, thereafter proclaimed a holy day on Moss Side, they beat Manchester United 5-1. Their last decline began in 1993 when Peter Reid, City's most successful manager since Joe Mercer, was summarily dismissed before the season was a month old. Until the arrival of Royle, a dab hand at salvage operations, just over two years ago Manchester City were a rusting hulk, holed below the water-line and crewed with the expertise of the good ship Venus. Now the hoists, cables and pulleys have all but done their job. The right result at Ewood tomorrow and City will sail back into the Premier League next season amid much splicing of mainbraces. Already, however, doubts have been raised about the ability of Royle's team to survive in Premier League waters which are rougher than those in which they sank four seasons ago. Without a substantial and costly refit, it is argued, this City side will be ripe for relegation. Such comments may be ill-timed and nobody is likely to put the point to Royle should Manchester City get the result they need tomorrow. All that concerns Maine Road for the moment is reaching the Premier League. Then and only then will City and their supporters start to wonder about what happens next. Yet there is little doubt that, should the close season find City fans anxiously awaiting the new fixture lists, while smacking their lips at the prospect of renewing local hostilities with United, Royle will need to attend many a summer boot sale in order to bring his squad even remotely in line with what is required to survive. It would remain to be seen whether the extraordinary scoring technique of Shaun Goater, the First Division's leading scorer with 28 goals, could prompt any emotion in Premiership defenders other than helpless laughter. Good man Goater, but another Kevin Phillips he is not.

fields.headline: The importance of being earnest
fields.standfirst: Back on track Robbie Fowler is set to lead Liverpool's final assault
fields.trailText: Robbie Fowler is nicknamed God at the Kop. The Liverpool goal machine is at last showing signs of maturity and one could...sniff (pardon the pun) true greatness approaching.
fields.body:
Robbie Fowler does not strike one as a big Oscar Wilde fan. And even if he were, he would certainly not agree with Wilde's suggestion that the only thing worse than people talking about you behind your back is them not talking about you.

Fowler is delighted that the Liverpool rumour mill, which at one time could have been kept spinning purely by stories of his misbehaviour, has not come up with a juicy titbit for the past 12 months. In fact, alarmingly for headline writers, the word on the streets is that at 25 years of age and a father for 18 months, Fowler has finally emerged from one of the world's longest cases of puberty.

It is particularly depressing news for Leeds and Arsenal because if he had gone off the rails again an exasperated Liverpool might finally have pitched him out and into their willing arms. Instead, restored to full health after two ankle operations, he has emerged into the May sunshine to be hailed as the man to rescue his club's European dream and the player likely to deny Andy Cole or Kevin Phillips a place in England's Euro 2000 squad.

After Fowler's excellent second-half performance against Leicester in midweek, Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier is expected to give him his first start for four months against Southampton at Anfield tomorrow.

And the England coach Kevin Keegan, despite admitting that the striking positions are the only ones in which he is over-blessed, says he is waiting for Fowler to prove he is fully fit before naming the 22-man squad for Euro 2000.

This time last year Fowler's exploits were all over the newspaper front pages daily, never mind whispered in the Merseyside streets. In the space of a few weeks he was pictured sniffing an imaginary line of cocaine in the derby game against Everton, shoving his backside in Graeme Le Saux's face and emerging from a hotel with a broken nose after an early-morning fracas.

Fowler, pardon the pun, has apparently kept his nose clean since then. And if he can score the goals that take Liverpool into the Champions League for the first time, it will be a triumph for both the patience and the firmness of Houllier.

When Fowler was suspended for the final six games of last season for the incidents in the games against Everton and Chelsea, Houllier told him that rather than go off for an early holiday he must work on his game in twice-a-day training sessions. "It will be a month of hard labour," said the manager.

Privately Houllier, who invited Fowler to grow up by appointing him the Liverpool vice captain, also made it clear that he had received his final warning. If he stepped out of line one more time he would be sold from the club and the city he loves.

Fowler, who has scored 150 goals in 264 Liverpool senior matches, was unable to capitalise on that extra work, because he has missed most of this term through injury. But experienced Fowler-watchers point out that, significantly, he has returned looking lean and hungry whereas in the past his body might have betrayed the signs of easy living while injured.

He has, of course, a triple incentive: to prove that he is still the best striker at Anfield despite the £11m purchase of Emile Heskey in March; to secure Liverpool's place in Europe; and to play alongside Alan Shearer in Euro 2000.

Few people at Anfield doubt that he is the most natural striker in the club. And Keegan would appear to share the opinion of almost every Premiership manager that he is the most natural finisher in the country.

When Heskey signed for Liverpool, Arsène Wenger volunteered to take Fowler off Houllier's hands. And the Arsenal manager was not joking; he has long dreamed of signing the striker. The Leeds manager David O'Leary also inquired about Fowler last summer, making it clear he would also be interested at any point in the future. And Manchester United's Alex Ferguson would willingly have spent his Ruud van Nistelrooy money on Fowler, but knows Liverpool would never sell to him.

The former England coach Glenn Hoddle once described Michael Owen as not being a natural goalscorer. It seemed a curious remark to make about a man who has scored at the rate of one every two games but, not for the only time, Hoddle was guilty not of a deliberate insult but of choosing the wrong words to express his thoughts.

What one assumes Hoddle was trying to impart, which everyone at Anfield understands, is that there is a broader base to Owen's game. He, like Heskey, likes to make runs down the flanks and drop deep occasionally. Fowler, by contrast, is the classic penalty-box finisher, the Jimmy Greaves of his time or, perhaps more pertinently, the Ian Rush.

Rush scored a goal every 1.61 games during in his first spell at Anfield, fractionally faster than Fowler's rate. But he slowed down in his second term at the club, and Fowler now has the better return. If he stays healthy, one can expect him not only to eclipse Rush's 346 first-team goals but Roger Hunt's club record of 245 league goals.

"The last two years have been a nightmare but I don't think I am injury-prone," Fowler has said. "I have just been too brave for my own good." He is fast learning that he cannot be too good for his own good.

Fowler Owen Heskey Shearer Phillips* Cole

Goals per season 8.7 15.7 8.7 12.7 29 17.3

Goals-to-shots ratio 14% 22% 11% 21% 24% 21%

England caps 11 17 5 57 3 7

England goals 2 5 0 28 0 0

webTitle: The dread before the biggest drop of all

fields.headline: The dread before the biggest drop of all
fields.standfirst: Carlisle, Chester and Shrewsbury stare into the Conference abyss: Paths to glory or disaster this weekend
fields.trailText: Carlisle, Chester and Shrewsbury stare into the Conference abyss: Paths to glory or disaster this weekend.
fields.body:
Martin Wilkinson will never forget the scenes after that Jimmy Glass goal: elated fans invading the pitch, one jumping on the referee; directors weeping in their seats. Wilkinson was Carlisle's chief scout then; a year on he is in charge. "My worst nightmare," he admits, "was to be in that situation again."

The nightmare, though, has come true. For the second season running Carlisle's Football League status is at stake on the final day. Win at Brighton and they can hit the beach. Lose or draw and they could feel like plunging themselves into the sea. The 305-mile trip home would feel that much longer.

"It's the last place on earth you'd want to be," Wilkinson says. "That's a good part of the team talk: make sure you have a nice journey back rather than sitting for hours thinking over what might have been."

Wilkinson sounds relaxed for a man who confesses to waking terrified in the night. Perhaps, after last May, he is trusting in fate. "You begin to wonder," he reflects, "about miracles and whether your future is panned out for you." Last month his side won 1-0 at Chester in injury-time with nine men.

Wilkinson's mail bag this week has been heavy. Some fans accuse the club of not learning: "They're right." Others ask whether the staff care. Presumably the keeper Peter Keen, playing only his sixth League game, has been practising his shooting just in case.

"The ironic thing," Wilkinson says, "is that last year we had a miracle with the goalkeeper. This year the goalkeeping situation, I think, has got us in this problem." The No1 Luke Weaver has missed a hefty chunk of the season. In all, five keepers have been used.

Below Carlisle sit Chester and, at the foot, Shrewsbury. For Shrewsbury the task is clear; they must win at Exeter to stand any chance of seeing in a 51st League year. A little over 10 years ago they were in the old Second Division.

"I feel OK, not too bad," says their manager Kevin Ratcliffe, though he admits this has been the hardest season of his career. He started it at Chester, left them early on at the bottom and has since led his new team to 92nd. On March 4 Shrewsbury were 10 points off the foot with a game in hand.

Two wins (both at home) in 23 games hardly bode well for this afternoon. "Most people are expecting the worst," says Stuart Dunn, football writer on the Shrewsbury Chronicle. The allocation of 1,500 tickets still went in a couple of hours.

Ratcliffe has known tension before, not least in Cup finals with Everton in the 80s. This, though, is different. "Completely different," he says. "It's hard to explain. When you go into a final it feels a lot different to knowing that losing means you will go out of the League; simple as that.

"Usually my last words to the players are 'Go out and enjoy it' but it's very hard to enjoy these games. We've got to make sure we don't run around, all wound up but with no pattern."

If Shrewsbury sink, there will be sorrow amid the joy for Chester's manager Ian Atkins. He played 279 league games for the Shrews and is a "big mate" of Ratcliffe's from their Everton days.

Form suggests Chester will survive. Nineteen points from 12 games is top-seven stuff and Peterborough arrive with play-offs assured and an automatic spot beyond them. The turnaround Atkins has overseen since January, with the aid of free transfers, has been terrific.

"Everyone thought we'd be down by now," he says. "I'm confident and this would beat anything I've achieved." That includes hauling Northampton from 91st into the Second Division and taking Colchester out of the Conference. Someone, by 5pm, will be heading the other way.

A mystery punter who had a £35 bet with William Hill at the start of the season will collect £500,000 if Rotherham and Queens Park win their titles today and Lazio win Serie A next weekend. He has correctly predicted the winners of five divisions: Manchester United, Charlton, Preston, St Mirren and Clyde.

webTitle: The nightmare is over... isn't it?

fields.headline: The nightmare is over... isn't it?
fields.standfirst: Forget all that rubbish about Manchester City fans being happy only when their team loses. The Premiership is in reach and, writes true blue Simon Hattenstone, any fluke will do
fields.trailText: Forget all that rubbish about Manchester City fans being happy only when their team loses. The Premiership is in reach and, writes true blue Simon Hattenstone, any fluke will do
fields.body:
We are on the train to Manchester doing the City conversation. We have been doing the City conversation for years now. Decades actually. Occasionally it results in bitter arguments.

Who's the worst striker you've seen at Maine Road: Tony Cunningham, Trevor Christie or Lee Bradbury? The worst buy: Steve Daley, Steppy Stepanovic or Lee Bradbury? The most heartbreaking moment: Luton's David Pleat dancing across the pitch after he sent us down in 1983? Relegation in 1996 when Liverpool were desperate to let us win but we couldn't oblige? Further relegation in 1998, despite winnning 5-2 at Stoke on the final day? Losing at Wycombe and the train breaking down at Wembley Stadium on the way home? Signing Lee Bradbury?

Manchester City have a massive following, arguably the best. Even Sir Alex Ferguson has called us the most steadfast. In the Second Division we averaged 28,000. This season in the First we are averaging 32,000. Next season in the Premiership we will average 67,000. Well, we would if we could.

Despite being one of the biggest clubs in the land we last won a trophy in 1976. I went to that League Cup final with my dad who missed both goals because he was lighting up. Our greatest triumph came in 1968 when we won the league championship. A few days later Manchester United became the first English team to win the European Cup.

City fans are the butt of endless bad jokes. The nub of them is that we are masochists, that we enjoy failure. A couple of years ago Colin Schindler wrote an opportunistic book called Manchester United Ruined My Life. It purported to tell the story of the downs and downs of a City fan. Every City fan I know hates the book. Not only is it horribly written, it is also a kick in the soul for any true Blue. As Rob Gretton, the former manager of New Order, said shortly before he died: "Manchester United didn't ruin my life. Manchester City ruined my life."

Presumably Schindler thought it would sell more copies with United in the title. He portrayed us as loveable, stoical fans, wryly smiling at our misfortune. What bollocks. We hate failure.

We have always wanted to be the best, the best at anything. A couple of years ago we were voted the top team for celebrity fans (Oasis, Bernard Manning, Little and Large - well, they're famous). We've produced the best inflatables in football history (for a season no self-respecting City fan went anywhere without being attached to a five-foot banana). We've even had the best cross-dressing fans (Boxing Day, away at Stoke, Trevor Francis's debut, two goals, 3-1 win and thousands of Manc bruisers dolled out in the daintiest frocks).

Blue army!

My mate Johnny Bryce is feeling down. He's the one who made me buy a ticket weeks early for the Birmingham match because they'd all be sold out. Now he can't go and he's feeling sick to the knees. I try to cheer him up by reminiscing about City's greatest day. Not beating United 4-0 or 5-1, not winning the championship or European Cup Winners' Cup, but last season's promotion from the Second Division.

We were 2-0 down with no time to play against Gillingham. When Kevin Horlock scored we didn't even bother celebrating. 2-1. The little boy next to me was red and swollen, soaked in tears. He was so broken I don't think he noticed the equaliser five minutes into injury-time. We finally won on penalties.

There was all kinds of vicious talk. The referee was a Blue; he was said to have celebrated with City fans that night. But we didn't care. It was the greatest day because we fluked it. Every time we have failed we have fluked failure against all odds. Gone down in the last minute on goal difference. And here we were fluking success, just like United have done all these years.

It has continued this season. We've fluked our way into the top two of the First Division. We know the team's no good but, for the first time in years, at least they care. And winning games in the last minute after being outplayed is as good as it gets...

We head off to Rusholme's curry mile before kick-off. Past Nayub, Imran's, Mehraj, Shandaar, Jutta, Mahal, Tabuk. Fifty curry houses filled with blue shirts. Girls are walking through the streets lipsticked blue and white. All we need to do is beat Birmingham and for Ipswich not to win at Charlton. And there's no way Ipswich can win away to the champions.

We're ggoing u-uu-up.

Going up, ggoing up, going up.

Mike's got the shakes. He is too nervous to eat his curry.

A bad team doesn't tell the story. Bad teams need bad managers. And bad managers need bad chairmen. We've had the lot. Sixteen or so managers in 25 seasons. Only two chairmen to talk of - Muppet businessman Peter Swales and toilet-roll king Francis Lee. But they did enough damage for 20.

Franny, as we used to call him, came here as a hero, the supreme diver who took us to the championship all those years ago. We were bound to love him. But the day he took over, 30,000 blues were forced to sing 'Happy Birthday, Dear Francis' as he walked on to the pitch through two lines of City ancients. He didn't even put any money into the club. Not the type we needed anyway.

We're City till we die,

We're City till we die.

We know we are,

We're sure we are,

We're City till we die.

And we almost did. In addition to his Maoist tendencies, Lee also appointed his mate as manager. Which is fine if your mate happens to be Bill Shankly or, let's be frank, Ferguson. But Lee's mate was Alan Ball. Now everyone knew that Ball was the worst football league manager since his father a generation previously. He had relegated just about every club he managed. And he did the business for us.

Can a football club have a breakdown? I think ours started in 1996. Every home game we seemed to have a new manager... Alan Ball, Phil Neal, Steve Coppell, Frank Clark, even Asa Hartford. Coppell, a former United hero, left after six weeks, his nerves mangled.

When Joe Royle finally arrived we had more than 50 players in the first-team squad, the biggest in the country. Every time a new manager arrived he bought a new batch of third-raters, but found that he couldn't sell the old batch of third-raters. Only quality left the club. (Oh Kinky, we miss you!)

Joe said he couldn't tell the difference between the first team and the third team...

I think I had my personal breakdown about a third of the way through our season in the Second Division, when we were halfway down the table. If we're going to be so bad, I thought, why not be the worst? Why not go down all whole way, Third Division, the Conference?

Which is why the Wembley play-off was our greatest day. United had just completed the treble and we didn't care. As we were dancing away from the Twin Towers we came across big Alex Williams, who used to be our keeper till his back gave up and robbed him of greatness. Alex is one of the politest, gentlest men you could meet.

"All right, Alex!"

"All right, lads! I'll tell you what." And he burst into song.

"You can stick your fucking treble up your arse, you can stick your fucking treble up your arse... but that's off the record."

He was right - they could stick it up their arse. City had just come back from the brink, which meant more than any number of cups.

We sing some horrible songs at Maine Road; we say terrible things. We call United fans red scum, which is fair enough. We also call them Munichs - as in the aircrash - which is not. But there is a broader meaning to the phrase. After the air disaster Manchester United became the world's favourite football team. Everyone wept and cheered when they got to the cup final the very season they lost most of their team, even City fans. But at the same time as expanding their support, they loosened their ties with Manchester. Today you're as likely to find United fans from Belfast and Japan and China.

Looking round Maine Road, I am amazed at how many kids there are. It was easy for me to be a City fan when I was growing up. We had just won a handful of trophies, we were almost as good as United, on the verge of greatness. Today's kids are the real heroes. And now we're on the verge of greatness.

Actually we were on the verge of greatness against Portsmouth last Easter Monday, but we blew a 2-0 lead. Lee Bradbury, £3.5m super-flop, scored both Portsmouth goals.

Oh Bradbury, we hate you!

City fans are famously lewd and loud. Not during the Birmingham game, though. Joe Royle has told us not to count our points before they're hatched. He reminds us that as a club we've been damned by hubris for three decades. We love Joe. He's plain speaking, abrasive, none of the flash stuff like in the Allison-Bond days. No cigars, just the occasional post-match can of cider. True, he's a dictator who tends to drop players if they show any magic in their feet or a will of their own, but he's a real manager.

The game is tight, niggly, unpleasant. The fans are flushed with tension. We score a messy goal. Big fat Bobby Taylor, signed earlier this season, shuffles the ball into the net from three yards out. Funny how often heroic goals are scored by unheroic players. It's how the mediocre secure their place in history.

We cling on to victory. I'm 37, too old to be jumping fences and stampeding the pitch. I pick up a couple of square inches of turf to take home for Johnny Bryce. There's never been a celebration like this. The whole pitch covered in blue and white - the fans. The same songs are played as last year: Moving On Up (Mike's crying - he wrote it) followed by Status Quo's Rocking All Over The World. The Quo at their worst and we're doing our hips for all they're worth. Wonderful.

From Maine Road through Rusholme all the way to town, cars are tooting, scarves waving , heads popping out of windows. A fire engine passes parping "Du-du-du-du-du-du-du-du-du-du City!" And I'm surrounded by a surreal song from a distant nightmare.

We are not, we're not really here,

We are not, we're not really here,

Just like the fans of the invisible man, We're not really here!

Brycey and Mike hate that song. They think it's defeatist, an unwanted reminder of the days when things were so bad we refused to believe what we were seeing. Now we can sing the song in triumph. The air is warm, the sky light despite the time of night. A man is selling roses, yellow, red and pink, outside one of the curry houses. "Got any blue ones, mate?" asks a passer-by.

Next day I toddle off to the park with football, kids and radio. I'm happied out from last night and just here to complete the formalities. Charlton are champions and they'll want to thrash Ipswich to give their fans the top send-off. 1-0 to Ipswich. 2-0 to Ipswich. 3-0 to Ipswich.

I feel such an idiot for last night. Joe did warn us about being premature, and we ignored him. When we went down from the Premiership in 1996, Steve Lomas was playing out time near the corner flag at 2-2 with Liverpool because he thought we were safe. This could be even more humiliating.

Tomorrow we need a draw to secure automatic promotion. Otherwise it may be back to the play-offs. Brycey reminds me that last season at Wembley he said we'd be back, same time, same place next year.

Perhaps it's inevitable our return to the top is as painful as possible. But return we will. Blue army!

fields.bodyText: We are on the train to Manchester doing the City conversation. We have been doing the City conversation for years now. Decades actually. Occasionally it results in bitter arguments. Who's the worst striker you've seen at Maine Road: Tony Cunningham, Trevor Christie or Lee Bradbury? The worst buy: Steve Daley, Steppy Stepanovic or Lee Bradbury? The most heartbreaking moment: Luton's David Pleat dancing across the pitch after he sent us down in 1983? Relegation in 1996 when Liverpool were desperate to let us win but we couldn't oblige? Further relegation in 1998, despite winnning 5-2 at Stoke on the final day? Losing at Wycombe and the train breaking down at Wembley Stadium on the way home? Signing Lee Bradbury? Manchester City have a massive following, arguably the best. Even Sir Alex Ferguson has called us the most steadfast. In the Second Division we averaged 28,000. This season in the First we are averaging 32,000. Next season in the Premiership we will average 67,000. Well, we would if we could. Despite being one of the biggest clubs in the land we last won a trophy in 1976. I went to that League Cup final with my dad who missed both goals because he was lighting up. Our greatest triumph came in 1968 when we won the league championship. A few days later Manchester United became the first English team to win the European Cup. A couple of years ago Colin Schindler wrote an opportunistic book called Manchester United Ruined My Life. It purported to tell the story of the downs and downs of a City fan. Every City fan I know hates the book. Not only is it horribly written, it is also a kick in the soul for any true Blue. As Rob Gretton, the former manager of New Order, said shortly before he died: "Manchester United didn't ruin my life. Manchester City ruined my life." Presumably Schindler thought it would sell more copies with United in the title. He portrayed us as loveable, stoical fans, wryly smiling at our misfortune. What bollocks. We hate failure. We have always wanted to be the best, the best at anything. A couple of years ago we were voted the top team for celebrity fans (Oasis, Bernard Manning, Little and Large - well, they're famous). We've produced the best inflatables in football history (for a season no self-respecting City fan went anywhere without being attached to a five-foot banana). We've even had the best cross-dressing fans (Boxing Day, away at Stoke, Trevor Francis's debut, two goals, 3-1 win and thousands of Manc bruisers dolled out in the daintiest frocks). Blue army! My mate Johnny Bryce is feeling down. He's the one who made me buy a ticket weeks early for the Birmingham match because they'd all be sold out. Now he can't go and he's feeling sick to the knees. I try to cheer him up by reminiscing about City's greatest day. Not beating United 4-0 or 5-1, not winning the championship or European Cup Winners' Cup, but last season's promotion from the Second Division. We were 2-0 down with no time to play against Gillingham. When Kevin Horlock scored we didn't even bother celebrating. 2-1. The little boy next to me was red and swollen, soaked in tears. He was so broken I don't think he noticed the equaliser five minutes into injury-time. We finally won on penalties. There was all kinds of vicious talk. The referee was a Blue; he was said to have celebrated with City fans that night. But we didn't care. It was the greatest day because we fluked it. Every time we have failed we have fluked failure against all odds. Gone down in the last minute on goal difference. And here we were fluking success, just like United have done all these years. It has continued this season. We've fluked our way into the top two of the First Division. We know the team's no good but, for the first time in years, at least they care. Franny, as we used to call him, came here as a hero, the supreme diver who took us to the championship all those years ago. We were bound to love him. fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The strain of extra-time in a recent Norwegian Cup game was just too much for Olav Fiske. The Surnadal goalkeeper felt the pressure so badly that at half-time of the extra period of the game against Sunndal, he just had to go.
fields.body:
The strain of extra-time in a recent Norwegian Cup game was just too much for Olav Fiske. The Surnadal goalkeeper felt the pressure so badly that at half-time of the extra period of the game against Sunndal, he just had to go.

The problem was, where? With neither team allowed to leave the pitch, Fiske was forced to relieve himself behind the goal.

Unfortunately he was caught with his trousers down, for the referee restarted the game while he was still in mid-pee and an opposing striker, spotting that Fiske had left himself dangerously exposed, scored directly from the kick-off into an open goal.

It proved to be the winner and Surnadal are now appealing against the result, presumably on the ground that the referee was taking the p . . . ; er, mickey.

 When Swansea's Jamaican striker Walter Boyd was sent off after zero seconds against Darlington in November he set a world record. Now Clive Wilkes, the referee who dismissed him for flattening an opponent who allegedly insulted him as he came on to the pitch, has had a weather vane made to commemorate the moment. It shows him brandishing a red card and sits proudly on top of his house.

 Cardiff fans depressed at their team's relegation might wonder just how far the club have come in this their centenary year. A recent programme recalled the year 1910 when players and supporters rallied round to help build a wooden main stand at Ninian Park. A few pages on there was a club appeal for supporters with carpentry and building skills to help upgrade the ground this summer.

 To say that Beryl Owen is a football nut would be an understatement. In the past four years the 61-year-old has commuted 4,270 miles from her Welsh home, braving hail, rain and snow to follow Newcastle United.

The 530-mile round journey to St James' Park takes her six hours on the train. But there she is at home games dressed from top to toe in black and white.

What makes Beryl's devotion stand out is that after all this travelling, that is just what she does: stand out. She stands in the ground's car park listening to the game on her radio because she can never get a ticket to get into St James' Park.

"Newcastle fans create a brilliant atmosphere and when I'm standing outside I get as carried away as everyone else," she says. "I wave my arms about and go crackers. It feels like I'm inside with everyone else."

The merry widow has stood there in all weathers. "I get absolutely soaked and one time I couldn't move for cold." And what do people think? "My family think I'm nuts."

Well, Beryl finally reaped her reward at the recent game with Leeds. She was invited inside by one of the sponsors and given the VIP treatment.

 Two players had to cry off from a Kick Out Racism launch in the north-east this week. But they had valid reasons. Kieron Dyer had to rush to London to renew his passport in time for Euro 2000. And an unnamed thirtysomething international was having a vasectomy that day.

 John Hartson was refused a seat on Eurostar this week; they said they couldn't carry anything likely to explode in the tunnel.

webTitle: Last orders under the Twin Towers

fields.headline: Last orders under the Twin Towers
fields.standfirst: Today's Pub Cup final sees the Vic and Eastleigh battle to the bitter end.
fields.trailText: Today's Pub Cup final sees the Vic and Eastleigh battle to the bitter end
fields.body:
The memories of Wembley Way may be blurred, the Twin Towers appearing in triplicate through the alcoholic haze, but tomorrow's thumping headaches will be a reminder of a dream day out for regulars at two pubs, in Suffolk and Hampshire.

More than 500 teams entered the Carlsberg Pub Cup last August. Today, after an eight-round crawl including a semi-final at Anfield, the bell will ring for either the Earl Soham Victoria or the Eastleigh Social Club - all in pursuit of a cut-glass vase which stands 28 inches high. "How much beer can you get in that, then?" asked one of the participants.

"We thought it was a bit of a laugh when we started," said Mel Aldis, manager of the Earl Soham Victoria. "The nearest some of my lads have come to playing at Wembley was going down the dogs. Now we could qualify for Europe."

Continental competition does indeed beckon for the winners, although the pub teams' European Cup in Rotterdam next month might be overshadowed by another tournament in the Low Countries. But there is no talk of Euro 2000 down at the Vic, where they have even brewed their own Twin Towers bitter - potent at 5.5% - to mark the occasion.

Eastleigh have done nothing in halves, either. Earlier this week they let Trevor "golden scissors" Mitchell, the Guinness Book of Records' fastest hairdresser, at the squad's bar nets. Now all 15 players and their manager are as bald as the day they were born.

Around 4,000 pub-goers will be dotted around the stadium as Aldis and his opposite number, Trevor Parker, lead their teams out this afternoon. By half-time fans from Chippenham and Deal will be arriving for the FA Vase final, swelling the crowd to nearer 20,000. "They'll be thinking, 'Christ, who's this lot?'" said Aldis.

But the pub teams are hardly alehouse kickers. Aldis coaches Stowmarket in the Jewson League and seven of his players have joined him at the Victoria, while Deal beat Eastleigh FC - the social club's Wessex League side - en route to Wembley. "We lost the Vase tie because we knew we couldn't play twice at Wembley on the same day," said Parker.

"We've got two lightning quick wide men," claimed Aldis. A few pints of Twin Towers and they might be wider still.

The Earl Soham outfit earned a new nickname on Merseyside, where the Ferrybridge Progressive Working Mens' Club dubbed them the Tractor Boys. "It was the old country bumpkin thing because we're from Suffolk," said the landlord Paul Hooper. "But then they started going on about Ambrosia . . ."

The Tractor Boys stayed on to see Eastleigh thrash Leigh Athletic 5-0. "That was a scintillating performance," admitted Parker. "The Victoria boys must have been terrified. But favourites? Garbage. It was just nice for it all to come together at a stage like Anfield."

So one of the last fixtures to be played under the Twin Towers will be no pint-sized prelude to the Vase final. "I'm sure we've had more people in here recently," added Hooper. Glory-seeking pub football fans? Surely not. "Everyone will be piling back to the Victoria in the evening. Win or lose, it should be a good night."

webTitle: Awards dinner turkey leaves a sour taste, but that's nothing compared with the sweet and sour in Saigon

fields.headline: Awards dinner turkey leaves a sour taste, but that's nothing compared with the sweet and sour in Saigon
fields.trailText: Following the trail of Man U last summer in Dazza will have pre-season in the Far East. But not in China. He's gonna Tackle Vietnam.
fields.body:
Monday

A crisis is tearing this club that I love apart even as we all watch. Yours truly warned all along it was a disaster waiting to happen and I take no pride from being able to say "I told you so", no pleasure whatsoever can be gleaned by Darren Tackle from putting his thumbs in his ears, waving his fingers around, sticking his tongue out and going "Ner ner nee ner ner." Believe me. I have tried.

The whys and wherefores as to what I am pertaining to is these: Old Demo has announced he is dumping the long-standing Greens pre-season summer tour of Florida theme-park land, complete with team bonding R and R sessions in Beer Mountain, E-World and Hooker Haven (finishing up, traditionally, with a whistle-stop tour through Penicillin Peninsula) and instead sending us on a ground-breaking partnership deal with our new kit suppliers to Vietnam.

Bleedin' 'ell: where? The Man U lads went to China last summer (close enough, apparently) and they filled us all in with the grim details at the PFA awards dinner: crap hotels lacking in the barest of essentials (one of the lads told Wattsy there wasn't even a porn channel in Shanghai); mingin' food ("just try ordering sweet and sour pork in Peking, Dazza," Becksy warned me); not to mention birds what go all coy at the merest hint of a video camera (leastways that's according to Yorkie).

"Nothing I can do, it's a condition of the sponsorship deal," Demo tells us. "But look at it this way: travel broadens the mind."

"Yeah, well, why don't you broaden your mind by minging off," says Wattsy, voicing a feeling in the dressing room so universal even Old Grandad Mickey Scanlan, what can usually be relied upon to apply his tongue to the task of spring cleaning the management colon, is looking choked.

Vietnam. Personally, Darren Tackle did not become a professional footballer to wind up in Vietnam. This is serious enough to warrant thoughts of a transfer request.

Wednesday

You will have noticed I used the words "PFA", "awards" and "dinner" above without comment. Because to be honest, that particular charade is best left not commented on. Except to say that Darren Tackle is man enough to admit that he is hurt. As per usual, as your Roy Keanes and your Harry Kewells was being lauded and larded, the name Tackle was conspicuous by its absence when the gold-embossed envelopes was being opened.

That much I has come to expect, jealousy being very much part of human nature, even among highly honed professional athletes. No, what disappointed yours truly was the completely unnecessary, demeaning and frankly childish list what circulated around the tables, emanating, rumour has it, from the wild and wacky West Ham corner, detailing the PFA's unofficial turkey of the year award. And yes, it is true what you have read in the papers, topping a list of names including Taibi, Silvestre and Sutton was that of Tackle.

But sod 'em. Roll on next year, I'll show them. I'm determined to put humiliation behind me and prove what I am really worth when it comes to awards dinners. This is all the motivation Darren Tackle needs to shove their cackling and sniggering right down their throats. Yeah, next year I'll make sure it's yours truly what sends round the turkey nomination list before anyone else thinks of the idea.

Thursday

fields.headline: Anderton says no to England
fields.trailText: Darren Anderton has saved Kevin Keegan the trouble by saying he will not be going to the European Championship next month.
fields.body:
Darren Anderton has saved Kevin Keegan the trouble by saying he will not be going to the European Championship next month. The injury-prone Tottenham midfielder is putting club before country in order to enjoy a full summer's rest on the advice of his surgeon.

However, it is unlikely Anderton would have been one of England's final 22 for Euro 2000 anyway. He was not in the squad for the last game against Argentina and he has not been foremost in Keegan's thoughts, especially since the return to form of Steve McManaman.

Anderton, who contributed much to England's path to the quarter-finals of the 1998 World Cup, has often been held back due to his susceptibility to injury. The immediate beneficiary of his decision will be Spurs, who are looking for a more consistent return on his £24,000-a-week extension to his contract, agreed in March.

He has been experiencing problems with the achilles tendon on which he had surgery last September and was told by his surgeon John King to take the summer off.

"I hope to be involved in Spurs' last two league games," said Anderton, who is keen to maintain his ever-present record since returning to the side in January. "But after that I am going to follow Mr King's advice and take a complete break. At this time of the season the grounds are becoming harder and that was only going to aggravate the achilles. That could mean I would miss the start of next season and I don't want that to happen. It is a blow to ask not to be considered for England but I am determined to be fit for August. It means a lot to me to be ready for Tottenham."

 Milan have joined the pursuit of Leeds United's Australian prodigy Harry Kewell. The Italian club's managing director Ariedo Braida is in England to find out what it will take to persuade the Yorkshire club to sell.

Juventus, Roma and Internazionale have already been linked with the midfielder but, after his impressive performances in the Uefa Cup and with so many high-powered clubs vying for his signature, his price may well be pushed even higher than the £20m so far mooted. Milan hope to persuade Kewell to sign a pre-contract to join them some time next season. It is understood that he wants to move to Italy but is keen to play for Leeds for one more season.

 Chelsea have turned down an offer from Rangers for Tore Andre Flo. It is the second time the Scottish champions have been rebuffed in their quest to sign the Norwegian international striker. He is valued at about £12m but Chelsea would be looking for a lot more if they were to consider selling him.

 Bristol City's former chief scout and the caretaker manager, Tony Fawthrop, will today be appointed as the club manager. The City board is divided over the decision and the chairman Scott Davidson has threatened to resign. Fawthrop has been in charge since the departure of Tony Pulis for Portsmouth.

 Wimbledon have reported that the club captain Robbie Earle has undergone a further emergency operation on a blood clot. Earle has been in hospital for three weeks after he was kicked in the stomach during a reserve match.

 Hamilton Academical have lost their appeal against the 15-point deduction imposed by the Scottish Football League. The unprecedented loss of points confirms their relegation to the Third Division.

fields.headline: Sleeping beauty
fields.standfirst: You don't expect to kip outside in the Caribbean, especially when you've booked a hotel. But it's all part of the natural high of staying in the rainforest.  Lindsay Baker  reports
fields.trailText: You don't expect to kip outside in the Caribbean, especially when you've booked a hotel. But it's all part of the natural high of staying in the rainforest. Lindsay Baker reports
fields.body:
It is a peculiar experience, to lie in bed surrounded by the still, tropical air and pitch darkness, listening to rainforest sounds that are so clear they could almost be coming from a new-age tree-hugger CD - the insistent whirr of a cicada, the croak of a tree frog, not to mention the less soothing squeak of a bat, and one or two indeterminate rustlings that you don't even want to think about.

But when you wake, breathe in the fragrant morning air, and take in the view from your outdoor bed - the pink dawn spreading out behind the towering, twin volcanic peaks of the Piton mountains that rise for half a mile out of the Caribbean Sea - it's worth every minute of the occasionally spooky night-time chorus. It comes as no surprise to discover that this was sacred territory for the Arawaks - it's a truly awesome sight.

The resort

The two mountains, Gros Piton and Petit Piton, frame a peaceful bay in the south-westerly part of St Lucia, one of the Windward Islands of the Eastern Caribbean, and Ladera Resort - perched 300m high on the verdant hillside of rainforest that overlooks the bay - has made the most of these dramatic landmarks. The resort doesn't go in for air-conditioning. Its 24 rooms are all completely open to the elements and steep hillside on one side (so, not ideal for kids), more like tree houses than hotel rooms - and mozzies are kept at bay with a net.

Built in the 60s as a series of villas by pioneer American architect John de Pol, the resort retains its swinging 60s air - the curvy plunge pools on the terraces and exposed brick give the place a Bond-style glamour - and the breathtaking view it affords has earnt Ladera several film appearances (notably as a location in Superman 2).

It is not the most predictable of Caribbean-holiday scenes. A more usual image is of a stretch of white sandy beach and a large hotel - often of the all-inclusive variety. And certainly, in the more commercial, northern region of St Lucia, that is what you will find. St Lucian poet Derek Walcott has described the proliferation on this tiny island of large, beachfront hotels as "a succession of mini-Miamis", and he has expressed anger that local people do not feel welcome on their own beaches.

But here in the south-west, in the area surrounding the harbour town of Soufrière, "boutique", hillside hotels are a growing, and welcome, phenomenon (Stonefield Estate and Anse Chastenet are two other notable examples).

Ladera respects island culture - it is crammed with locally-made art, furniture and design, and uses all local materials - and it doesn't monopolise the island's shoreline, though guests who wish to visit the beach can catch the hotel's daily bus-ride down the hillside.

Three days into our stay, my companion and I still hadn't made it to the beach. This is the perfect spot to zone out. The odd refreshing plunge in our tiny pool and intermittent scoops of mango ice cream were enough to keep us occupied.

Within walking distance

On the afternoon of our third day, we ambled a mile or so down the road, lushly lined with avocado, breadfruit, citrus and almond trees, to visit Mount Soufrière's hotly bubbling (and odoriferous) sulphur springs and "drive-in" volcano, dormant since 1766. It's a spectacular sight, though it's easy to understand why this moonscape was known, doomily, to the Caribs as Qualibou, or Place of Death.

The nearby mineral bathing pool is said by locals to take 10 years off you. The water is hot, bubbly - and pitch black. We wallowed in it for a while, taking it in turns to enjoy the power-shower-like waterfall, and emerged 20 minutes later feeling, if not younger, then at least blissfully relaxed.

The excursions

Ten minutes away in a cab is the town of Soufrière, over which the giant Pitons loom. It was the capital under French rule - the island has a complicated history that encompasses waves of native conquests and extinctions, the arrival of the Spanish and slavery, long struggles between the French and the British for dominance, and then, finally, independence 21 years ago.

Soufrière's pastel, wooden houses, shops and rum bars, with their traditional Caribbean gingerbread fretwork, make for a picturesque scene, and the imposing Catholic church in the centre of town is particularly impressive. By the harbour, the seaside shacks are weatherbeaten, and bat tered boats bob in the water. We allow ourselves to be fleeced a little by hawkers selling engraved coconut shells fashioned into pots. To spend nothing would seem churlish.

The nightlife

A couple of days later, we venture down the hillside to the restaurant and bar owned by Colin Tennant, the English Lord Glenconner who once owned nearby Mustique. Named Bang Between The Pitons - and known in the area simply as Bang - the restaurant is just that, situated in the "cleavage", as one local described it to us, of the towering peaks. Tennant (he doesn't use the title here) has become something of an institution on the island, and, surprisingly perhaps, locals speak of the eccentric Englishman with a kind of affectionate indulgence. He used to own the entire coastal valley, much of which is now taken over by a Hilton hotel, complete with imported white sand for the beach.

Our evening at Bang, fuelled by red snapper and rum punch, was a fitting finale to a wonderful holiday. Locally renowned twin acrobats from the capital Castris are enlisted by Tennant to perform every Wednesday, and a DJ plays a blend of reggae and calypso to the assembled throng of tourists and locals.

The food may not be quite up to the impeccable cuisine at Ladera, but for sheer, unadulterated exuberance, the evening was hard to beat.

Places to eat, things to see

Restaurants

1 Dasheene, Ladera
Renowned chef Orlando Satchel created the menu, in his absence talented local Nigel Mitchell runs the show. Recommended: shrimps Dasheene, Ladera loco (chocolate rum mousse). Dinner for two including one bottle of wine, around US$100 (£60).

2 Anse Chastenet
This beachside in-hotel bar and restaurant serves delicious West Indian dishes, weekly barbecue buffet recommended. Beautiful setting. Reachable by car or water-taxi. Dinner around US$90.

3 Bang Between The Pitons
Colin Tennant's easy-going restaurant is an island institution. Wednesday nights feature acrobatics, fire-eating, live music and cocktails. A mixed crowd of locals and tourists. Dinner, around US$80.

4 The Hummingbird
French creole cuisine in a garden setting by the sea. Recommended: marinated stuffed dorado. Daily happy hours and special cocktails. Live creole music some evenings. Favourite with locals and yachties. Dinner around US$60.

5 Camilla's restaurant and cocktail bar
In the town of Soufrière, this small, authentic eaterie offers tasty, home-style St Lucian cooking. A favourite with locals. Specialities: national dish of green fig and saltfish. Dinner around US$30.

Tours

1 Botanical Gardens tour
Three-hours, taking in the sulphur springs, waterfall and lush grounds of the Diamond Botanical Gardens. Dozens of labelled tropical species, plus Japanese garden. About 3 hours. Price: US$12 for transport and guide laid on by the hotel, plus $7 entrance fee.

2 Rainforest tour
Four hours around the island's lushest areas of rainforest. If you're lucky, you may spot the national parrot. US$30pp for guide and transport.

3 Horseback tours
One hour around Soufrière Estate, a former 18th-century sugar plantation. Also goes to a sulphur spring in the hills, US$30pp; half-day trip to Malgretoute Beach, US$50; full-day trek, including picnic lunch, US$70.

4 Scuba diving tours
Can be arranged through Anse Chastenet or Hilton hotels.

5 Sailing tours
Four-hour sunset cruise, with captain on board, in a 30ft yacht around Soufrière and the Pitons. US$35pp.

Cocktail of the week

Piton surprise

 1 measure of lime or lemon juice

 2 measures syrup (dissolve 1lb white sugar in a pint of water or similar proportions)

 3 measures rum (golden, pref Bounty St Lucian rum)

 4 measures mixed fruit juices (pineapple and orange in equal quantities)

 A good sprinkling of Angostura Bitters

Serve with plenty of ice, and a sprinkle of grated nutmeg.
