fields.headline: What teens want on holiday
fields.standfirst: Esther Addley  listens in while teenagers tell Cosmos what they should do to keep kids happy
fields.trailText: Esther Addley listens in while teenagers tell Cosmos what they should do to keep kids happy
fields.body:
If Harry Enfield's nightmare character Kevin the teenager was enough to make some couples seriously reconsider having children, his current film Kevin and Perry Go Large, will have terrified many parents out of holidaying with their teenagers.

The film chronicles the stroppy adolescent's trip to Ibiza accompanied by his parents and best friend Perry. It makes a fine comic set-piece, the family holiday descending into misery because there's just no pleasing the kids. But one company at least has decided to take the situation seriously. Cosmos, one of the UK's longest established package tour companies and the largest indepen dent operator, has decided to listen directly to teenagers, promising to adopt their recommendations into the company's family holidays.

It's not an easy task. Teenagers are some of the most sophisticated consumers around: media-savvy, fantastically diverse in their interests, aspiring to adulthood but still in need of security.

Little wonder that Danny Talbot, product director at Cosmos, admits that tackling the teenage market had proved daunting to the company: "We have got it more right for younger kids, but this is the hardest one."

Six "teenage directors" aged between 12 and 17 were invited to feed their comments to the firm's "real" directors in exchange for a free family holiday this summer - and none of them needed much prompt ing on what they would and wouldn't enjoy.

Top of the list for both younger and older kids were water-based activities: a fun pool, water polo, water chutes and banana boats. "Lots of people don't like to leave their hotel," said Laila Rayegan-Tafreshi, 15, from Manchester. "If there's stuff going on there, why would you want to go anywhere else?"

But the young people also knew what they didn't like, and that was the way operators try to "entertain" them into groups. Inzone is Cosmos's club for the over 12s: its "trendy" T-shirt (which all the children had been told to wear) and baseball cap (where each had drawn the line) received the definite thumbs down. "Groups are like controlled fun-time," said Laila scornfully. "Groups wearing T-shirts and hats - it can repel people. I like to be individual on holiday."

So, too, the marshalled activities where children were simply put with lots of others their own age and expected to bond immediately. "It's awkward to meet new people," said 13-year-old Laura Gregory from Wisbech. "If you are having fun, you will make friends. But if you're all in a circle saying your name, it doesn't really work."

Yet all agreed that some social engineering was necessary to get them together with other young people. So how to keep them happy? Younger adolescents, aged between 12 and 14, want activities: beach discos, barbecues, beach volleyball and the frequently-mentioned watersports. The girls suggested make-overs and talent shows, while the boys were keen on computer games and arcades, team sports and videos.

With older teenagers, it becomes more difficult. The word "freedom" was written in capital letters and underlined by the group of 15- to 17-year-olds. They would like to see more activities organised especially for them - "where you wear your own clothes", stressed Laila.

Teenagers could sign up for shopping trips to local towns, non-alcoholic discos ("in real nightclubs") and local water parks. They wanted their own keys to their bedrooms when they were sharing with parents, and a discount to allow them to bring a friend more cheaply on the trip. Once again watersports scored highly, though with more adventurous spin - water skiing, bungee jumping, jet skiing. Karaoke and Blind Date competitions would provide marshalled opportunities for flirtation.

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: FLO CAN GO TO UNITED In-demand Tore Andre Flo can leave Stamford Bridge for Old Trafford provided Manchester United hand over Andy Cole and Nicky Butt in exchange.
fields.body:
FLO CAN GO TO UNITED In-demand Tore Andre Flo can leave Stamford Bridge for Old Trafford provided Manchester United hand over Andy Cole and Nicky Butt in exchange.

PETIT PACKS HIS BAGS FOR REAL! Arsenal's Emmanuel Petit will end his midfield partnership with fellow French World Cup-winner Patrick Vieira this summer by moving to Spain, probably Real Madrid, for £7.5m.

AND THE REST...

Fabain Barthez may be the answer to Manchester United 's goalkeeping problem, but the French international may resolve his differences with Monaco - who had accused him of throwing a match - and stay put instead; Celtic's 28-goal Australian hitman Mark Viduka, Scotland's Player of the Year, could be on his way to Chelsea or Tottenham ; Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov is making a big mistake by going to Spurs, says ex-teammate, Arsenal full-back Oleg Luzhny; Vinnie Jones is ready to become Wimbledon 's new manager; David Ginola, 'frustrated' at not playing for a really big team, could end up at Fulham during a Spurs summer clearout; Peter Taylor may take over as Sheffield Wednesday boss in the summer.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Peak District safaris | Steaming Kent | Huge in Nottingham
fields.body:
Peak District safaris
Land Rover safaris through the least-known parts of the Peak District national park are now available.

 Bespoke tours from £15pp - contact Peak Safari (01298 70524). Mystery tours £16pp (child reductions) - contact Buxton tourist information centre (01298 25106).

Steaming Kent
Steam trains along Kent and East Sussex Railway, a museum line starting at Tenterden, now run 10 miles to Bodiam station.

 Trains run daily until September. Tickets: single £6, return £7.50. Kent & East Sussex Railway, Tenterden Town Station, Tenterden, Kent TN30 6HE (01580 765155).

Huge in Nottingham
An Olympic-sized ice rink makes Nottingham's new National Ice Centre the largest indoor sport and live entertainment venue in the East Midlands. In the next few weeks, Paul Weller, Simply Red, Shirley Bassey and Tom Jones are appearing.

 Open Sat/Sun,10am-12am. Tickets: adults £2.80-£3; child £2.30-£2.50. Skate hire £1. Family tickets available. Lower Parliament Street, Nottingham NG1 1LA (0115-948 4526).

Climbing in Bristol
Everest is one of three films showing at the new IMAX theatre in Bristol.

 Tickets: £6.50/child £4.50, family £19, double bill £10, at the door or on 0117-915 1000. Wildscreen Walk, Harbourside, Bristol BS1 5DB.

Hats off in Stockport
Hat Works in Stockport is the UK's first museum dedicated to the hatting industry.

 Open Sat 10am-5pm, Sun 11am-5pm. Tickets: £3.95/£2.50 concessions, family £11. Wellington Mill, Wellington Road South, Stockport SK3 OEU (0161-355 7770).

The Drayton Manor drop
Apocalypse offers theme park riders a 50mph drop from a 180ft tower, the latest £2m ride at Drayton Manor Park.

 Park and zoo open 9am, rides 10.30am-5/6/7pm depending on weather. Entry for unlimited rides: £14/£10 child, family tickets. Drayton Manor Family Theme Park, Tamworth, Staffordshire (01827 287979).

Glagow's buses are better
Hop on and hop off one of Glasgow's new bus tours on two routes which between them take in most of the main attractions.

 Scotguide's Glasgow Tours run daily every 30 minutes from 9.30am-4pm. Main stop George Square. Tickets valid for 24 hours on both routes: £7, child £2, family £16.

Wind up in Powys
The Centre for Alternative Technology in Powys will put you wise on wind power, solar energy and organic growing.

 Open 10am-5pm daily. Tickets: adult £6.90/£3.50, family £19.50. Machynlleth, Powys (01654 702400).

Sharks in Plymouth
The coral seas display and the imaginative shark theatre are reasons enough for visiting the National Marine Aquarium in Plymouth. Closely followed by the displays on fish and plant life on the estuary, the shore and the deep reef. Lots for children, including free activity leaflets at entry.

 Open 10am-6pm. Tickets: £6.50, child £4, family £19. Rope Walk, Coxside, Plymouth, Devon (01752 600301).

fields.headline: Frozen assets
fields.standfirst: Next year, 14,000 visitors are expected to succumb to the attractions of Cape Disappointment and Exasperation Inlet.  Erlend Clouston joins the cold rush
fields.trailText: Next year, 14,000 visitors are expected to succumb to the attractions of Cape Disappointment and Exasperation Inlet. Erlend Clouston joins the cold rush.
fields.body:
We were not sorry to leave Ushuaia. We were heading south for boldness, rawness, international solidarity and all the other virtues Antarctica represents. The former penal settlement pitted with casinos and memorials to the Falklands War was a bit too brash for our tastes. The four-decked Akademik Boris Petrov, aka the Peregrine Endeavour, was a much more exciting prospect.

At least half of the 14 regular Antarctica tour ships are now hired from hard-up Russian organisations; ours belonged to Moscow's Vernadsky Institute and normally cruised in Arctic waters, hunting oil.

The £1m it cost to hire an ice-strengthened, grade-two research ship for a four-month season provided wages that would otherwise not exist. Anatoly, the sad-eyed doctor who trudged after every shore excursion with a bright aluminium casket of medicines, showed photographs of the Kaliningrad children dependent on his southern exile.

The cabins were comfortably plain, with two bunks, a washbasin, a table, various cupboards and, strangely, a small refrigerator. There was a large porthole which nobody ever dared open.

In the dining room, decorated with studies of Russian rural scenes, we gamely clung to pitching chairs while experts lectured on polar wildlife.

The atmosphere, oddly for a boatload of Australians, was muted. Maybe we were apprehensive: everyone knew the agonies of Scott and Shackleton, and we were warned that our brains would freeze in 90 seconds if we fell overboard. Fur seals, too, would bite, and they move faster than a human clad in rubber boots. The map featured places with names like Exasperation Inlet, Cape Disappointment and Danger Island.

There were other reasons for unease. We were excited about visiting a land mass bigger than the US without streets, towns, cows or soldiers, but we knew we were part of a process that had smudged that innocence. In their defence, the tour operators - who will ferry 14,000 people to Antarctica next year - argue that awareness enhances protection, and they have helped draft laws against penguin rustling.

The first landfall was King George Island, an 100-mile dribble of rock and ice at the upper end of the South Shetlands archipelago where Polish scientists shivered in yellow huts on the southern shore of Admiralty Bay. It was after 10pm and bright daylight when we tumbled on to the inflatables and then crunched along a gravel beach to inspect the penguins. Bleached whale vertebrae were strewn along the foreshore like the fuselage of a shattered airliner.

Next morning, the ship slid past shards of ice hundreds of yards long. Smaller fragments, which sagged into the water, were occupied by groups of penguins who stood impassive as skittles as our 2,800 tonnes shot past. Eighty-five years earlier, Shackleton with 27 men and several dogs pitched camp for three months on an ice raft just like these.

We were in a dream, gliding in a turquoise glow. Once or twice a day, we were counted down the aluminium ladder, swung into the twitching rubber boats and taken to desolate beaches where penguins leered at us like inverted exclamation marks. These were all strange and haunting places. Perhaps the strangest was Deception Island, a fractured volcano crater where the huts and rusting blubber tanks and the graveyard of an old Norwegian whaling station were swamped by lava.

Past eruptions had blistered the hulls on anchored boats, and the water was so warm at the still-steaming shore that some passengers managed a quick swim. A silver aeroplane without wings or motor lay spreadeagled outside a corroding hangar. The air reeked of sulphur.

On Paulet Island, there were 100,000 penguins, letting out the kind of juddering screech a wardrobe makes when dragged across a varnished floor. Grey-furred penguin chicks squawked on the ledges of a tiny roofless ruin in which a century ago three shipwrecked Swedish scientists had sheltered for nine months.

Dogged creatures, penguins: in the ceramic cleft of Orne Harbour, on the continent itself, we ploughed up an almost sheer snow face to a plateau 500ft above the glistening Gerlache Strait and there, on the crags, were a dozen nesting pairs dug in like eagles. Below us, amazingly, a three-masted schooner slipped south, a phantom from the days of Scott.

At Hannah Point on Livingston Island, Simone, a researcher from Jena University, explained that she was using electronic eggs to monitor the penguins' heartbeat when tourists passed. A boulder beside her orange tent was piled high with fossils from the time Antarctica was part of the lush land masses to the north. Not far away, elephant seals lay scratching their foreheads with clawed flippers.

The weather was too wild to land at Esperanza, the Argentinian base where, 22 years ago, Emilio Marcos de Palma became the first native-born Antarctican. Through the raging snow, we counted 15 dark brown huts and nine white crosses on the slope above them.

Britain's Port Lockroy base was built in 1944 to monitor German naval movements in the area, and it remained occupied until 1962 to help with research into the ionosphere. We had expected a large fortress-laboratory, but instead found only an 80ft-long creosoted garden shed.

Inside, it was like an ancient Hebridean shop, where domestic and commercial matters had twisted together. We wandered, stooping, from wooden cubicle to wooden cubicle, poking at old machinery and the sleeping bags neatly laid out in the sleeping quarters.

The shelves in what was probably the kitchen were stocked with Bronco toilet paper, Sunlight Soap and Pearce Duff's custard powder. Its homely crudeness was a reminder of how inhuman a place Antarctica is, something you could forget when admiring ice packs from the comfort of a cruise ship. Even Ushuaia looked better when we returned, pleased to have seen the beginning of the world, and pleased to rediscover civilisation.

Things you may not know about Antarctica

 The name Antarctica comes from the Greek Antarktikos meaning "opposite the Bear", Arktos being the Great Bear constellation above the North Pole.

 The land area is 5.4 million square miles with a coastline of 73,730 miles. Some 98% is covered in ice.

 The highest mountains top 14,000ft. Average altitude is over 8,000ft.

 The Antarctic ice sheet contains 70% of the world's fresh water and 91% of the world's ice. If melted, it would raise the global sea level by 200ft.

 Precipitation is less than 2 inches a year, only slightly more than the Sahara desert.

 Winds can reach 200mph. An earthquake on March 25 1998 registered 8.1 on the Richter scale, the highest ever recorded.

 Temperatures average 0-5C in summer. The lowest recorded winter temperature is -90C.

 The South Magnetic Pole is moving northwest at the rate of 6-9 miles per year.

 The largest Antarctic iceberg measured 86 by 22 nautical miles.

 There are six species of seal (crabear, fur, ross, southern elephant and weddell), seven species of penguin (Adelie, chinstrap, emperor, gentoo, king, macaroni and rockhopper) but no polar bears. The largest indigenous land creature is a midge.

 The Adelie penguin was named after the wife of French Antarctic explorer Jules Dumont d'Urville, who also discovered the Venus de Milo.

 Flora consists of lichens, mosses, algae and fungi. There are only two flowering plants, the Antarctic hair grass and the Antarctic pearlwort.

 Captain John Davis of the Connecticut sealer Huron is said to be the first person to have set foot on the continent at Hughes Bay on February 7 1821. The first authenticated landing was by Norwegians Henrich Bull and Carsten Borchgrevink from the ship Antarctic at Cape Adare on January 18, 1895.

 Antarctica has a human population of 2,000 in summer, 800 in winter.

The practicals

Adventure specialist Peregrine (01728 862 222) organises 10-day Antarctic voyages from Ushuaia aboard the 52-berth Peregrine Endeavour from £1990 per person.

fields.headline: Eastern parade
fields.standfirst: Recent events in Istanbul should not put you off visiting this extraordinary city, says  John Cunningham
fields.trailText: Recent events in Istanbul should not put you off visiting this extraordinary city, says John Cunningham
fields.body:
In a café just below the Blue Mosque, four elderly ladies are lunching lightly. You'd take them for expatriate Brits who'd spent dusty decades in Istanbul; in fact, they're Home Counties tourists on a city break. The previous evening, I spied them in another local eaterie discussing spiritual salvation while deftly placating their flirtatious waiter with cigarettes. Snug and safe, they could have been in a teashop in a cathedral close.

It takes more than soccer hooligans or earthquakes to knock the shimmer off Istanbul for its devotees. Both of last year's quakes were well away from the city. The recent murder of two Leeds United fans took place on the other side of the metropolis from the quarter where most historic sites cluster: this is Sultanahmet lying in the crook of the watery arm formed by the Sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn.

Happily, the worst that generally befalls tourists is the smothering entreaties of carpet-sellers from morning till midnight, or being overcharged in a restaurant. Such minor mishaps don't dim the unique, undisputed lure of Istanbul as the clasp that hooks Europe to Asia.

The history

So much has happened in it, the city is a pop-up history book, or rather a pop-down book, since many of its early layers of history lie buried or are partly excavated. The eyeline that meets you is of a squabble of domes and minarets rising above city walls; waterfronts clogged with cargo boats and ferries; bridges making daring leaps over the Bosphorus and the Golden Horn. And, in May at least, almost as much greenery as in central London.

The timeline is three millennia long, and complicated. But it's useful to remember a few key bits: the Greek and Roman origins; the founding of Constantinople in 330 (by Constantine, of course); the start of the intermittent Arab sieges of the city around 670, which culminated in 1453 when Sultan Mehmet II conquered the city for Islam.

Istanbul has two faces. It presents itself as a holy city, crammed with mosques, some big as soccer stadiums, others just ancient, tiny kiosks. But it's also a maritime metropolis, living by and trading on its waters. However, if you stay in Sultanahmet, which is stuffed with many small and medium-size hotels and has most of what you'll want to see and do on a brief visit, there's no need to cross the Golden Horn (except for the pleasure of experiencing its bridges) or the Bosphorus (except to enjoy one of the many ferry trips).

The guides

The best aren't necessarily from the tour companies. Those I encountered (at around £18 for a half day; £36 a full day) skimped on info, either historical or practical. Their favourite phrase was: "Now we're going to X or Y, where I will give you free time."

Since site-strewn Sultanahmet is easily walkable, you can saunter, stroll, gape and gawk, with Tom Brosnahan (his Lonely Planet guide) and John Freely (his Penguin book, Istanbul, The Imperial City) as informed companions who'll go at your pace.

What to see

There's no getting away from Topkapi, the palace built soon after Arab conquest and occupied by sultans for almost 300 years. It's a sort of Turkish Hampton Court, with endless sets of chambers quadrangled round lawns and gardens. You could easily spend all day there for the £3 admission. But the chances are you'll just want to loll on the lawns after a couple of hours of the Hall of the Halbardiers with Tresses, the Dormitory of the White Eunuchs (not much fun there, after lights out), the Door of Repentance or even the Harem (there's an extra charge, and always a queue).

Mercifully close is Aya Sophia (the church of the Divine Wisdom). For 900 years it was a fabled domed basilica of Christian art and worship. But how quickly even great architecture can be adapted to new purpose! Three days after Mehmet II entered the city, the edifice had been adapted as a mosque, ready for prayers at Friday noon. Now, it's a monumental museum which you can enter for £3.

To see a proper prayed-in building, go to the Blue Mosque, which dates from the 16th century. Its massiveness and emptiness (except for the faithful) are its most impressive features. Both are rather negative attributes, which make it something of a disappointment. It looks at its best at night when its exterior is brilliantly lit, turning it into a Disney-like frenzy of domes and minarets, a sort of mad prayer-factory. Anyway, its touchingly beautiful.

The markets

There are two must-sees. The Spice Market (also known as the Egyptian Bazaar) is housed in a handsome building almost on the waterfront. Inside, everything is arranged in apple-pie order, reminiscent of old-fashioned chain grocers. Caviar to candy, apricots to apple pie. Beware, though: behind it, lies a whole chaos of streets, teeming with open-air stalls with everything from wooden coat-hangers to mobile phones - the full gamut of the Turkish economy, in fact.

The Covered Market is the grandmother of all those arcaded municipal markets, once the pride of all big provincial cities in Britain. Istanbul's overshadows them all: jewellery stores glittering like Asprey's, endless carpets, and caffs to delight any London cabbie. The scale is immense.

The baths

There is one place, hung with beautiful carpets for sale, where you won't be urged to buy; where you'll be treated with indifference, unless you ask. It's a beautifully-restored Lady Hurrem Baths. The galleries were built in the 16th century as baths to serve worshippers at the nearby Aya Sofia. Admission is free.

Even better than a real Turkish bath (several ancient, over-rated ones are in business, for both men and women) is something eerily different. It's the so-called Basilica Cistern (tickets £1.25), a cool, colonnaded watertank built by Justinian the Great in the mid 6th century to sustain the population in times of siege.

Illuminated only by red lamps flickering at the base at a few of its 336 columns, and with a soundtrack of dripping water and electronic music, you can wander safely round in utter tranquillity. If the authorities allowed the water to rise a few feet, Istanbul would have an amazing municipal flotation tank.

The joyrides

For 25 pence (single) you can ride all the way on Istanbul's single tram line, west through Sultanahmet to the suburbs - just to give you a 30-minute taste of their drabness. And for about £3, you can buy a ticket for one of the daily Bosphorus cruises, stopping at, for instance, Sariyer, after 90 minutes or so, lunching at one of the many fish restaurants, and taking an afternoon boat back.

Food and drink

You can easily have lunch or dinner in the small restaurants of Sultanahmet for around £10. Whatever else you imbibe, drink bottled water (it's as cheap as 30 pence). And keep the Immodium handy, just in case.

The practicals

John Cunnigham travelled with Britsih Airways Holidays (01293 723121/1810), staying at the three-star Hotel Avicenna. A two-night break including flights costs £375pp until June 15, £395 until the end of August.

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Online Britain | YHA freebie | Philippines warning
fields.body:
Online Britain
All across the country stately homes and other attractions are peeling back the dust sheets for the start of the tourist season. To help you plan your leisure time, AboutBritain.com provides information covering 500 tourist attractions, including stately homes, castles, zoos and museums. There is also an accommodation directory with an online booking facility.

YHA freebie
The Youth Hostels Association is celebrating its 70th birthday by welcoming visitors to its 230 hostels on May 13 and offering a year's free membership worth £12 for adults and single-parent families, £24 for two adults with children under 18. For details, visit www.yha.org.uk or call 0870 8708808.

Philippines warning
The FO's Travel Advice Bureau urges against travel to the Philippines islands south-west of Mindanao, especially Basilan, Sulu and Tawi Tawi , where 21 people, including foreign tourists, were kidnapped last month from the diving resort of Sipadan, off the coast of Sabah, East Malaysia.

Novel enterprise
Trailfinders, the travel agency and information centre for independent travellers, has opened a new travel centre in Waterstone's bookshop, Cambridge, at 6/7 Bridge Street. For reservations, call: 01223 461600.

Channel addition
Brittany Ferries is to launch a new ship for its Portsmouth-Caen service in early 2002. With a capacity for up to 2,000 passengers, 600 cars and 175 trucks, and representing an investment of £80m, it will be the largest ferry ever planned for Channel crossings. The company is yet to decide whether the ship will be purpose built or adapted from a nearly-new acquisition.

Devils for Tasmania
More Brits go to Tasmania than any other foreign visitors. According to figures from Tourism Tasmania, 20,000 of us payed a visit to the island last year. And the reason? For the wilderness and adventure packages, such as white-water rafting down the Franklin River, hiking in the Cradle Mountain National Park, rock climbing and diving.

Restoring breaks
BCTV, the conservation charity, runs holidays from two days to three weeks, in which you get the chance to improve the world. Projects range from dry stone-walling to restoring paddyfields and protecting rare wildlife habitats. You can choose from locations in the UK, or go as far afield as Japan. UK holidays start from £25 for a weekend; international locations go up to £1,000. For a brochure, call 01491 824602.

webTitle: Colin Prescot: My briefcase | Mobile phone | Breitling emergency watch

fields.headline: Colin Prescot never travels without...
fields.trailText: My briefcase | Mobile phone | Breitling emergency watch
fields.body:
A necessity: My briefcase because I feel very insecure without having my work beside me. I like to remind myself of what I should be doing even when I'm ballooning. I keep my toothbrush and so on in it, but also a file or two.

A luxury: A mobile phone for security, and I could hold it in reserve for when I was really down in the dumps. It's a means of contact with the real world.

A memento: I'm not superstitious or the kind of person who collects things, but I always have my Breitling emergency watch, which has an emergency transmitter built into it. If ever I need rescuing, all I have to do is unscrew a bolt on the side and pull out the aerial and it will automatically transmit to the nearest aircraft within 200km. It also has a built-in party trick: whenever you cross time zones all you have to do is pull out the stalk at the side and give it a spin and it automatically changes with a great flourish and without losing a second.

If only: Something that could change the weather when I needed it and deviate me on to a good course, so that when I get to the other side of Japan and there is a thunderstorm looming, I wouldn't have to ditch in the sea but could carrry on.

 To The Edge of Space, Memoirs of a Balloonist by Colin Prescot, is published by Boxtree at £20.

fields.headline: Just book it...
fields.standfirst: www.thomascook.co.uk
fields.trailText: www.thomascook.co.uk
fields.body:
How many holidays are available?
Plenty, providing you have at least seven days to spare. The range is a familiar one: sun, flights, villas, skiing, over-50s, Club 18-30 and Lakes and Mountains (the tourist industry's euphemism for land-locked central European destinations), flying from everywhere in Britain. What other kinds of holidays are there?

Is it easy to navigate?
Ridiculously easy: indeed, the determined traveller could probably book in less than five minutes. The main drawback is that price comparisons are difficult. Thomas Cook encourages visitors to search by other criteria and only reveals the full cost further down the line.

How much background information is available?
The amount of detail is substantial, and is sourced from Rough Guides and Thomas Cook's own travel guides, taking care to accentuate the positive and eliminate the negative. The copious photography and succinct descriptions are a considerable improvement on bucket-shop sites such as bargainholidays.com.

How do I book?
Somewhat strangely, phone bookings can be made at any time, but online bookings (from a secure server) are restricted to office hours - unusual in a medium that vaunts its capacity to be "always on". E-mail comments are encouraged, but a reply isn't guaranteed.

This site is for...
The families who monopolise Thomas Cook branches on Saturdays and, after two hours' deliberation, settle on the resort with the swim-up bar and £40 discount. Cautious last-minute bookers who will pay an extra £200 to see a photo of their hotel and a description of the resort. Older travellers who might otherwise book with Saga but are happy to pay online.

webTitle: Cool, calm and collectable - our 101 tips for travellers

fields.headline: Cool, calm and collectable - our 101 tips for travellers
fields.standfirst: You've dreamt about it, planned it, saved for it and booked it. But there are still so many things to fret about. Let us ease your worries and make sure that this year's holiday is hassle-free
fields.trailText: You've dreamt about it, planned it, saved for it and booked it. But there are still so many things to fret about. Let us ease your worries and make sure that this year's holiday is hassle-free
fields.body:
Before you go

1 Never take more luggage than you can run with.

2 Always take more money and fewer clothes than you think you'll need.

3 How to pack: take one wheely suitcase, ideally small enough to pass as cabin baggage. Lay out the absolute bare minimum of clothing you think you can get away with for the type and length of trip. Pack half of it.

4 Always travel with a picture of a large English country house and make out it's yours. This works particularly well in the US and can lead to you getting laid.

5 Always travel with someone apparently more appetising to mosquitoes than yourself.

6 Photocopy passport, credit cards, driver's licence, vaccination certificates, even airline tickets and travellers' cheques. Leave the copies with a friend at home who has a fax machine. If you have your documents stolen, you can have a copy faxed to the Embassy - which can issue you with a full replacement passport in 24 hours, instead of seven days.

7 Obvious but important - always take a credit card on holiday even if you think you have enough cash (so that you don't run out of money in Portugal, have to run away from the resort restaurant and live on melon and chips for three days.).

8 Check out whatsonwhen. com before you go away to find out about any interesting happenings in the place you're going.

9 Check the best route from the destination airport into town on the Web before you leave for the airport.

10 Get an e-mail address you can access through the Internet, such as hotmail - in lots of traveller-type places, especially in south-east Asia, Internet access is easier to find and more reliable than a phone.

11 If your mobile phone works where you're going, connect to an update service with your football club, so you'll get the scores by text message while you're away.

12 Take a Palm Pilot loaded up with software from www:avantgo.com to pick up the Guardian wherever you travel.

13 Get a BT chargecard. Cheaper phone calls from abroad without the hassle of finding coins.

14 Eat live yoghurt two weeks before you leave - it builds up a "friendly" bacteria in your system and you can then tolerate more things.

15 Those anticipating travel sickness and who take travel sickness pills, do better if they start taking them two or three days prior, whatever the label says. This is particularly helpful in the case of Stugeron, the brand favoured by sailors, because of minimum side effects.

16 Three days before flying, start using a nasal spray two to three times a day and again during the flight. Your sinuses will all clear up and you won't suffer from that horrible pain in your ears during landing.

17 Take three tablets of Immodium with you: bungs you up for a good 24 hours.

18 Unplug everything in your home before you leave. One of the most common disasters is a fire while you're away, and the most common cause of fire is electrical.

19 Always pack a pair of underpants in your carry-on luggage, just in case your suitcase is lost . . .

20 Remember PMT - passports, money, tickets.

21 And finally . . . don't forget to cancel the milk and newspapers. Lock that small loo window. Tell your neighbours (if you trust them) that you're going away. Oh, and lock the front door behind you.

At the airport

22 Best way to get an upgrade: arrive on the lateish side, don't make a fuss till it's really late and then raise hell. The airline always overbooks on the assumption that some people won't turn up. They stick you in first class. Hurrah!

23 If you're delayed at an airport or have got a transfer wait, you can pay to go into a first-class lounge. Different airlines charge different amounts, ranging from £5 - £15. In exchange, you get free coffee, croissants, juice, papers and even showers. And, of course, they're quiet.

24 If you've got hours to kill in Hong Kong airport, the spa lounge costs $25 but, as well as showers and sofas, has free e-mail facilities, massage chairs for stiff backs and as much food and drink as you can eat (they even give you bottles of water to take on your next flight).

25 Stuck waiting for a plane at JFK? Despite the name, anyone can get a check-up at Dentists for Airport Employees, a facility that serves passengers and employees alike. Call for an appointment (718-656 4747), or stop by room 2311 in terminal 4.

26 At O'Hare airport in Chicago, there's Hilton's health club, where for $9, you can use the club's sauna, steam room, lap pool, and gym equipment.

27 Use a strip of sticky tape to hold down the button on your alarm clock. Otherwise it goes off when you chuck your hand baggage on the X-ray machine and men with guns start twitching.

On the plane

28 If you're flying to the US, ask for a seat at the front of the plane so that you'll be among the first passengers off - that way, you'll beat the worst of the stand-behind-the-line visa queue.

29 If you find you're hemmed in when you get on a plane, listen out for the captain starting his welcome chat, as that means all the passengers are on and it's time to jump up and find yourself a lovely row of empty seats to crash out on.

30 On long flights, take your watch off and don't look at any clocks. If you're not aware of the time, you can just enjoy a glass of wine, watch some films, read some magazines, sleep a little. Next thing, you're landing. And drink lots of water, too. And take ear plugs.

31 Or... as soon as you get on a long-haul flight, adjust your watch to the local time in your destination and act accordingly (ie sleep and eat according to the time zone you are travelling towards).

32 If you're a nervous flyer, try a dab of lavender oil before take-off to quell anxiety and help you sleep.

33 Take a pair of warm socks on the plane; take your shoes off as soon as you're in the air and put your socks on. Feet swell in the air and this helps make your journey more comfortable.

34 Take a jumper on the plane. They're always colder than you think.

35 Drink lots of water to combat jetlag.

36 Try to get a seat at the front of the plane - the air is better than at the back.

37 Get an exit seat - more legroom.

38 On charter flights, buy a headset then take it on all future flights - one headset fits all planes.

39 Buy a pair of noise-cancelling headphones. You can use them instead of the ones supplied by the airline. They don't eliminate all plane noise, but they're a big help. (Recommended: Sony MDR NC20 phones.)

40 When you walk through first class to get off, look out for any goody bags that haven't been taken away - Virgin's Upper Class gives out lovely proper-sized Jo Malone smellies and Cathay Pacific's first-class kit has a fantastic velvet eye mask.

For the kids

41 Make sure you pack that favourite toy. Nothing beats a GameBoy unless it's two GameBoys and a link cable.

42 Take a two-day supply of favourite drinks.

43 Always take a puncture repair kit: be the poolside hero when little Jeremy's inflatable dinosaur goes limp.

44 Check about high chairs and cots.

45 Include Calpol, wipes etc.

46 Get youngsters into a routine as quickly as possible.

47 Take Chuba Chips lollipops for take-off and landing so your ears pop properly. Also good to give to annoying, noisy children. Strawberry and vanilla is the connoisseur's flavour of choice.

48 If you are forced to spend a few hours in Miami International airport between flights with children in tow, take them for a walk along the giant glass xylophone, which stretches between the main terminal and the British Airways departure gates. As you pass by the 20ft sheets of rainbow-coloured translucent glass, you become the hammer that "plays" the notes. It's the most fun you will ever have pretending to be Jean-Michel Jarre. It's free and the sound is pretty and soothing.

49 Warning to the Florida-bound: Disney classes children aged 10 and over as adults.

50 Take the babysitter.

For the fashionable

51 Buy a high-altitude moisturiser (Molten Brown) and apply on the plane every hour (and on your lips) - it helps avoid tight and dry skin when you get where you're going. It also makes it easier for women to apply make-up when nearing the end of a flight . . . therefore, you look better when meeting potential holiday friends.

52 Body Butter from Body Shop is better than after-sun and comes in massive tubs for a couple of pounds, so much cheaper, too.

53 Essential for all women: Think pink but pack black.

54 Sunglasses are good for looking glamorous at the airport for upgrade purposes and also for hiding red-eye after overnight flights.

55 Always have St Tropez all-over fake tan done before you go somewhere hot, so that you don't look English and pale when you go sunbathing for the first few days.

56 Beach etiquette 1: when sunbathing, lie on a sarong, not a towel. Towels take much longer to dry, and sand sticks to them. Not a good look.

57 Beach etiquette 2: after swimming, forget the towel and dry off in the sun - by standing or wandering - before you lie down again. Otherwise sand will stick to your skin - very uncouth.

58 No longer the height of fashion, maybe, but - for women - a soft, cosy pashmina is still de rigueur on long-haul flights. So much nicer than nasty, synthetic airline blankets.

59 A thin cotton sarong is really useful as it can be used as a pillow case, sheet, towel, sunhat, shawl, bag, picnic rug, tablecloth, or, of course, a skirt.

60 Beware of buying cheap silk in the Far East - it may turn out to be shimmering viscose (which you can identify by the way it burns: if it produces acrid smoke and little blobs of plastic, it's not real silk); in Bangkok, resist the lure of the Khao San Road and buy from the Silk Shop in the arcade at the Shangri La hotel. It has a huge selection of cloth and gorgeous shot silk cushion covers for about £2.50.

61 Don't turn your nose up at wheely luggage - so much better for your back. And prim flight-attendant chic is now very cool.

62 To keep your clothes clean, take Spotkleen - brilliant stain-removing wipes from John Lewis.

63 Always carry two metres of thin elastic shock cord, which can be used for anything from a makeshift clothesline to keeping your trousers up.

At the other end

64 Women travelling alone should take a wedding ring - a fake one if necessary - to prevent being hassled. A huge fake diamond ring (the kind you buy in Top Shop for a fiver) works even better, as people think you have a scary gangster fiancé.

65 Mel Brooks in his 2,000-year-old man routine suggested "never travel in a small Italian car". He's right.

66 Cover your Travel Guide so it doesn't get stolen and sold on and so you don't look such a tourist.

67 If staying in a hotel, always befriend (and tip) the maid - she'll have all the local info and gossip.

68 Make friends with the restaurant manager at the resort, learn his name and enjoy the best sea view every night.

69 At all-inclusive hotels, if you want a bottle of water, ask at the restaurant where they will give you them free - in the shop, you will have to pay.

70 Always leave your key at reception in hotels as men will invariably dive into the sea with it in their swimming trunks pocket.

71 If you book a room at a Fairfield Inn or a Residence Inn next door to a larger, plusher Marriott resort hotel, you have full access to the hotel's amenities and room-charging privileges, which can make a huge difference to the holiday budget.

Money matters

72 In poor countries, go to a bank on arrival and get a large number of small-denomination notes. Keep large-denomination notes separate. Keep a small wad of small notes available in a pocket for tips, porters, beggars and all sorts of other people. Once they spot large notes, you will be killed in the rush.

73 On trips to India and Sri Lanka, take loads of Biros to give to the children (plan about five a day). The girls also like make-up testers.

74 In Rio, mugging capital of the world, carry a wad of small-denomination notes in an obvious place - back trouser pocket, shirt breast pocket - so when you are mugged, these notes are grabbed and the larger notes are still safe in an inside pocket.

75 For women, if you're in a really dodgy area and are concerned that you're going to get fleeced, wrap up your money and cards in a plastic bag, then a sock, then pin the sock inside your knickers; just leave a bit of cash and one card out somewhere with your passport to look convincing. 76 Always have sterling or dollars with you; useful for extras, bribes etc.

77 Don't buy travellers' cheques - clumsy and a waste of money - most countries have cashpoints now. (Check beforehand.) And most places take Visa - which often takes quite a long time to come through on the bill.

78 In New Delhi and other large Indian cities (particularly Bombay and Calcutta), always go to the pre-paid taxi counter. These are regulated by the city authority and you state your destination and how many pieces of luggage you have. Customers are then given a receipt and are guided to a taxi outside where they are taken to the destination they have paid for. Don't give any more.

79 Never buy coffee on the Champs-Elysées - go one street away and pay a quarter of the price.

Survival instincts

81 Tropics only: four large jam jar lids. Put the feet of your bed in them, top up with water, and the ants can't climb up and bite your arse.

82 For survival fantasists: carry a square of bright metal with a hole in it. When lost on the tundra, look through the hole at a passing aircraft and the reflecting sun will catch the pilot's attention. Nice idea, anyway.

83 African camping safari tips: if confronted by a lion, stand stock still; if confronted by a rhino, climb the nearest tree; never look a leopard in the eye; and always drink half a bottle of Scotch before settling down in your tent for the night.

84 Cute as they may look, hippos kill more people in Africa than any other animal. If you're out in a boat or camping in the bush, avoid them. They are extremely volatile.

85 A few limes placed around your bed at night will keep the centipedes away.

86 The only foolproof protection against the Highland midge? A pair of knotted tights slipped over the head, mugger-style. Even the most persistent beastie won't get through. Avoid fishnets.

87 If you're going to a malarial country - and that currently includes most of Africa and large parts of Asia - eat lots of garlic. It's not a substitute for anti-malarial drugs, but mosquitoes seem to be as averse to garlicky fumes as we are.

88 Get to see the Statue of Liberty for next to nothing by boarding the Staten Island ferry ( for free) rather than paying top-whack on a regular cruise. You get to see Staten Island, too.

89 When sailing from Scrabster to Orkney on the St Ola, stand on deck on the right (starboard) to gaze at the Old Man of Hoy; move to the left (port) as the boat turns into Scapa Flow to see the sun make long evening shadows over Stromness, a town almost as beautiful as Venice. Sport

Technicalities

97 If you use a notebook computer, always carry UK/US and UK/Continental mains adaptors and a US phone plug adaptor.

98 Instead of plugging the modem cable into the wall, see if you can plug it into a telephone handset.

99 Take a universal plug for baths and sinks.

They think it's all over

100 If at the end of your holiday, you have no money to buy snacks at the airport café, offer to buy someone else's duty free goods on your credit card in exchange for their cash, and then you can go on a munchies raid.

101 If you've got this far and are still worried, then stay at home.

We will publish questions in Guardian Travel and invite readers to send in their advice which we will print two weeks later. Send your questions to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Treasured island
fields.standfirst: Can you take your family to Florida and enjoy yourself without going anywhere near a theme park? Charles Burgess heads for Sanibel Island, in the Gulf of Mexico, and finds that you can
fields.trailText: Can you take your family to Florida and enjoy yourself without going anywhere near a theme park? Charles Burgess heads for Sanibel Island, in the Gulf of Mexico, and finds that you can
fields.body:
The first sight of a squadron of pelicans came as we crossed the three-mile causeway to Sanibel Island. Gliding at door height, a few metres away, a couple of them turned to look in the car, checking out the new neighbours for the week. They looked pre-historic and funny. We were all laughing by the time we reached the island.

The next morning we were out on the beach early, taking a swim in the Gulf of Mexico when another flock glided past, just over our heads. And a couple of minutes later, when I had gone in to make breakfast, my wife returned to say that several dolphin had passed by within touching distance. And wasn't that an osprey sitting atop a lone pine?

We had stumbled across an extraordinarily well-stocked island for wildlife, extraordinary, too, in that it also plays host to 20,000 holiday-makers in the busy winter months. But not many Brits.

Sanibel Island, and its neighbour Captiva, are just off Fort Myers on Florida's Gulf of Mexico. Twelve miles long and three miles wide, Sanibel has 17 miles of beaches and 26 miles of bike-trails, virtually no crime and has easily enough attractions, most of them natural, to occupy a family of four for a week without any resort to television, GameBoys or theme parks.

And we did not see a single big-eared mouse.

What to do

Watching the wildlife is a priority and there are two musts. First is to take the five-mile drive - or better still bike-ride - through the JN "Ding" Darling National Wildlife Refuge. Mr Darling was a political cartoonist by profession but an avid conservationist by choice. The 5,000-acre Refuge, occupying most of one side of the island, was established in 1945 and is stunning. Among the birds, we saw were roseate spoonbills, snowy egrets, anhingas, white ibises, cormorants, little blue herons and ospreys. There was a basking crocodile a few feet away at one point, although we missed the alligators. Remember to take binoculars.

Early morning or late afternoon is best. It is too hot in the middle of the day.

The second must is to explore the mangrove forests from a Canadian canoe - one of those ones seen on the top of American station wagons. You rent a canoe, for $20 (£12) for two hours and $5 for each one after that, from Tarpon Bay and set off following a numbered trail into the waterways of the mangrove forest. We took one child in each boat and that worked out fine. The children thought it a great adventure paddling through the shallows, ducking under branches and avoiding those enveloping roots. Remember to take wide brimmed hats and insect repellent.

The place is teeming with fish. Lots of people go and throw a line off the fishing pier down by Lighthouse Point, a quiet area on the eastern tip of the island. Depending on the season, there are mackerel, flounder, grouper, mangrove snapper, tarpon, trout and snook, around. The way to guarantee catching some fish and have a great ride with the wind in your hair is to hire a boat with a captain for the day or the afternoon. He will know where the fish are. We used Captain John Carpenito, and from the Back Bay we caught redfish, which lurk at the edge of the mangrove, and ladyfish which jump and twinkle in the sunlight when they take the bait. John had all the rods and the bait. The cost for four hours was $250. This may seem expensive but was worth it. While out there we saw tens of ospreys, a bald eagle, some dolphins and a manatee. Both boys caught something, which we then put back.

The boats can also take you to remote beaches for another of Sanibel's major activities - shelling. The fact that the island lies east to west, rather than north to south, means that it acts a magnet for shells - hundreds of millions of them - making it one of the great places in the world for shelling. On any beach you see people walking slowly, slightly bent, eyes to the ground - the Sanibel stoop. Even novices like us picked up an incredible variety. A laminated beachcomber's field guide to the shells of the tropical Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico for $8 was useful. The people out early seemed to do the best, and it made for pleasant conversation. By the end of the trip, we had so many that there had to be a ruthless clearing-out process.

 The JN "Ding" Darling Refuge, off the Sanibel-Captiva road, is open every day except Fridays. Cars cost $5, hikers and bikes $1. Tarpon Bay Rentals and Tours, Tarpon Bay Road, tel: 941 472 8900. Captain John Carpenito, tel: ( home) 941 481 9423, (boat) 941 850 5939.

How to get about

Once on the island, cycling is the best way around and the 26 miles of bike trails make this easy. We hired bikes for the week. Nothing too fancy, as the place is flat. They deliver and pick up the bikes from your hotel or other accommodation. There is only one road on and off the island - the causeway with a $3 toll - and only one main road. It gets very busy at peak times.

 Finnimores bike hire, 2353 Periwinkle Way, tel: 941 472 5577 (www.finnimores.com). Five-speed bikes cost $35 for five to seven days.

Shopping

There are several shopping centres along Periwinkle Way, the main street, most of them with shaded walkways and none of them feeling like an American mall. Shopping is mostly up-market - lots of jewellery, summer clothes, and beach gear. At the centre of the island is Jerry's Supermarket and shopping centre. They do classic American breakfasts in the diner there.

 Jerry's, corner of Periwinkle and Casa Ybel, tel: 941 472 9300 (www.jerrysfoods.com). You can order online and it will be ready for you to pick up.

Where to eat

We had a self-catering cottage so did a lot of barbecues with Jerry's supplying most of the goodies and lots of ready-made salads. There are more than 40 restaurants. Our blow-out was at the Thistle Lodge, which served slightly over-elaborate so-called Floribbean sea-food. A meal for four including one bottle of wine and cocktails was $180.

Basic seafood and a grand view of spectacular sunsets can be had at the Lazy Flamingo just near the bridge to Captiva. Main courses are from $8 to $14. They will cook your own catch and provide the trimmings for $7.95.

There are several Italian restaurants. Matzaluna does pizzas from a wood-fired oven for around $8 and pasta dishes from around $10.

Most places have cocktail bars attached. Booking is advisable.

 Thistle Lodge, West Gulf Drive, tel: 941 472 92000. Lazy Flamingo, 6520 Pine Avenue, tel: 941 472 5353. Matzaluna, 1200 Periwinkle Way, tel: 941 472 1998. Cooper's Cuisine-Scene restaurant guide magazine, available free at many locations, lists all the restaurants on Sanibel and Captiva with menus and prices (www.cuisine-scene.com)

Where to stay

There are hotels, cottages and hundreds of condominiums to rent. We stayed at Gulf Breeze Cottages, a collection of 13 cottages directly on the beach. A two-bedroom cottage costs $1,925 a week in high season (December 15 - May 1) and $1,080 at other times, except national holidays. The Chamber of Commerce has lists of everywhere to stay, plus information on everything that moves.

 The Sanibel-Captiva Island Chamber of Commerce, 1159 Causeway Road, Sanibel, Fla 33937, tel: 941 472 1080 (www.sanibel-captiva.org). Gulf Breeze Cottages, 1081 Shell Basket Lane, tel: 941 472 1626 (www.gbreeze.com)

The practicals

We flew to Miami on Virgin (£1500 for two adults and two children), which is expensive, but we did it at the last minute for the Easter holiday and everything else had gone. Virgin Holidays (01293 456789, www.virginholidays.co.uk) has packages to Sanibel Island starting from £559pp for a week based on return flights, room only at the West Wind Inn and car hire. Children go from £249. Unijet (08705 336336) offers a one-week package for £1199 for two adults and includes return flights direct to Fort Myers, car hire and room only at the Wets Wind Inn. Children go from £335 each.

fields.headline: Contented of Wells
fields.standfirst: A pint and a walk along the beach of the north Norfolk coast are enough to help actress  Amanda Holden  switch off from her TV role
fields.trailText: A pint and a walk along the beach of the north Norfolk coast are enough to help actress Amanda Holden switch off from her TV role
fields.body:
When you turn away from the mile-wide sands and head inland, through the pine trees and past the boating lake known as Abraham's Bosom, you come across a sudden splash of colour among the subdued tones of the flat landscape: a line of beach huts, perched on stilts, on the way into Wells-next-the-Sea.

For actress Amanda Holden, it's the high point of her favourite walk among the marshes, dunes and parkland of the north Norfolk coast.

"They're a rainbow of colour, slightly worn by the weather," she says. "Such a stark contrast to the paleness of the countryside up there. It's a bit of Victorian magic that makes me think of ghosts - Punch and Judy shows and women being wheeled down to the sea to bathe with all their clothes on."

The walk starts at another piece of the 19th century: the Victoria Hotel by the northern entrance to the great stately home Holkham Hall.

After a pint of Ansell's, she sets off beachwards with husband and dog down Lady Ann's Drive, an avenue that reminds her of French country roads lined with poplars.

"Before you get to the beach, the road ends in woods of pine and silver birch, and in the summer you can smell the honeysuckle and wild roses. The beach itself is like walking on the moon, it's so flat and wide, and there are horseriders and sunbathers and people playing cricket, with plenty of room for everyone."

After turning past the lake, the old lifeboat station and the line of huts, they follow the path into Wells along the embankment that keeps the sea out of the drained marshland. If the tide's out, an eccentric flotilla of battered boats sits on the mudflats on the other side, waiting to be painted or photographed beneath the vast Norfolk sky.

A cut past the shops and church brings them to the East Lodge of Holkham Hall and the second phase of the walk. The sea is almost forgotten in the manicured parkland of the 7th Earl of Leicester, where fallow deer wander with the sheep and a huge monument in the shape of a wheatsheaf pokes above the trees.

The drive veers left and you suddenly come upon the Hall, looking magnificent up on the skyline," says Holden. "With the landscape and the animals, it looks as if it's never changed, like something out of a Constable or a Gainsborough painting," she says.

Holden, whose latest TV role is as a self-improving hairdresser in the new BBC1 drama series Hearts and Bones, has become so fond of Norfolk that she and her husband have bought a cottage there. "If you go to Italy or the Caribbean, it takes about five days to relax, but in Norfolk it only takes me a couple of hours, with a glass of red wine and a log fire in winter.

"There are lots of other good walks up there, which I often do on my own. I love it because I find I can get so much into my own kind of space that I don't think of anything at all, and I'm often surprised when I get to the end because I can't remember the process of getting there."

How Holkham changed the face of farming

Thomas Coke, Earl of Leicester, built Holkham Hall, near Wells-next-the Sea, after a grand tour of Europe awakened him to the beauties of classical art. Completed in 1764, the huge Palladian-style mansion is one of England's most impressive houses, full of Classical statuary and fine paintings.

But Holkham's contribution is more than aesthetic: it's partly thanks to events there more than 200 years ago that Britain is no longer a country of fewer than 10 million people struggling to feed themselves adequately and risking scurvy each winter for lack of fresh produce.

From about 1780, Coke's great-nephew, also called Thomas, turned the estate into a showpiece, pioneering and developing many of the new methods of draining, drilling, sowing, manuring, feeding and breeding that created a revolution in English agriculture. The average weight of sheep and cattle sold at Smithfield market doubled during the 18th century.

Coke was following "Turnip" Townshend, another large Norfolk landowner who had shown the way to rotate crops, planting root vegetables to increase turnover and feed animals through the winter: earlier there had been mass slaughter at the end of summer, leaving people to rely on salted meat.

As many as 600 agricultural experts from all over Europe would gather at the "sheepshearings" held by Coke at Holkham to demonstrate how land should be farmed and animals cared for. He showed, for example, how a large flock of ducks could rid a beet field of a plague of black slugs.

The wheatsheaf-topped obelisk in the park was erected to commemorate Coke's achievements, and the story of the 18th-century agricultural revolution is told in a History of Farming exhibition in the porter's lodge. A museum in the stable block has more then 4,000 items of domestic and agricultural memorabilia, and the nursery, in a huge, symmetrical walled garden, has plants for sale.

The practicals

Nearest railway stations to Holkham are Norwich and King's Lynn. The grounds of Holkham Hall are open all year, admission free. The Hall is open on Sunday May 28, 11.30am-5pm; and May 29 - Sept 28, Sun - Thurs 1pm - 5pm. Joint ticket for Hall and museum £6, with various concessions. For more information, visit www.holkham.co.uk or www.north-norfolk.gov.uk/tourism. OS Landranger map (1 inch to 1 mile) 132 (NW Norflok, King's Lynn and Fakenham), £5.25. OS Explorer map (2 inches to 1 mile) 24 (Norfolk Coast Central), £5.50. Part of Amanda Holden's walk is on The Peddar's Way and North Norfolk Coast path, a National Trail from Thetford to Sheringham: National Trail Guide No 15, Aurum Press, £9.99.

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: Spain | Dominican Republic | Thailand
fields.body:
Europe

Spain: A week in a villa with pool in the Ardales Natural Park from Gatwick through May for £425pp. Simply Spain (020-8541 2277).

France: Two night breaks at the Auberge Champenoise at Moussy, near Epernay from £122pp. Price includes Eurotunnel crossing for car and passengers. Eurotunnel Motoring Holidays (0870 3332001).

Belgium: Two nights at the two-star Hotel Asiris in Bruges including Eurostar departing May 19 for £125pp. Eurotours (0870 3330889)

Switzerland: Seven days guided walking. From Heathrow from May 25-29. Sherpa (020-8577 2717).

Ireland : Two-night break in Dublin, including flights from Gatwick, at the Comfort Inn for £189pp. Premier Holidays (0870 7898944).

Zakynthos: Singles specialist offers those between the ages of 28 and 55 a seven-day walking holiday, departing Gatwick on May 24. Half-board at the Alexandra Hotel. Solo's (020-8951 2800).

Caribbean

Dominican Republic : 14 nights all inclusive at the Hotel Seagrape in Cabarete for £529pp from Gatwick, May 12. Thomas Cook (0870 7519927).

Asia

Thailand : 12 nights at the Woodlands resort in north Pattaya. From Gatwick every Tusday and Saturday until June 30. Tropical Journeys (020-7849 4113).

Sri Lanka : Seven nights at the three-star Tropical Villas in Beruwela is £349pp departuring May 14 and 22 from Heathrow. Tradewinds (0870 7510004).

Africa Morocco: 15-day expedition truck leaving Casblanca May 13, visiting High Atlas and oases, for £395. Flights extra, from £200. Encounter (020-7370 6845).

Egypt: A week on a Nile cruise and a week in Luxor. From Gatwick with full-board on the Princess Eman and half board at the Phillipe Hotel for £399pp. Discover Egypt (020-7407 2111)

North America

NY state: Lake Erie and Niagara River Fishing tour, five nights from London to Buffalo, including car hire, boat and guide. From £859pp until June 30. Thomas Cook Holidays (01733 418100).

Las Vegas: Three nights in Las Vegas from Manchester or Gatwick on Delta, staying at Circus Circus for £429pp, until June 30. Funway Holidays (020-8466 0222).

Australia

Northern Territory: 10-night tour including Darwin, Kakadu National Park, Katherine Gorge and Arnhem Land. From Heathrow for £982, June 1. Austravel (0870 0550206).

fields.headline: Ken shows grace in victory - for all of three hours
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone finally ascended the podium in the QEII Conference Centre in Westminster yesterday at 12.20pm. With a brief, businesslike and gracious speech of acceptance, he became mayor of London, concluding a long, disordered and sometimes thoroughly malignant process.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone finally ascended the podium in the QEII Conference Centre in Westminster yesterday at 12.20pm. With a brief, businesslike and gracious speech of acceptance, he became mayor of London, concluding a long, disordered and sometimes thoroughly malignant process.

He stretched out the hand of friendship to his defeated opponents and the government. Since it was so freshly dipped in the magic waters of the democratic will, no one actually spat on it. Not even from a distance; Tony Blair sought refuge in Belfast, which had suddenly become a politically congenial city compared with London.

The new mayor's rivals again heard him offer them jobs in his administration, this time for real. Steven Norris smiled; Susan Kramer looked as though she was thinking it over; Frank Dobson grimaced - perhaps thinking it was the best offer he had had. They were all equally stylish in response, helped by weeks of knowing how it would all turn out.

This inaugurated an era of good feeling and reconciliation, and it lasted a full three hours. Mr Livingstone then began lecturing the government on the over-valuation of the pound and the threat to Ford jobs in Dagenham.

In the old days of County Hall, across the river from the Commons, Mr Livingstone was an irritant to Margaret Thatcher, until she abolished him. In his new headquarters, tucked away in a Westminster back street, he will be less constantly visible to Tony Blair, but far more audible, powerful and unswattable. Thus begins the brave new world of 21st century English pluralism.

The Livingstone approach to mayor-making remained eccentric to the last. He arrived early, by tube (which broke down), then went for a swim. He couldn't keep the "told-you-so, Tony" out of his voice, but his behaviour was engagingly untriumphalist.

Meanwhile, the election itself was ending in a manner in keeping with the main parties' handling of it: shambolic.

It was predictable that the new machines used for counting the votes would cause trouble. Some politicians had speculated that the supposedly slow Brent and Harrow constituency would never get finished in time for the supposed 5am announcement.

It didn't. Its result came nearly two hours after that. But it beat every other sector in the capital. With a 30% poll, the first results were supposed to be available at 2.30am. Instead, there was dust in the hard drive at Enfield; a malfunction at Bromley; a breakdown at Kensington. It sounded like the morning travel round-up.

Too late, it was realised that this election introduced too many novelties at once. Londoners - asked to make a first and second choice for mayor, pick an assembly candidate and then a party as well - were confused enough to make Spoiled Ballot Papers a contender for a top-up seat in the assembly. The effort to make local democracy accessible and popular had failed spectacularly.

Party officials also admitted that the numbers of votes involved meant that they could give the ballot papers only cursory scrutiny, and that they had only the haziest idea whether the figures that emerged were accurate. Since they were broadly in line with exit polls and expectations, they were assumed to be all right.

It all seemed an alarmingly untransparent form of democracy. "In the end, you have to trust the machines," said Jim Fitzpatrick, chairman of the London Labour party. It was trusting the machine that screwed up Labour in the first place.

Since the runner-up, Steven Norris, was the candidate who most exceeded expectations - and was happily issuing coded messages to William Hague about the need for inclusive Conservatism - they did not complain, especially as they had the foresight to go to bed.

However, the returning officer, Robert Hughes, was fairly ratty by midday. In everyday life, he is chairman of the Horserace Betting Levy Board, a job that ought to make him attached to first-past-the-post. While the mayor-to-be dreamed happily, Mr Hughes was stuck at the conference centre, along with the media and the more improbable candidates, who stood around hoping someone would interview them.

When the first results finally came in, these were accompanied by near-carnal shouts of "Yessss", and "Sensational". The noise came from the Christian People's Alliance contingent, whose champion, Ram Gidoomal, exceeded expectations, out-polling the rightwing BNP and Arthur Scargill - if not the Spoiled Papers party.

Since an unauthorised assembly candidate in Merton and Wandsworth had polled exceptionally well by putting himself down as "pro-Ken Livingstone", it was clear that if anyone had had the wit to stand as a "Christian pro-Ken anti-Asylum seeker" candidate, they would have romped in.

The QEII Centre was like the departure lounge at Gatwick during a baggage-handlers' walk-out. There were rumours, but few facts. People slumped across the furniture and tried to kip. Dawn broke; there was no news.

Suddenly, the loudspeaker played a tinny fanfare, like the music from a 1980s corporate video, proclaiming that the first result was imminent-ish. But the obvious landslide, the delays and Mr Hughes's flat voice removed any shred of drama from the moment.

He did not announce the results, merely directed attention to a screen, which then changed before anyone (except the Christian People's Alliance) could take it in. This process was repeated at prolonged intervals - aversion therapy for politics junkies.

Lord knows what the next four years will be like, but Things Can Only Get Better.

fields.headline: Perks of mayoral office
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: As London's first mayor, Ken Livingstone will receive a salary of £84,384 this year and a chauffeur-driven official car - if he wants one.
fields.body:
As London's first mayor, Ken Livingstone will receive a salary of £84,384 this year and a chauffeur-driven official car - if he wants one.

Although his official duties do not start until July 3, Mr Livingstone will be paid from next Monday. His pay will be reviewed in 2001 and uprated annually in line with senior civil servants' pay.

The MP for Brent East already receives an annual parliamentary salary of £47,008 as well as an allowance of £51,571 to cover his staff and office expenses, free first class rail travel and parking at the Commons - all of which he will keep.

But if he chooses to remain an MP, he will be paid only one third of his GLA salary, in his case £28,128, as will the deputy mayor and any assembly member who remains an MP or MEP.

Mr Livingstone's deputy will be paid a salary of £51,743 and the assembly members £34,438 each.

The mayor is not entitled to any severance pay if he is removed from office before the end of his four year term, although his deputy will be entitled to compensation if he or she loses that role other than at an election.

Mr Livingstone's pension and that of the 25 assembly members will be paid through the local government pension scheme. But all pay, expenses and pensions - based on recommendations from the senior salaries review body - will be reviewed next April when the workloads and responsibilities of the GLA are better known.

A spokesman for the GLA said it would be "up to the mayor" if he wanted an official car; arrangements for travel and entertainment expenses have yet to be agreed.

Mr Livingstone will have the use of the £150m GLA offices in the Foster-designed building at the More London Bridge site on the south bank of the Thames, when they are completed in 2002. Until then, he will have free use of offices in Romney House, Westminster.

London taxpayers will also cover the costs of the mayor's two political advisers and the 10 GLA staff personally appointed for his term of office.

webTitle: It's so good to be back

fields.headline: It's so good to be back
fields.standfirst:
Livingstone celebrates election by placing Blair in dilemma

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: An exhausted and emotional Ken Livingstone yesterday celebrated his remarkable election as independent mayor of London by offering the hand of renewed friendship to his humiliated Labour opponents - and immediately placing them on the horns of a near-impossible dilemma.
fields.body:
An exhausted and emotional Ken Livingstone yesterday celebrated his remarkable election as independent mayor of London by offering the hand of renewed friendship to his humiliated Labour opponents - and immediately placing them on the horns of a near-impossible dilemma.

As final details of Thursday's council elections confirmed that William Hague's Tories had gained 600 seats, mainly at Labour's expense, Labour and the Liberal Democrats shared one comfort. Tactical anti-Tory voting in the Romsey byelection produced a convincing Liberal Democrat majority of 3,311 in south Hampshire.

Such a defeat on a 60% turnout, double the disappointing rate elsewhere, is certain to dent Mr Hague's new populist tactics on immigration and asylum as the general election looms, especially when contrasted with the leftwing populism successfully promoted by the former GLC leader.

Hours after the long-delayed confirmation that he had won enough second-preference votes to beat off the Tory Steve Norris's late surge, mayor-elect Livingstone staged a chaotically informal first press conference in his temporary HQ at Westminster.

He used it to announce his title - he wants to be addressed as "Ken" - and that he will be offering key posts in his administration to rival mayoral candidates, including the post of London's "poverty tsar" to Frank Dobson. They had all fought for "the city we love", he explained.

The new mayor also revealed urgent plans to meet two senior ministers, John Prescott and Stephen Byers, next week to discuss Ford's threatened factory closure at Dagenham - an early pointer to the interventionist style he will deploy to radicalise New Labour's economic policies.

"I am overwhelmed that London has given me a mandate against the three most powerful party machines in Britain," Mr Livingstone told reporters before walking through the streets of London cheered by supporters.

Cheekily quoting Sir Winston Churchill's maxim - "in victory, magnanimity" - he explained: "The job of the mayor is to unite all of the capital so I will immediately be taking measures to involve all parties in the government of the city. This process of consultation has already begun."

Speaking from Hillsborough, where he was engaged in Irish peace talks, Tony Blair was equally diplomatic. "Whatever my personal views about Ken Livingstone, they haven't changed, that's not the point. The people of London have made their verdict clear and it's my responsibility to make sure it works for London," he said.

Mr Livingstone is stressing that he wants to "heal this wound, not deepen it". But pressures to readmit him to Labour's ranks will be strongly resisted. Despite his praise of Mr Dobson - his "old friend and colleague has borne a terrible brunt of opprobrium which was not his" - the former health secretary is not for wooing.

Mr Dobson managed a gracious concession speech when his third-place defeat was confirmed, but is certain to say no to his tormentor's job offer. "In a democracy we have to tell the truth whether it turns out to be popular or not," he said. That was a coded attack.

Also set to decline are Mr Norris and the Liberal Democrat candidate, Susan Kramer, whose 28% of the second-preference top-up votes - by far the highest share - was a tribute to her plucky underdog's campaign.

But the real dilemma to be resolved in the days ahead is what Labour's nine members on the 25-strong Greater London assembly will do when Mr Livingstone invites them to join his cabinet or take other senior posts in his gift.

Pending a direct approach to his nominees he named no names. But the Haringey council veterans Lord Toby Harris and Nicky Gavron are in the frame along with the broadcaster Trevor Phillips, who would have been Mr Dobson's deputy.

Darren Johnson, the Green GLA member, is also likely to get something, although Mr Livingstone withdrew an earlier promise of the deputy's spot because the Greens are, as yet, too inexperienced.

Much to Labour's fury, the Greens benefited from Mr Livingstone's tactical support and picked up three assembly seats. Labour's nine, the same as the Tories, are fewer than predicted. Mr Livingstone called it a drubbing, Labour's "worst election defeat in London", but insisted it was not his fault, because Mr Blair had refused his own offers of a deal.

Such talk will make it even harder for the Labour GLA trio to accept the mayor's olive branch - thus risking accusations that it is Labour, not Mr Livingstone, that is blocking the chance for a new consensual politics.

"They're damned if they say yes, and damned if they don't," admitted one Labour official. Downing Street has learned its lesson from excess control freakery in the past and will leave the group to resolve its own dilemma.

In the face of Mr Livingstone's appeal not to replicate the "sterile politics of Westminster", the Labour group in tends to stick together. So will the Tories, who unexpectedly have the chance to wield considerable influence on the £3.6bn Livingstone budget.

Mr Livingstone refused to say yesterday if he will take John Prescott to the high court over his public-private partnership scheme to modernise the London Underground. But he insists he has a mandate to change the plan.
