fields.headline: London's assembly
fields.standfirst: Profiles of the new membersOther Politics news
fields.trailText: Profiles of the new members
fields.body:
Trevor Phillips Lab, London-wide list

The broadcaster, who will be the best known face in the assembly, is well placed to emerge as the Labour leader in the new body.

The presence of such a loyal New Labour supporter - he stood as Frank Dobson's deputy - will provide some comfort for Millbank as strategists contemplate the prospect of four years of Ken Livingstone as mayor.

Phillips, 46, is likely to have a frosty relationship with Livingstone after last year accusing him of being racist and patronising when he offered him the post of deputy mayor while he was still hoping to win the Labour nomination.

Born in London, Phillips was sent to school in Guyana. He returned to Britain to study at Imperial College where he rose to become president of the National Union of Students. Married with two daughters, Phillips is a close friend of Peter Mandelson who was best man at his wedding. He will ensure that the assembly does not lose sight of race issues.

Angie Bray Con, West Central

A former presenter on LBC radio, Bray will have little difficulty in establishing herself as the most prominent Tory in the assembly.

She is a popular figure at Westminster where she was an endless source of gossip during her time as Chris Patten's press secretary in the early 1990s. Since then she has become a successful lobbyist for firms such as Boeing and Thames Water.

Bray, who lives in Kensington with her partner Nigel, is one of the most popular Tory socialites in London.

Their dinner parties in London and their country house in Gloucestershire are a must for leading shadow ministers and journalists attracted by the gossip.

Since the election, Bray has become a close lieutenant of the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, who won promotion as shadow chancellor in 1998 after she launched a successful lobbying campaign on his behalf.

She and her partner recently survived a horrific car crash on their way back to London from their country house.

Lady (Sally) Hamwee Lib Dem, London list

As Susan Kramer's deputy in the mayoral contest, Hamwee is likely to emerge as the leader of the Lib Dem group in the new assembly.

A stalwart of the London party for nearly 30 years - she has been a Richmond councillor since 1978 - Hamwee was rewarded with a peerage by Paddy Ashdown in 1991. In her manifesto Hamwee, 53, promised to be a "critical friend" of the mayor. "Old-style confrontational politics won't work," she said. "But members must stand up to the mayor if necessary."

A solicitor with the entertainment and media firm of solicitors Clintons, Hamwee is the Lib Dems' environment spokeswoman in the House of Lords. She won her spurs as a party activist by camnpaigning on grassroots issues. In her manifesto she boasts of widening a level crossing for pedestrians, clearing up litter - "and donning rubber gloves to do it" - and restricting lorries.

Darren Johnson Green, London list

Johnson, who ran a strong campaign in the mayoral race, will be one of the liveliest members of the assembly. The PhD student will invigorate proceedings with his plans to impose a 20mph speed limit across London and a daily £10 charge on motorists to drive into town.

During the election Johnson, 33, has liaised closely with Ken Livingstone who may at some time make him his deputy or award him the environment portfolio. Until he stood as the Green candidate for mayor, his great est claim to fame was his successful infiltration of the military base at Aldershot, dressed as Ivan the Terrible, during an arms fair.

The guards were so taken by Johnson that they saluted him as he drove through the gates in a large limousine with tinted windows. "I looked the part so they just waved me through," he recalls. "Then I took out all these briefcases full of Monopoly money and tried to buy weapons."

Lord (Toby) Harris of Haringey Lab, Brent and Harrow

Harris, 46, will be one of the key Labour figures in the assembly who will be relied on by Downing Street to try to rein in Ken Livingstone.

As chairman of the Association of London Government and leader of Haringey council since 1987, Harris is a Blairite loyalist who was rewarded with a life peerage in 1998.

Throughout the election campaign the Labour peer has gone to great lengths to present himself as plain Toby Harris, to the amusement of the Tories who have insisted on referring to him by his formal title.

Married with two teenage sons and a baby daughter, Harris has lived in London all his life and has served as a Labour councillor since 1978. He was director of the Association of Community Health Councils from 1987-1998.

Although loyal to the party leadership, Harris played a leading role in the House of Lords in forcing the government to abandon its plan for a £10,000 bond for Asian visitors to Britain.

Bob Neill Con, Bexley and Bromley

Neill will be forgiven for feeling a tinge of nostalgia when he takes up his seat in the assembly - he is one of the few members who served in the old Greater London council. A bachelor who lives on the Isle of Dogs, Neill says he will keep a close eye on the new mayor: "The key issues are to ensure that the GLA is a value-for-money authority for London."

Neill, 47, also promises to champion the London suburbs in the assembly to confront the perceived "zone one" outlook of Ken Livingstone. "I want to make sure it is a proper voice for the outer London boroughs and the suburbs - which the GLC was not," he says. "One of the key issues is transport and I want a fare deal for rail users coming into London from the suburbs. I am talking Connex here, not buses and tubes. I am also totally against penalising motorists."

 Brian Coleman, Con, Barnet and Camden a lifelong Barnet resident who is a local councillor. Strong supporter of local grammar schools.

 Richard Barnes, Con, Ealing and Hillingdon, is the former leader of Hillingdon council. A multi-linguist, he works as a volunteer with victims of Aids.

 Andrew Pelling, Con, Croydon and Sutton, the deputy leader of the Tory group on Croydon council, has pledged to ensure that the GLA does not become a "GLC mark two".

 Elizabeth Howlett, Con, Merton and Wandsworth, a former international opera singer who is a professor at the Royal College of Music. A Wandsworth councillor since 1986.

 Tony Arbour, Con, South West, is a senior lecturer at Kingston University business school. Married with three sons and a daughter, he lives in Teddington.

 Roger Evans, Con, Havering and Redbridge, a former Royal Mail manager who now works as a barrister. Has served as a councillor in east London for the past 10 years.

 Eric Ollerenshaw, Con, London list, is the leader of Hackney council's Tory group. Works in education.

 John Biggs, Lab, City and East, who lives in Stepney with his wife and daughter, worked in the City for six years before becoming a full-time councillor and council leader in Tower Hamlets.

 Nicky Gavron, Lab, Enfield and Haringey, has worked with community groups across London for 30 years. She has recently been appointed by John Prescott to the independent commission for integrated transport.

 Len Duvall, Lab, Greenwich and Lewisham, a Greenwich councillor since 1990, is deputy chair of the Association of London Government. Duvall is a non-executive director of the New Millennium Experience Company.

 Val Shawcross, Lab, Lambeth and Southwark, is a former leader of Croydon council who used to work for the Commonwealth secretariat. She is a former national women's officer for the Labour party.

 Meg Hillier, Lab, North East, a journalist who has also served in the merchant navy, is a Labour councillor in Islington, serving last year as the borough's youngest ever mayor. She has a young baby.

Samantha Heath, Lab, London list, runs her own business, is a lecturer in design and construction management at the University of Greenwich and is a Wandsworth councillor.

 David Lammy, Lab, London list, became the youngest qualifying barrister in England in 1994. In 1996, he became the first black Briton to attend Harvard Law School.

 Lord (Graham) Tope, Lib Dem, top-up list, shot to fame at the age of 29 in 1972 when he won the Sutton and Cheam byelection for the Liberals. Now the Lib Dem leader on the Association of London Government.

 Lynne Featherstone, Lib Dem, London list, is the leader of the opposition on Haringey council. Director of an electrical business.

 Louise Bloom, Lib Dem, top-up list, is vice chairwoman of the Green Lib Dems. A school governor with two daughters, Bloom takes a strong interest in disability issues.

 Victor Anderson, Green, top-up list, works at the House of Commons as a researcher for Plaid Cymru. Anderson started campaigning on Green issues in the early 1970s as a roads protester.

 Jenny Jones, Green, London list, is a financial controller with a London business, and an archaeologist who has worked in the Middle East.

Relations between mayor and assembly

Labour will no doubt be tempted by the prospect of a fight with Ken Livingstone in the assembly.

However, the government has ensured, through the bill that set up the GLA, that it will be in the interests of both the mayor and the 25-member assembly to achieve a consensus.

Mr Livingstone will have a strong hold over the assembly because he enjoys enviable powers of patronage. He has the power to choose a deputy, who will chair the new police authority, and the right to nominate members of the boards to run the GLA's various services. Mr Livingstone has said that he would like to rotate the deputy's job among the main parties.

For its part, the assembly has powers to rein in Mr Livingstone. It can call him to account and, in an extreme case, it can block his budget.

This will be difficult because the assembly can only block the budget with a two-thirds majority, and no party has an overall majority. The assembly would also have to agree its own replacement budget.

All sides will agree on one thing: they will all be paid handsomely. Mr Livingstone will earn £75,136, his deputy will earn £51,743 and the assembly members will each earn £34,438.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Ibiza

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Ibiza
fields.standfirst: Colin Butts
fields.trailText: Colin Butts
fields.body:
I first went there in 1983 on a twenties holiday with a friend because it was cheap. Three years later, I was back working as a holiday rep. I was there when the whole Ibiza clubbing scene was developing. Being in Ibiza is like pushing the pause button on your life; the only worry is that one day you will have to return to the real world or make Ibiza your life.

The moment when I really fell in love with Ibiza was when I realised that the only decisions I had to make were which beach to go to, which bar I was going to get drunk in and I had none of the responsibilities I had in England. I love the laid-back café society in Ibiza. I had a birthday over there and a friend lent me the zoo he used to own. So a whole group of us, from all sorts of backgrounds, gathered around his pool and chilled out. We took three or four hours over lunch, had a few bottles of wine and watched the world go by.

I see Ibiza as rather like having a love affair. It can be painful seeing an ex-lover doing things you once enjoyed doing together. I now look at Ibiza rather like that: it's moved on, has new people and I've just become boring. You can't moan about Ibiza not being like it used to be; it's just changed. The pelloutes, which is what the Spanish called the 1960s hippies and draft dodgers, found different things than I did and the people who come now. I suppose my main complaint is that now everything is being thrust in your face and it is hard to just discover Ibiza for yourself.

How do I get there? Airtours (08701 577775) offers seven nights' self-catering in the Playa Bella apartments in San Antonio, departing Gatwick on May 22, for £179pp based on two sharing. Thomson (0990 502555) offers seven nights in the Fiesta Palmyra apartments in San Antonio, departing Gatwick from May 8, for £225 based on four sharing a studio.

 Is Harry on the Boat?, Colin Butts' novel about holiday reps in Ibiza, is published by Orion at £5.99.

fields.headline: Web woes
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... controversial material on our website
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... controversial material on our website
fields.body:
Discussion at two of the editor's morning conferences this week was dominated by the way in which recent events had been covered on our website. Firstly, concern was raised about an audio tape, which we made available from 2.30pm on Monday, describing - somewhat ahead of our rivals - the wrecking of McDonald's restaurant in Whitehall.

This had been fed in over a mobile telephone by a freelance journalist dispatched by us to report the May Day demonstrations. His account was recorded and put on the website after only a brief delay. It was followed later by a link to video material provided by an organisation called Undercurrents.

Among the questions raised at the conference, by someone who had not seen or heard any of this material at that time, were: are we confident that we are not appearing to condone criminal activity?; did we know, and did we tell visitors to the website, exactly where the material was coming from?

The reporter, who provided what was in fact a perfectly straightforward description of the attack on McDonald's, works frequently for the Guardian and is respected as a conscientious and trustworthy contributor. The principal merit of his commentary was its immediacy. The quality of the sound was poor and the tape would not have been considered broadcastable by, say, the BBC, but the piece suggested no reason whatsoever for questioning the motivation of the reporter.

To come to the video, Undercurrents describes itself as an alternative news organisation and uses the slogan: "Stop drinking from the mainstream." Its starting point is frustration at what it calls the established media's "lack of concern and analysis in reporting environmental and social issues". Its video footage is supplied by "activists at the forefront of local and global campaigns". It is perfectly frank about which side it is on and we also made that clear in our link to its video of the demonstrations.

There is no ethical problem with the use of either the audio or the video tapes in this way. Access to both of them was in the context of the Guardian's own substantial reporting of the demonstrations and the link to the Undercurrents video, material not originated by the Guardian, was clearly labelled.

The following day, the editor's conference spent some time debating another issue. Two staff journalists and later others raised strong objections to the presence on our website of the Diary of a British Nationalist. This was the British National Party's candidate for the London mayoral election, Michael Newland.

There was no contextual material to speak of with this. It was one of more than 20 quite disparate items included in a new feature called the weblog. A note explained that the weblog was in two parts: selected articles from current issues of the Guardian's partner publications, and "daily tips from around the web". Newland's diary fell in this section.

An introductory blurb "About the weblog" said: "Guardian Unlimited is working with some of the world's finest publications to bring you the most interesting and noteworthy online journalism." To those who were objecting to the inclusion of this item, the blurb added to the offence by appearing, in their view, to commend the various pieces, including Newland's diary, to our website users.

The editor of the website defended his decision to include the piece in the weblog. He pointed out that the weblog now carried an additional note, similar to that on the BBC website, saying, "We cannot accept responsibility for the content of external pages."

He argued that political debate was the currency of the Guardian, the BNP was a legal party participating in the elections and it was important that intelligent people had the opportunity to make up their own minds. The brief introduction to the diary said, in part, "Michael Newland... keeps an illuminating campaign diary online, offering sometimes offensive but mostly self-revealing insights into his party's extremist politics."

I suggested that there should be some distinction between links that were provided from within the context of Guardian reports and links, such as this one to a BNP site, which were provided with no surrounding context. The editor of the paper agreed that there was, in this case, at the least a presentation problem. The labelling on the piece should be made stronger, or it should be taken down.

As I write, on Wednesday evening, the following words have been added to the introduction to the diary: "Judge for yourself how much it [the BNP] has changed." This is not enough to satisfy most of the objectors. They believe that rather than shining a bright light into a dark corner we are helping the BNP to enhance its credibility. I agree with that.

 Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020 7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020 7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Bohemian rhapsodies
fields.standfirst: The Prague Spring international music festival opens next week.  David Ward knows the score
fields.trailText: The Prague Spring international music festival opens next week. David Ward knows the score.
fields.body:
I spied her in the interval, leaning miserably against a door and gazing out of the window. Around her milled concert-going Czechs sipping Bohemian sekt (sparkling wine) at 75p a glass.

I knew she was unhappy because I had sat next to her in the first half of the sober Dvorak Hall of the Rudolfinum, Prague's main concert venue. Locked in some private misery, she had not responded to quartets by Beethoven and Prokofiev, despite committed playing from the American Borromeo Quartet. For her, the Prague Spring, the city's annual music festival, had become deep winter.

Her boyfriend kept trying to hold her hand, but she wouldn't let him; perhaps he was her problem.

Things did not get better after the interval, when Josef Suk, Dvorak's grandson, joined the quartet for Dvorak's string quintet op 97. (I later bought a Supraphon CD of the piece at the Bonton megastore at the bottom of Wenceslas Square; Supraphons are very cheap in Prague.)

The quintet is warm and smiling, full of Dvorak's American tunes, which are not American at all.

We had two encores and I caught two trams home, hoping the pair might solve their problems on a May night too balmy for arguments. Perhaps they walked together over Charles Bridge, dropped down the steps on to the island called Kampa and fell into each other's arms in a quiet byway near the Maltese Gardens.

Or perhaps next day they wandered off to Nové Mesto (New Town) to find the Villa Amerika, a house that honours Dvorak even though he never lived there. They could have moved together through the house, admiring the composer's trilby, stiff cuffs and hanky embroidered with a D, and inspecting a plan of the seating of the Cambridge ceremony at which Dvorak was awarded an honorary degree and during which he sat next to the composer Charles Villiers Stanford.

My train of thought was broken by the clanks of the number 12 tram that took me back to the flat, where I played Le Jazz by Bohuslav Martinu (on another five quid Supraphon CD from Bonton). This four-minute piece, composed in 1926 as a recreation of the sound of the Paul Whiteman Band, sends itself up with a wordless chorus and is the perfect antidote to sentimentality.

I forgot the sad lovers and set off to find the unlikely home in Bohemia where Martinu spent his early years. I had to go the long way round via Moravia where I kept bumping into Mahler. First in Jihlava, where he spent most of his boyhood, and then in Olomouc where, in 1883 at the age of 23, he directed the local opera company for a few months. He made his mark: they hated him, he hated them.

Olomouc remembers Mahler in a café named after him on the far side of Horni namesti; close by lies Mahlerova, a narrow lane of tatty buildings and few street lamps. A plaque on a ruin of a house with broken windows appears to suggest Mahler lived here.

Policka, in eastern Bohemia, makes rather more fuss of Martinu, a local hero who was born in the town in 1890 and was re-buried there in 1979, 20 years after he died in Switzerland. Martinu is not in the premier league, and his music ranges from big-tune romanticism to nervy restlessness; but his voice is both individual and lovable and much of his work is available in excellent (and cheap) Czech recordings.

And his claim to fame is that he was born in a room 192 steps up the spiky-topped tower of St Jakub's church in the town centre and lived there with his mother, father, sister and brother for nine years. It's said that when he finally came down to earth he was amazed by the size of people.

Martinu's father Ferdinand had been appointed town fire warden after a disastrous blaze that caused much destruction in Policka. His duties were to keep watch day and night, wind up the tower clock and ring the evening bell. If he spotted a blaze, he had to bellow "Fire!" through a megaphone from the tower balcony.

I paid my fee at the town museum (which has an excellent pictorial record of Martinu's life and career) and was led across town by the guide.

She unlocked the church door and we climbed up spiralling stone steps to where the five bells hang (and where the Martinu family had their lavatory). We went through a big white door and continued climbing, first up wooden steps and then up angled ladders to the balcony, with its views of the town hall, town walls and fields beyond.

The guide opened another door and we were allowed into a vestibule but not into the room itself. It was about 18ft by 12ft and lit by several windows. There were two beds, a table, chest, sofa and rocking horse, plus pious pictures and a crucifix. And a bell to tell of visitors below. But no tap: where did Mr and Mrs Martinu wash?

I headed back (past a rather camp statue of frock-coated Smetana in his home town of Litomsyl) to Pardubice, where the editor of the local paper gave a me a tape of the town's chamber orchestra playing Martinu's Toccata e due Canzone.

You could call it an explosive performance: Pardubice is where they make Semtex.

Five best restaurants

1 Franz Kafka Café
In the Josefov. Brown, smoky and atmospheric. Good cheap snacks and rough red wine.

2 U Vinaru
On Helichova in the Malá Strana. For something a little more sophisticated. Vaulted, cool and comfortable. A place to write postcards while sipping white wine from Bohemia.

3 Café Slavia
On Narodní, opposite the National Theatre. Where Vaclav Havel and fellow intellectuals used to meet, but more like a railway buffet than a radical powerhouse. Decent food.

4 U Kalicha
On Na bojisti, near the Dvorak museum A tourist experience rather than a gourmet night out. Dishes have folksy names, and a uniformed accordionist and drummer stroll among tables playing Roll Out the Barrel and Beautiful Dreamer. A bit pricey.

5 Obecní Dum
West of the Staré Mesto. The magnificent art-nouveau municipal hall houses a concert hall and a brilliant café and restaurant. The restaurant food is neither cheap nor remarkable but the ambience is worth every penny.

 The Prague Spring runs from May 12-June 6. For the full programme of concerts, visit www.festival.cz For tickets and availability, call: Ticketpro on 00 420 2 8401 1150. Next week, David Ward samples the music of Budapest.

The practicals

BA and Czech Airways have direct flights to Prague from Heathrow for £204 return. Go (www.go-fly.com) has direct flights from Stansted from £95. David Ward stayed at Hotel 16, Katerinska 16 (0420 2 249 19676, www.hotel16.cz), about £48 for a double romm B&B. STA Travel (020 7631 6262) has flights for under 26 year olds for £176 return and accomodation from £9 per night.

My train of thought was broken by the clanks of the number 12 tram that took me back to the flat, where I played Le Jazz by Bohuslav Martinu (on another five quid Supraphon CD from Bonton). This four-minute piece, composed in 1926 as a recreation of the sound of the Paul Whiteman Band, sends itself up with a wordless chorus and is the perfect antidote to sentimentality. I forgot the sad lovers and set off to find the unlikely home in Bohemia where Martinu spent his early years. I had to go the long way round via Moravia where I kept bumping into Mahler. First in Jihlava, where he spent most of his boyhood, and then in Olomouc where, in 1883 at the age of 23, he directed the local opera company for a few months. He made his mark: they hated him, he hated them. Olomouc remembers Mahler in a café named after him on the far side of Horni namesti; close by lies Mahlerova, a narrow lane of tatty buildings and few street lamps. A plaque on a ruin of a house with broken windows appears to suggest Mahler lived here. Policka, in eastern Bohemia, makes rather more fuss of Martinu, a local hero who was born in the town in 1890 and was re-buried there in 1979, 20 years after he died in Switzerland. Martinu is not in the premier league, and his music ranges from big-tune romanticism to nervy restlessness; but his voice is both individual and lovable and much of his work is available in excellent (and cheap) Czech recordings. And his claim to fame is that he was born in a room 192 steps up the spiky-topped tower of St Jakub's church in the town centre and lived there with his mother, father, sister and brother for nine years. It's said that when he finally came down to earth he was amazed by the size of people. Martinu's father Ferdinand had been appointed town fire warden after a disastrous blaze that caused much destruction in Policka. His duties were to keep watch day and night, wind up the tower clock and ring the evening bell. If he spotted a blaze, he had to bellow "Fire!" through a megaphone from the tower balcony. I paid my fee at the town museum (which has an excellent pictorial record of Martinu's life and career) and was led across town by the guide. She unlocked the church door and we climbed up spiralling stone steps to where the five bells hang (and where the Martinu family had their lavatory). We went through a big white door and continued climbing, first up wooden steps and then up angled ladders to the balcony, with its views of the town hall, town walls and fields beyond. The guide opened another door and we were allowed into a vestibule but not into the room itself. It was about 18ft by 12ft and lit by several windows. There were two beds, a table, chest, sofa and rocking horse, plus pious pictures and a crucifix. And a bell to tell of visitors below. But no tap: where did Mr and Mrs Martinu wash? I headed back (past a rather camp statue of frock-coated Smetana in his home town of Litomsyl) to Pardubice, where the editor of the local paper gave a me a tape of the town's chamber orchestra playing Martinu's Toccata e due Canzone. You could call it an explosive performance: Pardubice is where they make Semtex. Five best restaurants 1 Franz Kafka Café In the Josefov. Brown, smoky and atmospheric. Good cheap snacks and rough red wine. 2 U Vinaru On Helichova in the Malá Strana. For something a little more sophisticated. Vaulted, cool and comfortable. A place to write postcards while sipping white wine from Bohemia. 3 Café Slavia On Narodní, opposite the National Theatre. Where Vaclav Havel and fellow intellectuals used to meet, but more like a railway buffet than a radical powerhouse. Decent food. 4 U Kalicha On Na bojisti, near the Dvorak museum A tourist experience rather than a gourmet night out. Dishes have folksy names, and a uniformed accordionist and drummer stroll among tables playing Roll Out the Barrel and Beautiful Dreamer. A bit pricey. 5 Obecní Dum West of the Staré Mesto. The magnificent art-nouveau municipal hall houses a concert hall and a brilliant café and restaurant. The restaurant food is neither cheap nor remarkable but the ambience is worth every penny.  The Prague Spring runs from May 12-June 6. For the full programme of concerts, visit www.festival.cz For tickets and availability, call: Ticketpro on 00 420 2 8401 1150. Next week, David Ward samples the music of Budapest. The practicals BA and Czech Airways have direct flights to Prague from Heathrow for £204 return. Go (www.go-fly.com) has direct flights from Stansted from £95. David Ward stayed at Hotel 16, Katerinska 16 (0420 2 249 19676, www.hotel16.cz), about £48 for a double romm B&B. STA Travel (020 7631 6262) has flights for under 26 year olds for £176 return and accomodation from £9 per night.

fields.headline: Trains of thought
fields.standfirst: The best rail sites
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor tracks down the best sites for those determined to go by rail
fields.body:
Judging from your emails, Guardian readers are keen train travellers and would like to be able to book trips across Europe by rail. It's possible to do this via an agency, such as STA Travel, but it should be feasible on the web, too.

Unfortunately, even overlooking a shameful abuse of prepositions and mangled translations, reliable timetable information - let alone booking - is even rarer than a punctual Virgin train. Many sites are aimed at the US market and offer discounts exclusively to impressionable would-be inter-railers. And the bigger sites have put all their efforts into assimilating flights and tended to overlook other means of transport.

Eurostar
Two genuinely useful sections lie amid the flotsam: the timetable and the new booking facility. Critics might say that the site would benefit from a redesign, but they obviously didn't visit it a year ago. If you register an e-mail address, which is a requirement if you intend to book a ticket, Eurostar will send you details of special offers. Eurostar now travels direct to the Alps on the twice-weekly Ski Train.

SNCF
Despite some minor glitches and poor translations, the SNCF is a rather useful service: you can book tickets in most EU countries, although certain discounts (such as Decouverte for the under-25s) are not given as options. However, given that the automatic ticket machines at French stations do not accept most British credit cards, booking ahead is still sensible.

Belgian Railways
Only of interest if you are travelling within Belgium, the SNCB site is clumsy and uninspiring. Much of the information available is of dubious interest, although you will find timetables. Try the travel formulas page for details of passes for foreigners, including the exclusive Day Out in Ardennes. (Ardennes recently came bottom in L'Express magazine's survey of the quality of life in every French region).

Deutsche Bahn
Astonishingly rapid, simple and efficient, the Deutsche Bahn search extends to trans-European services, although it does not always provide prices. Booking is also possible for services within Germany.

InterRail
An amateurish shared resource for inter-railers; the idea is to swap information or find a travelling partner.

Rail Connection
The travelling tips here are poor, and the chief attraction is a virtual online conductor who can sell you an appropriate European rail pass.

Renfe
Timetables and a virtual tour of the Spanish railway system's trains are the main features.

Trans-Siberian
Unlike its airline counterpart Aeroflot, the Trans-Siberian Express has not yet acquired its own site. Built by enthusiastic fans of the service, this is an evocative alternative and can also sell you a package deal. The accompanying music, however, is execrable and has the uncanny ability to automatically turn up a computer's speakers.

fields.headline: US rates rise 'a certainty'
fields.standfirst: Jobs figures increase pressure on Federal Reserve to rein in economy
fields.trailText: The odds shortened yesterday on possible aggressive action by the US Federal Reserve to cool the burgeoning domestic economy as government figures revealed that unemployment had fallen to its lowest level in 30 years.
fields.body:
The odds shortened yesterday on possible aggressive action by the US Federal Reserve to cool the burgeoning domestic economy as government figures revealed that unemployment had fallen to its lowest level in 30 years.

Dealers now believe that the fall in the jobless rate to 3.9% makes a half-point increase in borrowing rates a certainty when the Federal Reserve meets next on May 16.

The Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is expected to respond to the latest evidence of mounting inflationary pressure in the American economy by ditching his softly, softly approach to tight ening policy in favour of a more hardline stance.

Despite four quarter-point increases in borrowing costs since last summer, the economy accelerated and is growing at an unsustainable annual rate of 7%.

"I don't know why the Fed would not go with a 50 basis-point increase now there's a smoking gun on inflation clearly in view," said Paul Kasriel, chief economist with Wall Street analyst Northern Trust. He was referring to the strong US wages growth indicated in Friday's unemployment report along with other recent data showing rising wage and inflation pressures.

The US labour department reported that the strength of economy in March created 458,000 jobs, far more than had been expected, helped by a longer than usual reporting period and large-scale hiring of workers in order to carry out the US census.

In April, average hourly earnings - an important measure of inflation pressures - rose twice as fast as many analysts were predicting.

Average hourly earnings went up by 0.4% to $13.64. Many analysts were forecasting a 0.2% rise.

The markets shrugged off yesterday's jobs data with the Dow Jones industrial average surging by more than 100 points in early trading.

Analysts said the market had already factored in a May increase in borrowing costs and saw the evidence of rapid eco nomic growth as being good for corporate profits.

"We've already seen a lot of damage in this market. We had a vicious shake-out about a month ago," said Larry Wachtel, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. "Now they can throw bad news at us and we won't react as badly."

Guy Truicko, a portfolio manager at Unity Management, said: "There is kind of a relief here that it is going to be 50 [basis points]. I think the removal of the uncertainty has people coming back into stocks - as crazy as it seems."

The chief victim of yesterday's exuberance was sterling, which slid to a four-year low against the American dollar at around $1.5250 - bringing some respite at least for those British companies exporting to north America.

Undermining the pound's level was the sense that British rates are close to their peak, while the tightening of the American labour market, the widening of the US trade deficit and a booming domestic economy pointed to a gradual monetary squeeze by the Federal Reserve for the rest of this year.

"Sterling's had a bit of a rocky passage over the last 24 hours after the rate decision," said Jeremy Stretch, currency strategist at NatWest Global Financial Markets.

"It's going to be fairly nervous against the dollar because... the market's now focused on the growth differential in the US and UK, and the fact that we are going to see 6% while the Fed's going 50 basis points in two weeks' time, with probably more on the horizon."

webTitle: Playing snap with the race card

fields.headline: Playing snap with the race card
fields.standfirst:
The elections have shown that although Labour has joined the Tories, it can't beat them

Race issues in the UK: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Can it really be that William Hague has struck a chord with the British people? If the Today programme is to be believed, his two recent initiatives had a major impact on voters in the local elections, which would suggest that there is now a significant movement in favour of lynch law and refugee camps.
fields.body:
Can it really be that William Hague has struck a chord with the British people? If the Today programme is to be believed, his two recent initiatives had a major impact on voters in the local elections, which would suggest that there is now a significant movement in favour of lynch law and refugee camps.

Labour accuses Hague of playing the race card. In fact, none other than David Blunkett came on the telly to say that the Tories had misled pensioners about the benefit received by asylum seekers. The Tories had not mentioned that refugees have lost almost all their benefits and are now getting vouchers instead. So there we are. The Tories have unfairly omitted to mention that the government is treating refugees appallingly. Despite all Labour's efforts to flag up its cruelty towards asylum seekers, the opposition refuses to give credit where it's due.

When will Labour ever learn that you cannot fight bigotry by yielding to it? The race card can only be beaten by something higher, but instead Labour plays its own race card and shouts "Snap!" Will the Tories have to start wearing brown before Labour stops stealing their clothes?

Yes, of course the Tories are worse. They have always been worse. That is why people vote Labour. The Conservative party is a disgusting thing representing all that is base and vile. But rather than campaign against baseness and vileness, the government complains that it can't be as base and vile as it would like because the system inherited from the Tories was in such chaos that people awaiting baseness and vileness are facing unacceptable delays.

Instead of trying to deal with the social problems that provide fertile ground for scapegoat politics, the government seeks to reassure us that Britain is not a soft touch for scapegoats, that scapegoats will be dispersed, starved and exiled. But I suppose if you are a government opposed to decent low-cost housing and social equality, you are not well placed to react in any other way.

So what of the other main plank of Hague's platform? Labour has made such a bid for the role of law and order party that it can't very well go along with Hague's attempt to garner support among illegal weapon owners and general murderers. The police are shooting as many people as they can, so the government does not encourage people to take the guns into their own hands. Moreover, prisoners can't vote, and, since the police now sometimes nick people who have actually committed murder and not just whoever is available, one must assume that the homicidal end of the electorate is an unreliable constituency, liable to disenfranchisement.

But is Shotgun Willie really on to something? Is there an untapped resource of extremely violent and easily provoked people who might tip the balance at the next general election? There probably aren't enough wealthy rural snipers to make that much of a difference. So perhaps Hague will extend his appeal to men who glass people for spilling their pints and care-home staff who torture demanding residents.

Labour will have to decide whether to compete to win the votes of the disproportionately vengeful, or to use its influential role as the government to try to take some of the heat out of this crime-obsessed country. One of the reasons why people are so scared to go outside is the unrelenting message from politicians and broadcasters that outside is a cross between The Birds and Night of the Living Dead.

It is a wonder Labour got any votes at all this week. Who would risk trying to make a break for the polling station with all those squeegee-merchants, crack-dealers and eastern Europeans stalking our streets? You'd need to create a diversion, by throwing a rock that lands behind them, making a noise and distracting them temporarily. Tory canvassers probably issued videos of Death Wish to supporters to give them the guts to run the gauntlet and place a cross for vigilantes everywhere.

"Lions and tigers and bears - oh my!" has become Labour's rallying cry. Of course, we all worry about crime. I'd like to see more bobbies on the beat. Get them out of their cars to stop them running people over. But it is frankly sick-making for the government to invoke the name of Stephen Lawrence when the climate of racism, vastly worsened by the backlash against asylum seekers, is causing racist attacks every day. Every time neo-Nazis make a concerted electoral push, racial assaults increase in tandem. It is no coincidence that there has been a spate of attacks on refugees, Jewish, Asian and Afro-Caribbean people in the run-up to the local elections. Yes, Hague and Widdecombe have done more to encourage racism than Blair or Straw, but the latter are not blameless.

And yet one thing I have omitted to say is that Hague's ugly strategy did not triumph in the local elections. Rather, Labour's vote collapsed. Perhaps Labour should stop trying to appeal to the worst in people. New Labour isn't working.

webTitle: Canadian soldiers in mustard gas tests honoured

fields.headline: Canadian soldiers in mustard gas tests honoured
fields.trailText: An official memorial to human "guinea pigs" who were exposed to painful poison gases in little-known experiments by British and Canadian military scientists was unveiled in Canada yesterday.
fields.body:
An official memorial to human "guinea pigs" who were exposed to painful poison gases in little-known experiments by British and Canadian military scientists was unveiled in Canada yesterday.

Art Eggleton, the Canadian defence minister, unveiled the plaque at the chemical warfare establishment at Suffield, Alberta, to remember the 2,000 Canadian armed forces personnel who volunteered for the gas tests. He said: "They put their lives on the line in those early days of research."

During the second world war, many soldiers were badly burned with mustard gas at Suffield, which was jointly funded by the British and Canadians.

The establishment was headed by Emlyn Llewelyn Davies, a British scientist who had previously been head of experiments at the poison gas establishment at Porton Down, Wiltshire. Other scientists from Porton went over to Suffield during the war.

Suffield was set up in 1941 because British scientists wanted the space to try out different chemical weapons without affecting nearby residents. Porton was too small.

Part of the work at Suffield was to develop defences to protect allied troops against chemical and biological weapons. The plaque reads: "In recognition of those who suffered so that their comrades in arms might be spared the horrors of chemical warfare."

Much of the work carried out is still secret, but declassified documents have revealed that troops were sprayed with mustard gas from planes in a series of experiments on the wide-open prairie.

In one test, in 1942, two privates - recorded as LV Devitte and RH Caldicutt - were among a group of men who stood on the freezing prairie wearing a helmet and ordinary battledress. As they heard a plane droning in the distance, they were told to don their gas masks. After the plane passed, the soldiers dusted one another with decontamination powder and marched three miles back to camp.

According to one report, Private Caldicutt suffered "sharp" burns on his entire back and "between his buttocks, developing into opposing ('kissing') blisters in fold". He also had burns and blisters over his legs and forearms.

Private Devitte also had burns to his body and was sick for a fortnight.

Another 160 troops were sprayed in eight trials deemed to be "very valuable".

Military units across Canada had to supply a quota of men for the tests. By 1944, Davies wanted to double the number of human trials, but volunteers were in short supply.

Army chiefs circulated a letter telling potential volunteers, who were paid, that they were not "guinea pigs in some weird scheme". But some say the trials have since caused lasting illnesses. They are now being compensated.

In contrast, British volunteers who took part in gas tests at Porton have complained of being rebuffed and ignored in trying to win compensation from the Ministry of Defence.

A spokeswoman said yesterday that Porton was "very grateful" to the volunteers who helped to develop "world-class protection" against chemical and biological weapons. It has no plans to erect a plaque.

fields.headline: Wizard, Cheshire
fields.standfirst: There's some impressive magic at work in a corner of Cheshire, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: There's some impressive magic at work in a corner of Cheshire, says Matthew Fort
fields.body:
I was hurtling north. I needed supper. I was not prepared to endure trial by M6 service station. I wanted something to restore peace of mind, to bring cheer to a weary soul, to rest and water. All right, all right. Nether Alderley wasn't exactly bang on my route, but, if you are of a curious cast of mind, there is always pleasure in heading along unfamiliar roads in unfamiliar country. Who knows what delights may lurk along the way?

In this case, Wizard was an unexpected delight. The only reference I could find was in the Michelin that gave it a sign that is supposed to indicate decent grub at fair prices. That tends to be a contentious issue. Not so much the decent grub bit as the fair price. What passes on the nod in London tends to raise an eyebrow or an expletive elsewhere, although, to be fair, it seems to me that prices in the regions are catching up pretty fast.

Wizard is a case in point. First courses bounced around between £3.50 (soup, glorious soup) and £7.95 (fried scallops with salad, sweet chilli dressing and Parmesan). Main courses started at £9.95 (filo tartlet filled with creamed oyster mushrooms, spinach and goats cheese) and topped off at £15.50 for chargrilled fillet steak, horseradish mash, confit carrots and ruby port jus. These would not be unremarkable in Islington or Soho. Not that there would be any trouble paying these prices to judge by the well-minted parties at the other tables. Blue-rinse-and-chiffon, Gucci loafer and blazer, fat wallet and gold card were much in evidence, all expertly handled by the friendly, busy service, as indeed, was I.

I steered a sort of middle course through the menu, what with sautéed chicken livers with thyme jus (there was quite a bit of the jus line on the menu) and red cabbage marmalade at £4.50, and then a roast breast of Goosnargh duck carved over butternut squash with honey and white wine jus at £13.75. You can tell from this that the food has enough of the fashionable about it without being challengingly cutting edge. On the other hand the familiar was refreshed by distinct culinary individuality.

For example, you don't often see chicken livers on menus as often I would like these days, except in the parfait form. These were beautiful fat, buttery cushions, cooked with understanding and precision. The thyme jus tasted more of chicken than thyme, but never mind; it was clean, elegant and well judged. And the marmalade was not your average Golden Shred, but crunchy and slightly astringent, balancing the richness of the rest of the dish. So you see, the sum was fine because the parts had been clearly thought through and treated sympathetically.

I first came to appreciate the sweet and deep flavoured virtues of the Goosnargh duck thanks to Paul Heathcote. I won't say the Wizard's version was in the same class as that master craftsman's. For one thing, I don't believe that it had been cooked on the bone as the maestro recommends, which helps it to keep its shape, its juices and its natural tenderness. This had some of the qualities, but was a good deal more challenging on the teeth.

But the combination with butternut squash was spot on. The squash had been crushed rather than puréed, with little crunchy nuggets of caramel lodged around and about, and another clearly flavoured, nicely judged gravy to lubricate each mouthful. Other vegetables came on a separate dish. I shall pass over these not because they were badly cooked - they weren't - but because they were superfluous. I would guess that local custom called for them.

Under the benign influence of a glass or two of distinctly perky Hunters Pinot Noir from New Zealand from a very sound wine list the beamed, daub-and-wattle interior of Wizard was looking distinctly wizardish, like a made over, tidied up version of an Elizabethan front room with candles, chests, copper jugs, settles, sconces, tapestried curtains and cushions and dried hops hung along the beams. It was a warmly intimate scene that called for pudding.

Pudding came in the form of a warm chocolate brownie with hot chocolate sauce and vanilla ice cream. What was nice about this was that it wasn't too sweet, which it could very easily have been. The brownie itself, about the size of a breeze block, was a light version of the great classic. The sauce maybe lacked total chocolate conviction, but it was fine.

Looking back over this review, I notice a slightly carping note creeping in here and there, which maybe gives a wrong impression. I liked Wizard. It was good to me. It is a good place, well run and serving very well cooked, pleasingly put-together grub. The food part of the bill came to £22.20, which, on reflection, probably does come under the fair price limit. I managed to boost in a bit through the Hunters Pinot Noir at £25, but that was my choice. And choice is what it's all about

webTitle: David Garrick as Richard III, William Hogarth (1745)

fields.headline: David Garrick as Richard III, William Hogarth (1745)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: William Hogarth (1697-1764), who portrayed the frauds, phonies and doomed innocents of 18th-century London in The Rake's Progress and Marriage a la Mode.

Subject: David Garrick (1717-79), the first modern actor.

Distinguishing features: David Garrick transfixed London in 1741 when he played Shakespeare's Richard III as a human being instead of a stagy monster. No one had seen acting like it. They were used to rhetorical bombast but Garrick, a nobody from the Midlands, gave them a perfor mance of utter conviction. The impact was as revolutionary as Marlon Brando and the 'method' in 50s America. Garrick became Richard so convincingly that Samuel Johnson claimed to be scandalised. 'If Garrick really believed himself to be that monster, Richard III,' he said, 'he deserved to be hanged every time he performed it.'

Garrick didn't commission this painting, but he was a star so Hogarth knew it would sell. He got pounds 200 for it and the print version made Garrick's face available for anyone to pin on the wall.

Hogarth has captured the transformation of identity that people thought they saw when Garrick was on stage. Garrick's face looks past us at shadows, is absorbed in terrors we can't see. This is the eve of the Battle of Bosworth Field where Richard will be killed he has woken from dreams he blames on his 'coward conscience'. This is a humpless, vulnerable Richard.

The painting is full of images of theatrical illusion. Garrick/ Richard's armour, the disguise he wears to fight, lies to one side. The tent is opened up like the curtains of a stage. Hogarth heightens our sense that Garrick is wearing a costume by having the heavy clothes fill the picture and the ruff push at his neck. The crown in the tent is huge, another poor fit for Richard. Even the background is ambiguous , the fire is real enough, but the lack of action makes it tempting to see this as a stage backcloth.

The naked, direct expression on Garrick's face makes all the props and costume irrelevant. He is unshaven, his hair is wild, his brow furrowed. The palm of his hand is held out to ward off ghosts but it also suggests openhandedness. Garrick conceals nothing.

The novelist Henry Fielding, a friend of Hogarth and Garrick, wrote that the world is full of people 'personating characters no more their own, and to which... they have no better title, than the player hath to be in earnest thought the king or emperor whom he represents'. In a world where everyone wears a social mask, how do you recognise the true person? Hogarth portrays the moment of completely abandoned performance in which you become truly yourself.

Did he like it? Garrick and Hogarth became close friends, and when Hogarth died Garrick wrote a verse for his grave: If Genius fire thee, reader, stay,

If Nature touch thee, drop a tear If neither moves thee, turn away, For Hogarth's honoured dust lies here.

Where is it? Walker Art Gallery, William Brown Street, Liverpool (0151-478 4199).

fields.headline: Friend of the family
fields.standfirst: Growing up with a decent, loving family proved to be a disadvantage for Lisa Kudrow's latest role, but it could be the reason why Friends is still going
fields.trailText: Lisa Kudrow has done a marvellous job of playing dumb smartly as the surreally ditzy Phoebe on Friends. But unlike some comic actors, the Ivy League-educated Kudrow has little desire to prove her dramatic chops, preferring to stick with funny in most of her hiatus movies. Lately, she's been collaborating with the Ephron sisters (Sleepless In Seattle, You've Got Mail), in the screen adaptation of Delia's semi-autobiographical novel Hanging Up, and a Nora-directed lottery caper with John Travolta. In Hanging Up, she plays the youngest and least achieving of three overachieving siblings (the other two being Meg Ryan and Diane Keaton) who are forced to settle their differences when their dad is given a short time to live.
fields.body:
Lisa Kudrow has done a marvellous job of playing dumb smartly as the surreally ditzy Phoebe on Friends. But unlike some comic actors, the Ivy League-educated Kudrow has little desire to prove her dramatic chops, preferring to stick with funny in most of her hiatus movies. Lately, she's been collaborating with the Ephron sisters (Sleepless In Seattle, You've Got Mail), in the screen adaptation of Delia's semi-autobiographical novel Hanging Up, and a Nora-directed lottery caper with John Travolta. In Hanging Up, she plays the youngest and least achieving of three overachieving siblings (the other two being Meg Ryan and Diane Keaton) who are forced to settle their differences when their dad is given a short time to live.

What did you learn from Diane Keaton, who co-starred in and directed Hanging Up?

She was an absolute inspiration for me. When I first met her at a reading, it struck me how much of her sensibility informs my humour. I never realised, but the kind of fumbling over words and showing vulnerability that I do is straight from Annie Hall. An unintentional funny; she had no jokes but she was hilarious. That is my favourite kind of comedy.

And the father Walter Matthau plays is godawful, as is his long-gone ex-wife. Guess you couldn't relate to them.

No. I was really lucky, I got to have great parents who always filled me with confidence. But y'know, you always reach that point - for me, it was in my mid-20s - when you see them as just people who made mistakes and did the best they could. There's that period when you're a little angry, but then you forgive them and everything gets good again.

Did you always know you had a knack for comedy?

Yeah. My family was very funny, and I was so much younger than my brother and sister that, y'know, no one really paid attention to me. At school, though, I'd practise on my friends, 'cause I could certainly be funnier than them. I'd always look around at my family and say, well, we're not handsome folk, but we are funny, and that's the most important thing. Then, all of a sudden my sister became this beautiful girl and my brother turned into this hot guy. Even my mom became this beautiful woman; it was very weird.

Well, starring in America's most popular sitcom for six years must have lifted your self-esteem.

Oh my God! No one would even be aware of me if I wasn't on that show every week. It's still challenging, we're still telling different stories and they're still good. It's getting down to the wire as to whether or not there'll be more seasons of Friends.

We hear you were the instigator of the we-all-come-back-or-none-of-us-do bargaining strategy with the studio.

Well, there are a lot of things that go beyond just the work. The six of us have known for a long time that either we're all coming back or none of us are coming back, because no one wants to be there without one of us. We all get along so well that it's a nice place to be every day. If that could continue, then that would be great.

You take your mothering responsibilities pretty seriously, don't you?

Yeah. The toughest thing about it is the guilt. That's what gets in the way the most, more than working a lot. Mothers who stay at home aren't necessarily on the floor playing games with their children every single moment and they feel guilty also, every time the child falls down or they think, "Please take your nap, I need a minute to myself." Every mother feels guilty about the time they need for themselves, but I think I've got that time worked into my life already.

fields.headline: Truth and rumours
fields.standfirst: The Sex Pistols shoot straight from the hip in a new film about the band's spiky contribution to music history. Too bad most rockumentaries are not as honest about their stars, says Michael Holden
fields.trailText: The Sex Pistols shoot straight from the hip in a new film about the band's spiky contribution to music history. Too bad most rockumentaries are not as honest about their stars, says Michael Holden
fields.body:
Spare a thought for the rock'n'roll movie. As essential as the Swiss navy and often as well made as an institution-weaved basket, it is an art form whose highs are swamped by a tide of worthless lows as every great rock tale vies for attention with cynical, vain, artist-controlled marketing shams. None of which stops most such documentaries, or if you will, rockumentaries, being great fun. We all crave further evidence that our pop heroes are cool and cross our fingers for grubby endorsement of the hubristic depths of our villains. Whatever their faults, these films are as compulsive as a car crash and venal as only showbiz can be. You need not love the artist to dig the movie any more than you must truly care for penguins to watch a nature programme. Like rare animals, musicians are a breed apart and their special diets and bizarre mating rituals are a source of widespread national concern.

The top end of the rock doc market receives a welcome addition this month with the arrival of Julien Temple's Sex Pistols film, The Filth And The Fury. It's part, one suspects, an atonement for Temple's appalling Great Rock'n'Roll Swindle (to be fair, a project realised under some duress and inherited from Russ Meyer), and partly an attempt to get to the bottom of one of the most misunderstood and much maligned tales in rock history. John Lydon, who was heavily involved in the film's production, insists that "after 20-odd years of lies", (primarily, it transpires, from the mouth of a certain ginger-haired tailor turned style pundit), "this is the truth." It sure looks like it. Interviews with the band and contemporary detail produce a movie with far wider implications than the Pistols' story alone. It is a lesson in social history. Then there is a heap of priceless unseen footage. Chiefly, a long-lost interview with Sid Vicious, sat in a deck chair in Hyde Park wearing a swastika T-shirt and coming across, believe it or not, as a smart kid with a great sense of humour. The Vicious rehabilitation continues to the final scene of Lydon in tears as he recalls the trauma of his friend's unnecessary destruction.

But, as we've said, this is the high end of the market. Most rock documentaries suffer from the fact that they have already been parodied more effectively than the actuality of any genuine film can compete with. Spinal Tap did for tour films what Ali G has done for low-level drug dealing in Staines: rendered the truth impotent by comparison. Not that this stops bands, or presumably the Staines massive, carrying on regardless.

In Bed With Madonna should be instantly disqualified from the genre because the woman's too careful and involved to let anything slip. The only marginally revealing scene is when she offers food to an uninterested Warren Beatty, which has about as much to do with rock'n'roll as the chart listings in Hello!

To see a major act produce their own film and still look stupid we must turn to those old masters of reflex pomposity, U2. Amidst the mire of expertly lit concert footage that constitutes the majority of Rattle & Hum, we are treated to the sight of the whole band (presumably unaware of the exact same scene taking place in Spinal Tap) openly weeping at Elvis's grave. If I were in a band, I'd like to sit on his grave in a big nappy, eating drugs and mumbling about the Bible. But then I guess that's why U2 are so popular: they must really care.

One group of stadium legends who made a film so odd that it's actually fascinating are Pink Floyd with Live At Pompeii. We watch The Floyd setting up one of the largest sound rigs in history on the ashes of thousands of dead Romans and then playing a gig to absolutely no one. Mercifully, a faintly ridiculous idea transforms into a sizeable spectacle and in terms of the genre it remains a one-off.

All of which is a far cry from the 70s, when artists tried to strip bare the fame process by another means, ie acting as rock stars in films. What began so well with Mick Jagger in Performance led comically to David Essex and Ringo Starr pretending to be 17, working a Waltzer in That'll Be The Day, searching for "birds" and dreaming of stardom. Then there's what's known as the "false narrative" approach, as seen in Abba The Movie. Here, the stars are so dull that they play second fiddle to an actor playing an Australian reporter seeking an interview. Aside from concert footage and the Aussie sat in cabs going, "For Christ's sakes get a move on, mate, I'm trying to catch the Abba!", the Swedes' chief contribution consists of disappearing into lifts and saying, "sorry".

Sometimes, though, rock docs take us straight to the dirt beneath the fingernails of fame. The most entertaining, honest and recent example was Black Grape's The Grape Tapes. Marooned in a rural studio, Sean Ryder dissolves an entire packet of codeine-rich Solpadeine (maximum daily dose eight tablets) into a pint glass while asking the catering lady if she "knows the local chemist". Ryder is free to flash the mechanism of his genius, as well as his biochemical shortcomings, just enough to keep things special. For the ultimate in understated high degeneracy, check out Alan Yentob's 70s Horizon film of Bowie's American tour. An overall masterpiece worth seeing just for the footage of Dave coked up to Scarface levels in the back of a limousine, singing along to You Make Me Feel Like A Natural Woman while driving through the Nevada desert.

The truth is, though, stars only show us what they want us to see. While those arch degenerates the Stones offer their 25x5 lifestory on video, the legendary Cocksucker Blues '72 tour film remains locked away. The point being, it's just too true. "We'll have to leave it at least five years to calm down," said Jagger. That was in 1977. In truth, the best rock films are made by professionals, without the hindrance of musicians. The BBC's Dancing In The Street series is a case in point. And Melvyn Bragg's South Bank Show. His '86 Velvet Underground film persuaded me to buy a guitar. I never did play it, but I hung on to the bits about staying awake for days and looking sick and dressing as a woman. And it was the South Bank Show's Smiths doc which, legend has it, persuaded Damon Albarn to form Blur. Film-makers should beware: they're playing with dark forces. Not just the devil's music but teenage minds, the irony being that while the inspired viewer moves on, the subject remains in arrested development. As Steve Jones says in The Filth And The Fury, "I only wanted to get laid."

 The Filth And The Fury is out on Friday

Spinal Tap did for tour films what Ali G has done for low-level drug dealing in Staines: rendered the truth impotent by comparison. Not that this stops bands, or presumably the Staines massive, carrying on regardless. In Bed With Madonna should be instantly disqualified from the genre because the woman's too careful and involved to let anything slip. The only marginally revealing scene is when she offers food to an uninterested Warren Beatty, which has about as much to do with rock'n'roll as the chart listings in Hello! To see a major act produce their own film and still look stupid we must turn to those old masters of reflex pomposity, U2. Amidst the mire of expertly lit concert footage that constitutes the majority of Rattle & Hum, we are treated to the sight of the whole band (presumably unaware of the exact same scene taking place in Spinal Tap) openly weeping at Elvis's grave. If I were in a band, I'd like to sit on his grave in a big nappy, eating drugs and mumbling about the Bible. But then I guess that's why U2 are so popular: they must really care. One group of stadium legends who made a film so odd that it's actually fascinating are Pink Floyd with Live At Pompeii. We watch The Floyd setting up one of the largest sound rigs in history on the ashes of thousands of dead Romans and then playing a gig to absolutely no one. Mercifully, a faintly ridiculous idea transforms into a sizeable spectacle and in terms of the genre it remains a one-off. All of which is a far cry from the 70s, when artists tried to strip bare the fame process by another means, ie acting as rock stars in films. What began so well with Mick Jagger in Performance led comically to David Essex and Ringo Starr pretending to be 17, working a Waltzer in That'll Be The Day, searching for "birds" and dreaming of stardom. Then there's what's known as the "false narrative" approach, as seen in Abba The Movie. Here, the stars are so dull that they play second fiddle to an actor playing an Australian reporter seeking an interview. Aside from concert footage and the Aussie sat in cabs going, "For Christ's sakes get a move on, mate, I'm trying to catch the Abba!", the Swedes' chief contribution consists of disappearing into lifts and saying, "sorry". Sometimes, though, rock docs take us straight to the dirt beneath the fingernails of fame. The most entertaining, honest and recent example was Black Grape's The Grape Tapes. Marooned in a rural studio, Sean Ryder dissolves an entire packet of codeine-rich Solpadeine (maximum daily dose eight tablets) into a pint glass while asking the catering lady if she "knows the local chemist". Ryder is free to flash the mechanism of his genius, as well as his biochemical shortcomings, just enough to keep things special. For the ultimate in understated high degeneracy, check out Alan Yentob's 70s Horizon film of Bowie's American tour. An overall masterpiece worth seeing just for the footage of Dave coked up to Scarface levels in the back of a limousine, singing along to You Make Me Feel Like A Natural Woman while driving through the Nevada desert. The truth is, though, stars only show us what they want us to see. While those arch degenerates the Stones offer their 25x5 lifestory on video, the legendary Cocksucker Blues '72 tour film remains locked away. The point being, it's just too true. "We'll have to leave it at least five years to calm down," said Jagger. That was in 1977. In truth, the best rock films are made by professionals, without the hindrance of musicians. The BBC's Dancing In The Street series is a case in point. And Melvyn Bragg's South Bank Show. His '86 Velvet Underground film persuaded me to buy a guitar. I never did play it, but I hung on to the bits about staying awake for days and looking sick and dressing as a woman. And it was the South Bank Show's Smiths doc which, legend has it, persuaded Damon Albarn to form Blur. Film-makers should beware: they're playing with dark forces. Not just the devil's music but teenage minds, the irony being that while the inspired viewer moves on, the subject remains in arrested development. As Steve Jones says in The Filth And The Fury, "I only wanted to get laid."  The Filth And The Fury is out on Friday

webTitle: Wanted: strong, silent male with own sword

fields.headline: Wanted: strong, silent male with own sword
fields.standfirst: Actions not words make a classic movie hero, says Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: Actions not words make a classic movie hero, says Danny Leigh
fields.body:
To some, it's Charlton Heston, gamely whirring round the colosseum in Ben-Hur; to others Harrison Ford, twinkling cheekily through Raiders Of The Lost Ark; for a few - typically single men with poor inter-personal skills - it could only be De Niro's Taxi Driver.

A proper, bona fide hero: everyone's got one, but nobody can quite agree the job spec. And, if you're after clarity from a dictionary, the best you're going to get is some hokum about "a man idealised for possessing superior qualities in any field (noun)." Which could, technically, mean Stephen Hawking.

No, on-screen, you're only confusing the issue by venturing beyond a specific set of criteria largely unchanged since Rudolph Valentino stuck a tea towel on his head for The Sheik.

Take Russell Crowe's impeccably chiselled turn as hapless Roman patsy Maximus in the imminent Gladiator (a film which, in its fusion of political intrigue, extreme violence and hugely foolish costumes, really gives you everything you could ever want from a movie about gladiators).

Now, sure as eggs is eggs, Crowe's got the superior qualities bit down pat: rarely, for example, can an Australian actor in his mid-30s have decapitated a Barbarian horde with such artistry and precision. But, as becomes evident soon afterwards, there's more to Maximus than mere heads on sticks. The man is noble; stoic; in short, heroic.

The man is also a bitch magnet par excellence, his every glower of misery an open inducement to mass oestrogen overload. Which is where the first problem for the movie paragon comes in: namely, that the audience's enthusiasm for them is almost entirely dictated by its gender.

To wit, for most women, the idea of a rough-hewn gladiator holding a teary-eyed candle for his spouse - stuck toiling in a field somewhere while the emperor's daughter pouts up a storm - is emotional ambrosia. For the majority of men, however, it represents a profound betrayal of the male lead's basic remit: to save, then screw, as many female co-stars as possible. While straight women look at James Bond and clock a roguish, implausible philanderer, straight men gawp at the screen and see - sad to say - a role model.

So, somewhere between such mutually exclusive demands, our hero has to find a small patch of universal appeal: a thankless task, given the way people's taste in them routinely reflects their own personalities. This writer, for example, has always felt a vague unease about his own screen idols (Barton Fink and Pee-Wee Herman); equally, if anyone ever tells you they totally empathised with Kevin Costner in Waterworld, you should probably make your excuses as a matter of urgency.

Yet, amid the disharmony, we can agree on one thing: any credible hero must, as the barest of pre-requisites, be physically fit (hence the Athena-poster makeover of the previously gutsy Russell Crowe). For a top boy to establish his mettle, there's going to be any number of nail-biting, near-death experiences to contend with, and wheezing on the floor feeling sick as the bad guy gets the girl isn't going to impress anyone. Sadly, for the biggest of big men, the world can - indeed must - be a parlous, hostile place; tastiness in a ruck is, therefore, pretty much statutory (otherwise, Ben Kingsley would have been deluged with action movie roles after Gandhi). On the other hand, no one wants to see their icon showing too much lust for glory. Too much lust for glory means revelling in the bloodshed, and revelling in the bloodshed means psycho, plain and simple. The same logic partially explains the recent box-office expiry of Arnold Schwarzenegger, as the world finally realised what he always was: a dead-eyed Teutonic Muscle Mary with all the charisma of a Dalston bouncer. An aura of assured masculinity, yes (which, incidentally, is why the best the genetically effete English ever produced was Roger Moore). Puffing up your gym tits and scowling, wellÄ no.

Besides handiness, however, other - yet more prosaic qualities are vital. Bravery, obviously, however ill-advised; a refusal to be intimidated by the odds; and, closely related to both, a certain bovine lack of intellect. Heroism, after all, isn't a business where high-school diplomas are necessary. Witness the ascendancy of last year's most popular human glove puppet, Keanu Reeves.

On a more practical note, any self-respecting hero needs a wardrobe worthy of their stature. Traditionally, of course, that's meant bare chest or tuxedo (preferably separately), despite mavericks like Bruce Willis in Die Hard boldly adopting the grubby white vest as emblem of celluloid heroism. Once again, the wisdom of such iconoclasm remains debatable: ever heard of the Village People, Bruce?

Still, as a grizzled, whining cop, at least Willis got his CV right. Because, in this game, your profession is every bit as important as your actual righting wrong. It's no good expecting to browbeat the audience into doe-eyed adulation when they've seen you dabbling in office stationery. Similarly, when choosing a hobby, a true hero goes with something which implies introspection and fortitude: fishing, or chess, or chronic alcohol dependency. Line dancing, the internet and transvestism are all obvious no-nos.

It's also worth considering that, whether through work or leisure, what the hero needs above all else is ceaseless, unforgiving adversity. Without it, he simply has no function (and the film's over before the opening credits). Occasionally, of course, an appropriate calamity can arise through fate; more often, the situation demands an oppressive tyranny or, at the very least, a malignant double-yolker as bogeyman. Only then can Kirk Douglas in Spartacus or Nicolas Cage in Con Air get started on the pointless acts of petty defiance that make up their daily routine. Likewise, a perpetual backdrop of casual brutality also represents licence to indulge in the painful but necessary business of martyrdom: when was Jack Nicholson ever more heroic than lobotomised and drooling during One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest? What it all comes down to is having the grounds to appear cosmically deflated at the state of the world (a bearing Crowe's Gladiator has in spades). No amount of charm or pectoral definition can compensate for the look of a man who's going to have to - for example - stab a pair of Bengal tigers to death, but who really, really doesn't want to. For the definitive article, we should perhaps refer to Sylvester Stallone; with the confused, heart-broken gaze of a freshly kicked puppy, and the diction of a stroke victim, Sly's always been a benchmark for the modern goody-goody.

Which brings us to one last point: talking, and the absence thereof. Because few things dent a hero's credibility like talking. Talking, in essence, is bad. John Wayne didn't blather in True Grit, Mel Gibson kept it to himself in Mad Max, and Mickey Rourke barely uttered a word in Rumblefish (probably because he couldn't). Obviously, certain moments call for a quip - narrowly escaping a falling boulder, or shooting someone who made an unkind comment in the opening scene - but, as a general rule of thumb, the more a hero gabs, the less seriously you'll take him.

Dialogue, ultimately, is for pussies; heroes say it with action. You want jokes, go and see a Joe Pesci movie.

 Gladiator is out on Friday
