fields.headline: DNA: It's war (part two)
fields.standfirst: Decoding the human genome will change the world. But, says Kevin Toolis, it's not just about science; it's UK vs US; public spirit vs private enterprise. And it's personal
fields.trailText: Decoding the human genome will change the world. But, says Kevin Toolis, it's not just about science; it's UK vs US; public spirit vs private enterprise. And it's personal
fields.body:
The Vietnam war was also a pivotal point in John Sulston's life. After doing a PhD in chemistry at Cambridge, he was awarded a post-doctoral scholarship at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, near San Diego, just as the anti-war movement took to the streets. "I was absolutely a child of the 60s. I feel very strongly that I was on the side of people who opposed the war. I remember arguing with lots of right-wing people in the lab, people who believed it was a just war and the US was totally right to go there. I was a real lefty figure."

Sulston, whose father, Ted, worked for the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel, in London, and whose mother, Muriel, was a schoolteacher, fell into science after what he admits was a fairly undistinguished undergraduate degree at Cambridge between 1960-63. "I never regarded myself, and I'm not an especially bright person, more of an artisan than an intellectual. I tried to go off with VSO and was signed up for some programme that collapsed. So, at the end of the summer term, without any particular plan, I asked about doing a PhD. And they said, 'Oh fine, come along in' - this was the 60s. That was tremendous. I did not like book work, I never have liked book work. What I actually liked was being in the lab and playing with the toys. I just played and played and played."

Sulston's scientific awakening came in California. "I was spoilt at the Salk Institute. I was the post-doc who got all the goodies. You were invited to have dinner with Nobel prize winners, made to feel bigger than your boots. I was absolutely in love with California. I loved staying at home, having babies, going to the beach - we bought a pick-up and put the pram in the back - and growing runner beans."

In 1969, Sulston returned to Cambridge and its world-famous molecular biology laboratory, where DNA was originally discovered. In California, he had worked on nucleic acids - how genetic inheritance might get going - but techniques were primitive. He made his scientific name with a detailed study of a tiny worm, Caenorhabditis elegans.

There are thousands of these little worms, also known as ringworms, in every handful of soil, where they eat bacteria. As part of a research project examining the worm's genome, Sulston had the simple but audacious idea of tracing the "choreography" of the way the cells divided by just watching them hatch through a Nomarski light microscope, that magnifies at 2,000 times.

Every human starts off as one cell, a fertilised egg, but our cells soon divide, spine, bones, eyes, kidney, blood and hair. Understanding the lineage of how our cells specialise is fundamental to understanding genetics. Even in C. elegans, with just 1,000 cells, it is a complex process. For 18 months, Sulston shut himself in a small room and watched worms hatch. "No one thought it was possible. Various people had looked at taking photographs, cutting and staining. But the resolution was not good enough. I twigged I could do it just by sitting and looking, so I did."

It was mind-numbing, fastidious work. Sulston fondly still keeps his old microscope in his office. In true British fashion, Sulston describes his work as "not the top stuff, the breakthrough that leads to Nobel prizes, but solid middle-of-the-road science". The results were published in 1983, and Sulston, with his US collaborator Bob Waterston, who heads the other major genome sequencing centre in the University of Washington, St Louis, moved on to map the worms' genes.

Although the nematode is tiny, its genome is still 100 million bases long. That is 100 million Cs, As, Gs and Ts. Decoding a genome is a bit like doing a very big jigsaw. In gene mapping, the genome is first divided up into big chunks - with the human genome there will be 22,000 segments, 150,000 letters long - and then each segment is analysed and their sequence, CATTGCC, read off. Because researchers know which big bit the individual sequence comes from, it's easier to put the whole jigsaw back together. Sulston and Waterston, viewed by James Watson at NIH as the best sequence team in the world, began sequencing the worm in 1990 as a test run for the human genome. The C. elegans genome was finally published in 1998. It was the first genome of a free-living animal ever decoded.

By then, a forerunner of the current war over the human genome between Sulston, his collaborator Waterston, and Venter had already broken out. At his research institute, TIGR, Venter was producing a library of ESTs - valuable biotech material indicating the site of potential human genes - and TIGR's funders, Human Genome Sciences, sold the exclusive rights to consult this library to big pharmaceuticals such as SmithKline Beecham. The five-year deal with SmithKline Beecham alone was worth $125m. HGS was effectively operating a monopoly and demanding "reach-through" royalties; anyone who used its material and subsequently came up with a commercial application for a drug had to pay HGS a royalty. Academic researchers unable to pay the fees were locked out. Most of the data was sitting in closed computer files, waiting for paying customers.

SmithKline Beecham's drug rivals, Merck, struck back. Rather than pay HGS fees, they gave Waterston a research grant to sequence a rival EST library and lodge them for free in Genbank - a public depository for genetic material and accessible to anyone. Overnight, it destroyed the economic value of HGS's precious library. "Everything they do seems to have more of a political lean to it than just science. Waterston was a willing employee, or just part of someone else's game plan, in the contest between giant pharmaceutical companies," says Venter provocatively.

But for Sulston, the open publication of the EST data was the ideal outcome. "The human genome is vastly more complex, and its implications far greater, than anything we have encountered before. There is no way it should be concentrated in the hands of the few - that is exactly where Bolshevism went wrong. The human genome should be spread out laterally. We want competition on the products, not on the information itself."

At TIGR, Venter had been developing a new way of sequencing genomes, called the "whole shotgun method" that relied on powerful computers and complex algorithms to reassemble tiny fragments without the aid of the gene-mapping sequences used by Sulston. Instead of first using big bits of the jigsaw, Venter just cloned the whole genome and then blasted it in small fragments. These fragments were then fed directly into sequencing machines and reassembled by concentrated computer power. In 1994, he used the shotgun method to sequence the micro-organism Haemophilus influenzae, the bug that gives children ear infection. It was the first actual organism, rather than an animal such as the worm, ever to be sequenced. Other bugs, syphilis and the bacteria that live in sulphur vents on the bottom of the ocean, followed.

Again Venter came under attack for his methods. Critics claimed the shotgun method was imprecise - shotgunning the human genome leaves you with 60 million gene fragments, 2,000-10,000 letters long, to put back together again. His opponents claimed shotgunning would leave gaps in the sequence data, and would be unable to cope with larger genomes. But again Venter was triumphantly vindicated when, in collaboration with public scientists from Berkeley in California, he published the 120-million base genome of the fruit fly - important in genetic research - in March 2000.

In 1997, Venter fell out badly with HGS's boss, Bill Haseltine, over the company's secretive business plan and ended their collaborative relationship. Haseltine and Venter swiftly became deadly rivals. Venter was out in the commercial cold again, lobbying for grants to sequence genomes from his academic enemies.

But then his old partners, Applied Biosystems, saved him. In 1998, Perkin Elmer finally completed a new sequencing machine, the AB3700, that could sequence at hundreds of times the rate of earlier machines. Sequencing the human genome was just a question of lining up enough AB3700s - Celera has 300 of them - and turning them on. Perkin Elmer's Mike Hunkapiller, who developed the machines from their infancy, called Venter to head the new company. Big business was going to do the genome.

In May 1998, Celera, which means swiftness, announced it would sequence the human code of life by 2001. Venter was his usual antagonistic self. "There was a suggestion that the public project should move on to the mouse, and that Celera would take care of the human," says Francis Collins, current head of the US government Genome Research Institute and a former colleague of Venter's. "Craig Venter does not lack for ambition or audacity."

Celera's birth shattered the complacency of the public scientists in the Human Genome Project. Every major centre, including the Sanger, went on a sequencing machine-buying race from what is still the leading manufacturer, Perkin Elmer. The HGP rapidly revised its target completion date from 2010 to 2005, to 2003 and finally to the publication of a "draft" sequence this summer. No one wants to come second in the race for the code.

Very quickly, the contest descended into a propaganda war, with each side questioning the other's scientific credibility, its motives, personalities and, crucially, who was going to get the credit. Sulston complains about Celera's "one-way trap door" that allows it to use the two billion bases in the public data, give nothing in return, but then claim credit for sequencing the entire genome. "They hoover up all the public data, add a bit of their own and sell it as a packaged product," says Sulston.

Venter, in turn, has accused the Wellcome Trust of orchestrating a "dirty tricks" campaign. On February 29, 2000, after a sustained effort to hype up their share price, Celera raised almost $1 billion from the stock market by issuing another 3.8 million shares, at $225 a share. Two weeks later, on March 14, President Clinton and prime minister Tony Blair announced in a rare joint statement that they would like to see "unencumbered access" to the human genome.

Celera immediately saw the hidden hand of the Wellcome Trust behind the statement. Although neither Clinton or Blair said anything new, Celera's shareholders panicked - believing the ongoing patent bonanza was under attack. Celera's share price dropped through the floor. The stock is now trading at $64. And to add to the company's woes, a New York law firm has just launched a class action on behalf of disgruntled investors, claiming the company suppressed vital details - later leaked by the Wellcome Trust - of Celera's secret talks with the public HGP.

In many ways, the differing techniques of both sides are complementary. Combining both the public gene-mapping and Celera's shotgun data would produce a far more accurate and comprehensive data set. Teams from Celera and the HGP met near Washington in December for secret talks to hammer out details of proposed collaboration. But instead of peace and co-operation, the meeting ended in a blazing argument. The irresolvable issue was the public release of the data. Celera wanted some form of exclusive deal so as to be able to sell the genome sequence to their paying customers before handing it over to the public. There were conditions, restrictions and the sequence would only be available from Celera's website. It was hardly surprising. Celera is a private company that wants to make profits. Whatever Venter might say in public about free data release, his business partner's fine print in private seems to undermine his rhetoric; Celera is not going to give its crown jewels away.

For the Wellcome Trust, the human genome was not for sale. "While establishing a monopoly on commercial uses of the human genome sequence may be in Celera's business interests, it is not in the best interests of science or the general public," it concluded in a joint HGP letter that was leaked on March 6.

Prospects of future collaboration now seem slim. "Tell the Wellcome Trust they missed their timing. They could have cost us a billion dollars. We have a billion dollars in the bank to do the next stage. We are in phenomenal shape," boasts Venter.

Ironically, the race for code has become an all too human story of rivalry, emotion and fear. But that is hardly surprising. The human genome is far too important to end up as just another bit of academia. It is an issue of fundamental importance, fundamental philosophy. Should our genetic code end up as the property of a private American corporation? Are our genes the property of who claims them first? Our instinctive answer is no. But in the real world, companies who invest in genomics, drugs, genetic tests, will only do so if their investments are protected. Nothing is free. Finding the right boundary between our common genetic heritage and proprietary ownership of bits of our genes is one of the many challenges that lie ahead.

Soon, possibly within the next two weeks, either Craig Venter or John Sulston will be able to hold a DVD disc containing the human book of life, our genome, in his hand. Either way, it will be a stunning achievement. It will not be the end of the race for the code. Decoding the genome, locating genes, creating new drugs, interpreting the genomic babble of our ancestry, is the work of decades. But it will mark a line. It will be a break point, a new beginning in our human story.

Sulston, whose father, Ted, worked for the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel, in London, and whose mother, Muriel, was a schoolteacher, fell into science after what he admits was a fairly undistinguished undergraduate degree at Cambridge between 1960-63. "I never regarded myself, and I'm not an especially bright person, more of an artisan than an intellectual. I tried to go off with VSO and was signed up for some programme that collapsed. So, at the end of the summer term, without any particular plan, I asked about doing a PhD. And they said, 'Oh fine, come along in' - this was the 60s. That was tremendous. I did not like book work, I never have liked book work. What I actually liked was being in the lab and playing with the toys. I just played and played and played." Sulston's scientific awakening came in California. "I was spoilt at the Salk Institute. I was the post-doc who got all the goodies. You were invited to have dinner with Nobel prize winners, made to feel bigger than your boots. I was absolutely in love with California. I loved staying at home, having babies, going to the beach - we bought a pick-up and put the pram in the back - and growing runner beans." In 1969, Sulston returned to Cambridge and its world-famous molecular biology laboratory, where DNA was originally discovered. In California, he had worked on nucleic acids - how genetic inheritance might get going - but techniques were primitive. He made his scientific name with a detailed study of a tiny worm, Caenorhabditis elegans. There are thousands of these little worms, also known as ringworms, in every handful of soil, where they eat bacteria. As part of a research project examining the worm's genome, Sulston had the simple but audacious idea of tracing the "choreography" of the way the cells divided by just watching them hatch through a Nomarski light microscope, that magnifies at 2,000 times. Every human starts off as one cell, a fertilised egg, but our cells soon divide, spine, bones, eyes, kidney, blood and hair. Understanding the lineage of how our cells specialise is fundamental to understanding genetics. Even in C. elegans, with just 1,000 cells, it is a complex process. For 18 months, Sulston shut himself in a small room and watched worms hatch. "No one thought it was possible. Various people had looked at taking photographs, cutting and staining. But the resolution was not good enough. I twigged I could do it just by sitting and looking, so I did." It was mind-numbing, fastidious work. Sulston fondly still keeps his old microscope in his office. In true British fashion, Sulston describes his work as "not the top stuff, the breakthrough that leads to Nobel prizes, but solid middle-of-the-road science". The results were published in 1983, and Sulston, with his US collaborator Bob Waterston, who heads the other major genome sequencing centre in the University of Washington, St Louis, moved on to map the worms' genes. Although the nematode is tiny, its genome is still 100 million bases long. That is 100 million Cs, As, Gs and Ts. Decoding a genome is a bit like doing a very big jigsaw. In gene mapping, the genome is first divided up into big chunks - with the human genome there will be 22,000 segments, 150,000 letters long - and then each segment is analysed and their sequence, CATTGCC, read off. Because researchers know which big bit the individual sequence comes from, it's easier to put the whole jigsaw back together. Sulston and Waterston, viewed by James Watson at NIH as the best sequence team in the world, began sequencing the worm in 1990 as a test run for the human genome. The C. elegans genome was finally published in 1998. It was the first genome of a free-living animal ever decoded. By then, a forerunner of the current war over the human genome between Sulston, his collaborator Waterston, and Venter had already broken out. At his research institute, TIGR, Venter was producing a library of ESTs - valuable biotech material indicating the site of potential human genes - and TIGR's funders, Human Genome Sciences, sold the exclusive rights to consult this library to big pharmaceuticals such as SmithKline Beecham. The five-year deal with SmithKline Beecham alone was worth $125m. HGS was effectively operating a monopoly and demanding "reach-through" royalties; anyone who used its material and subsequently came up with a commercial application for a drug had to pay HGS a royalty. Academic researchers unable to pay the fees were locked out. Most of the data was sitting in closed computer files, waiting for paying customers. SmithKline Beecham's drug rivals, Merck, struck back. Rather than pay HGS fees, they gave Waterston a research grant to sequence a rival EST library and lodge them for free in Genbank - a public depository for genetic material and accessible to anyone. Overnight, it destroyed the economic value of HGS's precious library. "Everything they do seems to have more of a political lean to it than just science. Waterston was a willing employee, or just part of someone else's game plan, in the contest between giant pharmaceutical companies," says Venter provocatively. But for Sulston, the open publication of the EST data was the ideal outcome. "The human genome is vastly more complex, and its implications far greater, than anything we have encountered before. There is no way it should be concentrated in the hands of the few - that is exactly where Bolshevism went wrong. The human genome should be spread out laterally. We want competition on the products, not on the information itself." At TIGR, Venter had been developing a new way of sequencing genomes, called the "whole shotgun method" that relied on powerful computers and complex algorithms to reassemble tiny fragments without the aid of the gene-mapping sequences used by Sulston. Instead of first using big bits of the jigsaw, Venter just cloned the whole genome and then blasted it in small fragments. These fragments were then fed directly into sequencing machines and reassembled by concentrated computer power. In 1994, he used the shotgun method to sequence the micro-organism Haemophilus influenzae, the bug that gives children ear infection. It was the first actual organism, rather than an animal such as the worm, ever to be sequenced. Other bugs, syphilis and the bacteria that live in sulphur vents on the bottom of the ocean, followed. Again Venter came under attack for his methods. Critics claimed the shotgun method was imprecise - shotgunning the human genome leaves you with 60 million gene fragments, 2,000-10,000 letters long, to put back together again. His opponents claimed shotgunning would leave gaps in the sequence data, and would be unable to cope with larger genomes. But again Venter was triumphantly vindicated when, in collaboration with public scientists from Berkeley in California, he published the 120-million base genome of the fruit fly - important in genetic research - in March 2000. In 1997, Venter fell out badly with HGS's boss, Bill Haseltine, over the company's secretive business plan and ended their collaborative relationship. Haseltine and Venter swiftly became deadly rivals. Venter was out in the commercial cold again, lobbying for grants to sequence genomes from his academic enemies. But then his old partners, Applied Biosystems, saved him. In 1998, Perkin Elmer finally completed a new sequencing machine, the AB3700, that could sequence at hundreds of times the rate of earlier machines. Sequencing the human genome was just a question of lining up enough AB3700s - Celera has 300 of them - and turning them on. Perkin Elmer's Mike Hunkapiller, who developed the machines from their infancy, called Venter to head the new company. Big business was going to do the genome. In May 1998, Celera, which means swiftness, announced it would sequence the human code of life by 2001. Venter was his usual antagonistic self. "There was a suggestion that the public project should move on to the mouse, and that Celera would take care of the human," says Francis Collins, current head of the US government Genome Research Institute and a former colleague of Venter's. "Craig Venter does not lack for ambition or audacity." Celera's birth shattered the complacency of the public scientists in the Human Genome Project. Every major centre, including the Sanger, went on a sequencing machine-buying race from what is still the leading manufacturer, Perkin Elmer. The HGP rapidly revised its target completion date from 2010 to 2005, to 2003 and finally to the publication of a "draft" sequence this summer. No one wants to come second in the race for the code. Very quickly, the contest descended into a propaganda war, with each side questioning the other's scientific credibility, its motives, personalities and, crucially, who was going to get the credit. Sulston complains about Celera's "one-way trap door" that allows it to use the two billion bases in the public data, give nothing in return, but then claim credit for sequencing the entire genome. "They hoover up all the public data, add a bit of their own and sell it as a packaged product," says Sulston. Venter, in turn, has accused the Wellcome Trust of orchestrating a "dirty tricks" campaign. On February 29, 2000, after a sustained effort to hype up their share price, Celera raised almost $1 billion from the stock market by issuing another 3.8 million shares, at $225 a share. Two weeks later, on March 14, President Clinton and prime minister Tony Blair announced in a rare joint statement that they would like to see "unencumbered access" to the human genome. Celera immediately saw the hidden hand of the Wellcome Trust behind the statement. Although neither Clinton or Blair said anything new, Celera's shareholders panicked - believing the ongoing patent bonanza was under attack. Celera's share price dropped through the floor. The stock is now trading at $64. And to add to the company's woes, a New York law firm has just launched a class action on behalf of disgruntled investors, claiming the company suppressed vital details - later leaked by the Wellcome Trust - of Celera's secret talks with the public HGP. In many ways, the differing techniques of both sides are complementary. Combining both the public gene-mapping and Celera's shotgun data would produce a far more accurate and comprehensive data set. Teams from Celera and the HGP met near Washington in December for secret talks to hammer out details of proposed collaboration. But instead of peace and co-operation, the meeting ended in a blazing argument. The irresolvable issue was the public release of the data. Celera wanted some form of exclusive deal so as to be able to sell the genome sequence to their paying customers before handing it over to the public. There were conditions, restrictions and the sequence would only be available from Celera's website. It was hardly surprising. Celera is a private company that wants to make profits. Whatever Venter might say in public about free data release, his business partner's fine print in private seems to undermine his rhetoric; Celera is not going to give its crown jewels away. For the Wellcome Trust, the human genome was not for sale. "While establishing a monopoly on commercial uses of the human genome sequence may be in Celera's business interests, it is not in the best interests of science or the general public," it concluded in a joint HGP letter that was leaked on March 6. Prospects of future collaboration now seem slim. "Tell the Wellcome Trust they missed their timing. They could have cost us a billion dollars. We have a billion dollars in the bank to do the next stage. We are in phenomenal shape," boasts Venter. Ironically, the race for code has become an all too human story of rivalry, emotion and fear. But that is hardly surprising. The human genome is far too important to end up as just another bit of academia. It is an issue of fundamental importance, fundamental philosophy. Should our genetic code end up as the property of a private American corporation? Are our genes the property of who claims them first? Our instinctive answer is no. But in the real world, companies who invest in genomics, drugs, genetic tests, will only do so if their investments are protected. Nothing is free. Finding the right boundary between our common genetic heritage and proprietary ownership of bits of our genes is one of the many challenges that lie ahead. Soon, possibly within the next two weeks, either Craig Venter or John Sulston will be able to hold a DVD disc containing the human book of life, our genome, in his hand. Either way, it will be a stunning achievement. It will not be the end of the race for the code. Decoding the genome, locating genes, creating new drugs, interpreting the genomic babble of our ancestry, is the work of decades. But it will mark a line. It will be a break point, a new beginning in our human story.

fields.headline: Old Bank Hotel, Oxford
fields.trailText: Although the hotel is a recent - five months old - conversion of a Barclays bank, reception is calm without being austere.
fields.body:
Address: 92 - 94 High Street, Oxford OX1 4BN.

Tel: 01865 799599.

E-mail: info@oldbank-hotel.co.uk

Web address: www.oxford-hotels-restaurants.co.uk

First Impressions. Although the hotel is a recent (five months old) conversion of a Barclays bank, reception is calm without being austere.

What are the rooms like? Big, creamy, beamy; ours had an extraordinary view of the dreaming spires (Rad Cam, All Souls). TV, CD player, CDs (Kenny G), Stanley Spencer prints on the wall, no mini-bar (good news), chocs on the pillow.

The bed test. Wonderful. Huge bed with good cotton sheets (heavy but not stiff). Room was a bit hot, despite air-conditioning.

The bathroom test. Carried on the creamy-beige theme: good bath, strong shower, piles of freebies: shampoo, body lotion, sewing kit, shaving kit, tooth kit (but only one). Cotton robes.

The restaurant. The Quod Bar & Grill didn't feel like a hotel restaurant at all. Instead, a lively meeting-place with zinc-topped bar, cocktails, groovy non-studenty mixed clientele. Italian food -good buffalo mozzarella and Caesar salad; too few vegetarian options. But you can't book a table and, on a busy Saturday, we waited 45 minutes - even with priority as hotel guests. £50 for two including good bottle of wine. Cocktails £4. Breakfast was very limited for veggies (eggs only), and a bit overpriced (not included in the room rate).

The lounge. No lounge but pleasant sunny courtyard and sociable bar - buzzy, but not great if you just want to relax with a book.

What is there to see within walking distance? All the delights of Oxford: the colleges, the Bodleian Library, Christ Church meadow, the Ashmolean, the river.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? The city's beautiful enough.

How much a night? From £135 to £300, room only.

Would you go back? If you're paying.

fields.headline: Resort's boost for gay rights
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Jaci Taylor, 55, will on Friday become mayor of Aberystwyth in west Wales and make her partner, Felicity Roberts, also 55, her mayoress. Ms Taylor, of Plaid Cymru, will be the first openly gay woman to hold such a post.
fields.body:
Jaci Taylor, 55, will on Friday become mayor of Aberystwyth in west Wales and make her partner, Felicity Roberts, also 55, her mayoress. Ms Taylor, of Plaid Cymru, will be the first openly gay woman to hold such a post.

Last night she said she had never hidden her sexuality: "It wasn't really a matter of coming out. Most people have been aware we were an item and accepted it."

Ms Taylor has two daughters and separated from her husband in 1980, since when she has been with Ms Roberts, a mother-of-six. She decided to make explicit her sexuality to pre-empt any comment when photographed with her mayoress.

"I suppose I am striking a blow for gay rights in some way, but this really shouldn't be an issue. There are more important things like getting a better life for people."

fields.headline: Ulster close to breakthrough
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, late last  night dramatically announced plans to restore  devolution to Northern Ireland in 16 days' time after a  second night of intensive negotiations at Hillsborough  Castle in Co Down.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, late last night dramatically announced plans to restore devolution to Northern Ireland in 16 days' time after a second night of intensive negotiations at Hillsborough Castle in Co Down.

They unveiled the surprise proposal to re-form the power-sharing executive at Stormont on May 22, as long as the IRA plays its part with a positive statement spelling out its willingness to put its weapons beyond use.

In a joint statement, the British and Irish governments revealed vital changes to the Good Friday agreement, now two years old, which appear to have been the price to be paid to pull the IRA on board. The switches echo republican demands. The deadline for decommissioning is to be extended to June next year. It was meant to be May 22 this year.

The definition of decommissioning is set to be widened. No longer will destruction of weapons be required. Putting them beyond use, an inexplicit definition less offensive to the IRA, will be sufficient.

The government also made it clear it would never again act unilaterally in suspending the institutions, as Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, did on February 11. That can now happen only after a review of the agreement, involving both governments.

Other key details of the governments' blueprint were being kept under wraps early today. Although the parties know the broad outlines, they will only receive the full details this morning, and will be asked to consult their memberships.

Sinn Fein welcomed the development. Gerry Adams, its president, said: "This is a decisive moment. The two governments have agreed to re-establish the institutions and have set out the mechanisms and steps necessary for achieving the full implementation of the many outstanding aspects of the Good Friday agreement."

But David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionist party, refused to speak to the media, issuing a holding statement. It was potentially positive.

He said: "For weeks now we have been calling upon the republican movement to tell us what they are going to do. We now hope they will tell us what they are going to do."

Mr Trimble, who two months ago survived a challenge to his leadership, will face difficulties in selling to his sceptical Ulster Unionist Council proposals that fall short of a start to IRA decommissioning before he is asked to rejoin government with Sinn Fein. His assembly party is understood to be divided on the plan.

The main elements encompass a positive IRA statement, committing to an arms gesture within two months; government plans to cut troop numbers; and perhaps a respite for the RUC's name. That might be the carrot to tempt Mr Trimble to push his party to accept the deal. The next few days will be crucial.

There was a growing sense of optimism as the day wore on at Hillsborough yesterday. Mr Blair, on a day when devolution turned on him in London, may yet have rescued his plans for self-government in Northern Ireland in sensational fashion.

fields.headline: Man, 75, in court over 1979 killing
fields.trailText: A man aged 75 went on trial yesterday for murdering a woman whose body has yet to be identified, even though it was found 21 years ago.
fields.body:
A man aged 75 went on trial yesterday for murdering a woman whose body has yet to be identified, even though it was found 21 years ago.

Maidstone crown court in Kent was told that the case had been reinvestigated in 1998 using a new DNA test, and Harry Pennells, a retired lorry driver from Ticehurst, East Sussex, had been linked to the body found in Bedgebury forest in Kent in 1979.

Despite repeated police appeals, her identity remains a mystery, although she was between 25 and 35, six weeks pregnant, and possibly from the north of England.

Opening the prosecution, David Fisher QC, said that when the body was found, the head and body injuries were so severe that identification was not possible.

Pennels had been questioned days after; he admitted picking up a female hitchhiker but claimed to have dropped her off, and was not charged. However, specks of blood found in 1979 in a sleeping bag in his lorry and in the cab were re-examine in 1998, and linked to the deceased. The case continues.

fields.headline: Refit for Ministry of Defence
fields.trailText: The Whitehall headquarters of the Ministry of Defence - a grade 1 listed building which houses an underground bunker and Henry VIII's wine cellar - is to be refurbished in a multi-million pound deal with a private consortium, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The Whitehall headquarters of the Ministry of Defence - a grade 1 listed building which houses an underground bunker and Henry VIII's wine cellar - is to be refurbished in a multi-million pound deal with a private consortium, it was announced yesterday.

In a move that will severely test training in logistics, 2,600 staff - civilian and military - will move out over 12 consecutive weekends next summer.

The large mid-50s construction is fast becoming a health and safety hazard. It has no fire certificate. A guided tour of the building reveals open wires supported by ageing metal trays screwed into corridor ceilings. Notices warn against sticking pins in asbestos boarding on office walls.

The ministry has now signed a private finance agreement whereby it will lease the modernised building from Modus Services plc for £55m annually for 30 years.

Questioned about such expenditure at a time when the armed forces are short of effective weapons and turning to foreign suppliers for cheaper combat clothing, the MoD insisted yesterday it was money well spent.

The cost of running its existing seven buildings already amounted to £40m a year and an extra £100m would have had to be spent anyway to meet health and fire regulations.

The ministry has now signed a private finance agreement whereby it will lease the modernised building from Modus Services plc for £55m annually for 30 years. Questioned about such expenditure at a time when the armed forces are short of effective weapons and turning to foreign suppliers for cheaper combat clothing, the MoD insisted yesterday it was money well spent. The cost of running its existing seven buildings already amounted to £40m a year and an extra £100m would have had to be spent anyway to meet health and fire regulations.

webTitle: Student's suicide leaves Columbine to grieve again

fields.headline: Student's suicide leaves Columbine to grieve again
fields.trailText: A week after observing the first anniversary of the Columbine school massacre, students and teachers were grieving yesterday for a star basketball player who committed suicide at his home.
fields.body:
A week after observing the first anniversary of the Columbine school massacre, students and teachers were grieving yesterday for a star basketball player who committed suicide at his home.

Six counsellors were at the school to offer help, and supply teachers were on call to fill in for staff members who wanted to stay at home, said the Jefferson County School District spokesman, Rick Kaufman.

"It's a sombre mood at Columbine High School," Mr Kaufman said. He did not know how many students were absent, but said it was "a fair number".

The death on Thursday of Columbine pupil Greg Barnes, who was 17, was the latest tragedy to strike the school. A source said he had hanged himself.

Mr Kaufman confirmed the death, but declined to give details. "We are bound by legal constraints of what the coroner was going to release," he said. "I can tell you it did not happen at school, it did not involve guns, and the student was in school last year on April 20."

He was referring to the day when two students at the school in the Denver suburb of Littleton shot and killed 12 schoolmates and a teacher and wounded 23 others. The killers, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, then turned their guns on themselves.

Last month parents of their victims condemned the decision by a local county lawyers' office to put on sale the official scene-of-the-crime video.

The sheriff's office and the Jefferson County coroner de clined to provide additional information about Barnes's death. "Some things should remain confidential to the family," the coroner, Nancy Bodelson, said.

College basketball coach Rudy Martin met his players at the Barnes home following the death.

"I didn't know what to tell them," Mr Martin said. "I don't know what to tell my own kids. For two years, their hero has been Greg Barnes."

He said he had no inkling that Barnes was suicidal. "He stopped in and talked almost every day," Mr Martin said.

Barnes told Sports Illustrated magazine last year that he saw teacher and coach Dave Sanders, who died in the rampage, "take two shots, right in front of me". He said that he was in a science room and saw Sanders get shot through a window in the door.

Barnes was also a good friend of one of the dead students, Matt Kechter.

"We're really praying for his family," said Kechter's mother, Ann. "We know how incredibly painful this is going to be for his family and what they're going to have to go through."

But grief counsellors cautioned against automatically linking Barnes's death to the Columbine shootings, or to other tragedies that followed, including the suicide of an injured student's mother and the fatal shooting of two Columbine sweethearts in a sandwich shop.

"It's important that we recognise these things as separate incidents," said Tom Olbrich of the Jefferson Centre for Mental Health.

Barnes, who was 6ft 5in tall, led Columbine's basketball team into the semifinals of the state championship.

webTitle: How the old allegiances are fast fading away

fields.headline: How the old allegiances are fast fading away
fields.standfirst: Livingstone motivated voters in London, Dobson did notNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Ever since his 1997 election triumph, friends and foes alike have talked of Tony Blair as walking on water. On Thursday night, three years and three days after the New Labour landslide, he sank.
fields.body:
Ever since his 1997 election triumph, friends and foes alike have talked of Tony Blair as walking on water. On Thursday night, three years and three days after the New Labour landslide, he sank.

That is not say that he drowned: he is still alive and thrashing about, and could well be back on dry land none the worse for his misadventure by the time the general election comes round. But what happened in this week's elections had not until now been thought of as the kind of thing that happens to Tony.

There were three ingredients in this mix and the outcomes were instructively different. In London, an independent who wanted to fight as Labour but was not allowed to trounced all the main party candidates. Though Ken Livingstone came out of a Labour environment he won the support of many who would never have contemplated voting Labour before.

This was a wholly new kind of electoral exercise - the direct election of a mayor - and it produced a wholly different kind of outcome from any we have seen before. In that it gave Tony Blair a bloody nose, this was a good result for the Tories. But their own candidate, Steve Norris, fell far short of victory - and only did as well as he did by downplaying his links with the Conservative party.

In elections for local councils across England, the swing was sharply towards the Tories. They needed 400 gains to suggest any substantial recovery from their general election debacle. They did far better than that, with around 600. They are still - on these figures - nowhere near back to the pre-eminence of Margaret Thatcher's prime. They still control only one metropolitan borough in England, Solihull. They are still unrepresented in great cities such as Manchester and Liverpool. But after all the turmoil they have recently been through, they seem at last to be on the mend.

And yet in the byelection at Romsey, the Tories were battered. The Liberal Democrats turned them out on a swing of 12%. But that is compared with the Tory nadir of 1997. Compare this result with what happened in Romsey in 1992 and last night's result is right in line with the Liberal Democrat swings of 20% or more at the Tories' expense in Newbury, Christchurch and Eastleigh in the 1990s. Inconsistent? Of course. But this is the new electoral politics. It is horses for courses. The rules that used to cover electoral behaviour no longer apply.

Sense of guilt

The old pull of party allegiance, loyal support for your party through thick and thin, is fading away. This is a shop-around vote, voting one way today and another tomorrow, switching - with none of that sense of the guilt people used to feel on defecting - from party to party. Or, in ever increasing numbers, voters exercising their right not to bother with voting at all.

Turnout is becoming as important an electoral indicator now as the share of the vote which each party achieves. That was evident in the 1997 election, when non-voters outnumbered the second-placed Tories.

On Thursday the turnout was generally very low; even in London, despite all the alleged excitements of the Livingstone experience, it reached only the mid-30s. Except in Romsey, staying at home was the norm and voting the aberration. That is probably the key to these results. They reflect a psephological phenomenon that might be called differential motivation. Livingstone motivated voters in London; Frank Dobson did not.

Across local councils, it was mainly the most discontented who were motivated to go out and vote. With Labour in power both nationally and in so many councils, that was bound to produce some grim results for Mr Blair.

So what does the mixture of outcomes tell us about the next election?

That Labour has ground to make up? Certainly, though we knew that already: their satisfaction ratings on issue after issue have been crumbling on the polls, even though their overall lead has hardly been dented.

That Labour is in danger of missing out on a second term? That is a much more dubious proposition. Since in politics success breeds success and failure breeds failure, we may now see last night's results reflected in a dip in the Labour lead on the national polls and a boost for William Hague, whose high-profile interventions on asylum and the Tony Martin case will be held by Tory supporters to have done the party a power of good in this week's elections.

But it may well be that Labour's lead in the polls will continue to look commanding. That is because the question opinion polls ask is how you would vote in a general election tomorrow, which is not what electors were asked to decide yesterday.

Martyr and hero

However well Mr Hague's hardline approach played elsewhere, it did not save him in Romsey, where the contest concentrated on issues that count in general elections - health, education, pensions - and the turnout was far closer to general election levels than anywhere else. Differential motivation again.

So the Tories, however euphoric they feel this morning, should not get carried away.

Mr Blair, meanwhile, ought to absorb the lessons of May 4 with the same humility that made him admit the other day that he should not have tried to wangle Rhodri Morgan out of the leadership of the Welsh assembly.

The techniques of control and manipulation to which he and close colleagues attribute their triumph three years ago have become a blight on the party.

In London, they made Ken Livingstone a martyr and hero and in effect sealed it for him.

It is intriguing to note that one of the towns that Labour lost in these elections was Hartlepool, the constituency of the master New Labour fixer, Peter Mandelson. That may be mere coincidence - but it is also, perhaps, symbolic.

webTitle: Bunged-up machines cause chaos at count

fields.headline: Bunged-up machines cause chaos at count
fields.standfirst:
Electronic system brought down by dust in works

Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The wrong kind of dust was blamed for "bunging up" the electronic vote-counting machines and causing chaos at the London mayoral election count yesterday.
fields.body:
The wrong kind of dust was blamed for "bunging up" the electronic vote-counting machines and causing chaos at the London mayoral election count yesterday.

Tiny fibres from old green baize cloths on the counting tables caused at least 10 machines to break down after they became electrostatically charged and the dust collected in the scanners. The chief returning officer, Rob Hughes, admitted: "We've had a few machines that have gone pear-shaped."

The 168 machines, which have never before been used in a UK election, were due to produce a final tally by 5am yesterday, but the build-up of dust and static meant the result came seven hours later.

The machines, which resemble large photocopiers and are already used to mark students' multiple-choice exam papers, were introduced because a traditional manual count would take at least three days, while each machine is able to count 150 ballot papers a minute.

Despite a smooth full-scale mock election in February and numerous real ballots, including the 1998 elections in Bosnia-Herzegovina, yesterday all but two of the 12 machines in the Enfield and Haringey constituency broke down, while another stopped briefly in Bromley, bringing the rate at which papers were counted down from 40,000 an hour to just 27,000 an hour.

Mr Hughes said: "Dust in the air is always something difficult to solve. It caused static and stopped the machines working. They have just got bunged up. This is a brand new system of voting and a brand new system of counting. It is not surprising we have had a few problems."

Engineers from the machine supplier, Data & Research Services, were called in and, 90 minutes later, identified the problem as the old, dusty green baize covers on the counting tables. A spokesman said: "Tiny fibres got electro-statically charged and got caught up in the papers, collecting on the scanners. We stripped down the machines and cleaned the scanners and everything was fine again.

"We've never had this problem before. We've operated these machines in a typhoon in Bangladesh before without any problems."

The machines - which use sensors to detect where crosses have been placed - also failed at times to separate and count correctly the two parts of the ballot papers, while one machine was reported to have overheated and another was damaged when a table collapsed. Problems were exacerbated by incorrectly completed papers, creating a long backlog needing individual adjudications by election officials and candidates' agents, and also folded papers, which the machines cannot read.

webTitle: Blame game begins in wake of defeat

fields.headline: Blame game begins in wake of defeat
fields.standfirst:
We don't want blood on the carpet they say, but accusations fly

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street last night tried to draw a line under Tony Blair's blackest day urging the party not to turn in on itself in a "blame game" as accusations flew after Labour's biggest electoral setback for three years.
fields.body:
Downing Street last night tried to draw a line under Tony Blair's blackest day urging the party not to turn in on itself in a "blame game" as accusations flew after Labour's biggest electoral setback for three years.

The prime minister's office made clear it did not want more blood on the carpet. "That would be utterly pointless. It wasn't the greatest story but you learn from it and move on," said a senior official. "If there was one strategic error it was not thinking it through early on."

The acknowledgement by Downing Street that it and the Labour hierarchy should have drawn up plans sooner to stop Ken Livingstone came as even the PM was privately blamed for the London mayor fiasco.

"The truth is you have got to blame Blair to some extent," said a party source. "If he has not taken leadership you know that this is his responsibility, and if he has taken leadership of it then it's his responsibility."

Westminster colleagues of Frank Dobson fear he will explode if any attempt is made to pin the blame on him.

During his disastrous campaign, the former health secretary denounced the party hierarchy as "prats" and "stupid" over their handling of his battle with Mr Livingstone.

A close associate of Mr Dobson yesterday predicted he would remain loyal unless backed into a corner. "Frank's problem is that he won't tell a lie," he warned.

Other names in the frame include Margaret McDonagh, Sally Morgan, Jonathan Powell, Trevor Phillips, Jim Fitzpatrick and Jeremy Fraser.

Ms McDonagh, 38, Labour's general secretary for two years, has been the victim of a whispering campaign claiming she failed to alert No 10 of the dangers of a Livingstone challenge.

She attempted to rally Millbank's demoralised troops yesterday, urging them to avoid getting sucked into the blame game and instead head off for Watford to canvass in a weekend poll.

"Sister McDonagh doesn't act without consulting Brother Blair. It would be be daft to blame Millbank or vice versa," said an aide.

Others blame the London defeat on Ms Morgan, No 10's political secretary who used to enjoy a Ms Fixit image. She is accused of not concentrating the premier's mind much earlier. "She'll want to make sure her hands are clean,"said a critic.

Ms McDonagh and Ms Morgan, 40, used to be bitter enemies though they get on better now, with another Labour source predicting they would "sink or swim" together.

Mr Dobson believes Mr Powell, Mr Blair's chief of staff, undermined his campaign by championing Mo Mowlam as an alternative candidate.

Trevor Phillips, Mr Dobson's running mate who would have been deputy mayor, did not perform as well as expected. "Proved not to be a very good campaigner," was one verdict.

London MP Jim Fitzpatrick is expected to quit as chairman of the London Labour party after he was one of several leading lights who advised the leadership that Mr Livingstone would "bottle" going alone if defeated in the electoral college.

And Jeremy Fraser, Mr Dobson's campaign manager, was unable to overcome formidable hurdles.

Labour's national executive and London party will rake over the coals while the executive will also review local results and the Romsey lost deposit.

Houghton and Washington East MP Fraser Kemp, a former Labour campaigns co-ordinator, cautioned: "We have to listen but there's no need to panic. We're still on course to win the next election."

Strategists including pollster Philip Gould will also study data to discover why so many Labour supporters stayed at home across the country and why others voted for Mr Livingstone.

Old loyalties of class and tribe have been crumbling for years but collapsed in London on Thursday.

Early fatal errors of not picking Labour's champion sooner to flush out Mr Livingstone's determination to run were compounded by Mr Dobson's and No 10's dithering.

At first Mr Blair batted for Mr Dobson, then realised he was making the "Blair's poodle" charge worse. "By the time Frank had won the nomination it was already a pyrrhic victory," said an official.

Mr Dobson was suddenly found to be an awkward if sincere public speaker, instinctively defensive, chippy when attacked.

Mr Dobson's obsession to keep his family life private cost him. He is a cultured man with a keen interests in the arts, theatre, film and books, but he would never be filmed in a gallery.

Among the heroes of the doomed Dobson campaign were a number of London Labour MPs who twisted arms and bashed the phone to help rescue him, notably Tessa Jowell, the Blairite employment minister and an old Camden council ally.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the loyalist Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "The big danger is that the Labour party turns in on itself and indulges in a futile bout of blood-letting in a search for a scapegoat.

"The main lesson of the 1980s was that an inward looking Labour party does not win elections. We have to focus on the big picture and the real enemy, William Hague and the Tories."

Mr Livingstone appeared to seek to exploit tensions between Mr Dobson and the party hierarchy as he celebrated his victory.

"I want to say a word about my old colleague and friend, Frank Dobson, who has borne a terrible brunt of odium which was not his, but which should have rightly been reserved for people who work behind the scenes," said the new mayor.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body: Contrary to the impression we gave in a report on page 31, Sport, May 3, Guus Hiddink was not the manager of Real Madrid when they won the European Cup in 1998. That was Jupp Heynckes. webTitle: Ken's appeal dented by Cenotaph effect

fields.headline: Ken's appeal dented by Cenotaph effect
fields.standfirst: Other Politics news
fields.trailText: In the end tactical voting - what might be dubbed the "Cenotaph effect" - meant it was not quite the runaway victory for Ken Livingstone that had been predicted. Nevertheless he did manage to assemble the kind of cross-party support that Tony Blair has defined as New Labour.
fields.body:
In the end tactical voting - what might be dubbed the "Cenotaph effect" - meant it was not quite the runaway victory for Ken Livingstone that had been predicted. Nevertheless he did manage to assemble the kind of cross-party support that Tony Blair has defined as New Labour.

The breakdown of the 667,877 Londoners who gave Mr Livingstone their first preference votes shows that he managed to attract support from the entire political spectrum - although it is worth noting that only 15% of the electorate made Mr Livingstone their first preference. Overwhelmingly, these were Labour voters and he managed to win the backing of 46% of those who say they would normally vote for a Blair government.

But he also attracted significant support from the voters of other parties. More than 33% of the Liberal Democrat vote backed Mr Livingstone; more extraordinarily 24% of those who identify themselves as Conservative voters did too. This suggests that in this first presidential-style election London voters liked the idea of ditching their party allegiances and shopping around the candidates.

Some called it supermarket voting but it appears that in the final 10 days of the campaign, deeper party ties began to reassert themselves.

Mr Livingstone's victory was one truly built on his cross-party - almost anti-party - appeal but an Evening Standard/ICM poll published on 27 April, a week before the actual vote, showed his initial support from traditional Conservative and Liberal Democrat voters was even greater.

After a weekend of anti-capitalism protests culminating in the defacing of the Cenotaph, significant numbers of Liberal Democrat and Conservative voters appear to have changed their minds about voting for Mr Livingstone. It appears that this whiff of danger was enough to convince them to either sit on their hands home or vote for Mr Norris in a bid to stop Mr Livingstone.

The figures are dramatic. In the Standard/ICM poll a week before the election 47% of Liberal Democrats said they were going to back Mr Livingstone but in the end this figure slumped to 33%. He won 24% of the Conservative vote, down from 29% the week before.

There is also a sharp divide in social class. Before the election, 57% of the professional middle classes - the ABC1 voters - said they were going to vote for Mr Livingstone but in the end, this dropped to 37%. It was only among the DE manual workers that his support, at around 43%, held up.

In the London assembly elections, as in the rest of the country, the Conservatives proved that if you can get your core vote to the polls in a low turnout election, you will be able to claim success. The Tories said yesterday that their 34% share of the vote meant London was now "a Tory city." But on a dismal turnout of only 32% - 1.7m voters out of a possible 5m - it was a shaky claim.

In some outer London suburbs the turnout was five points higher than in inner London, indicating that Tory voters were more enthusiastic in going to the polls.

However, the Tory share of the vote in London was up only two points since their dismal performance in the 1997 general election, casting doubt on whether this could provide momentum for a serious Conservative challenge in the capital at next year's general election.

webTitle: A good second, with no blue rosette in sight

fields.headline: A good second, with no blue rosette in sight
fields.standfirst: Tory maverick ran unorthodox but effective campaignOther Politics news
fields.trailText: As the man who gave Mr Livingstone a far closer race than anyone could have expected, Mr Norris's respectable second place at the end of the bruising mayoral race proved that the eventual victor's fears had been well founded.
fields.body:
Steve Norris was, according to Ken Livingstone, "the only Tory candidate that we feared having to fight".

As the man who gave Mr Livingstone a far closer race than anyone could have expected, Mr Norris's respectable second place at the end of the bruising mayoral race proved that the eventual victor's fears had been well founded.

But Mr Norris was far from being an ordinary Tory candidate, choosing to run his campaign from a basement office in Victoria rather than from Conservative central office, and with not a single blue rosette or Tory frontbencher in sight.

Mr Norris, who has been privately exasperated by the Tory leadership's lurch to the right, chose his words carefully after the results were formally announced at the Queen Elizabeth II conference centre in Westminster yesterday, but his message was clear.

He had done so well, he explained, because he had campaigned "on the basis of openness, inclusivity, fairness and tolerance, of reaching out to every Londoner".

This tactic was perhaps the crucial factor in attracting many Londoners who have never before voted Tory to choose to mark their cross by his name on polling day.

"I am proud of the fact that many people, indeed many thousands of people, who have never voted Conservative before actually voted for me in this election," Mr Norris said.

His had been, he said, a "pretty terrific performance" and "certainly one that confounded all the pollsters, certainly one that enabled me to say that I had scored more votes that the next two candidates put together, to run Ken into a second ballot and in the end to come as close as any of us would have dared hope at the outset of this campaign".

For the former Tory transport minister, it has been a remarkable journey from the embarrassing 1993 tabloid headlines about "Shagger" Norris's five mistresses to his return to the spotlight and reinvention as a serious politician.

A skilled political operator, he wisely realised that his only chance of victory over the independent Mr Livingstone in a Labour-voting city lay in attracting disaffected voters from other parties.

This meant distancing himself from the Conservative party. Although Tory officials deny there was any such split between the candidate and his party, voters were hard-pressed to spot anyone on his team sporting a blue rosette, and there was no mention of the party in his election posters or on his website.

Exploiting the growing rift between Labour and Mr Livingstone, Mr Norris touched all the right liberal buttons to manoeuvre himself into the extraordinary position of being the "least worst option" for many Labour and Liberal Democrat voters eager to punish the Labour leadership for rigging the ballot but fearful of a return to the worst excesses of the GLC.

As an MP, Mr Norris supported the death penalty, the poll tax and student loans, and described commuters as "dreadful human beings". Mr Norris the mayoral candidate was a champion of civil liberties, supporting gay rights and calling for the repeal of section 28, taking a strong anti-racism and anti-sexism stance, and being both anti-hunting and pro-freedom of information.

His colourful personal life, however, was always a factor and even threatened to derail his attempts to take on the party nomination after Lord Archer quit the race in disgrace last November, when party members complained about his infidelities.

Yet Mr Norris's ability to be all things to all men (and, as the tabloids had graphically pointed out, quite a lot of women too) was also apparent as the charming self-made millionaire succeeded in being both the lovable rogue and maverick not afraid of "ruffling feathers" while, at the same time, confessing to be an "appalling anorak who happens to know more about London's bus and tube network than almost anyone else alive".

Despite his repeated refusal, during the bruising battles between the left, to "intrude on private grief", it was ultimately Mr Norris who provided the greatest threat to Ken Livingstone - and the greatest hu miliation for Frank Dobson.

Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat - and sole female - candidate, was widely regarded as having run a solid campaign despite having no background in politics.

A keen advocate of devolution and regional government, she based her campaign on her pledge to walk each of London's 150 high streets before polling day, hearing the views of voters.

Yet while pundits repeatedly praised her financial and busi ness expertise, her managerial competence and her transport policies, her brand of "grown-up" politics was not enough to tip the balance for many voters wavering in the run-up to polling day.

fields.headline: Politics for a new age
fields.standfirst:
The old party rules no longer apply

Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Everything about these elections broke the rules. We knew that would happen in London - where the mayoral race had already violated all the laws of British politics - but the shattering of norms stretched far beyond the capital. The rule book was burned yesterday, leaving politicians and citizens alike to pore over its charred remains today. What can we see in there, both for them and for us?
fields.body:
Everything about these elections broke the rules. We knew that would happen in London - where the mayoral race had already violated all the laws of British politics - but the shattering of norms stretched far beyond the capital. The rule book was burned yesterday, leaving politicians and citizens alike to pore over its charred remains today. What can we see in there, both for them and for us?

The chief beneficiary of the blaze was, of course, Ken Livingstone. This newspaper did not give him (or any other candidate) an endorsement, but we congratulate him on his victory. He won by overturning the once iron law that party labels and organisation are decisive. He had neither and yet he won. His victory should cheer all those who have yearned for a public life free of the straitjacket of party politics. That is why we urge Mr Livingstone to drop his pleas to rejoin Labour. Londoners elected him as an independent. He owes it to them to be one. To relabel himself now would look like just the kind of double-dealing which put so many off Red Ken in the first place. No, as we discuss below, the new mayor should concentrate on his work for London - and rather less on his relations with Tony Blair and his old party.

What will they make of yesterday's results? For Labour also saw some old rules broken with impunity. London proved that Labour voters can break the tribal habit and live to tell the tale. The trouncing of Frank Dobson showed that putting up a Labour rosette in a Labour town is not always enough to win: in the new, personality politics of direct election different skills are required. Another Labour rule has taken a hit. A founding premise of the Blairite project was that no one could run on the left and win. Ken Livingstone has proved that, sometimes, that is not true. Unless one believes his campaign was one of ideology-free populism, his victory has drilled a hole through a foundation stone of New Labour thinking. Labour's high command need to think hard on whether the centrist strategy that wins them general elections is a blueprint that works just as well everywhere else.

Outside London, Labour has an equal worry: turnout. The party lost close to 600 seats in English councils yesterday thanks, in large part, to the lethargy of its own supporters. With turnouts as low as 14% in parts of the so-called heartlands, Labour is facing a new threat: the armchair revolt. The old rule book said that, while low turnout was a problem at local level, things would right themselves at the general election. But can we be so sure? Yesterday's results suggest that the loyalty habit is nearly dead and that when voters think the contest is in the bag - as they did in London, they stay away. Might not these factors, coupled with an armchair revolt among what's left of the Labour faithful, make the next election much closer than the polls suggest? It's possible.

But the best illustration of quite how mixed and complicated the new politics can be is surely the Conservative party. They won on Thursday - and they lost. They won by exceeding expectations to bag almost 600 council seats and by equalling Labour's representation in the London assembly. To do that in the capital, and to see Steve Norris perform so well, is a huge boost to the Conservatives. And yet they lost the "safe" seat of Romsey. How should William Hague make sense of that? He could reflect that, while his hard talk on asylum seekers and vigilante farmers played well with the core Tory vote - which punched above its weight to win low-turnout local elections - that same rhetoric turned off enough voters to lose in a high-turnout contest like Romsey. Put that result together with the success of Mr Norris's kinder, gentler Toryism in London and an unexpected conclusion emerges. Mr Hague's rightward drift may work on the faithful, but it hurts him when it comes to winning over the country. Yesterday's results are probably enough to secure his leadership until the next election - but they also point at why he will not win it.

The Lib Dems have a lesson of their own. Charles Kennedy hinted yesterday that, after Romsey, his aim would be to push aside the Tories as the main opposition to Labour. That may well make sense for the electoral survival of the 46 Lib Dem MPs - most of whom face competition from the Tories, not Labour. This will surely take Mr Kennedy even further away than he is already from his predecessor's "project" of cooperation with Labour. Romsey will also count as a long-awaited scalp for Mr Kennedy, silencing (for now) grumbles over his lacklustre leadership.

Which brings us to us - the voters. May 4 tells us that Britain has changed. We are no longer organised into tribal party camps, weighed down by a civic duty to vote whenever asked. Instead we are shop-around voters, picking and choosing from whichever parties, or candidates, we like and increasingly exercising the none-of-the-above option. When we have the chance, London suggests, we like to mix it up by casting several different votes at the same time. It is a change which fits with other shifts in our society. Whether this will prove to be a change for the better lies in no one's hands but our own.

webTitle: Transport will be sticking point with a bottom line

fields.headline: Transport will be sticking point with a bottom line
fields.standfirst:
Capital's new mayor may seek to be consensual, but some things are not negotiable

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: People would be "quite surprised", Ken Livingstone declared in characteristic style after voting for himself on Thursday, to discover that his election as mayor would not mean London "disappearing into a great cavernous anarchistic hole" after all. He would, he promised, be presiding over a "broad administration" for the capital's new city hall.
fields.body:
People would be "quite surprised", Ken Livingstone declared in characteristic style after voting for himself on Thursday, to discover that his election as mayor would not mean London "disappearing into a great cavernous anarchistic hole" after all. He would, he promised, be presiding over a "broad administration" for the capital's new city hall.

Livingstone's first move will be to offer the hand of cooperation to the prime minister who worked so hard and at such cost to prevent his election, having insisted that while elections highlighted political divisions, his aim would now be to unite Londoners and help heal the rift in Labour which was opened by the mayoral selection.

Quoting Winston Churchill's homily in favour of magnanimity in victory yesterday at his new Whitehall headquarters, the mayor was at pains to emphasise his consensual approach and his determination that the Greater London assembly dispense with the "sterile politics" of Westminster party caucusing.

Inclusivity will be the theme of his first days in office. The man who once terrorised the suburbs as Red Ken might have just secured the largest ever electoral victory by a candidate to Labour's left, but the former Greater London council leader has no intention of scaring off elements of the coalition he has assembled for his electoral comeback.

While New Labour and Tory politicians have vied with each other to brand him as a threat to jobs and public order, the Brent East MP has been wooing London business organisations and the police in a series of private meetings. Livingstone has, his aides report, developed a "genuinely high regard" for the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, and their discussions are said to have been particularly positive.

Now he will have to build a working relationship with the 25 newly elected assembly members and the 32 boroughs that will continue to deliver most local services to Londoners. But armed with his new powers of patronage and Tony Blair's edict to Labour GLA members not to seek confrontation with the new mayor - at least this side of the general election - that should not prove to be an insuperable task.

The new mayor's first key appointments, starting with a deputy - he has mischievously floated the idea of rotating the job around the main parties in the GLA - are likely to be announced in the next few days, though others will have to wait for more of the "listening to London" that Livingstone favoured in the run-up to his decision to stand as an independent.

Several of the new mayor's long-established advisers and allies - such as his agent Simon Fletcher, race and policing campaigner Lee Jasper, and Tower Hamlets councillor Kumar Murshid - are expected to get jobs in the new London administration, but most appointees will be less predictable.

Among the string of jobs effectively in the mayor's gift are two political advisers, a 10-strong policy unit, a cabinet and most of the members and chairs of the boards due to run transport, the police, fire brigade, culture and economic development when the GLA finally gets off the ground on July 3.

The new mayor's team has already targeted a group of Labour GLA members regarded as most amenable to forming alliances with his embryonic London administration.

But for all Livingstone's grand declarations for cross-party cooperation, there are some bottom-line issues his closest advisers insist are not negotiable, foremost of which is the mayor's opposition to the partial sell-off of the London Underground.

Speculation that the newly crowned independent is planning a graceful climbdown on the issue is wrong, they say, despite the fact that the government is not intending to hand over control of the tube until its public-private partnership (PPP) is locked into place.

"We have no technical powers to block them," one aide comments, "but Ken regards this election as having been a referendum on the tube privatisation issue and we aren't looking for face-savers - we're looking to stop the PPP."

That tallies with what Livingstone himself said in March, when he pledged: "I'll use all my resources, everything I can mobilise, including a court challenge, if the government doesn't drop their proposal to break up the tube and go for partial privatisation."

At his inaugural press conference yesterday, he repeated the warning, adding that just as he wanted to cooperate with Downing Street, the government "should also cooperate with London" by "respecting the views of Londoners" and accepting that an overwhelming majority had voted for candidates opposed to its part-privatisation plans.

In the longer term, Livingstone has said he will freeze tube and bus fares for four years, introduce a central London congestion charge and press for more government investment in London's transport system with the aim of cutting the capital's traffic overload by 15% by 2010.

Promising the "most open, accessible and inclusive style of government ever seen in the UK", the new mayor plans to pick up where the GLC left off with equal opportunities policies, an increase of police numbers by 2,000, sponsorship of ambitious arts, sports and environmental programmes, and cajoling of money out of Whitehall for more low-cost homes and better health and education services. At his victory party on Thursday night, Livingstone signalled that the greening of London would be a dominant theme of his administration.

But the mayor and GLA's powers are modest and tightly constrained by government. Livingstone's effectiveness will largely depend on how effectively he uses his electoral mandate and platform to exert political pressure on government, businesses and public service providers.

He was already up and running yesterday, pressing for government intervention to ensure the survival of Ford's Dagenham plant in Essex and blaming the high value of the pound for the threat to its future.

Having declared his election victory "independence day" for London, an early test of such tactics will come with the announcement of the government's new regional spending plans in the next few weeks. Livingstone will be demanding that central government stop "kicking London" and his campaign for more money for the capital is likely to be relentless.
