fields.headline: There are limits
fields.standfirst:
Mr Blair and the mayor must explore them

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Tony has not altered his view of Ken: the only place he would happily see him installed as mayor would be Timbuktu. But London has spoken. The prime minister says he accepts its decision and together they have to ensure this new enterprise works.
fields.body:
Tony has not altered his view of Ken: the only place he would happily see him installed as mayor would be Timbuktu. But London has spoken. The prime minister says he accepts its decision and together they have to ensure this new enterprise works. Ken has not changed his view of Tony. He is sad, rather than angry, that Mr Blair could not endorse his campaign for the mayoralty: had that happened, he added winsomely at his press conference yesterday, his victory would by now have been hailed as the jewel in Mr Blair's crown. In each case, though, magnanimity is mixed here with threat. Mr Livingstone, the prime minister said, must use his power "responsibly". Read that as meaning: "Don't start trying it on with us." As for Mr Livingstone, he several times yesterday reminded the government that Thursday's result was Labour's worst ever defeat in the capital. If it failed to adjust to this fact of life, it would pay a heavy price. Read that as meaning: "I've beaten you once and if you try to obstruct me, I can beat you again."

They may learn to love each other in time, but the odds are against it. There is ripe potential for disagreement, not least because the office is new and untried. The immediate dispute, in which opinion polls suggest most people in London are on his side - this newspaper backs him too - is over the Underground. Mr Livingstone means to stand by his plan to raise money through bonds: Mr Prescott is determined to stop him. Already yesterday the new mayor was talking of seeking a judicial review if thwarted. Again, the threat was patent: he could not believe that the government would seek to "pick a fight" on the issue after the drubbing Londoners gave it.

Then there is law and order and the policing of London. Yesterday Mr Livingstone could almost have been Jack Straw: "The drug dealer, the racist thug, the robber, the mindless yobs defiling monuments dedicated to those who gave their lives for our liberty, all these people will find the new mayor distinctly uncuddly." That is a change of tune which some of his hotter supporters may find unappealing. Others - the police and Mr Straw included - may ask: will it last? And how can he get the city moving again without alienating the motorists whom Mr Blair is so eager not to upset? On top of that, he is taking on, with huge ambition, an office whose powers are carefully reined in to prevent feared excesses. When the mayor proposes and the Treasury vetoes, will Mr Livingstone put his head down and negotiate, or will he merely denounce and demand that his powers be increased?

Yet tensions like these are inseparable from real devolution, as opposed to the brand of controlled devolution for which Mr Blair all too obviously yearns. There needs to be a courteous and reasoned, but not too continuous dialogue. The government created this office: it must give it the space to breathe and thrive. There must not be a climate of interference and censure. Mr Livingstone must remember that he got where he is on the back of a broad coalition which wants to see him concentrate on making London a safer, cleaner and more efficient city, not on trying to cut out a place for himself on the national stage. Londoners want him to be exciting, but not many would thank him for a state of perpetual conflict. Despite the low level of turnout, his is a famous victory. Tony needs to take proper account of that. But Ken should not push it too far.

webTitle: Green party's success puts environment at top of agenda

fields.headline: Green party's success puts environment at top of agenda
fields.standfirst: Other politics news
fields.trailText: The Green party yesterday hailed the election of three of its members to the London assembly as a historic move that would ensure the environment would become a central issue in the new body.
fields.body:
The Green party yesterday hailed the election of three of its members to the London assembly as a historic move that would ensure the environment would become a central issue in the new body.

Darren Johnson, who stood for mayor, is being tipped as a future deputy to Ken Livingstone after the Greens won 11% of the votes for the London-wide assembly.

The party, which polled a high of 16% in the North-East constituency, also won assembly places for Victor Anderson and Jenny Jones.

Mr Johnson, 33, a PhD stu dent, said: "It's a really historic day for the Green party and a historic day for London." He pledged that the Green group would "want to get stuck into the decision-making process", adding: "We aren't just going to be shouting from the sidelines."

In his mayoral manifesto, Mr Johnson proposed a 20mph speed limit across London and a daily £10 charge on motorists to drive into town.

The Greens' success in London means that the party now has six prominent elected representatives in Britain, including two MEPs and a member of the Scottish parliament.

The veteran campaigner Jean Lambert, an MEP, said the Greens were now a serious political movement in Britain. "We are catching up with our sister parties elsewhere in Europe," she said.

The proportional voting system, coupled with Labour's poor performance, has ensured that no party has a majority, giving the Greens a strong voice in the assembly.

Mr Johnson is likely to work closely with the new mayor -he could be awarded the environment brief - after Mr Livingstone advised his supporters to vote Green in assembly elections and told supporters at a private party on election night that the environment was one of the most important issues facing London.

webTitle: Ever his own man, but the world has moved on

fields.headline: Ever his own man, but the world has moved on
fields.standfirst:
Red Ken he may have been, but he has always been a realist

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair believed Ken Livingstone could not and should not be elected as mayor of London unless he had "changed" since the time he led the Greater London council in the 1980s. There is little evidence that he has.
fields.body:
Tony Blair believed Ken Livingstone could not and should not be elected as mayor of London unless he had "changed" since the time he led the Greater London council in the 1980s. There is little evidence that he has.

Livingstone did not get the largest personal vote in British electoral history by kow-towing to the machine politicians in the Labour party that evicted him. Three-quarters of a million Londoners chose him because he was his own man - articulate, irreverent and unwilling to obey instructions when he thought his party was taking a wrong turning.

In the early hours of yesterday morning, at his victory party in the Silk and Spice restaurant bar in the heart of the City, he promised his adoring supporters: "What you have invested in me, I will never betray."

That may not have meant much to many of the barely politicised twenty-somethings who flocked to his cause. But to the veteran socialists who accused him of treachery when he tried to keep the show on the road at the GLC, it was a signal that Livingstone's political purpose is undimmed.

When his long journey to the mayoralty started in 1997, he would not have encouraged speculation about his candidacy if he had not seen it as part of a wider political objective.

At the outset he was reluctant to be sucked back into the London municipal politics from which he graduated in 1986. Once the adrenalin of the campaign started flowing, he rediscovered a genuine interest in public transport, policing and the capital's other manifold problems. He started thinking and behaving like a mayor in waiting.

But the initial motivation had more to do with national politics. He saw the mayoralty as a platform for resisting the next stages of the Blairite project.

The prime minister gives the impression that he does not regard his modernisation of the Labour party as complete. We do not yet know whether that means further dilution of the trade union link after the next election, or perhaps closer liaison with the Liberal Democrats.

Livingstone saw his mayoralty as a powerbase to fight a final divorce between Labour and socialism. He had an ill-formed notion that he could do for Londoners what the Scottish National party had done for the Scots: provide a leftwing alternative that would make the prime minister worry about a leeching of support from the left.

None of that means that Livingstone is about to use the mayoralty to bring capitalism to its knees. He is a pragmatic politician, not a Marxist ideologue.

Blair's verdict that he could not be mayor unless he had changed was based on a misreading of those GLC years. On the key decisions Livingstone chose to keep his administration in office rather than chase popularity on the left.

When the law lords smashed his cheap fares policy in his first year of office, he refused to support the "can't pay, won't pay" campaign to defy their ruling. When Conservative ministers imposed a cap on the GLC's local tax bill, he voted to comply, against cries of treachery from the left.

For at least 18 months, he has privately made a clear distinction between two sides to his mayoralty. On matters affecting the administration of London he will be pragmatic and inclusive, attempting to build a consensus with the business community and the main political parties.

Tactically, he has no alternative. His executive powers are tightly constrained and he will achieve nothing if he cannot build a working relationship with London borough leaders and Labour ministers. They too will suffer if the relationship cannot be made to work.

Participants in this drama would do well to re-read Livingstone's open letter in the Guardian in January last year. He gave the prime minister "a categorical assurance that, if Londoners voted for me to be their first elected mayor, I would work with your government, not against it".

That was when Livingstone was seeking the Labour nomination. Blair has little option but to accept the offer now Livingstone is mayor.

So we are now embarking on a period of curious manoeuvring between a prime minister whose image of electoral invincibility has been dented and an independent mayor with untested powers and conflicting political objectives.

In his heart Livingstone will feel vindicated and elated that the people of London have given him an unprecedented solo victory against the might of the official party machines. He will be sorely tempted to score political points such as his warning on election night that the result was a wake-up call to the government to make Gordon Brown learn lessons from Labour's defeat. He will not give way easily on his campaign against partial privatisation of the tube.

But in his head Livingstone knows he must work with the Blairites. That is why he will be offering Frank Dobson a role as head of his anti-poverty unit and proposing a Labour assembly member as his deputy.

Over the next few days he may give conflicting signals as the balance between heart and head settles down. Pot shots at New Labour may get in the way of a deal. The relationship may take years to stabilise.

But Mayor Livingstone working with a Labour government will not be the same as GLC leader Livingstone battling with the Thatcher government. Circumstances have changed, even if the man has not.

The most likely outcome is that Livingstone will reach an understanding with ministers on London's affairs, but he will use the high-profile mayoral platform to fight Blair on party business. That is why the prime minister, amid the devastation of Labour's mayoral defeat, will console himself that denying Livingstone the party's nomination was in his interests in the long run.

 John Carvel is the author of Turn Again Livingstone, Profile Books, £6.99

webTitle: Peace hopes rise with IRA 'ready' to put new initiative

fields.headline: Peace hopes rise with IRA 'ready' to put new initiative
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's frantic efforts to spark a return to devolution in Northern Ireland went into overdrive as crucial talks continued last night at Hillsborough Castle amid signs that the IRA was ready to table a new initiative on arms.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's frantic efforts to spark a return to devolution in Northern Ireland went into overdrive as crucial talks continued last night at Hillsborough Castle amid signs that the IRA was ready to table a new initiative on arms.

Mr Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, were locked in negotiations with Ulster Unionists, Sinn Fein and the SDLP, with several sources suggesting discussions were more serious than at any time since the Good Friday agreement was negotiated two years ago. Mr Blair was expected to remain for an unscheduled second night.

The British and Irish governments, learning from previous experience, were downplaying expectations of progress. But there were increasing hopes of a breakthrough, and President Clinton was consulted.

Mr Blair's faith in devolution remained clear, despite his disappointment yesterday at Frank Dobson's humiliating defeat in the race for London mayor. He said he remained committed to the agreement.

Niall O'Dowd, publisher of the Irish Voice, a pro-republican US newspaper, fanned optimism when he said in a radio interview he believed the IRA was poised to make a new offer.

He believed it would go further than the IRA initiative made three months ago just as Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, suspended the power-sharing executive after 72 days. Mr O'Dowd, who was speaking on RTE, is a close confidant of Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president. His interpretations are usually correct.

Another important element was the government's failure so far to publish a policing bill, paving the way for the Patten reforms of the RUC. It had been expected this week.

That has lead to speculation that David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, would win a respite for the RUC name, alongside the new description, the Policing Service of Northern Ireland, to persuade his sceptical party.

The blueprint leading to re-formation of the institutions would include a statement from the two governments, and Ulster Unionist acceptance to rejoin the executive with Sinn Fein before the IRA begins to decommission its weapons. The most crucial element is an IRA statement.

Mr Blair would put pressure on Mr Trimble if the IRA fleshed out its February 11 initiative to put weapons beyond use. He is ready to alter the remit of General John de Chastelain's decommissioning body to widen the definition away from destruction.

fields.headline: Armchair rebellion alarms Labour
fields.standfirst: Disaffected supporters in heartlands key to Blair's lossesNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Senior Labour backbenchers and middle ranking ministers yesterday sounded new warnings about the party losing its grip in traditional heartlands after sweeping Liberal Democrat and Tory local election gains in parts of England.
fields.body:
Senior Labour backbenchers and middle ranking ministers yesterday sounded new warnings about the party losing its grip in traditional heartlands after sweeping Liberal Democrat and Tory local election gains in parts of England.

With Labour losing over 560 seats outside London along with 15 councils - almost twice as many as senior ministers were predicting earlier this week - Tony Blair attempted to play down the significance of almost 600 new Conservative councillors and Tory control in 16 more town halls.

While losing Torbay to the Tories, Liberal Democrats consolidated their hold on Liverpool and Sheffield, while taking Oldham from Labour and helping to remove Labour from overall control in Hartlepool, Peter Mandelson's constituency, after 21 years.

But the prime minister's claim that voters accepted the government was committed to a "long-term programme of change" - with the implication they were prepared to be patient while reforms, such as health and education, filtered through - was challenged by senior MPs, and privately some ministers, after Labour's worst elections defeat in eight years.

Viewing the opposition advancing from the south coast to the West Midlands, Pennine towns in Lancashire and Yorkshire and other northern citadels, backbenchers said the Labour losses should be viewed as a "wake up call" to the government.

With turnout around 30% overall, they warned that disaffected supporters were now handing seats to the opposition on a plate by refusing to vote. "We have to get across more effectively what the government has achieved," said Sir Jeremy Beecham, Labour chairman of the Local Government Association.

Two former ministers went further by warning that the "armchair rebellion" could threaten key seats at next year's general election unless monumental efforts were made to "re-connect" with traditional areas.

"There's a lot of unease out there," said Peter Kilfoyle, MP for Liverpool Walton, who resigned as a junior defence minister earlier this year. "The message for the leadership is, 'don't take your core vote for granted'. Let's hope this is a short, sharp shock which will renew the leadership's perception of what needs to be done."

Claiming the result was "not good but not catastrophic", Doug Henderson, another former defence minister and MP for Newcastle North, said voters in traditional areas had yet to see their high expectations of the government being met. "A lot of people need a lot of convincing before the general election and the battleground between now and then is persuading core supporters to come out and vote," he said.

A normally loyal middle-ranking minister joined colleagues in warning that continued uncertainties surrounding manufacturing, caused by the high pound and the government's "over-emphasis" on the south east, were driving voters away.

Such an argument was reinforced by opposition advances in Birmingham, where Labour's 36-seat majority was cut to 15, partly because of the "Longbridge factor" as well as the intervention of a Kashmiri freedom party, which split the Labour vote.

Sir Richard Knowles, the veteran former council leader, lost the seat he has held for 24 years. He said fears for the future of Rover had been a "big problem on the doorstep".

Conservatives also gained control of councils from Great Yarmouth to Rossendale, in the north west, while re-taking town halls in their old Surrey heartlands, as well as making steady progress in the West Midlands. They took Worcester from Labour after 20 years, regained overall control of Solihull and Stratford upon Avon, while in Walsall Labour lost overall control.

webTitle: Trouble at mill towns as Labour loses in Lancashire

fields.headline: Trouble at mill towns as Labour loses in Lancashire
fields.standfirst: Voters say cobbles to ruling party after 14 yearsOther politics news
fields.trailText: The Tories claimed a famous victory in Rossendale, snatching nine seats from Labour, which has held sway in this chain of small towns in the east Lancashire valleys for 14 years.
fields.body:
The Tories claimed a famous victory in Rossendale, snatching nine seats from Labour, which has held sway in this chain of small towns in the east Lancashire valleys for 14 years.

But no one was cracking open the Bollinger in Fitzpatrick's Bar in Rawtenstall, round the corner from the council offices. This is partly because they take a phlegmatic view of politics in these parts but mainly because Fitzpatrick's is Britain's last remaining temperance bar, home of warming alcohol-free cordials and Fiery Jack's rubbing ointment.

Dale Humphreys, who works for the council-owned bus company, popped in for a pint of blood tonic. He did not have time to vote on Thursday but was not surprised by the result.

"It used to be a very strong Labour council round here but I think people have voted Conservative because they were fed up with the way the council runs roughshod over them," he said. "They just did what they wanted."

Ask him about local issues and he will tell you, as will many voters on the street outside (where the La Lingerie shop advertises "control thongs"), that it all comes down to Ilex and cobbles. Ilex is a crumbling mill in the centre of town that has been an eyesore for years; the cobbles - some of them from Portugal - are those on Bank Street, newly relaid with the help of English Heritage.

Local people hate these cobbles with a passion, complaining of traffic rumble, poor drainage and the sheer expense of this retreat into Victorian fantasy. And they are not very happy that Rossendale has one of the highest council taxes in the country.

Houses are cheap, with a decent terrace home costing £35,000, but wages are low and the traditional industries, shoes and textiles, are dying.

"I've always voted Conservative because they are the only people who can run the country," said Ian Howarth, a goldsmith whose wife has a local jewellery shop. "I'm concerned about how the council spends money - or wastes it. There must be better ways of spending money to get the valley's businesses running."

Down in Waterfoot on the road to Bacup, solicitor John Holt, leader of the Conservative group, was trying to come to terms with the scale of his party's local victory (24 Conservatives, 12 Labour) after a campaign in which what line to take on asylum seekers never cropped up as an issue.

"We didn't expect to do as well although we thought we would take control," he admitted. "Part of the reason, without a doubt, was a reaction to the government and part was a reaction to the Labour-run council.

"And some people combined those two, saying they didn't think either national or local government was delivering much for the people of Rossendale.

"Stalwart Labour supporters just didn't vote. We got some switches but not enough to be significant in a general election. But the trend is there."

He makes no rash promises because he knows the council is hard up. "I'm being totally realistic. There is no room for highfalutin ideas and pipe dreams. We have to get our feet under the table and get things sorted."

Defeated Labour councillors, faced with long evenings with no committee meetings to attend, could do no better than visit Fitzpatrick's to pick up a bottle of Passion Potion.

"For lovers young and old," it says on the label. "Serve chilled and undiluted on a quiet night in."

fields.headline: Populism pays for buoyant Hague
fields.standfirst: Leader shrugs off Romsey blow amid council winsTories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Leader shrugs off Romsey blow amid council wins.
fields.body:
William Hague has endured a run of bad luck since taking over as Tory leader, but on Thursday night he struck lucky for the first time.

Had the Romsey byelection been the only poll on Thursday, with no other elections to overshadow the Tory defeat, he would now be facing the gravest crisis of his leadership with talk of an imminent challenge. Instead Mr Hague has reinforced his leadership by notching up more than 600 gains in the local council elections and hammering Labour in London.

A buoyant Tory leader, who yesterday launched a tour of former heartland councils which have now returned to the fold, hailed the nationwide results and dismissed the Romsey defeat. "We have lost an election in which 35,000 people voted and we have made gains in one in which 5mpeople voted," he said on the steps of Central office.

His aides believe the council results, where the Tories swept back into power in former strongholds, show that his strategy of latching onto populist issues has paid handsome dividends. They believe that the Tories' save the pound campaign has played well in the Eurosceptic west country, while Mr Hague's hardline stance on asylum seekers has played well in the south east.

Sources on the left of the party believe, however, that their defeat in Romsey is a devastating blow which shows that the Tories' grassroots recovery is not translating to a national level. Mr Hague may dismiss Romsey as a blip, but the result shows that even in supposedly Tory heartland areas, voters are prepared to vote tactically on a massive scale to block the Conservatives.

After a campaign with no freak local factor, fought primarily on national issues, the Conservative vote in Romsey slid by 4.1% on the last general election, already regarded as the high water mark of anti-Tory feeling by the party. "The voters have neither forgotten nor forgiven the Tories," the Lib Dem campaigns chief Lord Rennard said early yesterday.

One leftwing Tory said that the leadership should follow the example of Steve Norris who won 27% of first preferences in London after distancing himself from Mr Hague and appealing to the centre ground where general elections are won.

"The leadership have got to learn to reach out to all sides," the source said. "They must accept that the centre ground is not some mushy area, but a firm basis from which to appeal across the spectrum."

The source felt, however, that the Hague camp would not heed his warnings. "The Tory bunker is now several feet deeper than it was at the same time yesterday," he said. "They will say that our success in the local elections shows how the liberal establishment were wrong to criticise William over asylum and crime. That's fine as spin, but they should never believe their own spin."

This was borne out by a Hague aide who dismissed Romsey as a "bit of Hampshire" which contrasted with the "whole of England" the party had picked up at the local elections.

Two images of the Tories will endure from yesterday. There will be the picture of Mr Norris talking about reaching out to a wide audience and warmly congratulating Mr Livingstone on the stage of the London results centre after his victory as mayor.

And there will be the picture of the sour face of the Old Etonian and farmer Tim Palmer, who railed against the Lib Dems for having the audacity to deprive the Tories of Romsey. Almost spitting blood, Mr Palmer declared that Romsey was "a Conservative seat and to the Conservatives it will return".

If Mr Hague dispenses with the likes of Mr Palmer and embraces the Norris style of politics, he may reach out to a wider audience. But his camp seem set on picking on populist issues with their eye on core voters.

fields.headline: Polling experiments win popular vote
fields.standfirst: Other politics news
fields.trailText: Overall voter apathy in Thursday's polls obscured a run of successes for voting experiments by local councils that made the elections the most innovative since 18-year-olds were given the vote in 1969.
fields.body:
Overall voter apathy in Thursday's polls obscured a run of successes for voting experiments by local councils that made the elections the most innovative since 18-year-olds were given the vote in 1969.

Across the country, wards with pilot schemes for electronic voting, mobile polling stations and up to a week of extra voting days bucked the generally gloomy trend.

Allowing all electors to have a postal vote proved the most effective of the changes, which are being encouraged by the government under reforming sections of the Representation of the People Act 2000 that received royal assent in March. In Gateshead, where overall turnout was 29.6%, two wards chosen to test entirely postal elections - with freepost - saw the figure shoot from 30.1% last year to 62.2% and from 19.5% to 46.3%.

"The convenience seems to have done the trick," said Ian Clarkin of Gateshead council, "but we also had some 800 people handing in their postal envelopes at the library and civic centre on Thursday."

Exclusively postal voting also lifted the turnout in Doncaster where Conisbrough ward piloted the experiment and saw turnout jump to 39.8% from 16.1% in an autumn byelection and 24.4% last May.

The results, which are being sent to the Home Office for monitoring and a possible roll-out of reforms nationally next year, applied in politically unexciting areas as well as marginal wards where voters had an obvious chance to make a difference. The larger of the two increases in Gateshead was in inner-city Bensham, a Labour stronghold with scant prospect of change.

The charms of changing the voting system itself were less evident, with London's new preferential system scoring only 35% overall. But taking the polling station to the people, via mobile ballot boxes, proved generally successful. Norwich had 90 requests for home visits, in spite of the requirement of a GP's signature, and a tour of sheltered housing in Watford by a "voting van" achieved a 44% poll of elderly residents.

The main glitches hit electronic voting, with London's long delays matched at Stratford-on-Avon. But in Bury, the council is to extend a touch-screen voting system after a pilot in Besses ward attracted an unusually high number of older voters and a result within 50 minutes of close of poll.

Supermarket polling, believed to be in tune with an increasingly "shop-around" attitude to candidates by many voters, was also brisk in Watford, where customers at Asda had a polling station open from last Friday to Sunday.

Final results of the experiment in the borough, which has more pilots than anywhere else, will not be known until Monday, as voting continues throughout this weekend.

The complicated electoral system in London confounded tens of thousands of voters. Under the new system, voters had a first and second choice for mayor. In the assembly election Londoners voted for a constituency member, elected on a first-past-the-post basis, and for a London-wide list of members elected by PR.

Around 2% of mayoral ballot papers were rejected. In the City and East constituency, 8,050 ballot papers were rejected out of a total of 117,653 for the London-wide list in the assembly election.

webTitle: Lib Dems hail byelection win as snub to Tory hard line

fields.headline: Lib Dems hail byelection win as snub to Tory hard line
fields.standfirst: Kennedy says lurch to right repelled votersSpecial report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, yesterday hailed his party's shock by-election victory in Romsey as a "triumph for the politics of hope over the politics of fear" and said the result proved that William Hague's shift to the right could not succeed at a general election.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, yesterday hailed his party's shock by-election victory in Romsey as a "triumph for the politics of hope over the politics of fear" and said the result proved that William Hague's shift to the right could not succeed at a general election.

Congratulating Sandra Gidley, victor in the formerly true blue Hampshire seat, a jubilant Mr Kennedy sought to portray the win as a launchpad for his party's general election campaign and a highly damaging blow to the Conservatives, who lost the poll on a 12.6% swing.

The Liberal Democrats had succeeded in wooing not only disillusioned Labour supporters and tactical voters, but also former Conservative voters who were "repelled" by William Hague's Tory party, Mr Kennedy said.

After a frenetic Lib Dem campaign that outshone a somewhat complacent Conservative effort - despite three visits to the constituency from Mr Hague - Mrs Gidley, a pharmacist, defeated the Tory farmer Tim Palmer by a 3,311 majority and saw Labour's Andrew Howard lose his deposit. The byelection followed the death of the Tory MP Michael Colvin in a fire at his home in February.

After a long night that saw cautious Tory hopes turn to gloom during an exceptionally sluggish count, the Lib Dems partied till dawn in Romsey's balloon-decked town hall before Mr Kennedy's victory walkabout and a photocall beneath a statue of the Liberal prime minister and Romsey resident Lord Palmerston.

Tory banners still hung above the market square, but Mr Palmer, a personable but uninspiring old Etonian whose Dorset residency counted against him in the poll, was nowhere to be found.

Lib Dem strategists, who took the decision to "throw the kitchen sink" at the campaign in the hope of wrongfooting the Tories, point to the verdict as vindication of their argument that Mr Hague's recent hardline pronouncements on asylum and law and order can do no more than guarantee the hardcore Conservative vote.

Lord Razzall, chairman of the Lib Dem campaigns committee, said yesterday: "Hague is polarising the country between the 30% who buy those argu ments and 30% who find them repellent. Romsey shows that tactic only works with elections with a small turnout of around 30% or less, such as the local or European elections."

The Hampshire seat, with a turnout of 55%, was a far closer guide to the general election result than the local elections, he said. "There was a big Tory stay-at-home factor here, as well as those that came over to us. Hague is marching his party to electoral oblivion if he continues down this road."

Mr Kennedy said the result had left Mr Hague's election strategy in tatters. His party's win was "a triumph for the politics of hope over the politics of fear, for the politics of wanting to unite communities".

The Lib Dem leader, who succeeded Paddy Ashdown last August, can feel personally strengthened as a result of the win after an occasionally shaky first nine months.

The figures

Party / Vote

Gidley Lib Dem 19,571

Palmer Con 16,260

Howard Lab 1,451

Lib Dem majority 3,311

Swing (Con to Lib Dem) 12.56%

fields.headline: Poison theory booted out
fields.trailText: Sir Hudson Lowe was, like Napoleon (How perfidious Albion may have poisoned Napoleon, May 5), manipulated by de Montholon, who managed to get rid of most of his loyal supporters on one pretext or other, including changing personal physicians at regular intervals.
fields.body:
Sir Hudson Lowe was, like Napoleon (How perfidious Albion may have poisoned Napoleon, May 5), manipulated by de Montholon, who managed to get rid of most of his loyal supporters on one pretext or other, including changing personal physicians at regular intervals. The motives of de Montholon are reasonably clear, because he also succeeded in becoming Napoleon's heir, part of the justification for which was his own wife bearing Napoleon's daughter, Josephine.

The de Montholons scurried to rejoin Napoleon's sinking ship after Waterloo. Sir Hudson Lowe was personally chosen for the job by Wellington. He definitely relished the idea of Napoleon being lectured by that gentleman on the superior organisation of the Prussian army, whose first action at Waterloo had been an attack on the King's German Legion because their regimental shakoes looked French. In ac tual fact the Hudson Lowes ignored Napoleon as much as possible and revelled in their tinpot dictatorship of St Helena. They would never have wanted to poison the only man between them and the total obscurity awaiting them in England. As for Wellington, the man who refused to train cannon on his rival would not be able to imagine such an action, let alone give the order for it.

Ian Menz-McNicol
Hoechst, Germany
imcnicol@esoc.esa.de

 Several years ago a TV programme investigated the wallpaper in Napoleon's place of exile and found it was made with an arsenic green dye. It suggested a plausible route, involving the damp climate and a fungus, whereby the arsenic could have poisoned Napoleon.

EG Matthews
Wimborne, Dorse
wimtalk@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Eye balls
fields.trailText: Brilliant argument there by Simon Regan (Drooping Eye, May 4). Private Eye used to have lots of money to throw parties, which was good; now it has lots of money to throw parties, which is bad.
fields.body:
Brilliant argument there by Simon Regan (Drooping Eye, May 4). Private Eye used to have lots of money to throw parties, which was good; now it has lots of money to throw parties, which is bad. It's smug and lazy, but it should keep on doing the same jokes and characters it was known for in the old days. And a consistently massive circulation proves that people don't like it as much as they used to.

As a hack who's actually worked for the Eye in recent years can I point out a couple of tiny flaws in his thesis: Ingrams and most of his "sorely missed" chums are still very much in residence in the office and on the jokes pages, and TV's Ian Hislop is the most omnipresent editor I've ever worked for. He even has a frustrating habit of remaining in the office long after pub opening time.

Adam Macqueen
London
news@bigissue.com

fields.headline: Lessons from the polls...
fields.trailText: I write as a Labour candidate beaten in the elections for Amber Valley borough council. Low turnout and mid-term disillusionment with government were certainly factors in the defeat but, in my view, the problems run deeper.
fields.body:
I write as a Labour candidate beaten in the elections for Amber Valley borough council. Low turnout and mid-term disillusionment with government were certainly factors in the defeat but, in my view, the problems run deeper. For years the Labour-controlled council highlighted and attacked the unfairness of the Tory government's allocation of funding to councils. We consistently had to cut services whilst increasing the council tax well beyond the rate of inflation. We believed a Labour government would bring some equity, but those hopes have not yet been realised.

Instead, the quality of the local environment has continued to deteriorate and crumble. Gullies and drains are blocked; roads full of pot-holes; footpaths positively dangerous; grass cut irregularly; litter not swept; and so on. There has been little or nothing to tell the voters about what a Labour-controlled council has achieved in improving basic services. All the local problems stem from a long-term lack of resources and government's continuing failure to address funding inequality between councils.

This is a "heartland" issue for Labour; the role of councils in helping deliver a feel-good factor has been seriously underestimated. Labour party activists like myself are finding little to take comfort from nationally and nothing to compensate locally. Not only is the message being delivered to the electorate being doubted, I doubt if I want to deliver it.

Steve Freeborn
Ripley, Derbys
sdf@globalnet.co.uk

 May 4, 2000 will be remembered as the day Labour's core working-class voters finally rejected the "New" Labour leadership's lurch to the right. For many loyal Labour supporters, Tony Blair, Jack Straw et al are indistinguishable from previous Tory governments. Unless Labour adopts a policy of a living pension for the retired, a healthy NHS, truly comprehensive and properly funded schools that even a prime minister would be happy to send his children to and takes back into public ownership the Tory privatised public utilities, public transport for a start, then the prospects for the next general election do not look good.

Colin Penfold
Llanbrynmair, Powys

 Interesting, isn't it, that in his letter to London voters Tony Blair distinguishes between Labour supporters and "...everyone who believes in what I am trying to achieve for our country..."

Russell Levy
London
Russ@leighday.co.uk

 In Hastings we still have a Labour-controlled council. They have been in control for about three years and have made a big difference, for the better, to the running of the town. The Tories made four gains, one from Labour and three from the Lib Dems. Two of those gains were in seats that have a number of asylum seekers and the race card, so blatantly played at national level, has also been used here. So much so that the National Front are now wanting to march through our town. Before the media goes overboard and thinks that the Tory party are back, just remember they can only be elected by pandering to the right-wing racist and xenophobic element in society.

Trevor May
Hastings, E Sussex

 The new "Labour" New Zealand government (The Future is Kiwi, May 4) is a coalition government with the Greens, made possible by proportional representation. Many of the policies Jonathan Freedland cites with such enthusiasm are Green initiated.

Lesley Greene
Stroud, Glos
evans.greene@zetnet.co.uk

The axiom on which New Labour is built is that it is impossible for the party to win an election except by occupying a centrist position. Tony Blair's grip on the party is wholly dependent on its members believing this, but the result of the mayoral contest shows it is false. Uniquely, the electorate was given the opportunity to choose between New and Old Labour, having experienced them both. If Ken Livingstone's GLC was so bad, why did so many people vote for him? Perhaps the Labour party, at grassroots and parliamentary levels, will now realise its timidity will not do after all lead to electoral success.

Adam Riege
University of Glasgow

 Tony Blair places great importance on the support of the Sun, which urged its readers to vote for anyone but Ken. His victory in the face of hostility from all the tabloids shows that Blair should stop grovelling to Murdoch & co and get on with what he believes to be right.

Joe Devas
London

 A few months ago Ken Livingstone appealed for votes with heartfelt expressions of love and loyalty towards the Labour party. Now Norris, Kramer and Dobson will all be invited to serve under the all-conquering Ken, who now seems, like the Queen Mum, to be above mere politics. Many on the left have enjoyed the prospect of a defeat for the Millbank Tendency. How do they feel now Ken is espousing the most subversive tenet of the reactionary right, that government is about management and not a matter of political convictions?

Paul Taylor
London

webTitle: No softening as Putin plans direct rule for Chechnya

fields.headline: No softening as Putin plans direct rule for Chechnya
fields.standfirst:
Russia: special report
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Kremlin signalled yesterday that President Vladimir Putin is to impose direct rule on the breakaway region of Chechnya within weeks.
fields.body:
The Kremlin signalled yesterday that President Vladimir Putin is to impose direct rule on the breakaway region of Chechnya within weeks.

Two days before Mr Putin is formally sworn in as president and eight months after he launched the war that put him in the Kremlin, Sergei Ivanov, a key aide to Mr Putin, announced that the new president would shortly issue a decree establishing direct federal rule over Chechnya.

The move formally revokes all recognition of President Aslan Maskhadov of Chechnya who was democratically elected in 1997. Mr Maskhadov has been leading the war effort against the Russians since last September and lacks all legitimacy in Mr Putin's eyes.

Mr Ivanov, like Mr Putin, a former KGB career officer who heads the Kremlin's national security council and who is emerging as the key foreign policy player in the new administration, said the direct rule decree as well as an accompanying parliamentary bill would be ready by the end of the month.

Direct Kremlin rule would be for "a historically brief period, possibly two to three years", Mr Ivanov said. War-ravaged Chechnya was in no state to hold new presidential elections, he said.

Mr Putin's move came as General Vladimir Shamanov, one of the officers running the Russian campaign in Chechnya, said a division of Russian troops would be permanently deployed in Chechnya from next month.

The occupation force is to garrison Chechnya while the new Putin government works out what it intends to do with the unruly republic.

Although the war has disappeared from the headlines and is concentrated on a relatively small area of mountainous southern Chechnya, the separatist guerrillas remain highly active and are exacting a heavy toll on the Russians who, according to official figures, are losing more than 30 men every week.

Under the peace deal that ended the 1994-96 Chechen war, Chechnya acquired de facto independence although debate on its status was de ferred. That agreement has been shredded. Mr Ivanov said it was too early to talk about "the final form of government in Chechnya".

Russia's deputy prime minister responsible for Chechnya, Nikolai Koshman, said direct rule meant that Russian-staffed "territorial boards" would be established across Chechnya. This would be the form of local government until local elections were held in two years' time. The Russian authorities would also screen Chechen representatives and appoint them to the boards.

The risks to "collaborators" were vividly illustrated this week when guerrillas pulled a Chechen village mayor out of his car and executed him summarily for working with the Russians.

The timing of yesterday's announcement from Mr Ivanov, on the eve of the Kremlin ceremonies for the presidential inauguration, suggested that Mr Putin intends to boost his image as Russia's new strongman, stamping his authority on the wayward regions and centralising power in Moscow and in the presidency.

fields.headline: Toying with asylum seekers
fields.trailText: The home secretary has given an assurance that the government will not deduct from asylum seekers' allowance the value of toys that charities provide for their children (Straw attacks charity plea for gifts to asylum seekers, May 3). The problem remains that the government defines toys as not an "essential living need".
fields.body:
The home secretary has given an assurance that the government will not deduct from asylum seekers' allowance the value of toys that charities provide for their children (Straw attacks charity plea for gifts to asylum seekers, May 3). The problem remains that the government defines toys as not an "essential living need". The Medical Foundation believes that this is in violation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Article 31 of the convention enshrines the child's right to play and article 39 provides that states must take all appropriate measures to promote the recovery of child survivors of torture "in an environment which fosters the health, self-respect and dignity of the child". That the government's new and mean support system fails to do so is obvious.

As a charity, the Medical Foundation provides other non-cash items to asylum seekers, including food and blankets, and items that must be bought for cash: transport to visit doctors, school uniforms, physical aids such as orthopaedic equipment or eyeglasses where NHS equipment or spectacles will not suffice.

Whether charities are allowed to give these items without diminishing the asylum seekers' meagre allowance remains in doubt. We seek further assurances that the government will not violate the fundamental principle of the independence of charities to assess need and give assistance accordingly.

Our appeal for people to send toys to the National Asylum Support Service has succeeded in getting the first clarification of the government's policy. We await further clarifications.

Sherman Carroll
Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Audrey Insch on North Pembrokeshire
fields.trailText: Audrey Insch on North Pembrokeshire
fields.body:
Off to St Justinians for some coastal path walking: warm sunshine, calm seas reflecting the ethereal, seaside blue of the sky. As you gaze, it is hard to believe that these are among the most dangerous waters off our coast, although you can see a white turmoil where seas from one direction clash with those from another. In more boisterous times a water cliff sometimes a foot high is created. The St David's lifeboat, surrounded by its many trophies, demonstrates the courage and dedication of its voluntary crew.

Round the cliffs we stopped to lie on the cliff edge and peer over into the clear blue green waters. The cliffs carried primroses. Around the path flowered blue squills, pink thrift, white campion, pink campion, yellow coltsfoot, horseshoe vetch, gorse and buttercups. A shy green lizard darted off. The scent brought out by the warm sun, the swoop and twitter of swallows and martins all combined to reconcile us to not much sea bird activity.

It was time for Britain's smallest city. St David's cathedral sits in a hollow, invisible from sea where marauders and despoilers passed by with gimlet eyes. It is built of the grey-purple granite also used for surrounding walls and buildings. On the north side there's an old orchard and meadow with the river Alun flowing through it. This is probably the quiet, pastoral valley where David started his 6th-century community.

Green iris spears are enthusiastically raised; modest lady's smock gives a gentle, soft pink. There is an abundance of lichens. All we heard was the water and jackdaws and rooks celebrating spring. Blue speedwell flourishes at the foot of old walls; higher up there's mind-your-own-business and ivy leaved toadflax.

A part of the old 14th- century wall built to enclose the cathedral and the houses of the clergy presents a lively contrast to a newly restored wall with its mortar looking unfriendly to toadflax or anything else (although its stones still welcome lichens). Apart from the cars, the road from St Justinians to St David's is winding and pleasant.

fields.headline: Charge over fuel attack
fields.trailText: A boy aged 12 was charged last night with causing grievous bodily harm to Alfred Page, 11, who was doused in fuel and set alight.
fields.body:
A boy aged 12 was charged last night with causing grievous bodily harm to Alfred Page, 11, who was doused in fuel and set alight.

The 12-year-old was charged more than 46 hours after his arrest in Gillingham, Kent, where Alfred lives. He is to appear before Medway magistrates in Chatham today.

The boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was returned to police custody after being bailed into the custody of Medway social services.

Alfred was set alight on wasteland in Gillingham as he played with friends on Wednesday. He is in the burns unit at Broomfield hospital at Chelmsford, Essex, where he has had major surgery. His uncle, Edward Lovell, said he was comfortable and stable, but faced a further operation today.

Alfred's parents, Arthur, 39, and Maria, 40, praised the emergency services and the support of family and friends.

Mr Lovell said: "Everyone's thoughts are also with Aaron Trotter [Alfred's friend, whose hands were burned putting out the flames]."

webTitle: Wife causes real scene at theatre

fields.headline: Wife causes real scene at theatre
fields.trailText: The performance was in the best traditions of music hall, with bawdy humour, risque language and a curtain-raising finale.
fields.body:
The performance was in the best traditions of music hall, with bawdy humour, risque language and a curtain-raising finale.

The audience cheered and clapped as a furious wife took centre stage and berated her husband in suitably earthy language for having an affair.

Minutes later the police rushed in and dragged the wife away kicking and screaming to wild laughter and applause.

So delighted were the audience with the high drama that they failed to realise that the appearance of the actress Margaret Le Foe at the Players' Theatre in London's West End was not in the script but the real, unbridled fury of a woman scorned.

Mrs Le Foe, not listed in the show's dramatis personae of Ridgeway's Late Joys, had seized her chance during Tuesday night's performance to accuse her director husband, Daniel Le Foe, of having an affair with the actress Maria St Clare.

Last night Mrs Le Foe, who is in her 60s and has been married for 41 years, said she was delighted that her impromptu appearance had made the audience sit up.

"The police dragged me off the stage in my Yves St Laurent suit, down two flights of stairs, past the dressing rooms, and threw me out into the street," she said from the Westminster home she shares with her husband. "It was all very dramatic.

"My husband and this woman have behaved disgracefully. He has been deceitful and has been sleeping with this woman for a long time.

"He is behaving like a fool, and I wanted to teach him a lesson."

After she was led off stage by the police, the theatre manager announced that the final curtain had come down early.

Mrs Le Foe, who confirmed she has filed for a judicial separation from her husband, who is in his 70s, said she had been banned from going near the theatre.

Sources at the subscription-funded theatre - one of the few remaining homes of proper Victorian-style music hall shows - said that last Sunday Mrs Le Foe came in and spotted her husband with Ms St Clare in the theatre. Enraged, she went over and poured a glass of red wine over her.

Afterwards theatre officials wrote to Mrs Le Foe saying her membership had been cancelled and she must not come near the theatre.

Last night a member of the cast, who asked not to be named, added: "I later heard Mr Le Foe dropped his top hat during the row, and Mrs Le Foe stamped on it."

Yesterday a theatre spokesman said Mr Le Foe's relationship with Ms St Clare was a "private matter" for him and his wife but insisted the show would go on.

"The police dragged me off the stage in my Yves St Laurent suit, down two flights of stairs, past the dressing rooms, and threw me out into the street," she said from the Westminster home she shares with her husband. "It was all very dramatic. "My husband and this woman have behaved disgracefully. He has been deceitful and has been sleeping with this woman for a long time. "He is behaving like a fool, and I wanted to teach him a lesson." After she was led off stage by the police, the theatre manager announced that the final curtain had come down early. Mrs Le Foe, who confirmed she has filed for a judicial separation from her husband, who is in his 70s, said she had been banned from going near the theatre. Sources at the subscription-funded theatre - one of the few remaining homes of proper Victorian-style music hall shows - said that last Sunday Mrs Le Foe came in and spotted her husband with Ms St Clare in the theatre. Enraged, she went over and poured a glass of red wine over her. Afterwards theatre officials wrote to Mrs Le Foe saying her membership had been cancelled and she must not come near the theatre. Last night a member of the cast, who asked not to be named, added: "I later heard Mr Le Foe dropped his top hat during the row, and Mrs Le Foe stamped on it." Yesterday a theatre spokesman said Mr Le Foe's relationship with Ms St Clare was a "private matter" for him and his wife but insisted the show would go on.

webTitle: The night has come. The night has gone. And not a single result

fields.headline: The night has come. The night has gone. And not a single result
fields.standfirst: Other politics news
fields.trailText: From 11pm to 6am there were no mayoral results. The BBC's unrivalled coverage, as they described it before the full horror hit them, rolled on with a momentum of its own - though, of course, without a single hard fact.
fields.body:
At a performance of - I would like to think - Dick Whittington a flash-bang failed. King Rat, nothing if not resourceful, said "Dearie me, oh what a shame! Someone's pissed on the magic flame." And the crisis passed.

Much the same sort of thing happened in Vote 2000 (BBC1) when dust got in the sophisticated electronic vote counters. From 11pm to 6am there were no mayoral results. The BBC's unrivalled coverage, as they described it before the full horror hit them, rolled on with a momentum of its own - though, of course, without a single hard fact.

Peter Snow explained proportional representation with gesture and graphics, a sight that alone was worth the price of admission. He placed the candidates on top of imaginary columns ("Here come the second votes, pushing the column up!"). He indicated the ebb and flow of political fortune ("There goes the Tory buoy, bumping about on the tide!"). He argued, passionately if implausibly, that the London Eye had an uncanny resemblance to the Greater London assembly.

The London Eye had another starring role when people were put in pods and questioned about politics in mid-air. Three such peas in a pod were the chef Anthony Worrall Thompson, Lauren Booth, Cherie Blair's actress half-sister, and the Bishop of Stepney.

The whole thing seemed to remind you of some joke whose punchline you had, luckily, forgotten.

Meanwhile, back in the studio, David Blunkett frankly admitted "it isn't comfortable sitting here", stuck it out till 1.30am, then left, pleading a prior appointment in Lisbon. At 4am David Dimbleby went to lie down in a darkened room.

Leaving the world to darkness and Nick Robinson in the QEII conference centre. Nothing had been happening there for a very long time. Members of the media were draped over chairs like Dali clocks. Nick Robinson interviewed people who looked as if they had slept in their coffins. Happily, he has a high sense of drama.

3.10am. "Not a single piece of information! Some of the counts were delayed due to lack of machines and, would you believe, a table collapsed at one count actually damaging the machine!"

Lady Sally Hamwee, a large, calm woman and Susan Kramer's running mate, said soothingly that some times old-fashioned methods were best.

3.30am. "If you've just come home, let me tell you what you've missed. NOTHING!"

The returning officer told him the machines had been tested to destruction, which seemed all too likely. The problem was dust in the air. "This is good news," he continued stoutly. "It means there is nothing wrong with the counting equipment. It's just got bunged up." Slowly, outside the window, West minster Abbey became visible. "The night has come! The night has gone! Not a single result!" said Robinson, gesturing dramatically at the view. "These machines are very sensitive," said the returning officer, wounded.

At 7.45am a caption announced: "The BBC declares Ken Livingstone mayor". David Dimbleby told Ken Livingstone that the BBC had declared him mayor. "Oh good," he said drily. I am inclined to think he knew.

webTitle: Blair plans response to furious activists

fields.headline: Blair plans response to furious activists
fields.standfirst: Moves to woo core voters after disaster in LondonNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has agreed to sanction Labour party reforms in an attempt to calm some of the seething resentment among members over his bungled handling of the London mayoral election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has agreed to sanction Labour party reforms in an attempt to calm some of the seething resentment among members over his bungled handling of the London mayoral election. Millbank officals accept that the charge of control freakery is leading to massive cynicism across the party's political spectrum and a worrying decline in activism.

No big policy changes are planned by Downing Street, but government officials accept that the rhetoric needs softening if Labour's disillusioned core vote is to be persuaded to turn out at the general election.

Strategists acknowledge that the losses in the council elections were slightly higher than expected, but were dismayed by the collapse of Labour's share of the vote in the London assembly elections. The fall in the party vote to 32% rivalled last year's disaster in its Welsh heartlands and is the worst London borough results for Labour since 1982.

Jim Fitzpatrick, chairman of the London party, said: "We never got out out from the perception that some kind of fix was going on."

The Tories' unexpected disaster in Romsey is, not surprisingly, being seen at Millbank as the chink of light on a black night. An official said: "The launch of William Hague's new rightwing agenda helps us. It naturally sustains the kind of anti-Tory tactical voting that did John Major such damage in 1997."

Some Labour ministers, including the minister for London, Keith Hill, even praised Labour voters in Romsey for voting tactically with the Liberal Democrats. There will now be a higher level of implicit collusion, and targeting of resources, to ensure that the two parties do not compete in seats for the anti-Tory vote.

In the first sign that Millbank will move to restore its shattered relationship with its membership, officials said that rule changes would be agreed by June requiring all future party ballots for devolved bodies, or other city mayoral candidates, to be conducted by one-member, one-vote.

The proposals will be put to the 21st century party review by June for submission to party conference in the autumn. The reform will mean the unions will be excluded in party ballots for the Labour mayoral candidates in cities such as Liverpool and Birmingham. Officials will defend the change by saying union branch boundaries do not match those of the big cities.

The change has been pressed by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister. He believes Mr Blair damaged himself badly by in effect sanctioning the fixing of the party ballots in London and Wales.

A Downing Street policy adviser said: "It is incredible that we have lost the high moral ground on party democracy to the far left. In his first three years Blair led by persuasion, such as in the clause 4 ballot. But in government, he has resorted to the oldest fixes. It started inexplicably in Wales over Rhodri Morgan. No one here knows why he became quite so obsessed by Rhodri."

In a second reform Millbank will also propose a change in the system of election for MEPs by dropping closed regional lists, a proportional voting system that left local parties feeling disengaged from the candidates and discinclined to campaign. The system was hugely resented by party activists and contributed to the low turnout.

In a third change Millbank also indicated that while an electoral college will still be used in any election for party leader, unions will be required to hold full ballots and split their block votes accordingly.

Mr Blair has himself in recent weeks admitted that he has gone too far, saying: "I suppose I was perhaps too concerned about the party returning to the 80s."

Officials also said they might postpone plans to abolish meetings of general committees, the current democratic building block of local parties.

The mood of contrition within Downing Street will not stretch as far as letting Ken Livingstone back into the fold, a demand being raised by Mark Seddon, a leftwing member of Labour's national executive and editor of Tribune.

Millbank responded by saying: "Ken will not be coming for at least another five years."

Disturbingly for Mr Blair, many of his natural allies are worried that he no longer has a strategy for the party. Critics of Margaret McDonagh, the party's general secretary, say she is an extremely good organiser and administrator but not hugely political. There has also been a steady departure of staff from Millbank, including irreplaceable figures such as Phil Wilson, Mr Blair's loyal organiser from his Sedgefield constituency.

Other Blairites, worried by the loss of political direction, have formed a Labour renewal network and are trying to engage Millbank and the Downing Street political unit in dialogue. Its organiser, Neal Lawson, said: "There has to be a compromise between mad oppositionalism and a very sanitised Stepford Wives party.

"Millbank has to realise that they cannot only have a membership of cheerleaders who go leafletting every Sunday."

webTitle: The Judas kiss of the love bug

fields.headline: The Judas kiss of the love bug
fields.standfirst:
Forget rioters - cyber-terrorists are the ones to smash capitalism

May 2K: special report
FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning on the virus
Sophos virus information
fields.trailText: For all the media space they claimed, the anarchists who marched through London on May Day to "reclaim the streets" did very little damage to capitalism: the juvenile desecration of a Churchill statue, a football-thug mess in McDonald's. Calendar sentimentality had forced them to use a day - a bank holiday - when capitalism was at the beach. It was business as usual on Tuesday.
fields.body:
For all the media space they claimed, the anarchists who marched through London on May Day to "reclaim the streets" did very little damage to capitalism: the juvenile desecration of a Churchill statue, a football-thug mess in McDonald's. Calendar sentimentality had forced them to use a day - a bank holiday - when capitalism was at the beach. It was business as usual on Tuesday.

Compare this with the scale of trouble caused by the anarchists who dispatched, with a false kiss from the Philippines, the computer virus marked "I love you". They closed down major corporations around the world for a day - causing losses estimated at billions of dollars - and disrupted the legislative assemblies of Britain and America. They may even, if the love bug caused the computer problems at the counting of the votes for London mayor, have put democracy briefly on hold. At least Mayor Livingstone shouldn't have to worry about street demonstrations on the first of May next year. Any sensible anarchists will be at home trying to hack in to Tony Blair's laptop.

Earlier in the week, there had been much good news for the new economy: a report suggested that mobile phones probably didn't cause cancer and an American court ruled that service providers were not accountable for material posted on their sites. But any jubilation in cyberspace at this legal green light for e-commerce greed to resume was surely removed by the devastation caused by the love bug.

One of the advantages of the new computerised economy was thought to be that it reduced capitalism's vulnerability to terrorism and theft. Highly visible local branches or corporate headquarters were no longer necessary. If the IRA had frightened you away from Manchester, Belfast or London, it was plausible now to sell into those places from some distant, tranquil building. A corporation could become physically invisible while maintaining a global presence.

The use of computer viruses by anarchists, terrorists and pranksters has removed this illusion. The machines which free a chief executive and the staff from physical danger open them to commercial disruption on a scale which no conventional terrorist could ever contemplate: imagine the amount of plastic explosive and planning required to stall a major corporation in all its operations for a day.

And - crucially - cyber-terrorists and email guerrillas attract far less censure than the traditional kind. The general problem for anarchists has been that a majority of most civilised populations will balk at attacks on the innocents, no matter what the cause. But residual Luddism - and our accumulated experience of dealing with banks and our employers - means that it is hard not to feel an inner glee when the world's computers crash. Cyber-terrorism is able to present itself as a genuinely victimless crime. That military fantasy of the smart weapon is fulfilled in the e-mail grenade: the infrastructure is dismantled while the people survive. Resistance to these activities would begin only when people ceased to be paid on time or were frequently unable to email their loved ones.

Which brings us to the most compelling detail in this stunt: the romantic disguise the virus wore. It is an alluring paradox. If you hate capitalists, tell them you love them: the Judas kiss. What is surprising is that most of us would probably have bet that the general vulnerability was money: that the smart header on an email virus would be "You've won a million" or "This is the number of your Swiss bank account". But what did for them was the three words from which finally most human troubles follow: I love you.

It is true that many (even, hopefully, most) of those who let the virus in would have had someone who loved them. But the protocol of e-mail post boxes (showing you who a message comes from) is such that these people at their keyboards would have known that this declaration of passion came from a total stranger. They wanted there to be someone else. Romantic curiosity proved a bigger threat to capitalism than any bomb or ideology yet invented.

Apart from an almost inevitable rush of hacker movies from Hollywood in about 18 months time, there are two likely consequences of this ruinous exploitation of the human desire to be wanted. The kind of money and effort which was spent on the physical protection of corporate premises at the peak of Irish terrorism will now be expended on electronic fences and technological locks. The belief that cyberspace permitted the physically invisible corporation is finished. And, unless effective protection of computer systems can be found, the love bug may have the impact on confidence in the dot.com economy that BSE had on the meat factories.

An incidental effect even for those who never use computers may be a change in the nature of junk-mail. Those unsolicited envelopes which declare in golden letters that you have definitely won a major prize or that a car is just waiting for you to drive it away will be replaced by pretend-Valentines, pseudo-bouquets. For a few months, every day will be February 14.

For, on Thursday, the oldest human motivation - love - undermined the newest human invention: cyberspace. Anarchists targeted our Achilles' heart.

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Goals of women's football
fields.trailText: Statistics show that the progress of women's football over the past decade or so has been phenomenal (Women crowded out, May 5), but that the game still does not attract many spectators.
fields.body:
Statistics show that the progress of women's football over the past decade or so has been phenomenal (Women crowded out, May 5), but that the game still does not attract many spectators. However, it is not just the progress in talent, development and numbers who participate that will attract an audience. It is also investment, active promotion, skilful marketing and continued media attention.

Brian Alexander is wrong to suggest that these tools only work on an American audience. Women's football is popular in the US because it has always been a mixed sport there, and federal government investment is divided equally between the sexes.

The past few years has shown that the appetite for football in this country is insatiable. With continued media coverage, people will begin to recognise the stars of the game, develop a sense of identity with the clubs, and appreciate that women's football can be as skilful and exciting as the men's game. The only people who fail to acknowledge this will be "neanderthals" such as the author.

Marisa Knightley
KnightleyM@aol.com

 As Andy Croft's five-a-side team-mates (Rhyming sing-lets on great north run, May 3) we would like to point out that we changed our name to Dynamo Meths three seasons ago, in a successful attempt to change our fortunes through rebranding. Since then we haven't come bottom of the league once. Indeed we recently reached the semi-finals of the cup. We refute the term "hopeless" - as anyone who has seen us play will testify, hope is often the only thing we have left.

Mark Robinson and 8 others
Dynamo Meths

webTitle: Irving ordered to pay £150,000 interim costs

fields.headline: Irving ordered to pay £150,000 interim costs
fields.standfirst: The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: The financial ruin of the pro-Nazi author David Irving came closer yesterday when a judge ordered him to pay an interim sum of £150,000 towards the costs incurred by Penguin Books for his disastrous libel action against charges that he was a Holocaust denier.
fields.body:
The financial ruin of the pro-Nazi author David Irving came closer yesterday when a judge ordered him to pay an interim sum of £150,000 towards the costs incurred by Penguin Books for his disastrous libel action against charges that he was a Holocaust denier.

Last month Mr Justice Charles Gray found in favour of Penguin, which published a book by the American academic Deborah Lipstadt, Denying the Holocaust.

The judge found Ms Lipstadt was justified in saying that Irving had falsified history to exonerate Hitler, driven by anti-semitism and his own pro-Nazi views.

Yesterday Mr Justice Gray ordered the author to pay £150,000 by June 17 towards Penguin's estimated £2m legal and research costs. If Irving defaults he could face bankruptcy and the loss of his home.

The court heard that Irving had told reporters he had a fighting fund of more than £300,000 sent to him by supporters around the world.

After the hearing Mr Irving refused to say whether he could or would pay, and said the money in the fighting fund was resting in an offshore account.

Mr Justice Gray rejected claims by Adrian Davies, representing Irving, that any interim costs order could hamper the author's ability to mount an appeal.

Mr Davies had told the court: "Mr Irving has very little prospect of paying more than relatively little of the costs against him."

Heather Rogers, appearing for Penguin, had asked for an order worth £500,000. Mr Justice Gray said Penguin could seek a fresh order for Irving to pay more money if he was denied permission to appeal.

After the costs order was granted Kevin Bays, a solicitor for Penguin, said the publisher hoped to recover £1.5m of its legal and research fees. "On the one hand he says he doesn't have any money, on the other hand he's reported as saying he has 5,000 supporters around the world making donations," Mr Bays said.

He said the point of getting the order was to save Penguin the time and money of compiling a list of all its costs, by seeing if Irving could first pay a fraction of the final bill. "By making this order we'll find out if he has lots of supporters and money. If he doesn't pay the money, we'll have to enforce payment. The ultimate is bankruptcy.

"A trustee in bankruptcy would be appointed to assess any assets he's got. That would include his house."

For yesterday's hearing Irving, who represented himself during the libel trial, hired a solicitor and a barrister.

He said the firm of solicitors he had hired, Goldsmiths, had refused to represent him beyond the costs hearing on "ideological" grounds.

fields.bodyText: The financial ruin of the pro-Nazi author David Irving came closer yesterday when a judge ordered him to pay an interim sum of £150,000 towards the costs incurred by Penguin Books for his disastrous libel action against charges that he was a Holocaust denier. Last month Mr Justice Charles Gray found in favour of Penguin, which published a book by the American academic Deborah Lipstadt, Denying the Holocaust. The judge found Ms Lipstadt was justified in saying that Irving had falsified history to exonerate Hitler, driven by anti-semitism and his own pro-Nazi views. Yesterday Mr Justice Gray ordered the author to pay £150,000 by June 17 towards Penguin's estimated £2m legal and research costs. If Irving defaults he could face bankruptcy and the loss of his home. The court heard that Irving had told reporters he had a fighting fund of more than £300,000 sent to him by supporters around the world. After the hearing Mr Irving refused to say whether he could or would pay, and said the money in the fighting fund was resting in an offshore account. Mr Justice Gray rejected claims by Adrian Davies, representing Irving, that any interim costs order could hamper the author's ability to mount an appeal. Mr Davies had told the court: "Mr Irving has very little prospect of paying more than relatively little of the costs against him." fields.headline: Letter: Poul Hartling (Obituary, May 4)
fields.trailText: William Clarance writes: Poul Hartling (Obituary, May 4) was a resolute upholder of the principle of non-refoulement (whereby a refugee must not be repatriated when there is likely danger of persecution).
fields.body:
William Clarance writes: Poul Hartling (Obituary, May 4) was a resolute upholder of the principle of non-refoulement (whereby a refugee must not be repatriated when there is likely danger of persecution).

I was his representative in Kuala Lumpur in 1982 and had to protect a small group of the Free Aceh movement, who had been recognised as refugees by UNHCR. The Malaysian authorities demanded that they be handed over.

Already accepted for resettlement in a third country, I recommended to Geneva that we should seek the authorities' acceptance of that solution. The answer came back that they should be handed over. In the time it took for me to ask for confirmation, Hartling had read my report and dramatically overturned the decision. We could count on him in a tight situation.
