webTitle: Lebanon in darkness as Israeli jets strike

fields.headline: Lebanon in darkness as Israeli jets strike
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli warplanes early yesterday morning struck Lebanese "infrastructural" targets for the third time in less than a year, destroying or severely damaging two power stations and hitting an arms depot in the Beka'a valley.
fields.body:
Israeli warplanes early yesterday morning struck Lebanese "infrastructural" targets for the third time in less than a year, destroying or severely damaging two power stations and hitting an arms depot in the Beka'a valley.

The attacks followed injuries to 17 people when Shi'ite Muslim guerrillas fired dozens of rockets at the northern Israeli town of Kiryat Shmona and border settlements on Thursday. As Hizbullah guerrillas yesterday launched a fresh salvo of rockets on Kiryat Shmona, the Israeli president, Ezer Weizman, warned: "We shall plunge their world into darkness."

The Hizbullah guerrillas said: "We are firm today to defend our people, our country and the infrastructure. So we fired barrages of Katyusha rockets at Kiryat Shmona and Shlomi settlements."

Israeli F-16 warplanes attacked Lebanon just before 3am yesterday, blasting the relay station of Bsaleem, near Beirut, which was also hit last June. "It's a total wreck," said an eyewitness.

Many residential areas of Beirut were plunged into darkness. The electricity authority said the damage to the newly constructed Badawi power plant, near the port of Tripoli, would take two years to repair

The Lebanese prime minister, Salim Hoss, said: "No sooner had we finished repairing the damage done by the last aggression than Israel provides a new sample of its arrogance and barbarism."

Only one minor Lebanese injury has been reported.

The current escalation began in familiar fashion. In keeping with its vow to drive Israel out of every inch of Lebanese territory, Hizbullah had been keeping up a high level of attacks on Israel troops and their allies, the South Lebanon Army (SLA), in the "security zone".

In retaliation, the Israelis or the SLA killed two Lebanese civilians and wounded 12 on successive days this week.

Israel called the civilian deaths a "mistake", but Hizbullah immediately launched its attacks on border areas, killing one Israeli soldier.

The worst cross-border clashes since June 1999, when Israel blasted Lebanese infrastructure, came as an envoy from the UN secretary general was in Beirut to discuss Israel's promise to withdraw its forces from south Lebanon by July.

Terje Roed-Larsen wanted to secure Lebanese and Syrian cooperation in the withdrawal, but the complexity of the issue was reflected in a second unscheduled day of meetings with Mr Hoss and Lebanon's president, Emile Lahoud.

"Any attacks against any civilians are unacceptable," Mr Larsen said. "Such actions are particularly unhelpful at the present time."

Lebanese believe the Israeli attack is aimed at demonstrating that Israel will retaliate with massive force for any at tacks after the withdrawal. It is also intended to send a warning that Syrian targets risk coming under assault.

A third aim, it is believed, is to incite Lebanese public opinion against Syria. There is a big gulf between the public, which welcomes the Israeli withdrawal, and the government, which, in the words of one commentator, gives the impression that "we don't want a withdrawal, or we only want it with impossible conditions".

fields.headline: Revenue looks into Carroll break-up
fields.trailText: The inland revenue is completing an exhaustive investigation into the rapid break-up and sale of a multinational industrial group which once boasted assets totalling up to £500m. The report may be passed to the serious fraud office.
fields.body:
The inland revenue is completing an exhaustive investigation into the rapid break-up and sale of a multinational industrial group which once boasted assets totalling up to £500m. The report may be passed to the serious fraud office.

At the centre of the inquiry is the Carroll group of companies, a family-owned commercial dynasty stretching back three generations, which seemed in a healthy position in 1992 but had been liquidated by 1995.

The business spanned Europe, Australia and the Caribbean. It embraced sheep farms and meat processing operations in Australia, financial concerns in the Caribbean, commercial property in Ireland and a 5% holding in the Manchester Ship Canal.

Parts of the group were declared insolvent but it is thought that the inland revenue is not satisfied this was merely a series of routine business failures.

Assets that have been sold off or liquidated include Carroll Aircraft Corporation, which held the licence to operate the civil airfield at Farnborough, and the Burenda sheep stud farm in Queensland, Australia, covering an area half the size of Wales.

Also sold have been the Warren Park stud farm near Newmarket, the London & Central Properties group, alone worth about £100m at early 1990s prices, along with finance and leasing companies in Gibraltar and the Caribbean.

The family art collection - valued at £6m in 1991 - has been sold, along with bloodstock, fine wines and vintage cars.

Gerald Carroll, the most recent family member to run the business, is not prepared to comment. He lives in Belgravia, London, and is on the board of benefactors of Oxford University, having in 1990 endowed for £1.5m a chair of Irish history which is now attached to Hertford college.

In 1986, the Carroll interests - including 85 companies and the art collection - were placed in a British trust, the Carroll Foundation, thought at the time to be worth a net £250m.

It is known that the Carroll property interests suffered during the slump of the early 1990s and it is believed this may explain the July 1992 decision to move about £100m of assets from the foundation to a new vehicle, called the Urban Finance Corporation, which is understood to have been liquidated in 1995.

The inland revenue is believed to have first taken an interest in the Carroll Foundation in spring 1998 and at about that time to have questioned Mr Carroll as to the fate of his companies and other interests. Since then work has been under way on a detailed report into the foundation, and it is understood this report is likely to be passed to the SFO.

webTitle: Dickens writer in row with BBC sells script to ITV

fields.headline: Dickens writer in row with BBC sells script to ITV
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: As the crisis in television comedy deepens, one leading screenwriter has turned to Dickens for inspiration - and delivered an embarrassing snub to the BBC in the process.
fields.body:
As the crisis in television comedy deepens, one leading screenwriter has turned to Dickens for inspiration - and delivered an embarrassing snub to the BBC in the process.

The creator of Only Fools and Horses, one of the most successful comedies in British television history, is to recreate the David Copperfield character, Mr Micawber, for ITV. And the star of the classic BBC series, David Jason, has been cast in the lead role. BBC bosses are said to be furious.

John Sullivan, the writer of the new series, had originally been commissioned by the BBC to adapt the Dickens novel, but stormed out after a row. He took his idea to base a new programme around Mr Micawber to Yorkshire Television, which has agreed to produce the £4m project.

David Reynolds, the controller of comedy drama at Yorkshire, said at the Rose d'Or television festival in Montreux yesterday that he was delighted to have secured Sullivan and Jason. "This is a big deal for us," he said.

ITV bosses hope the new show will be a hit on the same scale as Jason's previous successes in the risky "comedy drama" genre, The Darling Buds of May and A Bit of a Do. Both won critical acclaim and high ratings.

Jason would be perfect for the role of Mr Micawber, said Mr Reynolds. "There is no doubt that he will make it totally his own in the same way that he became Pop Larkin, Del Boy and Jack Frost."

Recently, writers have found it harder to hit upon a winning formula. The BBC launched a clutch of new comedies last year, but with only limited success.

ITV's latest comedy drama, Bob Martin, in which Michael Barrymore parodies himself as a neurotic game show host of ambiguous sexuality, is suffering plunging ratings. Yet the programme has won plaudits from a number of critics - the Spectator magazine heaped intellectual praise upon it - and ITV is determined that it can be turned around. Production of a second series is already under way.

Executives hope that the partnership of Jason and Sullivan will make Micawber a sure hit. The character of Mr Micawber is a complex figure, whose attempts to portray himself as an educated man of riches inevitably end in comic disaster. The series will draw on the Dickens character, but will have new storylines.

Jason said of his new role: "I very much hope I can make him a household name. He's a loveable rogue with a heart of gold."

He said he was looking forward to reviving his successful partnership with Sullivan. "It will be terrific to work with the same team again and I sincerely hope some of the old magic will return."

Initially, the series will be in four parts. Since axing News at Ten last year, ITV has had only mixed success in fulfilling its promise to fill the peak time television schedule with quality, popular programmes. The John Thaw vehicle, Monsignor Renard, was a hit with viewers, but the programme-maker, Carlton, says it was too expensive to make and is not planning to film any more episodes.

ITV is determined to demonstrate its commitment to making the new evening schedule a success; later this month, the Independent Television Commission will decide whether it can force the channel to bring back News at Ten. Last week it ordered ITV to stem the decline in viewers for the channel's news bulletins.

Scheduling popular shows in the run up to the news bulletin at 11pm is one way of ratcheting up the ratings, although Micawber may be screened on Sunday nights.

"Wherever we put it you can't really go wrong with David Jason," said one ITV source.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Reuters taps mobile market
fields.body:
Reuters taps mobile market

Reuters Group and Aether Systems have launched a wireless data provider called Sila Communications, the companies said in a joint statement.

Sila Communications will host, design and manage services for customers through enterprise wireless data centres throughout Europe. It will provide wireless access to corporate information, Reuters content, internet information and applications, email and secure transaction capabilities.

WPP resumes flirtation

WPP's on/off $5bn (£3.2bn) discussions to acquire US advertising agency Young & Rubicam were back on again last night.

The flirtation between the two dates back to November. Talks have broken down twice already, most recently last weekend. An agreement would create the world's largest marketing services group. In recent weeks Y&R has pursued an alternative deal with French marketing group Publicis which would be more palatable to the US group's chief executive, Tom Bell.

Accountant sentenced

Simon Rogers, the accountant who created fictitious building workers as part of a £1m-plus fraud against the inland revenue, was sentenced yesterday to seven years in prison.

Mr Rogers, of Stevenage, Hertfordshire, attempted to nobble the jury in his trial at Blackfriars crown court, with offers of cash and alcohol, the court heard. He had used "quarter of a millions pounds in a slush fund" to buy his way out of trouble, according to the revenue, and during the trial it was alleged he bullied two others, also charged, into not giving evidence or withdrawing previous statements.

KPN ends merger talks

Royal KPN has ended its merger talks with Spanish telecoms firm Telefonica, a KPN spokesman said. KPN said in a statement that it was still in discussions with other potential partners. The talks with Telefonica ended after a minority of Telefonica management board members voted against the merger proposal, KPN said.

Dairy Crest raises bid

Dairy Crest is back in the driving seat to buy Unigate's dairy operations, after lifting its offer by £15m to £250m. This trumped Thursday's £240m bid from the Scottish group Robert Wiseman. If successful, Dairy Crest will have a 22% share of Britain's milk market, second only to Express Dairies.

DKB suffers defection

Dresdner Kleinwort Benson suffered another defection yesterday when Mark Fisher, head of its technology corporate finance team, was said to have left for Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

His departure comes amid continued uncertainty at the investment bank after the collapse of the takeover between its parent Dresdner and its rival Deutsche Bank.

fields.headline: BAA lands New York prize
fields.trailText: BAA, the British airports operator, has beaten off strong competition from Europe and America in a contest to run the Big Apple's two main airports, JFK and LaGuardia.
fields.body:
Two of New York's finest might soon fall into British hands. BAA, the British airports operator, has beaten off strong competition from Europe and America in a contest to run the Big Apple's two main airports, JFK and LaGuardia.

New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, confirmed yesterday that the city was negotiating with BAA over the terms of a contract for the long term management and operation of the two airports.

Under the contract BAA would assume control of the airports when the current lease with the port authority of New York expires in 2015, or earlier if the lease is terminated.

Mr Giuliani said: "New York ers and visitors to the city are not getting the kind of service they deserve.

"The port authority has proven itself unable or unwilling to maintain JFK and LaGuardia as first class airports."

webTitle: Sierra Leone cruelly exposes UN's crisis

fields.headline: Sierra Leone cruelly exposes UN's crisis
fields.standfirst:
Kofi Annan tries to win release of peacekeepers as new violence in Congo threatens deployment

Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: The United Nations is again facing a crisis of credibility in Africa as at least 300 of its troops remained missing, taken hostage, or encircled by rebels in Sierra Leone yesterday, and new fighting broke out in Democratic Republic of Congo just as the UN plans to deploy there.
fields.body:
The United Nations is again facing a crisis of credibility in Africa as at least 300 of its troops remained missing, taken hostage, or encircled by rebels in Sierra Leone yesterday, and new fighting broke out in Democratic Republic of Congo just as the UN plans to deploy there.

Six civilian UN employees, including a four-man Russian helicopter crew, were released during the day from eastern Sierra Leone after intervention by President Charles Taylor of Liberia, but tension remained high in several towns where UN troops are based. From New York last night the UN confirmed that 300 of its men are hostages and at least 12 wounded.

As the crisis deepened the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, talked by telephone to African leaders, and envoys were dispatched from several west African countries to Freetown in an attempt to confront the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) leader, Foday Sankoh. "He is already isolated and it is going to get worse," Mr Annan said. The secretary general persuaded six African leaders, including President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria and President Muammar Gadafy of Libya, to put pressure on Mr Sankoh.

"They've told him to take action. They told him to release [the hostages]. They've tried to impress on him the seriousness of the situation."

Britain is dispatching an advisory team to Freetown to assess technical support needed to enhance the UN force's effectiveness, Robin Cook said last night. It follows a request from the UN secretary general.

The UN's new crisis is as grave as its miscalculation in Angola in 1992 election when a UN-monitored election plunged the country into a civil war worse than the previous 20 years of fighting.

Underlining the long-term effects of such a failure, the UN yesterday announced a $100m (£65.5m) shortfall in funding for the humanitarian programme for Angola.

The events in Sierra Leone this week have cast a shadow over the current UN security council mission to central Africa, aimed at putting a 5,500-strong UN peacekeeping force into Congo.

The UN troops are intended to keep alive a fragile ceasefire involving half a dozen countries from Zimbabwe and Angola to Rwanda and Uganda who back rival forces in Congo.

Yesterday a summit meeting of all the forces and their outside backers planned for the Congolese capital, Kinshasa, was cancelled after heavy fighting in the north-east of the country.

Ugandan troops attacked their former allies from Rwanda before dawn just out side the rebel-held Congolese city of Kisangani and at least five civilians died in the crossfire, according to a UN official. "There is shelling all over Kisangani," he said. Kisangani is one of the four points the UN plans to install its peace monitors.

Colonel Akram Hossain, who heads a four-man preliminary UN observer mission in Kisangani, blamed Ugandan troops for the clashes - the first since the two sides fought a three-day battle in the town in August last year. "It was initiated by the UPDF [Ugandan amy] and since then there has been shelling and intermittent firing all around the town," Col Hossain said.

Rwandan military sources said their troops were under orders not to respond, but the shelling by Uganda's 120mm mortar shells and anti-aircraft guns became heavier until they had to choose between surrendering or firing back.

"We want to defuse things - we have no reason to fight with the Ugandans," said a Rwandan military spokesman, Major Emmanual Ndahiro.

Sources in both Uganda and Rwanda were pessimistic about any early reconciliation between the two former allies who have large military presences inside Congo.

In Sierra Leone the former rebels of the RUF, similarly unprepared for peace, continued to deny that they held any UN hostages. A spokesman for Mr Sankoh said they were not aware of any hostages being held, apart from the five civilians released yesterday. But Mr Sankoh, many miles from the various front lines, and long out of touch with the commanders of the various RUF units, does not have the authority to make the peace process and disarmament a reality.

UN officials said that the explosion of tension this week was linked to RUF commanders' demands for the return to their units of combatants who have handed in weapons to the UN, received indemnities, and were being prepared for demobilisation, as agreed in the peace treaty signed in Lome last July.

Part of the peace deal was a controversial amnesty for Mr Sankoh and his fighters. A UN spokesman yesterday emphasised that the amnesty did not cover any events after the peace treaty of July 1999.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Murder case suspects freed
fields.body:
Murder case suspects freed

A man and a woman being questioned by police about the murder of leading Roman Catholic solicitor Rosemary Nelson have been released without charge. The human rights lawyer died when a bomb planted by loyalists exploded under her car in Lurgan, Co Armagh, in March last year.

Boy arsonist sentenced

A 13-year-old boy whose friend died in a "reckless" game in a barn on Salisbury plain last September was freed yesterday after pleading guilty to arson.

The boy, who comes from the Amesbury area of Wiltshire and cannot be identified for legal reasons, was given a three-year supervision order at Winchester crown court.

Record £56,500 for rare pen

The world's rarest pen, a Dunhill-Namiki, once owned by a Japanese prime minister and hand-painted with a picture of Raiden, the god of thunder, fetched a world record £56,500 at Bonhams auction house in London yesterday.

BBC producer faces retrial

A BBC journalist accused of battering a female colleague's ex-boyfriend is to be retried on May 15 after a jury failed to reach a verdict yesterday. World Service producer Chiaka Nwosu, 40, of Stoke Newington, north London, appeared at Southwark crown court.

Who guitars on sale for charity

The Who legend Pete Townshend is auctioning guitars and memorabilia to help flood and drought victims in Africa.

Items, including a treasured 1957 Fender Stratocaster given to Townshend by Eric Clapton, will be offered from noon on Wednesday at www.auction.eelpie.com.

Tax inspector jailed

A tax inspector who used confidential company information to net £15,000 from insider share dealing was yesterday jailed for six months. Lawrence Champion, 50, of Harborne, Birmingham, pleaded guilty at Warwick crown court to 13 charges.

webTitle: Nearly a mile long and 40,000 on board - the first floating city

fields.headline: Nearly a mile long and 40,000 on board - the first floating city
fields.trailText: It may sound like something from a science fiction story - a floating city of 40,000 people that will slowly circumnavigate the globe - but the building of what will be the world's largest ship is about to begin.
fields.body:
It may sound like something from a science fiction story - a floating city of 40,000 people that will slowly circumnavigate the globe - but the building of what will be the world's largest ship is about to begin.

The Freedom Ship's creators say the vessel, whose constuction is due to start in Honduras this summer, will be one of the wonders of the world. The company behind the scheme said reservations for the 20,000 homes on board had begun to accelerate, and there were already plans to build two other floating cities.

Freedom Ship will be nearly a mile long (4,320ft), 725ft wide and 340ft tall and will have room for 40,000 people, including a staff of 10,000. There will be a school and university on board, not to mention a landing strip, a hospital, a casino, a shopping mall and 200 acres of open space.

The idea is that it will slowly travel the world, pausing a few miles out from chosen destinations such as ports or exotic tropical islands that can only be reached by sea. It will be on the move for 25% of the time and otherwise anchored off different ports.

People who want to live on board can purchase their homes for prices which range from $150,000 (£94,000) for a small unit to $40m for something rather larger. There will be 20,000 units in total and the whole venture will cost $9bn. Developers are being encouraged to pre-purchase space and sell it on in the same way as their real estate counterparts do on dry land.

"Already we have reservations for 15% [of the units]," said Roger Gooch, the marketing vice-president for the venture from his Florida office yesterday. "Once we are under construction, people will come running. It's already being termed one of the wonders of the world."

Construction would start in "60 to 90 days", and would take three years to complete, with the shipyard operating 24 hours a day, he said.

The ship is the brainchild of the project director, Norman Nixon of Engineering Solutions, an engineer from Arkansas who has overseen the construction of chemical plants and office buildings from Saudi Arabia to Texas.

Application forms for workers on either the construction or staff of the ship when it is finally launched have been placed on the internet and talks are under way with the Nova Southwestern University to ensure that an established academic institution will be responsible for running the degree courses on the ship.

Mr Gooch said that the hope was that the vessel would have a "global environment", with a large mixture of different nationalities and ages. It was not meant to be seen as a retirement cruise ship but one where people could run their businesses and educate their children. As a sales incentive, the company's material points out that there will be no local taxes to pay.

So far, the greatest interest had come from Europe, with Germans and Scandinavians already paying deposits to secure their units.

"We're just a giant landlord," Mr Gooch said, adding that anyone who wanted to start and run a business on the ship was free to do so. "We're not in the business of owning a barber shop or a restaurant. We're shipbuilders."

There had been scepticism, he accepted, about the safety of such a vessel, but the company's engineers were confident that a ship of such a size would be secure and viable.

But was there not a concern that the ship's size seemed to make it the stuff of which Titanic-style disaster movies are made, the vessel taken hostage perhaps by international pirates or the like?

Mr Gooch said that a former FBI man would head a 2,000-strong security force, and the ship would be equipped with "state-of-the-art defensive weapons". The laws on board will be those of the country under whose flag the ship eventually sails - that country is still to be decided, but will not be the US, he said. Serious offenders would be held until the ship reached its next port and then surrendered to the authorities, he added.

And will the city have its own government?

Different decks and floors would be able to elect their representatives, Mr Gooch said, but "the captain's word will be final".

webTitle: Nike gives US universities the boot as student anti-sweatshop demands rise

fields.headline: Nike gives US universities the boot as student anti-sweatshop demands rise
fields.trailText: The sportswear manufacturer Nike has withdrawn millions of dollars of sponsorship from three American universities because of the activities of campus-based anti-sweatshop groups.
fields.body:
The sportswear manufacturer Nike has withdrawn millions of dollars of sponsorship from three American universities because of the activities of campus-based anti-sweatshop groups.

The move is the latest in a running battle between leading multinational firms and the student anti-sweatshop movement which has mushroomed on campuses during the last year.

In the past three weeks, Nike has withdrawn from financial arrangements worth more than $50m (£30m) with the University of Oregon, the University of Michigan and Brown University.

The sports firm had provided free equipment for the universities' sports teams and had made large donations and endowments.

Nike objects to the demands being made by the Workers Rights Consortium, a body made up of students, university and union officials, and human rights campaigners.

The WRC, which campaigns for improved working conditions in countries which produce clothes for the western markets, supports unannounced visits to factories and minimum working conditions.

Nike has said it provides better working conditions than its competitors and makes a conscious effort to ensure that its factories operate fairly and humanely.

The company supports another monitoring group, the Fair Labour Association, which the WRC claims is dominated by companies and does not carry out tough enough inspections.

Last month Phil Knight, Nike's chairman and founder, announced that he would not be making a $30m donation to his alma mater, the University of Oregon, because the company considered the WRC, which has branches in nearly 50 universities, unfriendly towards business in general.

Nike has also accused the WRC of being a tool of the US unions, which have been unhappy at seeing manufacturing jobs go abroad.

Since then, Nike has broken its links with Michigan and Brown universities. The company equipped the Michigan athletics teams in a deal worth around $22m over six years and the men's and women's ice hockey squads at Brown.

Michigan is now negotiating with other sports manufacturers, including Adidas, Puma and Reebok. One Michigan athlete was quoted as saying: "The swoosh [Nike's logo] is just a symbol. The person makes the player, not the shoes."

The question of whether US manufacturers are using sweatshops at home and abroad has become an important issue in student politics. Last month, 12 university administration buildings were occupied by students objecting to the administration's investment policies.

Increasingly, student bodies are demanding that the universities should only engage in "ethical investments", and companies deemed to use sweated labour have been targeted in pickets and demonstrations.

Such is the interest in the issue that the Museum of Tolerance in los Angeles has staged a special sweatshop exhibition, detailing the history of sweatshop labour and campaigns against it.

webTitle: It's fast, crazy and chaotic... but it might just work

fields.headline: It's fast, crazy and chaotic... but it might just work
fields.trailText: It was dark and wet and he was driving very fast through heavy traffic when I reached for the seatbelt.
fields.body:
It was dark and wet and he was driving very fast through heavy traffic when I reached for the seatbelt.

"Don't touch it or we will have an accident," he yelled. My fingers wrapped around the belt and I slowly pulled. The yell jumped an octave. "Do not touch it. We are safe. You do not need it."

He said that his name was Mario, and he was in his early 40s, hulking, bearded and sincere.

His taxi, his rules. He explained: wearing a seatbelt transmitted negative, self-fulfilling vibes that confused the brain's frontal lobe, ruined coordination and led to crashes.

Superstitious nonsense, I replied, and yanked the belt. We skidded to a halt, he flung open the door and ordered me out. Then he sped away, leaving me in the rain to ponder his final, furious words. "You have offended a man of science."

Reason and logic are not readily apparent when it comes to looking at transport in Rome. Public or private, the system is commonly viewed as nuts. Traffic jams solidify from 8am, parking spaces verge on the mythical, the underground has only two lines which bypass the city's heart, scooters litter footpaths and strikes paralyse trains. To the soundtrack of blaring horns, everybody agrees that getting around Rome is a nightmare.

London's mayoral election has been followed with bafflement. Labour's wrangling was clear enough, but what on earth was that fuss about transport? All those underground lines, taxis you can hail in the street, buses that run all night, streets wide enough for two-way traffic. Heavenly. Why don't Londoners just shut up and enjoy?

Mayor Francesco Rutelli has the luxury of an excuse denied to Ken Livingstone. Rome was not planned over the centuries, like London, Paris or Madrid. It became the capital after 1870 and was experimenting with horse-drawn trolleys while others were building undergrounds.

The city didn't evolve, it improvised. When work did begin on an underground, digging had to stop after archaeological treasures were stumbled upon. The route was changed but treasures obstructed the new route, and the next one, and the one after that. A similar thing has just happened in Pompeii, where a 2,000-year-old luxury hotel has been discovered during a motorway widening.

Via della Conciliazione rolls from St Peter's Square with a width and majesty alien to Rome's narrow, winding streets. Only a dictator like Mussolini had the power and recklessness to raze the medieval quarter that stood there.

But antiquity's legacies do not fully absolve planners from today's problems. Waste, corruption and cowardice may have played their part, but chaos is in the eye of the beholder, for Rome is not so bad. The centre is small. Most things can be reached on foot, but try telling that to the natives. "You walked here?," asked a friend, incredulous that I had not scooted or bussed the one-mile journey.

Walking is better than ever since more than 100 piazzas were pedestrianised for the Vatican's holy year. That's another non-disaster. The infrastructure would collapse under the weight of the expected 26m pilgrims, wailed the experts. Well, you can hear it creak, but there's no collapse.

Even better, a third underground line is on its way, a new law has banned no-warning strikes and a series of car-free Sundays have been so popular that tomorrow's may not, after all, be the last.

Such optimism wins few converts among Mario's taxi-driving colleagues, who remain convinced the system is, always has been and always will be nuts. That's the world they know. To suggest otherwise is to possess a confused frontal lobe.

Superstitious nonsense, I replied, and yanked the belt. We skidded to a halt, he flung open the door and ordered me out. Then he sped away, leaving me in the rain to ponder his final, furious words. "You have offended a man of science." Reason and logic are not readily apparent when it comes to looking at transport in Rome. Public or private, the system is commonly viewed as nuts. Traffic jams solidify from 8am, parking spaces verge on the mythical, the underground has only two lines which bypass the city's heart, scooters litter footpaths and strikes paralyse trains. To the soundtrack of blaring horns, everybody agrees that getting around Rome is a nightmare. London's mayoral election has been followed with bafflement. Labour's wrangling was clear enough, but what on earth was that fuss about transport? All those underground lines, taxis you can hail in the street, buses that run all night, streets wide enough for two-way traffic. Heavenly. Why don't Londoners just shut up and enjoy? Mayor Francesco Rutelli has the luxury of an excuse denied to Ken Livingstone. Rome was not planned over the centuries, like London, Paris or Madrid. It became the capital after 1870 and was experimenting with horse-drawn trolleys while others were building undergrounds. The city didn't evolve, it improvised. When work did begin on an underground, digging had to stop after archaeological treasures were stumbled upon. The route was changed but treasures obstructed the new route, and the next one, and the one after that. A similar thing has just happened in Pompeii, where a 2,000-year-old luxury hotel has been discovered during a motorway widening. Via della Conciliazione rolls from St Peter's Square with a width and majesty alien to Rome's narrow, winding streets. Only a dictator like Mussolini had the power and recklessness to raze the medieval quarter that stood there. But antiquity's legacies do not fully absolve planners from today's problems. Waste, corruption and cowardice may have played their part, but chaos is in the eye of the beholder, for Rome is not so bad. The centre is small. Most things can be reached on foot, but try telling that to the natives. "You walked here?," asked a friend, incredulous that I had not scooted or bussed the one-mile journey. Walking is better than ever since more than 100 piazzas were pedestrianised for the Vatican's holy year. That's another non-disaster. The infrastructure would collapse under the weight of the expected 26m pilgrims, wailed the experts. Well, you can hear it creak, but there's no collapse. Even better, a third underground line is on its way, a new law has banned no-warning strikes and a series of car-free Sundays have been so popular that tomorrow's may not, after all, be the last. Such optimism wins few converts among Mario's taxi-driving colleagues, who remain convinced the system is, always has been and always will be nuts. That's the world they know. To suggest otherwise is to possess a confused frontal lobe.

webTitle: Ovarian cancer drug cleared for wider use

fields.headline: Ovarian cancer drug cleared for wider use
fields.standfirst:
NICE
Bristol Myers Squibb on Taxol
fields.trailText: Expensive new life-saving drugs for ovarian and breast cancer are to be made available to every woman who needs them anywhere in England following a landmark appraisal by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice).
fields.body:
Expensive new life-saving drugs for ovarian and breast cancer are to be made available to every woman who needs them anywhere in England following a landmark appraisal by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice).

Nice has officially ruled that paclitaxel (Taxol) for ovarian cancer must be the drug of first choice for every woman with ovarian cancer, which will cost the NHS an extra £7m. One in four with the disease, which kills 5,000 women a year, are not getting it because of the phenomenon of postcode prescribing - where some health authorities will pay the £7,000 it costs on average to treat a patient but others will not.

Nice's official verdict on Taxol and docetaxel (Taxotere) for breast cancer patients has been delayed by an appeal against the verdict on Taxol by its manufacturers, Bristol Myers Squibb, and the patient group CancerBacup.

They won the appeal, leading to assumptions that not only Taxotere will be approved - since the manufacturers were happy with the verdict - but also that Taxol will probably get the green light from the appraisal committee, who must now look at it again. The decision is expected in June. A ruling that the two drugs must be used in breast cancer treatment will push up the NHS drugs bill even further because of the far larger numbers involved.

Andrew Dillon, chief executive of Nice, said the guidance was good news for women suffering from ovarian cancer. "It doesn't matter where they live in England or Wales, they will get access to it in precisely the same way."

Nice estimates the cost per life year gained of the drug to be approximately £6,500 to £10,000. Mr Dillon denied that such a calculation suggested there was a price for life that Nice would balk at. Even the most expensive drug must be assessed on its merits, he said, and it might be that, in spite of a very high cost, it would be needed for only a few patients and so the bill for the NHS would not be extreme.

Jean Mossman of CancerBacup welcomed the verdict on Taxol for ovarian cancer. "We hope that health authorities will act immediately to implement this guidance and that women will no longer be denied this treatment," she said.

Hilary Thomas, professor of oncology at the University of Surrey and Royal Surrey County hospital, said there was substantial evidence that Taxol prolongs lives. "Private patients in the UK have had access to this treatment since October 1996, yet 30% of health authorities still do not fund Taxol for all women who could benefit from this drug."

The Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI) said it was concerned that Nice was delaying access to new drugs. It complained that medicines which had proved their effectiveness to the Medicines Control Agency to get a licence and were being used in other countries were now having to pass through another hurdle before patients could have them.

webTitle: 'Lost' Bacon to be sold at auction

fields.headline: 'Lost' Bacon to be sold at auction
fields.trailText: One of Francis Bacon's earliest and best "scream" pictures, which was lost for nearly 40 years, could fetch £1.8m when it goes under the hammer next month.
fields.body:
One of Francis Bacon's earliest and best "scream" pictures, which was lost for nearly 40 years, could fetch £1.8m when it goes under the hammer next month.

Study for Portrait (Man Screaming) disappeared in 1962 after being bought by one of Europe's most secretive collectors. The only evidence of its existence was a black and white photograph in one of the artist's old catalogues.

The mysterious connoisseur, whom Christie's would only describe yesterday as a "very, very private" person, has now put the painting up for sale. Brett Gorvy, a Bacon specialist at Christie's, said that Bacon experts had presumed the painting, inspired like many of Bacon's works by photographs of Himmler and other fascist leaders bellowing at their supporters, had been lost or destroyed.

"A dealer in Geneva sold it. Only a very small number of people knew who bought it and certainly none of the Bacon community knew anything of its whereabouts," he said. "It's an amazingly dramatic, intense and tormented picture, showing an authority figure descending into quite bestial rage.

"He painted it in 1952, which makes it very early and rare, at a time when he was alternating between doing pictures of these hole-like mouths and the earliest of his screaming popes."

Mr Gorvy said that the work was seminal in the development of that series, Bacon's most famous, based around Velasquez's Portrait of Pope Innocent X.

Bacon became obsessed with a book on diseases of the mouth in his twenties and his fixation intensified after seeing the famous close-up shot of the screaming nurse in Sergei Eisenstein's 1925 film, Battleship Potemkin.

Dublin-born Bacon, who died of a heart attack in 1992, was the most influential British artist of the last century. His reputation has been further enhanced by a series of huge retrospectives in America over the past year.

Man Screaming will be sold at Christie's in London on June 28.

webTitle: Herrings on prescription for Orkney heart patients

fields.headline: Herrings on prescription for Orkney heart patients
fields.trailText: Popping one under your tongue and letting it dissolve slowly is usually sage prescriptive advice from doctors to their patients.
fields.body:
Popping one under your tongue and letting it dissolve slowly is usually sage prescriptive advice from doctors to their patients.

But that could prove to be a bit of a mouthful to heart patients in Orkney. They are being prescribed herrings instead of pills.

Rich in omega-3 fatty acids, which can lower blood fat levels and reduce blood pressure, the fish is being handed out to patients instead of the more conventional beta-blockers or cholesterol-reducing drugs usually favoured by GPs.

For those who don't like the taste of herrings, tinned sardines are also available at the surgery in Stromness, which has 2,800 patients.

Each week Andrew Trevett dispenses two portions of marinated fish from the surgery's fridge to people who have survived heart attacks or suffer from coronary heart disease.

Doctors decided it was a logical step to persuade patients to eat more fish in their diet - by prescribing it.

Patients are further reminded of the health benefits by posters around the building stating that oily fish can reduce the chance of a second heart attack by up to 30%.

Stan Headley, a patient who survived a major heart attack two years ago, now eats a daily diet including sardines for lunch, trout for dinner and herrings for supper.

"The concept of getting fish on prescription seemed pretty radical to me - it was the last thing I expected."

Mr Headley, a keen fisherman, said he was happy to change his diet, but not all fishermen enjoyed eating fish.

He has also had a complete lifestyle change and has been encouraged to give up smoking a pipe and run a mile each day to make him healthier.

Fiona Holgate, of the Orkney Health Board, which is fund ing the scheme, said: "A lot of people used to eat salt fish in Orkney, but it no longer forms a major part of their diet.

"We are trying to encourage them to eat it because it is so good for them. The Orkney herring is locally caught and it really does taste lovely."

Patients can also take heart from the additional reputed benefits: it is a favourite ingredient for pet food manufacturers who claim it adds a sleeky shine to animals' coats.

webTitle: Cost put at $1bn as love bug mutates

fields.headline: Cost put at $1bn as love bug mutates
fields.standfirst:
Hunt closes in on computer hacker 'spyder' in Philippines while new versions of virus spread and half of firms in UK and US are infected

FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning
Information from Sophos anti-virus company
fields.trailText: Investigators in the Philippines appeared to be closing in yesterday on "spyder", author of the world's most devastating computer virus.
fields.body:
Investigators in the Philippines appeared to be closing in yesterday on "spyder", author of the world's most devastating computer virus.

But arresting and jailing the culprit, thought to be a 23-year-old man from a middle class suburb of Manila, will not prevent the love bug continuing its global destruction begun on Thursday, with new versions sprouting from computers around the world. One estimate puts the damage at $1bn (£650m).

Yesterday Microsoft, whose software was targeted by the virus creator, was accused by some IT specialists of having helped to create the conditions for the virus to spread, because of the ease with which different bits of its software could issue orders to each other.

Prompted by the FBI, investigators from the Philippine national bureau of investigations swooped yesterday on a Manila internet service provider, Access Net, which supplied "spyder" with two email addresses from which the virus originated.

Jose Carlotta, chief operating officer of Access Net, said that clues to the virus maker's identity had been obtained from online chatrooms. The person behind "spyder" had paid for one email account with a prepaid plastic card, and acquired others by hacking, so Access had no current name or address.

"We suspect that the guy is a 23-year-old from the suburb of Pandacan," said Mr Carlotta. "He's been very crafty. He's been very able to move around the network, the various ISPs, and been very hard to locate. He's been using a lot of hacked accounts." A local internet consultant, Toby Ayre, said the love bug had been uploaded onto the servers of another Manila provider last Friday, but had remained dormant for six days.

Estimates of the scale of infection and the damage caused varied wildly yesterday. Peter Tibbet of ICSA.net in Virginia, which was used by the US justice department to quantify the damage caused by the similar, milder Melissa virus, said he believed the scale of losses would reach $1bn by Monday, by which time half of all US companies would be infected.

In Britain, the Consumers' Association said 30% to 50% of UK businesses were affected.

Parliament, the Pentagon, the CIA, Congress, and numerous government agencies around the world were badly hit. The ingenuity of the virus was that it combined a simple, effective means of spreading itself and causing damage with a deft psychological trick - it came disguised as a love letter. When IT workers tried to open the letter by clicking on it, they launched the virus.

The virus spreads by mailing itself to every email address in a recipient's notebook; it overwrites potentially priceless picture and music files; and, most frighteningly, it downloads another piece of software from one of four remote websites which acts as a Trojan horse, reading a user's secret passwords and mailing them to the virus author.

Those remote websites have now been shut down. But to a hacker the code of the virus is so simple that other websites can be substituted and a new version launched to scan more passwords. That is what happened yesterday, with at least three other versions of the ILOVEYOU virus emerging.

One, "Very Funny", masquerades as a joke. Another pretends to be an email about Mother's Day. A third is called Susitikim, which means "let's meet" in Lithuanian.

A number of computer security experts yesterday voiced concern that the Microsoft software targeted by the virus author - later versions of Windows and the email application Outlook Express - were not secure enough for ordinary users.

Pierre Vandeveune, of the Belgian firm Datarescue, which makes software used by many anti-virus companies, asked why it was that in Outlook Express a single click by a naive user was all it took to launch an alien programme that could mess up the entire computer.

The virus was written in Virtual Basic, a Microsoft programming language."The problem with Microsoft is that all the pieces link together too well _ the system works so well you don't think about it; you just click, and this virus can email your password outside," said Mr Vandeveune.

"Microsoft only thought about how they could have more features. But then there are consequences."

A spokesman for Microsoft UK said that viruses could affect any software, and Microsoft tended to be a target only because it had the most users. "This is not really a tech nology issue, it's an issue of motives," she said. "That's why Microsoft provide security features and let our customers decided whether a programme should run or not.

"A virus can only spread if the person who receives infected mail opens it."

webTitle: Police arrest top operator of drug gang in Mexico

fields.headline: Police arrest top operator of drug gang in Mexico
fields.trailText: Mexico claimed it had captured the top operator of the Arellano Felix cocaine cartel after a gun battle in the northwest, dealing a blow to one of Latin America's most powerful and ruthless drug gangs.
fields.body:
Mexico claimed it had captured the top operator of the Arellano Felix cocaine cartel after a gun battle in the northwest, dealing a blow to one of Latin America's most powerful and ruthless drug gangs.

The Mexican anti-drug chief, Mariano Herran Salvatti, said an anti-drugs unit battled its way into a house near the town of Ensenada in Baja California state on Wednesday and arrested Ismael "El Mayel" Higuera Guerrero.

Mr Higuera Guerrero was wanted for the 1993 murder of an attorney general's office head and is regarded as the chief of the Arellano Felix brothers' drug smuggling, execution, kidnapping and bribery operations, he said.

"He's the main operator of the organisation," Mr Herran Salvatti said. "This is a major blow. We are witnessing the dismantling of the Arellano Felix organisation."

Led by the brothers Ramon Eduardo, Benjamin and Javier, the organisation, based in the wild border town of Tijuana, is considered one of Mexico's most bloodthirsty drug gangs, and rivals the Colombian cartels in its power and wealth.

The US drug enforcement administration applauded the arrest as "a major victory for both Mexican and US law enforcement".

"Higuera Guerrero's apprehension is a significant step toward bringing the leaders of the notorious Arellano Felix drug mafia to justice," a spokesman said.

The arrest - apparently as a result of an anonymous tip from a neighbour "scandalised" by Mr Higuera Guerrero's drinking, partying and gun-firing - was the second recent blow for the Arellano Felix.

Last month, announcing a crackdown against the organisation, Mexican authorities arrested its alleged financial controller, Jesus "El Chuy" Labra.

The cartel began a spree of retaliatory killings. It is suspected of being behind this month's murder of three anti-drug agents near Tijuana and the assassination of the city's police chief, officials said.

On Wednesday night, as rumours of the arrest of "El Mayel" spread, unknown gunmen fired shots at the official residence of President Ernesto Zedillo in Mexico City. But Mr Herran Salvatti denied that there was a link between the crackdown on the cartel and the drive-by shooting.

The anti-drug chief said that police and troops were led to a house near Ensenada after a telephone tip-off. When they approached the house, they were shot at.

Police and soldiers stormed the building but then came under fire from Mr Higuera Guerrero, who was hiding on the second floor. Eventually, the security forces lobbed three tear gas grenades into the house and managed to subdue him.

Eight people were arrested in the house, including his 15-year-old son and two Colombian women. A ninth suspect, also Colombian, was arrested later in Mexico City.

Mr Herran Salvatti said the police seized mobile telephones, shortwave radios, handguns, a machine gun, cocaine, cars and about $35,000 (£23,000) in a range of currencies.

The Arellano Felix brothers are wanted on both sides of the border. Ramon Eduardo is on the FBI's "10 most wanted" list.
Reuters

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: The Austrian government is to hold a referendum in the autumn to support its campaign for an end to sanctions by the other 14 EU states, unless their position changes before July
fields.body:
Austria to vote on EU sanctions

The Austrian government is to hold a referendum in the autumn to support its campaign for an end to sanctions by the other 14 EU states, unless their position changes before July.

"The question will contain a clear commitment to the European Union and a clear demand that the sanctions be lifted," the chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, said.
Reuters, Vienna

Peace talks collapse

Peace talks aimed at ending the two-year border conflict with Eritrea have collapsed in Algiers, Ethiopia said yesterday. The conflict has cost thousands of lives, but has recently retreated into a simmering stand-off.
Reuters, Addis Ababa

Bombs hit Karachi

Two bombs exploded in Karachi yesterday, killing one person and injuring six, Pakistani police said. The 14m-strong city has been racked by ethnic or religious violence in recent years.
AP, Karachi

Reuters, Vienna Peace talks collapse Peace talks aimed at ending the two-year border conflict with Eritrea have collapsed in Algiers, Ethiopia said yesterday. The conflict has cost thousands of lives, but has recently retreated into a simmering stand-off. Reuters, Addis Ababa Bombs hit Karachi Two bombs exploded in Karachi yesterday, killing one person and injuring six, Pakistani police said. The 14m-strong city has been racked by ethnic or religious violence in recent years. AP, Karachi

webTitle: The night Mark and Lard died - and took radio with them

fields.headline: The night Mark and Lard died - and took radio with them
fields.trailText: Somebody has shot JR? | Mr Souter's monopoly
fields.body:
Last week I mentioned some of the truly terrible aspects of British life, and I'm grateful for your response, to which I shall return. But on Tuesday I went to what was the naffest occasion I think I've ever attended - the Sony radio awards at the Grosvenor House hotel. I must confess that I and my colleagues hoped we were going to win an award for the News Quiz but I promise, I swear, that the sense of being overwhelmed by terminal naffness began long before we learned we'd lost.

There was the roped-off VIP reception we all had to pass on our way to the cash bar, where a gin and tonic cost £7. Then the clothes: all those ruffled shirts, bow ties like monarch butterflies, and paisley waistcoats worn over massive paunches, so that the place looked like a bouncers' convention in a Bournemouth nightclub.

Next, the 1,300 or so guests had to fight their way through crammed tables to their seats, pushing past waitresses who were already serving the first course. And the lighting was purple and blue, so the food looked like nuclear waste on a plate. After that things got worse.

Every time I'm rude about Radio 1, someone writes to say: "Oh, but you must listen to Mark and Lard in the afternoon, they're hilarious." So I looked forward to their stint presenting a batch of awards. They began with an eight-minute turn which won not a single titter from the audience. Not one audible voice was raised in laughter. I felt sorry for them. We've all died on our feet - I often have - but to die in front of 1,300 of your colleagues in the trade! If it were a dream, you'd wake up sweating with horror.

Somehow they kept going, and introduced Ulrika Jonsson, who is pregnant. A fat man called "Jono" Coleman from some commercial station came on and told the assembled company: "I've just been informed by Ulrika that I'm not the father, but with a huge schlong like mine, it's hard to keep the sperm in the condom!"

"Well done, Jono!" said Mark, or it might have been Lard. I finished my main course and pushed off into the night.Somehow I'd vaguely thought of radio as a last vestige of civilisation, but we seem to have lost that too.

A far pleasanter occasion was the Hatchard's Authors of the Year reception the next night. It was full of strange juxtapositions. Frances Partridge, the last surviving member of the Bloomsbury Group, who turned 100 in March, was there, talking to Gyles Brandreth, who squatted in front of her wearing that strange, shiny smile people adopt when talking to the very old. All that talk, all that bed-hopping, all that writing and arguing and drinking, and it comes to this: sitting immobile while Brandreth smiles at you like a retarded Moonie.

Then a colleague went for a word with Roger Katz, the bookshop's popular manager. "Can't stop now," he said cheerily, "I'm just dashing upstairs to find a copy of Marcus Aurelius for Jack Higgins!"

 After I watched Dallas Night on Channel 4, I caught up with the news about Zimbabwe and, oddly enough, the two events blended together. Years ago, some time after independence, a colleague and I gave a lift to a "troopie", a young white soldier who was just back from visiting South Africa, an industrial country which must have seemed as strange and exotic to someone from the essentially rural Rhodesia as New York would to a Mexican peasant. He was terrifically excited by the divided highways. Did we have them in England? We explained that, yes, we did have dual carriageways and he seemed a little disappointed. "In Sith Ifrica thi hivv colour tilivision!" he said. Did we have colour TV in England? Again, our response seemed to make him rueful. So when he asked if we had Dallas on English TV, to cheer him up, I asked: "Who do you think shot JR?"

There was a stunned silence from the back of the car. "Somebody has shot JR?" he asked in a strangulated voice. I realised that in the past anthropologists judged how advanced a society was by when they discovered fire and invented the wheel. In the modern age, it's how far they have reached in the latest hit American soap opera.

 The appalling South-west trains have a new trick. Sometimes the train leaves our local station early. This is because the timetable allows more time for it to get from the previous station than it needs. Since there's no clock on the station, the driver can't tell that he's leaving too soon, and so frequently does, sometimes by a whole minute. We've asked to have a clock installed, but they say it would cost too much. Presumably Mr Brian Souter, who is co-owner of the company, needs the cash to pursue his ferocious campaign against the repeal of Section 28 in Scotland.

After I missed one train, the next ran 10 minutes behind schedule, so I was very late for my appointment - a common experience when you depend on Mr Souter's monopoly to get you anywhere. As I waited in the cold (of course there's no waiting room), I reflected that he really does offer an equal opportunity business. Us straights living in the suburbs with our families are condemned to a dreadful train service partly so that 400 miles north, Mr Souter can pursue his vendetta against a minority which probably feels quite oppressed enough already.

fields.headline: Douglas Oliver
fields.standfirst: A poet articulating ethical values in a world of injustice and joy
fields.trailText: At the time of his death from cancer at the age of 62, the poet Douglas Oliver was at the height of his powers, and on the threshold of a new stage of work after retirement from teaching at the British Institute in Paris.
fields.body:
At the time of his death from cancer at the age of 62, the poet Douglas Oliver was at the height of his powers, and on the threshold of a new stage of work after retirement from teaching at the British Institute in Paris.

Until 10 years ago, his writing was known mainly to a select and exacting readership of fellow poets, as was inevitable since he chose to publish with specialist imprints run by poets. This was a deliberate choice, and a significant career move for a poet whose first appearances in print were in Encounter and the London Magazine.

His first book, Oppo Hectic (1969), registered this change of allegiance by acknowledging, alongside the names of those respected magazines, others with names such as The Anona Winn and Resuscitator. A volume of collected poems, Kind (1987), did much to consolidate his reputation, both with his initial readership and with a younger generation of poets.

Yet success at this level of public activity was not something Oliver was proud of; what was important was the fostering of a probity of literary relationship between poets, editors and publishers, and the development of a social space for poetry. This had enabled him to write as he wished - to sustain long-term projects (for instance, The Diagram Poems, published 1979 but begun in the early 70s) with an attentive audience for work-in-progress.

As the focus of his concern for ethical value and spirit shifted from the private and personal to the more inclusively human, social and political, Oliver insisted on his writing as a mode of public address, not seeking a wider audience from ambitious motives but the broadest possible spectrum of the public.

He was pleased to perform at Poetry Slams, while living in New York in the early 1990s, submitting his poems for approval to a popular audience to be scored competitively. His career began moving in a new direction.

Even before Howard Brenton's outburst in the Guardian in 1992, acclaiming Penniless Politics (1991) as setting the literary agenda for the next two decades, and invoking both Paradise Lost and The Waste Land, Oliver had taken the step, necessary in order to reach a broader public, of publishing with a trade paperback house.

Three Variations On The Theme Of Harm (1990) would be the best introduction to the range and diversity of his imagination and technique (had Paladin kept it in print), for it brought together new poems, his first novel, The Harmless Building (1973), and the long poem The Infant And The Pearl (1985).

More successful were Bloodaxe's republication of Penniless Politics (1994) and the Penguin Modern Poets (No 10, 1996), in which Oliver appeared. Just days before he died, Bloodaxe published A Salvo For Africa, in which, in opposition to the tendency of wealthy countries to regard Africa as no more than "a hopeless sink into which aid money disappeared", he pits his own imagination against that collective "failure to imagine" in an effort to redress it.

This book of reckless and driven optimism is sure to be seen as a summation, both political testament and poetic legacy. But there will be readers seeking a more inclusive view of his achievement, for whom earlier work, including poems in the lyric vein that he never abandoned, remains undiminished by later work with a more public stance.

Restlessness characterised the Oliver I knew: he moved from Cambridge to Paris, to Coventry, to Brightlingsea, back to Paris, to New York, to Paris again, where he finally seemed to settle. Born in Southampton, he went late to the University of Essex, having left school at 16, before becoming a journalist on local newspapers in Cambridge and Coventry (the latter stint yielding a deadpan interview with Philip Larkin, hilarious for insiders who knew that a poet was asking the questions), and at Agence France-Presse.

He has been acclaimed as a political poet on the basis of a utopian vision of human community, yet his journalist's feel for actuality led him to posit hope as utopian, and secreted somewhere was a Calvinist instinct of terror and guilt. He was, at bottom, an old-fashioned antinomian, led to seek the manifestations of spirit wherever they spontaneously occurred, in voodoo ritual or the ceremony of the Orthodox church - and, above all, in persons. But I doubt that he ever saw in himself the greatness and generosity of spirit that move his writing and, expended on friends and strangers alike, made them quicken in recognition and wish for the best in themselves.

He leaves two daughters from his first marriage. His second wife, Alice Notley, whom he married in 1988, survives him.

Greg Chamberlain writes: Doug Oliver was never the kind of poet who shuts himself off from the world, though he once spent several months in a Derbyshire cave to write a poem. He was game for just about anything - "Material!" he would say with a twinkle in his eye.

Whether toiling as a teenage insurance clerk in Bournemouth, a night computer operator in a New York cancer hospital, doing the muddy rounds as a farming reporter, or hob-nobbing with crooks, revolutionaries or local lovelies during a trip he and I made to Haiti and Grenada in 1984, he was always eagerly absorbing new things. Back in 1982, he was one of the first people I knew with a computer.

Pub crawls with him in Paris were based on the principle that "we must go on," not so much to get drunk as to check out new people and situations in the next bar. He was a good example to the faint-hearted.

He was equally at home discussing the plight of Caribbean banana-producers, the technicalities of foreign assaults on the economies of Africa, or bird-watching. He became fascinated by boxing (he went to Italy to study it) and wrote about Uruguay's Tupamaros guerrillas in the 1970s.

He would give a hilarious rendering of Churchill's last election meeting in the 1960s, which he covered as a young reporter, when the national icon, senility well-advanced, sat mutely on the platform, like a great toad, as embarrassed aides waved away questions on local matters about which Churchill knew nothing.

The agnostic he was would have smirked at managing to die on Good Friday, 29 years to the day after the Haitian tyrant, Papa Doc Duvalier. "More material," he would have quipped.

Douglas Oliver, poet, born September 14 1937; died April 21 2000

webTitle: O! You are men of stones

fields.headline: O! You are men of stones
fields.trailText: This has been a humiliating week for poor Shakespeare. Just after his birthday, too. There was Geoffrey Boycott in a French court quoting Richard II and still getting beaten. (Try Molière next time, Geoffrey. Or Racine. Or Victor Hugo.) Then there was some woman called Vodafone who was asked on a quiz show which of the plays featured Toby Belch. She could not anwer. Yet she was unashamed. It was all Shakespeare's fault, it emerged, for being so boring. But the bard has also been under fire from a much more serious quarter: the novelist, biographer, topographer and writer on football, Hunter Davies. The Daily Mail asked Hunt (as he affectionately styles himself) last weekend what books he was reading. "I haven't read a novel since, I dunno, I last wrote one," the master confessed. But he always had a non-fiction book on the go. And what would he take to a desert island? "Not the Bible or Shakespeare. Boring, boring. Can't understand why they've lasted so long. My theory with Shakespeare is that he got in first with all the clichés about the human condition. Reader's Digest have done it much better since."
fields.body:
This has been a humiliating week for poor Shakespeare. Just after his birthday, too. There was Geoffrey Boycott in a French court quoting Richard II and still getting beaten. (Try Molière next time, Geoffrey. Or Racine. Or Victor Hugo.) Then there was some woman called Vodafone who was asked on a quiz show which of the plays featured Toby Belch. She could not anwer. Yet she was unashamed. It was all Shakespeare's fault, it emerged, for being so boring. But the bard has also been under fire from a much more serious quarter: the novelist, biographer, topographer and writer on football, Hunter Davies. The Daily Mail asked Hunt (as he affectionately styles himself) last weekend what books he was reading. "I haven't read a novel since, I dunno, I last wrote one," the master confessed. But he always had a non-fiction book on the go. And what would he take to a desert island? "Not the Bible or Shakespeare. Boring, boring. Can't understand why they've lasted so long. My theory with Shakespeare is that he got in first with all the clichés about the human condition. Reader's Digest have done it much better since."

Well, at least poor old William shares his place in the stocks with God. But you have to hand it to Hunt, he's got a point, hasn't he? Just imagine how much better the bard's work would be, not to mention the book of Genesis, if touched by Hunt's magic hand. "I saw Barcelona v Chelsea in my son's house in downtown Tufnell Park," he wrote recently in the Statesman. "He's got ONdigital. Sounds like spots or a nasty rash... For Man Utd v Real Madrid on ITV, I was here, at home, in my room, on my tod... " Betcha Shakespeare never penned prose that elegant. I mean, who goes about the place nowadays asking damnfool questions like "Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?" when they could be saying "Cor, Kimmy, you're just like the sun coming out"? Or take all that tedious dated stuff of Hamlet's: "To be or not to be, that is the question." Hunt would cut through that guff. "Yes or no? It's a toss-up, innit," his Hamlet would say. Or Mark Antony after the death of Caesar: "Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears. I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him..." Who in the name of Becks talks like that nowadays? "Mates," the speech would begin in Hunt's version. "Get a load of this: I'm here to dump poor old Jules under a few squillion tons of earth, not to tell you what a great guy he was." Better already, right?

But enough of what I have come to think of as the sloven-demotic style in English letters, and on to the news that our cross channel friends, unlike us Brits, are happy to recognise, even to welcome, gay relationships in their armed services. The reports on this matter which I have so far read all fail to mention the great French military hero, Marshal Louis Hubert Gonzalve Lyautey (1854-1934). He should have been there on two counts. First, he famously said, I think with some justice, that the one truly indispensable quality in a leader was gaiety. Secondly, he was in fact (though the term wasn't used at the time) gay himself. Perhaps the Lyautey spirit has influenced the line the French are now taking? I await advice from psychologists.

When people complain in places like the Daily Telegraph that the police are not coping with crime, they often allege that the reason for this is that the force is too busy persecuting poor motorists. The Tony Martin case has brought forth a burst of such moans. Take this letter from a booby signing herself Councillor Lady Atkins (doesn't say which party: Socialist Worker perhaps?) of Garstang, Lancs. "It is unbelievable," she writes, "that the police go out of the way to trap drivers with their laser guns and cameras, but are unable to protect the Cenotaph or Churchill's statue." I would not for a moment defend Monday's vandals, who clearly subscribe to the view that there's no such thing as society. But as far as I know they did not kill anybody or even come close to doing so. High-speeding motorists, not to mention the drunken ones, constantly do so, which is why the police are entirely right to pursue them.

The behaviour of the river Trent has begun to disturb me. I recently repeated the doctrine that nightingales do not sing north of the Trent. It has since been pointed out that although this statement might make some sense when applied to a river the whole of which flows east-west, it cannot apply to the Trent, the final section of which, having said goodbye to Newark, runs steadfastly northwards until it reaches the Humber. Are we asked to believe that nightingales assume on reaching this point that the east bank is de facto a south bank, since that was its role near Nottingham? I await advice from psychologists. Meanwhile, the next time you hear the expression "north of the Trent" in a political speech or a BBC broadcast, ring up and complain.

On second thoughts, I think what Vodafone said about Shakespeare was that his writing was "dull as ditchwater". Whoever read this out on the radio corrected to that to "dishwater" though ditchwater, I think, was correct. Dull as ditchwater is one of those kneejerk similes, powered by alliteration, which I often condemn. We are probably better off without either usage but while they persist, I think dishwater has my vote. I spend little time studying either effluent, but I think on the whole that the water you find in ditches - which may be stagnant and smelly and have the odd old shoe in it but is full of the works of nature - is rather less dull than the mix of old bits of carrot, Tesco baked bean, shreds of rice and coffee grounds which you tend to find in dishwater. I await advice from psychologists.
