First, he famously said, I think with some justice, that the one truly indispensable quality in a leader was gaiety. Secondly, he was in fact (though the term wasn't used at the time) gay himself. Perhaps the Lyautey spirit has influenced the line the French are now taking? I await advice from psychologists. When people complain in places like the Daily Telegraph that the police are not coping with crime, they often allege that the reason for this is that the force is too busy persecuting poor motorists. The Tony Martin case has brought forth a burst of such moans. Take this letter from a booby signing herself Councillor Lady Atkins (doesn't say which party: Socialist Worker perhaps?) of Garstang, Lancs. "It is unbelievable," she writes, "that the police go out of the way to trap drivers with their laser guns and cameras, but are unable to protect the Cenotaph or Churchill's statue." I would not for a moment defend Monday's vandals, who clearly subscribe to the view that there's no such thing as society. But as far as I know they did not kill anybody or even come close to doing so. High-speeding motorists, not to mention the drunken ones, constantly do so, which is why the police are entirely right to pursue them. The behaviour of the river Trent has begun to disturb me. I recently repeated the doctrine that nightingales do not sing north of the Trent. It has since been pointed out that although this statement might make some sense when applied to a river the whole of which flows east-west, it cannot apply to the Trent, the final section of which, having said goodbye to Newark, runs steadfastly northwards until it reaches the Humber. Are we asked to believe that nightingales assume on reaching this point that the east bank is de facto a south bank, since that was its role near Nottingham? I await advice from psychologists. Meanwhile, the next time you hear the expression "north of the Trent" in a political speech or a BBC broadcast, ring up and complain. On second thoughts, I think what Vodafone said about Shakespeare was that his writing was "dull as ditchwater". Whoever read this out on the radio corrected to that to "dishwater" though ditchwater, I think, was correct. Dull as ditchwater is one of those kneejerk similes, powered by alliteration, which I often condemn. We are probably better off without either usage but while they persist, I think dishwater has my vote. I spend little time studying either effluent, but I think on the whole that the water you find in ditches - which may be stagnant and smelly and have the odd old shoe in it but is full of the works of nature - is rather less dull than the mix of old bits of carrot, Tesco baked bean, shreds of rice and coffee grounds which you tend to find in dishwater. I await advice from psychologists.

fields.headline: Nature's sociable loners
fields.trailText: The hunched man in the mist was trying to tell us important things. That we are animals, yes, but also that we are much more. That our brains may resemble computers, true, but they are not computers.
fields.body:
The hunched man in the mist was trying to tell us important things. That we are animals, yes, but also that we are much more. That our brains may resemble computers, true, but they are not computers.

At the start of the 13th and final instalment of The Ascent of Man (BBC2), Jacob Bronowski was in Iceland, at a place where the whole community of Norsemen would meet once a year to make and receive laws. This was, he argued, the cradle of the oldest democracy in northern Europe. He stood in a natural amphitheatre, where a farmer had killed a slave and had been outlawed for his crime. Innocent blood had been spilled, and it seemed fitting to ancient Norsemen that nobler human aspirations should honour that death.

"Justice is a universal of all cultures," said Bronowski in his precisely enunciated English. "It is a tightrope that man walks between the desire to fulfil his own wishes and his acknowledgment of social responsibility. No animal is faced with this dilemma. An animal is either social or solitary. Man is alone in being social and solitary."

This solitary man on the other end of the camera sociably invited us into his Californian home to continue the discussion. In a flash we were transported from curvilinear amphitheatre to rectilinear beachfront home, with its sliding patio doors and wire-backed chairs. The furniture told us this was 1973.

It was the unique biological feature of man - his sociable solitariness - that had excited Bronowski's move from physics to biology. Scientists had always tried to understand man by analogy with animals. Several millennia ago, Galen dissected the forearms of Barbary apes to understand the workings of human forearms. More recently, BF Skinner and Konrad Lorenz tried to understand human psychology by studying rats and ducks. But we are not animals: "There must be something unique about man because otherwise rats would be lecturing on Skinner and ducks would be giving papers on Konrad Lorenz." Bronowski allowed himself a small chuckle.

A marvellous coup de television (in TV there are precious few) followed: in a single 20 minute take, Bronowski wandered around his home like an infinitely more intellectual Loyd Grossman. Nearly everything in his astoundingly well-appointed home became a visual aid to dramatise his points. A model of a human brain helped us visualise the frontal lobes and their importance, a painting of Dr Bronowski helped us understand how artists conceive of scientists.

He reached into a cabinet and produced a little skull. "I have an object which I treasure," he said. It was a two-million-year-old human skull. "Of course, she's not strictly a human child. And if she - I always think of her as a girl - if she had lived long enough she might have been my ancestor." He held that little skull evocatively in the palm of his hand, the opposable thumb wrapped around it and nearly touching his index finger, in a gesture that only humans can manage.

It was a joy to watch and hear Bronowski ramble - around his home, around centuries of scientific and artistic human achievement. He dramatised the brain's distinctive plasticity with reference to Hamlet. Only reflect, he suggested, on the agonies of Hamlet's decision-making and you will understand why we are more than computers and animals. "What is Hamlet about? It's about a young man, a boy, making the first decision of his life [killing the king], and finding it beyond his reach_ The tragedy is not that Hamlet dies, but that Hamlet dies when he is ready to become a great king." It is a specifically human tragedy, then, characterised by Bronowski in such a way that we can all feel its poignancy: Hamlet matures, and when he is capable of acting, when he has deliberated in a way alien to lower life forms and machines, just then he is deprived of that very fulfilment.

True, Bronowski's thoughts are no longer at the cutting edge of science (artificial intelligence seems to have eclipsed his hard-wired philosophy of computers), but his intellectual excitement, his singular televisual showmanship, his captivating soul should make this series worth repeating at prime time. For the past 13 weeks, our nobler aspirations have been cradled in the unnatural amphitheatre of a 2am TV slot for Open University. Such is the descent of television.

At the end of his series, Bronowski returned to where he and our ancestors had begun, eastern Africa. On the first day of filming, his sound engineer and cameraman had crashed in a light aircraft. He stood in front of the plane and reflected that the cameraman, although terrified, had resolved to return to the skies. Bronowski took succour from this: "We are all afraid," he said, "for our confidence, for the future, for the world. That is the nature of human imagination and yet every man, every civilisation has gone forward because of its engagement with what it has set itself to do." In our often disengaged world, it was chastening to hear these words.

webTitle: Hostages alive and held in one group

fields.headline: Hostages alive and held in one group
fields.trailText: All 21 hostages, including 10 foreign tourists, kidnapped by Muslim rebels from a Malaysian diving resort are alive and are being held in a single location after apparently breaking through a military cordon, sources close to negotiators said yesterday.
fields.body:
All 21 hostages, including 10 foreign tourists, kidnapped by Muslim rebels from a Malaysian diving resort are alive and are being held in a single location after apparently breaking through a military cordon, sources close to negotiators said yesterday.

Several emissaries sent by negotiators attempting to free the hostages were able to visit the Abu Sayyaf kidnappers at their hide-out on Jolo island in the Philippines on Thursday, the sources said.

Acting on the report, a team of negotiators sent by the chief government negotiator, Nur Misuari, arrived in Jolo yesterday and planned to go into the mountains to meet the kidnappers.

The emissaries' account contradicted earlier reports that the hostages had been divided up and were being held in five different locations and that some had either died during a clash with the military or had escaped.

It also indicates that the kidnappers may have managed to break through hundreds of troops and police encircling them. The cordon had been formed earlier in the week, and a series of clashes erupted on Tuesday and Wednesday as the rebels attempted to escape.

On Wednesday, troops seized the simple bamboo hut where the hostages had been held and found three room keys from the Sipadan Island Resort, the Malaysian diving resort from which the hostages were abducted on April 23.

The rebels had threatened to behead two foreign hostages if the military did not pull its troops away from the area, but the government said they would stay.

"Our policy in this situation is containment in response to the request of foreign governments," the presidential executive secretary, Ronaldo Zamora, said.

"We don't want to assault the area where the hostages are being held, but we cannot allow the kidnappers to get away either."

A rebel leader, Abu Escobar, said in an interview broadcast on a local radio station yesterday that the group is discussing whether to go ahead with the threat if the military does not stop its rescue operations.

"We will see. If the situation remains, the surprise may happen," he said.

The Jolo hostages include 10 Malaysians, three Germans, two French nationals, two South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese and one Filipino.

On the nearby island of Basilan, troops continued to search for Abu Sayyaf rebels who are believed still to be holding several people from a separate group of 27 Filipino hostages seized nearly seven weeks ago, the military said.

Fifteen of the hostages were rescued on Wednesday but four, including a Roman Catholic priest, were killed, reportedly shot in the back of the head by their captors.
AP

webTitle: Disaster memories pay off at auction

fields.headline: Disaster memories pay off at auction
fields.standfirst: That night to remember still fascinates collectors, as Stewart Dalby discovered at a sale of Titanic memorabilia
fields.trailText: That night to remember still fascinates collectors, as Stewart Dalby discovered at a sale of Titanic memorabilia.
fields.body:
The blockbuster movie Titanic has fuelled a huge boom in sales of memorabilia such as menus and postcards - to say nothing of spin-offs such as paintings of the ship and related ephemera like sextants, compasses and other marine objects.

Postcards from Cobh (Cork) where the ship called before heading out into the Atlantic have proved particularly popular.

Some Titanic items feature in the Sotheby's auction of marine works of art running online until May 15 at www.sothebys.amazon.com.

This follows a sale at Sotheby's in London earlier this week which centred on the story of Sarah Roth, who sailed on Titanic to join her fiancé in America.

Sarah and Daniel Iles had been childhood sweethearts and when the young man emigrated to America in search of a better life, she agreed to wait and follow him when he had found work and made some money.

A year later, in 1912, when Daniel sent her the money for the fare to join him in New York, Sarah managed to secure one of the last third-class tickets on the maiden voyage of White Star Line's new flagship.

Sarah survived the disaster - which claimed 1,500 lives - but lost everything, including the wedding dress she had made herself.

The exception was her handbag containing her third class inspection card and that day's menu card, which she clutched tightly as she clambered aboard a lifeboat.

Six hours later she was plucked from the freezing cold by RMS Carpathia, which had responded to Titanic's emergency signal.

Eight days after the sinking Sarah married Daniel, a shipping clerk, at St Vincent's Hospital in New York. She wore a wedding gown bought with money which had been donated by a local women's relief committee in New York.

Their bridesmaid, Emily Badman, was another survivor of the disaster.

The inspection card made £12, 925, the menu card was bought by a British collector bidding by telephone for £20, 560, while her ticket holder went for £1,175.

Also sold, for £1,530, was a collection of correspondence written after the event.

This included letters which related to Sarah's claim for compensation for the property she lost in the disaster - including the original wedding dress she had made before leaving home.

The letters include a dramatic account of how she "... woke up feeling that the ship had stopped. I dressed and went outside my cabin.

"Here I had a conversation with my friend and her husband and we waited for some considerable time when seeing some officers or stewards... we asked them what was the matter and they said that the ship had struck an iceberg, but added that there was no danger and nothing to be alarmed about."

However, another officer ordered her to fit her lifebelt and proceed towards the second class deck - at which point she grabbed her handbag containing the menu, her inspection card and the ticket holder.

Sarah saw other third-class passengers being barred by a gate from getting near the lifeboats, although she was directed towards a ladder leading to the upper boat deck where she found collapsible lifeboat C about to be lowered.

Sarah's third class menu, which she had slipped into her handbag on the evening of the disaster, is believed to be the only one of its kind. It shows that she and her fellow passengers had enjoyed smoked herrings for breakfast, roast beef for lunch and cold meats and pickles for tea.

On the reverse of the menu the numbers of passengers and those that subsequently died or were rescued are listed in pencil, possibly by Sarah herself. No other third class menu is known to exist.

Sarah's inspection card is believed to be unique because so few people survived among the lower classes.

It relates to the daily inspections for head lice and diseases such as tuberculosis which were carried out among the lower-class passengers throughout the voyage.

The card was stamped in English, Swedish, French, German, Italian, Finnish, Croatian and Dutch.

The collection was sold at Sotheby's by the couple's great-grandson David Slossar, a real estate manager from Connecticut, who inherited the archive from his grandfather Albert Iles on his death last year.

These prices are well in excess of previous prices, suggesting that the Titanic boom is not over yet.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: These are extraordinary, worrying times for the UK auto industry. Hot on the heels of BMW's announcement that it would sell off the Rover Group we have Ford's bombshell that it plans to end volume car production at Dagenham.
fields.body:
These are extraordinary, worrying times for the UK auto industry. Hot on the heels of BMW's announcement that it would sell off the Rover Group we have Ford's bombshell that it plans to end volume car production at Dagenham.

It's no surprise that Tony Blair has dived into the fray: these developments raise real question marks over the UK's future as a manufacturing centre. But we should be very careful what conclusions we draw.

For one thing, these decisions reflect huge over- capacity in the European car industry. Ford CEO Jac Nasser recently commented that installed European manufacturing capacity is 20m cars, contrasted with annual sales of less than 16m. This restructuring, in short, could have been seen coming down the pike some time ago.

To say that Ford will also be closing assembly plants in Poland and Portugal hardly helps. The time has clearly come for a rethink of the whole sector. Which makes the sustainability strategy launched by the UK Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) topical. Its preparation, it should be said, predated the news from BMW and Ford, but its conclusions are worth reading in the wake of these momentous announcements.

The industry, the SMMT notes in Towards Sustainability: The Automotive Sector Strategy, is the UK's largest - and is also the first to commit to public reporting on its progress towards long-term sustainability. Readers, however, will not find any mention of any impending shakeout. A real pity, since there is no time like a crisis to focus minds on the future.

At this point, I should declare an interest, having contributed a "stakeholder comment" to the report. Worryingly, it notes, "some trends are steering in the wrong direction". Not the threatened closures, in this case, but the growing taste for huge, gas-guzzling sports utility vehicles (SUVs).

As a result, it is said, vehicles now being scrapped are often more fuel-efficient than those in the showrooms or on sale over the internet.

Some people in the industry are deeply uncomfortable with this line of argument. If consumers want to buy SUVs, they say, surely that is a way of securing the long-term future of at least some companies?

Well, maybe, but if I had to pick industry sectors certain to come under intense pressure over the next decade in terms of their triple bottom line performance, car-makers would be right there in front rank.

To be sure, there is good news in the SMMT report, which is the first in a planned series. For one thing, the industry has voluntarily committed to cut its carbon dioxide emissions from new cars by 25% by 2008. A useful start.

There is also a growing acceptance, if not yet a real enthusiasm, for the "take-back" laws proposed across the EU for "end-of-life" vehicles requiring recycling.

But the "continue-to-improve" targets scattered through the report can only be the beginning.

This sector will be swept by what the economist Joseph Schumpeter dubbed "waves of creative destruction". Unless it acts fast, paying real attention to likely trends in sustainable mobility, much of the industry will find itself consigned to the dustbin of history.

 John Elkington is chairman of strategy consultants SustainAbility (www.sustainability.co.uk.) The SMMT's web-site is at www.smmt.co.uk.

fields.headline: James Hill
fields.standfirst: Chairman of Lever Brothers UK
fields.trailText: When did you first become a manager?
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

In 1982, locking horns with the union representative in a print factory in the north west.

What has been your best moment in management?

I think it was when the Unilever board supported our plan to invest heavily in laundry tablets.

What was your greatest mistake?

Back in 1989, launching the Radion detergent with decidedly dodgy advertising.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Selling the houses I've bought at the times I bought them.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

They are a constant reminder that they deserve better leadership!

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

I'd like to say no, but the stats would suggest otherwise. But we are actively addressing the issue.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

The supremacy of strategy. Most strategies are obvious and copyable. Boldness and skill in execution is the differentiator.

What one lesson would you pass on to young managers?

Get a reputation for honouring your commitments.

Which management guru do you believe in?

None. I am deeply sceptical of prophets, fads and fanatics.

Who is your management hero?

Every woman who successfully juggles the demands of career and home life.

Who is your favourite politician?

Gordon Brown, for intellect, courage and substance over style.

How much were you paid last year?

Plenty, except in relation to my responsibility for turnover and profit.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

I overuse, "get to the point" and "give it a lash" in equal measure.

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Driving an open car on a sunny day, singing along to Counting Crows.

What annoys you most?

Life is too short - that stops me from exploring some interesting lifestyle options.

How do you relax?

Mainly by playing sport, travelling and listening to music.

What was your last cultural experience?

I was in the Tate last week - part hoping, part pretending, to understand.

What is your favourite city?

Madrid, where I spent three years, for its tradition, modernity, sophistication, fun and sun.

What is your greatest regret?

Not spending enough time with my children.

What is your biggest fear?

Running out of inspiring challenges.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

The shift in power and rewards from investors of capital to investors of life-time employees and managers.

A good singer-songwriter.

webTitle: How to buy wine in a cellar's market

fields.headline: How to buy wine in a cellar's market
fields.standfirst: If you want to progress from supermarket plonk to fine vintages, learning to store your collection is essential, says Eileen Sheridan
fields.trailText: If you want to progress from supermarket plonk to fine vintages, learning to store your collection is essential, says Eileen Sheridan.
fields.body:
The Queen does it and Andrew Lloyd Webber does it. Toffs have always done it, so why not the rest of us? We Brits like wine, we drink litres of the stuff, but we haven't got into the business of laying down our own cellars.

It may sound very grand, but anyone who spends a reasonable amount of money on wine ought to pay more attention to the way they treat the product of the noble grape. Slinging a few bottles into a rack next to your cooker is the British way, and it really doesn't do.

When wine writer Linda Johnson-Bell was a student in France she discovered kids of 20 putting down some decent wines; it was a national characteristic. And it is neither as difficult nor as expensive as you might think.

Johnson-Bell was so frustrated at the choice and cost of wine when she came to Britain three years ago that she decided to research the subject and then found the only way to inform herself was to write a book. Her Home Cellar Guide (Cassell £9.99) is a good place to start.

There are two basic aspects to laying down a cellar: choosing the right wines and storing them in the right way.

You don't absolutely need to have a cellar, just the equipment and knowledge to create the best possible conditions in your own home.

"Wine needs to be in a cool, dark, quiet place, free from vibration and strong smells," says Christopher Keiller who runs Fine Wine Services.

"Under the stairs is OK for a modest cellar. For valuable wines I would recommend a professional storage cabinet, hired storage or a proper cellar."

If your purse can stretch to it, there are specially constructed cabinets which mimic conditions in professional cellars. Eurocave has a range starting at £780 for a cabinet which holds 45 bottles and a best seller at £1,401 which holds 210 bottles.

Consort Wine Care Systems can boast that it installed its Chambrair wine conditioning door on the Queen's cellar at Windsor.

This arrangement is for those lucky few who have a cellar. The doors contain technology to control temperature, humidity and bacteria.

However, even if you do not have a cellar Consort can supply prefabricated wine cellars to fit into spare space in the home. For £800 plus VAT you can buy a store for 10 cubic metres or 15 cubic metres, which will hold 2,000 bottles, for £1,500 plus VAT.

So, once you have your cellar, or your space under the stairs, how do you fill it? Linda Johnson-Bell's formula is to find a good wine merchant who can be trusted and advise you, and, if necessary, store your wines for you as well.

If you have an idea of what you like then she reckons that you should buy a case for long term use once every six months at about £200, a case for medium term use every three months at £100 and a case for immediate use every month at £50.

"You're spending £1,400 or so a year and you are well on the way," she says."Don't wait too long to drink young wines and don't drink old ones too early. Buy wines you know and have tasted and buy wines that have a track record. It's far more satisfying to nurture a wine"

As the name of his business suggests, Christopher Keiller supplies good wines to private customers and offers a hand-holding service to newcomers. He recommends '97 and '98 Italian reds from Tuscany and Piedmont, '98 Chateauneuf du Pape, '97 Northern Rhone and '98 Australian reds as just some which have excelled in recent years and are worth putting away for the future.

"Having a cellar of personal favourites is the only way to ensure mature bottles will ever be available," he says.

Another way to learn about wines is to join a wine club. Johnson-Bell will have one up and running in a month's time in partnership with Robin Shuckburgh. Called The French Collection, it will cost £100 for membership, which will include a trip and night's stay at a chateau and wine to bring home, free from duty.

The Interesting Wine Club, which is London based, offers the chance to drink old wines at special tastings or exclusive dinners. The club costs a £10 introduction fee and £22 for single membership or £36 for a joint membership.

"You join up with people who know about wine," says the club's Michael Armitage. "It's absolutely essential to educate your palate. It's no good buying cheap plonk from the supermarket and hoping it will get better in time. It won't."

At the upper end of wine buying is the Bin Club based in a Victorian brewery near Bristol. This is for the real enthusiast and the wine investor. You pay a regular monthly subscription and what you buy is charged to your account plus storage charges.

"The lowest amount we would recommend is £500 a year," says the Bin Club's Rod Holt. "But the sky's the limit." He has members who might spend up to £10,000 a year.

"People who just want to start at the bottom and learn their way can buy from our spring and summer offers." He recommends buying two cases, one to drink now and one to lay down, possibly for sale at twice the price later if it's a good one.

The Bin Club is part of wine merchants Lay and Wheeler and has a sister company called Cellar Plan. It has a wine list containing ready-for- drinking suggestions and does discretionary buying once or twice a year.

For a bit of fun you can go the whole hog and rent your own row of vines in one of 33 vineyards operating a scheme with 3D Wines. "This is a wine club with a difference" says 3D's David Dickinson. "Everyone benefits.The winemaker has a positive cashflow and if you select the right winemaker he will make good wine every year."

Members pay £55 a year for their row of vines. Obviously you do not get wine made specifically from that row, but you do get the chance to buy exclusive wines at reasonable prices. Membership also offers trips to the vineyards and a bit of partying as well.

For further information:

3D Wines www.3dwines.com

Bin Club www.binclub.co.uk

Christopher Keiller Fine Wines www.gladys.demon.co.uk

Eurocave www.artofwine.co.uk/eurocave.htm

Consort Wine Cellars www.consortgroup.com

Interesting Wine Club katie@iwcl.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: The last word on   Delusion
fields.standfirst: Delusion is the child of ignorance - Bhagavadgita
fields.trailText: Delusion is the child of ignorance - Bhagavadgita
fields.body:
Last week a 500-strong group of Mayan Indians in Guatamala attacked a party of Japanese tourists and killed two of them. The tourists had stopped to photograph children wearing local, colourfully-embroidered dresses. The Mayans thought that the photographs were destined to appear in a catalogue used by child kidnappers. Some reports described the Mayans as suffering the delusion that tourists steal children, and appealed to the phenomenon of the "madness of crowds" to explain their lynch-mob behaviour.

Delusion is a vivid false belief, often felt by its victim to be threatening or exciting, and often associated with psychotic states. Normally sane people can suffer delusions when caught up in group hysteria, which explains crowd violence and mass witnessings of miracles. Demagogues like Hitler have always appreciated the advantage of bringing people together in large numbers, the better to influence and motivate them by non-rational means.

Delusion is not the same as illusion. In its primary meaning, illusion is misleading sensory experience, whose sources are physical rather than psychological. Entertainers who perform "magic tricks" are aptly called illusionists. But the word can be applied to beliefs or hopes, as when we speak of someone's illusions about his wife or his job, and in this usage it means a systematic misapprehension - a weaker and less sinister state than delusion, the product of mistake rather than pathology.

Leaving aside cases in which it is a concomitant of psychosis, and therefore the result of disturbed brain chemistry, delusion is rightly said by the Bhagavadgita to have ignorance as its mother. Her other offspring include superstition, prejudice and folly. "Ignorance is the womb of monsters," Henry Ward Beecher said.

There is a familiar tradition which elevates ignorance above knowledge, as a happier, more innocent state of being. The 18th century cult of the "noble savage" extolled the supposed freshness and serenity of a life unencumbered by knowledge, a life bounded only by the sky's visible horizon and the natural lifespan of man. "Where ignorance is bliss," Thomas Gray famously wrote in his lines on Eton College, "it is folly to be wise."

But the tradition is wrong. Ignorance is too fertile in wretchedness and tragedy, too ripe in error and falsehood, ever to stand comparison with knowledge. "Ignorance is not bliss," said Philip Wylie, "it is oblivion." It is the source of the great popular delusions of history - the Mississippi Scheme and the South Sea Bubble, the absurd belief in alchemy, witchcraft, astrology, ghosts and (as new additions) alien abductions and UFOs.

It is largely forgotten now that almost everyone in the 16th and 17th centuries in Europe believed that malevolent persons were busy poisoning food stores, water supplies, even the fish in the sea, using a colourless, odourless, undetectable substance called aqua tophana, which was said to do its fatal work with insensible slowness. An unpopular person had only to be labelled a poisoner to be lynched by a mob.

Was the Mayan attack a product of delusion? In remoter areas of Guatemala, lynch justice is a common resort - last year there were 71 recorded cases, carried out by local people banded together as vigilantes. And it is a fact that numbers of children - of all ages from infants to teenagers - are regularly kidnapped in Guatemala and southern Mexico, and never seen again. A healthy baby fetches more than $25,000 in illegal adoptions, while older children are sold as servants or prostitutes. The Mayans who attacked the tourists were not so much deluded as afraid and concerned. When people live in frontier conditions, without security, they feel vulnerable, and make their own laws for their own circumstances, sometimes on the spot - and administer them in self defence. That is what the Mayans did here.

It is lazy to attribute such tragedies to delusion. The real delusion is to think that people can live flourishingly without the mutual understanding, and therefore the safety, that comes from knowledge.

fields.headline: Stroke of genius
fields.standfirst: Steve McQueen won the Turner prize with a film of a house falling around his ears. His new work, Cold Breath, shows him fondling his nipple.  Adrian Searle reports
fields.trailText: Steve McQueen won the Turner prize with a film of a house falling around his ears. His new work, Cold Breath, shows him fondling his nipple. Adrian Searle reports
fields.body:
Around the corner from the new Tate, in Delfina Studios' new project space, Steve McQueen has just installed a new work, his first outing in London since winning last year's Turner prize. The Tate has a work on display too - McQueen's 1993 film installation Bear, featuring two naked wrestlers.

Over the past few years McQueen has astonished his audience with his manipulation of subtle images - the artist rolling an oil drum through New York, a wonky view of the sky above his head, a balloon taking off into the blue, and a wall collapsing around him. His new work, Cold Breath, is no less arresting and complex.

A light flashes on and off in a long, thin corridor. A TV faces out across the narrow space. It is a deceptive come-on, and I walk gingerly between the walls. There's an image on the screen. I walk past the television and take a turn, where more pulsating light leads me on into a large dark space. I turn. The same film is running, a big, cinematic image on the wall.

The first time I didn't quite believe it. It was, I imagined, a close-up, a detail of a bigger picture. But no. On the screen is McQueen's nipple, and the patch of goosebumped skin around it. Fingers and thumb hove into view, huge and purposeful. They pull at the nipple, yank and tweak it erect. The fingers go into a blurred frenzy, and it is clear that, at times, McQueen is more concerned with pleasuring himself than with staying in focus in front of the lens.

For long moments, the nipple remains alone. The bare chest looks like a lunar landscape, the nipple and its aureola an image from the dark side of the moon. Then he's at it again. I'm reminded of Billie Whitelaw's mouth, filling the screen in the TV production of Samuel Beckett's Not I. The speaking mouth, that wet, fleshy, involuted organ, eventually becomes something alien and alarmingly mobile. Now the hairless nipple looks like an eye. The nipple looks back, all-seeing, like the jailer's eye framed in the cell peephole in Jean Genet's great film Chant d'Amour.

Like Genet's still subversive film, McQueen's Cold Breath makes you wonder about your sexuality. It is as erotic as it is absurd. I mean, men's nipples? Why does no one discuss how erogenous they are?

McQueen compares his singular image to the eye-cutting scene from Bunuel and Dali's Surrealist film Un Chien Andalou. The Andalusian dog in question was the poet and playwright Federico Garcia Lorca, who studied with Bunuel and Dali in Madrid, and whose gayness troubled them both. The references keep on coming: to the eroticism in Joyce's Ulysses, to the film Robert Having His Nipple Pierced, featuring Robert Mapplethorpe. Overtly gay images, like Wolfgang Tillmans's photo of his late boyfriend masturbating and wearing a pair of heavy-duty nipple-clamps, also come to mind, if only because the erotic potential of the male breast has, unaccountably, been seen as a queer thing.

"Lots of people assumed I was gay," McQueen says about his early works, Bear and Five Easy Pieces. "I didn't mind," he smiles, but it raised the question of why sensual depictions of the male body are almost inexorably given a homoerotic spin. Don't straight men like having their nipples played with?

McQueen, talking about the strange hinterland between pleasure and pain occasioned by tweaking your nipples, points to the middle of his forehead, the third eye, and says, "The feeling's here, sharp, and one reason I wanted to work with the image of the nipple was that it is like an eye. I have a lazy eye, a squint that had to be surgically corrected, and there was something about the image of the single nipple_"

When McQueen fumbles for words, it is because he is trying to work out what only his work can tell you. He has great intellectual honesty, but doesn't take any shit. "My work is not a crossword puzzle. I get so pissed off when people ask me to explain it. I make these works to discover something, not to explain anything."

To me, Cold Breath is about the space between the lens and the body. It strikes me that its subject is that disembodied sensation of being behind the lens, making a film, and the narcissistic, subju gated and objectified feeling one has being in the camera's gaze. McQueen has dramatised the narcissistic moment. The viewer is also in the frame. It's easy to laugh at talk about desire and the gaze as though they were concepts to be kicked to death by Cultural Studies pedants, but they exist. McQueen never lets you forget it.

McQueen was working on Cold Breath before the Turner prize announcement. Like everyone else who's ever been nominated, he found that the experience resembled a horrible, numbing war. He now spends most of his time in Amsterdam, with his partner and child, out of the public eye. He's working on a film with author Zadie Smith and cult musician Tricky, who's living in New York and weaned off the cocktail of prescribed drugs he was taking to tamp down his asthma, but that drove him nearly bonkers. If what they end up with is half so strange, so complicated and so direct as Cold Breath, I can't wait.

 Cold Breath is at Delfina Project Space, 51 Southwark Street, London SE1 (020-7357 6600), till May 28.

McQueen, talking about the strange hinterland between pleasure and pain occasioned by tweaking your nipples, points to the middle of his forehead, the third eye, and says, "The feeling's here, sharp, and one reason I wanted to work with the image of the nipple was that it is like an eye. I have a lazy eye, a squint that had to be surgically corrected, and there was something about the image of the single nipple_" When McQueen fumbles for words, it is because he is trying to work out what only his work can tell you. He has great intellectual honesty, but doesn't take any shit. "My work is not a crossword puzzle. I get so pissed off when people ask me to explain it. I make these works to discover something, not to explain anything." To me, Cold Breath is about the space between the lens and the body. It strikes me that its subject is that disembodied sensation of being behind the lens, making a film, and the narcissistic, subju gated and objectified feeling one has being in the camera's gaze. McQueen has dramatised the narcissistic moment. The viewer is also in the frame. It's easy to laugh at talk about desire and the gaze as though they were concepts to be kicked to death by Cultural Studies pedants, but they exist. McQueen never lets you forget it. McQueen was working on Cold Breath before the Turner prize announcement. Like everyone else who's ever been nominated, he found that the experience resembled a horrible, numbing war. He now spends most of his time in Amsterdam, with his partner and child, out of the public eye. He's working on a film with author Zadie Smith and cult musician Tricky, who's living in New York and weaned off the cocktail of prescribed drugs he was taking to tamp down his asthma, but that drove him nearly bonkers. If what they end up with is half so strange, so complicated and so direct as Cold Breath, I can't wait.  Cold Breath is at Delfina Project Space, 51 Southwark Street, London SE1 (020-7357 6600), till May 28.

fields.headline: One-man show
fields.standfirst: Peter Maxwell Davies needs some support, says  Tom Service
fields.trailText: Peter Maxwell Davies needs some support, says Tom Service
fields.body:
There can be no doubting the elemental energy of Peter Maxwell Davies. As a composer, he becomes more prolific every year. He has also become the most important interpreter of his own music, a facet of his career that finds its current outlet in his association with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra. This week they together introduced Maxwell Davies's recent Mavis in Las Vegas to London and presented world premieres of his Horn Concerto and Roma, Amor, Labyrinthos.

Mavis in Las Vegas - whose title derives from a delicious slip of the tongue on Maxwell Davies's name by a Las Vegas hotel receptionist - is an attempt to ape the picturesque power of romantic tone-poems. The lonesome individuality of Mavis's solo violin theme is steadily engulfed by parodies of swing, Liberace's piano-playing, and rustling visions of the desert night.

The problem is that Maxwell Davies's invocation of Las Vegas's neon forest is at once overblown in its length and underpowered in its contained kitsch - more like the impressions of an English folk-song composer than a postcard from someone genuinely passionate about the place.

The Horn Concerto's incongruities stem from a completely opposite aesthetic. Here, Maxwell Davies affects the conventional pattern of fast-slow-fast, and a basically tonal trajectory of tension and release. Outwardly, the grand line of the first section has an easy flow, especially with a soloist of the finesse of Richard Watkins, and climaxes seem sonorous and well-constructed. It is just that the music's inner dynamic and momentum do not come across coherently.

Roma, Amor, Labyrinthos is a fusion of Maxwell Davies's referential and abstract styles, in which Rome's traffic, bells and monuments are integrated into a quasi- symphonic structure. In the second movement, a melancholy, plainchant-inspired texture is juxtaposed with disturbingly raucous folk music, before a final, beatific image of ancient choral music. There is a real compositional conviction behind this piece that outstrips the music of the rest of the programme.

Throughout, the RPO managed to keep themselves in line with Maxwell Davies's eccentric direction, but there were some moments of slipshod ensemble. This points up more general problems with the composer's self-promoting zeal. Maxwell Davies does not have famous champions to ensure his music's lasting place in the repertoire. Barenboim, Rattle and Boulez play Birtwistle on the world stage, creating an interpretative tradition that allows us to hear different sides to the same pieces. There is a danger that if Maxwell Davies continues to be virtually the sole performer of his recent orchestral music it will become increasingly difficult to prise apart the idea of Maxwell Davies the composer from Maxwell Davies the conductor. Unfortunately, the former is not always best served by the latter.

Future musicians may well feel stifled by the supposed authority of the composer's own performances. The interpretative tradition of his music may, in the future, amount to no more than a shelf of CDs. If that is not to happen, Maxwell Davies's music needs the illuminating light of other musical viewpoints. Only then will his latest orchestral pieces be heard to their full potential.

fields.headline: Nothing to be proud of
fields.trailText: Film and television awards ceremonies have long been lampooned for their celebrity gush and borrowed couture. But radio awards used to be different because a) there were so few of them and b) radio seemed like a small-scale, domestic and creative enterprise whose crafted excellence could do with celebration.
fields.body:
Film and television awards ceremonies have long been lampooned for their celebrity gush and borrowed couture. But radio awards used to be different because a) there were so few of them and b) radio seemed like a small-scale, domestic and creative enterprise whose crafted excellence could do with celebration.

All that has changed, as I was reminded at the tacky Sony awards bash in London on Tuesday. Greg Dyke's appointment notwithstanding, BBC Radio's best producers must now make do with prizes for their programmes instead of money to make them - and it shows. Meanwhile, commercial radio, much of which is owned by a trio of large groups, is so formatted that innovation is a foreign word.

Sony's prize-givers included a stream of C-list female celebrities whose connection to radio was dubious and whose most articulate feature was their cleavage. (Oh, and let's not forget rent-a-heckle Tracey Emin, extolling radio for the short-sighted.) This may guarantee the sponsor tabloid spreads the next day, but it seems a long time since the Sonys played tantalising extracts from winning programmes. No, Sony night is now unequivocally junket night.

Paul Gambaccini, one of the hosts, demonstrated his ability to get it wrong by claiming that the awards unite the industry. While broadcasters and producers move freely between commercial and BBC radio, there is a chasm between the two sectors in output and Sony awards. Each year the categories are changed to enable commercial radio to win more prizes. And each year they fail. This year was no exception, with only seven of the 24 awards going to commercial stations.

Where once there were drama awards for best adaptation, best production and best male and female performances, as well as best original script, there is now just one. Not only do the organisers reject the idea of restoring a drama category; they also promise to continue changing the goalposts to help the commercial sector win more prizes, lest it secede from the Sonys and build up the KPMG awards (currently for best jingle, promotion, etc) as a rival.

Of course there were incidental pleasures on Tuesday, like watching Malcolm McLaren bored at one table and Greg Dyke politely inscrutable at another. The splendid Gilles Peterson won the specialist music award for Worldwide, his Radio 1 programme. But how could Radio 3's terrific Late Junction, a critical and ratings success, not have made the shortlist ?

It was good to see local radio take on the big boys, with Radio Merseyside's Roger Phillips winning the broadcaster award against competition from John Humphrys and Andrew Neil, and Northern Ireland's Radio Foyle, in contention with Radios 4 and 5 Live, walking off with the breakfast news award. Malcolm McLaren looked even more bored.

Most remarkably, the Sonys failed to acknowledge Roger Wright's confident new Radio 3, giving the station of the year award instead to the glib Classic FM. McLaren looked as if he had lost the will to live, and who could blame him?

I propose that the Sonys come clean by introducing new categories, like station that attracts the greatest advertising spend. In the meantime, as one prominent industry figure forlornly said, "I don't know what they're trying to celebrate any longer."

fields.headline: After the revolution
fields.standfirst: Tracy Chapman's voice can still give  Elisabeth Mahoney goosebumps. She can't say the same for the new songs
fields.trailText: Tracy Chapman's voice can still give Elisabeth Mahoney goosebumps. She can't say the same for the new songs
fields.body:
Though still a young woman, with an audience large and loyal enough to sell out venues, Tracy Chapman is a sharp blast from the past. There was a time (1988, the year her eponymous album was released) when the personal was political, not cloying and self-indulgent; when songs about domestic violence, revolution and self-fulfilment could get radio airplay; when women wanted to hear songs about escape and independence. Back then, Chapman, a gifted songwriter with an unforgettable voice and message, was all the rage. Now, it is Macy Gray, Sex and the City, and ironic post-laddist babedom that rule. Where does Chapman sit in this not very brave new world?

During her show at the Edinburgh Playhouse, she sits squarely in that respect-is-due-but-what's-the-new-material-like realm where nostalgia is never quite enough to fill an evening. When it does hit, on stirring versions of Fast Car, Baby Can I Hold You and Across the Lines, her quavering yet soulful voice raises goosebumps. But songs from the new Telling Stories album never grab us in the same way. They are more personal (there are lots of love songs), and Chapman's calm minimalism is these days a blues-tinged, rocked-up sound. She is backed by a band of four guys. During the less gripping numbers you might notice how diverse their hairstyles are.

Diverse is not a term you can use to describe Chapman's stage presence. She doesn't do chat, she doesn't say the empowering things you think she might. A routine forms: the song ends, she changes guitars, she talks to the band, maybe about their hair. Then she's back, charming us with an oldie or offering us the fuzzy sentimentalism of the new material. She ends with a cover of Get Up, Stand Up, and she seems to mean it when she sings, "Don't give up the fight." Her music hasn't entirely - a brave thing when the world has changed in the meantime - but the performance verges on the tame, more status quo than the world turned upside down.

 Tracy Chapman plays the Opera House, Manchester (0161-242 2509), tonight, and the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), tomorrow.

webTitle: The long shadow of the Falcon

fields.headline: The long shadow of the Falcon
fields.standfirst: Dashiell Hammett's creation Sam Spade is father to every gumshoe that ever walked down a mean street, says crime-writer  Sara Paretsky
fields.trailText: Dashiell Hammett's creation Sam Spade is father to every gumshoe that ever walked down a mean street, says crime-writer Sara Paretsky
fields.body:
'After reading The Maltese Falcon, I went mooning about in a daze of love such as I had not known for any character in literature since I encountered Sir Launcelot," Dorothy Parker wrote in the New Yorker in 1931, adding that she had read the book 30 or 40 times in the two years after its publication.

The cynical journalist wasn't the only woman felled by Spade, or his creator: dozens went to bed with Dashiell Hammett when he moved from San Francisco to Los Angeles to join the throng trying to make money in Hollywood. Lillian Hellman even left her husband in Los Angeles to follow Hammett to New York in 1931.

Sam Spade made Hammett famous and, for a short time, rich. The man who had been unable to feed his family a few years before started getting $2,000 a week from Paramount to come up with original story lines. Hammett threw the money away on his idea of the high life: lavish parties that cost as much as $10,000; long weekends of drinking with starlets and writers in California; and some of it on settling a claim of forcible rape by a young actress.

Everyone who reads Hammett seems to read their own needs into his work: where Dorothy Parker found Sir Launcelot, Senator Joe McCarthy and the House Un-American Activities Committee saw communism. Hammett spent six months in a federal prison in 1951 when he refused to testify to Congress about the Civil Rights Congress, an organisation on whose board he sat which provided bail to communists.

A few years after leaving prison, Hammett was back in front of Congress, this time before McCarthy's committee. The senator believed Hammett could only have named his first novel Red Harvest because he was a red himself. (While it's true that, in the 30s and 40s, Hammett openly supported the Communist party, publisher Blanche Knopf actually named Red Harvest, as she thought Hammett's original title, Poisonville, would put readers off.) McCarthy even went so far as to remove copies of Hammett's novels from all American embassies so that State Department employees wouldn't be exposed to his communist writings. When Hammett died in 1961, a veteran of the first and second world wars as well as the McCarthy era blacklist, the FBI tried to stop his burial in Arlington.

Other readers have seen equally unusual landscapes in Hammett's work. One recent critic says The Maltese Falcon is an elaborate allegory about American foreign policy in the decade following the first world war, with the seductive sexuality of Brigid O'Shaughnessy representing the European seductions that drew America into the war, and the death of Spade's partner representing the useless deaths that war brings in its wake. Modernist critics claim Hammett was making a serious critique of the automobile; neo-Marxists share Senator McCarthy's view that the work was thoroughly red, albeit with admiration.

Hammett seemed to see his own face when he looked at Sam Spade. Aside from the fact that his own first name was Samuel (his mother called him by his middle name, Dashiell, to distinguish him from three other Samuels in the family) Hammett, too, had been a Pinkerton detective. In 1907, when he was 13, Hammett had to leave school to help support his family, but until he joined Pinkertons in 1915, he didn't stay at any job for more than a few months.

When America entered the war, he joined the army as an ambulance driver, and in 1918, he contracted the flu in the terrible epidemic sweeping through army camps. His lungs were damaged so severely that for years he often didn't have the strength to get out of bed. He lived on a meagre disability check; his post-war Pinkerton stint only totalled four or five months, when he moved to the San Francisco area in search of a cure for his tubercular lungs.

Although he exaggerated his role, and even his presence, in some of the agency's high-profile cases, he did have a first-hand knowledge of crime and criminals that other noir writers didn't possess. In a 1934 introduction to The Maltese Falcon, Hammett wrote: "Spade had no original... he is what most of the private detectives I worked with would like to have been and what quite a few in their cockier moments thought they approached. For your private detective does not want to be an erudite solver of riddles in the Sherlock Holmes manner; he wants to be a hard and shifty fellow, able to take care of himself in any situation, able to get the best of anybody he comes in contact with, whether criminal, innocent by-stander or client."

Somehow, in putting his private fantasy of himself on to paper, Hammett created a landscape into which each reader, from Dorothy Parker to Joe McCarthy and beyond, could project their own image. So I feel my own idiosyncratic reading of The Maltese Falcon fits into a tradition of highly personal reactions to the novel. When I read it, I see neither communists nor automobiles, but a world of dangerous female sexuality which Hammett found so terrifying that he needed to destroy it.

There are three major women in the book: Iva Archer, a 30-something blonde of ripe sexual charms, married to Sam's partner Miles but having an affair with Sam; Effie Perine, who is Sam's secretary; and Brigid O'Shaughnessy, the client who sets the wheels of the story in motion. Effie, a boyish and guileless young woman, opens the story by ushering in Brigid, who is soft, stylish and appears touchingly shy and vulnerable. Effie knows Sam will want to see Brigid, because "she's a knockout". From the start, then, we know that Sam is a sexual being, and it becomes clear pretty soon that Brigid is as well.

Brigid gives Sam an assumed name and an assumed story about a sister involved with a dangerous gangster. From that moment on we're involved in a deception of her making, which only Sam can see through and cut through. She kills his partner, gets Sam to do her dirty work in looking for the Falcon, so that she can double-cross her accomplices and then, at the end, tries to seduce Sam, so that she can get off the hook. Sam "sends her over" anyway, but only after an emotional struggle which causes the sweat to pour down his face.

Brigid O'Shaughnessy is part of a traditional way of describing women in western culture, starting with Eve, who ruins paradise for Adam, and moving on to such contemporary characters as Alex Forrest in the movie Fatal Attraction. O'Shaughnessy is the first significant modern temptress, the first to appear after the first world war when women could vote, cut off their hair, cast off the 12 pounds of heavy clothes they wore in Victorian times and move freely in society. Like Eve, O'Shaughnessy uses her body to try to make the hero do bad things, but unlike Adam, Sam is too strong for the temptress.

As a foil to O'Shaughnessy is Sam's secretary, Effie Perine. Sam never calls her Effie, though: she is sweetheart, darling, sister, and, especially angel. And Effie is an angel. In contrast to Brigid's sultry sensuality, Effie's "eyes were brown and playful in a shiny boyish face". The fact that she is boyish in her looks means that she is not a sexual, and therefore predatory, female. Sam can trust her, but her boyishness also makes her naive. She believes in Brigid: she tells Sam that, despite the two phoney identities the client has used: "I'm for her. I don't care if she has all the names in the phone book. That girl is all right and you know it."

At the end of the book, she cannot accept the fact that Sam sent Brigid over. Women work on intuition, as Sam tells her off and on throughout the novel, but a man has to deal in justice.

"So much for your woman's intuition,"[Sam said]... [Effie's] voice was queer as the expression on her face. "You did that, Sam, to her?" He nodded. "Your Sam's a detective." He looked sharply at her. He put his arm around her waist, his hand on her hip."She did kill Miles, angel," he said gently, "offhand, like that." He snapped the fingers of his other hand. She escaped from his arm as if it had hurt her. "Don't, please, don't touch me," she said brokenly. "I know - I know you're right. You're right. But don't touch me now - not now."

Still, Hammett recognises that Sam is not an innocent himself: he's been sleeping with Iva Archer, who is a blowsier, less sophisticated sexual animal than Brigid O'Shaughnessy. Right after the scene with Effie, Iva arrives. Effie returns to Sam's office to tell him that Iva is waiting.

Spade, looking down at his desk, nodded almost imperceptibly. "Yes," he said, and shivered. "Well, send her in."

The novel ends on this sombre note, with Sam Spade having to face the disagreeable consequences of his actions.

When Hammett sent Blanche Knopf The Maltese Falcon, both she and Harry Block, the editor assigned to Hammett's work, wanted him to tone down the novel's sexuality. They feared that not only the sex scenes between Spade and Brigid, but also the overt homosexual references to the life of Falcon-hunter Joel Cairo would offend readers. Hammett insisted that those passages remain; indeed, they help give the story its essential character.

The Maltese Falcon is an intensely physical novel, and not solely, or even chiefly, because of its sexuality. In contrast to some of Hammett's earlier work, especially Red Harvest, there's not a lot of violent action. In The Maltese Falcon, there are a couple of onstage murders, one scene where Sam is drugged and kicked in the head, and a fight between O'Shaughnessy and Cairo, but none of these scenes has the kind of graphic, numbing violence of Red Harvest. The Maltese Falcon's physicality lies rather in the intensity of the characters' struggles with their emotions, and the vividness with which Hammett brings their personalities to the page through their bodies.

The book opens with a description of Spade's long bony jaw, his yellow-grey eyes, his V-shaped nostrils. In every encounter that Sam has, whether with Brigid or "the fat man", another Falcon-hunter, or the police, we see his body acting and reacting: his eyes hold "an almost exaggerated amount of candour" when talking to the police, then they become "dull, almost dead". When the lieutenant hits him "his thick sloping shoulders" writhe under his coat. The effort not to hit back puts deep creases between his brows:

His nostrils moved in and out with his breathing _Red rage came suddenly into his face and he began to talk in a harsh guttural voice. Holding his maddened face in his hands, glaring at the floor, he cursed Dundy for five minutes without break...

The final scene with Brigid goes on for pages as Sam's eyes become bloodshot, his voice turns to a croak, and sweat pours from his body with the intensity of his struggle. Again and again Brigid tries to persuade him of her love for him, his for her, and why he should let her go; finally:

Spade pulled his hand out of hers. He no longer either smiled or grimaced. His wet yellow face was set hard and deeply lined. His eyes burned madly. He said, "Listen. This isn't a damned bit of good. You'll never understand me, but I'll try once more and then we'll give it up."

Of course, Brigid can't understand, partly because she's the murderer, and partly because, unlike Sam who is both body and mind, she exists only in the body. When the cops show up a few minutes later to arrest her, he pushes her forward into their arms, then discusses Falcon-seekers "the fat man" Caspar Gutman, and Joel Cairo for some minutes without any further mention of the woman. There's no description of her as she leaves, no word of Sam looking at her or thinking about her.

Whether Spade and Brigid represent Hammett's own views of men and women is a question for psychological biographers to grapple with. When he became famous, he did leave his wife Jose, to whom he dedicated The Maltese Falcon, and their two daughters with no more of a backward glance than Spade gives Brigid. In fact, after 1940, he didn't see his daughters for over a decade. While he left each daughter a share in his estate, he didn't help support them during their growing up.

Hammett's own problematic relations with women included the uncontested rape charge brought by the actress Elise de Vianne, but as it was a civil charge, Hammett paid damages without undergoing criminal prosecution. While Hammett and Lillian Hellman had a relationship that lasted until his death, it was interrupted not just by the second world war, but by Hammett's financial and alcohol problems. Hammett and Hellman were estranged for five or six years after the war. He did begin working with Hellman on some of her own writing in the early 50s, but they never lived together again. Perhaps, as he had described Spade, he was that "hard and shifty fellow, able to get the best of anybody he comes in contact with".

Hammett's work influenced every crime writer who came after him, from Raymond Chandler on. Even Chandler's famous essay, The Simple Art of Murder, the one that explains that Hammett took murder out of the drawing room and put it back in the alleys where it belonged, and includes the celebrated phrase, "Down these mean streets a man must go who is not himself afraid, who is neither tarnished nor afraid," derives from book reviews Hammett wrote in the 20s, and the Continental Op stories.

When he created the Continental Op, the detective about whom he wrote 26 short stories and four novellas, as well as Red Harvest, Hammett was trying to do two things. The first, frankly, was to make a living, and to do so in a way that would show his relatives back in Baltimore that he had amounted to something. He had two small daughters and a wife, and was too ill to work, but he took a vocational training course in typing and writing and began to do both ad copy and short stories. He sold his first fiction to a poorly-paying magazine run by HL Mencken, another Baltimore man, chiefly so that his family back east would see that he had become a literary figure.

Hammett was a self-taught writer who was able to analyse his own shortcomings, as well as to respond to criticism from magazine editors. fields.bodyText: 'After reading The Maltese Falcon, I went mooning about in a daze of love such as I had not known for any character in literature since I encountered Sir Launcelot," Dorothy Parker wrote in the New Yorker in 1931, adding that she had read the book 30 or 40 times in the two years after its publication. The cynical journalist wasn't the only woman felled by Spade, or his creator: dozens went to bed with Dashiell Hammett when he moved from San Francisco to Los Angeles to join the throng trying to make money in Hollywood. Lillian Hellman even left her husband in Los Angeles to follow Hammett to New York in 1931. Sam Spade made Hammett famous and, for a short time, rich. The man who had been unable to feed his family a few years before started getting $2,000 a week from Paramount to come up with original story lines. Hammett threw the money away on his idea of the high life: lavish parties that cost as much as $10,000; long weekends of drinking with starlets and writers in California; and some of it on settling a claim of forcible rape by a young actress. Everyone who reads Hammett seems to read their own needs into his work: where Dorothy Parker found Sir Launcelot, Senator Joe McCarthy and the House Un-American Activities Committee saw communism. Hammett spent six months in a federal prison in 1951 when he refused to testify to Congress about the Civil Rights Congress, an organisation on whose board he sat which provided bail to communists. A few years after leaving prison, Hammett was back in front of Congress, this time before McCarthy's committee. The senator believed Hammett could only have named his first novel Red Harvest because he was a red himself. (While it's true that, in the 30s and 40s, Hammett openly supported the Communist party, publisher Blanche Knopf actually named Red Harvest, as she thought Hammett's original title, Poisonville, would put readers off.) McCarthy even went so far as to remove copies of Hammett's novels from all American embassies so that State Department employees wouldn't be exposed to his communist writings. When Hammett died in 1961, a veteran of the first and second world wars as well as the McCarthy era blacklist, the FBI tried to stop his burial in Arlington. Other readers have seen equally unusual landscapes in Hammett's work. One recent critic says The Maltese Falcon is an elaborate allegory about American foreign policy in the decade following the first world war, with the seductive sexuality of Brigid O'Shaughnessy representing the European seductions that drew America into the war, and the death of Spade's partner representing the useless deaths that war brings in its wake. Modernist critics claim Hammett was making a serious critique of the automobile; neo-Marxists share Senator McCarthy's view that the work was thoroughly red, albeit with admiration. Hammett seemed to see his own face when he looked at Sam Spade. Aside from the fact that his own first name was Samuel (his mother called him by his middle name, Dashiell, to distinguish him from three other Samuels in the family) Hammett, too, had been a Pinkerton detective. In 1907, when he was 13, Hammett had to leave school to help support his family, but until he joined Pinkertons in 1915, he didn't stay at any job for more than a few months. When America entered the war, he joined the army as an ambulance driver, and in 1918, he contracted the flu in the terrible epidemic sweeping through army camps. His lungs were damaged so severely that for years he often didn't have the strength to get out of bed. He lived on a meagre disability check; his post-war Pinkerton stint only totalled four or five months, when he moved to the San Francisco area in search of a cure for his tubercular lungs. Although he exaggerated his role, and even his presence, in some of the agency's high-profile cases, he did have a first-hand knowledge of crime and criminals that other noir writers didn't possess. In a 1934 introduction to The Maltese Falcon, Hammett wrote: "Spade had no original... he is what most of the private detectives I worked with would like to have been and what quite a few in their cockier moments thought they approached. For your private detective does not want to be an erudite solver of riddles in the Sherlock Holmes manner; he wants to be a hard and shifty fellow, able to take care of himself in any situation, able to get the best of anybody he comes in contact with, whether criminal, innocent by-stander or client." Somehow, in putting his private fantasy of himself on to paper, Hammett created a landscape into which each reader, from Dorothy Parker to Joe McCarthy and beyond, could project their own image. So I feel my own idiosyncratic reading of The Maltese Falcon fits into a tradition of highly personal reactions to the novel. When I read it, I see neither communists nor automobiles, but a world of dangerous female sexuality which Hammett found so terrifying that he needed to destroy it. There are three major women in the book: Iva Archer, a 30-something blonde of ripe sexual charms, married to Sam's partner Miles but having an affair with Sam; Effie Perine, who is Sam's secretary; and Brigid O'Shaughnessy, the client who sets the wheels of the story in motion. Effie, a boyish and guileless young woman, opens the story by ushering in Brigid, who is soft, stylish and appears touchingly shy and vulnerable. Effie knows Sam will want to see Brigid, because "she's a knockout". From the start, then, we know that Sam is a sexual being, and it becomes clear pretty soon that Brigid is as well. Brigid gives Sam an assumed name and an assumed story about a sister involved with a dangerous gangster. From that moment on we're involved in a deception of her making, which only Sam can see through and cut through. She kills his partner, gets Sam to do her dirty work in looking for the Falcon, so that she can double-cross her accomplices and then, at the end, tries to seduce Sam, so that she can get off the hook. Sam "sends her over" anyway, but only after an emotional struggle which causes the sweat to pour down his face. Brigid O'Shaughnessy is part of a traditional way of describing women in western culture, starting with Eve, who ruins paradise for Adam, and moving on to such contemporary characters as Alex Forrest in the movie Fatal Attraction. O'Shaughnessy is the first significant modern temptress, the first to appear after the first world war when women could vote, cut off their hair, cast off the 12 pounds of heavy clothes they wore in Victorian times and move freely in society. Like Eve, O'Shaughnessy uses her body to try to make the hero do bad things, but unlike Adam, Sam is too strong for the temptress. As a foil to O'Shaughnessy is Sam's secretary, Effie Perine. Sam never calls her Effie, though: she is sweetheart, darling, sister, and, especially angel. And Effie is an angel. In contrast to Brigid's sultry sensuality, Effie's "eyes were brown and playful in a shiny boyish face". The fact that she is boyish in her looks means that she is not a sexual, and therefore predatory, female. Sam can trust her, but her boyishness also makes her naive. She believes in Brigid: she tells Sam that, despite the two phoney identities the client has used: "I'm for her. I don't care if she has all the names in the phone book. That girl is all right and you know it." At the end of the book, she cannot accept the fact that Sam sent Brigid over. Women work on intuition, as Sam tells her off and on throughout the novel, but a man has to deal in justice. "So much for your woman's intuition,"[Sam said]... [Effie's] voice was queer as the expression on her face. "You did that, Sam, to her?" He nodded. "Your Sam's a detective." He looked sharply at her. He put his arm around her waist, his hand on her hip."She did kill Miles, angel," he said gently, "offhand, like that." He snapped the fingers of his other hand. She escaped from his arm as if it had hurt her. "Don't, please, don't touch me," she said brokenly. "I know - I know you're right. You're right. But don't touch me now - not now." Still, Hammett recognises that Sam is not an innocent himself: he's been sleeping with Iva Archer, who is a blowsier, less sophisticated sexual animal than Brigid O'Shaughnessy. Right after the scene with Effie, Iva arrives. Effie returns to Sam's office to tell him that Iva is waiting. Spade, looking down at his desk, nodded almost imperceptibly. "Yes," he said, and shivered. "Well, send her in." The novel ends on this sombre note, with Sam Spade having to face the disagreeable consequences of his actions. When Hammett sent Blanche Knopf The Maltese Falcon, both she and Harry Block, the editor assigned to Hammett's work, wanted him to tone down the novel's sexuality. They feared that not only the sex scenes between Spade and Brigid, but also the overt homosexual references to the life of Falcon-hunter Joel Cairo would offend readers. Hammett insisted that those passages remain; indeed, they help give the story its essential character. The Maltese Falcon is an intensely physical novel, and not solely, or even chiefly, because of its sexuality. In contrast to some of Hammett's earlier work, especially Red Harvest, there's not a lot of violent action. In The Maltese Falcon, there are a couple of onstage murders, one scene where Sam is drugged and kicked in the head, and a fight between O'Shaughnessy and Cairo, but none of these scenes has the kind of graphic, numbing violence of Red Harvest. The Maltese Falcon's physicality lies rather in the intensity of the characters' struggles with their emotions, and the vividness with which Hammett brings their personalities to the page through their bodies. The book opens with a description of Spade's long bony jaw, his yellow-grey eyes, his V-shaped nostrils. In every encounter that Sam has, whether with Brigid or "the fat man", another Falcon-hunter, or the police, we see his body acting and reacting: his eyes hold "an almost exaggerated amount of candour" when talking to the police, then they become "dull, almost dead". When the lieutenant hits him "his thick sloping shoulders" writhe under his coat. The effort not to hit back puts deep creases between his brows: His nostrils moved in and out with his breathing _Red rage came suddenly into his face and he began to talk in a harsh guttural voice. Holding his maddened face in his hands, glaring at the floor, he cursed Dundy for five minutes without break... The final scene with Brigid goes on for pages as Sam's eyes become bloodshot, his voice turns to a croak, and sweat pours from his body with the intensity of his struggle. Again and again Brigid tries to persuade him of her love for him, his for her, and why he should let her go; finally: Spade pulled his hand out of hers. He no longer either smiled or grimaced. His wet yellow face was set hard and deeply lined. His eyes burned madly. He said, "Listen. This isn't a damned bit of good. You'll never understand me, but I'll try once more and then we'll give it up." Of course, Brigid can't understand, partly because she's the murderer, and partly because, unlike Sam who is both body and mind, she exists only in the body. When the cops show up a few minutes later to arrest her, he pushes her forward into their arms, then discusses Falcon-seekers "the fat man" Caspar Gutman, and Joel Cairo for some minutes without any further mention of the woman. There's no description of her as she leaves, no word of Sam looking at her or thinking about her. Whether Spade and Brigid represent Hammett's own views of men and women is a question for psychological biographers to grapple with. When he became famous, he did leave his wife Jose, to whom he dedicated The Maltese Falcon, and their two daughters with no more of a backward glance than Spade gives Brigid. In fact, after 1940, he didn't see his daughters for over a decade. While he left each daughter a share in his estate, he didn't help support them during their growing up. Hammett's own problematic relations with women included the uncontested rape charge brought by the actress Elise de Vianne, but as it was a civil charge, Hammett paid damages without undergoing criminal prosecution. While Hammett and Lillian Hellman had a relationship that lasted until his death, it was interrupted not just by the second world war, but by Hammett's financial and alcohol problems. Hammett and Hellman were estranged for five or six years after the war. He did begin working with Hellman on some of her own writing in the early 50s, but they never lived together again. Perhaps, as he had described Spade, he was that "hard and shifty fellow, able to get the best of anybody he comes in contact with". Hammett's work influenced every crime writer who came after him, from Raymond Chandler on. Even Chandler's famous essay, The Simple Art of Murder, the one that explains that Hammett took murder out of the drawing room and put it back in the alleys where it belonged, and includes the celebrated phrase, "Down these mean streets a man must go who is not himself afraid, who is neither tarnished nor afraid," derives from book reviews Hammett wrote in the 20s, and the Continental Op stories. When he created the Continental Op, the detective about whom he wrote 26 short stories and four novellas, as well as Red Harvest, Hammett was trying to do two things. The first, frankly, was to make a living, and to do so in a way that would show his relatives back in Baltimore that he had amounted to something.
