webTitle: Give us this day our daily miracle

fields.headline: Give us this day our daily miracle
fields.standfirst: Today in Naples the people will wait anxiously to see if the dried blood of a long-dead saint turns back into liquid. It usually does.  Rory Carroll  on the enduring need for the supernatural
fields.trailText: Today in Naples the people will wait anxiously to see if the dried blood of a long-dead saint turns back into liquid. It usually does. Rory Carroll on the enduring need for the supernatural
fields.body:
A hush will descend over the aisles today as the phial is held up above the altar of Santa Chiara cathedral. The blood of a saint beheaded in AD305 will almost certainly liquefy. And Naples will have its annual miracle. Shouts and cheers will break out in the cathedral and spread across the waiting city, because if the blood does not liquefy, disaster will strike: an earthquake or an eruption from Mount Vesuvius.

San Gennaro was martyred at Pozzuoli, just outside Naples, under the purges of Diocletian. Christians preserved his blood in a phial and made him the city's patron saint. The phial, trimmed with gold, is kept in a chapel beside the cathedral. Twice a year, it is carried in procession to the altar. Armed police, television crews and thousands of Neapolitans pack inside. There is a Mass, the phial is held aloft, cries of "Viva San Gennaro!" resound, then it is lowered and the cardinal peers at what minutes before was solid powder.

There is no reason why it should liquefy. But it does. For 600 years it has done so, every first Saturday in May and on September 19, the saint's feast day. The phial will be shaken by the cardinal archbishop Michele Giordano, whom local magistrates have demanded be sent for trial on charges of loansharking and misappropriating church funds. The congregation will queue for a week to kiss the relic. Occasionally the blood has remained solid. It did in 1944; Mount Vesuvius erupted. It did in 1980; there was an earthquake.

The hunger for miracles, those inexplicable occurrences that seem to defy the laws of nature and bear witness to an omnipotent force - spreads far beyond Italy. An ugly village in France attracts more visitors than Egypt because of six crutches hanging on a rusty wire, symbol of a miracle cure for those who join the pilgrimage to Lourdes. And 7m people a year trek to the remote Italian village of San Giovanni Rotondo to visit the grave of Padre Pio, a priest who apparently received the stigmata, cured the sick and was in two places at once.

Church attendances are plummeting but the sites of Christian pilgrimage are booming. Time magazine's poll says 69% of Americans believe in miracles. Charismatic and Pentecostal congregations, where worship revolves around signs and wonders, have swollen in Britain. Pope John Paul II scours the Catholic world for miracles he can attribute to the scores of people he wants to beatify (at least two miracles are needed for sainthood). Next Saturday, at Portugal's Fatima shrine, he will beatify two children whose visions of the Virgin Mary in 1917 he credits with saving his life when he was shot in 1981, on the anniversary of the first apparition.

Two thousand years after a Galileean carpenter is said to have walked on water and risen from the dead, despite the growth of scientific knowledge and our understanding of the natural world, many Christians still believe in supernatural occurrences. The Catholic Church is adamant that miracles are not superstition, they are facts produced by the intervention of God that transcend the normal order of things.

For David Hume, the enlightenment philosopher, miracles were violations of natural laws by supernatural agents. In the 1890s, Emile Zola reckoned they represented boredom and hunger for illusion. "I don't believe in miracles but I do believe in the human need to believe in miracles."

It's a continuing need. A weeping Madonna statue in Rincon, Puerto Rico, transforms villagers' lives. A retired postmistress and her daughter in Wicklow, Ireland, host thousands of visitors after their Madonna weeps blood and radiates peace. A priest in Virginia, US, causes statues to cry and has stigmata on his wrists and feet. Franciscan nuns in Benin reel when their convent statue weeps;100 people in Britain receive golden fillings while praying; a Mexican chef sees Jesus in a tortilla.

On an overcast morning, a coach pulls up at the entrance to San Augostino, a secluded church in Civitavecchia, a depressed port 50 miles north of Rome. Elderly and middle-aged pilgrims clamber out and bless themselves. They are here for a miracle. Greeting them is a life-sized replica of the parish's weeping Madonna, the most famous in Italy. Four stalls, with church permission, sell books and trinkets: keyrings, figurines blotched with red paint around the eyes, Padre Pio cigarette lighters.

"Before all this started I sold bags and hats," said Vittorio Sorbo. Does he believe in the miracle? He looks hurt. "Of course. If I didn't I wouldn't be allowed to have a stall here." Civitavecchia's miracle is 14 inches high and was bought for £6 from a stall in Bosnia six years ago by the parish priest, Don Pablo, and given as a present to an electrician, Fabio Gregori, who put it in his garden.

On February 2, 1995, Fabio's daughter Jessica, 5, saw two tears of blood roll down the statue's face. She called her father, who called Don Pablo, who called Bishop Girolamo Grillo, who called it a miracle. "It wept in my hands," he said. Before more than 50 witnesses, including communist unbelievers, it cried 14 times over 40 days. The blood was examined at a Rome laboratory and found to be male. "Christ's, it must be Christ's," said the bishop.

The statue was placed behind bullet-proof glass in an alcove inside the church. The blood is faded and invisible now, but photographs on the walls show how it was. Those who visit are said to leave converted, healed, or inspired. "Thousands and thousands come," smiled Don Pablo, watching the latest arrivals. Among them is Clara Ancheta, 63, who has cancer. "I've come to pray for my operations." Forty minutes later she emerges, supported by her husband, smiling. "The Madonna is beautiful. She has given me hope. I feel stronger."

Luigi Garlaschelli, a chemist at the University of Pavia, says the statue is a crude fraud. A member of the Italian Committee for Investigation of the Paranormal (Cicap), he has come across many different fakes: statues filled with a red liquid, and covered in glaze which can be slit with a fingernail; statues containing a pump, operated by remote control; statues coated with an acetone liquid activated when exposed to ammonia.

Civitavecchia's statue is solid plaster, and the stains are real blood, but there is a simple explanation, he says. Someone pricked a finger and smeared their own blood. Photographs of the stains taken at the beginning and end of the 14 weepings are identical. "An initial trick, followed by mass self-delusion, seems very likely."

A professional illusionist, Alfredo Barrago, sneaked into the church gallery and aimed a red laser beam at the statue's eyes, creating the appearance of weeping. A worshipper fainted and Barrago claimed vindication. "It's nonsense," he said. DNA tests showed the blood to be of a Mediterranean male with anaemia. The male members of the Gregori family agreed to be DNA tested, then reneged, saying they would do so only if asked by Bishop Grillo, who declined. By law they cannot be compelled.

Fabio Gregori's voice quavers when he answers the phone. No, he will not meet me, too many lies are being said about him and what really happened in his garden. "This is causing me much suffering, I cannot endure it."

Business is slackening, but the Civitavecchia statue remains the most popular of Italy's weeping Madonnas. The newspaper Corriere della Sera noted that maybe a depressed port with high unemployment thought there was no other way to make money.

Garlaschelli's analyses of more than 70 "miracles" have been published in scientific journals and in an imminent book, Investigators of the Occult. He has been accused of plotting to destroy faith. But a more measured official reaction comes from the Church. "It is very, very cautious," he says. Since 1830, the Vatican has approved a mere 15 apparitions of the Virgin Mary and just one weeping Madonna, in Sicily in 1954. It has yet to rule on Civitavecchia. Past experience suggests Bishop Grillo will be in his grave before the outcome is known. In 1974, the Vatican issued new guidelines distinguishing between the miraculous - physical acts without natural causes - and the supernatural, which is in the eye of the beholder.

Miracles are a theological quagmire. "Why does this generation ask for a sign?" asked Jesus, angry at the requests. He recognised that flashes of divine intervention bolstered faith, but that they dispelled all doubt about God's existence. Then there would be no need for faith. "Yet if we don't have miracles then what is the point in praying? That would be a God on permanent sabbatical leave who doesn't do anything for us," says Gerald O'Connor, a theologian at Rome's Gregorian University.

Sociologists and psychologists tend to explain away miracles as mass hysteria in societies experiencing upheaval or anxiety. Ireland's moving statues of the 80s, at a time of political and economic stress, were perfect examples. Devotion to shrines and sightings of the Virgin are relatively modern phenomena, said Canon Martyn Percy, who teaches theology at Sheffield. "The higher you go up the evolutionary scale of Christianity, the less likely you are to be interested in miracles."

A new generation of Bible scholars are re-interpreting Christ's miracles as metaphors. Even the Resurrection, the ultimate miracle of Christianity, was not a physical act, they say. Christ was resurrected in the lives and influence of his followers, not in a reconstituted body.

The Vatican's Congregation for the Causes of Saints, which employs a medical board to vet miraculous powers, rejects most claims; yet critics say the neutering of the Vatican's Devil's Advocate office has eased the burden of proof, allowing the Pope to churn out saints in unprecedented numbers.

In Naples today, the thousands who have gathered outside the cathedral from dawn, ready to race for front row seats when the doors open, are immune to doubts. The church has prevented independent scientists from ascertaining whether the substance inside the phial is blood. Luigi Garlaschelli's suggestion is that it may be a mix of iron chloride, marble dust, salt and ground eggshells, a red powder known in the medieval era, which liquefies if given a small tap (workmen who accidentally nudged the phial saw it liquefy). San Gennaro was martyred at Pozzuoli, just outside Naples, under the purges of Diocletian. Christians preserved his blood in a phial and made him the city's patron saint. The phial, trimmed with gold, is kept in a chapel beside the cathedral. Twice a year, it is carried in procession to the altar. Armed police, television crews and thousands of Neapolitans pack inside. There is a Mass, the phial is held aloft, cries of "Viva San Gennaro!" resound, then it is lowered and the cardinal peers at what minutes before was solid powder. There is no reason why it should liquefy. But it does. For 600 years it has done so, every first Saturday in May and on September 19, the saint's feast day. The phial will be shaken by the cardinal archbishop Michele Giordano, whom local magistrates have demanded be sent for trial on charges of loansharking and misappropriating church funds. The congregation will queue for a week to kiss the relic. Occasionally the blood has remained solid. It did in 1944; Mount Vesuvius erupted. It did in 1980; there was an earthquake. The hunger for miracles, those inexplicable occurrences that seem to defy the laws of nature and bear witness to an omnipotent force - spreads far beyond Italy. An ugly village in France attracts more visitors than Egypt because of six crutches hanging on a rusty wire, symbol of a miracle cure for those who join the pilgrimage to Lourdes. And 7m people a year trek to the remote Italian village of San Giovanni Rotondo to visit the grave of Padre Pio, a priest who apparently received the stigmata, cured the sick and was in two places at once. Church attendances are plummeting but the sites of Christian pilgrimage are booming. Time magazine's poll says 69% of Americans believe in miracles. Charismatic and Pentecostal congregations, where worship revolves around signs and wonders, have swollen in Britain. Pope John Paul II scours the Catholic world for miracles he can attribute to the scores of people he wants to beatify (at least two miracles are needed for sainthood). webTitle: Strong pound means savings in the sun

fields.headline: Strong pound means savings in the sun
fields.standfirst: Jessica McCallin looks how prices have changed in popular summer destinations - in both Europe and the US
fields.trailText: Jessica McCallin looks how prices have changed in popular summer destinations - in both Europe and the US.
fields.body:
It's just not fair is it? You try and be clever with your finances. You buy your holiday money in advance to benefit from low Euro rates and what happens? It falls even further, plunging again this week, to its lowest level yet of 57p to the pound.

For those of you who haven't yet bought any currency, you'll probably be wondering if you should buy your holiday money now or wait and see if the Euro falls any further.

If figures from Thomas Cook are anything to go by plenty of people are betting that rates are now at their best and have been buying foreign currency this week.

The company reported queues of would-be holiday makers outside its Norwich office on Thursday morning and says sales of the major European currencies are up between 30% and 40% on the same week last year.

So what will your money buy you in some of the British holiday-makers' favourite sunny spots? Prices should be cheaper in much of Euroland, with only holidaymakers in the US having to pay a bit more with the pound down 3% against the dollar over the past year.

 In Portugal, a bottle of house wine in a holiday restaurant is 45p cheaper than last summer, at £2.55 instead of £3. Beer, mineral water and coffee are also down. They will set you back, respectively, 43p (down from 50p last year), 43p (50p) and 46p (55p).

Hiring a car and buying petrol won't leave you too much out of pocket either. Last year it would have cost £100 to hire a car with petrol at 60p per litre. This year, a similar car will cost you just £85, while the price of petrol has fallen to 51p per litre.

Even taking extra holiday snaps is more of a bargain this year with the cost of a 24 exposure, 35mm film down 60p to £3.40.

 Corfu and the Greek islands offer even more attractive prices to British holiday makers. A bottle of house wine there will set you back just £1.72, down from £2.10 last summer.

Mineral water is only 24p, a bottle of beer just 86p and a cup of coffee just 69p. At £112.34, seeing the islands by car will be £25.26 cheaper and petrol is down 10p to 45p per litre.

And you can afford to take plenty of photos of your fun in the sun - a roll of film will set you back just £2.05 , which is down 45p on last year's price.

 Cyprus is a bit more expensive than other European destinations - although at 38p per litre, petrol on the island is about as cheap as you'll find anywhere else - but is still better value than last year, with sterling up 14% against the Cyprus pound.

Hiring a car is down to £128.52 from £149.45. Wine is down to £3.48 from £4.05, beer is down to £103.2 from £1.20, coffee £1.20 instead of £1.40, and mineral water costs a mere 25p, down 5p from last year. And a roll of film is priced at £3.09, compared with last year's £3.60.

 Sunny Majorca, always a favourite among the Brits will probably remain so if prices stay the same.

Wine is down to £2.63 a bottle, nearly 50p cheaper than last summer's asking price of £3.10. Beer is down 22p to £1.23, mineral water is down 6p to 40p a bottle, and a cup of coffee costs just 59p.

Hiring a car will cost you £103.70p and 51p for each litre of petrol. A roll of film should be only £2.80, saving 50p on last year's price.

 If you head for the US, the news is not so good. With the pound down 3% against the dollar you're money won't stretch quite as far as last summer, but any increases should be mininal.

A bottle of wine in Florida will cost £7.21 instead of last year's £7. Mineral water is up nearly 4p at £1.28, beer is £1.95 and coffee nearly 98p, up 3p on last year.

On the other hand, car hire and film are still keenly priced. A car should cost £117.40 for a week, over £3 more than last year - still cheaper than Cyprus and not much more than Corfu and the Greek islands.

Petrol will set you back 72p a US gallon and a roll of 35mm film shouldn't cost more than £2.57.

 Source: Thomas Cook

fields.headline: Go surfing with Hector
fields.standfirst: Take a tenner off the taxman by filing your tax return on the internet, says Ben Griffiths  - and there's plenty of advice on how to do it
fields.trailText: Take a tenner off the taxman by filing your tax return on the internet, says Ben Griffiths  - and there's plenty of advice on how to do it.
fields.body:
In the USA using the internet to file tax returns is now commonplace - and new incentives in the UK suggest that dealing with with Hector the taxman in cyberspace may well take off this year.

What's more there is a growing number of user-friendly sites which provide tax advice - and even give you the lowdown on tropical tax havens.

"Traditional tax preparation can be both time-consuming and intimidating, and each year we find more and more people turning to the net for tax preparation and filing," says Rob Shenk at AOL.

In the US, all taxpayers have to make individual returns. But here only around one in three is caught in the self-assessment net. These tend to be more complicated than average - but only about half of the estimated 9m who have to file the returns use an accountant to help them.

From this tax year, self-assessment taxpayers who file their returns over the internet and pay any tax due electronically are able to receive a £10 discount as an incentive to embrace internet technology.

But users who employ tax advisers to complete and submit their returns will miss out. At present the incentive is only available to taxpayers who file in person and not their agents.

Those who really go tax DIY may find that using the net to their returns is a sensible development. It's all part of a wider government plan which eventually will offer all services online.

Foremost is the Inland Revenue's own self-assessment web site www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk/e-tax/index.htm. The site provides free software for the most frequently used parts of the self-assessment tax return. And when you have submitted your return, the Revenue promises you instant acknowledgement of its receipt.

The Revenue's system is straightforward and seems to work. Users can capture information about discounts for filing returns electronically, view a list of vendors providing compatible software for completing them, and then file the returns themselves.

It is not just the Inland Revenue which offers online tax calculation packages. Professionals are queuing up to offer their advice and services online.

One of the best services is provided by tax advice web site Digita (www.digita.com) which has developed a new tax centre on the Freeserve web portal; find it at freeserve.digita.com.

It has tax calculators, a daily tax news feed, a question and answer forum, and a search facility to find a tax adviser in your area. Plus an online tax check-up where you can input your details to see if the taxman is taking more than his fair share of your income.

The facility to file a tax return will be added in the summer. Inland Revenue forms are available to download or can be edited online.

Another site offering a good tax calculator is Virtually Anywhere (www.virtuallyanywhere.co.uk/detax.html ) which also gives standard tax information along with links and contact details for tax advisers.

But this site's strong point is its 'E-advise me' facility, which claims to offer personalised response to any tax related question from a team of experts who are all ex-Inland Revenue taxmen. Answers are later emailed to users.

The advisers will discuss any tax issue you may have via email and on the telephone and, if appropriate, agree a service for individual needs. If necessary they will visit taxpayers at their homes. An initial contact and phone call is free but charging kicks in for fuller consultations.

MoneyeXtra (www.moneyextra.com) is another good site with headlines, tax calculators, tax guides, question and answer forums and links to local tax advisers.

The Chartered Institute of Taxation, the professional body for tax advisers, offers limited information on its site (www.tax.org.uk). Although mainly dealing with how to find and contact its members, the site also gives some useful background to the tax system and explains self-assessment and taxpayers' obligations clearly and concisely.

Taxpayers interested in offshore investment should explore www.lowtax.net. The site describes offshore investment and who uses it as well as offering a news service. Lowtax.net is an open site - there is no registration and no logging-in. It has sections for those interested in the tax charms of tropical dots on the map including Aruba, Monaco, Vanuatu and Costa Rica. Switzerland and Hong Kong will arrive shortly.

fields.headline: Getting away with murder
fields.standfirst: 'Those who believe most strongly in the brotherhood of man often seem to believe that, by its very nature, it should exclude women'
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill: 'Those who believe most strongly in the brotherhood of man often seem to believe that, by its very nature, it should exclude women'
fields.body:
Last week, writing about the Tony Martin case and different lengths of imprisonment being appropriate to different types of murder, liberal commentators repeated that old chestnut about how men guilty of "desperate acts of domestic violence" ending in the death of the victim should not be punished as harshly as "contract murders by professional killers". I must say, what with two women each week in this country being killed by partners or ex-partners right now, I found this analysis offensive. There are few occasions when one even begins to understand what it must feel like to be a hated minority race in a country that recognises only the racially pure as having full civil rights, but reading, or hearing, the dismissal of domestic murder is definitely one of them.

Every week we hear that a man killed his wife for no more substantial reason than her "nagging", or for smiling at another man, and each week some moronic bully gets off with a derisory sentence for such a crime. For any government to suggest that "domestic" murderers will in future be treated with mercy seems to me as irresponsible as telling racist killers that they will be looked upon kindly simply because they let their feelings of rage and loathing, their emotional incontinence, get the better of them. For that is what we are talking about here; emotional incontinence - certainly not "passion".

Ah, passion! A rose between the teeth, a slap around the face, an adagio dance! Treat 'em mean and keep 'em keen! Like many stupid ideas about women, the crime passionel is French, and - like the also much-vaunted mistress/wife arrangement -was designed solely with the aim of making life easier for men at the expense of women. Are we truly to believe that such archaic notions have no connection with the chronic levels of sexual harassment and pornographic advertising that still exist in France, and which have created not a climate of enlightenment but one of bullying, hectoring oppression? Still, what can you expect from a country in which women didn't get the vote until 1945?

Yes, there certainly wasn't much for women in all that liberty, equality and fraternity floating about after the French revolution, and ever since then the human and civil rights of women have remained a blind spot with men who should know better. The list of otherwise intelligent, radical men who have talked about women in a style somewhere between Hitler and Al Murray the Pub Landlord is always surprising. Solzenitsyn, writing with great disapproval of all the poor guys he found in the gulags imprisoned for "trivial" crimes such as rape; Stokely Carmichael, telling women that their place in the black revolution was "prone".

Now, for your delectation, at London's Almeida Theatre, Tariq Ali, Howard Brenton and Andy de la Tour bring you Snogging Ken, a rigorous dissection of New Labour's blackguarding of the Livingstone mayoral campaign. And who's behind it? - Blair, Brown, Mandelson? Nah - women! A pair of "Blair Babes", as Andy de la Tour referred to them in a recent plug for the show. And what means do they use to bring the great man down? Typical woman's tricks - lying about sex. Treacherous bitches.

Men's need to believe in female perfidy seems to be the last prejudice to die, and is all present and incorrect even in men who would run screaming if you accused them of any sort of bigotry. And what starts with the type of mentality that believes you can never trust a woman ends up in the treatment of domestic murder as less serious than "real" murder. And, with the exception of those cases where the perpetrator was in fear for his or her life, this reinforces the medieval message that when a woman sleeps with a man, she becomes his property and may be disposed of as he sees fit.

Those who believe most strongly in the brotherhood of man often give the impression that, by its very nature, it excludes women. John Mortimer, that floridly humanitarian old ham, once said something along the lines of "My life is so challenging because I'll be writing a play in the morning and defending a wife-murderer in the afternoon." He wouldn't have boasted about defending a race murderer, would he? Yet an average-size black man has far more chance of defending himself against an average-size white man than an average-size woman does.

Around the time Mortimer said this, the actress Jane Asher was appearing in one of his TV series, and I was shocked to pick up the paper soon after and see that he was currently defending a man who had killed his wife because she danced with another man at a party - she was called Jane Asher, too. And it struck me then how symbolic this was: the famous, middle-class Jane Asher, free to go about her business without fear of male murderousness - whom John Mortimer knew, and referred to in glowing terms - and this unknown, working-class Jane Asher, killed by one of her own class only to have the cream of the legal elite rally around to defend a husband who did his level best to portray his wife as a strumpet. Mortimer, as a barrister, operates on the cab-rank principle. There are plenty of others who don't have that excuse.

Surely the whole point of being a liberal is being able to empathise, to put yourself in the other man's shoes? Yet when it comes to the domestic murder of women by men, the killer's brogues always seem far more easy for the liberal to slip on than the stilettos of the victim. It's a puzzlement.

With reference to my recent diatribe against those sad souls who hawk their wares in the bazaars of Thespus, I receive a letter from Emma Thompson, who is obviously a somewhat god-like being, despite the gallons of poison I have poured on her name in the past. "Some scientists were doing tests on dogs to see how like their owners they were. They took a mathematician's dog, an architect's dog and an actor's dog. Starting with the mathematician's dog, they put it into the first cubicle with a pile of bones. The dog looked at the bones, sorted them into three neat piles of two, four and six and then went and sat in the corner. Next, they sent in the architect's dog. It looked at the bones, and patted them into a nice geometrical shape, and went and sat in the corner. Then they sent in the actor's dog. It looked at the bones, ate them all, fucked the other two dogs and asked if it could go home early."

And the words "Kenneth Branagh" never even crossed our minds, did they?

fields.headline: The key to happy motoring
fields.standfirst: 'I can remember when AA repairmen on their motorcycles would routinely salute any passing car that had the AA badge on its front bumper'
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor: 'I can remember when AA repairmen on their motorcycles would routinely salute any passing car that had the AA badge on its front bumper'
fields.body:
A new Automobile Association card has just arrived through the post. It says I have been a member since 1964, which is rather an alarming thought. As you get older, people like to remind you of the fact. My bank manager recently told me I had banked with his branch since 1961.

What such institutions fail to point out is that while we, their customers, haven't changed very much, they have changed enormously. In the case of the bank, I am lucky to have a branch at all, since most of its branches have closed. As for the AA, it seems to have its fingers in lots of new pies that have nothing to do with motoring. My card came with a covering letter offering me a £15 saving on my membership fee if I bought electricity from British Gas. I find the concept of buying electricity from a gas company already difficult enough without it being tied to a discount on an automobile breakdown service.

The AA has also redesigned its plastic membership card to include images of happy people - a woman throwing her baby in the air, a businessman in suit and tie, a smiling Asian face. Many companies nowadays try to promote the idea that they exist principally to foster social cohesion and racial harmony. They want to make the world a happy place, but don't seem to care how they do it, whether by getting a gas company to sell electricity or by mending your car when it has broken down. They have probably got the idea from Tony Blair, whose popularity is mostly based on people thinking he is a nice, well-meaning person who will not deliberately let them down. What he actually does is less important.

Luckily, among its many activities, the AA does still take care of motorists, and the arrival of its new card telling me that I have already been a member for 36 years reminds me of the days when motoring could still be rather fun. There were fewer cars, fewer speed limits, and a less hostile police. I can even remember a time when AA repairmen on their motorcycles would routinely salute any passing car that had the AA badge on its front bumper. Even today, receipt of my AA card makes me think about going for a spin in the car, just to see if it can still be pleasurable. And I am glad to report that it can.

Last weekend, whilst in Northamptonshire, I went on a motoring expedition that was agreeably trouble-free, although it took me close to Silverstone, where at Easter many people got stuck in traffic jams for up to five hours because of a car-parking fiasco at the Grand Prix. Maybe this frightened the natives of Northamptonshire into staying at home this time. In any case, the weather was nice and the roads were clear. The problem was deciding what my destination should be. I can never think of anywhere to go in the country, except to some house or garden open to the public, and this can, frankly, be a disappointment.

Only a few miles from my house in Northamptonshire is Sulgrave Manor, which is famous only because of its association with the Washington family, ancestors of the first President of the United States. It is, however, written up in my guidebook as "a delightful 16th-century manor house, restored with scholarly care and attention to detail that makes a visit both a pleasure and an education". It is also described as "a perfect illustration of how a house should be shown to the public". So, having never been there, I gave it a try.

Well, Sulgrave Manor is a modest but nice enough place, built in the mid-1500s by Lawrence Washington, a Northampton wool merchant, whose great-great-grandson, Colonel John Washington, emigrated to Virginia in the 1650s and founded the dynasty that eventually produced George. It was bought by public subscription in 1914 to celebrate 100 years of peace between Britain and the United States, furnished with old furniture and Washington memorabilia, and endowed in perpetuity by the Colonial Dames of America. It is worth a brief visit, but the key word is "brief".

The curse of so many country-house visits is the guided tour, which it is often impossible to avoid. After half-an-hour seated with half a dozen other elderly tourists in the Great Hall of Sulgrave, listening to a guide give a joke-heavy account of the house's fundamentally boring history, explain that bits of furniture are called things like cupboard or sideboard because they once contained cups or were situated at the side of the room, and try to be coy and skittish about Anglo-American relations, I was on the brink of suicide. I had no alternative but to plead a pressing engagement and get myself released. The key to happy motoring, as many people seem to have discovered already, is never to get out of one's car.

fields.headline: Ex wife is watching you
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: The secret diary of a provincial man: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.body:
Tuesday, April 25, 2000, Arthur Askey Way, Gaitskell Estate

My father begged me to help him escape from the hospital this afternoon. He said he is losing the will to live due to lack of sleep and the pain from his bedsores. His false teeth have not turned up, despite a top-level internal inquiry. He is living on soup and porridge - when somebody remembers to feed him. He is almost entirely helpless.

Personally, I blame Tanya, his new wife, for his accident. My father is too old to be up a ladder trying to construct a Japanese-style pagoda under her exacting instructions. I have suggested to the rest of the family that we arrange a rota so that one of us is always in attendance at hospital meal times.

I rang Pandora at her Westminster office and asked her to visit the hospital incognito. I said that she should see the third-world conditions for herself. She said she would "drop in if she could", but she was "terribly busy" with Dobbo's campaign. I laughed a hollow laugh and said: "Did she realise it was Anzac Day; the anniversary of a similarly doomed campaign."

Thursday, April 27, Bevan Ward

A letter from my ex wife, Jo-Jo.

Dear Adrian,

Your mother has written to tell me that William is living in 'morally dubious circumstances'. She writes that he mixes with criminals 'on a daily basis'. Can this be true? I have looked at Arthur Askey Way using the world wide web satellite and was disturbed to see a burned-out car in front of your house. I also saw that your front garden was extremely squalid. Is that the mattress we used to sleep on?

Please do not forget, Adrian, that William is part Nigerian and is the grandson of a chief. It is essential that he is brought up extremely carefully. My circumstances are such that I cannot send for him at present, so I beg you to move William away from the Gaitskell Estate before his character and personality are irrevocably damaged.

I have tried to reach you on the telephone, but a recorded voice tells me 'it has not been possible to connect your call'. I looked you up on the net and was alarmed to see that you are considered a bad credit risk and that you owe £75.31 to your newsagent, £43.89 to your milkman and to BT £254.08. A further search revealed that you are overdrawn at the bank by £947.16. I scrolled on further and found that you withdrew all monies from your savings account with the Market Harborough Building Society on December 19, 1999. This money was put aside to pay for William's piano lessons. Is he having them?

I am very concerned about your mental health. A search of your medical records revealed to me that you visited your doctor's surgery three times last month, complaining that you were being spied upon. Your doctor has written on your notes 'could be mildly paranoiac'. Please contact me at jojomole.comataol.com.

So, 1984 is here in the year 2000. It is the end of privacy. I may as well walk naked through the streets shouting out the small details of my life.

I went to see my mother and charged her with gross disloyalty. She was unrepentant. She said, "William spends too much time playing round at the Ludlow's house." She said, "Vince Ludlow is a career criminal, for Christ's sake!" I have to admit, Diary, that William's frame of reference has widened lately. Last night I overheard him saying to Glenn, "Mad Frankie Fraser was well harder than Charlie Kray."

Saturday, April 29

I ask Pamela Pigg about that maisonette she promised me. She said (with relish, I thought), "I've let it to a family of asylum seekers." I asked her to arrange a swap. She said, "They're not that desperate."

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Margherita Taylor
fields.trailText: Margherita Taylor
fields.body:
Margherita Taylor was born in 1972. She studied Media and Communications at the University of Central England and went on to win a Search For A Star competition on a Birmingham radio station. She has since become one of Capital Radio's most popular DJs and a TV presenter. Currently, she hosts Channel 4's T4 on Sunday mornings. She lives in Croydon with friends.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Lying on a golden beach under a blue sky, yards from a clear blue ocean.

What is your greatest fear?
That the people I care about don't know how much I care about them.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
I identify with the words of Martin Luther King, 'I have a dream' - everyone should have a dream.

What objects do you always carry with you?
My diary and a pencil. I don't like the new electronic diaries - give me pen and paper any day.

What is your favourite smell?
Freshly-cooked popcorn.

What is your favourite word?
Sunday.

What is your favourite fantasy?
That chocolate is not fattening.

What makes you depressed?
That in the year 2000 people sleep on the streets, and that doctors and nurses get paid so little for what they do.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
On the days my jeans don't fit, I hate everything; on the days they slip on fine, it's all good.

How did you vote in the last election?
Labour.

How will you vote in the next election?
Labour. Let's hope Tony's put some real money into the health service by then.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Yes, sorry!

When and where were you happiest?
Standing on top of Ayers Rock in Australia as the sun was coming up.

How do you relax?
Have a bath with loads of bubbles.

What would your motto be?
Go for it.

How would you like to die?
Peacefully - but not until I'd achieved everything I want to do.

Do you believe in life after death?
Yes.

How would you like to be remembered?
Being remembered at all would be nice.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Tell people you love them while you have the chance.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Paris, Texas
fields.standfirst: 'Determined to eradicate from my child's mind the notion of foreigners'
fields.trailText: 'Determined to eradicate from my child's mind the notion of foreigners'
fields.body:
Harriet's French oral results very bad: 20 cavities, mostly involving verbs. I decide a weekend in Paris is required. Her face falls at the news. It means she'll miss Tracey's party. She confides that, in her experience, the French are nerds.

Assure her to the contrary, despite private reservations, mostly based on the loos of the 1950s - inadequately adapted wardrobes or stinking abysses over which one teetered on stirrups. Take advantage then of the Waterloo loo - subterranean rugby scrum without ball. Curse invention of turnstile and recall happy days when one could gain access to cubicle with heavy old penny by means of heavy old mechanism.

Eurostar performs its smooth miracle. "We were only under the sea for 20 minutes!" reports Harriet with relief. In other words, 10 minutes less than I spent queueing for Euroburger, frightful frites, and a DIY tea-making kit involving a teabag and a cup of tepid water. Trust these are minor inconveniences of travel and not signs of astrological foreboding. Saturn would probably be against a weekend in Paris. He would probably recommend a month in Scarborough. Determined, however, to eradicate from my child's mind the notion of foreigners, especially in association with Nerdhood.

Arrive in sunshine at the Gare du Nerd, taxi queue moves like lightning, and we are soon safe in our hotel room near the Bastille. Tempted to confide thrilling historical details vis-à-vis the Bastille, but refrain.

"Oh great, it's got satellite TV!" cries Harriet. Perhaps Paris is okay after all. She settles down to surf the channels. We are treated to an American evangelist, a French floor polish advert, and a brief glimpse of frenzied copulation from the PAY TV channel. Assure Harriet that the French must not be judged by satellite TV, and mention surpassing achievements of Gallic civilisation, such as croissants and Jean-Paul Gaultier. Tempted to mention exquisite 17th-century Place des Vosges, but refrain. Harriet is not listening anyway. She has found something of her own to admire: the hotplate and fridge.

Admittedly I booked us into an aparthotel with a view to self-catering. The kitchenette and bathroom are arranged with an ingenuity only previously encountered chez Polly Pocket. I could share this studio very successfully with a diminutive monk given to long bouts of meditation and with a minimalist approach to food. But in two minutes Harriet has hurled clothes, books and make-up about with such arbitrary bravado, I fear she may be steered into town planning when it comes to careers advice.

As the room is now uninhabitable, I am quite happy to go out food-shopping. There is a supermarket within 30 seconds' walk. fields.headline: How to go to sleep
fields.trailText: Sleep is like the M25, in that having it is vital and everyone can't wait to get off. The trouble is, the harder you try, the less likely you are to get to sleep
fields.body:
Sleep is like the M25, in that having it is vital and everyone can't wait to get off. The trouble is, the harder you try, the less likely you are to get to sleep. The trick is to try really hard at whatever it is you do during the day. This has the double benefit of tiring you out and lessening whatever you generally worry about.

The lessons you learn getting toddlers to sleep should also be applied to adults; rule number one is not to get them excited in the six hours before bedtime. So, if you really want to drop off quickly, don't do anything that will excite you beforehand - like sex, for example.

Driving has a miraculous soporific effect on toddlers. It's got something to do with the continuous background noise and movement - strangely, the marriage bed has the same features but the opposite effect.

Visualising your drive to work is a very good way of dropping off, as it is generally something you can do in your sleep and your mind won't bother to stay awake for it. However, if you've driven right past your office and you're nearly at the Channel ports, you should try a different technique.

Counting sheep is the traditional way of getting off to sleep. It's best to visualise young lambs skipping over low hedges rather than tired old ewes with messy arses failing to get over stone walls and having to be put down.

If you're churning things over in your mind, try to imagine that all the images are like a television; then make the televsions black and white, then make it a tiny picture, and then turn it off. This works well especially if you also turn off the wide-screen television at the foot of your bed.

Having a warm, milky drink is also claimed to be an excellent way of relaxing, unless you're in a pub, where you're likely to cause upset all round. Don't overdo it on the evening milk drink - if you drink too much, half way through the night you'll need milking.

Make sure your nightwear is thick, cosy and has a ridiculous pattern; this gives your body a very clear message that you definitely won't be going out or doing anything exciting, so you might as well sleep.

Sleeping pills are extremely dangerous, as they're a sure sign that you're having troubles with your days rather than your nights. Go for a long drive, throw them away and then count sheep on your way back.

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.trailText: Wychwood Brewery
fields.body: A little help in high places can't do the organic beer movement any harm. Wychwood Brewery in Witney, Oxfordshire, has recently launched Corn Circle in bottle, a new ale that uses a variety of barley grown on 22 acres of farmland in Wiltshire next to Prince Charles's Highgrove estate. The barley variety is Plumage Archer, which was thought to have disappeared after the second world war, when it was replaced by more modern varieties. But a seed merchant in Cambridgeshire had kept some Plumage Archer seeds, and they sprouted cheerfully in the Wiltshire soil. The barley is joined in Corn Circle by organic Target hops grown by England's only regular grower of chemical-free hops, Peter Hall, of Marden in Kent. Corn Circle is 4.7% alcohol, pale in colour, and has a ripe, earthy malt aroma balanced by citrus fruit from the hops, a tangy, complex palate of juicy malt, spicy hops and fruit, and a finish that is dry, hoppy and quenching. It's on sale in Oddbins, Safeway, Sainsbury, Somerfield, Tesco and Unwins.

fields.headline: Food
fields.standfirst: The curries we know and love are not the real thing. But they're now so popular that genuine Indian cooking in this country is under threat. Joanna Blythman reports
fields.trailText: The curries we know and love are not the real thing. But they're now so popular that genuine Indian cooking in this country is under threat. Joanna Blythman reports
fields.body:
On a recent visit to Kerala, I picked up a fascinating new book, Curry In The Crown, published by Harper Collins, but only in India. Written by London journalist Shrabani Basu, the book attempts to explain to Indians how their ex-colonial power became a "nation of curryholics". Basu reports on how a 1997 Gallup survey revealed that curry was, beyond doubt, the nation's favourite food with more than a quarter of Britons eating curry at least once a week. She notes how Marks & Spencer sells 18 tonnes of chicken tikka masala each week - this, the quintessential British "Indian" dish invented in the UK in the 70s and virtually unknown throughout the sub-continent.

Indian readers can now marvel at how "Vindaloo" became the battle cry of English football fans and chuckle at the prospect of a forthcoming album for "curry-mad Britishers" featuring numbers such as Korma Khameleon and Poppadom Preach. Many will be simply staggered to read the book's rags-to-riches tales of UK curry entrepreneurs such as Patak's, G K Noon and Parveen Warsi. "Their climb to the Sunday Times' list of the richest people in Britain adds extra spice to the fantastic tale of this industry," writes Basu.

The thing that will make Indians most incredulous is the fact that the curry to which we have become addicted is overwhelmingly fake. As anyone who has ever eaten a proper banana leaf or thali meal in India will know, the food eaten in the sub-continent bears little ressemblance to what is generally taken as "Indian" food in the UK. "Perhaps the most baffled . . . is the first time Indian visitor to the British Isles. For a start, which Indian has ever used the word 'curry' to describe Indian food?" asks Basu.

She points out that there is a North Indian yoghurt-based preparation called "karhi" and there is the fragrant herb called "curry leaf" - used in South Indian cooking. "But there is nothing in India quite as universal as the British curry," she notes.

The British curry seems to have begun with immigrants from Bangladesh (pre-independance East Pakistan) who settled in the UK, having worked as crew on P&O ferries from India, where they learned to cook Anglo-Indian dishes such as mulligatawny. Setting up "Indian" restaurants, Bangladeshi entrepreneurs then diversified from the "P&O menu" to the famous (or infamous) "one-curry sauce" made from bought-in catering curry paste that continues to reign supreme in curry houses throughout the UK today. As Basu diplomatically puts it, "The intricacies of Indian cooking, the array of non-spicy dishes simply did not feature."

Some 80% of "Indian" restaurants in the UK are still run by Bangladeshis. Basu charts the passing fashions that have reigned in the curry house: the 70s' tandoori phase, the 80s' "balti" phase, (a Birmingham invention), eclipsed in the 90s by the vogue for "karahi" dishes, which unlike balti, are authentic in theory, if not in execution. Though, according to Basu, there are a handful of exceptional London restaurants (such as the Bombay Brasserie, Chutney Mary, Rasa and Café Spice Namaste) which have broken with the curry-house tradition to offer distinctive Indian regional cuisine cooked by Indian chefs, she explains why, despite more discernment among diners and a genuine hunger for real Indian cooking, there is a chronic UK shortage of chefs capable of cooking the authentic article.

The Home Office only allows chefs from India into the UK for up to three years at a time, and only after endless paperwork and procedures are completed. By the time a chef is getting into his stride, it's time to go home. The MP Keith Vaz has been campaigning to have immigration rules relaxed for chefs from India. "Until we look again at the laws governing the entry of specialist chefs, some of these restaurants [seeking specialist chefs] will have to close or simply not sell the kind of authentic food they want," he says. More power to his elbow.

Another approach is to train second-generation British Asians to cook India's rich and diverse cuisines. These days, even Bangladeshi restaurants are trying to serve more authentic Bengali food. But while the Lion's share of our "Indian" food comes out of a bottle or jar, there's a clear need for a restatement of the sub-continent's sophisticated cooking techniques: masalas that are unique to each dish, spices and wet aromatics added at various stages, and the traditional tempering with spice-infused oil.

But in 1998, when the Department of Education came up with a grant of £300,000 for an Asian Academy of Culinary Skills, based at Thames Valley University, the headlines immediately betrayed the sneering racism that simmers just below the surface of our so-called love affair with curry. The Daily Mail described it as "The University of Madras", the Daily Telegraph as "Vindaloo Academy". No wonder that young Asians are not exactly queueing up to go into the restaurant business

 Curry In The Crown, by Shrabani Basu, is published by Harper Collins India, at 195 rupees (around £4). Details: www.harpercollins.com

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: A red haze descends on Malcolm Gluck
fields.body:
There is an abundance of Italian wines at Tesco, many at already low prices, but between May 10 and 23 the whole lot is subject to a 20% discount. Two of these wines I enjoyed with food recently and found them extremely attractive, offering that unique Italian characteristic of both quaffability and immense versatility with all manner of dishes.

Il Padrino Frappato Nero d Avola 1999 (15 points, out of 20, normally £3.99) is dry yet at the same time has a modern jamminess. It cannot be called sweet, or even rounded, but the fruit is of the level that exults in moderately spicy food. Terra Viva Vino da Tavola Organic Red 1998 (15.5 points, normally £3.99) is simply the best organic, for the money, I've tasted from Italy. It's dry and very darkly fruited, that is to say that black cherries and touches of catering chocolate come to mind.

But then this is more or less the sort of fruit you find in Asda s non-vintage Merlot Vin de Pays d'Oc (15 points, £2.99), which, in addition to the cherries, packs a terrific earthy bite. Asda's Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (16.5 points, £3.99) is more elegant. It s so drinkable and well-knit that it performs like a wine costing a good deal more, with great texture, richness and warm, aromatic fruit.

Asda's Tramontane range has continued to offer value and modernity, and the latest vintages are well up to par. Tramontane Grenache Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16 points, £3.99) is juicy with hints of herbs. Great rollicking style. Tramontane Vin de Pays de l'Aude 1999 (16 points, £2.99) has brilliant earthy richness and ripeness. Tramontane Merlot Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (16 points, £3.99) shows some delicious characterful earthiness.

There are three further reds at Asda worth investigating. Chteau Lahore Bergez Fitou 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99) has superb richness, character, weight and finesse. Yes, it has some mild rusticity, but this is its charm. It's a great food wine. Chteau de Parenchere Bordeaux Superieure 1997 (16.5 points, £5.99) is a superb young claret, with texture, class, richness, handsome tannicity and a well-concentrated finish. Asda s own-label Argentinian Syrah 1999 (16 points, £3.99) is not remotely like Aussie shiraz or Rhne syrah. It is a revelation of spiciness and richness and deeply textured fruit. There is great concentration of elements in this wine.

At Thresher wine shops, there is Concha y Toro Casillero del Diablo Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile. It is a consummately concentrated, juicy, fresh, fruity, character-laden, deep, shallow, subtle, extravagant - how many contradictions can a mouthful of alcoholic grape juice contain? At Thresher, and its partner Victoria Wine (but not at Wine Rack or Bottoms Up), there is Jumilla Senorio de Robles 1998 (16 points, £3.49), from Spain. A bargain wine for summer barbecues as well as winter firesides, it's dry, plummy, soft, characterful and hugely quaffable - and it'll go with loads of foods.

Somerfield has three delightfully drinkable reds on offer. The own-label Montepulciano d Abruzzo 1998 (15.5 points) has a quid knocked off its usual £3.99 from May 10 until May 23. Do not expect to get away with £2.99 for this wine until that date, because the individual stores are not advised of price reductions until a few hours before the commencement. It is worth waiting a few days for this wine. It is soft and ripe, with slightly smoky, earthy tannins to hold the whole structure up. It is intensely quaffable.

As is Bright Brothers Negroamaro Cabernet Sauvignon 1998, from Puglia, the heel of Italy. This wine has already come down in price to £3.49 (rating 15.5 points) and it performs much like the Montepulciano, though there is more hedgerow fruitiness but even then there are tannins to give it backbone. It s on offer until May 23. Also reduced, to £3.29 until that day, is the Spanish Sierra Alta Cabernet Sauvignon 1998, which is lovely stuff, parading, as it does, cherry and blackcurrants, terrific textures and a delicious warm finish. It has to rate 16 points. Just over three quid? It hardly seems believable, but then similar incredulity, for the same reasons, is appropriate for every wine on this page.

fields.headline: Windmills in your mind
fields.standfirst: Forget preconceptions about boring Dutch borders, says Christopher Lloyd. There's always something to inspire
fields.trailText: Forget preconceptions about boring Dutch borders, says Christopher Lloyd. There's always something to inspire
fields.body:
Along weekend in the east of Holland, last month, was revealing, as always, of differences and similarities with ourselves. The season was just about where we were, perhaps a week behind; the weather was equally unpleasant and predictably unpredictable.

There were no shabby front gardens; nobody would let the side down. Equally, there was none for which you could exclaim, "That owner obviously loves plants." A uniformity was evident in the plants used. There is something about worthy plants that brings out in me vicious stabs of hatred that are totally unjustified. I suppose "foundation planting" is the expression one would use of Mahonia aquifolium . It was in full bloom (yawn) and backed up by its evergreen foliage (tatty at winter's end). After flowering, the whole shrub can be pruned over without any loss of subsequent charm. It is a staunch friend in good times and bad. Can you bear to live with it? Can you bear to live without it?

This mahonia is often planted in the strips dividing a suburban road from the subsiduary road for bicycle traffic, which is such an important feature in Dutch life. You might have thought that, with its rather stiff habit and prickly foliage, it would be ideal for catching and holding all sorts of debris. That never happens, there, but in our own country, all the time.

Another time-serving shrub that you see a lot is Ribes alpinum . That, again, is tough and undemanding. It is deciduous, its currant-like leaves nicely shaped. The bush is stiff and can be mechanically shorn. I grow the yellow-leaved form 'Aureum' (1.5m) - it is a comely shrub, good when bare in winter, quietly pleasing at every season, no trouble to anyone.

Everywhere, in gardens, woods, along dykes and railway lines, Amelanchier was flowering, either as a shrub or as a small tree. Don't ask me the species: it has elegant, rather spidery white flowers and the young foliage is bronze. In early autumn, amelanchiers colour well. They are most charming trees for small gardens, unless you have a problem with birds - notably bullfinches or pigeons - stripping their buds in spring. They are by no means rare in England, but why we don't grow more of them is a little odd.

The other flowering tree that I saw everywhere, often as quite dramatically large specimens and always beautifully shaped, was Magnolia x soulangeana . No shortage of that in Britain. The one thing I have against it is the slightly dirty pink colouring. If it were pure white or a cleaner, less murky shade of pink, it would be improved.

Also, oaks are surprisingly widespread (they make roadside avenues) and their trunks are shaped up so as not to start branching before reaching a considerable height.

You scarcely need reminding that the land is flat and that water is everywhere - just as well, perhaps, that the soil is so often sandy and extremely light. Dyke-sides are often plastered with brilliant yellow ribbons of kingcups, Caltha palustris , and these never look better than when interlarded with clumps of white snowflakes, Leucojum aestivum . It is worth starting with the most telling clone, 'Gravetye Giant'.

If you have a fountain that gushes a high, vertical jet, wind is almost certain to lead to the water drifting beyond its allotted pond, but in Holland this causes no flooding problems. In such light soil, the water simply disappears. One of the prettiest ponds I saw was round, with a high jet in its centre; ferns and the broad, glaucous-leaved Hosta sieboldiana 'Elegans' all around its margins. There had been a pretty, zig-zag brick design in the paving, but this was overlaid by mosses (you make a virtue of their invasion) and the ferns.

In open woodland, the nicest colonisers to establish are bulbs that self-sow, and this is most likely to happen with species rather than hybrids. In any case, the small-growing, 'unimproved' species are more likely to look appropriate than their coarser, man-made relations.

A case in point was Narcissus triandrus . We usually grow this in one of its hybrids, 'Thalia' being typical - white, bunch-headed, free-flowering and relatively graceful. But I have never known it to spread much beyond where it was planted, whereas N. triandrus itself, which you rarely see, quickly gets around by self-sowing, and that is tremendously satisfying. Its flowers are smaller, but none the worse for that, and they are intensely fragrant.

I already find N. bulbocodium var. citrinus, pale-yellow version of the hoop-petticoat daffodil, an immensely obliging self-sower, with flowers from January to April. Another species that can do it and with which I really should make an effort, is N. cyclamineus . If you can make that happy, the hybrids such as 'February Gold' and 'Jet Fire' become also-rans. N. poeticus is another species with which we should make an effort. It is parent of the old pheasant's eye - but that is sterile

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Ring in the new...
fields.trailText: Ring in the new...
fields.body:
The subject
First spuds of the crop. Tiny temptations, except they're not always tiny. Seasonal sensation.

The basics
A potato is the tip of a stem, grown fat and bulbous as a store of energy-giving starch. If you harvest it when young, you get less starch and more sugar. Sweetness in spuds, I mean spades. Buttery flavours, even. And a texture that's variously described as waxy or creamy.

The details
Any potato can produce a small, new version of itself, but not all small potatoes are new. Size range: from minuscule (think quail's egg) to Juno-esque (think tennis ball). What separates new from old is that delicate skin and dense, sweet, well-knitted flesh. They crumble not in bowl or pot. They hold their shape even when overcooked. Top treatment 1: Boil (or steam), then sprinkle with salt and nothing else . Top treatment 2: Boil (or steam), then toss immediately with ingredients for potato salad. Top treatment 3: Cook in a covered frying pan (single layer) with a little oil or duck fat, water or stock, garlic or onion; cook to light brown, shaking frequently. New spuds originate all over the shop, but ours are in season now and they are the best . New kings: the Jersey Royal, isolated on the eponymous island in the 19th century and now sheltered by an EU Protected Designation of Origin. No one knows exactly why JRs are so wonderful, but variety, climate, topography, soil type and farming practice all come into it. (A floating polythene mulch lays claim to creating Royal Highness of flavour and texture.) JRs are on sale now. Pricey, not to be missed. Incidentally, some people peel new potatoes before cooking. Some people also iron their sheets.

Where to buy
Where do you think?

The easy way out
Irrelevant.
